description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 215.5 from 216.9 last week.

title: Diary of a Discerning Macy Shopper
description: Some time ago, Jill, my best friend's daughter, called to ask when we could have lunch. Problems with her family The request was nothing unusual but this time. admit that I was completely on her side.

title: Mexico Is Taking, a Healthy Swat at the Fruit Fly
description: MEXICO CITYThe Mediterranean fruit fly, which causes millions of dollars worth of damage to crops in Central and South America, has now spread into southern Mexico, raising fears that the pest may eventually reach the United States.

title: Antiques
description: THE RAVISHING exhibition of robes and masks from the No theater of Japan that opened at Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, this week, was seven years in the planningand it shows. The wealth of art invested over 500 years in this aristocratic stage form comes alive in costumes that range from diaphanous gauzes to exuberant brocades and in carved masks of grimacing, smiling and screaming faces.

title: Sirica Says Haldeman and Mitchell Will Probably Go to Jail June 22
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)H. R. Haldeman and John N. Mitchell will probably go to prison June 22, United States District Judge John J. Sirica said today.

title: S.E.C. Says Sucrest And Others Violated Antifraud Statutes
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the Sucrest Corporation, its former chairman and two officers and a New York sugar broker. yesterday with violating antifraud and reporting provisions of Federal securities laws.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday. June 2. 1977

title: Likud Aide in U.S. to Help Leader
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Menahem Begin has sent a representative to the United States in an effort to ease apprehension among Americans about the likely emergence of his rightwing Likud bloc as the head of the next Israeli government.

title: YOUNG SEEKS TO SMOOTH RELATIONS WITH QUEENS
description: Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, yesterday tried to smooth out his relations with the people of Queens by saying that he had lived four years in the borough and some of my best friends are from Queens.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 10%
description: WASHINGTON, June 2The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales last week were about $13.76 billion, up 10 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.55 billion. Department store sales were an estimated $1.35 billion, up 13 percent from last year's $1.2 billion.

title: Ramirez and Vilas Reach French Tennis Semifinals
description: PARIS, June 2 (AP)Raul Ramirez of Mexico and Guillermo Vilas of Argentina gained the semifinals of the French open tennis championships, today and ended the sevenyear domination of the title by European players.

title: Alaska to File Challenge To Pipeline Tariff Rates Proposed by 2 Owners
description: ANCHORAGE, June 2 (AP)The State of Alaska has hired lawyers in Washington to challenge tariff rates filed by owners of the transAlaska pipeline with the Federal Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: 6 Sentenced to Die in Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 2 (AP)The supreme state security court sentenced six persons to death today, three of them in absentia, for acts of sabotage and espionage for Iraq, according to an official announcement

title: Sirhan Says He Can't Remember Kennedy Slaying
description: SOLEDAD, Calif., June 2 (AP)Sirhan Sirhan told two Los Angeles County supervisors today that he still had a mental blackout about his killing of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and repeated, I can't remember, I can't remember. He also suggested, his lawyer said, that he be taken back to the scene of the killing, perhaps with a psychiatrist, to help him recall the slaying.

title: News Summary
description: Major oilproducing countries and other developing nations at the closing session of the 27nation northsouth conference in Paris rejected the demands of the United States and the rest of the industrial world for continuing consultations on energy questions. Acceptance of their demands was the principal objective of the eight socalled rich countries of the north, but they made no attempt to take back the pledges of assistance they had made to the countries of the south. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Laetrile: A Fraud
description: State governments are being manipulated to legalize the quack cancer nostrum laetrile. Their action is a negation of knowledge by the political process.

title: $185,000 Snake Bite Award
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 2 (AP)A Federal judge has awarded $185,000 to a 19yearold man who suffered permanent leg damage because of inadequate and negligent medical care given him at MacDill Air Force. base for a rattlesnake bite five years ago. Richard Sutton Buck 5th was awarded the money by Judge Sidney Aronovitz yesterday, a month after the judge ruled in favor of the young man's medical malpractice suit against the United States Government.

title: Bateman and Kean, G.O.P. Opponents for Governor, Seem to Agree on Issues and Differ in Their Style
description: The main rivals for the Republican nomination for Governor in New JerseyState Senator Raymond H. Bateman and Assemblyman Thomas H. Keansaid yesterday that new leadership was needed to revitalize New Jersey, and each said he was the man to provide that leadership.

title: 1977 Fur Shows Wrapped In a Luxury That's Versatile
description: The embarrassment of riches at this week's fur shows makes one almost wish for snow in June. With several successful years behind them, and anticipating that 1977 will be a record year, furriers seem to have lost their willitsell jitters and gone overboard on luxury furs.

title: N.Y.U. Holds 145th Graduation
description: Although many of his 7,000 fellow New York University graduates are worried about getting jobs, Abraham Arazy plans to give his up in three months.

title: The Pop Life
description: EVER SINCE WOODSTOCK, the ultimate image of the rockandroll concert has been the mass outdoor. summer festival, with hundreds of thousands of young people clustered together. But there aren going to be any such concerts in the entire metropolitan area this summer, and the lack sets one to pondering.

title: U.S. Deeply Concerned Over Soviet Jewish Activist
description: WASHINGTON, June 2The Carter Administration said today that it was deeply concerned over reports from Moscow that Soviet authorities planned to put a Jewish dissident and humanrights activist on trial for treasona charge punishable by a prison term of at least 10 years or execution.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 3, 1977

title: MILTON ROSENBLUM
description: Milton Rosenblum, chairman of the board of the J. Rosenblum & Sons Company of WoodRidge, N. J., a major food distributor, died Wednesday in his home in Lake Worth, Fla. Mr. Rosenblum, who also had a residence in Paterson, N. J., was 66 years old.

title: Model Flood Recovery Plan Too Costly to Be Used Again
description: RAPID CITY, S.D.,  For generations, survivors of devastating floods, usually to the bewilderment and concern of a watching nation, have moved back in as the waters receded and rebuilt their lives on the stricken plain.

title: Beating Victim Questions Justice As Court Frees Alleged Assailant
description: Crime does pay, if you're the criminal, Salvador Reale said sadly as he stood in front of the Manhattan Criminal Court at 100 Centre Street yesterday with a cast on his right leg and hand and watched as Pablo Gonzales, the man who had allegedly caused his injuries, walked down the street.

title: House Rules Out OneMan Power Over Gas Prices
description: WASHINGTON, June 2The House, considering a bill to establish a Department of Energy, defeated a major proposal of the Carter Administration by refusing today to give the head of the new department the authority to set natural gas prices.

title: Fog Shrouds Seattle Slew's Workout
description: Quicker than that old punchline, Ready when you are, C.B., Seattle Slew disappearedagain into the earlymorning fog at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Publishing: Reunion Beside the Bay
description: SAN FRANCISCO MARK TWAIN, who used to work the San Francisco beat for the Overland Monthly, called the city by the Golden Gate heaven on the half shell And so it was envisioned by the bookselling and publishing twain who flocked to San Francisco in record numbers this week from all over the country and from foreign lands for the American Booksellers Association annual house party.

title: Art People
description: THE LONGRUNNING proposal by Christo to wrap West Berlin's historic Reichstag building in 60,000 square yards of synthetic fabric for 14 days has hit a bit of a snag. The packaging artist, whose last projectin the fall of 1976was running fence of white nylon that snaked through 24 miles of northern California landscape for two weeks, reports that after considerable discussion, he has a nein from Karl Carstens, the conservative Christian Democratic president of the West German Bundestag, or parliament,

title: DEVELOPING NATIONS TURN DOWN DEMANDS OVER ENERGY ISSUES
description: PARIS, Friday, June 3The 27nation northsouth talks ended early today with major oilproducing countries and other developing lands refusing to agree to the demands of the United States and the rest of the industrial world for continuing consultations on energy questions.

title: Credit Markets Quiet, Ending April Rise
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's money supply showed no change in the week ended May 25 as it continued to decelerate from the unusually rapid growth rate it showed in April. At the same time, the Fed reported that New York bank loans to commercial and industrial corporations increased for the first time in eight weeks. And the central bank's data on commercial paper interest rates gave Citibank the chance, if it chooses to follow its formula, to increase its prime rate on corporate loans for the third time since midMay.

title: It's Nice, Gratifying and Temporary
description: When Johnny Pesky was a new manager in Boston, the Red Sox got off to a flying start and were still airborne the first time they reached Baltimore to play the Orioles. When you're winning, Pesky said, you sleep soundly, your food tastes great and your wife looks like Gina Lollobrigida. Before long, the Sox began to seek their own, level, which turned out to be one notch above rock bottom. By the time they played in Baltimore again, their manager had hollows under his eyes. Who does your wife look like these days? asked. Gordon Beard of The Associated Press. Bela Lugosi, Pesky said. Gordon put it on the Wire, Johnny related afterward, and when I got home my wife'wouldn't let me in the house.

title: U.S. WITHHOLDS SALE OF JETS TO PAKISTAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 2The Carter Administration, seeking to bolster its ties to India, has decided to withhold the sale of military jets sought by Pakistan, according to State Department sources.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended April 30 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange, and (O) overthecounter.

title: A LowCal Peanut Is Going on Market
description: Martin Solow Creative Services is handling a new product that has a lot going for it. It combines the assets of being the unofficial national fruit with the fact that it is lower in calories than others of its ilk.

title: A Birthday Party for The Jewish Museum
description: Between dealings with the usual avalanche of city business, Mayor Beanie took a few moments recently to tend to an item on his calendar marked Jewish Museum. He issued a proclamation naming Sunday as Jewish Museum Day.

title: The Typical Aborigine: Uneducated, Jobless
description: FITZROY CROSSING, AustraliaThe federal Government has spent more on aid to the Australian aborigines in the last five years than in the previous 50 years.

title: CAREY SEEKS TO LINK CONTROLS ON RENTS TO NEED OF TENANTS
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that rents in rentcontrolled or stabilized apartments should be related to the tenants' ability to pay so that those who need rent control will have it, and those who don't need it and can afford higher rents will pay them.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: For the second time in less than a month the Folger Coffee Company has announced that it is reducing the wholesale price of its ground coffee. Yesterday, Folger, the nation's second largest roaster after the General Foods Corporation, trimmed 20 cents from the wholesale price to $3.98 a pound.

title: Figueroa Gains Seventh Triumph in 103 Rout
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 2The Yankees found one of their better hitting grooves tonight as they punched out 14 hits and defeated the Minnesota Twins. 103.

title: Dane Takes Boxing Crown
description: RANDERS, Denmark, June 2 (AP)Joergen Hansen of Denmark knocked out Marco Scano of Italy in the fifth round tonight and won the European welterweight boxing title. The fight was Scano's first outside Italy, and only his second defense of the title he won in April 1976.

title: Pope Names Top Aide a Cardinal, Making Him Potential Successor
description: ROME, June 2Pope Paul VI today elevated his principal aide to cardinal, thus placing him among the candidates for the papacy.

title: Meadowlands
description: (C)Indicates conventional sulky, All others modified.

title: Brooklyn Promotes Coach
description: Joseph Margolis, swimming coach, was named athletic director of Brooklyn College yesterday. The 39yearold Margolis was graduated from Penn State in 1958.

title: OneMan Band at Modern
description: A singular ensembleconsisting of Robert Johnsonwill perform at 8 P.M. tonight and tomorrow in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art as the institution, carrying on a recent summer tradition, opens the garden to the public, free of charge, on weekend evenings.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, June 2, 1977

title: TV WEEKEND
description: SURROUNDED by repeats and a generally uninspired schedule, more energetic viewers might consider a visit this weekend to the film and video department of the Whitney Museum at Madison Avenue add 75th Street, A 70minute history of bloadcasting, produced by TVTV is being shown several times each day through Sunday.

title: Notes on People
description: Betty Ford, suffering from arthritis, is too weak to travel and has been told by her physician to cancel her schedule for the next few months, an aide said yesterday in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: A.M.C. Will Lay Off 3,000 Workers At Its Wisconsin Plants on Monday
description: DETROIT, June 2  The American Motors Corporation said today that would lay off 3,000 workers at its Wisconsin plants for a week beginning Monday. A.M.C. has been cutting production in recent months because of a long sales slump. A spokesman said the company would suspend production of Matador and Pacer models for the coming week, affecting 1,900 at the Kenosha assembly plant and 1,100 at the Milwaukee body plant.

title: Dance: Taylor Tale
description: WHEN THE extraordinary Paul Taylor retired from dancingat least temporarily, for it has never been made official  one wondered what would happen to his choreography, which, as with many modern dancers, seemed to be a personal extension of his body. Now, the really extraordinary thing about Mr. Taylor is that since leaving the stage, his choreography has become more extraordinary than ever. The man is a geniusand this is a word not to be used lightly.

title: Throng of Sharks Spotted Off Texas Resort for 2 Days
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 2Perhaps as many as a thousand or more migrating sharks converged off this Gulf Coast resort today for the second day, driving bathers from the 85degree waters and creating a scene that many said reminded them of the motion picture Iaws

title: World Team Tennis
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: New Display At Museum: 31 S.I. Pupils
description: Most visitors don't go to the Staten Island Museum to see children, but the truth is that one of the most unusual displays these days at the institution on Stuyvesant Place in St. George consists of 31 youngsters.

title: Around the Nation
description: HONOLULU, June 2 (UPI)Policemen and National Guardsmen in helicopters, jeeps and trucks continued a searchanddestroy mission today against the Hawaiian Islands marijuanagrowing areas.

title: 125 Abandon Ferry After It Hits An Iceberg Off Coast of Labrador
description: HALIFAX, Canada, June 2 (AP)A Canadian ferry, the William Carson, struck an iceberg off the Labrador coast late today and its 125 passengers and crew abandoned the vessel in lifeboats, a spokesman for the Canadian National line reported.

title: Advance in Swiss Franc Drives the Dollar Down
description: LONDON, June 2 (AP)The Swiss franc surged ahead on currency exchanges across Europe today, and the side effects drove the dollar down against most currencies.

title: Grover Cleveland Redivivus
description: Jimmy Carter is turning out to be the most conservative Democratic President since Grover Cleveland. Behind all the headlines about a foreign policy based on human rights, Andrew Young's gadfly attacks on entrenched racism and James Schlesinger's comprehensive energy program, the stark fact is that the Carter economic policies have turned out to be not much different from Gerald Ford's.

title: Restaurants
description: IF WE TAKE special delight in finding truly wonderful restaurants thriving in the city, it is because we firmly believe that serious eaters will go almost anywhere for a great meal, and that no socalled bad neighborhood can kill a really good restaurant. There could be no more perfect case in point than Gargiulo's in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, a popular meeting place for local politicians.

title: EXCHIEF OF ITALIAN EXXON RELEASED ON $113,000 BAIL
description: ROME, June 2 (AP)Vincenzo Cazzaniga, the former president of the Exxon Corporation's Italian subsidiary, arrested 12 days ago on fraud charges, was released on $113,000 bail today, court officials said.

title: U.N. Sending Messages Aboard Voyager Craft For Beings in Space
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 2If there are intelligent beings beyond the solar system, the United Nations has a message for themseveral messages, in fact, including a personal greeting from Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, goodwill wishes from many diplomats, a prayer in Arabic and a poem in Swedish.

title: TeenAge Canoeist's Body Found
description: BELVIDERE, N. J., June 2 (AP)Authorities have found the body of a Phillipsburg, N. J., teenager who had been missing since Sunday when the canoe he was riding in overturned in the Delaware River. Authorities said the body of the youth, Alex Levy, 18 years old, was discovered in the river yesterday about 200 yards from where the canoe overturned. Mr. Levy's companion in the canoe, Steven Lynn of Phillipsburg, managed to swim to shore.

title: Rich and Poor: Shifting Ties
description: PARIS, June 2The northsouth conference, ending here after 18 frustrating months of argument, has spotlighted the shifts that have taken place in nternatonal relations since the pattern of negotiations developed after World War II What it all proves, one northsouth veteran said, expressing a widely held view, is that international conferences just don't work any more. For one thing, the participants in the Paris meeting, which was up to tackle an overwhelming variety of economic issues, never really agreed on what they were negotiating.

title: Chain Store Sales Up Sharply in May
description: Buying of clothes, home furnishings, automotive accessories, sporting goods and other merchandise sold in the nation's big chain stores rose sharply in May over the yearbefore period, the retailers reported yesterday. Several had their biggest monthly gains of the year so far.

title: Philadelphia Looking to State Aid To Avert Major School Cutbacks
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 2The Philadelphia school system is edging closer to nother fiscal crisis.

title: Torre's Men Turn Bold and Steal 4 Bases
description: MONTREAL, June 2With Joe Torre manipulating the strings more adroitly than Bil Baird with his puppets, the Mets continued making impressive and aggressive changes in their play tonight as they defeated the Montreal Expos, 74.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 2. 1977

title: Fire Destroys Archives Of Watkins Glen Track
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., June 2 (UPI) The 30th season of racing this summer at the Grand Prix auto track will go on as scheduled despite an early morning fire that destroyed the track's archives in a downtown bank building, a track official said today.

title: Family Trees and Forests
description: Government is having some difficulty defining a family. It still approves of the idea of family (except in the Justice Department's organized crime division). But there is confusion about just who belongs to a nuclear family and who belongs to an extended family and what ought to be the legal rights of each. The innocent may think that a crude kind of genetic democracy decides such things; that biologically qualified applicants belong where they wish, subject to the sufferance of matriarchs and patriarchs. But the state is getting edgy.

title: Stock Trading Under Investigation In Sale of New York Magazine Co.
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Two investigations are under way to see if those with advance knowledge of the takeover of the New York Magazine Company by the Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch traded illegally in the company's stock. But there was no indication that any legal or disciplinary action was imminent.

title: Medicaid Mills in Bronx Linked to Organized Crime
description: Organized  crime racketeers, using strongarm tactics and death threats, became secret partners in Medicaid mills in the Bronx and extorted money from physicians and operators of health centers in slum neighborhoods, according to Federal and city law enforcement officials.

title: Albany Votes Bill to Aid Horsemen
description: ALBANY, June 2Increased purses at harness tracks throughout New York State, a 10th race nightly at Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways and substantial financial aid for breeders and owners of thoroughbred as well as standardbred horses are provided in an omnibus bill passed by the Legislature today.

title: At the Movies
description: SUDDENLY this summer Jane Fonda's an old cowhand. I couldn't believe it when I saw her roping and branding bull calves, said Alan J. Palm's, the rangy, redbearded director who once guided Miss Fonda to Oscarwinning glory as a tormented call girl in Kiute.

title: Rustic Turn of Art
description: There aren't many ways to mix culture and the summer sun. But visitors to the Silvermine Guild of Artists in Connecticut will be able to wander this weekend through six acres of green Nils and lawns set in the midst of a tiny preRevolutionary town near New Canaan. They'll picnic under the trees by a small stream, observe the ducks gliding across the nearby pondand peer at an extraordinarily eclectic sampling of contemporary art.

title: Kentucky Nightclub Fire Traced To Party Room by Investigators
description: SOUTHGATE, Ky, June 2 (UPI)The Beverly Hills nightclub fire that killed at least 161 persons started in a 15by30foot party room known as the Zebra Room just after members of a wedding party left, according to the chief investigator.

title: Belmont Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Music: Clamma Dale Goes Pop
description: There Is a side to Clamma Dale that might not be suspected by those who know her from her performances with the New York City Opera and in Porgy and Bess. On Wednesday evening at the Manhattan Theater, 321 East. 73d Street, she showed that she can also sing popular songs With results, that are so stunning that those who this on a fulltime basis might pick up a few pointers from her.

title: IRENE V. PALKA
description: Irene V. Palka, who retired in 1973 as .a librarian in New York City for Radio Free Europe, died May 26 in her home in Seattle after a lingering illness. Her age was 66.

title: Publisher to Lead Press Women
description: BILOXI, Miss., June 2 (AP)Charlotte Schexnayder, copublisher of the Dumas, Ark., Clarion, today was elected president of the National Federation of Press Women at the group's annual convention here. Mrs. Schexnayder, who has been a member of the press women's group for 27 years, will serve a twoyear term.

title: Art: Versatile Van Dyke
description: THE CAREER of Willard Van Dyke, though attached in one way or another to the creative use of the camera, has been a manysided one. In San Francisco, in the early 1930's, he ran a gallery devoted to photography. In New York, from 1965 to 1974, he was director of the department of film at the Museum of Modern Art, and earlier on he had himself made a number of distinguished filmsThe Photographer (about Edward Weston), The Bridge, and The Skyscraper, among others. A few years ago, he organized the museum's mammoth Weston retrospective, and today. in his early 70's, he is professor of theater arts on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York.

title: JAYNE SHOVER
description: CHICAGO, June 2 (AP)Jayne Shover, executive director of the National Easter Seal Society for Crippled Children and Adults, died today in a Chicagoarea hospital, the society announced.

title: Switzerland's Big 3 Banks: Alike, but Very Different
description: ZURICH, June 2Spokesmen for Switzerland's three biggest banks maintain that the agreement announced today by the banking industry and the central bank only codifies what these banks do already.

title: A Jazz Festival in the Lofts
description: The second New York Loft Jazz Celebration30 jazz concerts in a threeday, roundtheclock marathon that begins tonight at 8 P.M.shouldn't be called a Loft Jazz Celebration at all, according to John Fischer, the pianistcomposer who runs Environ, one of the four downtown performing spaces participating in the event. It should be called a Jazz Loft Festival.

title: Dividend Increases In May Set a Record
description: Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that more companies raised their dividends last month than in any previous May since it began keeping records of monthly dividends in 1955. The 262 companies that increased dividends compared with 212 a year earlier and the previous May high of 242 in 1974.

These two crews won their qualifying heats in competition that began at 6:30 A.M. in an effort to beat the weather.

I., June 2 (UPI)The New York Jets announced today the signing of Charles (Tank) Marshall, a defensive end from Texas A. & M. and their thirdround choice. in last month's National Football League draft. The Jets also signed Frank Russell, a wide receiver from Maryland, as a free agent. He is from Wantagh, L. I.

title: Stanley Fink Finds Instant Success In Albany Post
description: ALBANY, June 2It's not as if Stanley Fink was sitting on a stool at the counter of Schwab's Drugstore and was suddenly discovered by a bigtime Hollywood agent. Not exactly. This is Albany, not Hollywood, and a shaggyhaired, bluntspoken Assemblyman named Fink, whose mentor is the most powerful Democratic boss in New York City and whose debating style is roughly akin to the tone one would take to pick a fight on the Brooklyn waterfront, hardly seems like a good bet for overnight stardom.

title: Out of Doors
description: I CAN NEVER, if I am driving anywhere near northwest Connecticut in spring, summer of fall, resist swinging by the Housatonic River to wet a line.

title: Climate Peril May Force Limits On Coal and Oil, Carter Aide Says
description: To avoid accumulation in the air of sufficient carbon dioxide to cause major climate changes, it may ultimately be necessary to restrict the burning of coal and other fossil fuels, according to Dr. William D. Nordhaus of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Warmer Water Off Jersey Brings Abundance of Blues
description: AREA AStrong northeast winds last weekend made fishing poor, but in recent days blues have appeared in good numbers. On the beaches and inlets around Margate, N. J., where the water temperature is up to 61 degrees, good catches have been made with bucktails. At Point Pleasant and in Manasquan Inlet, blues in the fourtofivepound range have been taken with plugs. Blues and weaks of about six pounds are also abundant in Barnegat Bay. In Great Egg Inlet, fishermen using minnows or killies have taken summer flounder up to three pounds. Capt. Andy Applegate, running a party boat out of Atlantic City, has been getting blues from six to eight pounds on night chumming sails.

title: Stephen Boyd, Actor, 48, Was Messala in Ben Hur
description: Stephen Boyd, an Irishborn actor who was in dozens of Hollywood films but never quite reached star status, died in Los Angeles yesterday, apparently of a heart attack suffered while playing golf. He was 48 years old.

description: JERUSALEM, June 2 (Agence FrancePresse)Menahem Begin, Israel's prospective next prime minister, is to set up his private residence in Jerusalem's formerly Arabcontrolled Old City, an aide revealed today.

description: THE NEW School, which opened yesterday at the Film Forum, is a 90minute documentary about Cuba's intensive program to build and staff dozens of new junior high schools throughout the country. The subject sounds deadly dull, and in truth there are a number of predictable ??spects to the movie, produced by the Cuban Film Institute and directed by Jos Fraga.

Even though Mayor Beame was not supposed to be part of the final stages of the process, the critical negotiations on his budgets were held at Gracie Mansion.

title: Film : 'Katzelmacher' Hypnotizes and Amuses
description: Erich, who's becoming pudgy, wears a perpetual frown as if it were a fashion accessory. Marie, his pretty, romance-minded friend, clings to his arm as proudly as if Erich were an Olympics champion and not a petty hood.Paul, who's also getting fat, is proud of his hair, which he carefully combs whenever a lock might be out of place. Helga, who loves Paul, chatters too much and every now and then needs to be slapped into silence. Gunda has no guy but she hangs out with the others, hoping, probably, to pick up a castoff.Lower middle-class layabouts, they sit onor lean againstthe railing outside a Munich apartment house in various positions of boredom. They bicker. They brood. Mostly they just stare into space, lined up all in a row like the crows in Hitchcock's "The Birds."As they walk into or out of the frame, the camera rather ostentatiously refuses to follow them. Instead, it continues to stare straight ahead at the railing, as if mocking the world-weary attitudes it's been recording so patiently.Occasionally the scene shifts to the corner pub where Erich and Marie and Helga and Paul, sometimes with Gunda and Franz and Rosy, play cards. Sometimes they pair off to make love quickly and perfunctorily in barren rooms, only to return to the railing.Nothing much changes. Nothing changes, that is, until Elisabeth, who lives across the way, rents a room to a Greek worker named Jorgos. The rumors begin to fly. Jorgos is said to be a sexual wonder. Gunda reports a chance meeting in the park with Jorgos as an attempt at rape. The other young men feel threatened. Something has to be done.This is more or less the form of "Katzelmacher," Rainer Werner Fassbinder's second feature film, made in 1969 before he went on to become virtually a one-man German New Wave. "Katzelmacher"a slang term for troublemakeropened yesterday at the New Yorker as part of the theater's continuing Fassbinder festival. It is, with "Effie Briest," one of the two remaining Fassbinder festival films not to be missed.I've described the style of the film in some detail because it is so hypnotic and eventually so comic. Mr. Fassbinder, even in those early days when the influence of Godard was still apparent, was a complete original, one of the few directors who could make a deadpan film about lethargy, greed and small-mindedness that is simultaneously funny and tough, sympathetic and caustic.His characters, with the possible exception of Jorgos (played by Mr. Fassbinder), who never says much, are either slobs or dimwitted, and though they are totally self-absorbed and given to parroting clichs, they are sometimes capable of the unexpected gesture, as when Marie decides to leave Erich for Jorgos. Paul frets when Helga becomes pregnant; he considers murdering her, or, at the least, of aborting the child. When she loses it anyway, he decides to marry her.The static camera, the exaggerated mannerisms of the actors, the jump-cuts, the repeated themes and variations of scenes, all recall Godard, but the major influence on the film appears to be Mr. Fassbinder's early work in the theater.The screenplay, in fact, is an adaptation of a Fassbinder play, but having seen the film twice I find it difficult to imagine it as anything except an extraordinarily stylish film. It's quite unlike anything else I've seen, with the exception of another early Fassbinder film, "Recruits at Ingolstadt," which was also adapted from a theater piece.Unlike some of the later Fassbinder works, there's little ambiguity about what the director is up to here. "Katzelmacher" is scathing about the postwar German economic boom that has, of course, been so kind to the film maker himself. More importantly the flim is an early glimpse of his dazzling talent and the talents of the stock company of performers and technicians who, with him, have created a body of film work unique in any country in recent years.

title: 'Fraternity Row,' a 50's Film, Plays Neighborhoods
description: Not since "Lifeguard" has any American movie confronted secondary problems as steadfastly as "Fraternity Row," a film about one idealistic student's attempt to change the fraternity system at what is described as a small, elitist eastern college in 1954."Fraternity Row," which opened at neighborhood theaters yesterday, is itself a sort of campus product, having been written and produced by Charles Gary Allison to get material for his Ph.D. in philosophy and communications at the University or Southern California. Considering the lack of experience of both Mr. Allison and Thomas J. Tobin, the director, the film is something of a technical achievement.It really looks and sounds like a 50's movie. The color is just garish enough and the actors all a bit too prettylike studio contract players in the 50'sand it repeats its few ideas so many times that even the most dimwitted third-grader can get the point."Fraternity Row" comes out firmly against bigotry, hypocrisy and hazing in its story about a fraternity pledge named Zac (Gregory Harrison) who attempts to change the system from within, though his girlfriend, Jennifer (Nancy Mergan), remains properly skeptical. The movie also comes out firmly against the tactics of the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy when his charges were made against non-Communists. At the same time it displays great affection for the dopier rituals of the day, including solemn ceremonies in which a young man would publicly give his fraternity pin to the young woman of his choice ("With this pin I pledge thee my heart. . . .").The actors are all very attractive under the circumstances, which at best, are facetious and, at worst, embarrassing. They include Mr. Harrison, Peter Fox (as an upper classman), Miss Morgan, and, most effective of all, Scott Newman (Paul's son) as the fraternity's cheerful sadist. In another time these roles would have been played by Robert Wagner, Terry Moore and Jeffrey Hunter, and they wouldn't have been half as good.

title: A Sensible Welfare Solution
description: The idea that welfare people ought to have to work for their checks is sound .so far as it goes, but it does not go far enough. It has two great weaknesses. One, most of the welfare population is almost worthless in today's labor market and would, therefore, not be worth the welfare benefits that accompany its toil. Two, the present outrageous cost of the welfare program would remain as outrageous as ever.

title: Notes on People
description: Judy Langford Carter, a daughterinlaw of President Carter, has joined Redbook magazine as a contributing editor. She'll be working fulltime, but mostly at her home in Calhoun, Ga., with occasional sidetrips to New York, a source at the magazine said yesterday. The 27yearold Mrs. Carter is married to the President's eldest son, Jack, and they have a son, Jason, who will be 2 years old in August. Mrs. Carter holds a master's degree in early. childhood education from the University of Georgia. Her first article for Redbook, scheduled to appear in the October issue, is part of a collaboration with Frances Ruffin, an associate editor, on women who have been innovators in their communities or society at large. Mrs. Carter wrote for magazines at Agnes Scott College and the University of Georgia, and for Learning, an educational magazine.

title: State Department Aide Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI)President Carter nominated Richard M. Moose today to succeed William Schaufele as Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. Mr. Moose has had foreign affairs experience both on Capitol Hill and at the State Department. Early in the administration, Mr. Carter named him Deputy Undersecretary of State for Management.

title: DRUG AGENCY DROPS PLAN TO ALLOW POPPY GROWING
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Drug Enforcement Administration has backed off from a proposal to legalize commercial cultivation in this country of the great scarlet poppy, which can be used as raw material for manufacture of the painrelieving drug codeine.

title: CUBANS TO RELEASE 10 OF 30 AMERICANS THEY HOLD IN PRISON
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Cuba said today that it would free 10 of its 30 American prisoners immediately and review the cases of the rest.

title: Sniper in Car Kills Jerseyan
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 3 (AP)A Plainfield man died of a neck wound caused last night by a bullet shot from a passing car, the police said. The man, Claude E. Casey, 34 years old, was chatting with a friend on the sidewalk when a passenger in a passing car fired one bullet, which hit Mr. Casey in the neck. The police said they were questioning possible suspects, but declined to give any details.

title: 3 Italian Newsmen Are Victims Of Increasing Wave  of Violence
description: ROME, June 3The wave of political violence here has taken a new turn with a series of attacks on leading Italian journalists. In the last 48 hours three have been shot and bombs have destroyed parked cars owned by two others.

title: A Master of the Spectacular Dreams a Big New Dream
description: It is easy to fade into the landscape of crumbling Hudson River piers, gray and grimy highway girders and acres and acres of gravel and stone and trash that make up the West 60th. Street railroad yards  easy, that is, for almost anyone but a large cartoon character of a man in a purple flowered safari suit, standing by the water and sketching with his hands an alternative to the existing blight.

title: Community Services Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)President Carter said today that he would nominate William W. Allison, executive administrator of a Gedrgia community action agency, to head the Community Services Administration. Mr. Allison, 43 years old, has been with Economic Opportunity Atlanta since 1966. The agency serves Atlanta and four adjacent counties.

title: LOUISIANA INQUIRY BACKS VOTE CHARGES
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 3A Congressional inquiry into the disputed Democratic primary that led to the resignation of United States Representative Richard A. Tonry last month has confirmed substantial voting irregularities not only in St. Bernard Parish, which Mr. Tonry carried, but also in adjoining Plaquemines Parish, which is controlled by the powerful Perez family and which Mr. Tonry lost by a wide margin.

title: Prime Time Takes Jumper Title at Devon
description: DEVON, Pa., June 3Until a week ago, Prime Time was a mount known almost exclusively by his Owner and rider. Few other equestrians ever had heard of her.

title: Former Clergyman Is Convicted of Acts Against His Wards
description: WINCHESTER, Tenn., June 3 (UPI)The Rev. Claudius I. Vermilye, a defrocked Episcopal priest, was found guilty today of crimes against nature, the seduction of young boys at his farm for wayward youths.

description: WASHINGTON, June 3Henry A. Kissinger decided to continue an affiliation at Georgetown University, rather than move to New York and an appointment at Columbia University, because he felt more comfortable in Washington and closer to his work, close Kissinger associates said today.

title: Firemen Train in New Hampshire
description: LACONIA, N.H., June 4 (AP)Approximately 1,000 firemen from the six New England states and New York began today a weekend training course in all aspects of firefighting. The session was sponsored by the Lakes Region Fire Mutual Association.

title: Sheila Wertimer Is Engaged to Gary Gruca
description: Dr. Sidney Wertimer Jr., Leavenworth Professor of Economics and Provost of Hamilton College, and Mrs. Wertimer of Clinton, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Wertimer, to Gary Gruca, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Gruca of Clarendon Hills, Ill.

title: ART
description: WE often have difficulty explaining in art, as in other creative expressions, exactly what feeling is. We mention that an artist has a feeling for a subject, an artistic style or a kind of emotion and we mean that he grasps the essence of the experience in a natural, intuitive way.

title: Crop Prices Up
description: Prices received by farmers for their products rose for the sixth month in a row, the Agriculture Department announced last week. The 2 percent increase between April 15 and May 15 means food prices will continue to climb this year, at a time when fears of renewed doubledigit inflation are mounting.

title: Fiction
description: ACKROYD. Jules Feiffer. (Simon and Schuster. $8.95.) His first novel is a Dance to Creative Energy.

title: The Constable: What's His Role?
description: THE constableone parttime lawenforcement officer and the antiquated institution he representsis the focus of both a grandjury investigation into a Putnam County shooting incident and a debate over whether the position has outgrown its usefulness.

title: Ruth Hochberger Is Engaged to Martin Flumenbaum
description: Ruth Susan Hochberger, a feature reporter for The New York Law Journal, and Martin Flumenbaum, a lawyer with Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, plan to be married in October.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives killed a proposal to require deposits on all beer and soda contain ers. The attempt was made as an amendmen to an antilitter bill, which would tax businesses to pay for litter cleanup. In a rare weekend session, the House voted 77 to 61 to kill the deposit requirement, called the Bottle Bill. The Legislators then passed the tax measure by a vote of 77 to 64 and sent it to the Senate.

title: $114 Million Spent in '76 Race; 60% Was Public Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 4About $114 million was spent on the 1976 Presidential campaign, and for the first time in American political history about 60 percent of that was covered by public subsidies. As a result, according to statistics made public today by the Federal Election Ofanussion, the amount of private money invested in the national election dropped from $127 million in 1972 to $46 million last year.

title: Workers at Navy LogistiCs Unit Fail to Bar Move to Philadelphia
description: NEWARK, June 4 (UPI)Employees at the Navy Logistics Control Office in Bayonne have lost the first round in an attempt to stop the Navy from moving the facility to Philadelphia.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . .to Litchfield, the most direct auto route is via the Henry Hudson Parkway and the Saw Mill River Parkway (or, tollfree, the Major Deegan Expressway, the Cross County Parkway and the Henry Hutchinson Parkway) to Interstate 684 north, then east on Interstate 84, north on U.S.7 and east on U.S. 202. title: Essays & Criticism
description: THE AUDEN GENERATION. Literature and Politics in England in the 1930's. Samuel Hynes. (Viking. $12.50.) A study of the 30's and the literary left in Britain that promises more than it delivers.

title: Ingmar Bergman Lights Up The Munich Stage
description: MUNICH Ingmar Bergman's complex and exciting production of August Strindberg's A Dream Play is a smash hit at the Residenz Theater of Munich, a playhouse of which the world has not heard very much lately. But the world had better accommodate itself to this new theatrical comet, because Bergman apparently intends to keep directing plays there, although he considers its oldfashioned building an architectural monstrosity. Chekhov's The Three Sisters is next.

title: Recital: Erratic but Spirited Style
description: Although Maris Brody is an erratic and sometimes technically weak pianist, she had enough personal ideas about the music she played to make her appearance in Carnegie Hall Thursday night more interesting than many of those by more polished performers. A New Yorker, she has studied with such teachers as Hedy Spielter, Sascha Gorodnitzki and Byron Janis, and she is a Juilliard School graduate. She drew an enthusiastic capacity audience to this, her local recital debut.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: As Dean of the School of Arts and Sciences at one of the Westchester colleges mentioned by Liva Baker,After Briarcliff, Who's Next? [May 1],?? read her article with some interest.

title: William H. Ahrens Marries Betty Treiber in Connecticut
description: Betty Treiber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Treiber of Winchester Center, Conn., was married in the Congregational Church there yesterday to William H. Ahrens, son of Mrs. William Ahrens of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and the late Mr. Ahrens. The Rev. Ernest Bengston performed the ceremony.

title: Strike at a Chrysler Truck Plant In Missouri Enters Its Sixth Week
description: A strike at a Chrysler Corporataion truck assembly plant in Missouri entered its sixth week yesterday after union members voted down a tentative settlement on a new local contract, The Associated Press reported.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE POVERTY OF POWER, by Barry Commoner. (Bantam, $2.75.) The author of The Closing Circle (1971), a landmark in the ecological movement, resumes his inquiry into the dimensions of the energy problem. Barry Commoner's appraisal of the virtues and vices of such proposed technological solutions as Dfcssil fuel, nuclear power and solar energy are precise and illuminating  and far more persuasive than the radical economic alternatives he suggests.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Wayne W. Dyer
description: Reading Dr. Wayne W. Dyer's Your Erroneous Zones, one naturally looks at oneself in one's own mirror. I noticed a goodly number of erroneous zones reflected: Angst, anger, guilt and nostalgia for youth, desire for money and fame. Since the book is aptly called a selfhelp pep talk, it seemed to be just what my doctor ordered.

title: Ann Severance Is Wed To Charles Carter 3d
description: Ann Severance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Craig Severance of Locust, N.J.. was married in Rumson. N.J. yesterday to Charles Abbott Carter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Jr. of Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. George Willis. assisted by the Rev. R. Park Johnson, performed the ceremony in St. George'sbytheRiver Episcopal Church.

title: Led Zeppelin And the Alchemy of a Rock Group
description: Standing by the side of the stage, you couldn't hear too well: the stage monitors were pointing toward the band, and the loudspeakers were aimed out front toward the audience. But you could see the band very well indeed, and, even better, you could see directly into the enthusiastic faces of the fans packed in around the front of the stage. So maybe the critics don't acclaim Led Zeppelindue into Madison Square Garden for six shows starting Tuesday as the greatest or the most important band in the history of rockandroll. So what? The quartet may be the biggestdrawing concert attraction in the history of live entertainment, and the enthusiasm at this Cincinnati show a few weeks ago hardly undercut that notion.

title: UNIONS OF THE L.I.R.R. SOON FREE TO STRIKE
description: Unions representing 6,200 employees of the Long Island Rail Road have reached an impasse in contract negotiations with the carrier, and will be free to take strike action late this month or early in July.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Too many photographers think of darkroom work as pure drudgery, ignoring the fact that some of the greatest discoveries in this medium have actually been made in the darkroom. These photographers often do not realize that one of the easiest ways they can make creative pictures that are original and different is to indulge in a bit of darkroom magic when processing their negatives and making prints. They can employ numerous techniques which will enable them to produce unusual and imaginative looking images that will differ markedly from the ordinary looking pictures that would otherwise result.

title: THREE NATIONS PLAN SOLAR POWER PLANTS
description: PARISIn 1980, if the governments involved proceed with existing plans, the world will acquire its first megawatt solar power plants.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IF A HOMEOWNER discovered a hole big enough to throw a football through in one of the outside walls of his house, he would almost certainly take immediate steps to patch or plug this hole one way or another. Yet if that same house is missing most or all of the caulking around the outside windows, doors and other joints lb siding or trim, there may be cracks or open seams whose total area could be the equivalent of an opening that is just that large in the outside walls of the house.

title: Notes: A Bonanza Of Free Brochures
description: A Midwest publisher is helping to give away thousands of free travel brochures each year at absolutely no cost to the recipients and is turning a handsome profit for himself in the process.

title: CLUSTER OF POWER PLANTS FOUND TO CHANGE WEATHER
description: RICHLAND, Wash., June 4 (AP)Power plants can change the weather if they are built close together in large energy centers, a study for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission concludes.

title: The Township and the Single Renter
description: ALONG time ago before the advent of the Pill, doityourself divorce kits and group houses, being single was like having leprosy. Singles could not work in banks, join country clubs, enjoy sex or eat in restaurants without fingers pointing, tongues wagging, eyes staring.

title: Realty News
description: The New York General Building, which straddles Park Avenue between 45th and 46th Streets, has been sold by the New York Bank for Savings to 230 Park Associates, a partnership headed by Harry B. Helmsley.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: CHARLESTON Various northern journalists to the first Spoleto Festival in the United States, which opened in Charleston, S.C., on May 25, and ends today, were thoughtfully provided with Lord Ashley Cooper's dictionary of Charlestonese. Southern hospitality can extend no further. Lord Ashley's dictionary, that indispensible guide to pronunciation in this area, tells us that the word ain't means the sister of one of your parents, as in Ain't Catherine. Forks is a bushytailed animal hunted by riders in red coats. Garner is a man who tends flower beds. Lack means to enjoy, as in I lack fried chicken. Coat, is where they got that jedge an' all, as in Stannup for hizzoner, coat's in session.

title: Re Marriage and Remarriage
description: HAIL wedded Love! cried John Milton long ago, but who heeds him now? Aren't we all convinced that marriage has become unnecessary, reactionary and moribund? No, not all of us; here, in fact, are two new books, each by a liberated woman, and each celebrating modern marriageor at least certain kinds of modern marriage which they find valuable, uptodate and alive and well.

title: Rome Looking Over Illegal Builders' Shoulders
description: ROME, June 4A small plane flew over Rome recently taking pictures for the Mayor. He already knows what the city looks like; his problem, however, is to locate precisely where speculators are building illegally.

title: The World
description: Despite serious points of contention, the United States and Cuba are inching ever nearer to normal relations. The two governments announced last week that American diplomats will set up an interest section in the building that once housed the United States embassy in Havana, and Cuban diplomats will move back to their former Embassy in Washington. But to demonstrate that rapprochement is less than full, the American Embassy will fly the Swiss flag and the Cubans will work under the flag of Czechoslovakia.

title: If You Go...
description: . . . to Mrida, avoid the JulySeptember rainy season, or take a sturdy raincoat. You can fly to Mrida on any Wednesday, Friday or Sunday on Pan American via Miami; economy roundtrip fare from New York is $326. AeroMexico and Mexicana offer a seven to 30day excursion fare of $330 for the circle from New York to Mexico City, Merida, Cozumel, Miami, and back to New York; flights leave daily and unlimited stopovers are permitted in the three Mexican cities.

title: Settling Down to Business
description: June is a bouquet of roses and forgetmenots, veiled With morning mist and jeweled with dew. June is cornflower blue and daylily gold and lacy white with daisies. It is the scent of sweet peas on the garden fence. June is time settling down to the business at hand, which is growth and maturity after the lush preparations when all the trees were leafing out and all the meadows were full of fine new grass and bluets.

title: How Investors Can Save 75% on Commissions in 1977
description: On May 1, 1975, the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled that brokers were no longer required to charge fixed minimum commission rates as in the past. Brokers may now charge whatever rates they choose.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: SWACK and subterfuge are terms that crop up these days when Representative Jerome A. Ambro Jr. is talking about his running fight with the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: Cosmos Will Be Keeping Beckenbauer at Midfield
description: Judging from the way they played their last North American Soccer League game, the Cosmos can use three or four Franz Beckenbauers. Since there is only one Beckenbauer, however, Coach Gordon Bradley is attempting to get the most out of the taciturn West German star. Including Bradley, who is one of the most serious students of the game, practically all coaches who have worked with the 31yearold Beckenbauer have recognized that the position of Libero suits him best Few teams use that position because it requires a player of limitless ability to play the role to perfection. Beckenbauer is a master at the position, which entails primarily defensive duties with the option to organize moves on attack.

title: Music: Works of Stuart Diamond
description: Stuart Diamond, a young composer with degrees from Haverford and Sarah Lawrence colleges who also acts as associate conductor of the Bronx Philharmonic, presided over a program of his music Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% Municipal tax.)

description: Sunday June 5. 1977

title: Mrs. Carner Increases Lead From 1 to 6 Shots
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 4JoAnne Garner gained such a big lead in the third round of the L.P.G.A. Talk tournament at Wykagyl Country Club today that Pat Bradley, the defender, who was six strokes back in second place, said, I'd settle for a playoff tomorrow.

description: cop soy sauce

title: The $100,000 Broken Home: Who Gets Custody?
description: When a couple decides to get a divorce, the family home becomes one of their biggest problemsa nest egg almost valuable enough to keep them together.

title: ART VIEW
description: WASHINGTON The history of American painting is not exactly lacking in examples of dour and determined charactersartists who, though undoubtedly touched by genius, are narrow and obsessive in their interests, absolutely dogged in pursuing them, and unwavering in their indifference to al ternative modes of feeling or expression. The Puritan tradition excels in producing such types, of course, and even those who revolt against its more expendable tenets tend to be shaped by its constricting spirit.

title: Swiss Paper Says Solzhenitsyn Had Savings of Over $1 Million
description: ZURICH, June 4 (AP) Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Soviet author, reported an income of $320,000 and savings of $1.8 million to Swiss tax officials in 1974, the year he was banished from his homeland.

title: Dr. Pascal Imperato, Health Chief, Weds Eleanor A. Maiella
description: Eleanor Anne Maiella, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Maiella of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Pascal James Imperato, New York City Commissioner of Health.

title: Miss Sumergrade Is Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Larry Sumergrade have announced the engagement of their daughter, Candice Sumergrade, to W. Wayne Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Jones of Pompano Beach, Fla. The couple are graduates of the University of Tampa.

title: Janet Claire Mauriello Is Married To Peter Simon, a Securities Trader
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Sorrows in South Orange, N.J., yesterday, Janet Claire Mauriello, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Mauriello of South Orange, was married to John Peter Simon, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Simon of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Edward Kearns, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: NO MILITARY BUILDUP SEEN IN NORTH KOREA
description: SEOUL, South KoreaWhile contro versy swirls in Washington and here over the advisability of withdrawing American ground troops from South Korea, in view of the possibility that North Korea may be tempted to invade, South Korean and American analysts detect no unusual activity in the North.

title: THE STYLE OF THE 70's
description: I recently reviewed in these pages the second edition of E. P. Thompson's biographical study of William Morrisa book that falls happily between biography and history. It was first published in 1955 when the obscurity of the author, the immensity of his book and his lack of a major publisher would have been enough to assure its being ignored. But it was also ignored because Thompson's committed approach and the fact that in many ways Morris himself was a political failure had little appeal to the readers of the 1950's. It was, after all, a period when consensus historians were generally revered better to be safe than sorryand when ambitious young men were on the slick road to making it. Now our attitude towards failure is much more sympathetic: we are interested, I believe, in those who offer alternatives, who seem to be on the margins of history but nevertheless may have a far firmer grasp on what really matters than those who embody a flashy, meretricious and very often transient success.

title: Some Geographers in Specialized Fields Are Enjoying an Acquired Status as Admired Pioneers
description: It is hard to decide whether geography is a Cinderella or a dowager among scholarly disciplines. Geographers themselves have compounded this difficulty by asserting that their discipline was so radically transformed during the 1960's that only an insider could be expected to understand its character. In some respects geography is indeed new. During the 1960's many geographers adopted a more theoretical, approach than was characteristic of their efforts in the past, employed statistical and mathematical techniques in their research, and made effective use of computers, automated mapping devices and satellite photography. Yet not all geographers adopted the methods and modes of thought indicative of the new geography of the 1960's, and the science of spatial organization proclaimed then did not replace the traditional pluralism of the discipline.

title: Income Tax Is the Issue in Tuesday's Vote
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE will learn Tuesday just how upset people are about the state income tax, and whether his efforts to sell the benefits of the tax program are winning acceptance.

title: CHESS
description: Since June 1975, when Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union was proclaimed World Champion as a result of Bobby Fischer's refusal to defend the title, he has lost only three games.

title: Margaret E. Wiff Planning'78 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Wiff of Elgin, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret E. Wiff, to Hugh W. Whipple of Buffalo Grove, Ill. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Taggart Whipple of Syosset, L.I.

title: Painters Union in New York City Is Investigated on Misuse of Funds
description: The painters union in New York City which has had a history of corruption and internal wrangling, is under investigation by its international parent as well as under attack from dissatisfied members.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$17,000, pace mile.

title: JAPAN ASKS WORLD ACTION ON QUOTAS FOR WHALES
description: TOKYO, June 4 (Reuters)Japan, the world's largest whaling nation after the Soviet Union, wants catch quotas and the preservation of whales territorial waters to come under international control, a Japan Whaling Association spokesman has said here.

title: First U.S. Show in 1853 Building on Its Tradition
description: Back in 1853, Richard Henry Dulany of Upperville, Va., took a dim view of the breeding activities of his neighbors.

title: Ambulances Late for Mental Cases
description: A young man who tried to jump in front of a subway train is taken at 7 A.M. to the emergency room of Queens Hospital Center, where physicians decide he requires confinement and psychiatric care.

title: No Pits in Poe Home, Keeper Says
description: When Ralph Bruno hears a tapping at his door, window or roof, he is more likely to find a couple of neighborhood youngsters climbing on his cottage than a solitary raven, but he occasionally wonders what Edgar Allan Poe would have done about it.

title: The Basic Training of Al Pacino
description: Two years ago, having lunch in the garden of Greenwich Village restaurant, AI Pacino noticed troupe of actors seated nearby at a long table covered with a checkered tablecloth. The picture  softhued, idyllic, with the sun and shadows dappling the actors  made a vivid impression on him. It was like a Renoir, he remembers. Looking at them, you could tell that actors have existed for hundreds and hundreds of years. Now, as then, they are the chronicles of the time. They have their own world. There is something ancient and familial about actors, heightened by the fact that they travel.

title: Anarchy's the Rule as Anarchists Gather for a Banquet in New York
description: As faithful subscribers to the anarchist Freie Arbeiter StimmeFree Voice of Laborgathered at the Summit Hotel the other day for the 86th Anniversary banquet, circumstances were blissfully congenial, even anarchic. The Free Voice of Labor, the oldest Yiddish newspaper in America, was celebrating three anniversariesand it had picked the wrong date for all three.

title: Major Step In Concentration Of Europe's Car Industry
description: PARISOh sure, we looked at Citron all right. But it didn't fit into our European operations. I was really surprised when Peugeot agreed to take it over, remarked a senior executive of the Ford Motor Company a few weeks ago during an interview at the company's headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., with its views of factory roofs and smokestacks.

title: Yonkers Plays A Rival to Bingo
description: IF you happen to be in Yonkers almost any Sunday afternoon from September through June and have a dollar to spare, you can win 100 prizes. The odds against that undoubtedly are monumental, but with your dollar you can at least take chances on 100 prizes and with some luck fill a shopping bag. It happens all the time at penny socials.

title: INTERVIEW
description: OFFICIALS of the Federal Energy Administraton are reviewing an energy conservation plan submitted by state of ficials that is designed to cut energy consumption in the state by 6 percent by the year 1980.

title: Amy Marner, Social Worker, Is Married to Charles Venti
description: Amy Marner and Charles Venti, social workers with the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services in Jersey City, were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Martier of Interlaken, N.J., parents of the bride. United States District Court Judge Clarkson S. Fisher performed the ceremony.

title: A Group Tour
description: The hike described in the accomnpanying article is offered by Haron Ltd. (34 Assaf street, Ramat Gan, Israel, tel.: 03735490). Raton concentrates on programs for backpackers and climbers in groups of up to 20, with a trained guide for every six people. The groups hike for five to 12 miles a day; formal mountaineering experience is not necessary. The company supplies all the food for a trek  three meals a day plus snacks  and cooking and camping gear, although hikers must bring their own sleeping bags and ground mats. Most of the gear is carried by camels or donkeys. Allinclusive rates are about $200 for a sevenday trip, $270 for 10 days and $410 for 14 days and include transportation to and from Eilat. For explorers who prefer riding to hiking, tours of the desert by jeep or command car are run by Johnny Desert Tours (Eilat, Israel) and Neat Hakikar Desert Safari Tours (28 King David Street, Jerusalem). Johnny has twoday Mount Sinai from $57, with participants sleeping at a campsite at the mountain. Among Neot Hakikar's treks from Jerusalem is one of five days for $159. Both organizations provide all necessary equipment.

title: A Trek In the Sinai Range
description: I was in Israel on sittingdown business, writing a play, but I had resolved to hike, too, and had my sights fixed on the High Range around Mount Sinai. Like most of the world I knew this range only from photos: deliberately mystical, a region of harsh granite peaks without a sign of life. I was in for a surprise.

title: Peg Neppel Sets a Mark in the Park
description: It was a celebration of feet. For 2,263 runners, ranging in life styles from kindergarten through senior citizenry, filled Central Park to bursting yesterday for the world's largest sporting event for womenthe 10,000meter Bonne Bell Mini Marathon.

title: Economics Lesson at What Price?
description: THE fiveyearold Branford Intermediate School, unique in New England as a pure middle school, grades five through eight, embodying the twin concepts of classroom without walls and team teaching, is about to become a casualty of what its principal, Francis Walsh, calls Yankee economics.

title: THE STYLE OF THE 70's
description: Popular culture in the 70's can mean anything from the rockandroll group Kiss, whose lead singer breathes fire on stage, to softly reassuring singersongwriters who can hardly be said to breathe at all. It can mean est and similar solipsistic mass therapies, captured in all their banality in Jerry Rubin's hapless Growing (Up) at 37 or the invasion of American Life, particularly its campuses and airports, by Eastern religiona phenomenon chronicled with great critical intelligence in Robert Greenfield's overlooked The Spiritual Supermarket Popular culture can also mean Watergate. especially the Senate Watergate bearings, which in the summer of 1973 became our national theater, a shared moral drama. It can mean feminism and the cultural reaction to feminism, which can be found in the rape fantasies that decorate numerous popmusic album covers, in the highclass misogynist porn of fashion photographer Helmut Newton (whose White Women was a recent best seller) and in the explosion of middleclass porn in magazines like Cheri and urban moviehouses across the country.

title: Weiskopf, Rogers, Burns Tied at 207 for Golf Lead
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 4 (AP)Tom Weiskopf, who has won this event twice, and Bill Rogers and George Burns, who have never won on the tour of the Professional Golfers' Association, were in a tie for the lead today after three rounds of the $250,000 Kemper open.

title: SHOP TALK
description: SHOPPING, browsing, snacking, dining, plus a nostalgic promenade to yesteryearall these abound in a day's outing at Milleridge Village in Jericho.

title: From Politics to Priesthood
description: BILL Sangiovanni at 34 years of age was the top aide in Representative Stewart McKinney's district office, and was the choice of many Republicans to be the next First Selectman of Fairfield. Two years later, he is the Rev. William Sangiovanni, assistant pastor of St. Patrick's Church in Bridgeport's North End

title: CAPE VERDIANS LEARN OF THEIR HERITAGE
description: Young Immigrants Told How Their Countrymen Came to U S.The descendants of seafaring people, 80 youthful immigrants to Boston from the Cape Verde Islands discovered New York City recently on a oneday bus excursion, and learned bow their own people go deep into the history of the United States, particularly in New England.

title: Pioneer Educator, 71, to Retire After Running Grambling U. for 41 Years
description: GRAMBLING, La., June 1When a frightened, 19yearold Ralph Waldo Emerson Jones showed up at the Lincoln Parish Training School one summer night 51 years ago to take up duties as the rural black school's newest faculty member, he found little to inspire optimism.

title: Villains Male and Female
description: THE STYX COMPLEX By Russell Rhodes. 305 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $8.95.

title: Brown Rides Viscount To Open Jumper Title
description: DEVON, Pa., June 4There are days when a jumper can barely get over the fences at a horse show.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: mix it thoroughly, weigh out 55 grains at a time, then spoon it carefully into glassine envelopes. Each of these envelopes will sell on the street for $70.

title: Lee of Red Sox 52 Victor On a 6Hit, 78Pitch Effort
description: Bill Lee, Boston's fine lefthanded pitcher, is a freewheeling, freespeaking, freespirited individual, In the terminology of today's youth, Lee is far out. Taking note of that, the Red Sox baseball writers have nicknamed him The Spaceman.

title: Flood Spurs New Militancy in West Virginia Town
description: WILLIAMSON, W. Va., June 4Two months after this grimy little coal town was nearly drowned in a flood that inundated much of central Appalachia, a new mood of militancy has pitted many of the town's 7,000 residents against outofstate coal corporations and Federal relief regulations.

title: Conferences to Explore Meaning
description: NEW JERSEY has officially recognized alcoholism as a disease for more than a year now, Governor Byrne having signed the Alcoholism Rehabilitation and Treatment Act early in 1976. Now, the state's lawenforcement system is being asked to match its actions to the new policy.

title: Sewers: Rival Lines of Thought
description: THE lives of two dozen people were dominated for three solid weeks this spring by the struggle over whether 350 homes within the Hallocks Mill Drainage Basin in Yorktown should form a sewer district and reconstruct lateral sewer lines in their streets to enable their homes to tie in to an existing publicsewage system. It was a simple question, but a difficultand costlydecision for homeowners to make.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE GREAT PERPETUAL LEARNING MACHINE

title: Cheryl Neely Married
description: Cheryl A. Neely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Neely of Scotch Plains, N. J., was married yesterday to Henry O. Clutsam 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clutsam Jr. of Summit. N. J. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, N. J., by the Rev. George Chorba. The bride is a senior flight attendant with Northwest Orient Airlines in Minneapolis. Her husband is a vice president of Merrill Lynch Hubbard Inc., wholly owned subsidiary of Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith Inc.

title: LAETRILE NETWORKS BECOME MORE OPEN
description: After operating outside the law for a quarter of a century, the laetrile underground is finally going public.

title: Editorial Article 1  No Title
description: How many controversies have spun around the Food and Drug Administration in recent years: thalidomide, cyclamates, red dye No. 2, aerosol sprays, swine flu, and now saccharin and laetrile. The agency occupies an increasingly central place in an increasingly technical societybut its importance is too often matched by its impotence. Now, a federally sponsored Review Panel has completed a 27month study of the F.D.A.'s responsibilities for regulating drugs. In a final report, the body of experts offers some eminently sensible findings and recommendations for reform.

title: FILM VIEW
description: It may well be true, as some of my colleagues apparently fear, that the immense success of Annie, the Broad way musical incarnation of Harold Gray's Little Orphan Annie, and George Lucas's Star Wars, a gigantic comicstrip of a scifi movie, are the seminal works of a new age of NonThink, an antiintellectual reaction to plays and films that go out of their way to insult, shock, provoke and disturb, that question everything including the system that allows the artist to express his outrage. One can easily make a case for this argument.

title: New Zealand's Navy Seeks Loanof Men
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 4 (Reuters)The New Zealand Navy wants to borrow sailors from Britain and Australia because it is short of men.

title: THE REMAKING OF THE VICE PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON. The first clue should have been when Jimmy Carter allowed Fritz Mondale not Just While Houseroom but his pick of any office that wasn't oval.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: It was a good day for us when Marc Chagall made it to Paris in the late summer of 1910. He was ready for Paris, Paris was ready for him, and a blazing love affair sprang up between the two of them. It went on until Chagall went back to his native Russia four years later.

title: Weddings
description: Berkowitz Denis

title: No Farce The Second Time
description: PARIS  The argument between Western and Eastern power blocsvariously described as democracy versus autocracy or human rights visvis their lackis one of history's oldest ideological debates. The contrast was most clearly defined not by an American President but almost 25 centuries earlier by Pericles.

title: Mediators Start Talks in Netherlands Abduction
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, June 4Two newly chosen mediators started negotiating this afternoon with the South Moluccan gunmen who have been holding about 60 hostages in a hijacked railroad train and a school near here.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: When rainfall is scant, grass will naturally turn strawcolored and become dormant. Unless watering is deep and weekly, incorrect lawn watering does much more harm than good. Fall rains and cooler growing weather will green everything up again.... Mulch vegetables and annuals to keep soil moisture in and weed growth down.... Many like to disbud young annuals now so strength goes into developing strong, wellbranched plants. Don't forget light booster feedings.

title: Belmont Racing
description: 1977 by Triangle Publications Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: ARGENTINA ANNOUNCES RADICAL LEADER'S DEATH
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 4 (AP) The army announced today that it had killed the last nationally prominent leader of the Montoneros guerrilla group still left in the country.

title: A House of Nature
description: FOR years, people riding by Frank Santillo's hexagonal home in White Plains used to stare. Now Mr. Santillo is designing a newer kind of house, and with rising fuel costs and a dwindling energy supply, people are less apt to stare at its appearance and more likely to marvel at its efficiency.

title: CAREY AIDES LINKED TO REDLINE SYSTEM
description: Two close associates of Governor Carey are among present and former public officials on the boards of Brooklyn savings banks criticized in a recent report of the New York State Banking Department for investing too little of Brooklyn depositors' funds in Brooklyn mortgages.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: The other day we were looking at the television coverage of the demonstrations against the Concorde at Kennedy Airport. As we watched the angry protesters and the angry travelers and the angry airline personnel, my wife asked, isn't time we thought about vacation?

title: Falling Population Growth Worries Some Australians
description: PERTH, Australia  A prolonged drop in Australia's birth rate and a sharp decline in immigration are causing serious concern among some Australians over the future development of this vast but still only partially populated country.

title: New York's Worst Finest
description: CRIMINAL MISCHIEF By Paul Chevigny. 244 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $7.95.

title: The Flavor of General Foods
description: IN the sandcolored buildings that stand on a secluded 55acre tract of land on the banks of the Hudson River in Tarrytown, electronic equipment is winking and whirring, whitecoated technicians are peering at liquid protein bubbling away in test tubes, and scientists are exploring puddings, coffees, mixes and vegetables, freezing, thawing them, tasting them, adjusting them.

title: Maria Kelleher, Peter Rathbone Marry in Jersey
description: The marriage of Maria Kelleher to Peter B. Rathbone took place in Princeton, N.J.. yesterday. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, dean of the Princeton University Chapel, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Kelleher. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry T. Rathbone of Cambridge, Mass., and New York.

title: Not Exporting The Atom Also Has Some Risks
description: WASHINGTONA significant shift has taken place in the United States approach to an awesome dilemma. The international development of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes can also lead to the spread of atomic weapons, and from an approach of cooperation with other nations in promoting the development of atomic energy, the American policy, at least temporarily, is shifting to denial of cooperation.

title: In Search of Nantucket's Muse
description: The first time it's better to go by sea, rather than air, and let the twohour ferry ride gradually dissolve the mainland of America before the first glimpse on the opposite horizon of the hill above Nantucket town and, later, the domed, timepiece steeple of the Unitarian Church on Orange Street. In a peasoup fog, when the planes are grounded, anyway, the first Nantucket greeting comes from a clanging harbor buoy, quickly followed by the horn and flashing light at Brant Point Station.
