description: THE ABANDONED WOMAN By Richard Condon. 317 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $8.95.

title: Chinese Study Their Heritage
description: WHILE his two children sat inside, laboriously copying Chinese characters, reading aloud from Chinese books and singing Chinese songs, Dr. Donald Tang waited for them in the sun in front of the Yorktown Methodist Church.

title: Adelaide DeSano Manera Is Bride of Clark Schiller
description: Adelaide DeSano Manera, who is in the corporate circulation division of Time Inc., was married yesterday to Clark Schiller of Syosset, L.I., director of market research for Time magazine. The Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Mets end their series against the Philadelphia Phillies with a 1 P.M. doubleheader in Shea Stadium today. The Mets have 8 P.M. games here tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday against the Cincinnati Reds. The Minnesota Twins play the Yankees in Yankee Stadium 8 P.M. Friday and 2 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

title: Right on RedA Call for Repeal
description: BEFORE long, it will be six months since New York add New Jersey instituted their turn right on red laws. In this short time, it has become apparent that these measures should be repealed.

title: Reform Synagogue Young at 135
description: Richard Wechter, a Wall Street stock broker, described himself the other day as a drifting Jewuntil five years ago.

title: A LEVELING OFF SEEN IN HEALTH EXPENSES
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4 (UPI)Americans will continue to pay more for health care services over the next decade, but changes in the health care system already being started by the Carter Administration will help to level off spending, according to a special study.

title: Fish fillets in beer batter
description: Beer batter (see recipe)

title: Billy Joel Offers Rock From Middle of Road
description: Given the idolatrous reactions of his admirers Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, Billy Joel looked like one of America's most beloved popmusic stars. But he is actually a rather more curious case than that. He had a genuine national hit in Piano Man four years ago, and he has enjoyed intermittent success since with other songs.

title: ROUNDUP
description: Although 1977 has not been kind to every businessman, the year could hardly have been better for the holder of a Master of Business Administration degree. From Massachusetts to Californiaand, for that matter, Texasa sample of placement directors for the country's business schools unanimously hailed the justcompleted recruiting season as one of the best ever.

title: THE STYLE OF THE 70's
description: Trends. Overviews. Headlines. The more brutally reductive, the more helpful. Is literature a superbly ungovernable process in which individuals struggle to express a multiplicity of truths, merely imagining that they are in competition . . . or is literature a ghostterm, a nonexistent category, an invention of critics and professors and encyclopedists? Scanning the countryside, one is pressed to rely upon a horizontal method and cannot, despite one's sanest instincts, see much beyond cartoon simplicities.

title: NellDone Food And a Rare Day Draw Throngs
description: Throwing their ulcers once more into the breach, at least a quarter of a million New Yorkers turned out yesterday for A Taste of the Big Apple, which is possibly the city's fanciest food fair.

title: The Region
description: Mayor Beame has managed to achieve the improbable: municipal approval of a budget that seems genuinely balanced for the first time in memory, and with none of the service cutbacks that were predicted several months ago. He can point to the $13.9 billion expense budget as a sign of New York City's fiscal recovery. More immediately, he has given himself a significant asset in his campaign for reelection.

title: Blazers, at Home, Hoping To Wear a Crown Today
description: More than 5,000 fans greeted the Trail Blazers at Portland International Airport in Oregon at 4:30 A.M. yesterday after their charter flight was an hour late in arriving from Philadelphia. The airport police had to call for additional help from the Portland Police Bureau and the county sheriff's office when the traffic in and around the airport was backed up for 31 blocks.

title: G.David Schine
description: Twentythree years ago this month, the curtain rang down on one of Washington's greatest television dramas: the ArmyMcCarthy hearings. At the start, the focus was on G. David Schine, an Army private who had been chief consultant to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which Senator Joseph R. McCarthy headed.

title: Arts Center Marks 10th Year
description: COMES summertime, and the mind wanders to thoughts of sandy beaches, backyard barbecues and, for the last 10 years, relaxing under the stars for an al fresco evening of music at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel.

title: British and Irish Workers' Beer Is the HardestEarned in Market
description: BRUSSELS, June 4 (Reuters)Britons and Irishmen must work longer for their beer than the citizens of any other European Common Market country, according to statistics published by the Common Market's Commission.

title: Baseball in 2001: Sparky From Cairo and a SureHanded Aussie
description: Cheap intercontinental rocket travel probably had a lot to do with it. So did the development of the $14.95 color television set. Whatever the causes, big league baseball in 2001 was being played all over the world.

title: U.S. Judge Stays Effort to Collect From Some Medicaid Beneficiaries
description: A Federal judge has issued a temporary order restraining New York State from taking any further actionpending a court hearingto make Medicaid beneficiaries over the age of 21 pay part of their bills.

title: Laws Against Discrimination
description: Racial discrimination has become enough of a problem that the Government has had to pass laws forbidding it in many areas, including employmenthousing and public accommodations. It is common to see pubs refuse admission to blacks in some cities.

title: Home Style
description: It may be possible to leave town like a thief in the night, but move in that way? Slim chanceat least where Welcome Wagon is in operation.

title: Headliners
description: Pope Paul VI has moved to make his principal aide, Archbishop Giovanni Benelli, a prime contender to succeed him by elevating him to Cardinal and naming him Archbishop of Florence. Monsignor Benelli has served as the Vatican's deputy secretary of state for ten years, a post Pope Paul himself held under Pope Pius.

title: Ballet: Villella Fine in Watermill
description: Dancers have problems all during their performing careers outside of the normal runofthemill injuries, hurts and inconveniences. While in the corps they are desperate to be noticed, once being made soloists they find that most of their performing opportunities have been removed while they are expected to grow in the limited number of roles available.

title: LETTERS
description: Tobacco Control

title: Interface, Jazz Band, Evolves Over a Year
description: Interface, a group led by the pianist John Fischer, seems to change, chameleonlike, with each shift in personnel. There are certain predictable elements. Mr. Fischer's rambling, friendlysounding piano playing and Mark Whitecage's mercurial work on reeds are holdovers from the Interfacethat performed at last summer's Loft Jazz Celebration. An Interface set usually includes a freeform improvisation in an idiom Mr. Fischer calls Poum!, an idiom that makes use of nonsensical vocal sounds and attempts to build a music out of almost random noises.

title: SPAINAFTER 40 YEARS OF FEAR
description: The country moves toward its first democratic elections since the civil war  with some of its people predicting great upheaval, with others regarding next week's elections as a device to insure a continuity with the Franco past. Perhaps a more accurate view may be seen in the tiny eastcentral province of Soria, which is at once a reflection of past and contemporary Spain. Text, starting on Page 20, by James M. Markham; photos by Leonard Freed.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Perhaps the most disconcerting sight as you come into New York by air or car right now is the unfinished top of the Citicorp Buildinga huge, 46story structure that has been taking shape as midManhattan's third tallest building quietly, if not exactly invisibly, on Lexington Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets. The tower tops out at a 45degree angle, and this massive slope is currently an ugly open metal frame against the sky.

title: Scotland Beats England In Soccer Tourney
description: LONDON, June 4 (AP)  Scotland beat England at Wembley Stadium today, 2I, to win the Home International soccer championship. The loss was England's first at home to Scotland in 10 years.

title: Letters: UngryArry's New Life as u Seagull
description: In midDecember of last year something funny happened on the way to New York aboard great luxury liner.

title: Colombo Family Underboss Flees After Failure to Overthrow Chief
description: The underboss of the Joseph A. Colombo Sr. crime family has gone into hiding after trying unsuccessfully to oust the family's current leader. Thomas DiBella, according to law enforcement officials and underworld informants.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: For NuclearWordLimitation Talks
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  If President Carter really wants to slow the arms race, he will have to uncouple this objective from what currently passes for a nuclear debate.

title: Michigan Students Oppose Pact
description: LANSING, Mich., June 5 (UPI)Hundreds of students protesting a film production contract by Michigan State University with Iran ended a weekend sit in today by posting a list of grievances on the front door of the university president, Clifton Wharton. More than 250 marchers, including Iranians wearing masks to conceal their identity, walked, a halfmile from the International Center to present their demands to Mr. Wharton, who was not home.

title: Police Baffled by Disappearance Of a Wealthy Chenango Woman
description: GREENE, N.Y., June 6 (AP)  The state police said today that they had checked out a variety of theories on the disappearance of Cynthia Raymond, the wife of a wealthy business executive, but remained mystified on why she was missing.

title: Children Are Dominating Subject At 50th Class Reunion in Leonia
description: LEONIA, June 5Class reunions are happily alike, but 50th reunions are happy in their own special way. At the one here yesterday, for example, Gordon Cross had a chance to tell Edith Beck about the insurance company he had worked for and the two sons he has and about the trips to Florida and California and everything else that has happened since June 23. 1927, when they graduated from Leonia High School.

title: Pravda Sees Warhead Deployment Threatening a New Arms Accord
description: MOSCOW, June 5(Reuters)The Soviet Union today criticized the United States decision to deploy a new multiple warhead on its Minuteman III missiles and hinted that the move could hamper progress toward a new accord on limitation of strategic arms.

title: Weiskopf Takes Golf by 2 Shots
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 5(AP)Tom Weiskopf, making his move on the parfive holes, broke out of a threeway tie today with a twounderpar 70,and captured the Kemper open golf tourney by two strokes. It was his first PGA Tour victory in two years.

title: Lebanon's Banks Emerge From Wreckage of War
description: WASHINGTON, BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 5Through all the brutal confusion and senseless destruction of the Lebanese war, the Banque Libano Francaise kept its doors open and even prospered.

title: Califano Asks Goals on Minority Students in Colleges
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday that the Federal Government must rely on numerical goals to monitor college and university efforts to recruit and help minoritygroup students.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Just about everyone agrees that improvements can be made in the policymaking operations of the New York City school system, and some say that the way to do this is to abolish the Board of Education and put the schools under the control of a commissioner of education.

title: In the Stands, Many Cheers Have a Higher Pitch
description: For most of this century, the image of the female sports fan was almost grotesquea Hatpin Mary, rushing up to ringside to jab a villainous wrestler in the thigh.

title: Albany Bill Would Require Legal Papers To Be Comprehensible to Most Consumers
description: ALBANY, June 5People should read contracts before they sign them, Assemblyman Peter M. Sullivan declared solemnly during a recent floor debate.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 6, 1977

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Overture to Radamisto, Handel; Magnificat in 8 Parts, Palestrina; Horn Concertina, Weber; La Campanella, PaganiniLiszt; Violin Sonata No. 7, CoreIli.

title: Brezhnev Vows Stalinism Is Dead
description: MOSCOW, June 5 (Reuters)Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party chief, pledged in a speech published here today that there would be no return to the illegal repressions practiced under Stalin.

title: Camus Caligula Staged With Flair
description: Albert Camus's play Caligula tackles that venerable philosophical redoubt, the problem of evil, with hand grenades disguised as paradoxes. His evil is not banal, as it was for Hannah Arendt; it is the misshapen but lofty drive to conauer a misshanen universe.

title: New York A.C. Pair Win Middle State Rowing Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP)Jim Dietz and Larry Klecatsky of the New York Athletic Club won the elite doubles by 10 lengths today in the Middle States rowing championships on the Schuylkill River.

title: U.S. Will Not Limit Grain Exports
description: TOKYO, June 5 (Reuters)Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland pledged today that the Carter Administration would never impose export restrictions on grain. In a television interview, Mr. Bergland, who arrived here early today for a threeday visit at the start of a threeweek, sixnation Asian tour, said the Carter Administration did not believe food was an effective diplomatic tool and wanted to establish an international food security agreement.

title: Thirty Years On
description: PARIS, June 5 Thirty years ago today I heard the Secretary of State, George C. Marshall, speak in the Harvard Yard about the shattered economies of postwar Europe. It was a brief speech, delivered without drama, and I think few of us there understood how much was implied in General Marshall's spare sentences:

title: Major League Scores
description: ECromartie, Speler. DPSt Louis 1. Montreal 1. LOBSt. Louis 2, Montreal 6. 2BParrish, EValentine, Cromartie. 38Falcone. HRScott (3), Dawson (3), Perez (7), Carter (9), Meilas (1). Sspeier.

title: Hundreds of BahamianAmericans in the Miami Area Celebrate Their Cultural Heritage With Roots Salute
description: MIAMI, June 5There wasn't any Miami back when I was growing up, said 81yearold Irene Pratt, picking at a piece of fried conch and moving farther into the shade of a huge banyan tree.

title: Dance: Sweet Finale to Spoleto
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., June 5The Spoleto Fstival U.S.A. 1977 ended tonight in a shower of fireworks and with the sweet smell of success. Yesterday Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. said that the triumph of this year's festival meant that Spoleto U.S.A. would be continued. He announced that the dates would be May 27June 10, 1978.

title: U.S. ASKS COURT TO LIFT STAY ON BENZENE LIMITS
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)The Government is asking a Federal appeals court to dissolve an order that is preventing enforcement of a new limit on the amount of benzene to which workers can be exposed.

title: Meadowlands
description: Hoses listed in order of post positions

title: Turner's Tenacious Leads Yacht Victors
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 5R. E. (Ted) Turner's Tenacious, AgnewFisher's Jubilee, John H. Page's Pageant and Lawrence Huntington's Cascade were series winners in the respective classes of the New York Yacht Club's 123d regatta that ended on Long Island Sound off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today.

title: Dakota Staton Sings A Standard Program
description: Dakota Staton, a jazz singer whose early successes came during the 1950's, is not an artist one might have associated with the jazz lofts of downtown Manhattan. But the theme of this summer's Loft Jazz Celebration seems to be that all kinds of jazz flourish in the lofts, and besides, the Ladies Fort, the loft run by the singer Joe Lee Wilson where Miss Staton performed on Saturday, has always presented jazz vocal ists of all persuasions.

title: OFFERINGS THIS WEEK OF TAXFREE ISSUES MAY TOP $12 BILLION
description: With interest rates on taxfree bonds close to their lowest levels in three years, the volume of taxexempt bond offerings this week is expected to exceed $1.2 billion,'which would make it the third most active on record.

title: Denise Camille Linen Is the Bride of John Colangelo
description: Denise Camille Linen and John B. Colangelo were married yesterday in the chapel of Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., by Msgr. Robert Fox.

title: The Ships Won't  Be Tall,     But Harbor Festival 77 Will Have Its Own Flair
description: If you loved Operation. Sail, you'll like the New York City Harbor Festival 1977. As long as you don't expect a repeat of last year's extravaganza, you probably won't be disappointed by this year's Salute to New York Harbor.which will take place over the Fourth of July weekend.

title: Campbell Saves Red Sox In Defeat of Former Club
description: The surroundings were familiar, but the crowd of 37,756 was a surprise to Bill Campbell as he hurled four innings of relief at Metropolitan Stadium in Bloomington, Minn., yesterday.

title: A Society of the People. And by. And for.
description: People sit back and wonder why their taxes keep going up, why It is that government keeps getting bigger. And it has gotten bigger. It has taken a dramatic jump forward under the leadership of individuals whose entire philosophy and public utterances are to the exact opposite. I refer not only to my predecessor, but to President Carter's predecessor.

title: Mine Worker's President Avoids TV Debate With 2 Challengers
description: HUNTINGTON, W.Va., June 5Only nine days before the election in which he hopes to win a second fiveyear term as president of the troubled United Mine Workers of America, Arnold R. Miller was conspicuously missing today in the most widely televised debate of an apathetic fourmonth campaign.

title: When a Girl Picks Baseball Over Ballet, Her Team Gains
description: My daughter is a second baseman. That is, she's a second basewoman. Second baseperson? Whatever she is, she plays second base and she plays it darn well.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1977

title: Music: Soprano
description: Giedre Kaukaite, Lithuanian, Sings Folk and Arias

title: Dole Declares Nixon Is Not Rehabilitated
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, who wax the Republican VicePresidential nominee last year, said today that Richard; M. Nixon might become an elder statesman in the Republican Party, but he is not yet rehabilitated. I don't see any active role for former President', Nixon, he said.

title: A.M.A. HEALTH STANDARDS FOR PRISONERS ARE TESTED
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)Federal, state and local officials are moving toward adopting national standards for the health care of jail and prison inmates.

title: Tennis
description: AT ROSLYN, L.I.

title: A British Jubilee Commemorates 25 Tough Years
description: LONDON, June 5On a February morning in 1952, Princess Elizabeth awoke at Treetops, the African game lodge, to find that she had become Queen Elizabeth II on the death of her father.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A New York State Court justice has upheld the constitutionality of a state law requiring that health insurance policies provide coverage for maternity care to the same extent that coverage is provided for illness or disease. However, policies that were guaranteed renewable,meaning that an insurer must renew at the option of the client were excluded from the requirement, in an opinion rendered by the justice, Abraham J. Gellinoff, in Manhattan.

title: North Carolina Proves Toyota Country to Dealer
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., June 5Wall Street investment analysts and Detroit automobile wizards may be puzzled as to why small foreign autos are blazing trails in the sales category, but not Garson L. Rice.

title: Sudanese Leaders Off to China
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, (Agence FrancePresse) June 5President GafaralNimeiry left here tonight for Peking for a weeklong official visit to China starting tomorrow. Top Sudanese officials said his talks with Chinese leaders would cover eastern and southern African hot spots and the Middle East.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Belmont Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post Positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: 8 in Primary for the Governorship Report Owing a Total of $1 Million
description: TRENTON, June 5When Governor Byrne's campaign committee agreed last week to pay $30,000 to the defunct political organization of the outgoing Mayor of Jersey City, Dr. Paul T. Jordan, it cut Dr.lordan's campaign debt by 25 percent.

title: Bethpage Victor in Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., June 5Bob Clark and Dave Rizzo scored three goals each and led the Bethpage polo team to an 83 victory over Huntington today.

title: Intensive Corporate Tax Scrutiny By I.R.S. Finds 481 Suspect Cases
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)  The Internal Revenue Service says its intensive tax probe of major United States corporations has thus far uncovered 481 cases of possibly illegal corporate slush funds.

title: Study Finds Various Frustrations Affecting Efficiency of New York City Policemen
description: A study made for the New York City Police Department has found that a pervasive frustration with existing conditions on the part of police officers and superiors appears to be preventing the department from operating at maximum efficiency.

title: Police Strength Stepped Up in Park Where 2 Hispanic Men Died
description: CHICAGO, June 5Sporadic looting and vandalism continued today in. the Humboldt Park section, which was rocked by rioting that left two men dead last night.

title: Spanish City, Preparing to Vote, Lives With. Fear Bred by War
description: BADAJOZ, Spain, June 1The old Plaza de Toros, where hundreds of men, women and children were executed in August 1936, is not used for bullfights any more. Its peeling walls are enlivened with brightly colored campaign posters for the parliamentary election June 15.

title: Carol Eilbott Married To David A. Klebanow
description: Carol Eilbott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Eilbott of New Hyde Park, L. I., was married there yesterday in Temple Emanuel to David A. Klebanow, son of Mrs. Robert Klebanow of Danbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Klebanow. Cantor Ephram Steinhauer officiated.

title: Byrne Leadership and Income Tax Top Issues in Primary Tomorrow
description: A grueling, sixmonth primary campaign in New Jersey, marked by a multitude of candidates and issues, ends tomorrow when a fraction of the state's electorate chooses the major rivals for Governor.

title: Golf
description: AT CHARLOTTE, N.C.

title: Eliezer Greenberg, Poet, Critic And Yiddish Translator, Was 80
description: Eliezer Greenberg, the poet, critic and editor whose work brought Yiddish literature to a wide English readership, died Thursday at the Cabrini Health Care Center here after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 455 East 14th Street.

title: Three Convicts Escape in Vermont
description: ST. ALBANS, Vt., June 5 (AP)Three men, described as dangerous, escaped yesterday from the St. Albans Correctional Center. The police throughout New England were searching for them today. The authorities identified the three as Donald Brant, 44 years old of Providence, RI., held on murder conviction; Philip Creaser, 32, of St. Johnsbury, Vt., awaiting trial on unspecified Federal charges, and Peter Mulholland, 19, of Peabody, Mass., held on kidnapping and larceny charges. They apparently escaped by sawing through bars on a window.

title: Leaves Found Green After 30 MillionYears
description: Scientists at the New York Botanical Garden are studying 30millionyearold leaves that are still green and almost as unaltered as if they had been pressed in the pages of a book a few weeks ago

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TraitsAtlantic

title: Son of Sam Adds Four Names In New Letter, Police Disclose
description: The police have released part of a second letter from Son of Sam in the hope that it may help them find the man who used a .44caliber pistol to murder five people in the Bronx and Queens.

title: Hijacker Overpowered Aboard 707 in Kuwait
description: KUWAIT, Monday, June 6 (AP)Army commandos early today overpowered a hijacker who had forced a Lebanese airliner to fly to Kuwait, airport sources reported. They said that the other 112 passengers and crew members aboard the Middle East Airlines jet were freed safely.

title: Chess.
description: In the Moses Mitchell tournament of champions at the Manhattan Chess Club, there appeared an unheralded rash of Schliemann gambit games1 PK4, PK4; 2 NKB3, KQB3; 3 BN5, PB4featuring 4 NB3, NQ5, an old suggestion of Alekhine.

title: Macedonian Relics Belie Image of Barbarians
description: PELLA, GreeceTwenty years ago, a villager unearthed a piece of a marble column while building a storeroom in this rural area of Macedonia Archeologists explored further and found wellpreserved roof tiles clearly stamped with the name of the ancient city of Pella, the birthplace in 356 B.C. of Alexander the Great.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: The late novelist Elliot Paul, who wrote The Last Time I Saw Paris, along with many mysteries, was by no means a major writer: But we remember with wry amusement a circumstance he describes in one of his mysteries, the name of which eludes us. The setting is Paris, and the cast of characters included a rich Texan, his daughter and the French police.

title: Indian Congress Party Finds It Hard to Shake Authoritarian Image
description: NEW DELHI, June 3A recent frontpage cartoon in The Times of India depicts the president of the Congress Party on his knees, appealing to the average voter for support in the state assembly elections this month.

title: Commodity Index Rises in Week
description: The Commodity Research Bureau's index of futures prices (1967=100) closed, last Friday at 220.5, up from 220.1 the week before. The index stood at 209.7 a year ago.

title: Young Says Africa Race War Would Start One in U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 5Andrew Young says that a race war in South Africa would inevitably precipitate racial conflict in the United States by causing whites to panic and to begin attacking blacks.

title: A Silver Jubilee for Britain
description: Once upon a time, monarchs were totemic figures, embodying symbolic and religious authority. Later, they became chief warriors and political rulers. Now, in the penumbra of the 21st century, most surviving monarchs have been stripped of military and political power and are, once again, symbolic. They represent not transient majority opinion on political and economic issues as do elected political leaders but rather the continuity of the nation and of the whole people.

title: Zeber's Wallop Provides Decisive Run
description: CHICAGO, June 5The Yankees rocketed six home runs into the humid precincts of Comiskey Park this afternoon and they were just enough to defeat the White Sox, 86.

title: Cuomo Opposes Some Parts of Albany Bill Tightening Lobbying Rules
description: ALBANY, June 5Unexpectedly strong opposition from Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo and several publicinterest groups is threatening a bill to strengthen regulations on political lobbying that had been agreed on by legislative leaders.

title: Legalization of Laetrile: Actions Confront Doctors With a Dilemma
description: Seven states have legalized laetrile, confronting doctors with their newest dilemma  if, when and for which cancer patients they should prescribe the apricot pit derivative called laetrile. More states are considering such legislation and courts elsewhere have allowed individual patients desperately seeking hope from laetrile to receive it from their doctors.

title: Hanoi Reports Attempt by Farmers To Save Rice Crops From Drought
description: SINGAPORE, June 5 (Reuters)Large areas of Vietnam have been suffering in a drought and. farmers are trying to save their rice crops, the Hanoi radio reported today.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The New Jersey Pharmaceutical Association warns people over 65 years of age who are not eligible for Medicaid that they have until June 30 to submit claims for rebates on their prescriptiondrug bills or on bills for insulin for 1976.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Grand Prix Race Taken By Nilsson
description: ZOLDER, Belgium, June 5 (AP)Gunnar Nilsson of Sweden, driving JPSLotus, won a rainplagued Belgian Grand Prix today for his first victory in the competition for the world. championship.

title: State Income Tax Looms as Main Issue In Jersey's Governor Race Tomorrow
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Sarah Kaiser Bride Of Robert S. Hyams
description: Sarah Elizabeth Kaiser, daughter of Mrs. Jerome A. Kaiser of New York and Westport, Conn., and the late Mr. Kaiser, was married yesterday to Robert Steven Hyams. He is a son of Mrs. Sidney Sewitch of Seaford, L. I., and the late Victor Hyams. The ceremony was performed in Temple Israel in Westport by Rabbi Byron T. Rubenstein.

title: Kidnappers Appear To Gain Recognition For Political Views
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, June 5After two weeks of siege, the battle of nerves and endurance btween South Moluccans holding hostages on a train and at a school near here has begun to take on the political dimensions desired by the gunmen.

title: JUDGE'S RULING AIDS MEDICAID RECIPIENTS
description: It Suspends CoPayments of Fees for Prescriptions in New York

title: Tennesseans Fear Loss of Jobs If Carter Cancels Breeder Project
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 2This prosperous scientific community, America's atomic energy, capital since World War II, has been rattled and dismayed by President Carter's policy on nuclear development, especially his attempts to prevent the spread of atomic weapons.

title: Dance: Rotantes
description: Nora Guthrie and Ted Rotante started out six years ago as a young dance duo full of fresh, witty, even zany, ideas. Now they have grown up and threaten to go serious on us.

title: Carter Attends Church Service
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)President Carter attended services at his church here today for the first time in five weeks, with the pastor offering prayers for his wife, who is traveling in Latin America. The President, his daughter, Amy, and daughterinlaw, Caron, took communion at the service at the First Baptist Church.

title: cosmos Treat 31,208 Fans To a 60 Rout of Metros
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, NJ., June 5Steve Hunt scored three goals, Giorgio Chinaglia two and Jomo Sono, the man destined to replace Pele, scored an unbelievable goal today as the Cosmos defeated the Toronto Metros, 60.

title: Clerics and Civic Leaders Greet Patriarch of Antioch In Manhattan Service
description: With more than a score of religious and civic leaders in attendance, Patriarch Elias IV of Antioch and All the East celebrated the ancient liturgy of St. John of Chrysostom yesterday in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, at 319 East 74th Street.

title: House Inquiry Reported Fruitless On KennedyKing Assassinations
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The House Select Committee on Assassinations, which has been in operation for eight months, has come up with virtually no new information or evidence relating to the death of President Kennedy or of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and has discovered that much of the socalled new information on which Congress based its decision to reopen the investigations is in error, according to a wellplaced committee source.

title: Karen LeVine and Allen Saperstein, Lawyer, Wed
description: Karen Dale LeVine. a member of the law department of Sheason, Hayden, Stone Inc., and Allen Howard Saperstein, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, were married yesterday morning in Temple Judea of Manhasset, L. I. Rabbi Arthur Buch performed the ceremony. Cantor Richard Berman assisted.

title: Town in Idaho Salutes Volunteers Who Helped After 76 Dam Collapse
description: REXBURG, Idaho, June 55 (AP)If it hadn't been for the 50,000 volunteers who put in one million manhours of work after the collapse of the Teton Dam, Rexburg might not have gotten out of the mud.

title: World Team Tennis
description: LAST NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Politicians Abound on Route Of Salute to Israel Parade
description: At yesterday's Salute to Israel parade in Manhattan, there sometimes seemed to he as many politicians, both incumbents and aspirants, as there were delegations from Solomon Schecter Schools.

title: WILLIAM P. SINNOTT
description: William P. Sinnott, the president of the Peter Sinnott Heating Company of New York City, died Saturday. He was 56 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: DR. CHARLES R. WEETH
description: Dr. Charles Reed Weeth, the director of the department of otolaryngology at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn from 1947 to 1959, died Friday in Rochester. He was 81 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: U.S. TO DETAIL STAND ON CONCORDE FLIGHTS IN COURT BRIEF TODAY
description: The Carter Administration, in its first entry into the court battle in New York over the Concorde supersonic jetliner, will detail today its position on test flights to Kennedy International Airport. Authoritative sources said the brief would reiterate the stand that Federal authorization of the flights did not rule out a ban on them by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Marilyn Fedder, Pratt Alumna, Is Married to James Michael
description: Marilyn Laura Fedder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Fedder of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to James Michael, son of Mr. and Mrs Patrick Michael of Floral Park, L. I. Nassau County Judge George Greenstein performed the ceremony at the Swan Club in Greenwood Landing, L. I.

title: More Safety, Less Government
description: Almost from the day it was created in 1971, the Occupational Safety and Health AdministrationOSHA for shorthas been a symbol of Federal bureaucracy at its worst. OSHA is the agency that sets and enforces work safety standards, and it quickly acquired a reputation  partly deserved  for needless harassment and poor technical judgment. Even those most concerned about occupational health were therefore pleased with the Carter Administration's recent decision to redirect OSHA's efforts toward serious safety problems in highrisk industries.

title: Peruvian Girl, 13, Living on L.I., Fights Deportation as an Alien
description: Isabel Carrasco, an illegal alien, excused herself to have some milk and cookies yesterday in the kitchen at 18 Hawthorne Lane in Valley Stream, L.I Since she arrived there on a visit at the age of 9, the sixroom house has been home to the slender 13yearold Peruvian.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: For week ending June 4, 1977

title: Food Festival Cleanup Runs Into Snags
description: The crowds had gone and only stray plastic eating utensils and a paper plate or two remained yesterday from the second annual A Taste of the Big Apple food festival Saturday in Central Park. A few picnickers had settled in on the site of the colorful booths and tables, but their fare was considerably less exotic than the mimosa cocktails and calamari on the menu the day before.

title: Overriding by Congress Seen If Carter Vetoes H.E.W. Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)  The chairman of the House Budget Committee predicted today that if President Carter vetoed a major appropriations bill for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare, Congress would override the veto.

title: Mrs. Carner's 284 Wins By 5 Shots at Wykagyl
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 5JoAnne Carner was assured of victory in the third annual Talk Tournament at Wykagyl Country Club today when her next to last. shot in the 72hole I.P.G.A. event struck a woman spectator in the face and nearly took all of the pleasure out of Mrs. Carner's first victory in 11 months.

title: Second Top Journalist Quits Paris Newspaper
description: PARIS, June 5 (Reuters)The editor of the French conservative daily Le Figaro resigned today over differences with its publisher. He is the second journalist to quit the paper this weekend.

title: JETLINER RUNS OVER CAR ON A RUNWAY IN NEW ARK
description: A Jetliner undergoing lastminute repairs before takeoff from Newark International Airport ran over a repair vehicle Yesterday moments after workmen atop the car leaned to safety.

title: The Standings
description: Monday, June 6, 1977

title: Three French Strikers Shot
description: RHEIMS, France, June 5 (Reuters)Three gunmen fired on a group of strikers picketing a glassworks here today and wounded three, the police said. They said the shooting occurred after the attackers had torn down posters and banners outside, the factory where 1,800 workers have been on strike since Wednesday.

title: Moluccans Release 2 Women From Hijacked Train
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, June 5The South Moluccan hijackers holding hostages on a train north of here freed two women this afternoon. One of them was in the fifth month of pregnancy.

title: LoftJazz Celebration Livens New York
description: Singers were the dominant note at the New York Loft Jazz Celebration Saturday evening. The veteran Eddie Jefferson was at the Ladies Fort, 2 Bond Street, and six singers were heard at a fivehour session at Jazzmania, 23 West 23d Street. And there were almost as many different concepts of jazz singing as there were jazz singers.

title: Further Rise Seen For World Lending
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The volume of international lending increased by 40 percent last year, and bankers expect it will continue rising sharply this year to nonoil developing countries, some industrial countries and even some oil exporting countries, according to data compiled by the International Monetary Fund.

title: 6,000 GROUND TROOPS IN KOREA WILL LEAVE BY END OF NEXT YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The United States has informed South Korea and Japan that it intends to withdraw about 6,000 American ground troops from South Korea by the end of next year in the first phase of President Carter's pullout program, Administration officials said today.

title: Inside Justice's Politics
description: WASHINGTONPolitical maneuvering inside the Justice Department is getting fierce. Saddened professionals sketch this outline:

title: Beame Acts to Cut Tax Delinquencies By CitySales Rule
description: The Beame administration plans to prohibit people who are in default on property taxes involving buildings bought at citysponsored auctions from purchasing additional properties at such auctions.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: All Star Cast: An Anecdotal History of Los Angeles, by Stephen Longstreet (Crowell, $13.95).

title: Deborah Cousminer Bride of Ezra Millstein
description: Deborah Ann Cousminer and Ezra W. Millstein, social workers, were married yesterday at the home here of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Harold Cousminer. Rabbi Israel Margolies performed the ceremony.

title: Auto Racing
description: AT ZOLDER, BELGIUM

title: Muscular Dystrophy Association Issues Appeal for Contributions
description: An appeal for contributions has been issued by the Muscular Dystrophy Association, which says that it provides help today and hope for tomorrow to thousands of adults and children afflicted with neuromuscular diseases.

title: JAMES M. SELDEN
description: James M. Selden, former assistant vice president of the Shell Chemical Company of New York, died yesterday at Sarosota Memorial Hospital in Sarosota, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: LOOTING, VANDALISM FOLLOW CHICAGO RIOT
description: CHICAGO, June 5Sporadic looting and vandalism continued today in the Humboldt Park section, which was rocked by rioting that left two men dead last night.

title: Schedule for Harbor Festival 1977
description: Saturday, July 2

title: Congress Wrestles With Problems Of Writing an Effective Lobby Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The issues involved in rewriting the 30yearold ineffective lobbying law are so sensitive and controversial, constitutionally and politically, that only one thing appears certain as the process begins: Congress will pass a new law within the next year or so.

title: 76ers Unhappy Season Ends Unhappily
description: The season of struggle ended yesterday in Portland, Ore., for the team of turmoil.

title: TV: A Sensitive, Passionate Man Deals Effectively With Problems of Alcoholism
description: Considered in a television vacuum, A Sensitive, Passionate Man merits some serious attention if only because it wanders beyond the escapistentertainment boundaries that normally define prime time. The NBC movie, which can be seen tonight at 9, deals with alcoholism and a number of that disease's attendant horrors. After 15 years of marriage, Marjorie Delaney suddenly finds out that her husband is an unemployed drunk. Her world of comfortable affluence begins to disintegrate rapidly into private pain and public humiliation.

title: WORLD BANK ALTERS STRATEGY TO FOCUS ON AID TO VERY POOR
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The World Bank, which administers $40 billion of loans to nonindustrial countries, says it is making a fundamental change an its development strategy by trying to focus more on projects that meet the needs of ,the very poorest people.

title: 4TH MATTEAWAN ESCAPEE ARRESTED IN NEW YORK
description: BEACON, N.Y., June 5 (UPI)The state police have arrested the fourth of 10 inmates who had escaped from the Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane two weeks ago along with a man who had been wanted for extortion, the police said.

title: Hebrew Union College Honors Catholic for Her Aid to Jews
description: Discarding traditional synagogue etiquette, the graduating class of the Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion burst into applause yesterday as a tiny, frail, 76yearold woman received an honorary doctorate of humane letters at commencement exercises in Temple Emanuel.

title: Leftist Overthrows Seychelles Leader
description: VICTORIA, Seychelles, June 5The proWestern Government of President James R. M. Mancham was overthrown today by rebels led by the leftist Prime Minister of these Indian Ocean islands.

title: Opposition Takes an Early Lead in Turkish Election But Its Slim Margin Points to Search for Coalition
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Monday, June 6The Republican Peoples Party held a narrow lead today as returns came in from Turkey's national election, according to the national television network. If this trend holds, the Republicans, or social democrats, would not gain a decisive mandate and would be forced to form a coalition government.

title: RULES AT PARIS AIR SHOW TIGHTENED AFTER CRASH
description: PARIS, June 4 (AP)Paris Air and Space Show officials are tightening regulations governing flight demonstrations following the crash of an American A10 jet attack plane, the sixth fatal accident at the show in 12 years.

title: A British Jubilee Commemorates 25 Tough Years
description: LONDON, June 5On a February morning in 1952, Princess Elizabeth awoke at Treetops, the African game lodge, to find that she had become Queen Elizabeth II on the death of her father.

title: Nearby Horse Shows
description: AT NEW VERNON, N.J.

title: Seniority vs. Fairness
description: In considering the social impact of the Supreme Court's decision this week on seniority and job discriminationand the immediate dismay it provokedit is useful to be quite clear about what the Court actually did and did not decide. The Court did not repeal the provisions of the 1964 Civil Rights Act banning employment discrimination. Rather, it decided that some of that act's language created a specific exemption from the general policy embodied in the act. Hence, the direct effect of the decision is limited. The exemption applies only to some people in some jobs. Nevertheless, it will have some direct effect, and perhaps a larger indirect effect; both effects are troubling.

title: Soviet Actress Visiting Moscow
description: MOSCOW, June 5 (AP)  Victoria Fyodorova, the actress, returned to Moscow this weekend for a reunion with her mother and friends, two years after leaving to live in the United States. Her mother, Zoya, greeted Victoria and her American husband, Frederick Pouy, and the couple's yearold son, Christopher. She married Mr. Puoy after she had gone to the United States to meet her American father, Adm. Jackson R. Tate, whom she had never seen.

title: BIAGGI GIVES HINTS HE WILL ENTER RACE
description: Describing, himself as unscathed and undaunted by the accusations that derated his mayoral compaign four years ago, Representative Mario Biaggi hinted to 700 supporters at a luncheon yesterday that he was about to make another citywide race.

title: Priests From Japan Conduct Service at Ground Breaking
description: SOMERSET, June 5In an ancient religious ceremony of prayer, hymns, chants and the striking of bells and gongs, seven Buddhist priests from Japan conducted groundbreaking services here today for new construction at the Takara Belmont Company.

title: Annie Sweeps 7 Tonys;Shadow Box Named Top Play
description: Annie, Broadway's darling and everybody's favorite waif, was named best musical of 1977 and swept six other Tony awards last night as the New York theater establishment gathered at the Shubert Theater to honor what everyone says has been the best season in years

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two Newark firemen were injured yesterday when the third floor of burnedout building collapsed soon after the fire was extinguished, authorities said.

title: Leftist Overthrows Seychelles Leader
description: VICTORIA, Seychelles, June 5The proWestern Government of President James R. M. Mancham was overthrown today by rebels led by the leftist Prime Minister of these Indian Ocean islands.

description: Week ended June 3, 1977

title: New Rules to Speed Up Evening Traffic To Queensboro Bridge Start Tomorroo
description: New York City announced yesterday new traffic regulations that are intended to reduce evening rushhour congestion for Manhattan motorists headed for the Queensboro Bridge. The regulations will go into effect tomorrow and will be enforced weekday evenings between 4 and 7 o'clock.

title: Chicago Votes Tomorrow for Mayor To Fill Daley's Unexpired Term
description: CHICAGO, June 5Voters in the country second largest city will choose as their Mayor Tuesday either a Democrat who promised not to run for the office if given the post of Acting Mayor or a young Republican who seconded the Democrat's nomination as Acting Mayor

title: Advertising End to the PlayboyPenthouse War
description: The PlayboyPenthouse circulation war is over, at least as far as Playboy is concerned.

title: FORMER AIDE TO PARK ASSAILS U.S. DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, June 5A former senior political and military leader in South Korea has entered the controversy over the withdrawal of American ground forces there, criticizing both President Park Chung Hee and President Carter.

title: BEIRUT'S CENSORSHIP HOBBLES THE PRESS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 5The other night there were rumors of fighting in the streets of the Christian eastern part of Beirut and of a bomb explosion in the Moslem western sector. They were only rumors, but many people believed that, something happened that night because press censorship bars reports on such incidents as matters of security.

title: Production by G.M. and Chrysler Is Threatened by Labor Disputes
description: DETROIT, June 5 (UPI)Nearly one year after contract negotiations opened with the United Automobile Workers, the General Motors and Chrysler Corporations still are plagued with labor disputes disrupting what could be record production schedules this summer.

description: Bruno George Ronty, a Polishborn artist who once sang leading roles at Moscow's Bolshoi Theater and whose career was subsequently interrupted for 20 years by injuries received during World War II, made a belated first appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday night.

description: NORTH AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Califano Asks Goals Not Quotas On Minority Students in Colleges
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday that the Federal Government must rely on numerical goals to monitor college and university efforts to recruit and help minoritygroup students.

description: CAROL STEWART, pianist, and JAN SCHMIDT, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8.

title: Amin Asserts Defector Embezzled Funds
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 5 (AP)President Idi Amin of Uganda says the Health Minister who defected to Britain with reports of mass killings in Uganda had channeled Government funds into a very fat bank account abroad.

title: Antique Fire Equipment Snarls and Puffs Its Way to Museum
description: Antique Fire Equipment Snarls and Puffs Its Way to Museum

title: CARTER ASKED TO BAN SALE OF COMPUTER TO RUSSIANS
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)At least 65 Congressman have urged President Carter to ban the sale of the advanced Cyber 76 computer, manufactured by the Control Data Systems Corporation, to the Soviet Union for fear it will add to Soviet military strength.

description: The Internal Revenue Service has begun a broad investigation of amateur athletes who conceal income and thereby avoid payment of taxes, according to a report in Time magazine.

title: To Sixth Graders, Politics Equal Tax
description: WILLINGBORO, N.J., June 5 (UPI)What is uppermost in the minds of sixth graders when the subject is politics? The income tax, of course.

title: Jack Dweck Weds Shari A. Koslowe
description: Shari Ann Koslowe, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Irving Koslowe of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Jack Dweck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Dweck of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed in the Westchester Jewish Center by the bride's father, who is the center's spiritual leader. He was assisted by Rabbis Zvulun Lieberman of Brooklyn, Ezra Labaton of Boston, Herman J. Zwillenberg, Isaac Dweck, a cousin of the bridegroom, and Cantor Abraham Veroba.

title: Music: Skulte
description: Bruno Skulte's symphonic poem Daugava, performed for the first time at Sunday afternoon's Bruno Skulte Memorial Concert at Alice Tully Hall, is a stirring patriotic epic so traditional in concept and execution that it might have been composed a century ago.

description: N.Y.Y.C. 123d REGATTA

title: Market Place
description: The news could hardly be worse for shareholders of Cook Industries, the beleaguered grain conglomerate. Two top officials have recently resigned under fire after exceeding the company's grain tradirig limits and, presumably, being partly responsible for losses totaling $87 million for the fiscal year ended last month.

title: Books of The Times
description: It has been William Safire's profession, since 1973, to offend the liberal pieties of our readers twice a week on the OpEd Page of The New York Times. Before that, he was a senior speech writer in the White House of Richard M. Nixon. And before that, he was a successful public relations man. (Indeed, in his first book, The Relations Explosion, a very entertaining chapter is devoted to how he set up the notorious NixonKhrushchev kitchen debate. His client at the time was the model kitchen.) Whether or not you choose, then, to consider Full Disclosure Mr. Safire's first work of fiction will depend on how much he has managed to hurt your feelings in the past.

title: OneMan Police Patrol Cars Are Safer, More Efficient, Foundation Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 5A studysponsored by the Police Foundation concludes that one police officer in a patrol car is more efficient, safer and at least as effective as the usual twoofficer patrol.

title: Mrs. Carter Doing Well on Tour, But the Toughest Part Lies Ahead
description: SANTA CLARA, Peru June 5Midway in her diplomatic mission to the Caribbean and Latin America, Rosalynn Carter is poised between the clear successes of the past week and the tougher challenges she is likely to face in the coming one.

title: Reborn Nightclub on Coast Shuns Glitter, Now Rocks to a Gospel Beat
description: BEVERLY HILLS, CalifThe Daisy, which bloomed in 1962 as this area's first private discothque because its founder said celebrities needed someplace evil to go, wilted after a decade and became a health food lunch house.

title: Vilas Trounces Gottfried For First Big 4 Victory.
description: PARIS, June 5Determined to shed the tag of Eternal Second that had become his personal albatross, Guillermo Vilas of Argentina blitzed Brian Gottfried, 60, 63, 60, today for the French open singles title in weather more suited for football than tennis.

title: QuarterHorse Betting Curb Held Unfair
description: YAPHANK, L.I., June 5Ron Parr, head of Parr Meadows, where Sunday quarterhorse racing was introduced today, complained this afternoon about what he termed unfair treatment from the state and New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: NORTON OPTIMISTIC ON E.E.O.C.'S GOALS
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. which has treated its leadership over the last 12 years as the French once treated their governments, welcomes Eleanor Holmes Norton tomorrow as its new head.

title: Effective WagePrice Policy Still White House Objective
description: The mood of investors brightened at the end of last week in response to better news about both inflation and Unemployment. The wholesale price index, which had been climbing at doubledigit rates from February through April, rose by only; 0.4 percent in May4.8 percent at an annual rate. And the unemployment rate dipped to 6.9 percent, the first time it has been below 7 percent in the last two and a half years. Even better; the total number of people with jobs climbed to a record of 90,408,000.

title: Bridge
description: A quintet of stars from Westchester County and New Jersey battled with a strong New England squad in the zonal final of the Grand National Team Championship at the Sheraton Motor Inn at 42d Street and 12th Avenue in Manhattan yesterday. WestchesterNew Jersey led by 31 international match points at the halfway mark, but New England stormed back to lead by 27 points after 48 deals, with 16 more to go.

title: Attica: Who's in Charge?
description: An argument now raging among the New York State Department of Correctional Services, the Attica corrections officers union and the State Commission on Corrections may strike some as a lot of WhostruckJohn?. But who struck Albert McQueen in Attica prison on July 11, 1976, and why, and under what circumstancesand why don't we know eleven months after the eventare questions of great consequence to the way the prison system functions in t his state.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, June 5 (Reuters)The Rhodesian Government announced today that the frontier town of Kariba, a popular resort on the northeastern neck of Lake Kariba, had been shelled last night, without a doubt from Zambia. The announcement turned attention in this country's guerrilla war against black African nationalists from the southeast to the northwest.

title: Rum + Vodka + Irish = Fight
description: NOTRE DAME, Incl., June 5A card on the breakfast table recommended a Fighting Irish cocktail. Perhaps recommended is the wrong word. The card merely announced that the confection was available at $2.50 (souvenir glass $1.75). I'd like orange juice, a guest said, pancakes, crisp bacon and coffee. But first, what is a Fighting Irish cocktail? All right, the waitress said. One shot of rum, one shot of vodka, half a shot of Galiano, about this much orange juice and some green food coloring. There was a respectful silence. Then: Thank God it's Sunday and you can't serve me one. I've never tasted one, the waitress said, but anybody I ever served one never asked for another. This was in the Holiday Inn about three furlongs from the campus the road to Niles, Mich. Six days a week the Fighting Irish and other refreshments are available here in Gippers Lounge, a shrine dedicated to the memory of George Gipp, the patron saint of football and eightball pool at Notre Dame. Walls of the lounge are covered with photographic blowups of football plays and players. Three dominate the decor: behind the bar stands the Gipper himself, half again larger than life, wearing the soft leather headgear and canvas pants favored by allAmerica halfbacks around 1920; at his right is a huge head shot of Frank Leahy, the late, great coach; at Gipp's left, Harry Stuhldreher, Jim Crowley, Elmer Layden and Don Miller sit astride four plow horses. The riders wear football regalia with cowled woolen windbreakers, and each has a football tucked under an arm.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SOUND YOUR B Two series of openreading choral evenings start tonight in Greenwich Village, both led by prominent conductors, with supplied scores and postperformance gettogethers for singing guests and musicians. The older West Willage Chorale is featuring Brahms's Requiem, conducted by Harry Saltzman, at 7:30 P.M. at St. Luke's Chapel, Hudson and Grove Streets. The tab is $2, and $1 for the elderly.

title: Blazers Win Title, Beating 76ers by 109107
description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 5The Philadelphia 76ers finally came out of their trance today, but the Portland Trail Blazers rose to the challenge and held them off in a 109107 victory that gave them the National Basketball Association championship.

title: Article 2  No Title

title: Relative of the Gandhis Is Found Shot in Head
description: NEW DELHI, June 5 (Reuters)The body of Sanjay Gandhi's fatherinlaw, Lieut. Col. T.S. Anand, who was found shot dead near his farm yesterday, was cremated today.

title: WARD MELVILLE, 90, SHOE MAGNATE,DIES
description: Ward Melville, the guiding force behind the development of the Melville Corporation and the originator of the Thom McAn name, had a world of interests outside of his halfbilliondollar shoe business.

title: Peruvian Girl, 13, Fights to Stay in U.S. With a Long Island Couple
description: Isabel carrasco an illegal alien, excused herself to have some milk and cookies yesterday in the kitchen at 18 Hawthorne Lane in Valley Stream, L.I. Since she arrived there on a visit at the age of 9, the sixroom house has been home to the slender 13yearold Peruvian.

title: Signet Program Won By Benton &Bowles
description: Benton & Bowles, having beaten out 14 other agencies, has been named by Interbank to handle the new Signet electronic funds transfer program. The planned budget for the first year is $1.8 million.

title: Kingman's Slide and Clout Help Mets Take Pair; Yankees Defeat White Sox, 86, With 6 Homers
description: Dave Kingman, whose nosebreaking slide helped the Mets win the first game in 10 innings, hit a threerun homer for all the New York runs in the second game of a sweep of the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday.

title: SOVIETAMERICAN DEBATE ON RIGHTS SET BY NBCTV
description: A RussianAmerican debate on human rights will be televised live Sunday from 1:30 to 3 P.M. on Channel 4 by NBC News. The topic will be What is the appropriate role of human rights in SovietAmerican relations?

title: Jeweler and His Wife Kidnapped In West Virginia, Slain in Tennessee
description: JACKSBORO, Tenn.,June 5 (UPI)A West Virginia jeweler and his wife were abducted and robbed of $176,000 in jewels, then taken to Tennessee where they were bound and slain, officials said yesterday.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, June 6 (UPI)In an effort to forestall new unrest in the Basque region, the Government today, flew two Basque guerillas serving jail sentences to exile in Norway.

title: Kensil, Top N.F.L. Aide, Named President of Jets
description: The New York Jets yesterday selected Jim Kensil, the man Pete Rozelle calls my offensive and defensive coordinator, to run the club as its new president and chief operating officer.

title: YOUNG BACKING OFF ON RACIST CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Andrew Young said today that, in describing Gerald R. Ford and Richard M. Nixon as racists, I certainly didn't mean anything derogatory about the personal lives of either.

title: Mrs. Carter Is Given a LowKey Welcome in Brazil
description: BRASILIA, June 6Rosalynn Carter received a brief, lowkey welcome today in a city troubled by student unrest, capital of a country whose relations with the United States remain strained.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Twentyseven of 36 medical specialistsincluding nine out of 11 department headsquit at the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, the only hospital in Hunterdon County. The resignations, effective tomorrow, came over a requirement that doctors at the hospital work fulltime and not maintain their own practices elsewhere in the county. They indicated that they were willing to take care of patients at the hospital while practicing outside, but there was no word whether they would be allowed access to the hospital.

title: Around the Nation
description: RICHMOND, June 6 (AP)Gov Mills E. Godwin today partly lifted a ban on crab harvesting in the Keponecontaminated James River and simultaneously imposed a new fishing ban in three western Virginia rivers because of mercury poisoning in fish.

title: Finley Says He'll Sue Kuhn
description: CHICAGO, June 6Charles O. Finley revealed today that he was preparing a new lawsuit against the basebal lcommissioner, Bowie Kuhn. The owner of the Oakland As refused to divulge the nature of the suit.He said also that he was appealing the verdict of an earlier suit in which.Kuhn was upheld in blocking the sale of three Oakland players.

title: Man Killed in Homemade Plan
description: OXFORD, Pa., June 6 (AP)A Chester County man was killed in the crash of his homemade experimental airplane about seven miles southwest of here near the Maryland border, the authorities said. The victim, John McIver, was reported to have been flying the single seat monoplane, which he had built and flown for several years.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMOWITZEvelyn. On June 5, 1977. Wife of Louis. Mother of Harold and Aaron. Grandmother of Jennifer. Services Midwood Chapel, Bklyn., Tuesday, 1:30 P.M.

title: People and Business
description: Margaret Greene, who joined the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1967, has been named a vice president, the first woman to reach this rank at the bank. She has been an assistant vice president in the New York Fed's foreign exchange department and will continue to have responsibility for foreign exchange operations at the bank.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 7, 1977

title: 20th Spoleto Season Will Open June 22
description: With the first Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S. C., having come to a successful conclusion, its parent organization, the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, has announced plans for its 20th season.

title: Cree Indians on a Canadian Island Are Facing Disruption
description: FORT GEORGE, Quebec . This Cree Indian community, one of the largest in northern Quebec, may soon be moving from its island in the mouth of La Grande River as the white man's world crowds in on it.

title: Police Agree on Rights Of Onlookers at Arrests
description: The city's Police Department and the New York Civil Liberties Union have come to an agreement specifying that onlookers at police actions can take pictures, write down the badge numbers of police officers and make comments without being subjected to harassment or arrest.

title: Big Board Options Bid Covers Puts
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a detailed plan to begin trading in options, including a request that it be allowed to offer the latest in the options market the put option.

title: Beame's School Plan Gets Mixed Reviews
description: mayor Beame's proposal to replace the Board of Education with an education commissioner met with mixed reaction yesterday at the Mayor's first day of hearings on the proposal.

description: For periods ended April 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) OvertheCounter

title: 100 Bonfires Mark Elizabeth's Jubilee
description: LONDON, June 6Queen Elizabeth II inaugurated a weeklong celebration of her silver jubilee on the British throne tonight by lighting a 30foot bonfire on a hill near Windsor Castle.

title: U. S. TO PRESS SOVIET ON HELSINKI ACCORDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States, at an EastWest review conference later this year, would urge the Soviet Union and its allies to carry out all provisions of the Helsinki accords, including the controversial human rights clauses.

title: KATHLEEN C. O'SHEA
description: Kathleen C. O'Shea, a former instructor at Finch College and the wife of James C. O'Shea, the New York State Commissioner of General Services, died Sunday at the Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo. She was 62 years old and lived in Rome, N.Y.

title: Frank Thompson, Top Designer Of Costumes for Stage and Ballet
description: Frank Thompson, a leading costume designer, died Saturday at St. John's Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 56 years old.

title: Loft Jazz Festival Ends on a Popular Note
description: The idea that the music played in New York's jazz lofts is necessarily experimental or avantgarde was effectively exploded by the activities on Sunday at the Ladies Fort, 2 Bond Street, the last day of the New York Loft Jazz Celebration.

title: Crucial Primaries in Jersey Today
description: Candidates for the Democratic and Republican gubernatorial nominations in New Jersey spent their final primary campaign moments yesterday looking for the few votes they believed could mean the difference today in what is likely to be the two close contests.

title: An Unlikely Celebrity. Scoffs At Commercialism
description: After George Willig's walk up the side of the 1.350foot South Tower of the World Trade Center last May 26, a television news reporter looked him in the eye and asked, What's your angle. anyhow?

title: Cristofer a Winning Workaholic
description: Michael Cristofer looked remarkably wide awake yesterday for a man who had been up all night celebrating, after his play, The Shadow Box, won, the Tony award Sunday night as best play of the year.

title: Rhodesia Guerrillas Interrupt Service On Major Rail Link
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 6 (AP)The Government reported today that black nationalist guerrillas blew up a bridge last night on Rhodesia's major rail link to South Africa, forcing a ninehour halt in service.

title: What's What in Who's Who
description: On the theory that everybody is somebody, publishers of the world are churning out Who's Whos at an allinclusive rate.

title: HOUSING AID TO POOR TRIMMED BY SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)The Senate trimmed $123 million from Federal housing assistance for lowincome families today as it began debate on a $14.7 billion authorization bill for housing and community development.

title: Belmont Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan announced yesterday that the nowcompleted search of the rubble of the Everard Baths at 28 West 28th Street had turned up no additional victims of the fire that killed nine men in the early morning of May 25. The Fire Department also said its records showed that the Everard Baths was one of only 10 such establishments operating in the city, all of them in midtown Manhattan. According to a spokesman, the nine others have been reinspected since the fire.

title: Yale Study for 5 Journalists
description: NEW HAVEN, June 6 (AP)Five journalists have beer. awarded Ford Foundation fellowships for one year's work at the Yale Law School leading to a degree of Master of Studies in Law. They at Pamela Bullard of WGBHTV, Boston; Stephen Cook of The San Francisco Examiner; Linda Greenhouse, The New York Times; Elissa Papirno, The Hartford Courant, and Miranda Spivack, The Port land (Me.) PressHerald.
