title: Film: Gutman's Wit And World War I
description: THE MARCH ON PARIS 1914of Generaloberst Alexander von Kluck  and His Memory of Jessie Holladay," which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is the wittiest, most appealing film yet made by Walter Gutman, the stock-market analyst, art critic and patron, painter, philosopher and lover of beauty who, at 74, is one of the more exuberant of independent American filmmakers.In his program notes for the film, Mr. Gutman would have us believe that the making of the movie was really just an excuse to take a trip to France last summer in the company of Jessie Holladay Duane, whom he describes as "a beautiful young woman who, curse the fates, is a half century younger than me (sic). . . ." Don't you believe it. The film is much more complicated than that.It's a meditation on loveidealized sexual love, love of war and Mr. Gutman's own love of the beautiful women he appreciates with the intensity of an obsessed collector. The form of the film is free, almost haphazard, though sophisticated in its intent.The inspiration is a book written by Alexander von Kluck (whose name prompts some Gutman jokes), the German general who led the advance on Paris in 1914 and who was turned back at the outskirts of Paris by, among other things, the "taxicab army."It is Mr. Gutman's fantasy that von Kluck, some years before 1914, met and had an idyllic affair with a young American woman (Miss Duane) as he was reconnoitering the northeastern French countryside disguised as a painter. The film cuts back and forth between scenes of this affair, chastely mimed and set with no embarrassment at all in contemporary landscapes and scenes detailing von Kluck's drive on Paris, complete with military maps and lengthy quotations from von Kluck's memoirs.Did von Kluck fail because he was bemused by memories of his lost love as he drove his armies through France toward Paris? Probably not. I don't think that's the sort of thing that would appeal to Mr. Gutman's sense of history, though at one point he suggests that the American Civil War could have been over in two years if the Union's Gen. Winfield Scott Hancock had not made the unfortunate decision to go on the wagon. Hancock without booze, says Mr. Gutman, lacked the necessary boldness. Von Kluck was not a great general, drunk or sober.In "The March on Paris" Mr. Gutman is not especially concerned with causes and effects. Mostly he is recalling for us his feelings about the war he remembers as a little boy, a war, he says, almost crossly, that few people know anything about any more. He evokes those feelings in still photographs, newsreel footage and drawings, and especially in the recurring images of Miss Duane, whose dark-haired beauty, by seeming so fresh, immediately suggests something so impermanent that it must already have disappeared in the time it took to process the film.Miss Duane is a far cry from earlier Gutman hercinesthe aggressive circus performers and "strong" women he so lovingly presented in films such as "The Graps-Picker's Daughter" and "Unstrap Me." When he photographs her walking through a wheat field, chest-high, we see her as the director doesdesirable, ripe, but also a bit self-conscious, squinting into the sun, quite puzzled about the project she has somehow become a part of."The March on Paris 1914" is most personal, original and charming, the best film by far in the Whitney's current season.

title: Preservation: A 1921 House

But here in Los Angeles, the past does not go back that farthis city's heritage comes almost exclusively from the 20th century. A lot of the buildings worth saving here are not only 20th century but are modern oneslike the R. M. Schindler House, a lowlying structure of concrete and Wood that has been sitting on Kings Road in West Hollywood since 1921.

The British rock quartet, which opened a run of six longsincesoldout shows at Madison Square Garden last night. makes a monstrously loud, deliberately abrasive kind of music far removed not only from the sweet rustlings of classical music, jazz and Tin Pan Alley, but even from the tuneful, rhythmicaliy en?vening rock songs of the 1960's.

title: No Place for Idi Amin
description: If doubts still lingered about the murderous nature of Idi Amin's regime, they should have been resolved by the disclosures of Uganda's former Minister of Health, Henry Kyemba, after his recent defection in London. Mr. Kyemba told an interviewer that he saw the bulletriddled bodies of the Anglican Archbishop, Jonan Luwuum, and two Ugandan Cabinet ministers, whose deaths in captivity last February Mr. Amin attributed to an automobile accident. They had been shot at very close range several times. Mr. Kyemba also gave a harrowing description of 73yearold Dora Bloch, one of the ElAl hostages at Entebbe, being dragged screaming from her hospital bed by Ugandan security men and later murdered, to satisfy President Amin's lust for vengeance for the Israeli raid.

description: AMERICANS are obsessed with hair. They spend $600million annually on shampoo and the shelves of an average drugstore can display as many as 200 different bottles and tubes. There are shampoos for babies and teenagers, for dry hair and oily hair, for hair with dandruff, for long hair and short hairfor virtually every condition except no hair.

title: Schoolboy Scouted by Veeck First Player Chosen in Draft
description: A player first scouted in Little League by their owner was selected and signed by the Chicago White Sox yesterday as the top pick in baseball's annual summer freeagent draft.

title: People and Business
description: Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps told a Congressional committee yesterday that President Carter is preparing to set up an interdepartmental task force to examine what the Federal Government can do to encourage women in business.

title: West German Payments Deficit Up
description: FRANKFURT, June 7 (UPI)West Germany recorded a $373 million balance of payments deficit in April, the Bundesbank reported today. This represented a turnabout compared with the March surplus of $299 million, but was lower than the $645 million deficit in April 1976. During the first four months of 1977, West Germany's balance of payments remained $125 million in the red.

title: PEABODY DIVESTITURE BY KENNECOTT SALE IS APPROVED BY F. T. C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission unanimously approved yesterday the Kennecott Copper Corporation's plan to sell its Peabody Coal Company subsidiary for $1.2 billion in cash and securities. This would be the largest divestiture of a single company ever forced by the Government.

title: Shops and Banks in Seychelles Reopen After the Weekend Coup
description: VICTORIA, Seychelles, June 7 (Reuters) Shops and banks reopened today in the Seychelles and tourists ventured out in the streets for the first time since the coup on Sunday that overthrew President James R.M. Mancham.

title: The Labor Scene
description: A. H. Raskin discusses the fight of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union against sweatshops overseas. No American union has been harder it by the jobkilling competition of imports from countries where wages are low. Page D5.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The petition said that Honda, Yamaha, Kawasaki and Suzuki, the Japanese manufacturers, are selling motorcycles here at prices as much as 58 percent below those being charged for the same motorcycles in Japan and Europe. Such practices are prohibited by the Antidumping Act of 1921, HarleyDavidson said.

title: Witcom Uncovers Overbillings
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The Witcom Chemical Corporation has uncovered $765,000 of customer overbillings and $415,000 of commissions paid to agents in countries other than the one in which they operated, a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosd today. The New Yorkbased company, which said its investigation covered the years 1972 through 1976, also reimbursed employees for small domestic political contributions totaling $650.

title: A New Delay In Selection of N. H. L. Head
description: MONTREAL, June 7The National Hockey League's board of governors was ready today to name 42yearold John A. Ziegler Jr. as the new league president, but a constitutional technicality prevented the announcement from being made until June 22, when the board meets in Chicago.

title: Fuqua Expected to Lift Its Offer For Avis Stock From $15.50 a Share
description: Fuqua Industries Inc., the Atlantabased leisuretime conglomerate, indicated yesterday that it expected to make a new offer for 47 percent of the shares of Avis Inc. A spokesman declined to indicate what the new offer would be.

title: State Says 18% of New York City's Welfare Clients Are Not Eligible
description: The New York State Welfare Inspector General, Richard V. Horan, said yesterday that a new study indicated that 18 percent of those receiving welfare in New York City were ineligible and that 19 percent of eligible benficiaries were overpaid. He estimated annual welfare losses at $244 million.

title: MARTIN I. ROSE, LAWYER AND MEDIATOR, WAS 73
description: Martin I. Rose, labor lawyer and mediator, died Sunday at University Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 279 East 44th Street.

title: Daley Machine Scores Sweeping Victory for Bilandic in Mayoral Race
description: CHICAGO, June 7Michael A. Bilandic, Acting Mayor of Chicago since the death last December of Mayor Richard J. Daley, scored an impressive victory today in a special election to fill the remaining two years of the late Mayor's term.

title: HarleyDavidson Accuses Japan Of Dumping Motorcycles in U.S.
description: The HarleyDavidson Motor Company, the only American maker of motorcycles, filed a petition yesterday with the United States Treasury Department accusing Japanese motorcycle manufacturers of illegally dumping hundreds of thousands of motorcycles in this country. HaleyDavidson is a subsidiary of AMF Inc.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, June 8, 1977

title: Article 5  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Albany Alters Plans for Controversial Hatchery
description: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has decided to build a controversial $11 million fish hatchery near Lake Ontario, but with drastically modified plans.

title: Notes on People
description: Ablack woman from Texas, Azie T. Morton, was nominated by President Carter yesterday to be Treasurer of the United States. The appointment continued a tradition begun by President Harry S. Truman, which has resulted in all treasurers being women, but Mrs. Morton is the first black to hold the post.

title: Chilled Cherry Soup
description: 1. Simmer together for 20 minutes the raisins, orange and lemon slices, lemon juice, cinnamon stick and water. Remove the cinnamon stick.

title: Some States Going Beyond Laetrile To Legalize Unlicensed Substances
description: To bypass Federal regulations that prohibit the sale of drugs with unproved medicinal values, several states in recent weeks have gone beyond laetrile to legalize the manufacture and sale of a variety of unlicensed substances.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Celtics Sign Heinsohn To New Multiyear Pact
description: BOSTON, June 7 (AP)Coach Tommy Heinsohn signed a new multiyear contract with the Boston Celtics today, the National Basketball Association announced. Terms of the contract were not disclosed, but Heinsohn was reported to be seeking a threeyear contract calling for $100,000 annually.

title: The Quality of Federal Justice
description: A recent report to this newspaper well conveyed the irony of political events. It began: The Senate passed tonight a bill to create 148 new Federal judgeships, which would ease the burden on the judiciary and provide patronage for Senate Democrats and President Carter.

title: Hartford Votes Legislators a Raise
description: HARTFORD, June 7  Connecticut legislators gave final approval today to a bill that would raise their pay for a twoyear term from $13,000 to $17,000.

title: TaxExempt Sector Easily Absorbs Sale of New Issues
description: The taxexempt bond market handled its unusually heavy schedule of newissue sales yesterday with an impressive amount of strength, holding interest rates from rising and yet attracting investors. Four statesCalifornia, Georgia. West

title: Agreement on C.I.A. Material
description: WASHINGTON, June 7Agreements have been negotiated between the Central Intelligence Agency and the House ethics committee for delivery of classified material the C.I.A. has compiled on alleged influence buying by South Korea, according to a report the committee has made to the House.

title: 8% in New York State on Relief
description: One of every 12 persons in New York State was getting welfare aid last year1,484,144 people in the average month, or 8.21 percent of the population. Relief costs took 1.66 percent of the state's personal income, or $2.12 billion of the total $128.39 billion.

title: Touche Ross Gets S.E.C. Subpoenas
description: In an initiative that has upset two of the nation's most prominent public accounting firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission has subpoenaed the confidential workpapers of Touche Ross & Company, one of the two firms, and asked a Federal court to compel Touche Ross to produce the documents.

title: Advertising
description: As more and more regional ad agencies are acquired by the big New Yorkbased national shops seeking growth without conflict problems, one wonders what impact this is having on the local scene. Does having a big, ?ellknown parent in the Big Apple make you tougher competition down home?

title: JEWS IN U.S. SEEKING UNITY BEHIND BEGIN
description: WASHINGTON, June 7  American Jews have been going through weeks of soulsearching over the victory of Menahem Begin in last month's Israeli elections and the likelihood that his rightwing Likud bloc would predominate in the next Israeli Government.

title: Reichhold Prices Up
description: Reichhold Chemicals Inc. said it was increasing the price of all coating resins containing soybean oil and glycerine by 1 cent to 2 cents a pound. Prices of resins with chinawood oil will be increased by 3 cents to 10 cents a pound. The increases are effective June 20.

title: Tablets to Go in Safer Packages
description: WASHINGTON, June 7 (Reuters)The Bristol Myers Company has agreed to replace 150.000 packages of its 225 and 375 Excedrin analgesic tablet sizes with new packages that cannot be opened by children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

title: Meadowlands
description: Hoses listed in order of Post positions

title: C. C. (Jim) Randolph Leaves McGrawHill
description: Charles C. (Jim) Randolph, a group vice president at McGrawHill Publications and a former publisher of Business Week, resigned from the corporation yesterday, a spokesman said.

title: U.S. Wins Suit Against Hunts as Court Backs Curb on Futures Holdings
description: The Government won a signal victory yesterday in its suit against the oilrich Hunt family for exceeding legal limits on holdings of commodity futures contracts when a Federal judge in Chicago ruled that such ceilings were valid.

title: U.S. Said to Bar Sale of 250 Jets Ordered by Iran
description: WASHINGTON, June 7The Administration has decided against selling 250 fighter planes to Iran, according to Government sources.

title: Letters
description: Checking Passport Agency

title: Hartford Welfare Work Law Greeted With Caution
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 7The mandatory work program for selected welfare recipients passed by the General Assembly in Hartford last night was received with caution by the head of this city's Welfare Department.

title: 1,492 Princetonians Given Degrees In Ceremony Marked by Tradition
description: PRINCETON, June 7Blending a reverence for tradition with levity and good spirits, Princeton University today conferred degrees on 1,492 members of the class of 1977 at its 230th commencement outside Nassau Hall.

title: Mrs. Carter Keeps Stress on Rights
description: BRASILIA, June 7Rosalynn Carter said today that she was not minimizing the topic of human rights in her talks with leaders of Brazil, a country whose relations with the United States have been strained over that subject.

title: Bache Halsey Names Loeb, Rhoades in Suit
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Inc. filed a $5 million punitive damage suit here yesterday against Loeb, Rhoades & Company charging Loeb, Rhoades with illegally enticing top salesmen away from Bache branch offices in New Orleans and Orlando, Fla. Bache and Loeb, Rhoades are among the top 10 brokerage houses in the country.

title: 370 PRISONERS ARE LISTED ON DEATH ROW IN 19 STATES
description: A total of 370 persons are now under sentence of death in the United States, 178 of them white and 178 black, according to a deathrow census released yesterday by the National Coalition Against the Death Penalty. Thirteen other persons awaiting execution are Hispanic and one is an American Indian. Prisoners are awaiting execution in 19 states.

title: A. H. Raskin
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla.No American union is richer in tradition than the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, born of immigrants in the sweatshops of the Lower East Side at the turn of the century. Today the union's fight against the sweatshops has turned overseas. No American union has been harder hit by the jobkilling competition of lowwage imports.

title: Eritrea Rebels, Expecting Victory, Seek to Set Up a New Social Order
description: NAKFA, Ethiopia (AP)In the 11 weeks since insurgents captured this northern Eritrean town, they have turned it and the nearby area into a center for the instruction of thousands in new skills.

title: Arsenal Seeks 817 to Fill Jobs In Transfer to Center in Jersey
description: DOVER, N.J., June 7 (UPI)About 65 families have moved from Philadelphia to this Morris County community, bringing to 560 the number of persons transferred from Frankford Arsenal to Picatinny Arsenal to work in a new Army command headquarters.

title: Miami Votes 2 to 1 to Repeal Law Barring Bias Against Homosexuals
description: MIAMI, June 7In a decision almost certain to have national impact, residents of the Miami area voted by a margin of more than 2to1 today to repeal a law that protects homosexuals from discrimination in employment, housing and public accommodation.

title: Jersey P.U.C. Aides Scored on Trip Costs
description: NEWARK, June 7 (UPI)Joel R. Jacobson, the president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, has forbidden his staff to make overnight trips to conventions.

title: About Real Estate
description: The Palace Hotel, a temporal cathedral that will rise 56 stories on New York Archdiocese land behind the Villard Houses on Madison Avenue, is nearing realization.

title: CARTER'S FORMER PASTOR ACCEPTS POST IN HAWAII
description: PLAINS, Ga., June 7 (AP)The Rev. Bruce Edwards, former pastor of President Carter's hometown Baptist church, said today that he had accepted a post with a church in Hawaii.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: DR. JOSEPH RICH
description: PLYMOUTH, Conn., June 7Dr. Joseph Rich, who was an obstetrical and gynecological clinical director of Flushing Hospital in Queens and the president in 1958 of the Queens Gynecological Society, died Monday in Bristol Hospital, following a long illness.

title: Market Place
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation, a construction company organized by a minorleague pitcher who parlayed offseason carpentry work in Phoenix into a major business a generation ago, now has interests in shopping centers, office buildings, hotels, retirement communities and gambling casinos.

title: Red Cross Checking on Prisons
description: GENEVA, June 7 (Reuters)Delegates from the International Committee of the Red Cross have visited prisoners in Portugal, Paraguay, Iran, Thailand and Yemen in the last few weeks to inspect the conditions under which they are being held, the committee announced today. In its monthly bulletin, the committee said that a group of delegates, including doctors, was now visiting prisons in the eastern and western provinces of Iran after inspecting five detention centers in Teheran.

title: TV: On the Scene, From Pirouettes to Prizes to Pomp
description: CERTAIN TELEVISION buffs have a standard routine that involves getting a bit mistyeyed when the subject turns to live presentations. The phenomenon is relegated to the good old days. to some golden age when, supposedly, classy programming was given the added dimension of spontaneity. The element of distorting sentimentality in this nostalgia is thick enough to be cut with an antenna.

title: Careers
description: While the stock market has been nothing to write home about of late, investment houses doing business there may well be promising places for securitiesminded men and women seeking career oportunities.

title: Western Electric Lifts Bell Prices 1.2 Percent
description: The Western Electric Company, a unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Compny, announced an overall increase of 1.2 percent in prices paid by the Bell System companies for products manufactured by Western Electric, effective July 1.

title: A Legal Guide To Cohabitation
description: JEANLOUIS HYMS, who comes from Paris, and Carole Goldberg, who comes from the Bronx, have been sharing a loft in Soho for more than a year now. He calls her my fiance and she calls him my lover, but they do not plan to marry. Today, as they see it, there are only two real reasons to marry: religion and children. Having neither, they chose to live in unconnubial bliss.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: LAST AUTUMN during a brief visit to Belgium we chanced to stop in a little known restaurant outside Brussels. It was a small place and generally undis tinguished, but we were tempted by one dish that the owner, a gentlemas from Liege, told us was his own creation and a specialty of the house. don't recall his name, but the dish I remember well. Perhaps all the more so be cause it is reminiscent of a dish I've eaten in France called pork chops avesnoise.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption under a picture on Page 1 of The New York Times of May 24 identified color guards as belonging to the New York Maritime College. They were midshipmen of the United States Merchant Marine Academy.

title: Joint TimesCBS Poll Sampled 35 Districts
description: The poll conducted jointly by The New York Times and Channel 2 News (WCBSTV) is based on interviews with a random sampling of New Jersey voters as they left the polls yesterday. Thirtyfive election districts were sampled, and within each district, every voter had an equal chance of being interviewed.

title: Forest Hills Not Fazed by Loss of Open
description: Despite the shock of losing the United States Open after this year, the West Side Tennis Club says it is determined to see that Forest Hills does not die.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Front Page 2  No Title

title: Zimmerman Sets Senior Golf Pace
description: RYE, N.Y., June 7If any of their employees dared treat the captains of industry the way the Apawamis Club's golf course did today, they would all be out of work.

title: Suspect Accused of Defrauding Welfare Agency of Over $30,000
description: A man who allegedly defrauded the city's Department of Social Services of more than $30,000 in welfare payments by collecting benefits under six different names at seven different welfare centers was arrested yesterday, Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau announced.

title: Private Lives
description: IN A MONTH OR SO, he will be 15, which is absurd. I never intended him to be old enough to contemplate driving a car or applying to college. He was supposed to stay 8, or maybe 12. I examine him for stigmata of sullenness; no, merely the clouded look of afternoons with books, and, where the light collectsat the rims of his aviator glasses, in the braces on his teethsome fire. His feet are huge; I have ordered sevenleague boots.

title: Blue Jays Buy Rader
description: TORONTO, June 7(AP)The Toronto Blue Jays purchased the contract of Doug Rader from the San Diego Padres tonight. The 32yearold third baseman hit .269 in 52 games with the Padres this season. Last year, he batted .257, driving in 55 runs and hitting nine homers.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ;ONE night, says Mike Winship, I made the mistake of walking up Central Park West on the park side wearing a bright bumblebeelike orange and red windbreaker that made me stand out like a storm warning. I was approached by a panhandler, stooped and dusty, mumbling, with his hand out for spare change.

title: With Splendor and Affection, Britain Rejoices at the Queen's Silver Jubilee
description: HIGH WYCOMBE, England, June 7Buckinghamshire wore a smile today, and why not?

title: Phone Contract Talks Begun
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)Negotiators for the Chesepeake and Potomac Telephone Company and the Communications Workers of America began talks on a new labor contract today. The talks involve labor agreements for 30,758 employees in Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia and Washington.

title: Four Die in Nebraska Plane Crash
description: GORDON, Neb., June 8 (UPI)A small plane buzzed a farmhouse, failed to regain proper altitude, slammed into a 75foot deep gully and burst into flames last night, killing all four occupants.

title: Market Place
description: The Tandy Corporation, which has quietly compiled one of the strongest growth records in recent years among companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange, passed out disappointing news to shareholders this week.

title: Books of The Times
description: INCEST, I WAS informed by a publicity release the other day, is the next hot subject in popular fiction (coming, I believe, on the heels of vampirism). If incest it is, Twins, by Bari Wood and Jack Geasland is already well out of the starting gate in the trend sweepstakes. To be fair, although Twins does involve incest it is attempting a psychological exploration of an obsessive bond between the twins of the title, rather than exploiting their sex lives.

title: NEW &
description: Joy Nagy has been walking around the city for years looking at buildings. One day she decided to put what she'd been seeing on placemats; they're now at Macy's in the housewares section of The Cellar. Line drawings of shops, restaurants, galleries and theaters, ranging from Chinatown to 125th Street, circle the placemats, in vinyl or paper. The vinyl mats white on a chocolatebrown background, are $3.50 each; the paper, brown on beige, $3.25 a dozen. Matching mugs are at $2.50.

title: About New York
description: In the night, the long white frock coat and plantation hat of the tall man gave him a shepherd's bearing as he stood in the light of a coffee shop and kept a proprietor's eye on the women standing on the corners hawking themselves to motorized streams of men.

title: MORE CONCERNS VYING FOR CONTROL OF AVIS
description: A tug of war for control of Avis Inc., the nation's second largest car rental company, appeared to be in the making yesterday. Two biddersNorton Simon Inc. and Fuqua Industrieshave already come forward and reports are circulating that others, including one offing. Industry sources, however, said the likelihood of the airline making an offer was doubtful.

title: Dignified and Efficient
description: LONDON, June 8Monarchy in Britain fulfills a public need for ritual: So the writers say, and every royal ceremony proves their point. Only a professional skeptic could fall to be moved a little by the medieval uniforms, the golden coach, the staffs and swords and heraldry.

title: Ellen Rose, Nurse, Married to Dr. Paul Scharf
description: Ellen Karoline Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Rose of Old Westbury, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Old Westbury Golf and Country Club to Dr. Paul Lloyd Scharf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Scharf of Roslyn, L.I., and Hallandale, Fla. Cantor David Benedict of Lawrence, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: Bomb in Paris Newspaper Office
description: PARIS, June 8 (Reuters)A parcel bomb exploded at the offices of the Trotskyist daily, Rouge, in suburban Montreuil today, causing widespread damage but no casualties, members of the newspaper staff said. A journalist who began to open the package saw smoke coming from it and threw himself to the ground seconds before the blast. Police bomb disposal experts said the device failed to explode completely because of a faulty fuse. They said it contained enough explosives to have gutted the entire building, which contains both the daily's editorial offices and printing plant.

title: Home Repair Q & A
description: Q. We have oilfired, hot , water heat and get our domestic hot water from a coil located inside the same boiler that provides our heat. When the house does not need heat we leave the oil burner switch off, turning it on only when we anticipate the need for hot water. Thus, our oil burner does not fire at all during the night, or during the day when no one is at home. Is there a reason we have never seen this recommended as a means of saving fuel and money?Mrs. H.E.E., North Babylon, L.I.

title: Companies Vying for Avis
description: Norton Simon Inc. and Fuqua Industries are vying for control of Avis Inc. amid reports that other offers are in the offing. Page D9.

title: Sports Today.
description: BASEBALL

title: Jersey Unit Scores Prosecutor In Passaic for Fixing Tickets
description: TRENTON, June 8 (UPI)the Passaic County prosecutor's office has been criticized by a state agency for having parking tickets that have been given to its staffers routinely dismissed.

title: Connecticut Assembly, at Its Close, Hailed as Most Significant in Years
description: HARTFORD, June 8The Connecticut General Assembly adjourned tonight, four hours before its midnight deadline, with leaders on both sides of the aisle calling the session the most productive one in many years.

title: Summer Food Plan Loses Sponsor
description: The New York City Board of Education voted last night to withdraw from the federally financed Summer Food Service Program, which would have provided free breakfasts and lunches for more than 100,000 needy children.

title: MEDTRONIC PROFITS UP 63% IN QUARTER
description: Medtronic, Inc., maker of implantable heart pacemakers and other electronic medical devices, reported yesterday a 63.3 percent rise in fiscal fourthquarter earnings and 11.5 percent for the fiscal year ended April 30.

title: Insulation: A Summer Boom
description: This is the time of year when insulation contractors are usually able to take a little time off. The winter and the flurry of lastminute insulation Jobs that goes with it is past, and their pace generally does not pick up again until the first nip in the autumn air sends worried homeowners to the yellow pages.

title: TaxExempts Get Good Response; Corporate Bond Trading Subdued
description: Taxexempt issues continued to occupy the credit market spotlight yesterday, with good response shown for such new offerings as Missouri's $31 million of water pollution control bonds and Chicago's $45 million of school bonds. The corporate market was somewhat more subdued, but underwriters headed by Goldman Sachs were pleased with the response to Norway's $100 million offering of notes, which was reported to be about 85 percent sold yesterday afternoon.

title: A Fabric Store That Thrives on Staying Small
description: THE SACHETS were an invention of necessity, Carol Berlin said. When Handloom Batik Importers started out, four years ago, Miss Berlin and her associate, George Wheeler, sold only fabulous fabrics, by the yard or covering pillows. But, as Carol explained while stuffing tiny batik sacks with fragrant dried herbs, she couldn't stand to throw away the scraps left over from the pillows.

title: 3 Furniture Warehouse Stores Are Sold by Federated Chain
description: Federated Department Stores, a Cincinnatibased department store chain, announced yesterday the sale of its three Gold Key furniture warehouse stores to a group of purchasers that includes the present divisional management.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Some events of interest for enthusiasts of the house and home.

title: Gems and jets
description: THE OTHER SIDE OF MIDNIGHT. Directed by Charles Jarrott; screenplay by Herman Raucher and Daniel Taradash, based on the novel by Sidney Sheldon; produced by Frank Yablans; executive producer, Howard W. Koch Jr.; music, Michel Legrand; editors, Donn Cambern and Harold F. Kress; director of photography, Fred J. Koenekamp: distributed by 20th CenturyFox. Running time: 163 minutes. At the Coronet Theater, Third Avenue near 59th Srreet, and National Theater, Broadway at 43d Street. This film has been rated R.

title: Consumer Agency Bill in Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, June 8Three times in the last seven years, Representative Thomas S. Foley voted to create a consumer protection agency. This year, he intends to vote no.

title: Creature Comforts for the Small Fry
description: As zoos go, the one at Stendig International, 410 East 62d Street, is definitely tiny and so are its tame inhabitants. And that's just fine for the tots these colorful beasts were designed by Juhanni Manner of Finland to attract.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, June 8 (AP)A steadly increase in Rocky Mountain spotted fever, caused by ticks, is causing concern among public health officials, the national Center for Disease Control said today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MOTION PITCHERS A fourday, lunchtime dance festival hour will enliven Battery Park, starting today at 12:30 P.M. The free performances will take place in front of Castle Clinton, presented by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. Today's entertainers are advanced scholarship students from the Alvin Ailey School, in works from the Ailey repertory, including excerpts from Revelations and Blues Suite.

title: Scaffold Fall Fatal
description: A scaffold threp stories up the side of a Brooklyn building collapsed, killing one painter and injuring another. A 9yearold boy walking home from school with his mother was also injured when the platform plunged to the sidewalk at 145 Smith Street, near Bergen Street.

title: RHODESIAN RAIDERS SAID TO BE WELCOME
description: SALISBURY, June 8A week after Rhodesia provoked international controversy with its extended incursion against guerrilla camps in Mozambique, the government here has produced six Mozambican refugees who say that Rhodesian troops crossing the border are welcomed by the local population as potential liberators from the rule of that country's Marxist Government.

title: Sound
description: MUSICIANS AND engineers, normally far apart in temperament, training and basic perceptual patterns, are finding fruitful common ground in the field of recording, where art and science join in the service of music. This was not always so. In the phonograph's younger years, a recording session was often a contest of wills between mutually uncomprehending factions on the musical and the technical side. The great Arturo Toscanini, for example. clearly regarded recording engineers as a lower order possibly a cross between a janitor and an electricianand his vocal disdain for the technology of recording seriously hampered the sonic results. Fortunately, today's musicians no longer view the engineer as an antagonist, but as a trusted partner in the tricky task of transmuting fleeting sounds into permanence.

title: Minority Goals In Education
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, seemed to provide a preview in New York this week of the Federal Government's strategy for increasing the enrollment of minorities in the nation's institutions of higher education. Speaking at the commencement exercises at City College, Mr. Califano called for more strenuous efforts by our colleges and universities to seek out minority students who possess talent and desire to profit from higher education.

title: TV:Visit With Castro
description: IN FIDEL CASTRO SPEAKS, an ABC News interview scheduled for 10o'clock this evening, Barbara Walters questions, confronts, flatters, cajoles, laughs, reprimands and, in general, turns in the kind of performance that has made her a major figure in television journalism, much to the consternation of many of her men colleagues.

title: Banking on Art As the Bottom Line
description: KATHARINE KUH swore she'd never do it. After all, she reminded her self then, I've been antiestablishment. all my lifeI couldn't, wouldn't work for a big bank. But now, nine years, 4,000 works of art, close to $1 million and countless hundreds of thousands of miles later, she says she has enjoyed her job with the First National Bank of Chicago more than anything she has ever done..

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 9, 1977

title: Now Ease Up, Anita
description: WASHINGTON,June 8  Militant leaders of the gay rights movement cannot minimize the defeat they suffered at the polls in Miami this week.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Wedding March, Glazunov; Al Santo Sepolcro Sonata, Vivaldi; Variations ona Theme of Paganini, Lutoslawski; Trio in G, Hummel; Hopak from The Fair at Sorochinsk, Mussorgsky; Impromptu, Faure.

title: MGM Weighs Casino
description: Metro  GoldwynMayer, which operates the world's largest casino hotel, the MGM Grand in Las Vegas, expressed interest in opening a casino hotel in Atlantic City.

title: At Your Service: City Framing Shops
description: IMPATIENT to hang some Modigliani pencil sketches that had been rolled up in cardboard tubes for years. I pounced on the first framing shop I came across in the Village. The shop had an appealing Left Bank qualityeven the front door stuck. But it wasn't until later that I realized that the messy workbench and the broken glass on the floor were symptomatic of the shop's workmanship.

title: Mrs.Carter Told By 2 Americans Of Brazil Ordeal
description: RECIFE, Brazil, June 8Rosalynn Carter met today with two American missionaries who said they had been treated like animals in a Brazilian jail.

title: DOLLAR MOVES DOWN IN EUROPEAN TRADING
description: LONDON, June 8 (AP)The dollar slipped back a bit on Europe's currency markets today except in Amsterdam, where it rose to 2.4700 guilders from 2.4675 yesterday.

title: MGM, Reversing Earlier Stand, May Open Casino in Atlantic City
description: MetroGoldwynMayer Inc., operator in Las Vegas of the world's largest casino hotel, expressed strong interest yesterday in the possibility of opening a casino hotel in Atlantic City.

title: Sanhedrin's Weapon: Stretch Kick
description: Like a Captain Ahab pursuing an equine Moby Dick, Lou Rondinello paces the shedrow of his barn at Belmont Park wondering what it takes to catch Seattle Slew.

title: $100 CoasttoCoast Plane Fares Restricted to 10 Cities by C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it would limits its considerations of proposals for cheap under $100 coasttocoast air fares to four cities in the East and six in the West, all in California.

title: Fire at Garden City Medical Unit
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 8(AP)Fire heavily damaged the Garden City Medical Center today, causing minor injuries to two patients and two firemen. Fire officials said there were 12 persons inside the twostory, white building at 520 Franklin Avenue here when the fire broke out at 8:10 A.M.

title: The Blues Are a Thing Old Blues Don't Have
description: Jackie Robinson was hitting .338 for the. Brooklyn Dodgers, a steak dinner cost $3.95, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Robert A. Taft were battling it out for the Republican nomination for President, Joan Crawford starred in a film called This Woma nls Dangerous and paratroopers stormed a Korean prison compound on Koje Island when Yale's Memorial Tower bells sumnioned 1,066 young men to receive their undergraduate diplomas under a brilliant New Haven sun. That was 25 years ago today.

title: 20 States to Lose $142 Million in Medicaid Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that it planned to cut $142 million in Medicaid payments to 20 states because they had failed to meet requirements for reviewing the quality and efficiency of nursinghome care for the Door.

title: Shipments of Aluminum Ingot Rose 10.6% for First Quarter
description: The Aluminum Association reported yesterday that first quarter shipments of aluminum ingot and mill products reached 1.65 million tons, up 10.6 percent over the corresponding 1976 period. S. L. Goldsmith, president of the trade association, said that the seasonally adjusted shipment rate for Match amounted to 7.59, million tons, or 25.1 percent higher than a year ago and 24.1 percent ahead of the February adjusted rate.

title: Dance: Tudor's Beautiful Leaves Are Fading
description: The Leaves Are Fading, which American Ballet Theater presented for the first time this season Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is one of Antony Tudor's few plotless ballets.

title: Mayer Blanks Gerulaitis As Apples Down Loves
description: Sandy Mayer and Vitas Gerulaitis are supposed to be good friends. But you would never have known it last night the way Sandy handled his buddy as the New York Apples beat the Indiana Loves, 3120, in World Team Tennis before 3,270 spectators at the Felt Forum

title: Grant Trustee Seeks to Settle Claims of Debenture Holders
description: Charles G. Rodman, trustee for the estate of the W. T. Grant Company, the bankrupt retail chain, announced yesterday that he had filed an application with Federal Bankruptcy Court for approval to settle the claims of the holders of the Grant 4 percent sinking fund debentures due Jan. 1, 1987.

title: $1 Million Libel Suit Dismissed
description: CONWAY, S.C., June 8 (UPI)  A $1 million libel suit against The SunNews Company of Myrtle Beach and United Press International was dismissed yesterday. Jack Jones, a Myrtle Beach businessman, had filed suit against U.P.I. and The SunNews Company, which publishes The Myrtle Beach SunNews, charging that a U.P.I. report printed in the paper in February 1975 had damaged his reputation and character. Circuit Judge James B. Morrison dismissed the suit against The SunNews Company, but let a Horry County jury decide the case against U.P.I. The jury, after the twoday trial, brought in a verdict in favor of U.P.I.i

title: Andrus Cancels 2 Offshore Leases In Oil Because of Lack of Activity
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)Making good his promise to crack down on delays in offshore drilling, Interior Secretary Cecil Andrus said today he had canceled two Gulf of Mexico oil and natural gas leases for lack of activity.

title: 3 Areas Cut From Jobless List
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)Three metropolitan areas were removed in May from the Labor Department's list of areas with substantial unemployment rates, the department said today. They were were Chicago, Memphis and the GaryHammondEast Chicago, Ind., area. This reduced to 101 the number of areas still listed with substantial unemployment, the lowest level since February 1975, when there were 74 such areas. The number peaked in September 1975 at 135 out of a possible 150.

title: GARDENING

title: Army Secretary Cautions Cadets on Discussing Policies
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., June 8Army Secretary Clifford L. Alexander Jr. today asked members of a United States Military Academy graduating class depleted by the recent cheating scandal to assume new responsibilities as officers and to learn how to communicate personal views on nationalsecurity matters.

title: Gov. Byrne Challenges Bateman To Early Debate on Tax Program
description: TRENTON, June 8Fresh from his victory over nine opponents in yesterday's Democratic primary, Governor Byrne today challenged his Republican rival, Senator Raymond H. Bateman to a debate on the issues as early as this Sunday..

title: Dave Anderson
description: When the New York Jets were concluding another embarrasgng season six months ago, a suggestion was offered that the owners should sell the franchise. They haven't. But they have done the next best thing. They have hired Jim Kensil to rule the organization. Until now, most pro football follwers knew Jim Kensil vaguely, if at all. But people the pro football structure knew him. More important, they respected him. For the last nine years Jim Kensil was Commissioner Pete Rozelle's executive director in the National Football League office, For seven years before that he was the N.F.L.'s publicrelations director. During those 16 years Pete Rozelle took the bows or the blame because he made the big decisions, but Jim Kensil was doing much of the work behind those decisions. He was, the commissioner has said, my offensive and defensive coordinator. And now Jim Kensil the Jets president. For the first time in their history the Jets have a football man in command, a football man with almost unique credentials

title: PRICEFIXING INDICTMENT NAMES SCHLITZ, 8 OTHERS
description: Article  No Title

title: New Bond Issues
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 8, 1977

title: Screen: Into the Supernatural
description: TERE'S NO DOUBT that the supernatural is a natural for the movies. And the current stop of "Journey Into the Beyond" at local theaters yesterday is another illustration of the commercial value of filmed things that go bump in the night. As a collage of color and black-and-white footage, from the laying on of hands to levitation, this exotic "Journey" should keep viewers awake and, perhaps, occasionally startled, if not convinced that seeing is believing.One may wonder how the camera happened to be where it is at just the right time, but a viewer might also be puzzled how photographers managed to be on hand in that remote village in Benin when the local necromancer, Nana Owaku, rose from the ground without visible means of support. Or, for that matter, when "the great Issah," an African witch doctor, performs the dual feats of bloody eye cataract surgery and rain-making.Although the squeamish, who are warned in advance, may not take to the "psychic" abdominal surgery, performed, it seems, without anesthesia or antiseptics, both in the Philippines and in Brazil, they are treated to a variety of less traumatic events. Included among these are the "psychic" healing done by a couple of Italian practitioners as well as religious occurrences such as statues and madonnas and humans with unexplained stigmata or tears."Is there life after death?" the film's ads teasingly inquire. The commentary in this "Journey" is short on explanations and as full of disclaimers as the raisins of a fruit cake. With the decidedly abnormal life depicted here, inquiry into death doesn't appear to be absolutely necessary.

title: Miami Vote Increases Activism on Homosexual Rights
description: MIAMI, June 8Though Miami area residents voted overwhelmingly yesterday to revoke broad legal protection for homosexuals, the argument over their status in society resumed full force today, not only in Miami but also in other parts of the country.

title: Two Soviet Dissidents Report They Will Be Emigrating Today
description: MOSCOW, June 8 (Reuters)A Soviet literary critic and his journalist wife who last month formed an unofficial news agency, said today that they were leaving the Soviet Union tomorrow after the authorities suddenly decided to let them emigrate.

title: Income Tax Fails as Issue in Legislative Primaries; Dugan and. Mrs. Ammond Defeated in Senate Races
description: TRENTON. June 8The state income tax Issue failed to take:its predicted toll in yesterday's 120 legislative pimarles in New Jersey.

title: Senate Unit Backs Curb on Dams In Conciliatory Gesture to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, June 8A key Senate subcommittee, seeking to head off a water projects veto by President Carter. tentatively agreed today to kill eight of the 18 dams and irrigation schemes he wants eliminated. Senate sources said.

title: Chicago Mayor in Mold of His Predecessors Michael Anthony Bilandic
description: CHICAGO, June 8Michael Anthony Bilandic was destined to become Mayor of the nation's second largest city. Like his predecessor, Richard J. Daley, Mr. Bilandic was born and reared in the Bridgeport section of the city, and still lives there. This neighborhood has produced the last five Mayors of Chicago. Also like the late Mr. Daley, the new Mayor is Roman Catholic, attended De LaSalle High School and De Paul University Law School and got into politics by hanging around 11th Ward Democratic Headquarters.

title: Gellinoff Appointee Has Got $504,000 In Receiver's Fees
description: Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff of New York State Supreme Court has appointed a partner in his soninlaw's law firm as receiver in two foreclosure actions involving the Chrysler Building, a position for which the lawyer has so far received $504,000 in legal fees.

title: IMPORTS OF CRUDE OIL DOWN SLIGHTLY IN WEEK
description: Crudeoil imports for the week ended June 3 were down slightly, to 6.7 million barrels daily from 6.8 million barrels in the preceding week, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks of crude oil dropped to 306 million barrels from 308.5 Million barrels a week earlier.

title: DOW RISES BY 4.32 AS RALLY BROADENS AND TRADING GROWS
description: The stock market continued to move ahead yesterday, broadening Tuesday's rally in steppedup trading.

title: An Upholstered Island For Living and Sleeping
description: PEOPLE GIVE THEIR houses names and their cars names, but now there is an apartment whose environmental furniture has a nameit's called The Structure. We don't know what else to call it, said Charles Boxenbaum, the architect who designed if for Bob Sauer, an advertising copy writer. It's like a sculpture piecethe parts are all clamped together.

title: Experts Outlook for Older Cities: Gloomy Future, Difficult Changes
description: ST. LOUIS, June 8Fifteen leading urban scholars gathered this week in this aging manufacturing city on the Mississippi to ponder the fate and future of the mature metropolis in America. They concluded their deliberations today with a prognosis for the older, declining urban centers that was not very optimistic.

title: Congress to Study Many Free Services It Gives News Media
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)A House commission will review the free services estimated at more than $1 million a year that Congress provides news organizations, the panel's chairman said today.

title: Zeppelin Soars
description: EVEN THOUGH millions of young people have managed to acquire it, Led Zeppelin remains an acquired taste. The British rock quartet, which opened a run of six longsincesoldout shows at Madison Square Garden Tuesday, makes a monstrously loud, deliberately abrasive kind of music far removed not only from the sweet rustlings of classical music, jazz and Tin Pan Alley, but even from the tuneful, rhythmically en??vening rock songs of the 1960's.

title: HOUSE MEMBERS TOLD TO DISCLOSE TO PANEL DEALINGS WITH KOREA
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The House ethics committee voted today to require every member of the House to disclose details of his association with South Korea in an effort to ascertain the scope of the allegedly illegal Korean attempt to influence Congress.

title: THOMAS SCIURBA
description: Thomas Sciurba, who retired in 1960 after having served for many years as chief clerk of the old Yorkville Magistrates Court on East 57th Street, died Tuesday in the Parkview Nursing Home, Massapequa. L. I. He was 89 years old.

title: Soybeans and Products Decline Sharply; Corn Futures Drop; Wheat Mostly Steady
description: Prices of oldcrop soybeans and products dropped their daily permissible limits yesterday, while the newcrop deliveries closed with steep losses.

title: Opera: Wise Woman
description: GARL ORFF?s Die Kluge, which is being presented by the Manhattan Theater Club under the title The Wise Woman and the King, is musically very much like Carmina Burana, which has been a quite popular item in the New York City Opera repertory for many years. It is. however, much more entertaining.

title: Standing Nightly Triage Watch On Bellevue's Busy Battlefield
description: Frances Holm Saponaro, five feet tall and weighing 95 pounds, runs outside and pulls arriving patients from the back seats of automobiles or through the rear doors of ambulances and helps carry or push them into the emergency room of the Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 8A 2 percent surcharge on all commergial property insurance policies designed to finance fire and casualty coverage in highrisk urban centers, as well as the state's Crime Indemnity Program, will go into effect July 1.

title: New Aide for City Courts
description: William J. Gallagher, who has been in charge of the criminaldefense division of the Legal Aid Society, has been named director of administration for New York City courts by Richard J. Bartlett, the statewide administrative judge, and David Ross of State Supreme. Court, who is the citywide administrative judge.

title: Lockheed Accepts Report
description: BURBANK, Calif., June 8 (UPI)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which recently released a report blaming two former company officers for past illegal activities, today announced it had accepted the entire list of recommendations by the committee that wrote the reportincluding the appointment of nominating and public issues committees, expansion of the audit committee, and broadening of the functions of the compensation committee to add review of management performance and development activities.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Murderer Serving 7 Sentences Gets 2 More Life Terms in Camden
description: CAMDEN, N.J., June 8 (UPI)Ronald Harvey, who is serving seven life sentences for the murders of seven Hanafi Muslims in Washington, now faces two more life terms for the slaying of Major Benjamin Coxson, a onetime Camden mayoral candidate.

title: Soviet Steps Up Propaganda Against Carter on Rights
description: Moscow, June 8The Soviet press agency Tass and other outlets have stepped up attacks on President Carter's human rights campaign in the last two days as an apparent warmup for a propaganda fight at a meeting on EastWest cooperation opening next week in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.

title: Syrian in Beirut Sees Action on Pact on Palestinians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 8Syria's Foreign Minister said here today after seven hours of talks with Lebanese leaders that the eightyearold agreement regulating the presence of Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon would be put into full effect soon

title: Ceausescu Visiting East Germany
description: EAST BERLIN, June 8 (Reuters)President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania flew here today for his first official visit to East Germany in a decade. He was greeted warmly by Erich Honecker who, like President Ceausescu, is both head of state and Communist Party leader.

title: Letter From Home
description: REUNIONS. The very word sends anxiety through the populace. To go or not to go? Will I know anybody? Will anybody know me?

title: N.H. L. Decides To Continue Merger Study
description: MONTREAL, June 8Having hoped to solve the question of accommodation with the World Hockey Association at these meetings, the National Hockey League's Board of Governors despaired today of untwining the web of complications and directed its factfinding committee to continue its work.

title: Rx Against BrandName Medicine
description: You are ill or otherwise in need of medication and the doctor prescribes a drug, say a tranquilizer. He has read some or much literature; he has heard the testimony of patients; he has been inundated with the claims and samples of detail men representing dozens of drug manufacturers. Thoughtfully, or instinctively, he pulls out his prescription pad and, instead of chlordiazepoxide, he writes Librium. In choosing the more familiar trade name, he lightens the burden on his memory, invokes welladvertised distinctions to avoid error, simplifies the task of the pharmacist and allows the patient to ingest a Pronounceable medicine. And he makes millions more for the successful manufacturer, whose product has won out over dozens of similar drugs. The chances are that the drug with the easy trade name costs two or three or six times more than the same dose known only by its scientific, or generic, name.

title: SEYCHELLES LEADER REJECTS MARXISM
description: VICTORIA, Seychelles, June 8 (Reuters) President France Albert Rend who was brought to power in a coup on these Indian Ocean islands Sunday, said today his Government would not be Marxist but would develop a form of socialism appropriate for the country.

title: Phils 3, Astros 2
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP)Jay Johnstone broke an 0for13 slump with a tworur. homer in the fifth inning that gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 32 victory over the Houston Astros tonight. The Phils swept the threegame series.

title: Beame Signs a Bill Allowing City To Finance Three Sewage Plants
description: Mayor Beame yesterday signed a bill that will let the city finance on a payasyougo basis more than 50 percent of its share of the cost of completing three major sewagetreatment plants.

title: I .C . C . Puts 2 Aides On Leave in Inquiry Related to Trucking
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that two of its employees had been placed on administrative leave pending the outcome of a Justice Department investigation involving I.C.C. trucking decisions.

title: Institute of Architects Keeps Bans On Advertising and Contracting
description: SAN DIEGO, June 8The American Institute of Architects rejected by a narrow margin today proposals that would have restructured the architectural profession by permitting architects to engage in building contracting and advertising.

title: Dollar Eases In Tokyo
description: TOKYO,June 8(AP)The dollar fell another sixtenths of a yen today amid expectations of a large oversupply of dollars on the Tokyo market this month.

title: Yanks Rout Brewers and Take First
description: MILWAUKEE, June 8Straight from being cooled off in the torrid heat of Texas, the Yankees turned hot again tonight in the evening coolness of Wisconsin. Coming from 100degree to 50degree weather here, the Yankees looked 50 degrees better, too, in beating the Milwaukee Brewers, 92, and regaining first place in the American League East.

title: Yeshiva U. Gives 750 Degrees, One of Them to a Black Rabbi, 22
description: Yeshiva University conferred 750 academic degrees in commencement exercises at its Washington Heights campus yesterday, one of them to Rabbi David Dore, a 22yearold black man who heads a 50yearold congregation of black Jews in Harlem.

title: Carey Seeks to Delay Harrison Decision On Disputed Site for the Nestle Company
description: HARRISON, N. Y., June 8Governor Carey today stepped into the controversy over the Nestle Company's proposal to switch corporate sites in Westchester County. He asked the Harrison Town Board to refer the issue to its Planning and Zoning Boarda procedure that would give the state time to help resolve the dispute.

title: Unurilings
description: ESTERSONDr. Harold. Unveillng In his memory. Sun, June 12, 11. A.M. Cedar Park, BethEl Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Cosmos Win, 30, Take First Place
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 8 Pele, Giorgio Chinaglia and Franz Beckenbauer scored the goals tonight to lead the Cosmos to a 30 triumph over the Strikers. The victory moved the Cosmos into first place in the Eastern Division of the North American Soccer League for the first time this season.

title: ExRoselle Official Is Told to Pay Borough $10,000 Taken as Bribe
description: ELIZABETH, NJ., June 8 (AP)A former State Civil Service Commissioner was ordered yesterday to pay the Borough of Roselle $10,000, which he accepted as a bribe when he was a Roselle councilman.

title: Mrs.Carter Told By 2 Americans Of Brazil Ordeal
description: RECIFE, Brazil, June 8Rosalynn Carter met today with two American missionaries who said they had been treated like animals in a Brazilian jail.

title: Taking Care of Terrace Plants
description: THOUGH many a city terrace gardener may not agree that he lives on a scept'red isle, at least he can escape to that other Eden, demi  paradise that Shakespeare describes. There on his simple balcony or sprawling penthouse terrace is his kingdom, Peace. Relaxation with a few tubs of trees, pots of geraniums and a hanging begonia or two.

description: On Sexual Crusader

title: Giants 3, Pirates 2
description: PITTSBURGH, June 8 (UPI) Consecutive fluke doubles by Darrell Evans and Jack Clark drove in two runs in the sixth inning tonight and helped the San Francisco Giants post a 32 victory over Pittsburgh and complete a threegame sweep of the Pirates.

title: Vilas Ousted In First Round At Nottingham
description: NOTTINGHAM, England,June 8(AP) Guillermo Vilas, who won the French open title with ease last Sunday, was ousted from the $100,000 John Player grais tennis tournament by unheralded Tim Gullikson today.

title: 1.53 BILLION BUSHELS OF '77 WINTER WHEAT IS FORECAST BY U. S.
description: CHICAGO, June 8A 1977 winter wheat crop almost as large as last year's bumper yield was forecast today by the Agriculture Department.

title: The Indomitable Sylvia Sidney
description: IN SCORES of Hollywood movies of the 1930's, Sylvia Sidney always was a nice girl. Sometimes in trouble with the law, sometimes intent on revenge, underloved and underfed, overworked and oppressed, putupon, pursued, and passedoverbut always somehow nice. She was a nice girl offscreen, too, who arrived in Hollywood with a duenna and made five films in her first year there by sometimes camping out at the studio.

title: Arizona State Posts 295 For 2Shot Team Lead
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., June 8It has been so cold in upstate New York this week that the Oklahoma State golf coach, Mike Holder, went to a local store last night to buy thermal underwear and a woolen ski cap for each of the five members of his team. The Cowboys wore the longjohns today when ,they began defense of their team title in the 80th National Collegiate golf championship tournament at Colgate University's Seven Oaks Golf Course.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Four Japanese motorcycle makers denied charges that they were dumping their products in the United States market.

title: 28 INDICTED IN A PLOT TO TAKE CONTRABAND INTO BROOKLYN JAIL
description: In what may be the largest corruption scandal ever to rattle the city's prison system, 21 current and former Department of Correction employees and seven alleged confederates were indicted and arrested yesterday on charges of taking bribes to smuggle narcotics, guns and ammunition, liquor and restaurant food into the Brooklyn House of Detention for use by inmates.

title: East 63d: Street Under Siege
description: HALSTON IS FUZZY ON the dates, but clear on the chronologyit happened last spring, when New York City was going through hard times, when its prestige was plunging like a Cosmo girl's neckline and its credit rating was somewhere south of awful. The city Secretary of Symbols had come up with a campaign called, I Love New York, and Halston had agreed to lend it his name. On the night of the benefit, Mayor Beame was shaking Halston's hand and patting his back. As they spoke, Halston considered bringing up the subject the subway, but decided against it. Not the right place. Not the right time.

title: The Standings
description: Thursday, June 9, 1977

title: Eleanor Miller Carmody, at 68, Daughter of a Former Governor
description: Eleanor Miller Carmody, the widow of Francis T. Carmody, a lawyer, died Monday at Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital. She was 68 years old and a resident of Glen Head, L.I.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The name of one of the companies providing mortgage financing for the projected Palace Hotel was given incorrectly in The Times yesterday. The correct name is the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: Thousands Backing Homosexuals March Uptown to Columbus Circle
description: Responding to the repeal Tuesday in Miami of a homosexualrights law, several thousand demonstrators turned out in Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village last, night and then marched uptown to Columbus Circle to declare a new fight to ban discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Massachusetts Is 9th State to Seek A Convention on Issue o0f Abortion
description: BOSTON, June 8 (UPI)Massachusetts today became the ninth tate in the nation to ask Congress to convene a convention for the purpose of adding an amendment barring abortion to the United States Constitution.

title: Cyprus Force Extension Urged
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 8 (Reuters)Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations today recommended a further sixmonth renewal of the world organization's peacekeeping force in Cyprus when its current mandate expires on June 15.

title: President Assails Proposals to Loosen Auto Emission Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  President Carter sharply assailed today proposed legislation, backed by the automobile industry, that would significantly loosen air pollution controls.

title: JOHN LAUDADIO
description: JEANNETTE,Pa, June 8 (UPI)State Representative John Laudadio died of a heart attack yesterday in Westmoreland Hospital, Greensburg His staff said he had suffered two previous attacks. He was 60 years old and a Democrat.

title: Notes on People
description: THE FORMER Attorney General, John N. Mitchell, will serve his prison sentence for his part in the Watergate conspiracy at minimum security camp at Maxwell Air Force Base in Montgomery, Ala. Normally, Mr. Mitchell would have been sent to a similar camp at Allenwood, Pa., since it is closer to his New York home.

title: Personal Beauty
description: NO WOMAN wants to fuss with her hair in summer. There are too many more interesting things to do. One needs a hairdo to swim in or play tennis. in, that will need nothing more complicated than a shampoo and drying in the sun.

title: INDIA'S MORAL FORCE IS AN AILING ASCETIC
description: BOMBAY, India, June 4In the simply furnished bedroom of a borrowed apartment overlooking the Arabian Sea here, Jaya Prakash Narayan is holding court as the moral force of India's new political order.

description: KARP, JOSEPH

description: A former University of Michigan football center and a former New York Yankee catcher shot holesinone yesterday.

description: ALBANY, June 8Bernard M. Kilbourn a 53yearold practicing dentist from Utica, was chosen today as the next Republican state chairman.

description: Morning

title: France Plans Dassault Takeover In Realigning Aerospace Industry
description: PARIS, June 8The French Government announced today its intention of acquiring a controlling interest in Dassault, the big airplane manufacturing company, as part of its efforts to stream. line the nation's aerospace industry.

title: Negotiators Complete Revision Of Geneva Convention on War
description: GENEVA, June 8 (AP)Negotiators completed work today on revisions to the Geneva Convention that would give better protection to civilians in time of war and gives wars of liberation the statue of international conflicts.

title: Castro Says Cuba Has 2,000 to 3,000 Political Prisoners
description: WAFHINGTON. June 8 (AP)In an ?nusual public admission, President Fidel Castro of Cuba says there are maybe two to three thousand political prisoners in Cuba. down from a peak of more than 15,000 in the early years of the revolution.

title: Environmental Agency to Study Health Hazard Linked to Gravel
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)The Environmental Protection Agency is starting a program to find out whether there is a public health hazard associated with asbestos dust from a type of crushed rock used in many Eastern states and in California, the agency announced today.

title: Blacks in Los Angeles Are Urged to Move to Suburbia
description: NORTHRIDGE, Calif., June 8The car drives slowly past new subdivision homes in Northridge, Encino, Chatsworth, Grenada Hills, and other cities in the sprawling San Fernando Valley, and black faces look out from the car windows.

title: Backgammon:
description: The annual spring tournament at the Clermont Club in London is one of Europe's major backgammon events. This tournament always attracts strong players from all over the world, for the stiff competition and the substantial prize money offered by the club. Stephen Raphael, long considered the dean of British backgammon players, won the tournament, defeating Brian Gilbert 2113 in the finals. In the course of the match, Raphael gave an example of what is known as tempo playwhere one hits for the purpose of creating a momentary distraction. In the diagrammed position, X, Raphael, correctly plays 24/20, 6/1,*, splitting his back runners with a 4 to the 20 point, and hitting on the 1 point with a 5.

title: AMIN, ABSENT, STEALS COMMONWEALTH SHOW
description: LONDON, June 8The conference of Commonwealth heads of government opened in London today, preoccupied with the big man who wasn't therePresident Idi Amin of Uganda.

title: Bridge:
description: The most unusual game in town is certainly the Imp played each night at the Manhattan Club, 228 West 71st Street.

title: MOE O'BRIEN
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., June 8 (AP)Funeral services are scheduled here tomorrow for Moe O'Brien, captain of Tulane University's football team when it won the Southeastern Conference championship in 1949. Mr. O'Brien died yesterday after a onemonth illness. He was 53 years old and, at the time of his death, was assistant football coach and head golf coach at McNeese State.

title: Regulation Withdrawn On Metric Road Signs
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)The Federal Government has decided to withdraw a proposed regulation that would have forced states to convert all highway signs to metric measurements or face loss of Federal funds, Representative Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa. said today.

title: JOHN J. M'GOURTY
description: John J. McGourty, a softdrink industry executive, died Monday at his Atlanta home. He was 50 years old.

description: HACKENSACK, June 8Little by little,Bergen County is moving toward transforming into reality a decadesold dream of changing a 7.5mile stretch of the Hackensack River into a freshwater lake offering recreational, cultural and historical attractions for tens of thousands.

title: Nets to Iron Out New L.I. Lease
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 8Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, said today after meeting with Roy Boe, the owner of the New York Nets, that the basketball team would remain in the county.

title: Film: Midnight a Dark Time
description: SIDNEY SHELDON'S The Other Side of Midnight is one of those bestselling novels that all too soon has become not a major motion picture, but a lengthy, expensive one.

title: Mortgage Commitments at High
description: Mortgage commitments of mutual savings banks in New York State rose to $3.3 billion in April, the highest level in more than three years, the state savings bank association reported. New mortgage commitments in April were $750 million, up from $734 million in March and $601 million in April 1976.

title: N.B.A.'s Draft Pool Loses 3 Players
description: Larry Moffett of NevadaLas Vegas, Freeman Williams of Portland State and Earl Holmes of Los Angeles Mission Junior College formally withdrew their names from the National Basketball Association college draft yesterday.

title: The School Board's TwoFront War
description: New York City's Board of Education is now fighting a twofront war. On one front, it is completing a deal with City Hall to obtain additional funds, invoking the threat of the Stavisky law, an unworthy state mandate that more money than is available must be spent on education in the city. On the other, it is struggling against City Hall's desire to abolish the sevenmember lay board and replace it with a commissioner accountable to the Mayor.

Taft were battling it out for the Republican nomination for President, Joan Crawford starred in a film called This Woman Is Dangerous and paratroopers stormed a Korean prison compound on Koje Island when Yale's Memorial Tower bells summoned 1,066 young men to receive their undergraduate diplomas under a brilliant New Haven sun. That was 25 years ago today.

title: Dutch and South Moluccans Worry That Future Will Bring More Strife
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, June 8It is still too early to foresee an end to the ordeal of 55 Dutch hostages taken by young South Moluccan radicals 17 days ago. But already, the Dutch and young people in South Moluccan communities in their midst are saying they see no way to avoid more violent actions in the future.

title: Ads Carry Wolff's Apology in Suit
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 8Representative Lester L. Wolff, DemocratLiberal from the Sixth Congressional District, which straddles the QueensNassau County line, has paid $2,902 for advertisements containing an apology to Vincent R. Balletta Jr., his Republican opponent last year. The ads were part of a settlement of a $10 million libel suit.

title: VENEZUELAN SAYS THAT OIL WILL BE BARGAINING TACTIC
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 8 (Reuters)Oil would be used as an instrument in economic bargaining between the third world and the developed nations, Venezuelan Minister of State Manuel Perez Guerrero said here today.

title: Hysterectomies Reduced Sharply Under Monitoring Plan in Canada
description: The number of hysterectomies performed in Saskatchewan hospitals dropped dramatically after a medical committee, which started monitoring the reasons the operation was done, found a large percentage to be unjustified.

title: House Unit Indicates Delay in Applying Gas Guzzler Tax
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The House Ways and Means Committee signaled today that it probably would postpone beyond 1978 the effective date of President Carter'proposedgas guzzler tax on biz cars.

title: Mets Records
description: BATTING

title: Overcrowding in New York City Prisons Presents Problems That May Force Releases of Detainees
description: Overcrowding in New York City prisons is being seriously aggravated by the inability of the state to accept hundreds of felons sentenced here, according to city corrections authorities.

title: World News Briefs
description: OTTAWA, June 8 (Reuters)Eight NATO defense ministers today began two days of talks on how the 15nation Western alliance should react to the development of new Soviet ballistic missiles.

title: U. S. Fights Penalty Duties on Japan
description: WASHINGTON, June 8(AP)The Justice Department asked a fivejudge Federal appeals court today to overturn an erroneous and ambiguous lower court ruling that would force the Government to impose penalty duties on a wide range of consumer electronic products from Japan.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Fort Lee man was indicted by Federal grand jury on charges he planned a scheme in which automobile dealers were able to roll back odometers and resell cars.

title: Guards Twice Became SuspiciouS of the Agent Serving as Gold's Spy
description: Three close calls almost abruptly ended the investigation of corruption at the Brooklyn House of Detention.

title: A New Method of Carbon14 Dating Expected to Double Science's Range
description: Atomic scientists have devised a new method of carrying out carbon14 dating of archeological and paleontological specimens that promises to more than double the time span from which ancient organic objects can be dated.

title: Reds and Billingham Subdue Mets, 50
description: Leo Durocher, battlescarred but now retired from the baseball wars, went out to Shea Stadium last night to watch the revived New York Mets try to work their new magic against the Cincinnati Reds, and observed:

title: Czech Dissidents Say 80 Lose Jobs
description: VIENNA, June 8The Czechoslovak human rights group Charter 77 has charged that 80 dissidents have lost their jobs in reprisal for endorsement of the movement's manifesto urging respect for human rights.

title: Commodity Pacts Tied to Inflation Rein
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)The Carter Administration will not sign any commodity price stabilizing agreement unless it is convinced that it will ease the risk of inflationary pressures in the United States, a Treasury Department official said today.

title: Ballet: Exciting Exorcism
description: BY COMMON CONSENT, the New York City Ballet is among the most musical dance companies the world has ever known. Now for a conundrum: 52 works, of one size or another, were originally announced for the company's current season at the New York State Theater. Of these, only four had their choreography set to specially commissioned scoresall the others used existing music.

title: Bando, Almon Drafted By Brothers Teams
description: Baseball wound up 24 regular rounds and seven secondary rounds of amateur freeagent drafting yesterday, with Milwaukee and San Diego selecting brothers of players on their rosters.

title: Janata Favored in India Elections
description: PATNA, India, June 5A leader, a leader, we want a leader to address the election meetings! the candidate on the phone shouted.

title: Home Beat
description: THE DEAL is almost set for Terence Conran, the industrial designer who owns London's Habitat chain, to design a collection of furniture for Kroehler, the massmarket furniture company that raised its design level this year with a line by Angelo Donghia.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Hills Agrees to Become Peabody Coal Chief
description: The Peabody Holding Company announced yesterday that Roderick M. Hills, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has agreed to become chairman and chief executive officer of the Peabody Coal Company. Mr. Hills would take over the posts following the holding company's impending purchase of Peabody Coal from the Kennecott Copper Corporation.

title: Title to Chaminade Nine
description: EAST MEADOW, LI., June 8Chaminade of Mineola defeated Holy Trinity of Hicksville, 42, today at EisenhowerPark and won the NassauSuffolk Catholic High School Baseball League championship series, two games to one. Jim Scudero, a lefthander, gave up only four hits in the victory.

title: City Gets Job Funds
description: New York City will receive nearly $300 million in Federal job funds this year to pay the salaries of 14,000 employees already working under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act and to hire an additional 14,000 to work in city jobs and in job training programs.

title: Law That Works for the Poor
description: The Federal program of legal help for the poor has come of age. After a long and turbulent fight in Congress the program was removed from Executive control in 1974 and established as a sheltered, independent corporation. Now, three years later, there is general agreement that the experiment has worked.
