title: Riese Brothers May Get Horn & Hardart Option
description: Principals of the Riese Brothers Organization, the largest privately held restaurant owners in New York, are expected this morning to be named to the board of the Horn & Hardart Company and to receive an option to buy 200,000 shares of the concern's common stock for $5.50 a share. If exercised, the option to buy would make Irving and Murray Riese the largest shareholders in Horn & Hardart.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The name of one of the companies providing mortgage financing for the projected Palace Hotel was given incorrectly in The Times yesterday. The correct name is the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: Warden Not Convinced That Ray Was Racist
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 8 (AP) A former warden says he told Congressional investigators that he had no reason to believe that James Earl Ray, convicted of assassinating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was a racist when he was an inmate at the Missouri State Prison.

title: Stage: Miss Tyzack Shines at Stratford
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 8The trouble with All's Well That Ends Well is that it doesn't. In Shakespeare's comedies, as they are traditionally and often inappropriately called, the heroes tend to be relatively limp. It is the women that shine.

title: Boondoggles
description: If a few key members of Congress had voted to hand out some $3 billion in public funds to a select number of politically potent constituents as a reward for committing permanent and irreversible mayhem on the nation's natural resources, the average American voter on learning of such venality would resolve to throw the rascals out at the next election.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Two articles of faith (or perhaps they might better be called articles of lack of faith in government) have come to dominate the thinking of the business community. Taken together the two articles may make it impossible for the Carter Administration to sustain the rate of growth the economy at 6 percent or reduce the rate of inflation below 6 percent. The two articles are these:

title: Miami Vote Increases Activism on Homosexual Rights
description: MIAMI, June 8Though Miami area residents voted overwhelmingly yesterday to revoke broad legal protection for homosexuals, the argument over their status in society resumed full force today, not only in Miami but also in other parts of the country.

title: A Helping Hand Is Extended By German Shepherd Club
description: Although the Knickerbocker German Shepherd Dog Club is only a onemonthold baby, it wants everyone to know that Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Manhattan are caught up in its bib. We exist and we take care of all four boroughs, said Mrs. Clare Matlin, the secretary. We really want people to know we are here. We have novices com ing into the breed and we're anxious to help them with advice on breeding and showing. A good 80 percent of our membership is actively involved in exhibiting and we also have breeders.

title: Rhodesia, in Widening War, Finds Resources Near the Breaking Point
description: WARREN HILLS, Rhodesia, June 7The funeral here yesterday for a 37yearold pilot who was the only Rhodesian casualty in last week's raid on guerrilla camps in Mozambique lasted only 14 minutes from the opening prayer to the concluding rifle volley by a whitegloved air force honor guard.

title: Indonesia Bans Trade In Commodity Futures
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 8President Suharto today banned all commodity futures trading, which is unregulated in Indonesia. He said the move would help farmers with small holdings.

title: DENIAL OF JETS TO IRAN NOT DECIDED, U.S. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The State Department said today that the Administration had not yet made a decision on the sale of 250 F18L fighter planes to Iran.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON  The income tax system can be simplified for everyone except the people who prefer their taxes complicated, according to Senator Russell B. Long.

title: Klein Scores Lilco
description: Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein accused the Long Island Lighting Company of wrongfully collecting deposits from new customers in 35 out of 50 cases reviewed by the county's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Albany Act Bans Pilot Light in Gas Appliances Sold After June 1 , 1980
description: ALBANY, June 8Governor Carey signed into law today a ban on pilot lights in gas appliances sold after June 1, 1980, an action intended to avoid wasteful use of energy.

title: Consumer Price Rise Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (Reuters)Consumer prices in the industrialized world rose at an annual rate of 7.9 percent in April, unchanged from the rate in March, the International Monetary Fund said. The rate in the United States accelerated slightly to an annual rate of 6.8 percent in April from 6.4 percent in March, while the rate in Japan slowed to 8.4 percent from 9.2.

title: Newspaper Chain Buys Shopper
description: SAN ANTONIO, June 8 (AP)HarteHanks Newspapers Inc. has purchased the California Shopper, a 147,000 circulation freedistribution advertising publication, company officials announced today. The sale, which was for slightly less than $3 million, was concluded yesterday. The San Antoniobased HarteHanks organization owns and operates 25 daily newspapers and 47 nondaily publications in 31 markets.

title: Attempt by New York Delegation to Block Concorde Fails in the House
description: WASHINGTON, June 8An attempt by members of the New York delegation to have Congress ban the supersonic Concorde jet from Kennedy International Airport was defeated, 274 to 128, in the House late today.

title: G.A.O. Criticizes Carter Energy Plan for Failure to Meet Its Own Goals
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The General Accounting Office sharply criticized the Carter Administration today for proposing an energy program that the Administration itself concedes is in conflict with its own national goals for energy use.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.

title: ByrneBateman Race Boils Down To a Test of 2 Taxation Systems
description: The election for Governor of New Jersey this fall will apparently be a public referendum on the relative merits of an income tax vs, a sales tax as the most palatable method of providing increased state aid and providing courtordered refinancing of public education.

title: Dodgers 4, Cubs 2
description: CHICAGO, June 8 (UPI)Don Sutton stopped Chicago on three hits before he was ejected from the game with one out in the eighth inning today as the Los Angeles Dodgers posted a 42 victory over the Cubs.

title: Writing Prizes In Film Given
description: LOS ANGELES, June 8Winners of the 21st Samuel Goldwyn Film and Television. Writing Awards competition were announced today by Samuel Goldwyn,Jr. First prize of $4,500 went to Vincent Gutierrez for a screenplay entitled Ring. The two second prizes of $1,000 each were presented to Walter Davis for a play, Panhandle, and Howard Delman for a screenplay, The Life and Times of Jamile Haftorah.

title: U.S. Urges Pupil Voice on School Lunches
description: Perhaps as early as next September, New York City schoolchildren will find a greater variety in their school lunches as a result of an intensive Federal task force investigation recommending that planning of school lunches be localized. The Board of Education is expected to endorse the plan.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Robert Hall's Value Going Down, So Chances of a Phaseout Go Up
description: Robert Hall, the retail clothing chain that for years has told the public that its values go up but its prices go down, may be phased out by its parent company after several years of losses.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: MAJOR FOOD CHAINS FACE MEAT PRICEFIXING SUIT
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 8 (AP)A pricefixing suit has been filed in United States District Court here against Safeway Stores, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and most of the major grocery chains in the country by 43 Utah cattlemen.

title: $50 Million Outlay by Korvettes Planned to Upgrade Part of Chain
description: Korvettes Inc., which had a loss of $1.6 million in its most recent fiscal year, plans to spend $50 million to $55 million over the next five years to remodel and upgrade half of its 58 stores, many of them in the metropolitan area.

title: Advertising
description: Imported French beer? You've got to be kidding. The French are big in wine, what do they know from beer?

title: Spanish Rightist Often Heckled But Tireless in Pursuit of Votes
description: AVILA, SpainHe is Spain's indefatigable campaigner. Setting off with a battered leather briefcase and an aged overnight bag, he has covered 80,000 miles in the last few months, crisscrossing the nation.

title: ISRAELI RELIGIOUS PARTY AGREES TO SUPPORT BEGIN
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, June 8 (UPI)A small ultraorthodox religious party agreed today to support Prime Ministerdesignate Menahem Begin in Parliament, insuring the rightwing leader's prospective government of majority control of the 120member body.

title: FORMER HARTZ EXECUTIVE IS FOUND GUILTY OF FRAUD
description: A former executive of the Hartz Mountain Corporation was found guilty by a Federal jury of commercial bribery and fraud yesterday in what was described as the first conviction in a drive against white collar crime.

title: Giant's Bid: Bring Back Drop Kick
description: Dave Jennings, the punter for the New York Giants and a young man of intensity who brings a lot of thought to football, believes the time has come for the drop kick to return to the game. While working out two or three times a week at Giants Stadium, Jennings has been fooling around with drop kicking, and if he continues to improve he will ask John McVay, the coach, to let him try such a kick in a preseason game.

title: South Carolina Governor Signs Bill Reinstating Death Penalty
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., June 8 (AP)Gov. James B. Edwards signed today a bill to reinstate the death penalty in this state.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 9, 1977

title: Quake Strikes Japan
description: TOKYO, June 8 (Reuters)A fairly strong earthquake jolted wide areas of central and northern Japan today, but there was no immediate report of casualties or damage, the Meteorological Agency here said.

title: Letters: On Bottle Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Califano Accuses Ford of Trying to Fund Social Security by Taxing Less Affluent
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, accused former President Gerald R. Ford today of trying to solve the Government's shortterm Social Security financing problem by raising taxes on workers least able to pay. In speech to the National Council of Senior Citizens, Mr. Califano said the financing problem had been apparent for some time, but no solution had been put in force by the time President Carter took office.

title: Muraskin Is 8and7 Victor
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 8  Dave Muraskin, a 30yearold New York attorney, carted off a silver trophy today for winning his second consecutive Westchester Golf Association amateur championship.

title: Brezhnev Receives Gus Hall
description: MOSCOW, June 8 (AP)Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today met at the Kremlin with Gus Hall, the United States Communist leader, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: To Many a South Moluccan, Price of Spice Is Key to Life
description: PASSO, Moluccan IslandsFor hundreds of years fragrant crops of cloves, nutmeg, vanilla and copra have been produced here on land that was once known more descriptively to the West as the Spice Islands.

title: Design Notebook
description: THE ANDREW CARNEGIE Mansion, on Fifth Avenue be tween 90th and 91st Street, is celebrating its 75th birthday and second reincarnation this year. To mark the occasion, the CooperHewitt Museum (the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, and the building's current occupant) has mounted a small exhibition on the history of the house.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 9, 1977

title: Judge Dismisses Some Charges Against Nurses in Poison Deaths
description: DETROIT, June 8A Federal judge, citing insufficient evidence, today dismissed murder charges against one of two nurses charged with poisoning patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, but let stand a murder charge against the second nurse as well as some of the poisoning and conspiracy charges against both of them.

title: BARRED BROKER PLEADS GUILTY IN FRAUD CASES
description: A former partner in S.J. Salmon and Company, a defunct stock brokerage firm, pleaded guilty in Manhattan Federal Court yesterday to charges in separate indictments that he conspired to manipulate overthecounter stocks and tried to defraud the Securities Investors Protection Corporation.

title: 3 Held in Hackensack on Charge Of Bid to Smuggle Drugs Into Jail
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 8 (UPI)Three persons, including a Bergen County sheriff's officer, have been arrested for allegedly attempting to smuggle drugs into the county jail.

title: Hers
description: Benjamin Felson, M.D. Medical Opinion & Review, November, 1965. AFTER UNDUE consideration, I have decided not to take up tennis this year. Although it is the 19th year in a row that I have made this same decision, I don't mean to imply that I ever make it lightly. On the contrary, I make it downright heavily, especially now that tennis has become a warmweather feminist issue.

title: Family Money: How to Buy Insurance on Recreational Vehicles
description: DUNE buggies, snowmobiles, trail bikes, campers, mobile homes and motor homesartifacts of the good life, allhave proliferated with such bewildering speed over the nation's recreational landscape that there are times when even the insurance companies are confused.

title: Morey Wins Seniors Golf For Third Year in a Row
description: RYE, N.Y., June 8The day he became 55 years old, Dale Morey was invited to join the 915member United States Seniors Golf Association. It also meant he could enter the group's championship tournament.

title: ROBERT F. PITTA DIES; MEDICAL RESEARCHER
description: Dr. Robert F. Pitts, a physiologist who was internationally known for his studies of the kidney and nervous system, died Monday at a nursing home in Live Oak, Fla. Be was 68 and had been in poor health for several years.

title: CARTER'S 1975 TAXES ARE BEING AUDITED
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The White House acknowledged today that President Carter's 1975 income taxes were being audited and then admitted that it had made a misleading statement in asserting that the President had sought the audit in a voluntary effort to set a precedent in Government ethics.

title: HOUSE MEMBERS TOLD TO DISCLOSE TO PANEL DEALINGS WITH KOREA
description: WASHINGTON,June 8The House ethics committee voted today to require every member of the House to disclose details of his association with South Korea in an effort to ascertain the scope of the allegedly illegal Korean attempt to influence Congress.

title: Disks: Caballe Ventures Into New Songs
description: During her career, Montserrat Caball the Spanish soprano, has sung a lot of different things, evidence of which can be found in reading her repertory list. Some of the variety has been dictated by the natural development of her voice. Light at the beginning, it has grown bigger over the years. That growth may still be in progress, of course, but whether it is bringing her to fullfledged dramatic soprano strength is open to question. This recording suggests that the answer is No.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (Reuters)A Federal grand jury today charged the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company and eight other defendants with conspiring to fix beer prices in Hawaii.

title: The Information Age
description: WASHINGTON Just as we were beginning to feel comfortable about living in the space age, bold headlines in an I.B.M. advertisement told us there's growing agreement that we now are in the information age.

title: Tennis
description: AT CHICHESTER, ENGLAND

title: Albert King Reveals His Choice: Maryland
description: Albert King, the cream of this sea. son's high school basketball crop, announced last night that he would attend the University of Maryland in the fall.

title: ARAB CAUTIONS U. S. ON BOYCOTT CURBS
description: CAIRO, June 8 (UPI)An Arab League official warned today that President Carter's attempts to keep United States companies from complying with the Arab boycott of Israel would result in the blacklisting of those concerns, from business in the Arab world.

title: AMIN, ABSENT, STEALS COMMONWEALTH SHOW
description: LONDON, June 8The conference of Commonwealth heads of government opened in. London today, preoccupied with the big man who wasn't therePresident Idi Amin of Uganda.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC PROMENADE, Avery Fisher Hail, Lincoln Center, 8:30.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, June 8, 1977

title: Art: Collages of Many Persuasions
description: THE COLLAGEa picture made, either wholly or in part, from cut and pasted materialsentered the history of modern art with the Cubism of Picasso and Braque, but it underwent a decisive change in the hands of the Dadaists and the Surrealists. The interests of Cubism were largely formal, whereas the interests of Dada and Surrealism were polemical and poetic, and it was the latter movements that turned the collage into a medium of comedy and satire.

title: Bridge:
description: Those who live by the sword usually die by the sword, at any rate in knockout team contests. Surprisingly, often a team that struggles through to win a match by one or two international match points, the smallest possible margins, goes down to defeat in the next round after an equally close battle. The fates have balanced the account.

title: DR FREDERICK BALDI; WAS PRISON WARDEN
description: Dr. Frederick S. Baldi, a physician who headed the Philadelphia County prison system from 1938 to 1953, died on Tuesday at a Philadelphia nursing home. He was 90 years old and had been in retirement since 1956 when he ended his career as warden of the Rockview State Penitentiary.

title: New Face: Anne DeSalvo
description: Several years ago, Anne DeSalvo left her West Philadelphia home, in what she calls one of that city's two big Italian ghettoes, to come to New York and start a new life as an actress. Last month, Miss DeSalvo made her Broadway debut in Albert Innaurato's wellreceived comedy Gemini, after acting in the play Off and Off Off Broadway, and has since won an Obie to boot. In Gemini, which is at the Little Theater, Miss DeSalvo plays a fairly freaky Italian widow livingwhere else?in the other Italian stronghold, South Philadelphia.

title: Pop: Outdistanced by a Smile
description: Anthony Mucci, who has melting brown eyes, a dimpled smile and a promising voice, is putting all three on display this week at Barbarann, 349 West 46th Street. At the moment, the smile is overdone and the voice is underdeveloped, although the eyes are holding thir own. If Mr. Mucci could get things in balanceconcentrate more on projecting the warmer qualities of his voice and place less dependence on a studied sexinesshe might be an interesting performer.

title: Cynthia S. Jarvis Is Bride Of John S. MacGregor 3d
description: Cynthia Suzanne Jarvis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Jarvis of Babylon, L.I., was married yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral to John Strathern MacGregor 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. MacGregor Jr. of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Michael Crimmins performed the ceremony.

title: Washington Opera Ball: A Winner Before It Opens
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The whole idea is to create an illusionthe dream of a ball in a great castle, explained Countess Ulla Wachtmeister, wife of the Swedish Ambassador, as she fingered one of the beautful banners she had created. When you think of opera, you think of pageantry, and we want it to be a night which conjures up images of castles and ballsand the opera.

title: Futures Contract in Treasury Notes
description: CHICAGO, June 9 (UPI)The Chicago Mercantile Exchange board of governors approved today a futures contract in fouryear United States Treasury notes. The contract has been submitted to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for approval.

title: O'DWYER SIDESTEPS GOVERNOR AT DINNER
description: Ireland's political problems, never too far removed from New York City's, came up again Wednesday when City Council President Paul O'Dwyer walked out of an Israel Bonds dinner rather than appear with Governor Carey.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York State Court of Appeals agreed yesterday to hear argument on June 29 that will decide whether results of the reading tests in New York City can be disclosed and entered on pupils records. Last month the court partly lifted a preliminary injunction, allowing 650,000 students to take the test, which had become a subject of litigation after, disclosure that 3,000 students had been drilled on the actual test. But the court said the Board of Education could not use the official test results until the judges had decided whether to grant the board the right to appeal a lowercourt injunction. Yesterday it granted the board that right.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Port Authority Is Planning to Put $240 Million Into Bus Programs
description: Administrationconfined itself to the four Port Authority bridges linking New York and New Jersey, it has been interpreted to apply to the Lincoln and Holland TunnelP as well. The bridges are the George Washington, Goethals, Bayonne and Outerbridge Crossing.

title: Inquiry Links Institutional Indifference To Deaths of 7 at Bronx Mental Facility
description: Six patients at the Bronx Psychiatric Center diedthree of suicideand a seventh was beaten in circumstances of institutional indifference and ineptitude, the State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday.

title: Mobile HotDog Stands Curbed in Suffolk
description: FARMINGVILLE, L.I.The roadside hot dog, that sustainer of travelers and truck drivers, is becoming harder to find in Suffolk County.

title: On the SunbeltSnowbelt Controversy
description: WASHINGTONI am disturbed by the growing tendency toward aggressive regionalism in the United States Senate.

title: Senate Compromises on Car Fumes
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Senate reached a compromise on the highly controversial automobile pollution issue tonight, voting to delay imposition of stricter controls on car fumes but not to weaken the standards permanently in a significant way.

title: Responsibility for Attack
description: BEIRUT, LEBANON, June 9, (AP)A man identifying himself as spokesman for a group called Justice Commandos for Armenian Genocide claimed responsibility for the killing of the Turkish Ambassador to the Vatican. In a telephone call to The Associated Press office here, he said his group had carried out the attack as revenge. He then hung up.

title: BEGIN NEAR SUCCESS IN FORMING COALITION
description: TEL AVIV, June 9Efforts by Menahem Begin, leader of the rightwing Likud bloc, to form a coalition government backed by a majority in Parliament appeared near success today as the way was opened for a small religious party to support the coalition though not join the cabinet.

title: Amex Planning to Rent Seats And Sell Option Memberships
description: Among the great traditional American ambitionsbecoming a movie star or a Presidenthas been the ownership of a seat on a stock exchange. Soon they'll be for rent.

title: Senate Republican Chief Criticizes President for Cozying Up to Cuba
description: WASHINGTON. June 9 (AP)Howard H. Baker,the Senate Republican leader, today sharply criticized the Carter Administration's moves toward normalization of relations with Cuba.

title: BILL WOULD RESTRICT ABORTIONS ON YOUNG
description: ALBANY, June 9A special panel set up by Governor Carey today recommended a number of procedural restrictions on abortions on teenagers that it said would reconcile the right of a young woman to get a legal abortion with the right of a parent to care for his child.

title: Badillo Enters Campaign for Mayor
description: Standing in front of a big oblong sign that read Badillo . . .for all minorities, Representative Herman Badillo declared his mayoral candidacy yesterday with a tart attack on Mayor Beame's financial talents and an appeal to the lawandorder issue that politicians believe is Paramount in the minds of New Yorkers.

title: Amy, at School, Gets Presidential Award
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)When the President's Physical Fitness Awards were handed out tonight at the Francis Junior High School, Amy Carter was the first to get one.

title: Dance: Phoenix at the Cubiculo
description: SOMETHING different, something worth seeing for those interested in avantgarde theater and dance turned up Wednesday night at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street.

title: Art People
description: IT SEEMS TO BE Richard Diebenkorn's season here, No sooner had a show of the California painter's recent works closed (at Knoedler's last week) than a Diebenkorn retrospective opened (at the Whitney Museum yesterday, through July 17); more than 130 works that display the full range of his talents, both figurative and abstract.

title: Laurie Susan Manes Is Bride of Michael Jay Kaplan
description: Laurie Susan Manes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Manes of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Jay Kaplan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Kaplan of Northport, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Mill River Club in Upper Brookville, L.I.

title: A OneRing Circus Can Be a Lot of Fun, Too
description: Come down, Chris, the man in the orange suit shouted and Chris Thomas, a slightly built, 16yearold tumbler from Harlem, plummeted nonchalantly from atop a 15foot human pyramid. No one applauded his feat.

title: News Summary
description: The Polish Government is facing a growing human rights movement and widespread discontent ever food shortages. The mood is very angry, a member of the human rights movement told a Western visitor. Basic food prices have been frozen in Poland since 1971 at levels so low that heavy subsidies are required and there are few incentives to increase production. An increase in some basic food prices started riots a year ago and was quickly revoked. [Page A1, Columns 12.]

title: DANNY KNIGHT
description: TUSTIN, Calif., June 9 (AP)  Danny Knight, former allBig Eight basketball player at the University of Kansas, died last night of injuries suffered three weeks ago in a fall down steps in his home. He was 23 years old and had played one season with the AthletesinAction team.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: QUEENS SCHOOL BOARD OVERRULED BY PANEL
description: The Chancellor of New York City schools ordered a Queens school district yesterday to comply with a ruling that would send 100 white students to predominantly black high schools and 1,400 black or Hispanic students to either predominantly white high schools or to their neighborhood school, virtually allblack Andrew Jackson High School in Cambria Heights.

title: Major League Scores
description: EBurleson. DPBoston 1. LOBBaltimore 13, Boston 4. 2BYastrzemski, Burleson. HRDauer (1), Lynn (5), Rice 2 (14), Fisk (11). 5BBelanger. SFMurray, Singleton.

title: Moynihan Charges Carter Is Neglecting EastWest Conflict
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that President Carter had downgraded and diverted attention from the central political struggle of our timethat between liberal democracy and totalitarian communism.

title: On Fulton St., Taste Of Flings to Come
description: The longawaited Fulton Mall project will get under way officially tomorrow, and downtown Brooklyn is kicking up its heels.

title: Concert: Modern Rumanian Music
description: FOR ITS FINAL concert of the season, the New Repertory Ensemble of New Yorkwhich is directed by Dinu Ghezzo and based at Queens Collegepresented an evening of modern Rumanian music Wednesday at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Mets Are in No Hurry to Trade Seaver
description: Six days from the trading deadline in baseball, the Mets left New York last night for seven games in Houston and Atlanta, still hot, still in last place, still denying that any highlevel deal for Tom Seaver was imminent.

title: Racers Fate Seems Uncertain
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 9 (AP)The Indianapolis Racers general manager, Brian Conacher, said today the team's future in the World Hockey Association was uncertainjust like the W.H.A.'s.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)Describing Hamaas Abdul Khaalis and 11 Hanafi Moslem codefendants as a ruthless, unified band of killers and kidnappers, the Government vowed yesterday to prove each guilty of at least 31 felony counts, including firstdegree murder.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 6.5%
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15 billion tonmiles, up 6.5 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings during the same period totaled 441,911 cars, a rise of 5.7 percent from last year.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: Total time deposits excluding large

title: U.S. to Prod O.A.S. To Give More Help To Its Rights Unit
description: WASMNGTON, June 9The Carter AdministraVon has quietly begun a drive to improve the machinery for the collective defense of human rights in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Weather Is Dampening Efforts Of Eastern SaltWater Anglers
description: Unsettled weather in recent days has sometimes limited the success of East Coast saltwater fishermen.

title: Discoverer of Pitchblende Dies
description: TORONTO, June 9 (AP)Gilbert Adelard LaBine, a prospector and businessman who made the first discovery of uraniumbearing ore in Canada in 1930, died yesterday at 87. Mr. LaBine discovered pitchblende, which eventually was applied to cancer therapy and atomic energy.

title: REVERIE LOSS SEEN IN TAX REFORM PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, suggested today that the White House is now prepared to accept a net revenue loss in the tax reform program it will propose to Congress this year.

title: Pippin to Close Sunday
description: Pippin, which has won five Tony awards and has been a big profitmaker, will give its last performance at the Minskoff Theater on Sunday afternoon. The production opened at the Imperial Theater on Oct. 23, 1972. It will begin a national tour Aug. 1, at Kennedy Center in Washington. Pippin's net profit to date a $3,318,415.

title: Judy Cooperstein Victor
description: GREAT NECK, LI., June 9  Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks won the 27th Women's Cross Country Golf Association's 54hole championship today when rain canceled the final round at Fresh Meadow Country Club. The winner's scores for the first two rounds were 74, 78152. Phoebe Dempsey of St. George's was second with 81, 78159.

title: Deaths
description: BLACKRose, beloved wife of the late William, devoted mother of Arthur and Morris, loving grandmother. Funeral Services today, 1 P.M., at The Colonial Chapels of I. J. Morris Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, L.I. Interment, Montefiore Cemetery.

title: FRANK H. KAUFMAN
description: Frank H. Kaufman, a retired advertising executive, died Wednesday at Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 74 years old and a resident of Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Manhattanites Use Hoboken Garage
description: HOBOKENWhen Joan Mann of Manhattan wants to take a weekend spin in the country, she boards a train in the 14th Street Port Authority TransHudson tube station, rides to Hoboken, walks two blocks to the municipal parking garage and picks up her 1972 Hornet station wagon.

title: Researchers Report Doctors Lead Public In Quitting Smoking
description: ATLANTA, June 9 (UPI)A decline in cigarette smoking among doctors and dentists may presage a similar reduction in tobacco use among the general population in the next 10 to 15 years, a physician said today.

title: Wilson Hired to Coach Penguins Next Season
description: PITTSBURGH, June 9 (AP)The Pittsburgh Penguins have hired John Wilson as coach. Al Savill, owner of the National Hockey League team, will make the official announcement next Monday at a news conference.

title: 41 Die in a Nightclub Blaze In Capital of Ivory Coast; Most Identified as French
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, June 9 (AP)Fire raced through a nightclub in this West African capital early today, killing 41 people trapped when flames destroyed an electrical system operating an automatic exit, the French Consulate reported.

title: BELL NOT CERTAIN IF F.B.I. HAS ENDED ILLEGAL TACTICS
description: WASHINGTON. June 9 (AP)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that he was not certain that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had stopped the allegedly illegal investigative tactics carried out in the 1960's and early 1970's.

title: Today's Draft In N.B.A. Has Them Guessing
description: Sitting behind a desk cluttered with papers and hurriedly scribbled notes, Willis Reed thumbed through a book of blue, yellow and pink looseleaf pages yesterday. Each page was devoted to a different college player. The new Knick coach was getting ready for today's college draft that will be conducted by telephone hookup between the National Basketball Association office and the 22 league cities.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Julius B. Richmond was nominated by President Carter yesterday for the combined posts of Surgeon General and assistant secretary for health of the Department of Health, Lducation and Welfare. Dr. Richmond, who is 55; oars old, has been chairman of prev.:atative and social medicine at Harvard Medical School since 3971. He was chairman of the pediatrics department at the College of Medicine of the State University of New York at Syracuse from 1953 to 1965, when he was named dean of the medical faculty there. While in the Boston area he had served as psychiatristinchief at Children's Hospital Medical. Center and director of the Judge Baker Guidance Center. He is a native of Chicago.

title: Restaurants
description: TAVOOSPersian for peacockis the name that's been given to the lavishly handsome new Iranian restaurant on 52d Street just a few doors east of Fifth Avenue. It is spacious and plushly done up in restful tones of deep vermilion and dark green offset by brassy touches the service plates, a few old wood carvings and a stunning, painted, coffered ceiling at the entrance. Booths for two are a bit cramped, perhaps, and the color scheme could use a bit more lighting to come alive, but the staff is completely flawless. Rarely does one come across such genuine concern and elaborate but sincere courtesy in these or any other parts.

title: PORT AGENCY PLANS TO PUT $240 MILLION INTO BUS PROGRAMS
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, blocked recently in an attempt to spend money for new rail transportation, voted yesterday to shift a $240 million masstransit commitment to bus projects.

title: Papp Quits Lincoln Center, Citing ArtisticFiscal Trap
description: Joseph Papp is leaving Lincoln Center. In a surprise move, the impresario announced Yesterday that his New York Shakespeare. Festival, which has operated the Vivian Beaumont and the Mitzi E. Newhouse theaters since 1973, would vacate the theater complex at the conclusicn of a return engagement of Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard, which will begin June 28.

title: The Positive Effects of Arms Transfers
description: Many intellectuals and policymakers have advocated United States military retrenchment on the ground that some thirdworld regional powers can sustain local stability and safeguard American interests abroad without United States military involvement; they also, however, denounce arms transfers to nonWestern countries as immoral and detrimental to their economic development. Many thirdworld countries previously under the United States security umbrella and now forced to seekand pay for their own means of selfdefense must find the dialectics of the debate puzzling indeed. Iran is a case in point.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two women were indicted in Newark on charges of marrying 18 illegal aliens from Haiti as part of a phony marriage scheme to help them obtain permanent residency status. Twentyfive aliens pleaded guilty to the scheme yesterday.

title: Dance: Steadfast Tin Soldier WellOiled and Predictable
description: The mechanical doll is second only to the mythic bird as a pretext for creating a ballet, so it was inevitable that George Balanchine would succumb to the lure eventually. At this time of year two summers ago, he created The Steadfast Tin Soldier, which has taken its modest place in the repertory of the New York City Ballet.

title: Gottfried, 5 Other Americans Reach Tennis Quarterfinals
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 9 (UPI)  Brian Gottfried won two matches within three hours today and led a group of six United States players Into the quarterfinal round of the $100,000 John Player grass court tennis tournament.

title: Louis Miniclier Dies in Spain at 66; Community Development Pioneer
description: Louis Merlin Miniclier, an early pioneer in the concept of community development, has died in Seville, Spain. He was 66 years old. Memorial services were held there April 30.

title: Goldin Finds Almost Half Idle After U.S.Financed Job Training
description: Almost half the unemployed workers who participated in a $10 million Federal jobtraining program in New York City were unemployed again 30 days after the program ended, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

title: ORTHODOX ECONOMICS FOR WORLD RECOVERY BACKED BY EXPERTS
description: PARIS, June 9The best hope formajor industrial nations to get back to steady economic growth and low inflation lies in the cautious pursuit of orthodox economic policies, an international group of experts suggested today.

title: Papp, Citing FiscalArtistic Reasons, Leaves Beaumont
CORRECTIONS
description: An Associated Press dispatch from Washington that appeared in The Times yesterday incorrectly listed. Alabama instead of Alaska as one of 20 states that will have Medicaid payments cut by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare because of inadequate review procedures. The amount to be withheld from Alaska is $274,083.

title: Retail Store Sales Advance 14%
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales last week were about $13.85 billion, up 14 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.17 billion. Department store sales totaled an estimated $1.32 billion, up 11 percent from last year's $1.19 billion.

title: Increase in Diplomatic Activity in China Indicates Shift in Priorities
description: HONG KONG, June 9China has had an upsurge of diplomatic activity, with a major increase in trips abroad by Chinese officials and visits to Peking by foreign leaders, including the arrival this week of President Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan and Vo Nguyen Giap, Vietnam's Minister of Defense.

title: 21 Debutantes to Be Presented
description: Twentyone young women will be presented to Terence Cardinal Cooke. Archbishop o New York, tonight at the annual St. Vincent Debutante Ball at the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y. The proceeds will benefit St.. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison, N.Y., a 200bed facility for the treatment and rehabilitation of psychiatric patients. Among the debutantes will be Susan Helen Smith, a greatgranddaughter of the late Alfred E. Smith, former Governor of New York.

title: Papp Quits Lincoln Center, Citing ArtisticFiscal Trap
description: Joseph Papp is leaving Lincoln Center. In a surprise move, the impresario announced yesterday that his New York Shakespeare Festival, which has operated the Vivian Beaumont and the Mitzi E. Newhouse theaters since 1973, would vacate the theater complex at the conclusion of a return engagement of Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard, which will begin June 28.

title: Albany Assembly Agrees to Delay Basic Changes in Public Pensions
description: ALBANY, June 9The Assembly today approved a bill that delays any substantive revision of the state's public employee, pension law by extending for two years the system of three coexisting retirement benefit plans.

title: BeIco and Petroperu in Sales Pact
description: The Belco Petroleum Corporation announced the signing of a new crude oil sales contract with the Peruvian Government's oil company, Petroperu. It covers the sale of the contractor's share of 22.5 million barrels of crude oil at prices ranging from $12.25 to $13.25 a barrel. The contract must be approved by the Peruvian Government.

title: Topics
description: One for the Money A new study reveals that using one officer in patrol cars is just as effective and a great deal cheaper than using two. Sponsored by the Police Foundation, whose director is former New York City Police Commissioner Patrick Murphy, it shows that each oneman car saves San Diego more than $112,000 a year. The potential savings in New York are wellnigh unimaginablebecause of the emotional opposition to oneman cars by some officers and by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. The San Diego study imposes a new burden on them. San Diego is not New York; there may be some justice to the opponents' case. But, this illuminating study will make it a lot harder for them to prove it.

title: Senate Compromises on Car Fumes
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Senate reached a compromise on the highly controversial automobile pollution issue tonight, voting to delay imposition of stricter controls on car fumes but not to weaken the standards permanently in a significant way.

title: Art: A Genius at Finding Geniuses
description: HE WAS THE foremost art dealer of this century, and he was tough. His manner was boorish, the bargains he drove were hard. He was sly, secretive, inquisitive, eccentricand to a young artist he seemed altogether forntidable. In the aark, dusty shop windows, nothing but old newspapers and a little statue by Maillol, as if it had wandered there by mistake, wrote the young Marc Chagall of his first look at Ambroise Vollard's gallery on the Rue Lafitte in 1910. I hesitate to go in. He looks badtempered. I don't dare.

title: America's Cup Entries Of U.S. Are in Newport
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 9 (AP)The 12Meter yachts Independence and Courageous joined the Enterprise here today, making the United States' contingent of America's Cup entries complete.

title: Commodity Price Index Declines 2.8 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 212.7 from 215.5 last week.

title: Mary McSweeney, Volunteer Adviser On Health Matters
description: Mary Hartzell McSweeney, a medical research and medical care volunteer worker, died Tuesday in Essen, West Germany, while on vacation. She was 71 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Kissinger Warns of Gains by Communists in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Henry A. Kissinger warned tonight that the growing political strength of Communist parties in Western Europe posed a grave threat to he nature of the Western world and he urged concerted efforts to prevent Communist election victories in Italy, France and Spain.

title: Hospitals Corporation Dissolves Unit, Names Lynaugh as President
description: The board of directors of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to dissolve the interim operating committee, which managed its operations, and to name Joseph T. Lynaugh, its executive vice president, as the corporation's acting president.

title: Bess Myerson's Advocacy A Business Matter Now
description: When Bess Myserson left her job as New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, several companies saw an opportunity for a public relations coup if they could hire her as consumer adviser, spokesman or consultant. One auto manufacturer offered her $350,000, she says, to spend six days shooting advertisements. She turned it down.

title: Free OffHour Buses Due in Trenton in '78
description: TRENTON, June 9 (UPI)The country's first freebus program will begin here next January with the help of Federal masstransit funds, according to the State Transportation Commissioner, Alan Sagner.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 9, 1977

title: The Tax Reform Program: Task and Problems Huge
description: WASHINGTONIn about three months, the Carter Administration has promised, it will put a major taxreform package before the American public. The task it faces in the meantime is mammoth, as are the problems that will confront the Congress, the business world, investors and other interested parties once the President finally makes his proposals.

title: At the Movies
description: I HAVE butterflies confessed Joseph E. Levine in an unguared moment. It was like hearing Muhammad All whimper that he was afraid to enter the ring. After all, jumbo spirited Joe Lovine is celebrated for his jolly cool, his unswerving selfconfidence. He is the man who came from nowhere two decades ago and shook up the movie industry with his razzledazzle promotion of an then went on to sprinkle the public with an exotically mixed bag of movie goodies, from the insipid pooting of Carroll Baker in Harlow to the sublime emoting of Sophia Loren in Two Women. He was also the one and only movie mogul with the courage to gamble on such risky ventures as The Graduste, The Lion in Winter,  The Producers and A Touch of Class.

title: Management
description: The nation's 7,500 largest companies spend more than $1.6 billion annually for what is called inhouse education of their employees, according to a survey just released by the Conference Board.. The independent research organization said the figures did not include some $220 million for tuitionrefund programs and $180 million for other outside courses taken by employees.

title: Beame Holds a Wet News Parley, But Noisy Planes Fail to Make It
description: In a heavy downpour, Mayor Beame held an outdoor news conference yesterday on the outskirts of Kennedy International Airport to prove his contention that the Federal Aviation Administration had been lax for years in failing to reduce noise levels of aircraft.

title: 22 Seized in Tampa In Arson Fraud Plot
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 9 (AP)Twentytwo persons, including a fire department captain, were arrested today on arson conspiracy charges involving 22 busines's and residential fires in the last four years.

title: Sound Planning Is Elusive Goal. In Soviet Cities
description: MOSCOW, June 10Any city planner in New York would be envious: no crazyquilt pattern of privately owned land, no protesting citizens, no need for elaborate zoning incentives to induce profithungry developers to do what's right for efficiency and esthetics.

title: Newspaper Headline From '27 Tells Son of Mother's Murder
description: As the years slipped by and the pic tures drawn in a child's mind faded away, Clifford C. Doze sometimes tried to remember what his mother had been likehow she had looked, the color of her clothes and what she had said to him the day she went out to buy him an icecream cone and never came back.

title: Glory of Thrace Shines at Met
description: GARLANDED with quotations from Homer, Herodotus and Xenophon and glittering with the irresistible glamour of exquisitely wrought silver and gold, the exhibition of Thracian Treasures from Bulgaria, opening tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an event to delight the eye and beguile the mind. Consisting of loans from the state museums of the People's Republic of Bulgariaover 500 objectsthe exhibition has already been seen in Paris, London, Moscow, Vienna, Havana and Mexico City, and will travel to Canada and Japan after its American showing.

title: Advertising
description: Young & Rubicam and Time Inc., its client for 39 years, ran handinhand to glory at last night's One Show, the advertising awards event.

title: Publishing: Finds Of Oscar Lewis
description: THE FINAL WORK of Oscar Lewis, the anthropologist, will be published this summer. His studies in the culture of poverty The .Children of Sanchez and La Vidawere widely acclaimed. Now his last research project has been completed by his widow, Ruth M. Lewis, and Susan M. Rigdon, their research associate.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Dismissed Summa Board Member Asks Court to Oust Hughes Cousin
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 9The expected fight between William R. Lummis and Chester C. Davis over control of the Howard Hughes estate has broken out in chancery court in Wilmington, Del.

title: Sound Planning Is Elusive Goal In Soviet Cities
description: MOSCOW, June 10Any city planner in New York would be envious: no crazyquilt pattern of privately owned land, no protesting citizens, no need for elaborate zoning incentives to induce profithungry developers to do what's right for efficiency and esthetics.

title: Cubs Win With 2 Pinches and Squeeze in 11th, 10
description: How good are the Chicago Cubs? Good enough to win the National League's Eastern Division, according to Bruce Sutter, their star relief pitcher.

title: Carter and Communism
description: ROME, June 9United States officials are watching the rise of Communist influence in Western Europe with the utmost care, but under Jimmy Carter they are not following the Kissinger line of issuing public warnings about it.

title: Universal PicturesThen and Now
description: The black tower stands a few hundred feet north of the Hollywood Freeway, a sullen black box guarding the gates to a Hollywood version of Eden.

title: REAGAN IS CRITICAL OF CARTER ON RIGHTS
description: Ronald Reagan, former Governor of California and Republican Presidential contender, criticized the Carter Administration yesterday for what he described as a double standard on human rights.

title: Time to Face the Issues in New Jersey
description: What the voters of New Jersey did not need and should not have is what their primary votes have now ordained: yet another major election devoted to futile argument over the income tax. Thanks largely to a crowded field of opponents, Gov. Brendan Byrne won renomination among Democrats with 30 percent of the vote, an inauspicious sendoff for an incumbent. He will face a formidable challenge from State Senator Raymond Bateman, who won the Republican nomination for Governor with his party organization's support and 56 percent of the vote. About a fourth of the state's 3.7 million registered voters participated in the selections.

title: In a Changing World, Lapps Herd Reindeer by Snowmobile
description: KILPISJARVI, FinlandJouni Labba presides over a land majestic in its simplicity. Hills, lakes and birchstudded tundra sweep north to the Arctic waters beyond the horizon. The sun dazzles the melting patches of snow and the silence is punctuated by the bells clunking from the leather collars of his foraging reindeer.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Airbus Industries, the French, German and Spanish consortium that manufactures the Airbus A300 jumbo jet, announced in Paris that it had signed a joint venture agreement with the Pratt & Whitney aircraft unit of the United Technologies Corporation to produce a version of the A300 powered by Pratt & Whitney's JT 9D59A turbofan jet engine.

title: Congoleum Withdraws Universal Leaf Offer
description: In what was described on Wall Street as a hostile tender that did not work, the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company said that the Congeleum Corporation had withdrawn its proposed tender offer and agreed not to seek control of Universal Leaf.

title: TURKISH AMBASSADOR TO VATICAN IS SLAIN
description: ROME, June 9 (AP)An unidentified gunman shot and fatally wounded Turkey's ambassador to the Vatican today. It was the third assassination of a Turkish ambassador in Europe in two years.

title: Circus Dispute Settled
description: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus has reached agreement with the American Federation of Musicians, ending a dispute that had led to a nationwide union boycott of the circus. A joint announcement said the settlement provided for employment of local musicians in conjunction with a traveling group of 10 permanent musicians. The local musicians hired at each site are to be paid at the federation's standard national rate.

title: REVENUE LOSS SEEN IN TAX REFORM PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, suggested today that the White House is now prepared to accept a net revenue loss in the tax reform program it will propose to Congress this year.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Management
description: A study made in 1975 and just released by the Conference Board, a business research organization, shows that more than $1.6 billion is spent annually by the nation's 7,500 largest, companies for inhouse education of their employees. Page D5.

title: 500 at Bobick Funeral
description: BOWLUS, Minn., June 9 (AP)An overflow crowd of about 500 persons was present at St. Stanislaus Catholic Church today for the funeral of Rodney Bobick, a 25yearold professional boxer who was killed on Sunday night in an automobile accident near here. The mourners included the former heavyweight champion, Joe Frazier, who is manager of Bobick's older brother, Duane.

title: Kellogg Gives J.W.T. Homework on Salada
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, which has been the Kellogg Company's agency internationally for more than 40 years, has just picked up a domestic assignment. Its Chicago office will handle Salada Foods Inc.United States division, which has billings estimated at $1.5 million to $2 million.

title: The U.N. Today
description: June 10, 1977 TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M and 3 P.M.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS PUBLISHER'S PLANE
description: WASHINGTON, June 9A Florida newspaper publisher who has designed and testflown a warplane that he believes could be used by the armed forces won a measure of Congressional approval for his project today over objections of the Defense Department.

title: Whither Alaska's Oil?
description: Although oil will soon start flowing through the Alaskan pipeline, the plans for its distribution are still curiously unsettled. The Pacific Coast states need relatively little of the crude from Prudhoe Bay while the Midwest is thirsty for it. Nevertheless, in the ten years it has taken to plan and lay the pipeline, no definite route has been chosen to move the oil eastward.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 9Assured that there would be no elephantsthe symbolic mascot of the Republican partyin the State Opera's performance Saturday night of Adida, Governor Byrne proclaimed today the start of Festival '77 in the summer cultural season sponsored by the New Jersey Council of the Arts.

title: Books: Muted Memories
description: In A Personal Book, Dorothy Rodgers has written charminglyand with charming discretionof a life lived in the shadow of her husband, the composer Richard Rodgers. It is Dick I think of first, and I always have, she writes with ingenuous pride. Her days, it seems, have for the most part been happy ones. This is a book for the tub, to be read in an atmosphere of steaming fragrance as lulling as her modulated memories.

title: BarryGreenberg Duo Wins Tennis Tourney
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. June 9 (UPI)Rick Barry, the pro basketball star, and Hank Greenberg, the baseball Hall of Famer who at 66 is twice Barry's age, won the Dewar's Cup sports celebrity tennis tournament today at the Hotel Riviera.

title: Kaplan, Rogers Gain Final
description: ROSLYN, L.I., June 9Robert Kaplan of Cranford, N.J., defeated Scott Schwartz of Great Neck, L.I., 64, 61, tonight and reached the final of the Long Island men's tennis championships tonight at the Tower Tennis Club. He will play Weldon Rogers of Great Neck, who defeated Weller Evans of West Orange, N.J., 75, 46, 75.

title: World Cup Qualifying Spices Competition in A.A.U.Track
description: LOS ANGELES, June 9A new factorqualifying for the United States team that will go to the first World Cup Championships in Germany in Septemberadded tension and interest to the 89th annual Amateur Athletic Union national track and field championships which opened today at Drake Stadium on the campus of the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: Broadcasting Chief Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI)  President Carter has nominated John Gronouski, who was Postmaster General and Ambassador to Poland during the Lyndon B. Johnson Administration, as chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting, the White House said today. The board was established as a result of recommendations of the Milton Eisenhower commission, which reviewed the mission of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty in 197273. Mr. Gronouski, 57 years old, a native of Dunbar, Wis., was organizing dean of the LBJ School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas in 1969 and has been professor of economics there.

title: 9 Named to Challenge Seattle Slew's Streak
description: While daylong rain pelted the statue of Secretariat yesterday at Belmont Park, nine owners fearlessly named their horses to challenge undefeated Seattle Slew in tomorrow's 109th running of the Belmont Stakes.

title: Jazz: Back to Hard Bop With Horace Silver's Quintet
description: Horace Silver, who led the jazz world into hard bop more than 20 years ago, has sustained his distinctive qualities as a composer and pianist as well as the crackling drive of his quinat with remarkable consistency for the fist two decades.

title: Broadway
description: EVOLUTION OF THE BLUES has been playing in San Francisco since August 1974, which means it has been one of the most popular shows in that city's history. It is really a history of black music, and it has une basic seta churchand a cast of 18. Now Evolution of the Blues will come here, opening on Broadway late next season, and bringing with it Jon Hendricks. Mr. Hendricks is perhaps best known as onethird of the old jazz vocal trio LambertHendricks R. Ross, but he wrote the book for Evolution of the Blues and stars in it, too. The director is Charles Blackwell. The producers will be Irving Siders, Jerry Wexler and Eugene Wolsk.

title: Gullett and 101 Triumph Give Yankee Trip a Happy Ending
description: MILWAUKEE, June 9A tornado ripped through the Milwaukee area Sunday. The Yankees roared through the Brewers today and last night. You could hardly tell the difference.

title: Cuomo Takes a Long, Hard Look At Himself on TV and Scowls
description: A quizzical Mario M. Cuomo watched yesterday as commercials depicting an angry Mario M. Cuomo were shown on a television screen.

title: Dollar Declines in Tokyo Market
description: TOKYO, June 9 (AP)The dollar fell by almost one Japanese yen today, bringing its slide this week on the Tokyo currency exchange to a total of 2.6 yen.

title: HOUSE PANEL REJECTS RISE IN GASOLINE TAX; NONE EXPECTED IN '77
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The House Ways and Means Committee rejected today an increase in the Federal gasoline tax, evidently killing any such plan for the rest of this year, but approved in modified form a gasguzzler tax on big cars, a key element of President Carter's national energy program.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Annenberg to Give $2 Million to Art Museum
description: Walter H. Annenberg, president of Triangle Publications in Radnor, Pa., and former ambassador to Britain has pledged $2 million to the Philadelphia Museum of Art's Second Century Fund, the museum announced yesterday.

title: Successful Appeal of Parking Ticket May Be Boon to New York Drivers
description: A lawyer who says he spent $1,000 to fight a $15 parking ticket won his fight yesterday, and thousands of drivers who never got around to fighting City Hall may benefit.

title: Track and Field
description: MEN'S TRACK EVENTS

title: 14 Hostages Taken in Italian Jail
description: SPOLETO, Italy, June 9 (Reuters)Prisoners led by three alleged urban guerrillas took 14 guards hostage at Spoleto jail today, the police said: The men were demanding to speak to their lawyers and the press. Two guards who fainted were later released and two others locked themselves into the safety of an unoccupied ??ell.

title: 31 NAMED IN L.I. THEFT OF UNDERSIZED CLAMS
description: Thirtyone persons and three companies were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of stealing millions of undersized seed clams from the Great South Bay in Suffolk County, posing a threat to Long Island's $100 millionayear hard clam industry.

title: Out of Doors
description: WHEN WE ARRIVED at Island Pond in Harriman State Park, our only companions were an elderly man fishing from the rocks near the boat landing and a pair of mating Canada geese in the marsh on the west shore.

title: Truck Kills 8 in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, June 9 (AP)A truck went out of control and plowed into a crowd at a bus stop in central Moscow, killing eight persons and injuring 18, a source at Moscow's first aid service said today. The source said the accident occurred Monday.

title: Young Sees Regime In Rhodesia Falling Within 18 Months
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate here, said tonight that the Rhodesian Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith could not last 18 months more.

title: 31 NAMED IN L.I. THEFT OF UNDERSIZED CLAMS
description: Thirtyone persons and three companies were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of stealing millions of undersized seed clams from the Great South Bay in Suffolk County, posing a threat to Long Island's $100 millionayear hard clam industry.

title: Manhattanites Cross Hudson To Park Cars
description: HOBOKEN, N. J.When Joan Mann of Manhattan wants to take a weekend spin in the country, she boards a train in the 14th Street Port Authority TransHudson tube station, rides to Hoboken, walks two blocks to the municipal parking garage and picks up her 1972 Hornet station wagon.

title: Raytheon Opens Talks With Falcon Seaboard
description: Preliminary talks were announced between the Raytheon Company and Falcon Seaboard Inc. concerning Raytheon acquiring Falcon, a coal mining company. Both said no definitive offer had been. made.

title: ALICE FRANKLIN BRYANT, WAR CRITIC AND AUTHOR
description: SEATTLE, June 9 (AP)Alice Franklin Bryant, an outspoken antiwar activist, teacher, political candidate and author died at her home here Tuesday. She was in her late 70's and had been ill for more than a year.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT IS 1,000 years from Hrotsvitha of Gandersheim, the first woman playwright, to Eve Merriam, the author of The Club, but it is clear from Honor Moore's introduction to her anthology of plays, The New Women's Theater, that women playwrights are sisters in feminism; they have always been concerned with consciousnessraising. A 10thcentury Saxon nun, Hrotsvitha was known as The Strong Voice of Gandersheim  and no wonder. Though cloistered, she wrote six Romanstyle comedies, including Dulcitus, which is about a lascivious Roman governor who plans to ravish three maidens in a kitchen but is so overcome with sexual anticipation that he mistakes the pots and pans for the three virgins and fondles them the whole night through.

title: Soaring Visions and Dashed Hopes
description: The story of theater's 12year struggle to survive at Lincoln Center is a story of soaring visions and dashed hopes.

title: The Bear and the Bee
description: The Soviet Union, reacting like a bear to a bee sting, has taken another clumsy swipe at one James Carter, who has now been accused by Tass of having assumed the role of mentor to the U.S.S.R. and other Socialist countries on the issue of human rights.

title: Money
description: Thursday, June 9. 1977

title: Byrne Presses Button in Ceremony to Open Pipeline Carrying Reservoir Water to Raritan and Passaic
description: READINGTON TOWNSHIP, June 9With a ready, set, go, Governor Byrne pretnd a button today that electrically opened a valve at the White House Station pump house and released five million gallons of water from the 55 billiongallon Round Valley reservoir.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Storey Stuns Memphis Field With 65 and TwoShot Lead
description: MEMPHIS, June 9 (AP)Tom Storey, a former songanddance man in a Las Vegas hotel, scored a surprising sevenunderpar 65 today and established a twostroke lead in the $200,000 Memphis Golf Classic.

title: Toyota Recalls Some Cars in Japan
description: The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest auto producer, said it was recalling 142,119 mediumsized passenger cars after a defect was found in their carburetors. The recall involves several makes and includes 353 police patrol cars. The company noted that the cars, manufactured between July 1975 and December 1976, were all sold in Japan.

title: Chinese OperaA Lavish Spectacle
description: There's a show being given tomorrow evening that includes acrobatics, dance, grotesque makeup and elaborate costumes, and it will all be presented under the rubric of opera. But this will be Chinese Opera, which is not at all like Western opera.

title: Science Tours Offered by Natural History Museum
description: An all day free program of paleontoheical and natural science, with activities and tours run by schoolchildren, will be offered tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. on the grounds of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 81st Street.

title: Extradited Rhode Island Legislator Undergoes Surgery for Cancer
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 9 (AP)William H. Bailey, who was denied his seat in the Rhode Island legislature and was sent to Michigan to serve a prison sentence for shoplifting, underwent more than five hours of surgery today for cancer of the rectum.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended April 30 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) OvertheCounter.

title: Castle & Cooke in East
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., the Honolulu food company, said it had chosen East Windsor, Conn., for its previously announced Eastern mushroom producing facility. A 300;000squarefoot farming operation will produce more than 10 million pounds of mushrooms a year and employ more than 200 people. The facility will be the eompany's.Octh mushroomgrowing operation and its first in the East. Cost of the project was not disclosed.

title: The Standings
description: Friday, June 10, 1977

title: Opera: A Too Lavish Orfeo and a Zesty Orpheus
description: FEW SUBJECTS have inspired more operas than the Orpheus legend. The story of the Greek musician who tames the furies of Hell with his art and brings his wife, Eurydice, back from the realm of the dead has fascinated composers for centuries, and every generation seems to view the myth in a different perspective.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: IN A RARE expansion to a twohour format, CBS News offers, at 9 o'clock tonight, a portrait of The C.I.A.'s Secret Army. This army consists of antiCastro Cuban terrorists operating with impunity from American soil in Miami. The story behind the establishment of this army goes back to the unsuccessful Bay of Pigs invasion of April 1961 and works its way forward through the missile crisis, the assassination of President Kennedy, Watergate and ctontinuing terrorist actions, including last October's destruction of an Air Cubans olane. leaving 73 people dead.

title: Barons' Sale Is Approved By N.H.L.
description: MONTREAL, June 9The Cleveland Barons, a major financial headache to the National Hockey League since the original franchise entered the league in 1967, found their sixth group of owners today.

title: 2 Bankruptcy Petitions Dismissed
description: Bankruptcy Judge Edward J. Ryan has dismissed involuntary bankruptcy petitions against Elliot Meyer and the National Dynamics Corporation. A court order signed by Judge Ryan said the petitions were jurisdictionally defective in that they failed to state an act of bankruptcy as provided by the Bankruptcy Act.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: AROAD THAT LIES between two gracious mansions  one on Fifth Avenue and the other, the home of the Mayor, on the East RiverEast 86th Street leads several lives that seem to be mutually irreconcilable. In its center reaches it is a roisterer, a street of cafes, drinking places and restaurants, and it comes alive with darkness. On other blocks it is an Upper East Side shopping street, a mixture of fast food and boutiques. Elsewhere, it tucks away a tranquil landmark enclave with neat, small old houses that cling like old moss to the new trees that are the highrent high rises. On its western end, East 86th, subdued by Park Avenue and Central Park, becomes rows of quiet, older apartment houses that speak of comfortable, quiet living.

title: Market Place
description: Tagamet, a promising new drug for the treatment of ulcers, cleared a hurdle in Washington this week, with final approval soon by the Food and Drug Administration for sale in the United States considered assured.

title: Seagram Net Off 10.9% in Quarter But 20.6% Higher for Nine Months
description: The Seagram Company, the world's largest distillers, yesterday reported a 10.9 percent decline in net income for the third fiscal quarter ended April 30, but a 20.6 percent rise for the ninemonth perod. Sales in both periods set records.

title: Dance: Debuts
description: AMERICAN Ballet Theater has always thrived on variety, but even in this spiceladen atmosphere the program of Petipa's La Bayadre, Anthony Tudor's The Leaves Are Fading and Glen Tetley's Le Sacre du Printemps, which the company repeated at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night, must be something special. The finedrawn classicism of Petipa, and the modern neoRomanticism of Tudor and the almost abstract agony of Tetley's visualization of Stravinsky's score, can be regarded as a wide stretch of anyone's imagination.

title: The Brezhnev Constitution
description: We have read the new Soviet Constitution, from Article 1The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is a socialist state of the whole people, expressing the will and interests of the working class, the peasantry and the intelligentsia, of all the nations and nationalities in the countryto Article 173Amendment ... shall be by decision of the Supreme Soviet ... by a majority of not less than twothirds of the total number of deputies of each of its chambers.

title: Pop: Gospel With Flash
description: Stephanie Mills's rise from a gospel and soul singing background in Brooklyn to Broadway, where she stars in The Wiz, has been remarkable, especially for a perforrner who is still a very young woman. A decade ago, it would have been almost impossible. Black pop singers who wanted to work in supper clubs, let alone on Broadway, had to polish their styles and divest themselves of the sort of rhythmic drive and hard timbres that have thrilled black audiences for generations. Now, with unabashedly black vocal mannerisms firmly embedded in the mainstream of popular culture, socalled soul singingit really is gospel singing with secular subject matteris at home on Broadway, and Broadway is much the better for it.

title: Tribute to Howard Swanson
description: If you want to get in touch with Howard Swanson, write him a letter. The Manhattanbased composer does not have a telephone. If you work where you live, as I do, he said the other day, a telephone is just distracting. I tried having one once, and had to give it up. I just couldn't get anything done.

title: Antiques
description: BOSCOBEL, the splendid Adamstyle mansion that graces a bluff high above the Hudson River at Garrison, N.Y., has been saved twice in 20 years. First it escaped cannibalization after having been dismantled, but before its parts had been dispersed. Now it has been saved again, this time from the fate of mediocrity into which it had slipped when it was furnishedflamboyantly, but not accuratelyby a decorator and opened as a historical house museum in 1961.

title: CORPECTIONS
description: An Associated Press dispatch from Washington that appeared in The Times yesterday incorrectly listed Alabama instead of Alaska as one of 20 states that will have Medicaid payments cut by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare because of inadequate review procedures. The amount to be withheld from Alaska is $274,083.

title: The Pop Life
description: PERIODICALLY, this column takes it upon itself to conduct a quasirandom examination of the most popular records in the country. The purpose is to ascertain the state of the art, or if not the art, then the state of a country that elevates this stuff into its pop art. The last time we attempted this experiment which consists of picking a week at random and examining the top 10we used a metaphor that evoked the analysis of riverbed sludge for pollutants. In retrospect this seems rather unpleasant for the noble art of American popular music, wino 1977. So let's try another: what we're doing is rather like winetastingsipping through a heady assortment of vintages to discover their quality.

title: New Dorp's Defense Rarely Rests In Bid for P.S.A.L. Baseball Final
description: The end of the school year is reward time for many, of the outstanding athletes and teams in the metropolitan area. For the New Dorp baseball team the biggest prize would be a trip from the Staten Island school to Yankee Stadium on Tuesday for the Public Schools Athletic baseball final. New Dorp plays at Cardozo of Queens today in a semifinal. But for a while it seemed the Centrals' season would end unsuccessfullythe team's No. 1 pitcher moved to New Jersey at midseason. That left Bob Coscia, a sophomore, as No. 1 and he did the job. He was the winning pitcher in New Dorp's 72 quarterfinal victory over Jefferson Wednesday.

title: PORT AGENCY PLANS TO PUT $240 MILLION INTO BUS PROGRAMS
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, blocked recently in an attempt to spend money for new rail transportation, voted yesterday to shift a $240 million masstransit commitment to bus projects.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: Belmont Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Fuqua Raises Its Bid for Avis Stock
description: The New York Stock Exchange halted trading in Avis stock early yesterday as Fuqua Industries made a new bid for the nation's No. 2 car rental cornriany and repoits continued to build that several new bidders would soon enter the picture. A leading Middle Western industrial company, a container maker and pet food companyflush With cash or the ability to raise itwere widely mentioned as possible new bidders.

title: Ford to Shut Two SmallCar Plants
description: DETROIT, June 9The Ford Motor Company announced today it would close two of its smallcar plants with 3,525 workers for a week beginning Monday to keep inventories under control.

title: H.E.W. Fines State $4.6 Million For a Late CareHome Inspection
description: TRENTON, June 9New Jersey, which had considered its controls on various welfare programs, including nursinghome care for Medicaid patients, to be the most efficient in the nation, was fined $4.6 million yesterday for failing to inspect a nursing home on time. Nineteen other states were similarly penalized.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: The last person invited to a boygirl party, as they are known in junior high school circles, is a parent. It's nothing personal, parents are told, but would they please plan to be out of the house on the night of the party? And would they please stock the refrigerator before leaving?

title: A Graham Family Reunion Uncovers Lost Dances of 30's
description: In a dancefilled season, the most talkedabout event has been the revival of Martha Graham's 1931 Primitive Mysteries, which will be on view tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M., and at 2 P.M. tomorrow at the LuntFontanne theater.

title: For Children
description: Folk Music for Children

title: Sunday Bachanalia on WBAI
description: There will be Bach around the clock on WBAI this Sunday as the listenersponsored FM radio station celebrates its second annual Bach Day with 20 hours and 30 minutes of programming devoted to the music of Johann Sebastian Bach.

title: Events/Sports
description: 2:303:25 P.M., WNYCAM: Commencement Excercises for John Jay College of Criminal Justice,

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, June 9, 1977

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: SauterFinegan Echoes at the Y
description: The SauterFinegan Orchestra, the most innovative big jazz band of the 1950's, made adventurous use of piccolos, oboes, English horns, tuba, xylophone, harp and a huge battery of percussion instruments as well as elephant bells, kazoo, toy trumpet and keyboard glockenspiel, all in addition to the customary jazz band trumpets, trombones and saxophones. It disbanded 19 years ago, in 1958, after a controversial sixyear career.

title: High Court Voids New York ContraceptiveSales Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that it is unconstitutional for states to insist that nonprescription contraceptives be sold only in drug stores or by doctors.

title: Foundation Sued to Force Disclosure of Its Finances
description: HACKENSACK, June 9A classaction lawsuit was filed here today against a charitable foundation in Orange, demanding a full accounting of all donations it has received and dispersed since its founding in August 1974.

title: Ralph Lauren Joins Coty's Fashion Hall of Fame
description: Ralph Lauren, who has brought a special panache to his women's sports clothes, became the newest member of fashion's Hall of Fame yesterday. He was selected for the top award of the Coty American Fashion Critics by a jury meeting at the St, Regis Hotel.

title: PATRICIA J. THOBEN, 44; AIDED THE HANDICAPPED
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)Patricia J. Thoben, a lifelong paraplegic who was instrumental in ending discriminatory treatment of handicapped persons by airlines, died of cancer in Georgetown University Hospital on Tuesday. She was 44 years old.

title: Soybeans Meet Further Selling
description: CHICAGO, June 9 (AP)Commodity futures in the soybean complex again ??ame under active selling pressure today in the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Swedes to Try Soviet Hijacker
