description: STOCKHOLM, June 9 (UPI)The Swedish Government today rejected Soviet appeals for the return of a 37yearold Soviet engineer who hijacked a domestic Soviet airliner on May 26 over Latvia and forced it to land in Stockholm. Vasily Sosnovsky, who had asked for political asylum, will be tried for the hijacking on June 17, a Stockholm court official said.

title: Licensing Is Planned For Ringling Abroad
description: Arthur Spear, president of Mattel Inc., told the annual meeting yesterday in Los Angeles that the company had initiated international licensing procedures for its Ringling BrosBarnum & Bailey Combined Showns Inc. unit looking beyond our existing traveling shows. He noted that the limited number of domestic cities having facilities for a large circus had prompted the move for licensing circus units abroad.

title: Poland Facing Demands for Rights And Discontent Over Shortages
description: POZNAN, Poland, June 3One year after workers' riots over food prices shook Poland, the authorities are confronted, with a growing human rights movement and popular discontent over widespread supply shortages.

title: Delay in Indictment Upheld Despite Loss Of Two Witnesses
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Supreme Court ruled today that even if prosecutors have amassed enough evidence to prove a criminal case against someone, they are permitted to wait many months to charge him formally while they seek possible accomplices.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 10, 1977

title: HOUSE PANEL WARNED ON DANGERS OF COAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 9A House subcommittee examining the future impact of doubling the country's use of coal as a substitute for oil and gas heard gloomy reports today that cast doubts on President Carter's energy plan.

title: Children of Couple Who Fled Bulgaria Reunited With Parents
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The State Department announced today that the Bulgarian Government had allowed the young daughters of a Bulgarian couple who came to this country 10 years ago to join their parents here yesterday.

title: Ford Honored, Urges An End to Terrorism
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford, in a speech in New York City last night, called for an end to terrorism and attendant lavish media attention, and also to bargaining with terrorists or giving them sanctuary.

title: Bateman Selects Norcross to Succeed Todd as the State Republican Chairman
description: TRENTON, June 9Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican candidate for Governor, said today that David F. Norcross, his campaign manager, would be the next Republican state chairman, and predicted that the Republican platform would contain a no income tax plank.

title: About Real Estate
description: Hearings on the future of the Federal Housing Administration are on the agenda in Washington this summer at a time when the F.H.A. is bearing a heavy load of operational problems.

title: HERMAN HEUVERS
description: TOKYO, June 9 (Reuters)A Germanborn Jesuit scholar and playwright, Herman Heuvers, honorary pastor of St. Ignatius Church and former president of the Catholic Sophia University of Tokyo, died of a heart attack here today. He was 86 years old.

title: TWO SPACE PROJECTS FACE FUNDING BLOCK
description: Two major scientific projects of the National Aeronautics and Space Administrationa mission to orbit and probe Jupiter and the placement of a large optical telescope in Earth orbithave run into strong opposition in Congress.

title: Memorial Service for Jenkins
description: A memoral service will be held Saturday for Cornelius W. (Connie) Jenkins, one of the first black supervisors in the New York City post office. Mr. Jenkins died on May 20 at the age of 78. In 1964, when he was named assistant operations manager, he was the highest black official in the city postal system. The services will be held at the First Presbyterian Church, East Lincoln and North Columbus Avenues in Mount Vernon, N.Y., where he lived.

title: OILFIELD REPORTED FOUND IN BIG FLORIDA SWAMP
description: MIAMI, June 9 (AP)An oilfield has been discovered in the middle of the Big Cypress Swamp, but the size of the find may not be determined before next year, Exxon USA has annnounced.

title: Rumors of Amin Travel WidelyHe Stays in Uganda
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 9The Uganda radio reported this morning that President Idi Amin was in London but then announced this evening that he had returned to Kampala not from Europe but from Uganda's southern border where he had consulted with Zambian and Tanzanian revolutionaries.

title: Michigan Nurse Testifies She Did Not Poison Patients
description: DETROIT, June 9Filipina Narciso took the witness stand today in Federal District Court to declare her innocence of charges that she murdered and poisoned patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, where she worked as a nurse.

title: Vietnamese Who Fled to Speak Out Find It Isn't Easy
description: TORYO, June 9When I left my country, I had a different idea of what I would do in the outside world, said Nguyen Cong Hoan dejectedly. I have had much sadness. I must not let myself be discouraged, although I feel that my hands and feet are tied and I can't do or say much.

title: TASS SAYS SOVIET EXPERTS SEE JUPITER AS EXPANDING
description: MOSCOW, June 9 (UPI)Soviet scien tists contend that the planet Jupiter a sun still in the process of being born rather than a dying sun as some astronomers have long believed.

title: Jesus Rock Now a New Musical Industry
description: ATLANTA, June 9On the stage, The Second Chapter of Acts looks like any other rock group, bluejeaned, shirts open, guitars slung down low in front of the microphones.

title: People in Sports
description: Wesley Walker, who Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets says is the fastest wide receiver we've had since Don Maynard, signed a series of oneyear contracts with the National Football League club yesterday.

title: Stark Leads College Golf With 72142
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., June 9John Stark is a strong young golfer from the University of Houston who yesterday admitted that he'd rather play the Northern courses with the high grass than the hard pan around the greens down home in Texas.

title: Jim Hill Has Been Dreaming
description: Dr. Jim Hill is a practical man, a matteroffact guy, a veterinarian with knowledge and experience, and no starryeyed dreamer. To be sure, the first time he laid eyes on the yearling now known as Seattle Slew he did stick his neck out far enough to declare. If this isn't a race horse, my name's not Jim Hill, and later when Paula Turner was breaking the colt on a farm in Maryland, even before Billy Turner started training Slew for his first race, Dr. Hill did predict that the horse would win the Champagne Stakes.

title: World News Briefs
description: NATO Official Says Soviet Has Deployed New Missile

title: U.S.Arab Accord Reached in Dispute On I.L.O. Measure
description: GENEVA, June 9 (Reuters)United States and Arab delegates today patched up a dispute over an issue involving Israel that had contributed to an American threat to withdraw from the International Labor Organization next November.

title: Gold Declines in Europe While Dollar Closes Mixed And Pound Eases Slightly
description: LONDON, June 9 (AP)The price of gold fell back today in London and Zurich, Europe's principal bullion markets. The dollar closed mixed on European money markets.

title: People and Business
description: Paul Red Adair, the expert who headed the successful capping of the North Sea oil well blowout in March had not, as of a month ago, even sent a bill for the spectacular job. We'll get around to it someday, he said. He did.

title: Dow Off 3.14 to a 909.85. Close; Movie Stocks Up, Falcon Adds 5
description: The movie stocks were Wall Street's star performers yesterday as the general market retreated slightly after two days of higher prices.

title: Caracas Official Won't Confirm Oil Price Report
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 9 (AP)A highly placed Government spokesman refused today to confirm a published report indicating that Venezuela would forgo a 5 percent oil price increase scheduled for July 1.

title: Dutch Hostages' Relatives Wait and Worry
description: GRONINGEN, the Netherlands, June 9 Relatives of the 51 passengers held on a train five mites south of here for the last 18 days have passed through the emotional states of anxiety, fear and despair. Now all they feel is helplessness, they say.

title: Vesco, Fugitive Financier, Asked to Leave Costa Rica
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 9 (Reuters) Costa Rican President Daniel Oduber said tonight he had asked Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, to leave the country.

title: G.M. Wins a Delay in Answering Complaint Involving Its Engines
description: The General Motors Corporation today won a delay until June 30 to answer a complaint by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz that thousands of buyers of 1977 Cadillacs, Buicks, Pontiacs and Oldsmobiles got cars equipped with engines made by other divisions.

title: Malcolm Acts to Clear Cloud of Suspicion Over Prisons as a Result of 28 Indictments
description: Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm, in an effort to clear a cloud of suspicion he said was hanging over his department in the wake of 28 indictments in a major corruption scandal at the Broolyn House of Detention, said yesterday that he had been told by four of the city's District Attorneys that they knew of no similar investigtions in their boroughs.

title: Dr. Edith B. Jackson Dies at 82; Was Pioneer in Care of Newborn
description: Dr. Edith B. Jackson, who was a pioneer in the observation and treatment of infants and very young children and developed roomingin care of newborn babies by their mothers, died Suday at her home in Denver. She was 82 years old.

title: A Bit of the Old In New Bookstore
description: A bit of Old New York is returning to old New York. Its people, trades, history, sights and celebrations are being gatheredfor sale it should be saidat the New York Bound Bookshop in one of the oldest parts of town, at the corner of Fulton and Front Streets, at the South Street Seaport Museum.

title: GOULD DID NOT DISCLOSE REALTY DEAL, S.E.C. SAYS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Gould Inc. and two executives of the electronics company with failure to disclose a $940,000 real estate deal involving some company officers. Named in the suit were William T. Ylvisaker, chairman, and Edwin C. Parker, financial vice president.

title: VIETNAM NATIONALIZES MICHELIN SAIGON PLANT
description: PARIS, June 9Michelin, the giant French tire company, announced today that its Saigon factory had been nationalized by the Vietnamese authorities, last April 20. The takeover followed seizure of all Michelin plantations in South Vietnam in the wake of the Communist takeover of 1975. The plantations, covering a total of 250,000 acres, were acquired by Michelin in the former French colony of Indochina in the 1930's.

title: O'Malley Undergoes Surgery
description: LOS ANGELES, June 9 (AP)Walter O'Malley, chairman of the board for the Los Angeles Dodgers, underwent chest surgery today at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., the baseball club announced. Although no details were given, a Dodger spokesman said the surgery had been described as very successful. O'Malley, 73 years old, reportedly was resting well and will spend several days recuperating at the clinic's Methodist Hospital.

title: Theater: A Splendid, Deadly Richard III
description: IF A MAN STANDS up on stage and announces that he is a monster, we may register it with our mind, but it is not so easy to accept it with our emotions.

title: Badillo Enters Campaign for Mayor
description: Standing in front of a big oblong sign that read Badillo ...for all minorities, Representative Herman Badillo declared his mayoral candidacy yesterday with tart attack on Mayor Beame's financial talents and an appeal to the lawandorder issue that politicians believe is paramount in the minds of New Yorkers.

title: Two Trucks Rip Net Over Hudson, But Bridge Beam Catches the Cabs
description: Two tractortrailers bound for New Jersey on the lower level of the George Washington Bridge narrowly missed falling into the Hudson River yeserday afternoon when they jackknifed in tandem, hurtled off the roadway and ripped through a steelmesh safety net parallel to the roadway.

title: KLM Royal Dutch
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, the only foreign flagship carrier with publicshare ownership, reported profitable operations in its fiscal year ended March 31 for the first time in five years.

title: C.A.B. BACKS FLIGHTS TO LONDON FOR $135
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday it had recommended Presidential approval of a Laker Airways plan for noreservations, nofrills New YorkLondon service at a oneway rate of $135.

title: Carter Veto of LaborH.E.W. Bill Would Surprise Party Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Democratic Congressional leaders met with President Carter this morning and said afterward that they would be surprised if the President vetoed the LaborHealth, Education and Welfare appropriations bill, scheduled to come up on the floor of the House next Wednesday.

title: Bond Prices Gain as Rise in the Money Supply Slows
description: The nation's money supply continues to grow more slowly, the Federal Reserve disclosed yesterday, and the slowdown caused the credit markets to advance strongly late yesterday afternoon after the data were punshed. The basic money supply fell $700 million in the week ended Wednesday, but the broader money supply rose $600 million. Most shortterm interest rates monitored by the central bank declined slightly, while the latest threeweek average of commercial paper rates put Citibank closer to raising its prime rate on loans if it decides to follow its formula this morning.

title: Meadowlands; ENTRIES; Hoses ??sted in order of post positions
description: FIRST$9,000, pace, cl., mile.

title: BILL VOTED TO RETAIN 10CENT PHONE CALLS
description: ALBANY, June 9The New York State Assembly today adopted a number of bills dealing with consumer and environmental issues, including one that would bar any increase in the 10cent charge for local telephone calls from coin boxes.

title: Port Is Held Unlikely to Regain Lost Arab Business
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 9An official of the Port of New York said today that chances for regaining lost Arab business were slim even though a Federal antiboycott law would equalize competition for Arab trade among Northeast ports.

title: A Thames Tribute Paid to Queen Elizabeth
description: LONDON. June 9The Thames, London's broad avenue to the sea, was transformed into a vast stage today as this maritime nation paid spectacular tribute to Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Special KoreaInquiry Prosecutor Urged by Congress Republicans
description: WASHINGTON. June 9The two top Republican Congressional leaders urged President Carter today to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate alleged South Korean bribery, giftgiving and other favors intended to influence United States policy toward Korea.

title: HIGH COURT RULES AGAINST DAMAGES TO INDIRECT BUYERS
description: WASHINGTON June 9 (AP)The Supreme Court ruled today that indirect purchasers do not have the right to collect damages from businesses that illegally increase prices.

title: So we to Triangle: Foundation Woos Ghettos, Government
description: JOHANNESBURGElsewhere, a foreigner who advocated a total reformation of the political and social order to a business gathering might expect a chilly reception. But when Andrew Young did just that here recently at a dinner for some of South Africa's most powerful executives, he was warmly, in some cases enthusiastically, applauded.

title: Beaumont's Future
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 10Whatever each man's feelingsJoseph Papp obviously was unhappy, an dit has to be a shock for the chairman of the board of a theater to learn suddenly he has no theaterthere was a fundamental agreement in the statements made yesterday when Mr. Papp announced that he was quitting Lincoln Center. Although he talked about other things as well, Mr. Papp said that no theater company could make a profit there. Amyas Ames, the board chairman whose lap is once again occupied by the neverresolved question of what to do with the place, said Mr. Papp's departure showed the need to find a way to pay for serious theater in America.

title: SURPLUS OF PAYMENTS IN BRITAIN AT $3.4 BILLION
description: LONDON, June 10 (UPI)Money and confidence poured back into Britain in the first quarter of this year, to provide a balanceofpayments surplus of nearly $3.4 billion.

title: Alabama Legislature in Final Hours Votes Funds to Keep Courts Going

description: WASHINGTON, June 10Democratic leaders voted today to reduce the number of delegates to the party's 1978 midterm conference, a possible arena for airing criticism of President Carter. But the decision may not stick.

description: CAPE TOWN, June 10 (AP)South Africa said today it would appoint an administratorgeneral for SouthWest Africa instead of proceeding with earlier plans for a transitional government to independence.

title: Screen: 'Rollercoaster' on Track:Suspense Melodrama Stars Widmark and Fonda
description: "Rollercoaster," which opened at theaters all over town yesterday, is effective pop entertainment that, like an amusement-park ride, deals in the sensation of suspense for the foolish fun of it. It is not, as you might suspect, one of those not-quite-all-star, group-jeopardy movies ("Earthquake," "The Towering Inferno") in which disaster strikes in the first reel and continues to pick off actors for the next two hours or so."Rollercoaster" is a suspense melodrama of the sort that Alfred Hitchcock does best and most wittily (and sometimes most cruelly), and one wonders what he might have made from the material that James Goldstone, the director, treats benignly, as if he didn't want to rattle the teeth of the very young or those of the somewhat older crowd who wear detachable replacements. The Sensurround sound effects, though noisy, are more amusing than scary.The screenplay has the air of something assembled through the good old Hollywood process of, first, treatment, then screenplay, followed by suggestions, counter-suggestions, compromises and rewrites. In whatever manner it was written, it accomplishes what it sets out to do. With a minimum of wasted energy it dramatizes the attempts of various safety officials and law officers to apprehend an extortionist who has been sabotaging roller-coasters from coast to coast.There's no mystery to the audience about the identity of the fellow, played by Timothy Bottoms, a cool young man who carries on a cat-and-mouse game with his prinicipal adversary, a Los Angeles safety inspector played by George Segal."Rollercoaster" opens with one quite spectacular rollercoaster crash, but after that it's mainly concerned with tracking the killer from Los Angeles to Pittsburgh to Chicago, to Richmond and then, for the grand finale, back to Los Angeles for a rollercoaster ride that features a 360-degree loop.Considering the material, Mr. Goldstone rather resolutely refuses to allow the rides themselves to dominate the film. As if to emphasize that this is a man-hunt movie instead of a series of cinematic simulations of roller-coaster rides (like the one featured in "This Is Cinerama," which made a number of non-fans queasy), he continually cuts between his subjective camera, mounted on a speeding roller-coaster and the point of view of people on the ground (including us, who always expect the worst).It is just one of the various intelligent options he has exercised to make a movie of such good sport, and one that makes few unreasonable demands on our credulity. The actors, including Richard Widmark as a gritty Federal agent and Henry Fonda as a safety executive, take their roles with the sort of graceful gravity that never betrays the nature of the film."Rollercoaster," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), treats its mayhem so discreetly that, indeed, one has to look fast on a couple of occasions to know exactly what dreadful event has taken place. The fun is not in the violence, which is almost nonexistent, but in its possibility.

title: U.S. and Soviet Will Start Talks On Pact to Ban All Nuclear Blasts
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The United States and the Soviet Union will begin discussions in Washington on Monday on a possible agreement to ban all explosions of nuclear devices, the State Department announced today. President Carter has made such an accord one of the priority arms control goals of his Administration.

title: Geiberger's 59 Lowers Record For P.G.A.
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 10(AP)Al Geiberger, a softspoken, 39yearold golfer, slowmoving and seemingly casual under a broiling sun, shot a 13underpar 59 today that broke the PGA Tour record for 18 holes. Geiberger posted his score in the second round of the $200,000 Danny ThomasMemphis Golf Classic.

description: Governor Byrne remained silent yesterday on a plan by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to shift a $120 million spending commitment from mass transit rail projects to bus improvements in both states.

title: THEATER MEN REACT TO PAPP DEPARTURE
description: Joseph Papp's announcement Thursday that he was pulling his New York Shakespeare Festival out of Lincoln Center caught most theater people by surprise. But by late yesterday they had turned their major attention away from Mr. Papp himself and to the questions raised by his departure: Is the Vivian Beaumont a workable theater in its present configuration? Who or what sort of an institution should succeed Mr. Papp as the Lincoln Center theater constituent? How are the nonprofit performing arts to be sustained financially?

description: Questions on Page 17.

title: A Story With a Happy Ending
description: Last year the sidewalk at our corner was resurfaced. As soon as it was dry, the youngest of the children who hang out at the corner sat on the sidewalk squares. They looked like country kids enjoying the new grass in the fields, but to some of my neighbors these children and their friends, ranging in in age from 8 to 18, were dangerous.

title: Appalachian Women Just Beginning Fight On Poverty and Bias
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va.  Though many people here are trying to bring about change, most of the gains enjoyed by women elsewhere have not come to poor and rural Appalachia, where women are still expected to be fully subservient to their husbands.

title: Chicago, a Wonderful Dance Fete

It is being produced by Geraldine Freund, includes the Chicago Balletfor whose partial benefit the festival performances are being givenand involves the participation of 18 guest dancers from nine countries, including an American Judith Jamison from the Ailey company.

title: State Elections Starting in India

The voting, for state, assemblies in 10 of. India's 22 states, will be spread over five days, ending Tuesday.

description: TANGSHAN, China, June 10The rusting remains of a factory, a mangled burnedout train, a vast plain of rubblethis is all that is left of Tangshan. Last July the world's worst earthquake in centuries killed about 750,000 in and around this north Chinese city.

Herman Radillo got into it the other day by announcing that he would fight for New York; and Bella Abzug, who announced several weeks ago that she would fight for New York, has already kayoed the New Democratic Coalition in a brisk tworound warmup bout.

title: Bridge:

description: Harriet Hoctor, a noted ballet dancer, died Thursday in Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital in Arlington. She was 74 years old and lived in Lorton, Va.

title: Officer in Disguise Seizes a Meterman On Bribery Charge
description: It was not the most serious crime he had ever dealt with but Police Officer John Brady improvised some detective work yesterday to catch a meterman in what he said was the act of taking a bribe.

title: PRESIDENT SUGGESTS ENERGY INDUSTRIES SWAYED LEGISLATORS
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  President Carter suggested today that Congressional committees had surrendered to pressure from the oil and automobile industries by diluting his energy program and said the people of this country will be the ones to suffer if his energy proposals are thwarted.

title: WEST THE TOP BUYER OF SOVIET OIL IN '76
description: The Soviet Union, for the first time, shipped more oil to the West last year than to its Communist allies as soaring Siberian production and high world prices apparently made it attractive for the Russians to divert more oil to earn Western currencies.

title: About New York
description: ALBANY, June 10Moving right along, Perry B. Duryea has invested three more years of his life waiting for one last chance to try for the governorship next year. Politics is like that; the years of an ambitious life can become slender poker chips for keeping a stake open in a roundabout game and waiting for a big hand to be dealt.

title: Fears of a Rise in Interest Rates Fade and Stock Prices Edge Up
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday against a news background that tended to calm Wail Street fears of higher shortterm interest rates. Some oil issues showed good gains.

title: Balancing in Brazil
description: In her brief visit to Brazil this week, Rosalynn Carter met with President Geisel and also with two missionaries who told her they were tortured in a Brazilian jail. The conjunction of those two meetings was symbolic of the Carter Administration's emerging approach toward Brazil and other Latin nations ruled by military oligarchies. The apparent intention is to maintain normal channels of diplomacy and communication with the governments but some contact also with their democratic critics. This marks a radical departure from the practice of recent Administrations and has created a good deal of tension in hemisphere regimes.

title: Notes on People
description: The official announcement in Tokyo called him His Excellency Mister Michael Joseph Mansfield. But it was just plain Mike Mansfield, the former Senator from Montana and majority leader, who donned formal wear to officially present his credentials as United States Ambassador to His Imperial Majesty Emperor Hirohito. According to protocol, the new Ambassador was given his choice of transportation onto the Imperial Palace groundseither a Rolls Royce or a black lacquered carriage pulled by two imperial horses and bedecked with brocade, shiny lanterns, uniformed footmen, and the bright gold chrysanthemum seal of the Japanese Imperial family. Just plain Mike, like most arriving ambassadors to Japan, chose the horsedrawn carriage.

title: G.M. to Transfer 900 Out of New York City
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it was moving 900 employees from its New York offices on Fifth Avenue to Detroit over the next 15 months.

McCarthy, the former Democratic Senator from Minnesota, told a gathering of corporate executives today that they did not believe President Carter would be able to make good on his pledge to balance the Federal budget by 1981.

Most of the finals will be run here tomorrow.

title: Jazz Clubs Fight War of Decibels In New Orleans

title: CITIBANK IS KEEPING PRIME RATE AT 6%
description: Citibank, the nation's second largest bank after the Bank of America and often a trendsetter on loan rates, kept its prime lending rate unchanged yesterday at 6 percent.

title: Connecticut Blushing Over MomandPop Utility
description: SOUTHWICK, Mass., June 10In the long northward march of progress through Connecticut, the power companies and the state's regulatory authorities appear to have overlooked a small, half  forgotten community on the boundary that buys its electricity from a family in Massachusetts.

title: A Symposium on Herbs in an Urban Setting
description: The way to make cranky people more cheerful is to sprinkle a bit of basil on their breakfast eggs each morning. Basil, after all, is the happy herb.

title: Dollar Is Firm in Europe On Light Trading Volume; Gold Price Down Again
description: BRUSSELS, June 10 (UPI)The dollar held steady on European money markets today, closing with narrow fluctuations. Trading was light except in the Scandinavian nations, where it continued comparatively active.

title: Japan to Regulate Silk Deals
description: TOKYO, June 10 (UP)Japan will regulate silk fabric imports to protect domestic silkraising farmers, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The ministry said restrictions would be made under a cabinet order concerning import trade controls requiring importers of silk fabrics to obtain prior permission from the ministry. Ministry officials said the regulations would be enforced by the end of this month.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 11, 1977

title: The Separate Roads
description: BELGRADEWhat is now called Eurocommunism can in a sense be said to have started here 29 years ago when Tito faced down Stalin's attempts to stamp out his national heresy. But there are many differences between Eurocommunism and Titoism, both in theory and practice. It is indeed questionable whether either exists as a definable ideology.

title: French Reported Starting Work To Develop Own Cruise Missile
description: PARIS, June 10 (Reuters)France has begun development of its own cruise missile capable of carrying nuclear or conventional warheads over long distances at low altitude, informed sources said today.

title: For Clarity in Eyeglass Prices
description: Americans waste about $400 million each year on overpriced eyeglasses. They are the victims of excessive charges by uncompetitive retailers, paying more than necessary either because they mistakenly equate high price with high quality, or because they are unaware that identical frames and lenses can be purchased for less at discount stores.

title: JAMES EARL RAY FLEES A PRISON IN TENNESSEE WITH 6 OTHER CONVICTS
description: PETROS, Tenn., June 10James Earl Ray, serving 99 years for the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., climbed over the wall of Brushy Mountain State Prison with six other inmates and escaped tonight, the authorities said.

title: Beame Breaks Tie on S.I. President
description: With Staten Island's fourman City Council delegation split 22, Mayor Beame cast a tiebreaking vote yesterday to elect Anthony R. Gaeta the interim Borough President of Staten Island.

The transaction includes the afternoon Citizen, with a paid circulation of 6,000, and the weekly White County Citizen, which as a circulation of 11,000. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the South Korean and Japanese Governments supported the Administration's plan to withdraw American troops from South Korea so long as adequate measures were taken to insure the security of Northeast Asia.

title: Albany's New York City Agenda
description: AS state legislators start talking about adjournment by the Fourth of July, urgent matters affecting New York City remain unattended. Traditionally, the closing days of the Albany legislative session are as hectic as the ??ulton fish market at 5 A.M. Strong leadership should be exerted to keep city matters from getting trampled in the closing rush.

title: JAMES EARL RAY FLEES A PRISON IN TENNESSEE WITH 5 OTHER CONVICTS
description: PETROS, Tenn., June 10James Earl Ray, the convicted assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., broke out of the Brushy Mountain state prison with five other convicts tonight and fled into the mountains of northeast Tennessee.

title: The New York Jazz Quartet, Aided by Carol Slone, at Peak
description: Playing this week and next at Hopper's, Avenue of the Americas at 11th Street, the quartet, led by Roland Hanna, the pianist, with Frank Wess playing tenor and soprano saxophone and flute, and George Mraz on bass and Richie Pratt, drums, not only has strikingly imaginative, virtuoso soloists at each position, but projects a constant sense of ensemble excitement as it sets one jazz style against another in a richly varied repertory. An ethereal, soaring melodic piece, highlighted by Mr. Wess's flute and tenor saxophone, may give way to a lusty, rocking bit of funk colored by a skillfully calculated edge of rawness that is followed by a dazzling drive and a serious tempo through Sonny Rollins's Oleo.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Broadway column of yesterday's Times the founder, chairman and thief officer of Atlantic Records was listed as the late Ahmet Ertegun. Ertegun is alive.

description: FORT MITCHELL, Ky., June 10 (AP)The fire that killed 161 persons at the Beverly Hills Supper Club on May 28 started in a concealed area and burned for some time before being discovered, ati investigation team said today.

title: MAX B. MEYERS, EDUCATOR IN CITY SYSTEM, WAS 73

title: 'Gods of the Plague,' 1969 Fassbinder Film, Is Quintessential American Gangster Movie
description: "Gods of the Plague" (Gotter der Pest), this week's new Rainer Werner Fassbinder film, was made in 1969, the year he also made his second film, "Katzelmacher," which is still one of his best, as well as his first. "Love Is Colder Than Death," which has not yet been released in this country. "Gods of the Plague" opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater on a double bill with "The American Soldier," a 1970 Fassbinder film that had its premiere here in January 1976.I mention this chronology because the New Yorker Theater's Fassbinder festival is presenting so many of the director's films in such short order that keeping them straight can be as difficult as sorting out which plots go with which titles of Frank L. Baum's Oz books.Although "Gods of the Plague" is described as a sequel to "Love Is Colder Than Death," which I haven't seen, it makes an appropriate companion piece to "The American Soldier," a comically dead-panned contemplation of American gangster films of the 30's and 40's. Where "The American Soldier" comes close to parody, though, "Gods of the Plague" is absolutely straight, which is not to say that it's realistic or that its narrative is important for itself. "Gods of the Plague" is a distillation. It's as if Mr. Fassbinder and his actors had taken a half-dozen Bogart films, mixed in an equal number of Cagneys and Robinsons, added a few Rafts and maybe one or two Monogram melodramas for flavor, boiled them until the stock was almost entirely reduced, and then used the residue to make this film in which gestures and attitudes, characters and events, have the formality of an art that's been dead for 200 years."Gods of the Plague" is the quintessential American gangster film if the quintessential American ganster film had been adapted and updated to accommodate a bunch of small-time Munich hoods for whom the holdup of a rather ordinary suburban supermarket is "the big job." If "The American Soldier" is about movies, "Gods of the Plague" is one of the movies it's about.Its hero is Franz (Harry Baer), a taciturn ex-con whose release from prison opens the film. When he goes to a restaurant with his girlfriend for his first taste of freedom, he orders Spam and eggs. He likes Spam and eggs, he says. Joanna (Hanna Schygulla) asks what it was like in prison. "No worse than on the outside," says Franz. His joylessness is profound, and it's consistent with his vision of a world in which everyone is an inmate.The plot of "Gods of the Plague" is not quite as complex as that of "The Big Sleep," but it helps to have some program notes, because Mr. Fassbinder, aping Franz's taciturnity, doesn't waste time on explanations. Franz drifts from woman to woman, becomes implicated (wrongly) in his brother's murder, resumes a relationship with a black hood nicknamed Gorilla (Guenther Kaufmann), who actually murdered his brother, and agrees to participate in the supermarket heist to finance an escape to a paradise that may or may not be Greece.It's a world of perpetual gray, of chance meetings, faithlessness, revenge, informers and crooked cops. People talk but they don't communicate. Someone says something and there's a 10-second delay before there's any response, as if the person spoken to felt that if he waited long enough there'd be no reason to answer. Everyone is mannered, even Franz's loony mom, who is not unlike the mom in "The American Soldier." Occasionally it recalls Jean-Luc Godard's "Breathless," but where Mr. Godard's characters have dreams, Mr. Fassbinder's have been sentenced to life imprisonment and know it."Gods of the Plague" is the work of a very young man who has just discovered the secret pleasures of angst. It's full of the movie associations that once so amused Godard, Truffaut and Chabrol, and it's impeccably performed by members of the Fassbinder stock company.

title: Books of The Times
description: For about four years Steven Phillips was an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, a prosecutor of accused criminals, who did his job well. He was young when he joined the D.A.'s staff in 1971. When he left, in 1975, he was old, old with the kind of age that comes when one's job calls for scrutiny of bodies pocked with stab wounds, of infants drowned in boiling water, of old people beaten by muggers. He learned, regretfully, that cynically displayed emotion is a powerful and useful courtroom tool and that appeals to the stomach quite often are more persuasive than those that rely on the exactness of the law.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Bobby, proclaim the ads for The Van, couldn't make it & till he went funtruckin'! No matter how you judge movies, The Van must rate as foolish, technically poor, outrageously sexist, cheapie exploitationmovie. It's entertainment designed primarily for sale at Hollywood's takeout counterthe drivein theater. Brought to us by the producers of The Porn Porn Girls, another movie you've never heard of but which earned an estimated $4,300,000 last year, The Van is an exuberantly crass, Rrated, California comedy about a young man named Bobby, played by actor Stuart Getz who looks a little bit like a reallife Raggedy Andy. Bobby works in a carwash and has as his dream the ownership of a van, a sort of superpanel truck whose interior is outfitted with a bar, a mirrored ceiling and a waterbed.

title: Nine Holes Where Golfers Meet Their Match

These holes have been selected for geographical and topographical variety. The club professionals and others who have helped pick them do not say they are the toughest on the Island, but consider them outstanding tests for players who shoot in the 90's. So take the head cover off your No. 1 wood and let's begin, using the regular tee markers instead of the championship distances.

The academy has sent a letter to the United States delegation to the Law of the Sea Conference, now under way at the United Nations, saying that such restrictions would be a disservice to mankind.

title: THE FRESH AIR FUND FOCUSES ON CULTURE
description: After watching the Dance Theater of Harlem's teenage troups give a performance of Peter and the Wolf, Gary Joseph decided that I liked the part where Peter slipped the rope around the wolf's tail.

title: $6,498,117 Track Handle 2d Highest at Belmont
description: Belmont Park enjoyed the second largest ontrack handle in its history yesterday when the 70,229 fans wagered a total of $6,498,117. of that amount, $1,446,714 was bet on the 109th Belmont Stakes. The record ontrack handle was produced in 1971 when a crowd of 82,694 poured in $6,972,209 while watching Canonero II fail in his bid for a Triple Crown.

title: ExVesco Yacht Leaves Nassau Mysteriously
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, June 11 (AP) A 137foot motor yacht once owned by Robert Vesco, the fugitive financier, has left Nassau harbor as quietly and mysteriously as it arrived four months ago, carrying an eightman crew and no passengers.

title: Cynthia Exton Has Nuptials
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Cynthia Exton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manning Phillips Mason Exton of Southport, to Dr. Paul Timothy von Oeyen, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Roland von Oeyen of Ubly and Harbor Beach. Mich.

title: William N. Fitzpatrick Jr. Marries Joyce J. Garman
description: Joyce Johanna Gorman and William Norwood Fitzpatrick Jr. were married yesterday in the Lady Chapel of the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Mary Our Queen in Baltimore. The Rev. Ken ieth Doyle, chaplain of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Doane Stuart Academy in Albany, performed the ceremony.

title: Lawyers Making Music Together
description: EDWARD N. COSTIKYAN, an attorney and former Manhattan Democratic chairman, pulled out of New York's mayoral contest recently. But he retains an unusual leadership position in Westchester: He conducts more than 100 lawyers, doctors and friends who gather once or twice a year to sing and play 18thcentury choral music.

title: British Open Draws 730 With Top U.S. Group
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, June 11 (UPI)A record number of 730 golfers, bettering last, year's previous best of 718, have entered next month's $170,000 British Open championship at Turnberry, Scotland.

title: Simpson, U. of Houston Victors in College Golf
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., June 11Southern California's unemotional Scott Simpson won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's individual golf championship for the second straight year today by one stroke, his margin a year ago.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IT WOULD be unrealistic, of course, to expect highly favorable data on the state of the nation's economy week after week in an unbroken string. Trees don't grow to the skies, and the fines on the economic charts seldom push uninterruptedly for an extended period in one direction. So, while the latest figures on some of the key economic indicators might not have been rampantly bullish, they showed nothing to indicate that the current business expansion was deteriorating after more than 25 months on its upward leg.

title: Frederick Eayrs Jr. Weds Miss Notman
description: In the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral in Washington yesterday afternoon, Andrea Trotter Notman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Notman of Washington, was married to Frederick Earle Eayrs Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eayrs of Middleboro, Mass.

title: Prison Had Relaxed Its Security for Ray After a Court Ruling
description: NASHVILLE, June 11For the first three years after his capture in London for the murder of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., security surrounding James Earl Ray, one of the nation's most notorious prisoners, was extremely tight. Tighter, in fact, than the law allowed.

title: Weddings
description: Dr. and Mrs. David B. Peters of Brooklyn, New York announce the marrlage of their daughter, Holly, to Marc Golden, at the Park Lane Hotel, on Sunday, June 12.

title: Undefeated Seattle Slew Wins Belmont and Captures Triple Crown
description: Seattle Slew won the 109th running of the Belmont Stakes yesterday and became the first undefeated horse to win thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown. He covered the 1 miles in 2:29 3/5, four lengths ahead of Run Dusty Run. Sanhedrin finished third.

title: Reischauer
description: At Tokyo American Schoolwith many Japanese studentsthere were no distinctions of race or nationality. Besides Japan, there are at least three other important facets of Edwin Reischauer's career. Harvard, China and John K. Fairbank (the two are almost interchangeable), and the U. S. Government.

title: Mrs. Margaret Lamont, Activist For Peace and Civil Rights, 72
description: Margaret Lamont, who had been active in peace and civilliberty causes and was the former wife of Corliss Lamont, the author and teacher, died Friday of heart disease at her home, 450 Riverside Drive. She was 72 years old.

title: Watershed Decision
description: ANY DAY NOW Northeast Utilities may sign an agreement with the Metropolitan District Commission of Massachusetts to siphon water from the Connecticut River. The water would be siphoned up Northfield Mountain and by means of a 10mile tunnel transferred into a reservoir that provides most of the drinking water for the 1.6 million residents of Greater Boston.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES 1977
description: the maiden volumes of a long series of poets who later became famous. To name a few: Hervey Allen, James Agee, John Ashbery, Sandra Hochman, John Hollander, Adrienne Rich, Muriel Rukeyser. Many of the collections won prizes: Alan Dugan's 1962 entry won both the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award.

title: 100 Young Hands Put Up a House
description: HOUSE for sale. Beautiful sixroom shake shingle ranch. One thousand three hundred and thirtynine square feet. Three bedrooms, two full bathrooms, eatin kitchen. Fully insulated. Opening bid: $9,800.

title: Jim Crow, Union Member
description: IT used to bother George Meany when critics accused the American labor movement of betraying its rebel heritage by turning unionists into members of the middle class. Now the patriarch of the A.F.L.C.I.O. takes all such comments as compliments, not reproaches. His only regret, he says, is that not all workers have yet made it into the middle class, but labor is working to get them there. Once does. Meanv cheerfully confides, it will keep right on pushing until all of the erstwhile prisoners of starvation move up yet another notch to become fullfledged members of the upper class. in his view, that will usher in a genuinely classless society, one in which everybody has a snug place at the top.

title: 3 Yachts Await Trials
description: The preliminary trials to select the United States defender of the America's Cup will begin off Newport, R.I., next Saturday, June 18, with two new boats and one old. The new ones are Enterprise and Independence, the older one Courageous. As a new vessel, Courageous successfully turned back the last challenge in 1974, defeating Southern Cross from. Australia, 4 races to 0.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: Todaytony Brook Rotary, North Shore Show Grounds, Old Field Club, Stony Brook, L.I. Regular, green, amateurowner, nonthoroughbred, special, maiden, junior and children's working hunters; green conformation hunters, intermediate and special jumpers, adult horsemanship, ponies, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: J. L. Moore, Medical Student, Weds Susan Howell, a Nurse
description: Susan Howell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer B. Howell of Bay Shore, L.I., was married yesterday to James Lewis Moore, son of Dr. and Mts. James Moore of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Donald S. McPhail performed the ceremony in St. ??? copal Church in Bay Shore.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: I am writing to set the record straight regarding a recently published letter by J. Carroll Bateman of the Insurance Information Institute of New York on medicalmalpractice insurance rates. feel that it is important that the public know the true facts concerning contingency fees.

title: Red Smith
description: Three or four strides before he reached the finish line, Jean Cruguet stood up in his stirrups and flung his right fist aloft in triumph. it was a typically Gallic gesture, an emotional flourish such as had not been witnessed in 108 earlier Belmont Stakes, but this was the 109th and Cruguet was astride Seattle Slew, the only undefeated horse that ever won a Triple Crown. Cruguet had a right to his moment of melodrama, but that didn't silence the dramatic critics in the jockeys quarters.

title: Improvement in SovietEgyptian Ties Seen After Talk
description: MOSCOW, June 11Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy flew back to Egypt today after two days of talks that raised hopes for an improvement in relations.

title: Robert H. E. Elliott, An ExMedical Dean At Columbia College
description: Robert H. E. Elliott Jr., former associate dean, of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and past chair;man of the Joint Allied Health Council of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, died at the center Friday after a long illness. He was 70 years old and Thad been living in retirement in Wainscott, L. I.

title: Everybody Got Into the Act
description: For the actors of the Yiddish stage, it was a rich life, warm and essentially intimate. The profession was so interconnected by marriages, divorces and love affairs as to resemble some great quarrelsome family.

title: AROUND THE Gardan
description: Warm weather firings on the tick population in grass and brush areas; check pets and children after a day's play outdoors. Cool weather (below 55 degrees) affects tomato pollination and causes flowers to drop without setting fruit. Give annurils and, transplanted vegetables a booster feeding with watersoluble fertilizer At onehalf rate. Follow spray schediaes to control fungus diseases on fruit trees and roses.

title: Horseradish Is A Novelty to Grow For Unusual Flavor
description: Submerge a root and grow plantation! Horseradish (Armorica rusticana) the pungent herb grown over 3,000 years ago in Greece, is a novelty to put in the vegetable garden. Easy to grow and free running, the plant vows to produce bumper crops as it becomes a permanent boarder on the grounds.

title: Ludmilla Thorne is a freelance writer who specializes in Russian subjects.
description: Ludmilla Thorne is a freelance writer who specializes in Russian subjects.

title: Poetry
description: Its libertine discursiveness and allusiveness, are partly a way of emphasizing the commentator's presence and his benign interpretive violence. Bloom is blessedly free of the spite and rancor that we find in many contemporary critics; he treats other commentators with much amenity, but they are always hisaudience, and his object is to stress the extent of his originality.

title: Envoy to Senegal is Named
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)President Carter said yesterday that he would nominate Herman J. Cohen, a political counselor at the embassy in Paris, to be Ambassador to Senegal and Gambia.

title: Caroline Ruth McFarland Bride on Coast Of Lieut. Comdr. David Moyer Jr., U.S.N.
description: Caroline Ruth McFarland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew McFarland of Carmel, Calif., was married yesterday afternoon to Lieut. Comdr. David Baxter Moyer Jr., U.S.N., son of Mrs. Milton Sands Dillon Jr. of Bernardsville. N.J., and the late Mr. Moyer.

title: Puerto Rican Five Wins
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., June 11 (AP)Puerto Rico's Olympic basketball team beat a team of Eastern allstars from the mainland, 9691, last night, sweeping a twogame exhibition series.

title: MANHUNT IS PRESSED FOR JAMES EARL RAY; ONE CONVICT GIVES UP
description: PETROS, Tenn., June 11A force of 150 prison guards, state and local policemen, sheriff's deputies and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation used helicopters and bloodhounds today to search the rugged mountains near here for James Earl Ray and four other inmates who escaped from the Brushy Mountain Penitentiary last night.

title: Radio
description: 810 A.M., WKTU: Mellow Child. Children's songs and stories.

title: Lane's Persistence
description: An examination by The New York Times has determined that much of the information on which Congress decided to reopen its investigation of the assassinations of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., is unfounded, and that it was Mark Lane, the author and lecturer, who provided the House subcommittee with most of its new leads.

title: What They Do
description: Amid the smoky blue mountains of North Carolina, in the town that Thomas Wolfe couldn't go home again to, near the great estate a Vanderbilt built to vie with Old World barons, a traditional annual rite of American book publishing will be conducted late this month. More than 325 representatives of 75 publishers, members of the Association of American University Presses. are due to converge on Asheville as guests of the University of North Carolina Press.

title: Little League: It's Not All Fun
description: HARRINGTON PARK IONCE vowed never to coach or manage a Little League baseball team. Not me, I told a friend several years ago, you won't drag me into that mess. I was not about to become an involved, frustrated, overwrought, oversensitive Little League father living fantasies through my children.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: William Sakren

title: Rebutting Galbraith on TV
description: Well, it's one sure way to have the last word in a debate with John Kenneth Galbraith, the liberal economist: Splice a rebuttal to the end of each segment of The Age of Uncertainty, his television series on the evolution of economic thought.

title: The Week's Concerts
description: Today

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Corbett Has Nuptials
description: In Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Troy, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, Constance Ann Corbett and Juan Andres Miejia, both of Washington, were married by Msgr. William M. Slavin.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: TORONTO It was in June, 1956, that we in the West got our first view of a Soviet ballet company. it was in Paris, and the company was not one of the two major troupes (the Bolshoi Ballet did arrive in London in September of that same year) but Moscow's second company, from the Stanislaysky and NemirovitchDanchenko Theater, whose director and leading choreographer was the late Vladimir Bourmeister. There were many surprises in store for us that season, and I remember leaving Paris almost dazednot so much by the dancing, which was not that strange because we had seen, by that time, quite a few Soviet dancers in concert, but by the esthetic.

title: Marion Rita Smith is Bride
description: Marion Rita Smith, daughter of D? and Mrs. Joseph Seton Smith of Lynd hurst, Ohio, and Frederick Joseph Per lack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G Perlack of Ludlow, Mass, were married yesterday in St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Belford Hills, N.Y The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William T. Smith, an uncle of the bride. He was assisted by the Rev. John Chwalek, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced April 28 that it was beginning a broad reexamination of its rules concerning shareholder participation in the corporate electoral process and corporate governance generally. The immediate cause of the commission's interest in shareholder democracy was clean During the last two years, the S.E.C. explained, more than 350 corporations have made disclosures of a wide variety of questionable and illegal corporate practices including bribes, kickbacks, illegal political contributions and improper accounting practices. The almost universal characteristic of the cases reviewed by the commission has been the apparent frustration of our system of corporate accountability.

title: MAYORS HAIL CARTER BUT VOICE CONCERN
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 11In their first gathering since Jimmy Carter became President, the mayors of the nation's largest cities convened today and voiced restrained praise for the new Administration coupled with renewed complaints that the national economic policy often harmed their cities.

title: 3 Share Lead by Stroke In L.P.G.A. Title Event
description: NORTH MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., June 11 (AP)A threeway tie developed today in the third round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship when Judy Rankin and Pat Bradley moved up and shared the lead with Chako Higuchi. All had sixunderpar, 36hole totals of 210.

title: Carlina Paul Married to Richard Della Pietra
description: Carlina Farncesca Paul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frederick Paul of Upper Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Alfonso Pietra, son of Mrs. Alfonso Della Pietra of Middlebury, Conn., and the late Dr. Della Pietra. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lattingtown, in Locust Valley, L.I., by the Rev. Charles G. Newberry.

title: Reserve Mining Starts Work on Waste Dump Site
description: STAPAUL, June 11The Reserve Mining Company, which each day for 22 years, has discharged 67,000 tons of potentially harmful iron ore wastes into Lake., Superior, has begun preliminary work on a 11mile disposal basin on land in northeastern Minnesota.

title: EXAIDES OF DR. KING LINK ESCAPE TO PLOT
description: Black leaders who were close associates of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Said yesterday they feared that James Earl Ray's prison escape was part of a conspiracy and that Dr. King's murder might never be solved.

title: HONE CLINIC
description: MANY homeowners have learned the basics of working with copper pipe and tubing, and have mastered the techniques of making neat soldered joints with one of the handy propane torches available in all hardware stores. However, one problem that often gives the amateur trouble is making a soldered connection to an elbow or other fitting that is already soldered at the other end. The trouble arises from the fact that when enough heat is applied to make the solder flow freely into the new joint, the heat sometimes loosens the old joint at the other end of the fitting. A simple way to solve this problem is to use the method illustrated in the accompanying photograph.

title: 3 From Bronx Hurt in Gunfire
description: HAVRE de GRACE, Md., June 11 (UPI) A sniper opened fire early, today on a chartered bus carrying a bowling team from the..Bronx and injured three persons, the Maryland state police reported. Bertha Lowe, 64 years old; of 3802 Pauling Ave., was shot in the face when three bullets shattered the windshield of the bus. Her husband, Richard B. Lowe, 74, end John Morrishow, of 3223 Bruner Ave. suffered cuts. All were treated at a hospital and were discharged.

title: Letters
description: Was Robert Moss's article on the international economic order (Let's Look Out For No. 11) meant as satire or fantasy? Far from being given without Cabinet permission, the $10 million loan to Cuba was discussed thoroughly at that level. I challenge Mr. Moss to cite any initiative of comparable policy significance undertaken by the Canadian International Development Agency without proper approval. C.I.D.A. did not irrationally start sending au tomatic dishwashers into the Senegalese desert, but rather provided modern equipment, including one large dishwasher, for Canada's first project in Senegal, a 900student residential school in the nation's capital. The Haitian project is for $21 million, not $40 million, and for integrated rural development, riot solely education. The rented power boat, needed because rugged terrain makes land travel impossibly slow, is presumably a small vessel seized by the Haitian Government from a tax evader, and later loaned to the

title: Landmarks Of Prehistory
description: WHILE it is widely known that Westchester is rich in history, those who have looked into it have found that it is literally bursting with prehistory as well. Places where ancient features of rock and topography poke through morerecent formations are clearly visible during a drive north along the Hudson River, east on Route across the top of the county, and south on 684 down the Connecticut border.

title: Reilly Report Highlights
description: Following are excerpts from the summary of the report by a special oneman grand jury into the arrest, interrogation, trial and conviction of Peter A. Reilly on charges of brutally murdering his mother in Canaan on the night of Sept. 28, 1973. The report, issued June 1, was written by Judge Maurice J. Sponzo of Superior Court after a fivemonth investigation.

description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., June 11What's that sweet smell?

title: MiniMAC's
description: New York politicians, looking at the rates as high as 11 percent that are available on Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds sold in lots no smaller than $5,000, have been urging the state agency to sell MiniMAC'sbonds in denominations as small as $50.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: OFFHAND, there might not appear to be any obvious link between an informationgathering lour of Europe and Israel that Representative Thomas. 1. Downey completed last week and 3,200 jobs on the Island. But there was, and the portents were not especially encouraging.

title: Sara Leland and Merrill Ashley Step in Gallantly for City's Jewels
description: George Balanchine's Jewels is ballet subtly unbalanced by the overwhelming appeal of its central Rubies section. The portion drew even more attention to itself Thursday evening, as two of the New York City Ballet's dancers, Sara Leland and Merrill Ashley, assumed elements of the female lead at the New York State Theater. To add spice to the occasion, Miss Ashley had, only moments before, danced in the first section.

title: State Title to Elmont
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 11Elmont High School defeated Ward Melville of Setauket, the defending Long Island champion, 1211, tonight, and won the first New York State lacrosse championship at Hofstra University.

description: LOS ANGELES LAKERS

title: Votes in Congress
description: I. Vote on housing bill, authorizing funds. for housing and community development assistance programs for fiscal years 1978 through 1980, passed, to 7, June 7.

title: Salvias Produce A Few Surprises
description: TWO salvias, scarlet sage and the grayleaved kitchen sage, are well known to New Jersey gardeners. All the other treasures in the salvia clan come as pleasant surprises. Some are aromatic herbs that have scented whole hillsides in Mediterranean countries for thousands of years; others were not dispovered until the New World was explored.

title: NOXFICTIONN IN BRIEF
description: My reading this month turns out to have a curious consistency. By chance I have chosen from the Book Review's groaning shelves four books that reexamine literary figures, a critical activity well known to the publishinghungry academic community. But in several of these volumes this return is journey of interest to the general reader as well.

title: Elizabeth M. Fried Engaged
description: Elizabeth Melgin Fried and Michael Paul Richman, 1975 graduates of Vassar College, plan to be married in July. Mr. and Mrs. Irving M. Fried of Wynnewood, Pa., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Richman of Long Beach, L.I. Miss Fried expects to receive a master's degree in international affairs May 18 from Columbia University Her fianc attends the Columbia Law School.

title: Scenes From a Marriage: A Golfer's Lament
description: The most climactic moments of my marital life have all taken place on the golf course. I am not referring, of course, to those evanescent matters so briefly engaged in and so swiftly forgotten. But rather to those deeply felt watershed events that indelibly color the relationship between a man and a woman. Joy and elation, despair and ecstasy, They have been the stuff of my marriage and all of them played out the par4's of life.

title: Geiberger Retains Lead by 3 Strokes
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 11Al Geiberger could do no better today than Of 72 but, still buoyed by his record round of 59, retained a lead of three strokes in the third round of the $200,000 Danny ThomasMemphis Golf. Clissic.

title: Intelligence Officials Are Split By Plan to Create Overall Chief
description: WASHINGTON. June 11Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence, has set off a major institutional struggle within the Carter Administration by advocating new, strongly centralized control of the nation's sprawling intelligence community under what his critics contend would be an intelligence czar.

title: Bergland Holds Talks in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 11 (Reuters)  President Suharto today conferred with Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland on conomic relations between the United states and Indonesia. Later Mr. Bergland ??? talks with Agriculture Minister ??? Hadiwidjaja oaqvays of increasing American agricultural exports to Indone

title: The Greek Isles: An Odyssey
description: One can spend a lifetime traveling the Greek islands and never see them all. There will always be another ruined temple, another whitewashed village  another day of the eternal summer that Byron wrote about.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Wall Sheet's lovehate relationship with round numbers on the Dow Jones industrial average reasserted itself last week. This time around, the Street loved Dow 900 because it resisted further selling at that level and, in turn, signaled some support for the entire stock market.

title: Truck Driver Stars On Television, Too
description: TO BELIEVE in stereotypes is not to believe that Bonnie Moffett is a truck driver. She just doesn't fit the standard cartoon image of an overweight, tattooed, stogiesmoking Tugboat Annie on wheels.

title: Miss Brokaw Bride Of Kirk P. Lindvig
description: Jeannette Sobotta Brokaw, who graduated last month from Denison University, was married yesterday to Kirk Philip Lindvig, a Denison graduate now in his second year at the Ohio State University College of Medicine.

title: Bird Fossil Found in China
description: HONG KONG, June 11 (Reuters)The fossilized remains of a bird between 12 million and 23 million years old have been discovered in Shantung Province, the Hsinhua press agency reported today.

title: More Coney Island Areas Approved for Swimming As Water Quality Rises
description: Because of what it regards as continued improvement in the quality of water along the Coney Island beach front, the Department of Health has approved for swimming this summer six additional blockfrom West 29th Street to West 35th Street. The area from West 35th Street to Seagate, however, is still not recommended for bathing.

title: She's Sweet On Bees
description: DR. MARYANN }CARPEL likes the weeds on her front lawn. Especially the dandelions and clover, for it is in spring that the nectar flows quickest from these plants to tempt the palates of the county's honey bees.

title: A stunning value in a functional wall system.
description: A beautiful wall system104 longof storage space, bookshelves, curio display, TV and HiFi areas, droplid bar and more! if you know Jon Krogstad's reputation for quality, you know I shun the shoddy and I feature the finest. So please don't confuse this with vague lookalikes in the marketplace. This value is extraordinary and I am proud to feature it at both of my New Jersey showplaces of Good Design.

title: Jean Leslie Aaron Married
description: Jean Leslie Aaron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Aaron of New York, and Stuart Goldshein were married yesterday at the Sky Terrace Roof of the St. Moritz Hotel. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Goldshein of Flushing, Queens. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: ELMSFORD'Camelot. Tuesday to Sunday (through July 17). The Best of Opera,'atlas performed by singers from leading opera companies. Tomorrow only. Opens at 6:15 P.M., dinner at 7 P.M., show at 8:30 P.M. Sundays one hour earlier. Evening Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. $15.50 to $17.50. Reservations. 5922222.

title: MANAGEMENT GIVING A HAND TO NEW YORK
description: This city is a very complicated animal, the business executive said thoughtfully with an overtone of discovery.

title: Mrs. Carter And Controversy
description: During her tour of Caribbean and Latin American countries, Mrs. Rosalynn Carter has like a good ambassador, carefully avoided controversy. But last week, she met with two United States missionaries who said they had been treated like animals in a Brazilian jail. And controversy followed.

title: Praise for a Nassau Court
description: THE Nassau County Family Court has been cited for doing an outstanding job in clearing up a major case backlog that had all but choked the court just 18 months ago.

title: Polygamist Sues Movie Concern
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June I I (AP)Alex Joseph, a polygainist in Utah, and one of his wives have filed a $4 million lawsuit in against two movie companies. The action names William Edward Thrush Productions Inc. and American Republic Pictures Inc. as defendants. The Josephs allege the movie Alex Joseph and His Wives injures their reputations.

title: Children and Books
description: FLORENCE BEAUJEAN is 70 now, and retiring after teaching for 34 years at the Greenacres School in Scarsdale. But she has toughminded ideas about what illustrated books are best for very young children, and to her, still, There's nothing to compare with reading to a child in your lap, your arms around the child, and sharing a book.

title: A Classic Problem
description: The news that high school students are not, by and large, infatuated with the classics is no calamity as the world goes. Still, confirmation of that perennial fact life by a Times survey of teachers and students in cities and suburbs must trouble anyone who believes that an education that scants great literature cannot much of an education at all.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Saturday, June 11, 18th day. Weather cloudy, track muddy. 1977 by Triangle Publications Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: OPEC Mystery
description: Since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries split over prices six months ago, the oil industry has been abuzz with rumors of compromise, capitulation, further division and stalemate. Now, at last, outlines of a solution to the dispute appear to have emerged, although they still lack confirmation.

title: The CanAm is Returning With Quebec Race Today
description: After a twoyear absence from North American motor sports, the CanAm series for sports cars returns today with a different lookso different. in fact, that some people are calling Son of CanAm, For tee thing, the series no longer is for the unlimited of road racing Each car must be powered by a fiveliter stock block engine or a twoor threeliter racing engine. in some cases, sports car body work, with use of a conversion kit, has been attachedto a Formula 5000 chassis.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the pattern. Black squares indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: Another Raid By Rhodesia
description: Rhodesia launched another raid into neighboring Mozambique, hoping to cripple black nationalist guerrilla bases before the nationalists can launch their own offensive. The military maneuvers can only impede the chances for negotiated settlement of the transition from white to black power in Rhodesia.

title: Sibelius Slept Here
description: IDON'T know about George Washington, but Jean Sibelius slept at the Ellen Battell Stoeckel estate in Norfolk, and the traditions of great music continue to pour vividly through the summer countryside there, courtesy of the Yale University School of Music and Art.

title: Hearings by Council Scheduled This Week
description: The following public hearings by New York City Council committees will be held this week:

title: Turkey Votes for More Coalition
description: Turkey can't seem to escape coallAns. Although the Republican People's Party made significant gains in last week's Turkish election  its leader, Bulent Ecevit, is likely to be the next Prime Ministerthe lack of a clear majority means that the country faces four more yearn of patchwork government and continued uncertainty in coping with Turkey's serious domestic and foreign difficulties.

title: 500 Worst Pittsburgh Criminals Targets for Priority Prosecution
description: PITTSBURGH, June 11 (AP)The city's 500 most active criminals have been selected for a priority prosecution program to get them swiftly through the courts and into jail if they commit, new crimes.

title: Two Races for the Fleet on the Sound
description: TWO BOAT RACES for money and fun have been scheduled for next month on the Sound. Prize money of $3,000 will be distributed among eight winners in The New York Timessponsored 80mile New YorkNew London Invitational Sail Regatta, which starts off Larchmont breakwater in late afternoon on July 7. And for those who don't wish to race for money, one division will receive trophies only.

title: STAMPS
description: The landscapes of Europe are depicted this year on the 1977 Europa stamps issued by most of the nations in the Conference of European Postal and Telecommunica tions Communications (CEPT).

title: Television This Week
description: special onehour edition with participants in the National Mayors Conference being held in Tucscon: Mayors Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark, George R. Moscone of San Francisco, Harvey I. Sloane of Louisville, Tom Moody of Columbus, Ohio, and Lewis C. Murphy of Tucson.

title: END RENT CONTROL, NEW YORK CITY URGED
description: The Temporary Commission on City Finances urged yesterday that New York City's rent control and stabilization programs be phased out over the next decade and said that such a move could increase local propertytax collections by tens of millions of dollars a year.

title: Will the Public Pay More for Less Service?
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Postal Service's Board of Governors, its policymaking body, begins each monthly meeting with a prayer. Oh God, intoned board member Charles H. Coddington at one session, bless this agency, so buffeted with criticism from so many quarters.

title: GARDENING
description: THE rhododendrons look magnificent this year; the severe winter seems not to have done any damage as far as the blooms are concerned, and the handsome shrubs are showing off for everyone.

title: In His Homeland He is Jean Who?
description: Jean Cruguet, the Frenchman who rides Seattle Slew, has not become a national hero in his homeland. The jockey hero of the American Triple Crown races has not been contacted by the French Consul in New York, the French Ambassador in Washington or the French President in Paris.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Architectural drawing is the stepchild of the arts. After seeing the exhibition of Two Hundred Years of American Architectural Drawing the Cooper Hewitt Museum (2 East 91st Street, through July 17), I have been wondering why the subject has always had a kind of secondclass status. By any definition, this is a major show, and it is also superb one, both as a record of the American building genius and as a moving experience of a consistently subtle and exquisite esthetic. Many of the drawings are breathtaking their technical mastery and expressive skills, and their beauty is further enriched by their revelation of conceptual ideals. Here is architecture as it comes straight from the mind and the eye and the heart, before the spoilers get to it.

title: Carly Simon The Fans Don't Scare Her Anymore
description: If one hadn't known any better, one might have expected some timid little flower of a performer. Carly Simon may be a wellknown pop singer and songwriter, but this was her return to live performing after five years of stage fright. People who have stage fright are supposed to be shy. Instead, at the Other End in Greenwich Village recently, Miss Simon strode confidently onto the small stage, radiating a smile and a confidence so overpowering that her whole retirement seemed as if it must have been a whim.

title: Track and Field
description: 100Yard Dash1, Ed Vlncoe, Wheatley 0:09.6; 2, Ray Allen, Long Beach 0:09.7; 3, Herman Simon, Troy 0:09.8; 4, Ed Rubio, Mt. Assumption 0:10.0; 5, Van Johnson, Centereach 0:10.0.

title: To the Helsinki Station
description: Contrary to popular impression and partisan propaganda, it was President Ford and Secretary Kissinger who helped design the Helsinki club that President Carter has been wielding to promote human rights Communist Europe. So Helsinki is best laid aside as an issue in American politics. Mr. Ford tripped on his own words about Eastern Europe and the Helsinki accords in last year's campaign debate and Mr. Carter gave him a demagogic shove on the way down. That should be behind us.

title: Theater
description: Tristate

title: Managing the Kennedy Millions
description: The Kennedy fortune, estimated at $300 million to $500 million, has advanced the political careers of a United States President and two Senators from one of the nation's bestkdown families.

title: IRVING E. MILLER
description: Irving E. Miller, a wellknown clothier who was president of Miller Brothers Men's Clothing of Brooklyn at 1120 Kings Highway died Thursday of a heart attack at Syosset (L.I.) Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: More Urban Aid Is Not Enough
description: The urban aid formula that the United States Senate proposed last week is even more generous than the House's to the graying cities of the Northeast and Midwest. Though the forecast is that the House formula will ultimately prevail (it has Administration backing), the Senate action may signify at least the beginning of change in habits of a body that has been dominated by rural legislators.

title: Summer Splash
description: Young Parisiennes, with their special chic. have started many a fashion. The newest is big blouson tops blousing over full, print skirts. Here is the look, adapted for New Yorkers to wear on the city's streets this summer. The polyester tops have been modified slightly, but are still loose, big but not bulky. The fluid skirts some with shawls  are made of tissueweight wool and polyester challis in pretty flower prints to wear on into fall.

title: His Inventions Save Lives
description: AS A BOY growing up in Plainfield, Walter Jinotti was a habitual tinkerer. He had a way of toying with the world around him. Now, some of his toying, far from being child's play, helps to save lives.

title: Rail Planning: A 2Way Track
description: Few years, but for various reasons Bridgeport has been unable to attract new business as Stamford has. Lower Fairfield County is now saturated with office parks and corporate headquarters and is beginning to overflow upcounty. Bridgeport hopes to catch some of that fallout.

title: Deaths
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300: NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: In Memoriam
description: 1SALLY MEHRSTEIN3 YEARS ADORED. SISTER, MOTHER, GRAND. MOTHER. SADLY MISSED AND LOVED FOREVER. JEANNE, MAX, NORMAN, ROBERT AND GRAND. CHILDREN.

title: Renaults Are in Control at Le Mans
description: LE MANS, France, Sunday, June 12The 24 Hours of Le Mans auto race began at 4 P.M. yesterday and seemed close to being settled just three hours later when the main Porsche entry was eliminated by motor failure.

title: Latin War Over Teaching of Language in Italy Ends in Compromise
description: ROMEAfter a 15year campaign with battles waged in Parliament, schools, newspapers and cafes, Italy's Latin war has come to an end.

title: Questions/Answers
