description: For the past two summers, our peonies developed a good number of flower buds but they never enlarged to become flowers. What is the cause and cure? M. T. S., Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Article 20  No Title
description: ROBERT CORAM is a freelance writer who lives in Atlanta, Ga.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, June 11 (AP)Commonwealth leaders struggled today over the form and substance of a possible condemnation of President Idi Amin of Uganda. Prime Minister Robert Muldoon of New Zealand predicted that Commonwealth leaders, holding their conference here in conjunction with silver jubilee celebrations for Queen Elizabeth II, would strongly condemn President Amin's military Government, accused of engineering a campaign of mass murder.

title: Why is an Outdoor Concert Like a Tax Rebate?
description: Ummer is the season of surplus. Even in belttightened New York, the slightly reduced horn of plenty pours forth extra daylight, indolence, chlorophyll, and club soda. Most people, save those helplessly bogged in the Puritan ethic, feel that we have earned a good time. We expect one trom nature and our neighbors; from the city and Exxon; from merciful breezes and our own pasts. We emerge in various conditions of fortune from condominium, triplex, and summer sublet, warily trusting that nature is still bountiful and entertainment cheap. In case they are not, we nave learned now to cater our own sensibilities, to cart along the paraphernalia of our favorite hedonisms. The largest number of cultivated pleasure seekers can be found in the city parks, lolling in states of amused intolerance or Babylonian satisfiction at those, headiest, historic and least expensive of summer gambolsOutdoor concerts.

title: Strictly by the Book Is Boom in Midtown
description: Bookstores are booming in midtown.

title: New York Teachers To See 5,000 Pupils in Move on Truancy
description: To reduce the 60,000 to 80,000 hardcore truants in New York City's school system, attendance teachers will this month visit 5,000 pupils who will be entering high school next fall and who have been absent at least 50 days this school year.

title: Around the Nation
description: MEMPHIS, June 11 (AP)The battle for the leadership of the Young Republican National Federation is over, with the forces of Roger Stone of Virginia sweeping over the moderateled opposition.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees end their series against the Minnesota Twins at 2 P.M. today in Yankee Stadium. The Kansas City Royals come into Yankee Stadium for 8 P.M. games tomorrow, Tuesday and Thursday (Wednesday is an off day). The Mets play the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium at 8 P.M:, Thursday and Friday and 2:05 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Clark Center for the Performing Arts, which has been associated with Meredith Monk, Alvin Ailey, George Faison and others at its former YWCA home on the West Side, is commencing its third annual dance festival at CUNY Graduate Center Mall this weekend. The program, Friday through next Sunday at 8, will show off works by nine new choreographers. Thereafter, 12 dance troupes will have a weekend apiece to perform in the agreeable midtown space. (See Dance)

title: LkNGUAGE FURY FAILS i TO STIR QUEBEC TOWN
description: ROBERVAL, Quebec, June 8  The Bound and the fury of Quebec's current debate over language rights are barely heard in this quiet rural community where everyone speaks French and allost never worries about doing so.

title: Mr. Papp Withdraws
description: Joseph Papp, whose New York Shakespeare Festival has operated the theaters at Lincoln Center for four years, leaving. Announcing his decision, Mr. Papp cited both nancial and artistic reasons, but emphasized the artistic. He came to Lincoln Center in 1973 intending chiefly to present new American plays, but a first season of such productions failed. Programs of classics have not fared better.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AFTER 15,625 hours on the Long Island Expressway (and the roads that were there before it opened), as a commuter for over a quarter of a century, I gave up carpooling between Roslyn and New York City.

title: Miss Chaves Wed To F. M. Ballard
description: Cristina Maria Chaves, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jose M. Chaves of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to F. Michael Ballard, son of Mrs. Edwin W. Roberts and Fred L. Ballard of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: CHILDABUSE PARLEY AT RIKERS IS SCORED
description: A new organization interested in reducing child abuse introduced a new program at the women's prison on Rikers Island and immediately ran into criticism from inmates and others who called irrelevant.

title: Caramoor Plays A Children's Tune
description: FOR more than 30 years now, the Caramoor concerts in Katonah have been one of Westchester's cultural glories, and this season, with its bountiful harvest of recitals, operas and orchestral programs, ought to be no exception. in future columns, I'll try to cover some of those events, but meanwhile I want to alert you to the Saturday morning shows for childrena spate of delightful happenings that often get overlooked in the shuffle of the regular attractions.

title: Music in Review
description: Carol Stewart, a pianist who is on the faculty of the University of Southern California, and Jan Schmidt, California soprano whose early training was as a cellist, gave a joint program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. it was the first New York appearance for both of them, but Miss Stewart proved better prepared for the debut than her partner.

title: Prison System: Reforms Studied
description: THE state is beginning to tackle some of the complexities of reforming its prison system. From the solitaryconfinement cells at Trenton State Prison, where the toughest and most recalcitrant convicts smolder and sometimes erupt, to Yardville and Annandale, where youthful offenders are offered schooling and training in trades, the corrections system is under scrutiny as prison officials try to find out why it is not working.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: MORMACVEGA (Amer. Rep.). Rio de Janeiro June26, Santos 28, Buenos Aires July 3 and Montevideo 5; sails from 23rd Street, Brooklyn.

title: Patricia Morehead Plays Courageous Oboe Program
description: Patricia Morehead, a Canadian oboist on the faculty of the New England Conservatory, made her New York, debut on Thursday night with courageous program of 20thcentury Music in Carnegie Recital Hall. She had the expert assistance of her husband, Philip Morehead, pianist, and Barbara Jacobson, flutisttogether file three function as the New England Chamber Trio.

title: Italy Reduces Bank Discount Rate, Reflecting Confidence in the Lira
description: ROME, June 11 (AP)The Italian Government today reduced the discount rate from 15 to 13 percent. it is the basic rate at which the central bank lends money to commercial banks.

title: Summer Brings Scientists Back To Loch Ness
description: As summer returns to the Scottish highlands, so have the searchers returned to Loch Ness in their quest for the monster alleged to dwell in the deep and idark waters.

title: TV VIEW
description: Late spring is here and reruns are in the air, leaving reviewers to the device of roundups containing not terribly logical assortment of observations. To begin, this past week has once again revived the stiffupperlipped rumor that there will always be an England. Queen Elizabeth's Silver Jubilee generated enough pomp and pageantry to distract the English from their economic woes and to bedazzle American television.

title: Diana B. Hole, Attended by 7, Wed to Lawyer
description: Diana Belden Hole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Witherspoon Hole of Devon, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard Stoner Strickler Jr., a lawyer in New York with the firm of Sullivan & Cromwell.

title: DEPARTMEIITS
description: Picture Credits: 7. Mannequin by Adel Rootstein. 42. Joan Bingham.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IM NOT going voluntarily or of my own initiation. What is going to happen is that at the instance of President Carter I am going to be replaced shortly.

title: The Met's GoldenAge Otello
description: It's hard to believe that Verdi's Otello was absent from the Metropolitan Opera stage for an entire generation between 1913 and 1937. Some members of the Met audience on the night of Dec. 22, 1937 no doubt were present at the company's last performance of the opera on Jan. 31, 1913 when the cast included Leo Slezak as. the Moor, Antonio Scott(as Iago and Frances Alda as Desdemona with Toscanini on the podium. No doubt, too, the inevitable nostalgic comparisons were made in favor of the old days.

title: The Start and. Finish of a Brief Boxing Career
description: I was 17 when I learned one day that a famous fighter was training at a gym only three, blocks from where I lived. I wondered if I could write a piece about him for a magazine. considered myself a writer because story of mine had recently been published in a literary magazine. I took the magazine to the gym to show as a credential in order to interview the fighter.

title: A Special $2aWeek Nursery
description: FOR THE MODEST sum of $2 week, any Westport youngster from 3 to 5 years of age may be registered to attend a nursery school operated by students in the Child Development II course at Staples High School. The money pays for snacks and materials. Registration may entail wait, since the list of applicants always exceeds the limit of 15 spaces.

title: Dartmouth Elevates Kelley
description: HANOVER, N.H., June 11 (UPI)Fred Kelley, a trainer and freshman baseball coach at Dartmouth the last 10 years, was named today as head baseball coach at the Ivy League school. The 40yearold Kelley replaces Tony Lupien, who resigned recently after 21 years as coach.

title: An Absent Amin Was Topic A
description: Given his past actions, ranging from farcical to brutal, the man who drew the most attention at Britain's celebration of the quartercentury reign of Queen Elizabeth II was the one man barred from the festivitiesPresident Idi Amin of Uganda. What was surprising, however, was the condemnation of Mr. Amin by fellow Commonwealth leaders.

title: Buddhism Of Himalayas At Home Now In the City
description: The shrine is filled with bells and Buddha statues, fresh flowers and photos, and the glow of candles. Below, on the redcarpeted floor, meditators sit crosslegged, their spines erect and their eyes closed, their voices rising and falling in quick, seemingly endless repetition of the mantra, Om mani pema hung. Om mani pema hung. Om mani pema hung

title: W. Germans Approve Ban On Steroids for Athletes
description: BADENBADEN, West Germany, June 11 (UPI)West Germany's top sports organization approved today a ban on the use of musclebuilding steroids by athletes in international competition. It said the United States Olympic Committee had given the ruling full support.

title: From U.S. Teaching Grant
description: During the school year, teachers will attend onsite seminars, workshops and demonstrations at the Park Avenue School and will work with the Hofstra faculty members in developing curricular, individualized instruction methods and new patterns of communication between teachers and children.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Gail Sheehy
description: Talking about Passages, Gail Sheehy said, I've now written something that I'll never be able to live up to in my own life. Nobody can; but somehow it helps to get it down on paper. Her book's subtitle'Predictable Crises of Adult Life'tells why. Here are the Stations of the Crossfrom what she calls Catch30 onward to life's changes in the 50'sfor many Americans. The signposts are identified with a journalist's eye. A large number of readers enjoyed shocks recognition. Passages, a Dutton book, has been on the best seller lists for a year this month.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY homeowners have learned the basics of working with copper pipe and tubing, and have mastered tithe techniques of making neat soldered joints with one of the handy propane q torches available in all hardware stores. However, one problem that often gives the amateur trouble is making a soldered connection to an elbow or other fitting that is already soldered at the other end. The trouble arises from the fact that when enough heat is applied to make the solder flow freely into the new joint, the heat sometimes loosens the old joint at the other end of the fitting. A simple way to solve this problem is to use the method illustrated in the accompanying photograph.

title: A Crisis Of Credibility
description: The House Ways and Means Committee's nearemasculation of the Carter energy program suggests that even the President's television hardsellthose three appearances in one April weekdid not persuade the gasguzzling American people that there is an energy crisis.

title: President Wants To Gain Friends In Soviet Sphere
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  President Carter has said he is inclined to aggressively challenge the Soviet Union for influence in critical areas around the world, some of them under Russian influence.

title: Editors Choice
description: FARTHER OFF FROM HEAVEN, by William Humphrey. (Knopf, 58.95.) A loving recreation of the novelist's boyhood and adolescence.

title: Maureen Lambrar
description: Joan Micklin Silver, director of Hester Street and Between the Lines, and her husband Raphael Silver, who produced and distributed both films.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Interest in the paper currency of our Revolution must have been a hot topic of conversation last weekend at the Memphis extravaganza of the Society of Paper Money Collectors. Due to Bicentennial fever the pieces shown here would bring perhaps five times their listed prices of 10 years ago. ($15 and 37.50 in 1967).

title: Conservatives Get Closer to G.O.P.
description: WESTCHESTER'S Conservative Party, which has contributed greatly to Republican political victories while getting little in return, has this year won Republican endorsement of its candidate for county judge. Gerard E. Delaney, a 47yearold attorney from Pound Ridge, was the first enrolled Conservative to get a Republican nomination for a countywide office. The combination of the two parties has proved virtually unbeatable in other judgeship races and it poses a serious problem for Joel M. Aurnou, who holds the county judgeship on an interim appointment by Governor Carey and is seeking a full 10year term as the Democratic nominee.

title: Duck Boy
description: I wanted to adopt Britt Masy. He was not preliteratehe was 15but he could not read, and he never did learn how to read during the two years he had to come to my classes. We would both grin and grin at each other so happily because he read two pages of a firstgrade reader, and the next day he would have forgotten it all. To adopt him or marry him would have been the only way I could have changed him a little, and even then it would have been too lateunless I could have adopted him when he was born. He had no mothMaxine Hong Kingston is author of The Woman Warrior. er, and his father, an alcoholic, had given him away. His foster parents took in a different child every few years for the $75 a month from the state. They must have done it for the money. Who else would take on Britt as a daily responsibility? Short. Skinny. Pimply. Glasses. Scared, darting, jumping eyes when he did not understand something or when the others teased him or hit him. But he was scared only when they pounced from hiding, or jumped on him from the back. After the surprise and pain, always sweet words and sweet smiles, not idiotic smiles. When I made an incomprehensible assignment to the class (it was a regular publicschool class, not Special Ed or E.H., whatever that stands for), I watched him staring are bored with listening to normal people's dreams.

title: An Early Start In the Symphony
description: THE big momentthe final concert of the seasonhas come and gone for most of the Island's youth orchestras. But, like Christmas ornament manufacturers, they are already deep into preparations for the coming season, holding auditions, selecting programs, arranging rehearsal and concert schedules, booking soloists and auditoriums and raising funds.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When she arrives in her suite at the Gloucester Hotel in London today, Billie Jean King will phone room service for a pot of tea. It's so good there, it's great stuff, it gets me in the mood. And as she prepares for the 100th anniversary Wimbledon tennis tournament that opens a week from tomorrow, Billie Jean King slowly will be transSports formed into a traditionalist. She'll be of absorbed by the ivyThe Times covered clubhouse, the strawberries and cream at the concession stands, the dressing rooms with bathtubs instead of showers and the grass stage of center court. Her stage. It's a great stage and I belong there. She has won 19 Wimbledon championships on that stagesix in women's singles, nine in women's doubles, four in mixed doubles. in her comeback, she now hopes to win a record 20th title, preferably in singles, after having retired two years ago on that stage where tradition is as important as the tennis.

title: Egypt's Burden Of Poverty Seen Shifting to City
description: CAIRO, June 11In Bulaq, a slum district of Cairo, the women are frequently possessed by devils, mischieous devils that want to play and dance and sing or greedy devils that must be appeased by gold jewelry and new dresses.

title: Victor Greenhut Weds Deborah Schneider
description: The marriage of Deborah Schneider, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Schneider of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Dr. Victor A. Greenhut, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Greenhut of New York, took place yesterday afternoon at the Schneider home.

title: A Nervous but Cheerful Teacher Says She Was Treated Correctly
description: BOVENSMILDE, the Netherlands, June 12Mrs. Sjann Abbink was asleep when the crack of gunfire woke her up just before 5 A.M. yesterday in the village school classroom where she and three other teachers had been held by four South Moluccan gunmen for 20 days.

title: Cruguet Keeps Winning, Rides Plate Trial Victor
description: TORONTO, June 12 (AP) Jean Cruguet, who rode Seattle Slew to victory in the Belmont Stakes yesterday, clinching the Triple Crown a racing, was aboard another winner,. Giboulee, in the Plate Trial Stakes at the Woodbine track today.

title: Tyranny of a Majority
description: LONDON, June 12In voting to rapeal a local law that protected homosexuals from discrimination in jobs and public accommodations, the people of Miami, Fla., sent an unintended message. They reminded us that the lights of minorities are too important to be trusted to the pasMons of passing majorities.

title: TAILEXEMPT SALES
description: Tile credit markets, flushed. with their success in marketing a nearrecord volume of taxexempt bonds last week, abound with optimism and talk of higher prices and lower interest rates in the weeks ahead. There's going to be a summer rally in the bond market and the money market, too, many fixedincome traders and analysts now predict.

title: Parks Are for People, Not Paper and Pap
description: How many liters of litter do half a million food lovers attending a food festival in Central Park leave behind? How many people does it take on Sunday to pick up the litter that the food lovers left on Saturday while Sunday's picnickers and paradewatchers keep littering? Who picks up the later litter?

title: Wilderness Society is Troubled by Staff Changes
description: WASHINGTON. June 12The Wilderness Society, a 70,000member conservation organization operating on a reduced budget, is seeking its third executive director ix two years. Although some in the society say the change in directors IS routine, other staff members and a former director say it is part of a longstanding dispute over financing.

title: Leibman as Richard III A DominatingPresence
description: Ron Leibman, an actor who has played Sheridan and Chekhov, Beckett and Arthur Miller, is now trying on the title role of Shakespeare's Richard III in an Actors Studio Production in it he proves again what observers have said about him that he is an actor of range and power, with a resonant voice, a dominating presence and ability to fill every foot on the stage. There is no cameo work in his portrayal, no casually raised eyebrow, no thrownaway line.

title: PALESTINIANS SAY LEADER WAS SHOT BY RIVAL GROUP
description: BEIRUT, June 12  The hardline Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine announced today that Faiz Mansour, 27yearold military commander in the Chatila refugee camp here, had been shot to death by gunmen in the street near the camp.

title: Congram Leaves Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, June 12  Walter (Buzz) Congram, freshman crew coach at Yale for seven years, was appointed today head coach at Northwestern University. He succeeds Ernie Arlett, who retired recently.

title: Democrats Expect Victory in Nassau if Caso Runs as an Independent
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 12Leaders of Nassau County's Democratic Party said Friday that the possible candidacy of Ralph G. Caso, the Republican County Executive, as an independent if he loses the primary in September will insure a victory for Democrats.

title: JAMES EARL RAY SEIZED AFTER 2DAY MANHUNT IN EASTERN TENNESSEE
description: PETROS, Tenn., Monday, June 13 James Earl Ray was captured early this morning, 54 hours after he and six other inmates had fled from the maximumsecurity prison here.

title: Moses Says He Can Beat His Hurdles Mark
description: Both in quality of competition and quality of performance, which are two quite different things, the national Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at Los Angeles last week deserved such high marks that it was almost a shame to have extraneous matters, such as mere recordhunting and the makeup of teams for future meets, dilute its effect.

title: Lake in Abandoned Lot Gives City a Country Feel
description: Children row in it, men. fish in it and the elderly admire its greenishblue colors. And while it doesn't quite have a name, residents of the Lenox Hill area refer to it as The Little Lake in the Abandoned Lot.

title: Revco Feat Doubles Stern Shop's Billings
description: A nice thing happened to William J. Stern on the eve of his recent 31st birthday. He brought in an account that doubled his agency's billings.

title: Social Security Checks Fall Short In Budgets of New York's Elderly
description: For a moderate living style in New York City an eledrly retired couple had to spend $641.25 a month, as of last fall, compared with the then nationwide average Social Security payment of $337.72 for a retired worker and dependent, according to the Community Council of Greater New York.

title: LIEUT. GEN. EUGEN STUDER
description: BERN, June 12 (AP)Lieut. Gen. Eugen Studer, former Chief of the Swiss Air Force, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in nearby Muri. He was 64 years old. General Studer retired in 1973. partly to protest against the Government's decision to drop plans for the purchase of American fighterbombers. He called the proposed $350million air forcemodernization program vital for Switzerland's defense.

title: NATIONAL GUARD JOINS
description: PETROS, Tenn., June 12Two National Guard units and a contingent of National Guard helicopters were ordered mobilized tonight in the search for James Earl Ray and three other convicts thought to be still hiding in the mountains of Tennessee.

title: CARTER TRADE PLAN FALLING INTO PLACE
description: WASHINGTON, June 12More by groping sweeps than by calculation, President Carter has fallen upon a new trade policy for the United States that tilts toward liberalism while satisfying the most urgent needs of importinjured workers.

title: A Remnant of British India Seeks to Preserve Its Identity
description: DARJEELING, India  St. Paul's, a boarding school with a distinguished past that reaches back to the grandest days of the British Empire, is concerned about its future.

title: Black Audience for Public TV Up 47%, Nielsen Report Shows
description: Black viewers for public television are on the increase, and so are programs of particular interest to blacks, Chloe Aaron, senior vice president of programming for the Public Broadcasting Service, has told a luncheon audience of the New York chanter of the Television Academy.

title: Bergenfield Homeowners Protest Designation as FloodHazard Area
description: PRGENFIELD, June 12Bergenfield dents who live in officially designated dhanard areas objected to that classition yesterday at a hearing attended by., representatives government, the reatestate industry and lending institutions.

title: Passaic Students Given Incentive To Reduce Vandalism, and it Works
description: PASSAIC, June 12The Passaic Board of Education, in an unusual move to combat vandalism in this city's high school, set aside the money it had estimated it would have had to spend to repair damages and is ready to give it to students for use in yearend activities for their help in averting vandalism.

title: HEAD OF N.U.D. HEARS PROBLEMS OF MAYORS
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 12All day long they came to vent their complaints, their hopes, their frustrations.

title: Geraldine O'Grady's Violin Sings
description: As a violinist who was born in Ireland, schooled in Paris and was a recitalist in Brazil, Geraldine O'Grady drew on all three of her musical backgrounds for an unusually interesting and wellplayed program Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Bolshoi Stars Will Dance With Ailey in Avignon
description: The impresario Paul Szilard, who arranges all of the overseas touring of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Company, has said that during the company's season at the Avignon Festival in France, July 24 through Aug. 6, it will be joined by two Soviet guest stars from Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet.

title: Pakistan Budget Provides Funds To Purchase Nuclear Fuel Plant
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan June 12 (ReUters)Pakistan has allocated $40 million for the purchase of a nuclear fuelreprocessing plant in its budget for the coming year despite American opposition.

title: COLIN W. GRAYLEWIS
description: Colin W. GrayLewis, a former treasurer of the Lily Division of OwensIllinois Inc., manufacturer of paper products, died Saturday at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived at 385 Ocean Boulevard in Long. Branch.

title: Bronx Street is Named to Honor Slain EntebbeRaid Commander
description: A oneblock street in the Bronx was renamed yesterday for Lieut. Col. Yehonatan Netanyahu, the New. Yorkborn Israeli paratroop commander killed in the Entebbe raid last July 3.

title: Miss Harvey Bride Of Michael Shapiro
description: Elizabeth Harlan Harvey, daughter of Judge Alexander Harvey of the United States District Court of Maryland and Mrs. Harvey of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Michael Edward Shapiro, son of Mrs. Edward A. Shapiro of New York and the late Mr. Shapiro.

title: Roger Jones Wins Coast Mile Run
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 12 Roger Jones of Ramsey upset his New Jersey rival, Kevin Byrne of Paramus Catholic, in the onemile run and Tony Tufariello of Hewlett, L. I., won the 440yard dash easily at the Golden West invitation schoolboy meet last night.

title: 10 PERCENT CUTBACK IN STRATEGIC FORCES IS PROPOSED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 The United States has suggested to. the Soviet Union, as part of a new approach to achieving a treaty limiting strategic arms, that each side's offensive strategic force be cut by about 10 percent below the 2,400 level agreed upon at Vladivostok three years ago.

title: Settlements Bank Cautions U.S. Over Payments Deficit
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 12A growing balanceofpayments deficit for the United States, welcomed by many economists as helping its allies recover from the recession, risks weakening the dollar and causing fresh monetary turmoil, a major economic institution has warned.

title: Commerce Secretary Optimistic On Bill for Consumer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps said today that she thought that President Carter's bill for a consumer protection agency might still be passed by Congress. She was interviewed on the CBS program Face the Nation.

title: Aluminum Shipping In 1976 Rose 28.4%
description: The domestic aluminum industry rebounded from 1975's depressed shipments of 9.9 billion pounds and shipped 12.7 billion pounds in 1976, the Aluminum Association reported over the weekend.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: A TOUCH OF CLASS Warm weather naturally prompts thoughts of outside diversions, but the Big Apple still leads the world in availability of good movie revivals the year round. A seasonal reminder is the usual stunning array of vintage screenings open to the public (on a single admission basis) in several summer courses at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. The events also include a commentary or analysis by the teacher.

title: Winning Can Be Costly
description: YONKERS, June 12 The Big Stable of Lanham, Md., lived up to its name last night at Yonkers Raceway..Following Big Towner's victory in the third division of the $118,340 New York Sire Stakes, Pat Kelly, principal owner of the Maryland stable, announced that he would pay a record $25,000 fee Wednesday to supplement his 3yearold to Saturday's Cane Pace at Yonkers.

title: Suburbs Seeking to Deal With Restive Youths
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.A rising incidence of teenage misconduct ranging from vandalism to loitering has sharply divided and unsettled this welltodo and outwardly serene Westchester village of 7,100 people.

title: Student Unrest Troubles Brazil's Regime
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, June 9 Widescale unrest has returned to Brazil's university campuses for the first time in nearly a decade, and the student movement is causing serious concern to the military Government.

title: Books of The Times
description: The struggle by Germans from diverse backgrounds to overthrow Adolf Hitler and the Nazi regime has an enduring fascination. A dramatic and tragic tale in its own right, it raises moral and political issues inherent in the effort to rebel against any totalitarian tyranny.

title: Scapegoats in World Economic Ills
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 12 Who is to blame for the world's present economic troubles with slow growth and high inflation? The Bank for International Settlements here in its latest annual report and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris have identified the following five scapegoats, put forward by different schools of economists.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A short while ago an acquaintance told us an amusing story about the origins of spaghetti carbonara, which means spaghetti charcoalburnerstyle. It had to do with an American soldier asking for an egg noodle dish in Italy during World War II. The waiter did not wholly comprehend his request and had the chef prepare him a noodle dish with raw eggs. it still left the origin of the name carbonara unexplained.

title: Bergman Denies He Wants to Stay As an Operator of Nursing Homes
description: Bernard Bergman, who was convicted on state and Federal charges of Medicaid fraud in the operation of nursing homes in New York City, denied yesterday that he wanted to remain in the nursing home business.

title: Suburbs Pass More School Budgets But Face Continued Fiscal Trouble
description: The taxpayers revolt in the New York metropolitan area's school districts appears to be over, but the struggle for solvency continues in the view of education specialists, there are many difficult years to come.

title: Suburbs Seeking to Deal With Restive Youths
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y.A rising incidence of teenage misconduct ranging from vandalism to loitering has sharply divided and unsettled this welltodo and outwardly serene Westchester village of 7,100 people.

title: The Screen
description: ToraSan, the peripatetic catalytic figure at the core of one of Japan's most popular film series, is back again. In ToraSan, Love Under One Umbrella, which opened a twoday run yesterday at the Regency Theater, the gentle, ponderous wanderer, portrayed by Kiyoshi Ataumi, finds himself playing nursemaid to a runaway businessman suffering a midlife crisis, and being compelled to entertain the idea of marriage to an old friend  Lily, a divorced cabaret singer.

title: Events Today
description: LED ZEPPELIN, rock group, Madison Square Garden, 8.

title: Carter News Parley On RadioTV Today
description: President Carter will hold a news conference at 2:30 P.M. today. it will be broadcast live by the three commercial television networks and their local stations.

title: AntiIntegration Protest Reported
description: BOSTON, June 12 (AP)  The headmaster of South Boston High School said today that officials had solid evidence an organized group was planning to disrupt the school's graduation ceremonies Tuesday. A spokesman for the school said that the group of South Boston whites wanted to protest. the courtordered desegregation of the school, in effect for three years. The spokesman said special security precautions would be taken.

title: Scarlett Net Victor
description: WALDWICK, N.J., June 12  Bill Scarlett won the New Jersey State men's 35er indoor tennis championship for the second straight year today. He scored a 61, 64 victory over Peter De Lames in the final at the Waldwick Covered Courts.

title: Soettal to The New York Times
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 12  The Swiss Credit Bank's total potential loss as a result of the socalled Chiasso affair will be about $410 million, Fritz Leutwiler, the governor of the Swiss National Bank, disclosed here tonight.

title: Britain Enters Web of Sports Politics
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 12  In the midst of a Silver Jubilee celebration and a meeting of Commonwealth countries, Britain also found itself in a bizarre web of international sports politics today.

title: Rutgers Study at Home Courses Provide Second Chance for Many
description: NEW BRUNSWICKOpen University, in which the classroom has been eliminated and virtually all the work is done at home, has become known as The University of the Second Chance for women over 30 years old, servicemen, merchants, truckers, the disabled and dropouts, including a 70yearold man who left high school in 1929.

title: SEABROOK RULING DELAYED FOR REVIEW BY PRESIDENT
description: CONCORD, N.H., June 12 (AP)A decision on the future of the Seabrook nuclear power plant, expected yesterday, was delayed for the weekend because of a review by President Carter, who spoke out against Seabrook in his campaign.

title: Shetland Rated Best at Fairfield
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 12  Paul and Donna Tidswell flew 3,000 miles from Portland, Ore., to show their new champion, Banchory Back Stop, at the American Shetland Sheepdog Association specialty. it was held today in conjunction with the LongshoreSouthport Kennel Club's 45th allbreed show on the Fairfield University campus and the Sheltie not only defeated 284 others of his breed, but also went on to a working group first and best in show over 2,038 other dogs.

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 12 (AP)In a case opening in the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit here tomorrow, blacks from four Southern areas are trying to topple a widely used form of municipal government where, according to them, it discriminates against members of minority groups.

title: Second Trial in Reporter's Slaying Gets Under Way Today in Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, June 10The second trial resulting from the murder of Don Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic, begins here Monday, exactly one year after he died of massive injuries from a bomb hidden in his car.

title: Solomon Wins Belgian Event
description: BRUSSELS, June 12 (UPI)  Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., turned back hardserving Karl Meiler of West Germany today. 75, 36, 26. 63, 64. and won the Belgian Grand Prix tournament. The victory was worth $11,750.

title: Upsets at North Shore
description: Jon Moses of Haworth, N.J., and John Shaw of Suffern, N.Y., scored upsets Sunday to reach the fourth round of the New York State men's championships at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club, Bayside, Queens. Moses defeated Miguel Morales of New York, 63, 63. and Shaw eliminated Tom Porter of Scarsdale, N.Y., 64, 26.

title: Ballet Theater Names New Chairman
description: The board of American Ballet Theater has named the head of one of the country's major business corporations as its new chairman in an overall reorganization designed to strengthen the company's national fundraising effort.

title: Jane Frisch Wed to Lieut. Comdr. Harvey Rosenkrantz
description: Jane Robin Frisch and Lieut. Comdr. Harvey Rosenkrantz, Medical Corps, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Morris Tolchinsky of New York and the late Nathan Rosenkrantz, were married yesterday morning. Rabbi David Posner of Temple EmanuEl performed the ceremony In his study.

title: School Hit on 4 Sides
description: BOVENSMILDE, the Netherlands, June 12 Mrs. Sjann Abbink was asleep when the crack of gunfire woke her up just before 5 A.M. yesterday in the village school classroom where she and three other teachers had been held by four South Moluccan gunmen for 20 days.

title: Half a Million Happy People Celebrate Puerto Rican Day
description: Everywhere we goo,  People want to knowo, Who we are, And so we tell therm We're from Puerto Rico, And now we're heeeere.

title: Frank &
description: WASHINGTONIn late 1975, a fascinating story that had been carefully burled on page six of The Washington Post, ignored by the national media when covered by the ScrippsHoward newspapers and brushed aside in footnote by the Senate committee investigating the C.I.A. was given serious treatment in this space.

title: LIBYA ASKS U.S. CONSENT FOR EXCHANGE OF ENVOYS
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, June 12 (AP)  Col. Muammar elQaddafi has challenged President Carter to improve Libyan. American relations by consenting to the appointment of ambassadors.

title: Jeffrey Jacobs Marries Ellen Harwood at Plaza
description: Ellen Harwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Harwood of Westbury, L. I., was married yesterday at the Plaza to Jeffrey Jacobs, son of Harold Jacobs of Chicago and Florence Brindel of River Forest, Ill. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Myron Fenster. He was assisted by Rabbi Joseph Tabatchnik and Cantor Harold Brindel, stepfather of the brideeroom.

title: Susan Ford is Hired as a Photographer for Jaws
description: HOLLYWOOD, June 12  Susan Ford, daughter of former President Ford, has been hired as a special photographer on the movie Jaws 2, it was announced yesterday by Richard D. Zanuck and David Brown, the picture's producers. She will report to the Martha's Vineyard location Sunday.

title: Suburbs Pass More School Budgets But Face Continued Fiscal Trouble
description: The taxpayers revolt in the New York metropolitan area's school districts appears to be over, but the struggle for solvency continues in the view of education specialists, there are many difficult years to come.

title: Californians Take Title
description: Brian Lee and Greg Lawrence of Santa Monica, Calif., won the United States Paddle Tennis Association doubles championship yesterday by defeating Sol Hauptman and Jeff Fleitman of Brooklyn, the defending champions, 75, 76, 16, 67, 1513, at Stuyvesant Town.

title: News Summary
description: Some of the freed Dutch hostages described their 20 days of captivity by South Moluccas terrorists and their rescue at dawn Sunday by Dutch marines. The Dutch Government and health authorities. however made an effort to ??? the released hostages from the press and television to ease the trauma of their ordeal. One of the four teachers rescued by the marines when they attacked an elementary school from four directions said they had been treated correctly by the kidnappers. It appeared that some of the women among the 51 hostages on the train that was stormed by the marines ware fairly friendly wilt their captors. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Michael Bartnett, War Veteran And a Construction Engineer
description: Michael Francis Hartnett, a construction engineer for more than 50 years, who served as a major in the Army Corps of Engineers in World War II, died Saturday in Cadiz, Spain, where he had been living in retirement. He was 78 years old.

title: Half a Million Happy People Celebrate Puerto Rican Day
description: So chanted the Gowanas Girls Marching Unit yesterday, their redandwhite satin glistening in the sun, their feet keeping perfect time on hot asphalt. So too, said almost half a million Puerto Ricans from the New York area, just by being at the 19th annual. Puerto Rican Day parade.

title: Graham Puts New Accent In Shadows
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company closed its season Saturday night at the LuntFontanne theater not only with a rousing ovation from the audience but also with a revised version of one of the premieres Miss Graham had created for that season.

title: Aides Say the White House Staff Will Be Hard to Reduce by 30%
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)  White House aides are acknowledging that, unless President Carter takes drastic action, he will not meet his goal of cutting the size of the White House staff by 30 percent.

title: Market Place
description: When the Congoleum Corporation made a surprise offer last October for all the common stock of the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company at $32.50 share in cash, there was initial bewilderment in Wall Street.

title: DR. ALVIN I. GOLDFARB, 63, PROFESSOR OF PSYCHIATRY
description: Dr. Alvin I. Goldfarb, a clinical professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and a former consultant on psychiatric services for the aged in the State Department of Mental Hygiene, died Saturday at his home at 21415 33d Avenue in Bayside, Queens. He was 63 years old.

title: Cleveland to Use Questionnaires To Determine Obscenity Standard
description: CLEVELAND, June 11 Mayor Ralph J. Perk and his staff are in the process of developing what they hope can be model for the rest of the nation in determining community standards as they relate to obscenity and pornography.

title: Dr. Jan Horrow, Teacher, Weds Mindy E. Meislich
description: Mindy Ellen Meislich, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Meislich of New Milford, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Jan Charles Horrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton B. Horrow of Philadelphia.

title: Rising Violence Creates Controversy Among Teachers at Bronx High School
description: At 24, Hilda Gore returned to New York City's publicschool system, as a teacher.

title: Texas Publishing Concern Bought
description: SHERMAN, Tex., June 12 (AP)  The Donrey Media Group has entered into an agreement to purchase a major interest in the Red River Valley Publishing Company, which publishes The Sherman Democrat, company officials announced today. The Democrat, a North Texas daily newspaper, has a paid circulation of 19,000.

title: Advertising
description: Joseph Feldmann has been in magazine publishing for 15 of his 47 years but most of the time has been involved with trade publications with relatiyely small circulations.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, June 12In April 1976, President Ford declared that the Federal Government machinery must operate without the taint of partisan politics and that, therefore, politicizing the Civil Service is intolerable.

title: Seaver Seems Upset by Trade Talk After His 5Hitter Defeats Astros
description: HOUSTON, June 12 After Tom Seaver completed a fivehit, 31 victory over the Houston Astros today, John Stearns, his catcher, came out to the mound and embraced the Mets ace pitcher. The gesture might have been one of joy over the team's comeback victory. Or it might have been one of farewell.

title: Saudi Arabians Plan to Put Wasted Natural Gas to work
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi ArabiaAt night the horizon here glows faintly orange, as it a large city in the distance were throwing its illumination skyward. But there are no large cities in this areaonly natural gas, billions of cubic feet of it, being flared away in bright orange flames 24 hours a day.

title: 10 Percent Cut in Strategic Forces From 1974 Level Proposed by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The United States has suggested to the Soviet Union, as part of a new approach to achieving a treaty limiting strategic arms, that each side's offensive strategic force be cut by about 10 percent below the 2,400 level agreed upon at Vladivostok three years ago.

title: Nora F. Huvelle Married to David Allen Lubin
description: Nora Featherston Huvelle, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. C. H. Huvelle of Litchfield, Conn., was married yesterday to David Allen Lubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Lubin of Pittsfield, Mass. The ceremony was performed at the Huvellest summer home in Wellfleet, Mass., by the Rev. David Parke, a Unitarian minister.

title: Glynn Rudich is Bride of Howard J. Cohen, Architect
description: The marriage of Glynn Rudich, daughter of Mrs. Nathan M. Rudich of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Rudich, to Howard J. Cohen, son of Dr. Rubin Cohen of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Cohen, took place yesterday. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in his study at Temple EmanuEl.

title: Wendy Evans Has Nuptials
description: Wendy Ellen Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin I. Evans of Woodmere L. L, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Lee Saltonstall, son of Margaret B. Saltonstall and John L. Saltonstall Jr. of Boston.

title: Associated Press
description: WHAT A DAY:

title: Dr. Howard Steven Manasse Weds Anne Ruth Teitelbaum
description: Anne Ruth Teitelbaum and Dr. Howard Steven Manasse were married yesterday in Lido Beach, L. I., at the home of the bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Gerhard Kisch. Rabbi Morris M. Goldberg performed the ceremony.

title: Foreign Choir Sings At a Mass in Peking
description: PEKING, June 12 (Agence FrancePresse)For the first time today a foreign choir sang at the weekly Latin mass in China's only Roman Catholic church.

title: Madelia Takes Rich Filly Race
description: CHANTILLY, France, June 12 (AP) Madelia, the favorite, continued the dominance of the Wildenstein family in France's leading race for 3yearold fillies today by winning the $280,000 Prix de Diane at Chantilly race course.

title: A Better Break for the Cities
description: Federal aid to the cause of saving the cities, called Community Development, has been dramatically transformed over the past three years to a program of block grants, or general funds, in place of specific grants individual projects. But students of the change have been raising two fundamental questions, about the fairness of the distribution formulas and about the vagueness of the Program's social goals.

title: Seem Fragile
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  The recent stepup in Soviet press attacks on President Carter and his human rights campaign underscores the fragile and uneasy relations between Washington and Moscow these days. The attacks pose a dilemma for the Carter Administration as it prepares for the opening this week in Belgrade of the followup meeting of the 1975 Helsinki conference on European security and cooperation. if the Administration responds by taking too aggressive a stand, it risks provoking a further deterioration in an already prickly relationship with Moscow. if it restricts itself to bland statements of principle while Soviet authorities pursue a crackdown against dissidents, it risks losing credibility for its human rights campaign.

title: Gulf Oil Faces Fire Code Inquiry
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (UPI)Representatives of the Gulf Oil Company have been summoned to Municipal Court for hearing July 6 to answer charges that 172 violations of the city fire code had been found at the company's Philadelphia refinery, where eight firemen died in a 1975 fire.

title: Mike Has Galloped Him Harder
description: By noon yesterday there weren't more than 100 people in the home of Jim and Sally Hill in Garden City, LI., but the party was beginning to show promise, it looked as though midafternoon would find everybody who counted in attendance except Seattle Slew, who was snoozing in Barn 54 at Belmont Park. Between naps he lived it up on hay, which he prefers to Jack Daniel's. He hadn't been, getting as much hay as he likes for several days because Billy Turner had been fitting him out for a place in history the only undefeated horse ever to win Triple Crown. Sometimes a bright horse learns that when the hay rack in his stall remains empty it means he's going to race that afternoon, but Turner tries to avoid sudden changes in the routine that might make the horse fret in the week leading up to Saturday's Belmont Stakes, he reduced Seattle Slew's ration of hay gradually, but that didn't fool the colt. Slew hasn't yet learned to read his press clippings and he had no way knowing specifically that victory in the Belmont, following his scores in the Kentucky Derby and Preakness, would make him America's 10th Triple Crown winner. Nevertheless, from the time he woke Saturday, he knew something special was happening. Perhaps he sensed it in the tone and manner of the people around him.

title: Johncock is Seriously Injured In Race Crash at Milwaukee
description: MILWAUKEE, June 12 (AP)  Gordon Johncock, the hardluck driver of the Indianapolis 500 two weeks ago, was apparently slammed in the head by wheel torn from his race car as he hit the wall today in the Rex Mays 150. which was won by Johnny Rutherford.

title: Nudist Movement, Shedding Old Stigma, Nears Its 50th Anniversary
description: MAYS LANDING, N.J.Lola, a 55yearold grandmother who cannot understand why she did not become nudist years ago, comes to Sunshine Nature Park here with her grandson and joyfully sheds her clothing at the precise instant that she passes through the rates.

title: Northeast and Middle West Join In Congress in Bid for More Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 12For years, Congress has been accustomed to Federal aid formulas that shoveled dollars into the South and West, but this year there is a new. emphasis on getting aid to the battered, older urban centers of the Middle West and the Northeast, including New York City.

title: Chess:
description: None of the other quarterfinal candidates matches carried as great weight of underlying tension as did the one between Viktor Korchnoi and Tigran Petrosian in Castelvecchio Pascoli Italy.

title: Captive From Train Says Guerrilla May Have Killed Passenger
description: HOOGHALEN, the Netherlands, June 12 One of the two hostages killed when Dutch marines stormed a terroristheld train Saturday died because he responded to a terrorist's order to stand up in the aisle at the height of the gun battle, according to another hostage.

title: Topics
description: The repeal of a Dade County, Florida, ordinance protecting homosexuals rights persuaded both sides the controversy that the vote had been a test of whether homosexuality merits community approval. Too bad. The ordinance was an explicit statement of the employment and housing rights of people who have long been denied both. But the larger aspects of the subject are unsuitable for referendum. The nature of homosexuality remains In dispute. Its place in society remains problematic. The 21 vote in Dade County suggests that the gay life is unattractive to most Miamians, but that was not the issue. Respect for the rights of others is necessary precisely to the degree that the community fails to share their values.. This victory of the straights must not lead to further discrimination against a group that has suffered enough.

title: CONSORTIUM IS NAMED NEW YORK'S AUDITOR
description: New York City will pay a consortium of six accounting companies nearly $3 million during the next three years to perform the first independent audits of New York's finances in the city's history.

title: Carter's Opposition to Water Projects Linked to 73 Veto of Georgia Dam.
description: THOMASTON, Ga., June 12  The key to President Carter's dogged insistence on killing 18 major water projects lies a few miles west of town in the white waters of the Flint River, which the Army Corps of Engineers wanted to dam.

title: Rumanians Triumph by 41
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 12 (UPI)  Rumania split the final two sin=. files matches today to complete a 41.victory over Britain and qualify for the final of the Davis Cup's European Zone tournament.

title: Conservative Virginia Democrat Favored in Gubernatorial Primary
description: RICHMOND, Va., June 12Although the staid old commonwealth of Virginia has never seen a gubernatorial primary campaign like the curious, costly circus in its final days here, when the voting begins Tuesday the odds will favor the distinctly duller of the two main performers.

title: HispanicAmerican Turns Down Envoy's Post Amid Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, June 12An attempt to appoint a lawyer with a Spanish name as United States Ambassador to Colombia has ended in failure, exacerbating delicate relations between the two Governments and adding to bitterness in the HispanicAmerican community .n this country against the State Department.

title: Waldheim, in Pittsburgh, Proposes Creation of World Energy Institute
description: PITTSBURGH, lune 12  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations proposed today the establishment of a framework that would lead to a World Energy Order. He said cooperation on energy was essential to all countries.

title: Frampton Back, Plays to 91,000
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11  A lack of suitable facilities has made the largescale outdoor summer concert a rarity in the New York area, although there is hope that the Meadowlands stadium in New Jersey may fill the void next year in the meantime the closest events of that sort take place here in Philadelphia, at John F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: TV: A Drama
description: Published a few years ago, The War Between the Tates, a novel by Alison Lurie, remains on my impossibly long list of books that really should be read one day. But time passes, and television lurches on, devouring all feasible properties in its potholed path. So, tonight at 9 on NBC, The War Between the Tates can be sampled as a dramatization by means of a Barbara Turner script based on the novel.

title: Nudist Movement, Shedding Old Stigma, Nears 50th Year
description: MAYS LANDINGLola, a 55yearold grandmother who cannot understand why she did not become a nudist years ago, comes to Sunshine Nature Park here with her grandson and joyfullrsheds her clothing at the precise instant that she passes through the rates.

title: News Summary
description: Some of the freed Dutch hostages described their 20 days of captivity by South Moluccan terrorists and their rescue at dawn Sunday by Dutch marines. The Dutch Government and health authorities, however, made an effort shield the released hostages from the press and television to ease the trauma of their ordeal. One of the four teachers rescued by the marines when they attacked an elementary school from four directions said they had been treated correctly by the kidnappers. it appeared that some of the women among the 51 hostages on the train that was stormed the marines were fairly friendly with their captors. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Mr. Carter's Cruel Abortion Plan
description: Faithful to the strong personal views of both the President and his Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare about abortion, the Administration is engaging in a curious and misguided legislative maneuver. it has included language in an appropriation bill for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare that would prohibit the use of any of that money for abortions. The principal effect would be to ban Medicaid abortions for the Door.

title: Light Trucks Adding Up to Heavy Sales
description: DETROIT, June 12They are all over the parking lot outside Bob Lamb's garage rough, rugged new adventure vehicles of the 1970's, with monster engines, bucket seats and rollbars. Shagcarpeted on the inside and jauntily decorated on the outside, they come with all the comforts of AM and FM sound, and they proclaim their individuality with names like Little Red and Patty Sue painted on their flanks.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: PER KEYSER FROLICH, 77, : RETIRED OIL EXECUTIVE
description: Dr. Per Keyser Frolich, a former president of the American Chemical Society and a former director of the chemical laboratories of the Standard Oil Development Company, died Friday at his hanb in Westfield, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: Geiberger Takes Golf After Lapse
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 12 (AP)  Al Geiberger, the leader since his record round of 59, lost a threestroke advantage and had to rally to win the Danny ThomasMemphis golf tourney today. He beat Gary Player and Jerry McGee, the runnersup by three strokes.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows.

title: Cosmos Top Kicks by 21 On Shootout
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 12 The Cosmos drew the largest home crowd in their history this afternoon 36,816  and to mark the day did something unusual: They won a game in a shootout, the North American Soccer League's device for deciding deadlocked games at the end of regulation time and the 15minute overtime.

title: Human Rights Only One Part of Helsinki Document
description: The Helsinki declaration, due for review in Belgrade, was signed on Aug. 1, 1975, to promote European security, international cooperation in various fields and, at the insistence of the Western nations, human rights and free movement of people and ideas across borders.

title: Chako Higuchi Captures L.P.G.A. Title by 3 Shots
description: NORTH MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., June 12 (AP)  Chako Higuchi of Japan won the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship today by three strokes with a final round 69 and 72hole total of 279, five strokes under par.

title: Lake in Abandoned Lot Gives City a Country Feel
description: Children row in it, men fish in it and the elderly admire its greenishblue colors. And while it doesn't quite. have a name, residents of the Lenox Hill area refer to it as The Little Lake in the Abandoned Lot.

title: Navy Project Slated In 2 Midwest States
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., June 12  Gov. Patrick J. Lucey, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Gov. William G. Milliken, Republican of Michigan, in a joint statement this weekend, expressed adamant opposition to. the Navy's reported suggestion to Congress that it place its controversial Project Seafarer in both states.

title: U.S. Canada Cable Cars Urged
description: DETROIT, June 12 (UPI)Officials on both sides of the United StatesCanadian border have revived a 12yearold idea to build a cable oar system over the Detroit River. Leon Atchison, city recreation director in Detroit, says that he and his counterpart in Windsor, Ont., Harry Brumpton, decided to resurrect the idea recently. The idea was first proposed in 1962, but money never became available and in 1970 Detroit officials revoked lease for a terminal site.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DART EUROPE (Dart). Antwerp June 23, Le Havre 24, Southampton 25, Copenhagen 26 and Dublin 27; sale from Global Marina Terminal, N.J.

title: Conservation Head Urges Fight on Environment Backlash in Congress
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., June 12Environmental progress is suffering markedly from a curious sort of Congressional backlash, but conservationists have netv weapons to hasten a change of mood, the head of a major environmental group said this weekend.

title: 2 L.I. Firemen Killed In a Rescue Mishap
description: Two volunteer firemen were killed when they entered a burning home in Greenport, LI., to save a 10yearold girl they did not know had already been rescued, officials said yesterday.

title: Music: Tribute
description: The Triad Chorale's tribute to Howard Swanson in Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon was a musically lavish and generally enjoyable event. The composer, who will be 70 years old this August, was represented by several of his songs, choral works and a Trio for Flute, Oboe and Piano, while a number of his colleagues had written new pieces to celebrate the occasion.

title: Frank R. Lyon Jr., 65, Officer And Counsel for Union Carbide
description: Frank R. Lyon Jr., retired senior vice president and general counsel of the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday in Dorset, Vt., following a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: 3 Filipinos Held in Protest
description: MANILA, June 12 (Reuters)  Three Filipinos working for Japanese and American news organizations were detained for a short time today while they were covering an antiGovernment rally in Quezon City to mark the country's national day. The police said later that the detention was part of a routine check as authorities watched for subversive activity.

title: Carol H. Levin is Bride
description: Carol Hollander Levin, daughter of Mrs. Walter C. Goldstein of New York and Westhampton Beach, LI., and Richard H. Levin of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married yesterday afternoon to Wolf D. Niemeyer. He is the son of Edith A. Niemeyer of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and Hubert K. Niemeyer of Cologne, West Germany. Rabbi David M. Posner of Temple EmanuEl performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club. The bride is a graduate of New York University. Her husband attends the New School. He is an assistant director of the office of judgment and execution of the Transportation Administration.

title: Italian Farmers Block Border
description: Brought their cattle to the pass, creating chaos and some nearfights as they hosed the road, cars and passing tourists with thousands of gallons of milk to protest lack of attention to breeding problems. human rights.

title: Two Soviet Lawyers Visiting U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  The exiled wife of a Soviet Jewish dissident, Anatoly Shcharansky, confronted two visiting Soviet lawyers at a reception in a restaurant in the Georgetown area today to ask their help in obtaining a fair trial for her husband.

title: 2 Yachts Set Pace Pace To Newport
description: Eric Ritter's Tempest, a 79foot ketch from Oyster Bay, was the first of the 75 yachts to round the Chesapeake Light at the bottom of Chesapeake Bay this morning. The Light is a key turning mark of the course, and the yachts in this biennial event then swing northnortheast in the Atlantic Ocean to Block Island or Montauk Point and then into Newport.

title: Helping the Elderly to Flee From Fear
description: Geza Kun has a view a king would envy. His wide windows are filled with sky and ocean, with great ships moving on the water under the distant VerrazanoNarrows Bridge. He hears the seagulls mew and the rush of waves far below on the beach at Sea Gate, Coney Island's western tip. He sniffs the tangy salt air and tells the social worker who is visiting him: A hundred times a day I say God bless Scheuer House. it is not enough.

title: Associated Press
description: Two mornings a week

title: Ceremony for Kennedy Library
description: BOSTON, June 12 (AP)The Kennedy family, friends and political associates gathered today in a light mist on a muddy field at the end of a peninsula on. Boston Harbor to break ground for the John Fitzgerald Kennedy memorial library.

title: 47 Salvation Army Cadets Graduate
description: Fortyseven men and women cadets pledged themselves to fulltime service in the Salvation Army yesterday at a service of dedication in the army's Centennial Memorial Temple at 120 West 14th Street.

title: Accord Near on Summer Food Plan
description: Representatives of the New York City Board of Education and the Department of Agriculture have reached tentative agreement on a plan that would enable the DOOM to continue as a sponsor or the Summer Food Service Program, providing free breakfasts and lunches for 100,000 needy children, officials said last night.

title: Experimental Prison is Troubled by Same Old Problems
description: BUTNER, N.C., June 9'There is no such place as a good prison, says Gilbert Ingram, the warden of the Federal Correctional Institution here. But if I had to go somewhere to do time, I'd come here.

title: How One Captive Died
description: HOOGHALEN, the Netherlands, June 12 One of the two hostages killed when Dutch marines stormed a terroristheld train Saturday died because he responded to a terrorist's order to stand up in the aisle at the height of the gun battle, according to another hostage.

title: Assoc!sled Press
description: GROUNDBREAKING FOR J.F.K. LIBRARY: Kennedy family members at ceremonies in Roston. From left: Joseph, son of Robert F. Kennedy; Joan and Senator Edward M. Kennedy; Rose Kennedy, Eunice Shriver, John and Caroline Kennedy and their mother, Jacquelhie Onassis. Article is on page 18.

title: Turk Farrell, ExPitcher, Killed in Auto Accident
description: BOSTON, June 12 (UPI)  Richard (Turk) Farrell, who won 106 games as a pitcher for 13 years in the National League, has been killed in an auto accident in Great Yarmouth, England. He was 43 years old.

title: Stacey G. Roth Married To Jeffrey M. Bachrach
description: Stacey Gaye Roth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Roth of Wyckoff. N.J., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Jeffrey M. Bachrach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Bachrach of New York and Southbury, Conn.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, June 12 (Reuters)  Leaders of developing countries pressed their industrialized British Commonwealth part. ners today to press for a new order that would give poor nations a greater share of the world's wealth.

title: Dance: International Festival a Success in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, June 12  The First North American International Dance Festival ended the three, days of its dance festivities at the Civic Opera House here last night. it has been a decided success, and one hopes that the fact that this was called the first festival will lead to a second, third, fourth, ad infinitum. Such a festival does meet a need for the North American continent  the need to see top international dance stars, both rising and ascendant, all in the space of a few days.

title: Tennesseans Uneasy With Ray at Large
description: PETROS, Tenn., June 12 When I went to bed last night, W. E. Hall Jr. said, I put my. 45 on the table next to my head and propped chairs against all the doors. There were dogs howling yonder until the sun came up.

title: Singapore is a Bitter Harbor for Vietnam Refugees
description: SINGAPORE, June 12In one of Singapore's least desirable corners, in a fishing harbor where the stench is overpowering, three boats no longer go out to fish. Instead. their oven decks serve as home for 34 Vietnamese who fled their country and have found no other country to give them even temporary shelter.

title: Albert Leaves Hospital
description: McALESTER, Okla., June 12 (AP)  Carl Albert, former United States Speaker of the House, was released from McAlester General Hospital today after treatment for minor injuries received in a hitandrun accident yesterday as he was stepping on a curb near his office. Mr. Albert, 69 years old, was treated for cuts and bruises. Sampson Benjamin, 81, of McAlester, was arrested several hours after the accident and chargedwith leaving the scene of a personal injury accident, the police said.

title: Bridge:
description: If there was any record of the youngest pair ever to finish first or second in a major championship, it would certainly have been broken during the recent Eastern Regional Championships.

title: Ickx Rally Wins Le Mans for Porsche
description: LE MANS, France, June 12 In an overnight comeback, Jacky Ickx drove a borrowed Martini Porsche 936 turbo to victory in the 24 Hours of Le Mans auto race, which ended this afternoon.

title: is Leader Accuses Carter Of Eroding Support of Israel
description: MONTICELLO, June 12, N.Y. (AP)The president of a major Jewish organization accused President Carter today of being antiIsrael and threatened him with loss of Jewish votes in 1980.

title: Watching Money Supply's Velocity of Circulation
description: The Federal Reserve Board has tried to keep the money supply growing at a reasonably steady and moderate rate in recent years, and on the whole it has succeeded. Though the money supply has bounced around somewhat

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: You report on June 2 that Anatoly Shcharansky, a leading dissident in Moscow, was charged with treason in a move by Soviet authorities that has few precedents since the days of Stalin.

description: WASHINGTON, June 12  President Carter, looking proud, welcomed his wife, Rosalynn, home from her sevennation tour of the Caribbean and Latin America today, obviously pleased with the results of the trip and with his wife's success as a fledgling diplomat.

description: MADRID, June 12  Felipe Gonzilez, the 35yearold Socialist leader whose electoral star seems to be rising fast, complains that the 21day official campaign for the parliamentary election on Wednesday allots half a day on the stump for every year of Francoism.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 12 (UPI) The United States press exaggerated reports of humanrights violations in connection with the imprisonment of two American missionaries in Brazil, Foreign Minister Antnio Azeredo da Silveira said in an interview published today.

title: Equality: The Remaining Barriers
description: We know that higher education eon cannot solve all the problems that beset our nation. But we know also'that without a strong system of higher education, we can solve none of them. And unless our system of education honors the principle of quality, we will make those problems worse.

Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Golden of Pennsauken, N.J. The couple will use the surname PetersGolden.

title: 301 Oil Exploration Units
description: TULSA, Okla., June 13 (AP)The total number of seismic land and marine vessels searching for oil climbed above 300 in May for the first time in two years, the Society of Exploration Geophysicists reported today. The total for the month was 301 crews and vessels, 22 percent higher than a year ago but 4 percent below the figure for May 1974. The society said four contractors were operating 10 of their 238 land crews and two of their 23 marine vessels on a speculative basis during the month.

title: Suarez, Ending Campaign, Urges Spain to Choose the Middle Way
description: MADRID. June 13Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez tonight wound up Spain's first open electoral campaign in four decades, urging citizens to vote for his new centerright coalition as an alternative to the far right and the Marxist left.

The occasion was a concert by the Studio Orchestra, formed more than a year ago by Harvey Estrin, a woodwind player in the original SauterFinegan band, specifically to play the S.F. repertory.

The Democrat, a North Texas daily newspaper, has a paid circulation of 19,000.

title: YONKERS IS ORDERED TO REHIRE TEACHERS

title: Around the Nation
description: PHOENIX, June 13 (UPI)The trial of two men charged with slaying Don Bolles, an investigative reporter, a year ago was delayed today until July 11 because of the discovery of new evidence.

title: Flag History
description: Two hundred years ago the first official flag of the United States was formally adopted by the Continental Congress sitting in Philadelphia, on June 14, 1777. The resolution stated that the Flag of the United States be thirteen stripes alternate red and white, that the Union be thirteen stars white in a blue field representing new constellation. Although the resolution did not specify the arrangement of the thirteen stars on the Blue Union, it is interesting to note that the first flag flown thereafter by the Continental Army used the design created by Betsy Ross about a month before the Declaration of Independence, July 4, 1776. The Betsy Ross flag followea a design suggested by George Washington wherein the thirteen stars were arranged in a circle, indicating that no colony should take precedence. Obviously the design took hold, as is evidenced by the minutes of the State Naval Board on May 29, 1777, recording payment to Elizabeth Ross for fourteen pounds, twelve shillings, and two pence for making ship's colours, thus leading to the adoption a month later of the flag which has served our nation for 200 years as a symbol of life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

title: THREE SOUGHT IN KILLING OF HASIDIC RABBI'S SON
description: The police said yesterday they were searching for three suspects in the fatal stabbing of a 17yearold student Sunday night in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

Danzig, an architect, is the artist in residence at Irvington.

title: Joseph Williams, Theatrical Agent; Opened BellyDancing Studio in 65

Suddenly and totally, he dropped out of the public limelight, delivered only a few unnoticed speeches at political functions and on college campuses, traveled to India and Brazil, and agreed to take on several parttime jobs.

description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 13President Carter was put on notice today that, even though relations between the cities and Washington had improved under his Administration, the cities still felt they were being neglected.

title: Aid Agency Said to Suppress Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)The Agency for International Development suppressed Census Bureau population estimates for several underdeveloped countries when the figures reflected unfavorably on A.I.D. birth control programs, according to a Congressional subcommittee.

title: WILLIAM J. A. GLANCY
description: William J. A. Glancy, a lawyer and former New York State Assemblyman, died Sunday at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived at 160 Cabrini Boulevard.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STILL THERE in 1762, a West Indian named Samuel Fraunces bought a Georgian, colonial style building that had been first a home and then a store and warehouse. Fraunces turned, the building into the tavern that now bears his name and is famous because George Washington said goodbye to his officers there in 2783.

title: Israeli Controllers End Dispute
description: TEL AVIV, June 13 (AP)Israel's air traffic controllers returned to work today, 18 days after the Government ordered military personnel to take over their jobs. The 85 traffic officers who work at the nation's five airports were suspended from their jobs and replaced by air force controllers after the Government said they had been causing delays in flights by working according to the rule book.

title: ParisNew York': A Century of Modern Art
description: PARISParisNew York at the new and still bitterly contested Centre National d'Art et de Culture Georges Pompidou (Beaubourg, for short) has one of the great subjects, not merely of modern art, but of modern civilization in general.

title: Wimbledon's Tennis Centennial Is Aglow Despite Commercialism
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 10The Victorian gentry who watched the Brat Lawn Tennis Championship tournament here 100 years ago would be dumfounded if they could see the AllEngland Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club today.

title: Chicago Daily News Names Four, Including a New Managing Editor
description: CHICAGO, June 13 (UPI)  The appointment of Gregory F. Favre as managing editor of The Chicago Daily News was announced Monday by James Hoge, editorinchief of The Daily News and Chicago SunTimes.

description: MILWAUKEE, June 13 (UPI)Gordon Johncock doesn't remember what happened, but he was in a hospital bed today wearing a neck brace.
