title: Abortion Foe Completes Trek
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)Paul Litkey, 25 years old, of Green Bay,. Wis., has completed a threemonth walk from ??? to the steps of the United States Supreme coat Protesting abourtion laws and court decisions. He carried a wooden cross on the entire. trip.

title: Soviet Confident it Cane Handle Rights Issue at Belgrade Conference
description: MOSCOW, June 13The Soviet Union is going into this week's preparatory session of the EastWest conference in Belgrade, Yugoslacia, outwardly confident that it can cope with criticism of its record on human rights.

title: PRESIDENT SOFTENS REBUKE TO CONGRESS, BUT WARNS ON ENERGY
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  President Carter softened his criticism of Congress today but warned that if special interests thwarted his energy goals the country would face a catastrophe.

title: Dow Up by 1.61 to a Close of 912.40; Bank Moves on Prime Rate a Spur
description: Stock prices rose slightly yesterday in response to indications of a letup in the recent rise in interest rates.

title: Ray is Back in Tennessee Prison; Governor Calls for U.S. Custody
description: Mr. Ray has asserted repeatedly that the slaying was part of a conspiracy. Several investigators from the House Select Committee on Assasinations, which is investigating the King slaying, arrived in Petros soon after Mr. Ray went over the wall. After he had been recaptured this morning, Robert Lehner, the committee's chief investigator, said. there was no evidence that Mr. Ray had had any outside assistance in his escape, they did not rule out the possibility.

title: Sharing the Higher Profits From Oil
description: President Carter's energy program is getting a rough ride in the committees of the House. The tentative decision of the Ways and Means Committee to delay the tax on inefficient automobilesthe gas guzzler levyuntil 1979 seems tolerable; the decision to eliminate the proposed rebate for the most efficient small cars is understandable, since no one knew how to avoid giving great sales boost to foreign imports. And the decision to shelve the standby gasoline tax, while shortsighted, is reparable. Most distressing so far is the decision a Commerce subcommittee to deregulate all natural gas prices, as if a truly free market were in operation and could be relied upon, overnight, to find its fair levels. As Mr. Carter has complained, this was a surrender of consumer interests to special interests and should be reversed by the House.

title: India's Courts Welcome Back Rule of Law
description: NEW DELHI, June 13Two young lawyers, wearing the black robes and starchy white dickies customary in Indian courtrooms, sat in a Bombay law library the other day, sipping tea during a trial break and discussing this country's new Government.

title: Associated Press
description: Two of the bloodhounds used in the tracking of James Earl Ray

title: U.S. Supreme Court Rules Illegal a New York State Statute That Denies College Tuition Aid to Some Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, June 13A New York State law that had denied college scholarships, tuition grants and loans to somebut not allaliens was struck down today by the Supreme Court as unconstitutionally discriminatory. The vote was 5 to 4.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter, commenting on the case of a Soviet Jew accused of treason, said he was completely convinced, that the man, Anatoly Shcharansky, had not been recruited as a spy by the Central Intelligence Agency, as Soviet press accounts have charged. Addressing the issue at a White House news conference, Mr. Carter also stressed that his commitment to human rights was, not specifically directed at the Soviet Union and said that he thought SovietAmerican relationscertain to be scrutinized in terms of his Shcharansky commentwere moving in the right direction. [Page 1, Column 2.]

title: Brett Experiments and Hits Homer
description: The Kansas City Royals, whose last view of Yankee Stadium was soured by the sight of Chris Chambliss's fly ball descending into the rightfield stands for a pennantwinning home run, returned in a different position last night and engineered a different outcome.

title: Agnes Clafin, 77; Was Art Professor At Vassar College
description: Agnes Rindge Claflin. professor emeritus of art at Vassar College, died Sunday at Benedictine Hospital, Kingstoh, N.Y. She was 77 years old and a resident of New Paltz, N.Y.

title: BILL TO ASSIST CITIES ADVANCES IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, June 13The State Senate approved today a oneyear extension of emergency financial assistance to the state's five largest cities outside of New York. But it tied the aid to the cities to a new, $40 million subsidy that will be spread around the 57 counties outside New York City next year to compensate them for growing welfare and Medicaid costs.

title: Soccer
description: SUNDAE'S MATCHES

title: Topics
description: As the President, the F.B.I., the Governor of Tennessee and all other authority well understood, the nation's sanity required that James Earl Ray be taken back alive. Had the murderer of Martin Luther King Jr. vanished or been slain in pursuit, the already difficult aspects of his trial and constant retrial in public debate would have spawned another decade's worth of itrefutable speculation and paranoia.

title: SUBPOENAS BY F.T.C. ON GAS DATA UPHELD
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)The Supreme Court today let stand a lower court's order that basically enforced subpoenas against seven big oil companies in an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission of shortages of natural gas.

title: Dr. George C. CeCotzias,Neurologist Who Developed LDopa Therapy
description: Dr. George C. Cotzias, an internationally prominent neurologist who developed LDopa therapy for Parkinson's disease, died of lung cancer yesterday at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center here, where he had taught, cared for patients and did research. He would have been 59 YEARS old on Thursday

title: ALBANY INTRODUCES DEATHPENALTY BILL
description: ALBANY, June 13Despite an almost certain veto, a bill to widen the scope of the state's death penalty and reshape it to comply with rulings of the United States Supreme Court was introduced in the Legislature today.

title: Japan Admits 37 Vietnamese
description: ICAICOGAWA, Japan, June 13 (Reuters) A group of 37 Vietnamese refugees rescued by a Liberian freighter obtained temporary permission to land in Japan today, the Tokyo office of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees said.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A public interest group filed a class action suit against the State Department of Education, charging that it failed to provide a thorough and efficient education for all public school children.

title: Senate Alters Rules to let Aides Of Members Solicit Voting Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)The Senate changed its rules today to allow a senator's aides, to solicit campaign funds for his nomination or election expenses. The change was quietly approved by voice vote without debate or opposition.

title: Dutch Questioning Hostages to Collect Evidence for Trial
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, June 13Officials of the Dutch Ministry of Justice today began questioning hostages of the hijacked train and the village school gathering evidence for prosecution of the seven surviving South Moluccans who held them captive for 20 days.

title: Camille Lavington Bride of Robert L. Edge11
description: Camille Perkins Lavington of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick John Perkins Jr. of Denver, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Louis Edgell of New York, president of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publications and senior vice president of that corporation. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl Robert EdgeII of Elmira, N.Y. The Rev. Bruce W. Forbes performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 14, 1977

title: A Top Mobster Pleads Guilty to 9 Bribery Charges
description: HACKENSACK, June 13Frank Miceli, an alleged lieutenant in the crime  family of the late Carlo Gambino. pleaded guilty today to nine bribery and conspiracy charges stemming from an 11month investigation of loansharking and other illicit activities in 1974 and 1975.

title: AFRIKANER UNIVERSITY TO ACCEPT NONWHITES
description: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa, June 13 (AP)  Stellenbosch University, South Africa's leading Afrikaanslanguage institution, has announced it will admit nonwhite students for the first time.

title: Ruling on REA Debt Affirmed
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)The Supreme Court today refused to hear an appeal aimed at canceling a $28 million debt owed to 86 railroads by the bankrupt REA Express Corporation.

title: Saudi Help Put at $12 Billion
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 13 (AP)Saudi Arabia's development fund has extended of $12.7 billion in aid and loans to Asian and African countries since 1973, the Saudi radio reported today.

title: Dollar Mixed A broad
description: LONDON, June 13 (AP)Gold closed at $138 an ounce in London today, its lowest price since the end of February, while the dollar had a narrowly mixed day in Europe in Tokyo, the dollar fell 2 yen in heavy selling.

title: Notes on People
description: Paul Newinan, the actor who drives sports cars in races as a sideline, narrowly escaped injury Sunday when another car flipped into the air and landed on the one he was driving. The accident took place in Garrettsville, Ohio, where Mr. Newman was driving a Datsun 510 in a 25car Sports Car Club of America race. A car driven by Robert Dyson, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., crowded Mr. Newman's on the approach to an overpass bridge. Mr. Dyson's car, going out of control, collided with barrier on the foundation of the bridge flipped into the air and came down on Mr. Newman's car. Both cars were wrecked but neither driver was hurt.

title: CARTER DENIES C. I. A. ENGAGED SOVIET JEW
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  President Carter said today that he was completely convinced that a Soviet Jew accused of treason had to our knowledge never worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Stage: Canada's Intimate Shaw Festival HasWit and Style
description: NIAGARAONTHELAKE, Ontario, Jude 13Canada's Shaw Festival, occupying a handsome new brick theater in a riverside park and a smaller theater in the courthouse, is smaller and more intimate than its Shakespearean neighbor at Stratford, 100 miles to the west. Its concentration upon Shaw tends to set its aim on wit and styleand frequently achieves itrather than power and innovation.

description: Should the owner of a major league baseball team be allowed to act as its field manager? Common sense, logic and the principles of free enterprise say yes. Major league rule 20 (e) says no. sort of.

description: Arbitrary quotas, Joseph A. Califano said the other day in his commencement address at the City College of New York, would not be part of the Federal Government's affirmative action program to achieve greater minoritygroup participation in professional and higher education. But, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare added, the Government would rely because we must rely, on numerical goals as benchmarks of progress.

title: Girl, 10 Months Old, Dies After Ingesting Laetrile; Doctor Issues Warning
description: Laetrile, the controversial cancer treatment, was blamed yesterday for causing the death of a 10monthold girl on Saturday at a Buffalo hospital. She had reportedly swallowed an unknown amount of the substance.

title: Court Backs New York's Policy onthe Removal of Foster Children
description: WASHINGTON, June 13The Supreme Court ruled today that children who have been living with foster parents may generally be taken from the foster families and transferred elsewhere without hearing on the merits of the transfer.

description: WASHINGTON, June 13The investigation by the Senate Government Operations Subcommittee into the accounting profession began in acrimony five months ago with a sizzling 1,760page report that scored the accountants and their nominal regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: WASHINGTON, June 13Defense Secretary Harold Brown warned Congress today that going ahead with the development of the experimental breeder reactor would increase the risk of the spread of nuclear weapons to nations that do not sow have them.

title: Investigators for House Uncertain Whether Ray Got Outside Help
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)Investigators for the House assassinations committee said today that they did not know if James Earl Ray had received outside help in his prison escape over the weekend.

title: 3 Die in North Carolina Crash

Josephine Jefferson, the girls mother, was hospitalized in serious. conditon.

title: Califono Asks Social Security Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI)The proposal to provide $14 billion to bail out the Social Security System is an attempt to prevent additional taxes for average Americans and, next to energy, is President Carter's most important bill, Secretary Califano said today.

title: Joseph Celli Offers MixedMedia Music
description: Joseph Celli, who plays the oboe and English horn and often performs in mixed media, presented a concert of live and electronic music and film Saturday and Sunday at the Experimental Intenneidia Foundation. Included in the program was a premiere, Two Octaves and a Fifth, by Phill Niblock. Each of the three continuous tones that made up the taped portion of the piece was actually a cluster of several oboe tones, in nearperfect unison, and Mr. Celli played in unison with one or another of the tones while walking around the performing space.

title: Soccer is Allie Sherman's New Toy
description: Everything in Clive Toye's vision for the last decade finally seemed to be coming into focus. The largest assembly of soccer aficianados in the history of the New York Cosmos had been rewarded with a 21 victory Sunday over the Minnesota Kicks on Tony Field's shootout goal. Standing the tunnel to the Giants Stadium locker rooms, Clive Toye had felt the noise as 36,816 spectators saluted the team he had constructed, the team with Franz Beckenbauer, Pele and Giorgio Chinaglia that was leading its North American Soccer League division in driving home along the Bronx River Parkway, he had noticed four different sandlots where youngsters were playing soccer. The youngsters were not involved in an organized soccer game or practice, they were just kicking a soccer ball around as if it was the most natural thing in their neighborhood to do, as if baseball was foreign game. Clive Toye should have been delighted with the future of his role. But yesterday he announced his resignation as the Cosmos president in order to become special consultant for the franchise.

title: Exporters Plan $10 Billion Limit InHelping World Defray Oil Bills
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 13The rich oilexporting countries have agreed to put up only about $10 billion to help the rest of the world pay its soaring oil bills this year, a senior international economic official disclosed here today. That is down sharply from the $15 billion to $20 billion that international groups had hoped to raise.

title: Dardanelle and Dean Join Forces at Cleo's
description: Dardanelle, a pianist and singer, and Peter Dean, a huskyvoiced singer and ukulele strummer, each of whom usually works as an individual act, have joined forces at Cleo's, Broadway at 63d Street, to make a whole that is a bit more than the sum.of the parts.

title: Syria Hangs 2 Alleged Iraqi Agents
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13 (Reuters)Two Syrians were publicly hanged in the main square of Damascus today after having been convicted of belonging to an assassination squad alleged to have been financed by Iraq.

title: Accord Reached at New York Post On a Pact With Newspaper Guild
description: Agreement on a new contract between The New York Post and the Newspaper Guild of New York was announced last night by Theodore W. Kheel, who served as mediator in the dispute.

title: Pupils Who Saw Teacher Slaying May Take Stand
description: DETROIT, June 13A jury of nine men and five women was selected here today to hear the firstdegree murder trial of Al Junior Lewis, accused last November of shooting to death his estranged wife, Bettye McCaster, in her firstgrade classroom in front of many of her pupils.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: One Day of Splendid Fly Fishing for Tarpon
description: MARATHON, Fla.Ominous, towering black clouds, high winds and bursts of torrential rain kept us ashore most of the second of two days of fly fishing for tarpon off the Florida Keys, and the excitement of our first day's encounter with those huge, silvery, acrobatic fish was not repeated.

description: Chub Feeney, National League president, said yesterday that Joe West would be called up from the American Association to umpire in place of the injured Ed Vargo. West will work the game in San Diego tonight between the Padres and Chicago Cubs. He is 25 years old.

description: DES MOINES, Iowa, June 11In the next few weeks, the bankers and the lawyer will finally start parceling out some of Joseph M. Dorgan's money.

title: Family Utility With 293 Customers Agrees to Regulation by Hartford
description: HARTFORD, June 13The Fletcher family of Southwick, Mass., agreed today to let the Public Utilities Control Authority of Connecticut set the rates for the electricity it sells to a little community of customers across the border in Connecticut that they have served for 46 years and that the rest of the world seemed to have lost sight of.

title: Nurse in Michigan Denies She Worked When Patients Died
description: DETROIT, June 13Leonora M. Perez, a Filipino nurse, testified today that she was not at work in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor on the nights she is accused of causing two patients to suffer breathing failure.

title: Constance Hope Berliner, Counsel In Public Relations for Opera Stars
description: Constance Hope Berliner, public relations counsel for many opera stars, died yesterday at her home at 171 West 57th Street. She was 69 years old.

description: MOUNTAINAIR, N. M., June 9Marie Autrey was ??? beans for lunch when she looked up and saw the Government truck bouncing along the dusty road toward the ranch house. Even before it pulled to a stop in the front yard she knew what was in store.

title: 2,900 Elderly Sail in the Sun on a Tide of Memories
description: YONKERS, June 13 Mr. and Mrs. James Hoar, 76 and 78 years old, were at the Yonkers pier by 9 o'clock this morning, their tickets in their hands. Half an hour later they had settled into folding chairs on the sunny deck of the Hudson River Day Line sightseeing boat, which was rocking gently in the water at the end of the pier.

description: BUENOS AIRES, June 13A former President of Argentina, Lieut. Gen. Alejandro Agustin Lanusse, was ordered released from jail today by a federal court of appeals that reversed an arrest order issued three weeks ago.

description: TELAVIV, June 13The Begin era opened in Jerusalem this afternoon with trumpets and fanfare as the members of Parliament who were elected May 17 were inducted.

title: A Day in the Life of Menahem Begin Reflects Fierce Loyalties of an Israeli Founder
description: JERUSALEM, June 13They were small things on an important day in the life of Menahem Begin, but they served to illustrate something about who he is and what might be expected from him if he takes over as Israel's leader.

title: Still Preoccupied With Death as Penalty
description: The frantic search of state legislatures, including New York's, for a capital punishment statute that will meet the requirements of the Supreme Court testifies to primitive obsession with execution as a symbol of law and order. The history of jurisprudence leaves little room for disagreement with Roy Jenkins's proposition, in 1973, that the penalty is too final to be controlled by the frailty of human judgment. The death penalty has been abandoned by virtually all Western industrial nations. it was abandoned by the Vatican in 1969. State legislatures that labor so hard to bring back the executioner are struggling to join South Africa and assorted totalitarian states that cling to capital punishment.

title: Horseman Protesting Maryland Bridge Ban
description: SKIDMORE, Md., June 13 (AP)Everything is quiet, Billy Marks of Newark said today on a grassy lot where he is camped with his two horses. But I'm getting some hunger pains.

title: TV: NBC Looks at Human Rights
description: Television news is frequently criticized, quite justifiably, for being unable or reluctant to deal with most current news developments in any depth beydnd that of an extended headline. It can be, done, say the critics, and this week, on the eve of preparatory sessions for the important EastWest conference in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, it is being done to a remarkable extent by one network's specialprogramming department. Somewhat ironically, that network is NBC, where a good part of the news operations has been buffeted, by rumors of indecision and low morale in the last several months.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The New York Times on Friday that an uudit by the City Comptroller found. that the J.E.T. consortium had received Federal Job funds to train 549 persons, and that more than half had been trained for Jobs for which little or no. training was needed: The consortitim, a unit of the B'nal Torah Institute of, Brooklyn, actually trained 102 persons, of whom 27 received lowskill Jobe requiring little or no training.

title: Avis Bidding Joined By a British Retailer
description: The bidding contest for Avis Inc., the nation's No. 2 car rental company, was joined yesterday by Sears Holdings Ltd., a leading British retailer, which said it was interested in buying 20 to 25 percent of Avis stock for $21 a shareor $41.4 million in cash.

description: LONDON, June 13Three British Navy helicopters in a team of six that was rehearsing for an air show off the Cornish coast near Penzance collided in the air today and three men were killed.

title: COMMONWEALTH TALKS EASE SOUTH AFRICA RIFT
description: LONDON, June 13 (UPI)Commonwealth leaders laid the groundwork for a compromise settlement of their dispute over sports links with South Africa during a weekend session at a tightly guarded retreat in Scotland.

title: New Designers Add Perspective to Fall Fashions
description: The upbeat feeling among those who have seen the fall fashion collections in New York has a twopart basis on the one hand, most established designers have created their best clothes in years, styles that are not only wearable, but also imaginative on the other, new names have come along to provide a different slant on the going looks. Their labels widen the scope of available fashion and contribute to the excitement of the new season.

title: People and Business
description: Bernard Cornfeld, founder of the defunct mutual fund empire, Investors Overseas Services, has become a member of the international jet set again, although the scene was sober rather than sybaritic. The 49yearold former social worker, who lives in Beverly Hills, Calif., appeared in a Swiss courtroom yesterday on fraud charges stemming from the collapse of the gigantic mutual fund complex.

title: If You Like. Fresh Herring, Your Ship is In

title: NEW PANEL TO STUDY FUTURE OF PUBLIC TV
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced yesterday the formation of a private commission to study the future course of public broadcasting in the United States in light of emerging new communications technologies and the fiscal and structural problems of the present nublictelevision system.

title: 2 Whites Killed in Johannesburg As 3 Blacks Open Fire in Garage
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 13  Three black men armed with submachine guns and.grenades burst into a downtown garage near police headquarters here today and opened fire, killing two white men and seriously injuring a, third. The Government, asserting that the weapons were of Communist origin, described it as an outburst of urban terrorism.

title: Basketball Star Receives A Conditional Dismissal Of Queens Theft Charge
description: Eddie Lee, a basketball star for the University of Cincinnati who was arrested last February in Jamaica, Queens, and charged with taking ft wallet from decoy police officer, received a conditional discharge yesterday in Queens Criminal Court.

title: Books of The Times
description: In 1949, mostly to embarrass the new Democratic Governor, Republicans in the Illinois Legislature teamed up with a flock of bird lovers to pass An Act to Provide Protection to Insectivorous Birds by Restraining Cats. The act would have imposed fines on cat owners who permitted their pets to wander around, would have permitted any person to captureor summon the police to seizea loose cat and would have permitted the use of traps. The idea was that no matter what the Governor did. he would offend someone.

title: The Dance: Leading Soloist Mugged, City Ballet Carries On
description: The unhappy aspect of New York City Ballet's weekend happened offstage, when one of its leading soloists, Bart Cook, was mugged away from the, theater after Saturday night's performance, resulting in a rearrangement of casting at the New York State Theater on Sunday on the specific instructions of George Balanchine, the explicit reason for Mr. Cook's absencehe has suffered a broken nose and various other injurieswas given to the matinee audience.

title: Seattle Slew Beats Fiction
description: Seattle Slew beat Run Dusty Run by four lengths in the Belmont Stakes, but defeated fiction by a margin wide no one bothered to measure it. Dozens of racing novels and movies were stirred together in a single story so implausible that many turf experts still refuse to believe what they saw. Despite Slew's triumph in the three major threeyearold stakes, as well as every other race he entered, they tell the world that he isn't as good Secretariat and that his jockey, Jean Cruguet, is not the same class as Earl Sande. They resemble the barroom experts who announce that Muhammad Ali could not have lasted ten rounds with. Jack Johnson, or that Francis Ouimet with Jack Nicklaus's clubs would have broken 60 at Brookline.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that it was hopeful that the $700 million Seadock offshore Texas crude oil port would be developed. The company said it had the proposal under consideration and will reach a decision by the Aug. 1 deadline. Last Thursday the Mobil Corporation confirmed its defection from the project but the largest participant, the Exxon Pipeline Company, said it was staying in. It indicated it, too, hoped to meet the Aug. 1 deadline on its 21.7 percent participation in the project.

title: Freight Trains Collide in Maryland

Amtrak officials said the crash blocked train traffic for several hours this morning between New York and Washington.. The authorities at Conrail saidthe accident occurred in Rosendale, Md., around 11:30 P.M.

Debris washed up on Long Island shores last year resulted in the closing of several beaches, including parts. of Jones Beach, during the height of the summer recreation season.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: HISTORIANS contend, of course that Italy was actually the cradle French cooking (I have yet to find a French chef, including myself, willing to admit to the truth of that claim) and that it all began with the arrival of Catherine de Medici, who came to France to wed Henry. in the 16th century. To be sure there are certain dishes in French cooking that are dead ringers for those produced in Italian kitchens and vice versa. One of most conspicuous of these is the dish known in France as foie de veau lyormaiss. or calves liver and onions, and in Italy as legato alla veneziana. The former is the style of Lyon, the latter, in the style of Venice.

title: Young Violinist Steps Ahead Her Way

Perhaps it is not even the best way. Within the musical world. disillusionment with contests as method of selecting the most talented artists has been apparent for a long tme and it seems to be growing stronger. Some young musicians now make a point of avoiding the competition circuit entirely, building their reputations by a wide variety of means: grants by arts councils, fellowships, internships, scholarships and with increasing success, privately endowed, noncompetitively awarded prizes.

title: Rosalynn Carter Elected
description: The unspoken question behind many appraisals Rosalynn Carter's journey to seven Latin and Caribbean nations has been Who elected her? People here and abroad have wondered whether it was somehow insulting to send the First Lady if the President and Vice President were too busy with other continents. People have winced at the thought of an Imperial Family taking over where the Imperial Presidents left off: Lillian Carter to India, Chip Carter to Buffalo and China; Amy Carter to the public school constituency and now Rosalynn Carter to eighthour summit conferences with chiefs of state. Some complain of nepotism and some have questioned directly whether First Ladies have any right leave the East, or distaff, Wing of the White House and to escape the FamilyStyle pages.

title: Pairings at Wimbledon A FirstRound Feast
description: LONDON. June 14  It was an old blue woolen hag, the kind grandma might have used 40 years ago to hide old coins or cookies. And as Peter Johns, the secretary of the British Lawn Tennis Association, began pulling numbered metal disks from it in a sec andfloor room at the All England Lawn Tennis Club today, the draw for the 100th Wimbledon championships became a feast of exciting firstround men's singles matches.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: trot C F. 3, mile.

title: Gregorek in Fast Mile As St. Anthony's Wins
description: GREENVALE, L.I., June 14 John Gregorek ran an anchor mile of minutes 8.3 seconds, his fastest ever, to lead St. Anthony's High to victory in the fourmile relay event tonight at the Long Island A.C. Meet of Champions on the C. W. Post'College track.

title: Taiwan Agrees to Trim Exports Of Shoes to U.S. Over 4 Years
description: WASHINGTON, June 14To avoid the imposition of higher American tariffs, Taiwan formally pledged today to reduce and limit its shoe exports to the United States over the next four years.

title: Governor of Louisiana Defends Gift Of $10,000 to His Wife by Korean
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana defended today his wife's acceptance of a $10,000 gift in cash from Park Tong Sun, the Korean businessman who has been accused of being an influencepeddling agent of the South Korean Government.

title: Is Mass Food Hopeless?
description: BETTER FOOD FOR PUBLIC PLACES. A Guide for Improving Institutional Food. By Anne Mover. 276 pages. Rodalo Press. $8.95.

title: Pop: Soul By Ronnie Spector
description: RONNIE SPECTOR, who was the lead vocalist for one of the most fondly remembered pop vocal groups of the early 1950's, the Ronettes, has been out of the public eye for 10 years now. As very young pop singer at the time of her greatest success, she was very much under the influence of Phil Spector,the producer of her records and later, her husband. He surrounded her voice, singular combination of innocence and toughness, with a densely orchestral, rhythmically supercharged wall of sound, turning threeminute love songs into epics. Reportedly, he kept Miss Spector from performing throughout their marriage.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Precisely what does the word f Ian mean?

title: Money
description: NEW YORK fell Money rates for Tuesday.

title: BARBARO OPENS CAMPAIGN FOR BROOKLYN PRESIDENT
description: Charging that the Democratic Party in Brooklyn was influenced by morally bankrupt politicians, New York State Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro yesterday announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Borough President.

title: Suburban Schools Are Evolving Basic Curriculums Geared to 70's
description: At Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, N.Y., 164 students have signed up for Latin next fall, more than at any time in the last 20 years. Parents and kids are more interested in good grammar, said Bertram Lipkin, who teaches the ancient language. There more seriousness of purpose.

title: Where to Find Super Stogies
description: ??? aficicnndos say New York is not the cigar hopper's town it used to be but there are still plenty of stores around Manhattan that carry a variety of handmade and machinemade, domestic and imported smokes in variety of colors. Here are some samples:

title: Mutual Savings Bank Inflow
description: NEW YORK, June 14 (AP) Mutual savings banks nationwide had a $560 million net deposit inflow in May, an industry organization reported Tuesday. The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said the inflow was well above average for May and is up from an outflow in April of $168 million.

title: State Is Revising Emergency Plan In Wake of Salem Nuclear Accident
description: TRENTON. June 11As a result of an accident at the Salem nuclear generating station 10 days ago, New Jersey is revising its state emergency plan and will require operators of nuclear plants to notify the Department of Environment Protection of all plant shutdowns and spills of lowlevel radioactive water used to cool reactors.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Records are crowding bureaucrats out of their offices. City Council President Paul O'Dwyer, chief sponsor of a bill permitting the city to discard some of the six million cubic feet of documents it has in storage. I.B11:4.]

title: Two Directors Resign At United Merchants
description: Two outside directors of United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc. have resigned from the board of the financially troubled textile company, which operates the Robert Hall clothing chain. One resignation was effective May 9 and the other last Friday.

title: Rangers Go for Forwards
description: After selecting Lucien DeBlois, a big right wing, and then Ron Duguay, an even bigger center, in the first round of yesterday's National Hockey League amateur draft, John Ferguson rose from the littered conference table and turned his palms outward.

title: YONKERS IS SEEKING APPEAL ON TEACHERS
description: YONKEFLS, June 14The Board of Education said tonight that it would try to appeal a decision by the Appellate Division requiring the rehiring and repayment of $5 million to S7 million in back pay with interest to 350 teachers dismissed during the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Changed South Africa Nears Anniversary of Soweto Riots
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 14A year ago Thursday, a burst of police gunfire on a dusty hillside outside this city ended the life of a 12yearold protest marcher named Hector Petersen. In the turmoil that followed, forces were unleashed here and abroad that have permanently, changed South Africa.

title: TV: End of Summer Revived
description: WNET/13's Theater in America series hits clinker tonight at 9, with an excruciatingly dull revival of S. N. Behrman's End of summer. The production has been sasted together awkwardly; the seams are unsightly and irritating. Billed as production of the Charles McArthur Center for American Theater in Tallahassee, Fla., the production mixes betterknown performers with members of Sarasota's Asolo State Theater. The lumpy result represents a pilot for projected series of 10 American plays to be used for a theater course in.

title: A Present for Pop to Puff On
description: Enjoying cigars at a benefit in 1935 were, from left, Harry Hirshfield, Alfred E. Smith and Fiorello LaGuardia. Story on cigars is on page C12.

title: U. S. COURT UPHOLDS PORT AUTHORITY BAN ON CONCORDE FLIGHTS
description: A Federal appeals court, reversing lower court, said yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey had the right to ban the Concorde from Kennedy International Airport so long as the han was fair, reasonable, and nondiscriminatory.

title: With Election, Spain Takes a Giant Step Into Democratic Europe
description: MADRID, June 14With its first open elections in two generations tomorrow, Spain is finally about to enter the era of partybuilding and institutionbuilding that engaged most West European countries 30 years ago. There are dozens of parties, some local and some national, with 15 to 20 competiting in single provincial constituencies. But apart from the Communists, who have been able to surface their wellknit underground, there are no real party organizations, only skeletal groups and loose coalitions built mostly around personalities rather than clear points of view.

title: Bayi, in 5,000 Race, Posts 2d Fastest Time of Year
description: STOCKHOLM, June 14 (AP) Filbert Bayi, the world 1.500meter recordholder, switched to the 5,000 meters at a track and field meet today and ran the distance in the world's second fastest time of the year.

title: Study Is Challenged
description: BOSTON, June 14 (AP)  New England Electric's finding that 100 experimental solarpowered home water heating systems were uneconomical was challenged today by the Massachusetts Office of Consumer Affairs. In a statement, the Secretary of Consumer Affairs. Christine B. Sullivan, said that the power company's experiment used inadequate controls because the company had based its findings on heating units from 17 different manufacturers.

title: Market Place
description: Oil analysts who have studied the soaring costs of the TransAlaska pipeline and the stiff demands of the state's Legislature are beginning to question whether there is a bonanza in Alaskan oil for the major partcipants and their shareholders.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: EXBANK COMMISSIONER IS INDICTED IN DELAWARE
description: WILMINGTON, Del., June 14 (AP)Delaware's former banking commissiorter has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of using his office to extort more than S30.000 in loans from the Farmers Bank of Delaware.

title: Major Imports of Foreign Cars
description: Major Imports of Foreign Cars

title: FORMER CHAIRMAN OF BANK INDICTED BY U.S. IN CHICAGO
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)John S. Gleason Jr., former board chairman of the Mercantile National Bank of Chicago, was indicted today on Federal charges of misapplying more than S500,000 in bank funds for his personal use. The indictment, returned by a Federal grand jury in the District Court in Chicago, was announced by the Justice Department.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: HISTORIANS contend, of course that Italy was actually the cradle French cooking (I have yet to find a French chef, including myself, willing to admit to the truth of that claim) and that it all began with the arrival of Catherine de Medici, who came to France to wed Henry. in the 16th century. To be sure there are certain dishes in French cooking that are dead ringers for those produced in Italian kitchens and vice versa. One of most conspicuous of these is the dish known in France as foie de veau lyormaiss. or calves liver and onions, and in Italy as legato alla veneziana. The former is the style of Lyon, the latter, in the style of Venice.

title: Croatian Nationalists Hijacked Jet Last Year to Publicize Cause
description: The gunmen who invaded the Yugoslav Mission to the United Nations and shot one person yesterday were members of a separatist movement that has been waging an international war on the Belgrade Government for several years.

title: Growing Up An Only Child
description: THIS great department of this great newspaper will not object to my disclosing the provenance this article. My wife and I were asleep on the floor we cannon afford a hed, not at French prices in our apartment when the bell rang viciously and awoke us.

title: Gold Price Drops Again In2 European Markets; Dollar Narrowly Mixed
description: LONDON, June 14 (AP)  Gold prices fell again today in Europe and the dollar was narrowly mixed against European currencies.

title: Books: Vignettes of a Son Growing Up in Texas
description: In many ways William Humphrey's memoir of his childhood up to the death of his father in an automobile accident is the traditional one happy days in field and woods with his father; parental quarrels, sometimes violent, that terrified the youngster; freeswinging holidays in the village square and a sense of poverty that threatened imminent disaster.

title: Stage: Black Experience In America Is Pictured
description: SQUARE ROOT OF SOUL, which opened last night at the Theater de Lys, is an attempt to assemble a picture of the black experience in America by using some 40 poems or pieces of poems. It was conceived by Adolph Caesar, a veteran actor in the Negro Ensemble Company; and Mr. Caesar, backed by music and .ound effects, is the sole performer.

title: Eastern Air Lines Agrees to Ban Smoking in 65% of Plane Seats
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Eastern Air Lines agreed to ban smoking in 65 percent of the seats on all its airplanes under a legal settlement announced today by two consumer groups that said it would be a precedent for the entire industry.

title: VANCE TAKES THEME OF RIGHTS TO O.A.S.
description: ST. GEORGES, Grenada, June 14Secretary of Slate Cyrus R. Vance today urged Latin American nations to respect human rights even when combating leftist terrorism.

title: New Schools in Caribbean Worry Medical Educators
description: Medical educators in the United States are becoming increasingly concerned about a proliferation of medical schools in the Caribbean and Mexico, which, they maintain, are being hastily created to tap the market of thousands of Americans who are rejected each year by medical schools in this country.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET DELEGATES AT BELGRADE TALKS CONFER
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 14On the eve of the preparatory conference on EastWest cooperation, the American delegate met today with his Soviet counterpart and said later he saw no need for confrontation with the Russians over human rights. The American, Albert W. Scherer Jr., said his talk with Yuli M. Vorontsov had resulted in no disputes.

title: Likud Assembling Narrow Coalition
description: JERUSALEM, June 14Menahem Begin today started setting up a narrow coalition composed of his Linked bloc and religious elements following the refusal of a new political party to join his cabinet.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: FLAG DAY AT THE CAPITOL: Army color guard from Third Infantry marching down Capitol steps in costumes representing all U.S. wars. Congress marked Flag Day with ceremony honouring the 288 recipients of Medal Honour. Johnny Cash, the Country and Western singer, recited his song The Ragged Old Flag before Congress.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ATLANTIC SAGA (ACL). Goteborg June 26, Oslo 29, Helsinki 29 and Leningrad July 1; sails from Pt. Eliza. beth, N.J.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Julius Lester teaches AfroAmerican studies at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: PROF. RICHARD M. BRACE, EXPERT IN FRENCH HISTORY
description: Prof. Richard M. Brace of the department of history at Oakland University in Rochester, Mich., died in Paris on June 5 while researching the history of French slavery. He was 61 years old.

title: K.G.B. IS QUESTIONING U.S. CORRESPONDENT
description: MOSCOW, June 14The Soviet security police today summoned an American correspondent for four hours of interrogation after he had been accused of gathering secret information.

title: Mondale and Chiefs Of House Democrats Agree on Voting Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Vice President Mondale and House Democratic leaders agreed today on three new proposals designed to increase Congressional support for voter registration on Election Day, the centerpiece of President Carter's election reform package.

title: Two Westchester Shelters to Kill Animals if Some Are Not Adopted
description: YONKERS, June 14It's tough when you have to go by and look at those eyes and say, You and you and you,' Vera Klein, a director of the Central Westchester Humane Society, said about 360 dogs and cats, some of which may have to be killed because there is not enough room to shelter them all.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: Bridge:
description: In midsummer each year, Deauville is the scene of a famous international tournament that attracts some of the world's greatest stars, and also course of lessons for intermediate players.

title: Pilot Killed in Jet Crash
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., June 14 (AP)An Air Force A10 jet fighter crashed and burst into flames 12 miles northwest of Georgetown, S.C.. yesterday, killing the pilot, the authorities said. He was identified as Maj. Richard H. Rogers, 34 years old, assigned to the 356th Tactical Fighter Squadron.

title: New Bridge to Open Near Yankee Stadium
description: The new Macombs Dam Bridge interchange to ease traffic congestion around Yankee Stadium and provide quicker access to midBronx areas will open today, Mayor Beame announced. The new $16.3 million ramp was paid for with 90 percent Federal funds and 10 percent state funds. It took two and a half years to constrict.

title: DOCTOR IS ACCUSED OF HARMING PATIENT
description: RIVERHEAD, L.L. June 14  A 49yearold anesthesiologist was arraigned today on charges of improperly injecting a drug into a patient at Central Suffolk Hospital in what was said to be an effort to discredit anesthetists at the hospital.

title: Letter: On BrandName Medicine
description: Your lead editorial of June 9, Rx Against BrandName Medicine, is hodgepodge of misinformation, inaccuracies, and naivete. You have done your readers a gross disservice. in fostering illusions of savings in drug prices that have little to do with the real world.

title: Fashion Shows As Theater
description: The fashion show has been chang ing from a commercial vehicle used to present and sell clothes as efficiently as possible to an esthetic experience. Fast disappearing are such accouterments as commentators, order pads, style numbers and prices. In their place are choreographers, models who dance and otherwise express themselves on the runway, and elaborate stereophonic systems and music planned as carefully as that in any successful discotheque. Rehearsals are de rigueur, and models who once dropped in casually to see if they fitted into the clothes are now booked for as much as two days of practice time.

title: Ronan's Public and Private Funds Often the Subject of Controversies
description: During his long public career, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, has been involved in controversies about his private assets, his use of public funds and his accountability to the State Comptroller's office.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: The directors of the Municipal Assistance Corporation met yesterday in happy mood and swiftly accepted an offer from an underwriting syndicate to sell $250 million in 18year bonds at 7.5 percent interest, a rate that had been agreed on the day before.

title: Music: Hindell Displays Bassoon
description: THE BASSOON is to the orchestra what the comprimario is to the opera, the hardworking character actor who performs in the background, but without whose presence few operas would make sense. The bassoonist spends most of his time laying down a rhythmic and harmonic foundation over which instrumental stars such as the violin or oboe can work their lyrical wonders. So a concert that puts the bassoon at the center of the universe for a moment deserves attention.

title: Stuttgart Ballet Retains Heritage
description: IT IS EIGHT YEARS since the splendid Stuttgart Ballet first visited New Yorkand a lot has happened to it since that warm June night at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1969. Last night, the company that the British choreographer John Cranko founded joyously opened its fifth New York season at the Met. Since Cranko's death, returning home from the company's third American visit in 1973, the troupe first had Glen Tetley as its director, and following his resignation, the Stuttgart's prima ballerina, Marcia Haydee took over the family apronstrings.

title: Ronans World Trip at Port Authority Expense Put Off
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, yesterday put off a roundtheworld air tour with his wife that was to be paid for at public expense, and called a special authority meeting for Friday.

title: Calif. StateL.A. Victor; Minnesota Is Eliminated
description: OMAHA, June 14 (UPI)  Gary Adair's runscoring single in the eighth game California StateLos Angeles a 10 victory over Clemson tonight in the college world series.

title: Mayor to Issue Ban on Parking In Midtown Area
description: Mayor Beame is to announce today 24hour ban on parking in mid town Manhattan, according to a spokesman for the Mayor.

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Palomino Knocks Out Foe To Retain W.B.C. Title
description: LONDON, June 14 (UPI)  Carlos Palomino of Mexico retained his World Boxing Council welterweight title tonight when he knocked out Dave Green of Britain in the 11th round of their scheduled 15 round fight at Wembley's Empire Pool.

title: GENERAL FEARS U.S. ROLE IN A SOVIETCHINA WAR
description: FRANKFURT, June 14 (UPI)A newly named American fourstar general has warned members of an American high school graduating class that the United States would probably become involved in a SovietChinese war during their lifetime.

title: Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  An economist and consultant to the Government told an advertising audience here today that the banning of certain types of advertising to children on TV could cause the networks to eliminate children's programming altogether.

title: CORRECTION
description: In yesteriday's Market Place column, the General Foods Corporation was incorrectly identified as having secured rights to manufacture toys relating to the Twentieth CenturyFox film Star Wars. The Kerner Products unit of General Mills Inc. has obtained those rights.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: How would you like to hold a million dollars in your hand and then wash down the draingradually, of course. It's possible with some imagination and something called the 51,000,000 bar of soap, which is a bar of soap, shaped like a bundle of one thousand $1,00n bills, and printed to look like money. We didn't test it but they say the printing lasts as long as the soap does. The bar comes in a canvas bag, which isn't quite the way banks transport their money but is close enough to be fun. Filthy rich, dirt poor, middleclass slobfor $5 anyone can walk away with the soap at Bobby Dazzler, a men's boutique at 1450 Second Avenue (76th Street).

title: House Democrats Say Carter's Patronage Policy Saps Party Discipline
description: WASHINGTON, June 14House Democratic leaders told three highranking members of the Carter Administration today that the President's failure to effectively use patronage had undermined Democratic Party discipline in Congress.

title: 1977 Amateur Draft
description: Detilcit, Dale McCourt, center, St. Catherines; Colorado, Barry Beck, Defenseman, New Westminister; Washington, Robert Picard, defenseman, Montreal Juniors; Vancouver, Jere Gillis, lett wing, Sherbrooke; Cleveland, Mike Crombeen, right wing, Kingston; Chicago, Doug Wilson, defenseman, Ottawa; Minnesota, Brad Maxwell, defenseman, New Westminister; Rangers, Lucien DeBlois, right wing, Sorel; St. Louis, Scott Campbell, defenseman, London; Montreal (from Atlanta), Mark Napier, right wing, Birmingham.

title: Like It Is
description: AMHERST, Mass.The continuing calls for the resignation of United Nations Ambassador Andrew Young are a sad but real reminder that a particularly pernicious kind of racism is alive and well. This is the racist mechanism which unconsciously expects and demands that any black in a position previously or usually occupied by a white conduct him or herself as whites wish, i.e., act, think and be like a white person. The black person who does so becomes what whites love and need: assurance that they are free of racism.

title: CHARLES WATSON 3D
description: Charles Watson 3d, retired managing director of the Yale Alumni Fund, died Monday at his Branford, Conn., home. He was 73 years old.

title: United Precs International SPANIARDS GO TO POLLS TODAY: A campaign worker in Segovia, Spain, displays Socialist Workers Party poster. Today, Spain will hold its first free elections since 1936. Details appear on page A2.
description: MADRID, June 14Spaniards are voting tomorrow in freedom and secrecy for a new parliament that is considered to mark the formal end of of four decades of dictatorship.

title: Getting Bugs To Buzz Off
description: AMONG THE arthropods are man's oldest, most prolific and persistent enemies. They bite, sting, suck, swarm, buzz, crawl and sap the pleasure from picnics, camping trips, fishing expeditions, summertime hikes and strolls in the setting sun. Just when you think you've found the peri'ect site to pitch a tent or build the summer cottage of your dreams, along come the black flies to drink your blood, or the wood ticks to bury their heads in your flesh, or the chiggers to dissolve your skinnot to mention the ubiquitous hordes of hungry mosquitoes. While man has never succeeded in completely controlling the multitudes of sixlegged and eightlegged creatures that plague him, he has found many ways to discourage these pests from feeding on him. Understanding the habits of manloving insects mites and spiders can help you to outwit them. And If that fails, it may be useful to know how to relieve the misery they inflict.

title: Senate Defeats Human Rights Amendment on World Bank Funds
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 The Senate, approving a $5.1 billion authorization bill to provide money for the World Bank and other international lending institutions, today narrowly defeated an amendment that would have required the American representative of the institution to oppose loans to countries that violate human rights.

title: Secessionists in Cabinda Report Heavy Fighting in Northern Areas
description: SANDA PASSALA, Angola, June 14 (Agence FrancePresse)Heavy fighting between secessionists and Cubansupported Angolan forces has been going on for four days in north and northwest Cabinda, the Liberation Front announced today.

title: INSIDE
description: Ronans Trip Postponed Dr. William J. Ronan, Port Authority chairman, and his wife postponed a world trip that vas to be made at public expense. Page B3.

title: Virgin Islands Held Disaster Area
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)President Carter declared the Virgin Islands a disaster area today as a result of a drought there, permitting the use of Federal funds in relief and recovery efforts.

title: Around the Nation
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 14 (UPI)The Justice Department is considering converting the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration's complex block grants into revenuesharing grants for states and cities, an official said today.

title: Helsinki's Halfway House
description: BELGRADEThis capital is extraordinarily wellsuited for its role as host to the first conference reviewing the Helsinki accord on European security. That agreement, signed two years ago after lengthy negotiations, outlined EastWest understandings on how detente and freedom should jointly be pursued.

title: Harris, Ram Quarterback, Is Traded to Chargers
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14 (UPI) The Los Angeles Rams, who recently acquired Joe Namath from the New York Jets as a free agent, traded James Harris, a quarterback, to the San Diego Chargers tonight for an undisclosed number of future draft choices.

title: KAISER ANNOUNCES RISES OF ALMOST 4% IN ALUMINUM PRICES
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation. No. 4 in the industry, announced yesterday price increases aver, aging almost 4 percent on a variety of aluminum products. The company, which said it had discussed the increases with the Council on Wage and Price.. Stability attributed the need for them to the initial added costs of a new labor contract signed last month and the impact of higher costs for energy and materials.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, MD omItlett)

title: Housing in Loft Buildings Key to New Urban Vitality
description: Not long ago, those urban neighborhoods from which the middle class had not fled, or those to which it had returned, tended to be picturesque places like Park Slope or Georgetown, with streets of brownstones or neat brick row houses. Now, the middleclass urbanite is almost as likely to reside in a former warehouse, factory or hotel. and this change comes not merely from a willingness to try one kind of building instead of another, but from a set of new circumstances that may portend major changes in urban real estate patterns.

title: Meadowlands
description: Hoss lispd in order of past posltions

title: City Finds Mountain of Documents Is No Paper Tiger
description: Plentiful enough to fill 800,000 file cabinets, long enough to stretch from New York to Tampa, Fla., bulky enough to take up six million cubic feet, and steadily gaining threequarters of million cubic feet a year. It's the New York City paperwork monster, which requires the care of hundreds and the feeding of hundreds of thousands of taxpayer dollars.

title: J. C. Penney to Buy Headquarters Here
description: The J. C. Penney Company, one of the nation's largest retail chains, announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase its 45story, national headquarters building in New York City for $55 million. The 1.5 millionsquarefoot building is owned by two of the Uris Companies from which it has been leased by Penney since 1964.

title: Jersey Court Holds Insurer Liable In Claim on Commandeered Auto
description: TRENTON, June 14 (UPI)A motorist's insurance policy must pay an accident claim even if the car was driven by an emotionally disturbed passenger who commandeers the auto, according to the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Lebanese Preparing Reforms to Avert New Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14Lebanon's leaders are working out urgent political reforms in an attempt to avert a recurrence of 19 months of bitter strife.

title: Goliath Specialist On Stock Exchange Challenges a David
description: In a DavidandGoliath drama that may signal the start of real competition on the New York Stock Exchange trading floor, the exchange disclosed yesterday that Spear. Leeds & Kellogg the Big Board's largest stock specialist, had applied for permission to compete against Blair S. Williams & Company, a little known specialist with only a few partners.

title: Boy Drowns in the Elbe
description: LUNEBURG, West Germany, June 14 (AP)A combined effort by East and West Germans failed to save a boy from drowning in the Elbe River, the West German police reported today. The body was later brought up by divers. Authorities said the boy had apparently been drawn under water yesterday by the wakes of tugboats on the border river.

title: Careers
description: Personnel departments of many companies are expanding and at the same time opportunities for advancement from personnel posts to highlevel management positions seem to be rising.

title: Legal Action Against Lamborn Takes Sweetness Out of Sugar
description: Lamborn & Company, one of the leading sugar trading houses in New York, was struggling yesterday against legal action taken by three of its creditors to recover S3 million in debt.

title: Eastern Air Lines Agrees to Ban Smoking in 65% of Plane Seats
description: WASHINGTON. June 14Eastern Air I Lines agreed to ban smoking in 65 perI cent of the seats on all its airplanes under a legal settlement announced today by two consumer groups that said it would be a precedent for the entire industry.

title: Scott Hits 2 as Red Sox Capture 6th in Row, 71
description: That rocket the major leagues are using for baseballs this season has been flying over fences at a nearrecord pace. And the Boston Red Sox have been hitting them out more than any other team has.

title: About Real Estate
description: The convention center plot is thickening as a special committee appointed by Governor Carey and Mayor Beame is rushing to choose a site so the design and planning for a new facility can take place in the fiscal year beginning next month.

title: Color TV Imports Show Record
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP1)  The United States imported a record 605,000 color television sets, mostly from Japan, between January and March, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Auto Sales Up 11.2% for 10 Days; Demand Still Strong for Big Cars
description: DETROIT. June 14The American auto industry today reported newcar sales for the first 10. days of June climbed 11.1 percent from last year to a record.

title: COURT PLAN VIEWED AS A FAIT ACCOMPLI
description: ALBANY, June 14Citing a 1927 legal opinion, representatives of three citizens' lobbying groups asserted today that the proposed court reorganization amendment to the State Constitution, which seems pinned in a legislative deadlock, had actually been approved.

title: Concessions in Labor's Pragmatic Stance
description: One of the foundation stones for George Meany's many successes in quarter century as chief lobbyist for organized labor at the White House and on Capitol Hill is his firm belief that ideology is baloney. In line with.

title: Seaver Trade Talk Angers Mets Fans
description: While Mrs. Tom Seaver and other players wives were staging a charity fashion show in the restaurant in Shea Stadium yesterday, the New York Mets switchboard was being besieged by hundreds of telephone calls from angry fans protesting the team's efforts to trade the No. 1 pitcher in baseball.

title: No Pain in Detroit on Imports
description: DETROIT, June 14  With sales of imported cars booming, Detroit seems curiously blase. The imports have accounted for more than 20 percent or the autos sold in May in the United States for the second consecutive month, but there have been no loud screams of pain here from auto companies or labor leaders. Why? Because for the most part, the In; Four auto makers have relinquished the market for the smallest fuelefficient cars to the foreigncar industry, concentrating on selling larger cars that earn more profit per unit. The domestic companies, the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation, as a group, are selling cars and making money with their strategy, and with some exceptions, there are also plenty of jobs.

title: News. Summary
description: An American newsman was forbidden to leave the Soviet Union after being detained by the secret pulice for four hours and questioned about a recent meeting with a Soviet parapsychologist. The reporter, Robert C. Toth of The Los Angeles Times, was ordered to return for further questioning. [Page A1, Column 2.]

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE BUS, traveling east on 57th Street the morning, rolled to a gentle, unscheduled stop between First and Second Avenues. The driverJoblike in his patiencerested his arms on the broad steering wheel. After a while, a dozen or so passengers, seeking the cause of the delay, flocked to the front of the bus. The cause, says Helen Wyle, was a young woman waiting for her Yorkshire terrier to do what was expected him. The passengers, she reported, burst into laughterwith the exception of a straightspined dowager carrying a handsomely silverinlaid cane. In voice that would have done credit to Cornelia Otis Skinner in her heday, she pronounced: This would never happen in Pitsburgh!

title: New Strike Threat Hangs Over Nursing Homes in Metropolitan New York
description: The longsimmering nursinghome dispute in the New York Metropolitan area that had seemed to have been settled in April erupted yesterday in a new crisis, with both the homes and the union reprecenting employees accusing each other of failing to live up to commitments.

title: Dow Up 10.17 to a 922.57 Finish; Rise Best in More Than 2 Months
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rang up a 10point gain yestudayits best advance in more than two monthschiefly in response to the surprise cut in the prime lending rate by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: 5 Policemen to Go to Court Today In a Prelude to Trial for Assault
description: HACKENSACK, June 14After months of delay, court proceedings will begin here tomorrow against five police officers charged with beating two civilians after a police fundraising dinner in Allendale in February 1976.

title: Sharp Drop in Saudi's Oil Exports
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14 (AP)  Saudi Arabia reported today a sharp drop in oil exports in May, presumably resulting from a fire in its Abqaiq oilfield. The Saudi news agency quoted Under Secretary Abdul Aziz Turki of the Oil Ministry as saying May exports averaged slightly more than 8.1 million barrels a day. Production in April averaged nearly 9.5 million barrels a day. The threeday fire halted production in the large field on the Persian Gulf for more than a week.

title: State Senate in Albany Approves Measure Broadening Coverage of the Death Penalty
description: ALBANY, June 14  The State Senate, tackling one of the most controversial issues of the session, today passed a measure to preserve the death penalty in the face of increasing constitutional chaltenges by the Supreme Court of the United States. The vote was 36 to 19.

title: White House Drops Appointment Of Lisbon Ambassador to New Job,
description: WASHINGTON, June 14In the face of unexpectedly sharp opposition from Democrats in Congress, the White House has decided not to appoint Frank C. Carlucci, now United States Ambassador to Portugal, to the top management position in the State Department, Administration officials said today.

title: CARTER BACKERS LOSE ONWATER PROJECTS BUT GAIN TACTICALLY
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The House today defeated, but only by a narrow margin, a bid by backers of President Carter to kill 16 dams and irrigation projects that he wants eliminated from a public works appropriations bill.

title: Bhutto and His Opposition Agree To a New Pakistan Vote This Year
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan. June 14The Government and the opposition announced today that they had agreed to hold a new election before the end of the year.

title: Technology
description: Two, leaders in advanced coalgasification research believe that the economics of existing technology for converting coal to gas appears so favorable that commercialscale projects in the West should go forward immediately. Page D9.

title: LONG BONDS YIELDS ARE AT 3YEAR LOWS
description: Long term bond yields yesterday dropped to their lowest levels in more than three years as bond prices continued the rise touched off by the surprising decision by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company to lower its prime rate.

title: HOWELL IS NOMINATED IN VIRGINIA PRIMARY
description: RICHMOND, Va., June 14Henry E. Howell Jr., a laborbacked, liberal consumerist and one of the South's most persistent underdogs, won the Democratic nomination for Governor of Virginia today, defeating Andrew P. Miller, the candidate of Democratic orthodoxy who had been shown leading in independent popularity polls.

title: Miller Takes Lead In Mine Union Race; Tally Is Unofficial
description: The three United Mine Workers presidential candidates cast their ballots yesterday and each left the polls predicting he would be chosen to lead the troubled, 277,000member union.

title: U.S. and Japan Agree to Seek Formula to Avoid Clash on Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The United States and Japan have agreed to seek a formula to avoid a clash over President Carter's nuclear policy that Japan fears could set back its plans to become selfreliant in atomic energy.

title: Miami, Pasadena Get Super Bowl Games
description: The National Football League bestowed gifts estimated at $50 million apiece to Miami and Pasadena, Calif., yesterday by awarding Super Bowl sites to those sunny cities.

description: NEW HIGHS90

description: The Bakke Case: I

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: Notes on People
description: FOR THREE days later this summer, John F. Kennedy Jr., son of the late President, will be alone on a small island off the coast of Maine, with no food and only one gallon of water, a few matches, and a book by Euell Gibbons on finding edible wild plants. The 16yearold youth has signed up for a 26day Outward Bound summer wilderness survival course n the Penobscot Bay.

title: U. S. COURT UPHOLDS PORT AUTHORITY BAN ON CONCORDE FLIGHTS
description: A Federal appeals court, reversing lower court, said yesterday that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey had the right to ban the Concorde from Kennedy International Airport so long as the han was fair, reasonable, and nondiscriminatory.

title: Around the Nation
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 14 (UPI)The Justice Department is considering converting the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration's complex block grants into revenuesharing grants for states and cities, an official said today.

title: Jacobs of F.D.U. Chosen To Tour With U.S. Team
description: Franklin Jacobs, Fairleigh Dickinson's 5foot8inch high jumper, who finished second to Dwight Stones with a jump of 7 feet 5 inches in last weekend's Amateur Athletic Union national meet in California, has been chosen for the United States national team that leaves this week for a threeweek tour of Italy, Germany and the Soviet Union.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE CREATIVE JOURNALIST The weekly Sports Illustrated has for practically all of its more than 22 yearsit'll be 23 in Augustconsistently displayed the best contemporary photography and art of sports and sports related activities.

title: Utah State Five Wins
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 14 (UPI)The touring Utah State University basketball team defeated a New Zealand team today, 8060, after trailing by 7 points at the half.

title: 25,000 LEADERS WILL GET CHIEF EXECUTIVE MAGAZINE
description: A new quarterly magazine, Chief Executive, is scheduled to begin publication at the end of June. It will have no newsstand sale and no subscriptions and will be sent only to 25,000 distinguished leaders of the world, according to art advance copy of the first issue.

title: Extraction of a Bullet For Evidence Voided
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 14 (UPI) The Missouri Supreme Court ruled today that the removal of a bullet from the buttocks of a suspected murderer for evidence used to convict him was unconstitutional search and seizure.

title: It Tore Seaver's Heart Out
description: Tom Seaver is Jack Armstrong, AllAmerican Boy, in baseball suit. He is an exceptional athlete who can think and talk as well as he pitches. He is easy to get along with because he is direct and honest and you both know exactly where you stand. There are 25 teams in the major leagues that could get along famously with Tom Seaver and would deem it a privilege and pleasure, There is one team that cannot, or rather, one man connected with one team who can't. This tells us something about the man. He M. Donald Grant, the minority stockholder in the Mets who is chairman of the board. It tore my heart out Sunday, Seaver said yesterday, to know that might be the last game I would pitch for the Mets to think of leaving people like Bud Harrelson, who has been there with me all those years, people like Jerry Koosman. But people just have to be honest across the board. In those circumstances, he pitched and won a fivehitter. This tells about Tom Seaver.

title: Roman' World Trip at Port Authority Expense Put Off
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, yesterday put off a roundtheworld air tour with his wife that was to be made at public expense, and called a special authority meeting for Friday.

description: AMERICAN LEAGUE LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Anker Appoints Trustee to Direct Integration Plan in Queens District
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker yesterday appointed a trustee to a Queens school district to carry out an integration plan. It would send 100 white students to high schools with black and Hispanic student majorities and 1,400 minoritygroup students either to high schools with largely white student bodies or to their mostly black neighbourhood school.

title: Clinton Nine Wins P. S.A.L. Title
description: DeWitt Clinton defeated Cardozo, 43, at Yankee Stadium yesterday and won its second Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship in the last three years.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
