description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 15, 1977

title: ANNIVERSARYEVE FIGHTING REPORTED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 14 (AP) Sporadic violence broke out in black townships outside Johannesburg and Pretoria today and reinforced police patrols tried to prevent a recurrence of the widespread rioting of last June.

title: Coffee and Norcross Head Parties; Democrats Spurn White House Call
description: TRENTON, June 14A telephone call from the White House failed today to help Anne D. Campbell of Fair Haven retain her post of Democratic state vice chairman as the Democratic State Committee reorganized following last week's primary elections. The Republican State Committee also reorganized.

title: Soothing Summer Soups, Soviet Style
description: People often associate the Soviet Union and its cuisine with severe Siberian winters and hearty hot soups. But that country's climate also includes hot humid summersand an array of refreshing cold soups.

title: Labor Delays Action on ScottishWelsh Home Rule.
description: LONDON, June 14The Government abandoned today all hope of making further progress during this session of Parliament on a bill granting limited selfgovernment to Scotland and Wales.

title: Cooking Out: A Happy Medium Is Rare
description: Do you remember how it all started? You had just moved to your first suburban house. You bought a rake, a spade, seed, a lawnmower and all the other equipment. Your wife referred to you as Lord of the Manor, but never explained just why you were equipped like a serf.

title: President's Plan To Tax Oil Wins Supportin House
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Carter Administration won its first major legislative victory in the energy field today as the House Ways and Means Committee approved the type of tax on crude oil that President Carter had proposed as a centerpiece of his energy policy.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Braves, at Atlanta. (Radio WNEW, 7:20 P.M.)

title: K.G.B. IS QUESTIONING U.S. CORRESPONDENT
description: MOSCOW, June 14The Soviet securi ty police today summoned an American correspondent for four hours of interrogation after he had been accused of gathering secret information.

title: Production of World Coffee Is Expected to Climb Sharply
description: WASHINGTON. June 14 (AP)  World coffee production is expected to increase sharply this season but still will be below the levels of two or three years ago before frost damaged the large Brazilian crop, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Judge's Remarks in Rape Case Create Tension in Blacks and Feminists in Madison,Wis.
description: MADISON, Wis.This university town Is in turmoil over a recall action against a Dane County judge who is accused of making sexist remarks last month at a hearing on rape charges against three youths.

title: MOLUCCAN FUNERAL TURNS INTO PROTEST
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, June 14A funeral for six young South Moluccans killed in the breakup of a train hijacking became a dramatic political protest today.

title: British Government Block Of 67 Million B.P. Shares Priced at Over $1 Billion
description: LONDON, June 14 (AP)Gold prices Gn,..c.'rnment today detailed the terms of th: ale of its 66.8 million shares of Britthe Petroleum Company stock for about It would be the nation's largest coyporate sale'ever.

title: M. A. C. Buys Time, Not Salvation
description: In 1975 New York City discovered that banks which had bought its notes and bonds for years suddenly refused to do so again, in fear they would not be repaid and the fiscal crisis was upon it. Since the city had to pay off old obligations as they came due, and had counted on new loans to make this possible, it faced default unless the state government could find a way for it to borrow money successfully. The state's response Was to establish the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which has proved able to sell its bonds to banks, pension funds and the public. But it has not been easy. Its sale to the public last November succeeded only because it paid the unprecedented taxexempt rate of 10.25 percent.

title: Events Today
description: LOVE! LOVE! LOVE!, a musical with music Johnny Brandon; choreography and direction by Buck Helier; at the Astor Place Theater, 434 Lafayette Street, 7:30.

title: Vietnam Veteran Gets V.A. Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)Maury S. Crall Jr., a highly decorated Vietnam veteran, was named today as assistant deputy administrator of the Veterans Administration. Max Cleland, the Administrator of Veterans Affairs, said Mr. Crall, who is 43 years old and an expert in financial management, would oversee financial management within the V. A. His decorations include two Silver Stars, the Bronze Star and the Legion of Merit.

title: Two Vegetarians: True to Themselves
description: Bean sprouts grow in a kitchen cabinet next to the plates and cups. The refrigerator overflows with cabbages and carrots, potatoes and parsley. In one corner a 25gallon jug of mountain spring water sits waiting to be tapped. A Chinese wok and an Acme juicer stand side by side on a counter. No, this is not the apartment of California food faddist. Theodore Mann and Patricia Brooks, of midtown Manhattan, have become vegetarians.

title: News Summary
description: An American newsman was forbidden to leave the Soviet Union after being detained by the secret police for four hours and questioned about a recent meeting with a Soviet parapsychologist.. The reporter, Robert C. Toth of The Los Angeles Times, was ordered to return for further questioning. (Page A1, Column 2.)

title: Oklahoma Town's Police Strike
description: MIAMI, Okla., June 14 (AP)The police force of this northeastern Oklahoma town failed to show up for work again today in a continuing contract dispute. For the second day, state highway patrol officers manned police headquarters and patroled streets in this town of 14,000. All of the 25 city officers called in sick or took days off today, according to officials.

title: THREE CROATS INVADE YUGOSLAVS MISSION
description: Three Croatian nationalists armed with handguns yesterday invaded the Yugoslav Mission to the United Nations, wounded the mission chauffeur, barricaded themselves in the mission for two hours and dropped leaflets from a window before surrendering to the police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: VW, in Bid for 5% of Market, Plans to Build 2d U.S. Plant
description: WOLFSBURG. West Germany Volkswagen, now in place behind two Japanese companies in the race to sell foreign cars in the United States, says it will eventually have to open a second American plantmost likely in the Westto regain its leadership.

title: Breakaway Brunches For a Leisurely Lift
description: ALTHOUGH the word brunch has a distinctly Amencan ring to it, it is, like smog and chortle, according to H. L. Mencken, of British origin. Brunch, designating a combination of breakfast and lunch, eaten about noon appeared in England about 1900, Mencken wrote, but it was 30 years later before it began to make any headway on this side of the water. The author added the following footnote: On April 10, 1941, the Fifth Avenue Hotel in New York was advertising a Sunday strollers brunch, $1 per person, served from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.'

title: Vote for Dams Kind of Easy For Freshman
description: WASHINGTON, June 14There was nothing hesitant today about Representative Robert A. Young's decision to abandon his President for a darn.

title: World News Briefs
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 14 (AP) Brig. Gen. JeanLouis Jeanmaire admitted to a military court today that he passed secret army information to the Russians after having developed a close friendship with the Soviet military attache, a military court spokesman said.

title: Medicare Fee Rise Curbed
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)  The Government announced today a 6 percent limit on fee increases for Medicare doctors in the year ending June 30, 1978. Under the limitation, benefit payments for Medicare part B medical insurance will increase from $5.5 billion to $6.9 billion in the next 12 months, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said.

title: Piniella, Facing Ban, Key to Tying Rally
description: Lou Piniella, playing on borrowed time, and Dan Gullett, whose time seems to have arrived finally, provided the sparks last night as the Yankees defeated the Kansas City Royals, 42, at Yankee Stadium.

title: Indiana Strives to Block Federal Water Projects There, in Keeping With Its Conservative Philosophy
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind.President Carter may be suffering setbacks in his attempts to cut off or reduce funds for 16 Federal water projects, but people in this state would be happy to help him out. For some time, they have been trying to return some projects they don't want.

title: CORRECTION
description: In yesterday's Market Place column, the General Foods Corporation was in correctly identified as having secured rights to manufacture toys relating to the Twentieth CenturyFox film Star Wars. The Kenner Products unit of General Mills Inc. has obtained those rights.

title: LEFKOWITZ IS ACTING TO REMOVE BERGMAN
description: The New York State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, will apply in Federal Court today for the appointment of nursing home official to take over operation of the Park Crescent Nursing Home from Bernard Berman.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Farah Manufacturing Company. the financially troubled Texas apparel maker, which was involved in a prolonged union dispute that led to a nanonwide boycott of its products, has accepted in principle an offer of finan11 aid from the V.F. Corporation. The offer opens the door to the eventual merger of the two apparel concerns.

title: FORD MOTOR DISCLOSES $283,000 PAYOFF ABROAD
description: DETROIT, June 15The Ford Motor Company admitted today making improper payments abroad of $283,000 during 197475.

title: Art Exhibition Focuses on Labor
description: In a departure from its usual union activities, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees will serve as an art sponsor for an exhibition entitled The Butcher, the Baker, the Candlestick Maker: Images of Labor.

title: Leonard Silk
description: During the late 1960's and early 1970's, it was fashionable to say that the business cycle had been mastered by modern economic theory and policy.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Wednesday JUNE 15, 1977

title: A Salute to Dogged Stage Survivors
description: AWEEK OR SO AGO I was thinkingI was forced to thinkabout how much pleasure I'I been given over the long, long years by performers who never quite became stars. It'It easy enough to take some relish in watching a star grow, after the fact. Once an actor or actress has really hit the top, a reviewer can feel quite smugand cause some breathless astonishment in his childrenas he recites the number of times he saw a still young nobody named George C. Scott cavorting about on school stages uptown, or as he describes the process by which a callow Paul Newman rapidly matured, a Dustin Hoffman called attention to himself playing a man twice his age, a Robert Redford leaped from juvenile to leading man in half a trice if that.

title: Mr. Vorster'Vorster Shift
description: LONDONThe conflicts in southern Africa are so profound that a wise person is wary of any talk about early or peaceful solutions. But among British leaders and American diplomats here who deal with Africa there is a new note of hope, cautious but too distinct to ignore.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bankruptcy Court Names A Trustee to Take Over Bergman Nursing Home
description: Owen McGivern, former Justice of the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, was appointed yesterday to take over from Bernard Bergman the operation of the Park Crescent Nursing Nome.

title: MerryGoRound Life for Hendrick
description: Exactly one year after he became a Yankee in a lastminute, 10player trade with the Baltimore Orioles, Elrod Hendricks returned to Baltimore yesterdaynot to play for the Orioles but to visit his family.

title: Books: Enigma of China Remains Perplexing
description: Orville Schell brought home a trunk full of poignant vignettes from two months in China. But because of Chinese restrictions and inhibitions, his readers get little but superficialities and uncertainties.

title: Janata Wins 7th State in India Vote
description: NEW DELHI, June 15The governing Janata Party continued to be the major winner today in returns from elections for the legislatures in 10 Indian states. Indira Gandhi'Gandhi Congress Party, which had controlled nine of them before the eiprtinnq wag the hie loser_

title: Watergate: Effect Five Years Later
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Bill Brock paid a visit the other day to the office of Kenneth M. Curtis. For two hours they shared coffee and sympathy. The event was rare enough, since Mr. Brock heads the Republican Party and Mr. Curtis the Democratic, but it was also symptomatic.

Robert I. Cohen. Presented by Robert E. Richardson.

title: Ferns Cast Their Spell, and She Succumbed
description: SOME resemble shields; others suggest delicate lace. They hang, they creep, they crawl. A few are tiny, others are massive and bold. They'They all ferns, and anyone beguiled by this phenomenal assortment of shapes and textures soon becomes a fern fancier.

title: Carter, in Agreement With. House, Will Not Veto H.E.W.Labor Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  President Carter retreated today from his threatened veto of the $61.3 billion appropriations hill for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare. In an agreement with House Democratic leaders, Mr. Carter said he would sign the legislation if it remained in its present form.

description: Muhammad All traveled around town with Percy E. Sutton yesterday to help attract attention to the voterregistration drive that is the key to Mr. Sutton'Sutton mayoral campaign.

title: UGANDA CONDEMNED BY COMMONWEALTH
description: LONDON, June 15The Commonwealth heads of government tonight condemned President Idi Amin'Amin regime in Uganda for its disregard for the sanctity of human life and its massive violation of basic human rights.

title: Senate Approves Bill Authorizing $1.6 Billion in Foreign Assistance
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Senate passed two major foreign aid bills in rapid succession today, authorizing $1.6 billion for economic assistance and nearly $3.2 billion for military assistance and related purposes for the fiscal year that bezins October 1.

title: Widow of Executed G. I. Asks Army to Clear His Name Associated Press Antoinette Slovik waiting to testify before an Army review board in Washington yesterday
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)The Pentagon met an unusual war casualty todaythe crippled and indigent widow of the only American soldier shot for desertion in this century.

title: About New york
description: The women were silent and out of sight in a draped section at the back of the bus as the men from the diamond district got aboard for the commuters ride home to the suburbs.

description: In an era of superstardom in professional sports, when a lylsketball franchise totters if Julius Ervin is traded, when a football franchise makes Page One if Joe Namath departs from Broadwaythe baseball franchise of the New York Mets finally shook the firmament, too

title: 30 in Chile Continue SitIn At U.N. Office Demanding Data on Missing Relatives
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 15 (UPI)Nearly 30 relatives of persons missing in Chile completed the first 24 hours of a hunger strike and sitin at the United Nations building here today, demanding an international inquiry into the fate of the missing.

title: Nixon, in Phone Conversation With Panel, Discusses Vietnam Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  Former President Richard M. Nixon, after having refused to come to Washington and testify on the secret Vietnam negotiations, spoke informally to a rump meeting of a House subcommittee over the phone today arguing against paying blacimkail for bodies to the Vietnamese.

title: Books of The Times
description: FORTYTWOYEAROLD Hannah Jackson in Gillian Martin'Martin first novel, The Goat, the Wolf, and the Crab, hasn'hasn done much with her life except marry Henry, live in London, watch her two children grow up and go away, and feel that, somehow, she has missed the point: There simply isn'isn enough of her to hold her interest by itself. And: No, I don'don think I'I known what is usually meant by pain, or hunger. My condition has been chronic, never acute. She has never thrown pepper at foxhounds or boycotted South African oranges. Even her own encompassing distress looks to her like a fifteenyear sulk. And anyway, she knew she was likely to cry, without quite meaning or wanting to, and who can regard as weighty and rational an explanation delivered through hiccups?

title: U.S. Orders Home General Who Called A Major War Likely
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Secretary of the Army Clifford L. Alexander today ordered a threestar general to report to him to discuss a speech the officer made in Germany last Week saying that the United States would probably become involved in a ChineseSoviet war in the future.

title: Two Dance Styles Brush Shoulders
description: It isn'isn too hard to remember when ballet dancers and modern dancers sat at separate tables. On Tuesday night they brushed shoulders both onstage and off at the opening of a sixday run by the Paul Sanasardo Dance Company at the Roundabout Theater, 333 West 23d Street.

title: In a Sweat? Look Sharp To Buy Cool
description: ROOM air conditioners are one of the biggest impulse items on the appliance dealer'dealer shelf. They sell best during the dog days when the tar in the streets turns spongy underfoot, subway straphangers shirts are plastered to their vertebrae, and tempers are snappish. Not exactly the most rational kind of climate in which to buy a machine that can cost a couple of hundred dollars or more.

title: Waldheim Responds
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 15Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has informed demonstrators at the United Nations office in Santiago that he is working to locate the missing members of their families and to assist those in jail. But he also has urged them to end their sit in and leave the building.

title: FIAT PLANNING TO BUILD VENEZUELAN ENGINE PLANT
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 15Fiat'Fiat Venezuelan subsidiary has secured a contract to build a plant for manufacturing fourcylinder gasoline engines here, high sources in the industry said edgedout the French automaker Renault and virtually guaranteed itself control over Venezuela'zuela small car market in coming years

title: Minimizing The Discord

Harris, a Columbia University professor of electrical engineering and architecturp, who has become one of tbe most soughtafter acousticians in the worldhe is now doing concert halls in Salt Lake City and Bombaysays that there are, several approaches to minimizing the sounds emanating from a piano.

title: Books: Super Scientific Elite
description: Harriet Zuckerman, an associate professor of sociology at Columbia, is among the comparatively few investigators of the sociology of science, a discipline that attempts to examine scientists and scientific advances and failures in much the same fashion as scientists collect and organize their own data.

description: LONDON, June 15 (UPI)Jimmy Connors, bothered by a sore thumb and the change from grass to indoor courts

title: Brooklyn College Gives Father and Son Degrees At 52d Commencement
description: For Stanley and Carl Sherman, Brooklyn College'College 52d commencement yesterday forged a further link between two generationsMr. Sherman and his son, Carl, received bachelor'bachelor degrees in accounting.

title: Computer Show: Preview Of More Ingenious Models
description: DALLAS, June 15  Computers, from giant down to microscopic size, are competing fiercely for attention, markets and the services of talented people here at this year'year National Computer Conference, described as the largest and most lavish exhibition of computer hardware to date.

title: Italian Bridge Watergate
description: TURIN, Italy  Somebody always calls it the Italian bridge Watergate whenever the recent cheating charges are discussed in card clubs here and across the country. With this summer'summer European bridge championships approaching, the affair is mentioned frequently these days.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: GARDENING
description: ROM THE LITERATURE on flowers and trees it would seem, almost invariably, that no one has a shady garden. Everything does best in full sun. Almost everything, anyway. At the very least, a half day'day sun is needed for happy plants. Yet for most of us a shady nook in the garden is a very real thing. And unfortunately it'it usually the neglected patch of balding lawn, because nothing grows there. Well, nature knows better. Something will grow just about anywhere on earth, and a shady garden is no exception.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.

title: Report on Unemployment Benefits For Former Prisoners Is Clarified
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)A United Press International dispatch Sunday incorrectly said that a change in Federal regulations would make former prisoners and prisoners in workrelease programs eligible immediately for unemployment benefits and nublic service jobs.

title: Mansfield Mystifies Japanese
description: TOKYO, June 15Mike Mansfield, the former Senate majority leader and now the United States Ambassador to Japan, today held his first news conference since his arrival here and promptly sent Japanese reporters racing for their slang dictionaries.

title: Yugoslavia Pardons Prisoners As European Conference Opens
description: BELGRADE, June 15 (Reuters)Yugoslavia pardoned an undisclosed number of prisoners today as the European conference on security and cooperation, which is expected to discuss human rights opened in Belgrade.

title: Zurlo Retains Boxing Title
description: CAGLIARI, Sardinia, June 15 (UPI)Franco Zurlo, the European bantamweight boxing champion, retained his title today by stoning Jacky Bihin of France at the start of the eighth round of their scheduled 15round tight, The 37yearold Zurlo weighed 118 pounds,

title: Marshall'Marshall Start Helps Rangers Win
description: Mike Marshall, the only relief pitcher to win the Cy Young Award, made his third start of the season last night. And although he tired after seven innings in the Texas Rangers 60 victory over the Cleveland Indians, the 34yearold righthander came away with his first American League victory since 1970.

title: Carter'Carter Nuclear Policy Encounters a Snag in Japan
description: TOKYO, June 15A new and unexpected difficulty has arisen in the JapaneseAmerican negotiations over carrying out President Carter'Carter controversial policy to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Alan Reed, a Film and TV Actor, 69
description: Alan Reed, an actor known as the voice of Fred on the television program The Flintstones, died Tuesday at the St. Vincent'Vincent Medical Center near his home in West Los Angeles. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. Gains in Federation Cup
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 15 (Reuters)The United States moved into the quarterfinals of the Federation Cup women'women team tennis competition today with a 30 victory over Switzerland. Billie Jean King and Chris Evert won singles matches and Miss Evert and Rosie Casals took the doubles.

title: 20Day Ordeal Aboard the Hijacked Dutch Train, as Described by Those Who Survived
description: ZWOLLE, the Netherlands, June 15The 20day hijacking of train 747 outside the village of Glinunen was an ordeal the 52 passengers still alive today survived with solidarity, luck, and the conviction that their South Moluccan captors would not kill any of them to achieve their aims.

title: Atlantic Leather Boat Near Goal
description: LONDON, June 13 (AP)The leather boat Brendan and its crew of four were reported today within 280 miles of Gander Bay, Newfoundland. A spokesman for the Leather Institute, which is sponsoring the crossAtlantic voyage, said the boat had reperted that all was well aboard. The crew is attempting to prove that a voyage as described by St. Brendan in an old manuscript could have taken place.

title: MARYAN S. MARYAN, PAINTER AND LITHOGRAPHER, AT 50
description: Maryan S. Maryan, a painter, whose work has been widely exhibited in this country and in Europe, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, on Tuesday in his home at the Chelsea Hotel, 22 West 23d Street. He was 50 years old.

title: Convicts Give Police Advice On Juvenile Crime Problem
description: SEA GIRT, June 15Troubled by the high incidence of crimes by juveniles, 25 state and local policemen sought today the advice of expertshardened criminals who once were juvenile delinquents.

title: ASTRONOMERS WATCH SOUR SYSTEM RERUN
description: Based on observations with two telescopes, astronomers believe they are witnessing for the first time a distant rerun of the process that formed the sun and its family of planets.

title: Levitt CoFounder, in New Company, to Build Community in Iran
description: William J. Levitt, the home builder and cofounder of Levitt & Sons, announced plans yesterday to build a community of homes, stores and other facilities in Iran, which he said would cost more than a halfbillion dollars.

title: Stay Ordered for Texas Killer
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. has ordered Texas authorities to keep James Paul Burns alive until the condemned murdarer has a chance to file a formal appeal with the Supreme Court. The stay of execution, announced by the Court today, will extend indefinitely a 30day stay granted by a Texas court. The stay would have run out June 24.

The sharp oneweek increase is probably attributable to the vagaries of tanker, arrivals, an industry spokesman said.

title: Watergate: Effect Five Years Later

title: At Your Service: Cleaning Oriental Rugs
description: SOLVENT ON A Kazan? Orvus on a Bukhara? Club soda on a Kerman? If you own an Oriental rug, you probably vacuum it regularly. But you should also have it washed every other year or so, according to leading Oriental carpet dealers. The frequency depends, of course, on where you live (city dwellers will need to wash their rugs more often than suburbanites), what kind of use the rug gets, and type and color of the pile.

title: Dance: Cragun as Onegin
description: O N THE OPENING of the Stuttgart Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night, I suggested that John Cranko'Cranko ballets were, rightly, to become fossilized and remain a permanent part of the German repertory. Well yesbut fossilized does have some rather unfortunate connotations, and perhaps preserved would have been a word more apt, if less striking. What is, of course, essential is that the spirit of Cranko is maintained, and that his ballets remain true to their own traditions in changing times.

title: Film: It's a Long War In 'Bridge Too Far'
description: JOSEPH E. LEVINE's "A Bridge Too Far," the film version of Cornelius Ryan's best-selling book about the disastrous Allied push into the Netherlands in September 1944, proves that there's life in the Old War yet. The movie is massive, shapeless, often unexpectedly moving, confusing, sad, vivid and very, very long.Directed by Richard Attenborough and acted by a cast of thousands, including some very expensive stars, "A Bridge Too Far" is certainly equal to Darryl F. Zanuck's "The Longest Day," the film version of the Ryan book about the 1944 Allied invasion of Normandy. In saying that, however, I should admit that this sort of film seems to me to have less to do with the art of movie-making than with the logistics of transportation, housing, food, actors' schedules, demolition, military cooperation and morale. One watches it not so much in admiration as in awe.Unlike "The Longest Day," which recalled one of the Allies' most stunning victories, "A Bridge Too Far" recalls one of their most tragic and costly defeats, when, in an attempt to conclude the war before the end of 1944, the English and Americans dropped 35,000 troops behind the enemy lines in the Netherlands to secure five bridges over the Rhine into Germany.The plan was the brainchild of British Field Marshall Bernard L. Montgomery, usually a cautious man, and it would have worked if intelligence reports had been heeded, if the weather had been perfect, if one German army had been surrounded and if luck had been with the attackers.Instead, just about everything that could go wrong did go wrong. At the end of the operation, which was supposed to last four or five days but went to nine, the Allied casualtieskilled, wounded and missingwere more than 17,000, compared to an estimated 10,000 to 12,000 in the Normandy landings.If one doesn't quite grasp the import of this in the film it's because, after a couple of hours, scenes of tanks, buildings and bridges being blown up, of shells exploding, of soldiers being mutilated and of other carnage are all pretty much alike, no matter who ultimately wins the day. Missing is some point of view more particular (and more historical) than the idea that war is hell.What Mr. Levine, Mr. Attenborough and William Goldman, who wrote the screenplay, have successfully brought off, though, is, in the initial sequences, the orderly exposition of what Operation Market Garden was all about, and, in the following sequences, an effective illustration of some of the things that went so wrong. The film is technically a wonder. The shots of the paratroop drops are breathtaking and, if one knows anything about the problems of such filmmaking, the very fact that all the color shots match so well is a major accomplishment."A Bridge Too Far," which opened yesterday at the Rivoli, also seems to me to demonstrate the wisdom of a policy that, until now, I've been inclined to scoff at, that is, the decision to cast star actors in so-called cameo roles. These dozen or so stars are as much the means of such a filmas necessary to narrative coherenceas the screenplay. Not many moviegoers, I suspect, would be able to keep track of the cascading incidents without the aid of the immediately identifiable actors who enact them. Their familiar faces are visual program notes.In addition, some of these actors are very good. Anthony Hopkins is fine as the British officer assigned to capture the bridge at Arnhem and whose troops, without any support whatsoever, hold one end of the bridge for nine days before being overtaken. James Caan stars in a furiously effective episode about a sergeant who forces a doctor, at gunpoint, to operate on his wounded captain. Laurence Olivier and Liv Ullmann give recognizable emotions to Dutch civilians caught in the crossfire, and Edward Fox is quietly but brilliantly funny as a gung-ho British officer.Some of these stars have more to do than others. Elliott Gould is on and off like a station break. Gene Hackman scowls a good deal as the commander of the Polish paratroopers and Gen. James M. Gavin, played by Ryan O'Neal, appears to be growing mysteriously young, having been played by Robert Ryan in "The Longest Day."Not all of the episodes are star-studded. There's an eerie moment early in the film when paratroopers come upon the newly liberated inmates of a mental hospital, wandering through a forest like smiling, catatonic ghosts. At Arnhem, in the midst of a German attack, a little old woman, whose house has been taken over by the British forces, frets about the disorder and unseemly noise.If "A Bridge Too Far" finally leaves one exhausted instead of exhilarated, this has to do not only with length, but also with the nature of a particular operation that failed. The scale of the failure is impressive, but it doesn't ennoble."A Bridge Too Far," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") includes some graphic battlefield footage that, under the circumstances, could not easily have been avoided.

description: TRENTON, June 15The former superintendent of Trenton State Prison, Alan, R. Hoffman, is under investigation by a state grand jury on suspicion of trying to plot the murder of an inmate, it was reported today.

title: Home Beat
description: VICTOR PAPANEK was waiting to have his picture taken. His eye fell on a photographer'photographer equipment carrying case that had wheels, and a handle on the side, but no handle on top with which to pull it. Mr. Papanek whipped out a pencil and drew a fast sketch of the case incorporating an improvement he thought could be made for about a dollar. Get a webbing strap from an ArmyNavy store, wrap it around the case, hook a handle on the top cornerand the photographer will be able to pull the case without bendine.

title: Seaver Dealt To Reds for 4 Players
description: Continued From Page D15

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ALBANY, June 15Governor Carey, in an effort to get his program for changes in nofault automobile insurance through a reluctant Assembly, today relaxed the barriers he originally proposed to lawsuits for pain and suffering of accident victims.

title: Jacknif e, After 4 Days, Captures Slowest AnnapolisNewport Sail
description: NEWPORT, R.I.June 15Regardless of how long it took, a winner had to emerge from the slow AnnapolistoNewport ocean race and one finally did this afternoon. It was Jacknife, a new light blue 42foot sloop owned and skippered by Jack Greenberg, a doctor from Miami.

title: Lord Montgomery Sword Auctioned
description: LONDON, June 15 (AP)The sword that Field Marshal Lord Montgomery carried in World War I was sold for $595 at an auction in London today. Lord Montgomery, who was British Army commander in World War II, died last year He had given the sword to his brother, Lieut. Col. Brian Montgomery, in 1923 when he was commissioned and needed a sword.

title: Illinois Votes Death Penalty Bill
description: SPRINGFIELD, M., June 15 (UPI)The Illinois House of Representatives has overwhelmingly approved reinstatement of capital punishment in Illinois and sent the death penalty bill to Gov. James R Thompson, who is expected to sign it into law. The bill passed its final legislative test last night, when the House approved three Senate changes on a 12442 rollcall. The measure is patterned after other capital punishment laws upheld by the Supreme Court.

title: The Mobile Home, Respectable at Last
description: CONCORD, CALIF. WHEN MOBILEHOME buyers come to Brookview Park, a mobile home community in this city east of San Francisco, they are told that a certain model of mobile home is preferred. Moreover, each buyer must have at least two mobile homes joined together. And the park requires that each mobile home be covered with cedarshake roof shingles, sheathed in vertical wood siding, and be given a carport, porch and deck. By the time the mobile home is installed, there is almost nothing to distinguish it from a conventional suburban house.

title: Fine Tosca
description: THERE WAS A KNIFING in Central Park on Tuesday night. A famous prima donna fatally stabbed a police chief. It was all good clean fun, of course, because it happened in a concert performance of Tosca by the Metropolitan Opera. It was the opening of the company'company 11th annual season of free park concerts and, as usual, took place in the Sheep Meadow.

title: Political Talk on Democratic Menu.
description: While the Human Rights for Ireland Cqmmittee picketed outside, Senator Edward M. Kennedy praised Governor Carey last night for speaking out against violence in Ireland.

title: Stage: Love!
description: IT WAS an unequal struggle, and it ended in a massacre. But for a while, for almost the first half of the evening, the slender virtues of Love! Love! Love! put up something of a fight.

title: 3 Men on a Horse Seek To Reap Cane Benefits
description: YONKERS, June 15This is a story of three men on a horse. The horse is Big Towner, a 3yearold pacer who cost $5,700 and will be racing Saturday night in the $286,500 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: jazz: Wild Bill Davison at 71
description: Wild Bill Davison, one of the regulars at Eddie Condon'Condon when the late guitarist opened his jazz club in Greenwich Village more than 30 years ago, is bringing some of the flavor of those days to the current Eddie Condon'Condon, 144 West 54th Street, where he is playing through Saturday.

title: New Defense Intelligence Head
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)President Carter has nominated Maj. Gen. Eugene'Eugene. Tighe Jr. of the Air Force for a third star and assignment as director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, the Pentagon said today. Gemeral Tighe, who will be 56 yew'yew old on Sunday, is assistant chief of staff for Air Force intelligence, In his new post, he will succeed Lieut. Gen. Samuel V. Wilson, who is retiring.

title: Sound
description: THE INTERPRETATION of a piece of music as heard on a recording is not that of the artists alone. You are also listening to the efforts of the man in charge of the complex technical operations involved in adapting the sound of the actual performance to the requirements of the phonograph and of the home listening situation.

title: Psychiatrist Slain and Husband, Also a Psychiatrist, Is Charged
description: A 38yearold psychiatrist fatally stabbed his estranged 30yearold wife, who was also a psychiatrist, in his upper Park Avenue apartment last night, the police reported.

title: British Steel Chairman Predicts Utter Chaos
description: Sir Charles H. Villiers, chairman of the British Steel Corporation, said yesterday that if United States steel interests, citing tax advantages, insist on the imposition of countervailing duties on steel shipments from Europe, it will create utter chaos.

title: Princeton Community Is Divided on DNA Research
description: PRINCETON, June 15This community remained divided today on whether to permit potentially hazardous genetic research, known as recombinant DNA, to be conducted at Princeton University.

title: Judicial Discretion Faces Curb in Senate Bill on Sentencing Methods
description: In late 1975, a Federal judge and a law school dean were dinner guests of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and they discussed far into the night their unhappiness with criminal sentences. The Senator borrowed their ideas, and embellished

title: PROSPECTS DIMINISH FOR NEW ARMS PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The prospect that the United States and the Soviet Union will negotiate a new accord on strategic arms before the present treaty expires in October looked unlikely today as the State Department announced that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would not meet again until September.

title: Wimbledon'Wimbledon Qualifying Tournament Vs a Rat Race
description: ROEHAMPTON, England, June 15The gray mist hung as a grim reminder for Bill Bowrey that nothing had changed at the Bank of England Club since the first time he had to enter the qualifying tournament for Wimbledon 15 years ago.

title: N. B. A. Moves Likely to Aid 4 New Clubs
description: CORONADO, Calif., June 15In a display of solidarity not always characteristic of its business decisions, the National Basketball Association voted overwhelmingly today to take three steps intended to assure survival of the four franchises that entered it from the American Basketball Association a year ago: the New York Nets, Denver, Indiana and San Antonio.

title: N.F.L. in Stalemate on Compensation Plan
description: The National Football League, at the end of its twoday annual meeting, discovered yesterday it could not legislate morality among its owners.

title: Garden Pact Is Upheld On AliShavers Title Bout
description: The New York State Athletic cornmission ruled yesterday that Madison Square Garden Boxing, Inc., has a binding agreement obligating Earnie Shavers to fight Muhammad All in Madison Square Garden this fall.

title: K.G.B. Questions U.S. Reporter About Shcharansky
description: MOSCOW, June 15The Soviet authorities today broadened their interrogation of the American correspondent Robert C. Toth by pressing him about articles that he had written and about his relationship with a jailed Jewish activist. Anatoly Shcharansky.

title: 35 COUNTRIES MEET ON HELSINKI ACCORD
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 15Two years after adopting the Helsinki declaration on European security and cooperation, 35 nations began preparations here today for a conference in the fall that is to assess how the accord has been observed.

title: My Father, The Prince
description: FATHERS. They say that a woman seeksin love, marriage, or any malefemale relationship of real heftto approximate the father she had, the father she didn'didn have but wanted, or the father minus the attributes that caused her mother to leave him for good and sufficient reason.

title: Serious Fires in New York City Have Jumped 40% in Last 3 Years
description: The number of serious fires in New York City has jumped 40 percent since 1974 and civilian deaths in fires in the city are running at a 35 percent greater rate this year than last, Fire Department records show.

title: Experimental House Unearths New Ways to Save Energy
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn. DEVELOPERS tend to exaggerate, but there is little doubt that Lands Gores and Paul Sturges are correct in claiming that they have overbuilt their energyconserving house here.

title: Letter FromHome
description: NEW HAVEN THROW me a hard decision and I will handle it with the coolness of a cucumber. But make me decide what kind of burger I want at a fastfood place and I will go into paralysis. Out here in the great beyond beyond the city limitsall Americans over the age of three can Choose instantly between the Double Iiteef Whopper With Cheese and the Double Beef Cheeseburger (to start with a simple example). They are the new breed of eaters in America and they can handle the permutations as easily as Mendel sorting peas. I don'don even know what the different names mean.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions. Letter designates OTB listing. FIRST$8,500, cl., 3Y0 and up, isiN

title: FAYGAH MARK
description: Faygah Mark of Memphis, who formerly taught Yiddish at the New School for Social Research in New York City, died yesterday in St. Joseph'Joseph Hospital, East Memphis, following a heart attack. Her age was 70.

title: Policeman'Policeman Killer Gets 500 Years
description: CHICAGO, June 15 (UPI)William C. Lewis, convicted of killing a Chicago policeman, was sentenced today to serve 500 to 1,000 years in prison. Judge Frank W. Barbaro said that since he could not sentence the defendant to death under state law, he would give him a sentence that would protect society from a man who cannot be rehabilitated.

title: DR. HAROLD J. HARRIS, 78; UNDULANTFEVER EXPERT
description: Dr. Harold J. Harris, an authority on brucellosis, or undulant fever, died Tuesday at his home in Westport, N.Y. He had retired from private practice and a former post as health officer for Westport. He was 78 years old.

title: A Swedish Institute Says Chances Rise Fora Nuclear War
description: STOCKHOLM, June 15 (AP)An international research body said today that the nuclear weapons race and the expanding international arms trade were increasing the probability of a general nuclear war.

title: Personal Beauty
description: TWELVE WOMEN, in varicolored leotards, hold out their arms, bend their knees and exhale with a loud hiss. They sound like a pride of enraged cats.

title: Deposits Up $161 Million in May At State'State Savings and Loans
description: The Savings Association League of New York State reported yesterday a net savings gain in May of $161 million for the state'state 136 savings and loan associations, $40 million more than April'April gain of $121 million.

title: Life and Death at Bronx Psychiatric
description: Stories of the mistreatment of inmates of mental institutions have become so familiar that the recent report of the New York State Commission of InvestigationLife and Death at the Bronx Psychiatric Center"may not shock many readers.

title: Trustee for Avis and Others Richard Joyce Smith
description: The New York Times/Ernie Hearion

title: Juvenile Fingerprinting Bill Backed
description: ALBANY, June 15Children as young as 11 years old who are arrested for serious felonies would have to be fingerprinted under a bill passed today by the Assembly.

title: California Drought May Spell End Of a Dry Spell for Jersey Canneries
description: TRENTON, June 15The continued drought in California, where many of the country'country vegetables are grown, has caused some food processors to take a new look at New Jersey.

title: Skirmish At Belgrade
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 "What works is good.". That is the essence of the philosophy William James named pragmatism" at the turn of the century; its teaching is at the heart of the attack many Americans are making on America'America humanrights emphasis in Bclgrade this week.

title: Redlining
description: DETROIT, June 15In what has been criticized as a flagrant case of credit card redlining, a Detroit couple with an annual income of 550,000 has been denied a Mobil Oil Company credit card because the couple lives in Detroit and because the husband'husband occupation was not considered a good credit risk.

title: House Panel Rejects HeatingOil Rebate
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The House Ways and Means Committee decisively rejected today the special energy tax rebate proposed by President Carter for families that heat with oil.

title: Hers
description: RANDOM thoughts while being towed 30 miles alonap Northern State Parkway at midnight in abattered 10yearold VW square back, with a sleepy child and a scared cat in my lap.

title: S. DAVID WEXLER
description: S. David Wexler, a retired elementary school principal, died Tuesday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 69 years old and lived at 11107 76th Drive in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Canto Retains Boxing Title
description: TOKYO, June 15 (UPI)The World Boxing Council flyweight champion, Miguel Canto of Mexico, retained his title tonight by gaining a unanimous decision over the thirdranked contender, Kimio Furesawa, in a 15round bout. Each fighter weighed 112 pounds it was Canto'Canto eighth title defense.

title: The Nuclear Breeder Still Breathes
description: We thought the Clinch River nuclear breeder reactor in Tennessee was safely dead when President Carter announced his opposition last March. Now, due aggressive lobbying by the nuclear power industry and its union allies, Clinch River appears to be coming alive again. The House Science and Technology Committee restored $150 million to the energy research budget this week to begin its construction. A close vote is expected when the bill reaches the Housc floor.

title: Tuesday'Tuesday Fight
description: LONDONCarlos Palomino, 147 sounds, knocked out Dave Green, 146, Britain, 11 rounds, and retained World Boxing Council welterweight crown,

title: U.S. Agency Urges Rules for Wine Labels
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)The Federal Government proposed new regulations on wine labels today to give consumers more information.

title: Ban on Nonprescription Sedatives For Use in the Daytime Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)Sedatives sold over the counter for use in the daytime should be banned from the market, the chairman of a scientific advisory governmental panel said yesterday.

title: For American Craftsmen, a Coming of Age
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C. WHEN J. PEARSON was asked to come to Young Americans 77, a major crafts exhibition that opened here last week, to accept an award, he politely declined. The reason? Mr. Pearson, who uses only his first initial, explained that he had to get on with making his living in leatherwork. He couldn'couldn take time out to be lionized at the big professional crafts conference that is held every few years in a different part of the country.

title: Memorial Seroices,
description: AMONTMargaret Irish. Beloved mother of Mrs. Florence AntonIdes, Mrs. Margaret Heap, Mrs. Anne Jafferis and Haves C. Lamont. Memorial Service will be held at Christ Chapel, Riverside Church, Riveriirle Drive and In St., Saturday, June 18 at 11 A.M.

title: Dave Anderson
description: TULSA. June 15Tommy Bolt knew he had returned Southern Hills when he walked into the men'men locker room with its dark wood, high ceilings and wide metal lockers.

title: Platoons of Protesters Bivouac at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15The Buddhist monk in his saffron robes arrived last Friday with a few followers, settled down on the pavement opposite the entrance gates of the United Notinne and began his fast.

title: Has England Run Out of Antiques?
description: London LIKE a departed loved one, Mentmore, the stately English home that went under the auctioneer'auctioneer gavel recently was mourned by dealers at the Grosvenor House Antiques Fair that opened here last week and will run to June 18.

title: Museum to Remove 40 Faded Homers
description: BOSTON, June 15 (AP)Some of the highpriced watercolors of Winslow Homer have laded so badly that the Boston Museum of Fine Arts said tocoy it would take them down.

title: Hnuritings
description: HOFFMANA monument to the memory of the late Bella Hoffman to ho unveiled June 19.12 P.M., Old MonIdlers Cemetery, Lot 105.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Cash Prices

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Algonquin Gas Transmission Company of Massachusetts and the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey said yesterday they had terminated their joint venture, known as Eascogas, LNG Inc., which had planned to import liquified natural gas from Algeria.

title: EDMOND ARTAR
description: ST. TROPEZ, France, June 15 (AP)Edmond Artar, a millionaire financier, was found dead in his seaside villa here Sunday, and the police said they believed his death, from an overdose of barbiturates, was a suicide. The Swissborn banker was 56 years old.

title: Around the Nation
description: Michigan Victim Denies Nurses Tried to Harm Him

title: A.T.&T. EARNINGS UP 23.4% FOR QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telephone Company, the world'world largest utility, yesterday reported earnings increases of 23.4 percent for the quarter ended May 31 and 21.5 percent for the halfyear period. Earnings and revenues set records for both periods, according to a company spokesman.

title: Design Notebook
description: SAN DIEGO ARCHITECTS do reasonably well in selecting cities for their conventions, but they seem to have trouble when it comes to actual buildings in which to meet. This year, the American Institute of Architects gathered in the San Diego Civic Center, a complex of buildings that one would think any city would want to invite a bulldozer to, rather than 1,500 of the nation'nation architects.

title: Broad Parking Ban in Manhattan Begins as Mayor Yields to Ruling
description: Acting reluctantly under court orders, Mayor Beame yesterday started implementing new parking rules that he said would eventually ban most street parking in Manhattan south of 59th Street.

title: Carey Offers CollegeTuition Plan Allowing Parents TaxFree Trusts
description: Governor Carey yesterday proposed a Itiew way to help middleincome parents pay for their children'children college education taxfree trust accounts to which they Would contribute, starting, perhaps, when 4 child was 12 years old.

title: Salt It Away, Shake It With Style
description: IT NEVER rains but it pours. First paper napkins began replacing linen ones. Then Washandpry'pry made finger bowls all but obsolete. And now Morton'Morton cardboard salt and pepper shakers are pushing more formal salts and peppers off the table. It'It quite a comedown for saltthe original status symbol.

title: Once Again, Court Reform
description: Unless someone in Albany displays some statesmanship soon, the long saga of New York court reform will end disgracefully in the next few weeks, when the Legislature adjourns. In case you haven'haven kept track, what is required of our, legislators is a second passage of the reform proposals, which include appointment of Court of Appeals judges by the Governor after the screening of candidates by a nominating commission: statewide court administration, and improved judicial disciplinary procedures. The required first passage occurred at a special session last summer. After a second favorable vote, the plan would be placed on the ballot in November for the electorate'electorate approval.

title: Senior Golf Is Captured By Remsen
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 15Richard Remsen Jr., the former squash racquets star who has been playing on Long Island'Island golf courses since he was 8 years old, reached another milestone in his sports career today. Now 57, he won his first senior golf tournament.

title: Robards to Star In a Western
description: Jason Robards, who won last year'year Academy, New York Film Critics and the National Society of Film Critics awards for his portrayal of The Washington Post executive editor, Ben Bradlee, in Alan J. Pakula'Pakula All the President'dent Men, has been signed to costar with James Crum and Jane Fonda in Comes a Horseman Wild and Free.

title: Adams Says Businesses Should Pay For the Use of Inland Waterways
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)The Carter Administration told Congress today that commercial vessels should be required to pay for the use of federally built and maintained inland waterways.

title: Restaurants
description: ALTHOUGH dozens of Japanese restaurants have opened in New York since Kitcho first came into being 19 years ago, few, if any, have managed to maintain the degree of excellence and authenticity the management here has achieved. Having moved from its bare and simple first home four years ago, Kitcho is now on 46th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Its trim, handsome, modern downstairs dining room, plus its two floors of traditional tatami compartments where guests remove their shoes and sit on the floor, are marked improvements upon this restaurant'restaurant former home.

title: Outings With Dad Within His Means
description: Sunday is Father'Father Day, and once again the question comes up: what in the world to do with the old man. Traditionally, Mother'Mother Day has been easier to handle: You take Mom out and feel smugly that you have committed a beneficence by taking her away from all this, the kitchen, the housework, the maidservant routine. For Dad, some sort of a gift filled the bill, cigars or a camera or a whathaveyou. But you knew Dad went out every day to work and it would seem silly to take him out on his day off, particularly when he will the bill.

title: Guard in Escape of Ray Ousted for Negligence
description: PETROS, Tenn., June 16 (UPI) A guard who allegedly was either reading or looked the other way when James Earl Ray and five companions went over the wall at Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary was dismissed today for negligence.

title: Psychiatrist Is Indicted
description: A psychiatrist with offices in Ma  hattan and New Jersey has been indicted on charges of stealing $50,000 in Medicaid payments between June 1973 and March 1977, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced.

title: Tulsa Mourns 3 Girl Scouts Murdered in Camp
description: TULSA, June 16Little Doris Denise Milner came home for the last time today inside a short  white coffin that was carried into the church two blocks from the home she left last Sunday on her way to summer camp.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: THE VILLAGE of Northport, L.I, is a deadly, straightforward town. The  hardware store and the sweet shop and the drygoods store and the meat market are called just that. There is a fiveanddime store that has oiled wooden floors and sells the kind of kitchen utensils that were made before kitchen utensils became chic. There are a row of stores that have taken nautical names, but they do so legitimately because they stand across from what could he Long Island'Island most beautiful recreational harbor.

title: Stage: A Pleasant Earnest
description: SCAR WILDE'WILDE The Importance of Being Ernest contains so many witty and familiar lines that in performance it can tend to sound like a group reading Roget'Roget Thesaurus out loud.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: TONIGHT at 8 o'o CBS comes down squarely on the side of family entertainment with The Prince of Central Park. Jay Jay, a I2yearold orphan, runs away from his foster home to set up a tree house refuge in Central Park for himself and his younger sister. Filmed in and around the park, the production is an attractive valentine to the park and, among other things, to the Metropolitan Museum of Art and midtown Manhattan.

title: Mrs. Bower, Mrs. Cooperstein Gain Final
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 16Neither played spectacular golf, but Mrs. Bea Bower of Pelham and Mrs. Walter Ccoperstein of Old Oaks had enough poise and experience to reach the final of the Women'Women Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

title: Plan to Eliminate Maternity Wards In 40 Hospitals Scored at Hearing
description: NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 16A disputed plan to eliminate maternity wards at 12 of the 40 hospitals in the seven county midHudson region, including Westchester County, drew the fire of residents, physicians, hospital officials and local politicians at an emotioncharged meeting here last night.

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Kidnapper Sentenced
description: Richard A. Bassik, a 33yearold insurcnce agent of Forest Hills, Queens, was senienced in Nassau County Court, in Mineola, L.I., to 20 years to life in prison for kidnapping 6yearold Paul Frieder from near his home in Jericho,. L.I., last July 13. The child, who had been held for 20 hours in a Westbury motel, freed himself and was not harmed. His abductor, who had asked for a $100,000 ransom later admitted the kidnapping, but pleaded that he was not mentally responsible.

title: No Place to Hide OPEC'OPEC Billions
description: Last year OPEC collected $44 billion more from oil sales than it was able to spend. In 1977 the exporters surplusesamassed mostly by Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are expected to exceed $50 billion. The international financial system has, to date, managed to accommodate Arab surpluses, recycling the cash back to debtor nations. But the debts pile up with no end in sight, and some economists, including Federal Reserve Chairman Arthur Burns, are wondering how it will all end.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO BALK CARTER BUSING POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The House of Representatives approved today legislation designed to block the Carter Administration'istration new policy on busing for school desegregation.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: A TwoMile Bazaar on 52d Street
description: THE BIGGEST, certainly the longest, street fair in the world, Americana 77, a kaleidoscope of antiques and crafts, of theater, dance and food stretching 12 blocks along 52d Street from Ninth Avenue to the East River will burst forth for the third year in a row this Sunday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U.M.&M. Ousts President, Plans End to Robert Hall
description: The directors of the financially troubled textile and retailing giant, United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., announced yesterday that they have dismissed George L. Staff as president and chief operating officer. They also approved phasing out the Robert Hall retail clothing division.

title: Canadian Official Bids Carter Hold Hearing
description: OTTAWA, June 16 (AP)  Finance Minister Donald Macdonald today criticized the United States Congressional investigation of uranium marketing and called on President Carter to halt it.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Sidewalks Are a Forum
description: The baseball trade that sent Tom Seaver, the pitching ace of the Mets, to the Cincinnati Reds converted New York into an angry forum of debate in which old friends screamed at one another and lifelong lovers of baseball portrayed the sport as the epitome of greed.

title: Film: Chronicle Of a Patriarchy
description: BA. PETERSON, an exceedingly selfassured, tough and robust Nebraska farmer; his wife, Eunice, a small, proud woman always ready to tell B. A. he'he absolutely right; their six sons, two daughters and assorted grandchildren and inlaws are the subject of We'We Not the Jet Set, a funny and slightly scary documentary feature made by Robert Duvall, heretofore known mainly as one of our finest actors ("Network, The SevenPerCent Solution, etc.).

title: DAVID L. SWASEY
description: David L. Swasey, a portrait painter, died Wednesday at his Essex, Corin., home. He was 68 years old.

title: U.A.W. Negotiates Contract
description: DETROIT, June 16 (UPI)Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and Teledyne Continental Inc., an engine manufacturer, reached tentative agreement last night on a new national contract covering 3,800 workers in six states. Details of the pact are being withheld pending ratification vote. The union said that negotiations to reach agreement on supplemental local contracts were continuing.

title: Beaths
description: BAKSTJoel A. Beloved husband of Norma. Father of Raney, Laurie, Julie, Mkt and Rip. Services Friday, 1:3( P.M. at the Jeffer Funeral Home Inc., 188th St. at Hillside Avenue, Hollis, LI.

title: T.W.A. Declares Dividend
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. directors declared a conditional dividend of $5.50 a share on its $2 cumulative convertible preferred stock, payable Aug. 31 to holders of record Aug. 10. It would consist of S5 accrued since Dec. I, 1974, plus the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents. It is conditional on the successful completion of its proposed $100 million public offering of a new series B preferred combined with a fractional share of common stock,

title: I.M.F. Plans 11th Gold Sale
description: NEW YORK, June 16 (AP)The International Monetary Fund said today that it would hold its 11th gold auction July 6. It said it would deliver the bullion to successful bidders from its gold stocks held by the Bank of France in Paris. As with the earlier sales, the I.M.F. will offer 525,000 ounces of gold at a marketrelated price.

title: Dollar Weakens Against Yen
description: TOKYO, June 16 (AP)The dollar weakened against the Japanese yen today as Japan announced surpluses for its May balance of payments and trade. The dollar closed at 272.375, down from 273.325 yesterday but still above Monday'Monday 271.775, the lowest closing since April 12.

title: Rococo Reigns Supreme
description: AS THE TIDAL wave of Bicentennial shows happily recedes, a last, lingering one has settled in at the Center for interAmerican Relations, 680 Park Avenue (at 68th Street). And it'it one with a twist: While museums all over the country were commemorating 1776 and all that with period displays of our decorative arts, trotting out silver and furniture of English and French descent, the Renwick Gallery, the decorativeart., branch of the National Collection of Fine Arts in Washington, had the offbeat idea of looking instead at the Spanish and Portuguese heritage of neighbors the

title: Congressional Negotiators Agree On Carter'Carter Jobs Bill for Youths
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPH)House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a bill, expected to cost $1.5 billion, containing a wide range of job and employment training programs for young persons.

title: Iowa Farming Town With a BigCity Fiscal Crisis Is Saved by Volunteers
description: SALIX, rowa, June 12Every now and then, there is a town that deserves contemplating just because of the troubles it has seen and the way it has dealt with them.

title: Expert Sees U.S. Action on Eastern Europe'Europe Debts
description: Mounting debt of Eastern European nations to the West may force the United States to choose between rescuing its overextended private banks or giving direct loan assistance to the most indebted nations, a specialist on the economics of Eastern Europe asserts.

title: Carter Picks a Florida Legislator As Vice Chairman of the C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)President Carter announced today that he had chosen Donald L. Tucker of Tallahassee, Speaker of the Florida House, to be a member and vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: Books: Roots for Jewish People
description: FINDING OUR FATHERS: A.Guidebook to Jewish Genealogy. By Dan Rottenberg. 401 pages. Random House. $12.95.

title: The Pop Life
description: LAST WEEK, we took it upon ourselves to discuss the top 10 singles, with the list derived from a collation of the sales charts of Record World, Billboard and Cash Box magazines. This week we'we apply the same approach to the top 10 albums. The idea, once again, is to select a random week, look at the bestselling disks in the country, and draw what conclusions we can about the state of music just now.

title: Norton Simon Could Replace Some Directors at Avis
description: As attorneys for Avis Inc. battled in court to upset an unwanted takeover by Norton Simon Inc.. the big consumer conglomerate, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday that Norton Simon seemed assured of getting at least two of its own) peopleand possibly threeon the Avis board to replace Avis directors with antitrust conflicts.

title: So. Carolina Loses First In College World Series
description: OMAHA, June 16 (AP)Jamie Allen pitched three innings of onehit relief and Bob Hornet collected three hits and drove in two runs tonight to carry Arizona State past South Carolina, 62, in the 31st annual college world series.

title: U.S. Steel to End Water Pollution Near Gary, Pay $3.5 Million Fines
description: CHICAGO, June 18The United States Steel Corporation agreed today to halt by 1980 the dumping of toxic pollutants from its huge Gary, Ind., works into Lake Michigan and the Grand Calumet River.

title: CLOSE RACE IS PREDICTED AS IRISH CHOOSE A REGIME
description: DUBLIN, June 16 (AP)The Irish people voted today for a government to grapple with this country'country deep economic troubles and with the political backlash of the sectarian conflict in neighboring Northern Ireland.

title: S.E.C. ACCUSES 3 EXAIDES OF BACHE DALLAS OFFICE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered administrative proceedings yesterday against three former employees in the Dallas office of Bache Halsey Stuart Inc. Similar proceedings were also brought against David Watkins, who formed a dealership in government securities called Listo Partnership with the three registered representatives.

title: Canada Extends Its Curb On Imports of Clothing Despite Criticism in U.S.
description: OTTAWA, June 16Restrictions on Canadian imports of clothing, the imposition of which has stirred sharp criticism in the United States, have been extended until June 30, 1978, the Minister of Industry, Jean Chretien, announced yesterday.

title: Pianist'Pianist Debut Begins on High Note
description: A year ago the National Endowment for the Arts released a list of grants to composers. Among names such as Elliott Carter, Gian Carlo Menotti and Virgil Thomson was that of Ken Noda of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He had been awarded $l.000 to compose an opera in three acts entitled The Rivalry, based on the personal and political life of Andrew Jackson.

description: ALBANY  New York State, with the help of the United States Department of Agriculture, opened entomological warfare this week against the cerealleaf beetle. Their big weapon was a flying armada of predatory wasps.

title: Red Smith

Donald Grant'Grant Wednesday Night Massacre, one significant fact emerged yesterday: Contrary to what the Mets chairman of the hoard had been saying and his tame columnist had been writing, Tom Seaver was not demanding renegotiation of his contract. He was not welshing. He was prepared to fulfill the commitments that extended through the 1978 season, provided the club would start negotiations now on a new agreement for the seasons of 19798081. He would, of

title: Film: The Decline and Fall
description: THE SETTING is a handsome old country house outside Berlin in the 1890's, the home of a welltodo uppermiddleclass businessman, his wife and their I7yearold daughter, Effi Briest. Effi, as played by the enchanting Hanna Schygulla, is all sunlit curls and radiant beauty, a combination of naivet, native intelligence, forthrightness and willful selfinterest.

title: Gas Shares Rise on Court ActionAnd Dow Closes With Gain of 2.88
description: Natural gas stocks ranked as prominent gainers yesterday as the general market overcame its early weakness to finish with a moderate recovery.

title: Chris Evert Player of Week
description: LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP)Chris Evert, who posted onesided singles victories over Billie Jean King and Sue Barker, was named today as World Team Tennis player of the week. Miss Evert, now in England to defend her Wimbledon crown, has won seven of her last eight W.T.T. matches.

title: From Halston, a Reprise of the Tunic
description: We left off the bottoms, a Ralston associate explained a few weeks ago when the designer showed his fall collection on Seventh Avenue. That'That the collection that goes to stores all over the country, The mannequins almost always wore heavy knitted tights with short tunic tops.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn disclosed today that the Soviet authorities had sentenced a Ukrainian craftsman of a sculpture honoring the United States Bicentennial.

title: West. Is Still Plagued by Drought, Despite Timely Rain in Wheat Belt
description: DENVER, June 16Despite rainstorms late last month, huge portions of the interior and coastal Western states continutito suffer moderate to extreme drought anclitions, Federal, regional and state offitiili said today.

title: Downtown Gears Up for AvantGarde.
description: As everyone knows, the World Trade Center, at the southern tip of Manhattan, has been the site of a number of unplanned, farout happenings, one only a couple of weeks ago when George Wittig scaled the sheer wall of one of the 110story buildings.

title: Gulf Aides Admit Cartel Increased Price of Uranium
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The chairman of the board and a top executive of the Gulf Oil Corporation acknowledged under questioning today that the international cartel with which the corporation cooperated had brought about an increase in the world price of uranium and, to a limited extent, in the cost of uranium in the United States.

title: NEW YORK NOW SAYS PARKING EDICT MEANS LOSS OF 12,700 SPACES
description: New York City said late yesterday that the immediate impact of a federally ordered parking ban would be a loss of all 12,700 onstreet parking spaces in the midtown core area of Manhattan  not the 940 spaces it had announced a day earlier. The core area lies between Third and Eighth Avenues, from 34th to 59th Street.

title: Cabbies Said to Favor Stands Over Cruising
description: A survey of 750 taxicab drivers by the New York Truth Squad, a community service group established in 1960 to study municipal problems, indicated that a large majority of the drivers would favor the elimination of cruising in favor of specified hack stands.

title: Antiques Abound at The Fair
description: Once again the Americana street fair promises to be the antiques bazaar to rival all others. Sunday'Sunday event is called Americana 77 and as many as 550 antiques dealers ana thousands of browsers are expected on 52d Street between Ninth and Park Avenues.

title: Retail Store Sales Rise by 11%
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales last week were an estimated $13.73 billion, up 11 percent from last year'year $12.36 billion. Department store sales were about $1.37 billion, up 10 percent from the year earlier $1.24 billion.

title: Rape Suspect Commits Suicide in Bergen Jail
description: An inmate at the Bergen County Jail accused of raping an 18yearold girl last month, hanged himself in his cell yesterday, officials said. Prosecutor Roger Breslin said that the body of Daniel McColgan, 27 years old, of Ridgefield Park, was found about 8:30 A.M. in the cell he shared with four other inmates. The prosecutor said that while the other inmates were sleeping, Mr. McColgan made a noose with torn bedsheets, fastened it to a beam, stepped on a bench and kicked it away, hanging himself,

title: Stage: Beatlemania'Beatlemania Formula Is Sincerely Flattering
description: BEATLEMANIA is a twohour halfconcert, halftheatrical event that blends a sequence of Beatles songs played by imitation Beatles with a slide show depicting events of the 1960's. It'It an ingratiating enough affair, if you don'don take it too seriously.

title: Swedish Goalie for Islanders?
description: The New York Islanders have scheduled a news conference at 12:30 P.M. today, at which they are expected to announce the signing of Goeran Hoegosta, the Swedish national team goalie who performed so brilliantly in the recent world ice hockey championship. Stefan Persson, a defenseman for the Brynas team in Swedish Division I, was also expected to join the Islanders.

title: Majorie FL Gross Wed To Thomas E. Yates
description: Marjorie Hope Gross, a designer of junior sportswear for Tomboy International, a division of Domino Inc in Los Angeles, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas E. Yates, program director of KLOS, ABCowned.FM radio station in Los Angeles.

title: Belgrade Conference Is Tackling Rules of Procedure
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 1613epresentatives of 35 nations began discussing rules of procedure today for a review in the fall of EastWest cooperation accords adopted two years ago, and the Soviet Union called for a constructive approach without polemics.

title: Carey, at Brooklyn Law School, Asks Support forCourt Changes
description: Governor Carey asked the 284 students who received degrees yesterday at Brooklyn Law School'School commencement exercise to help him persuade the State Senate to pass the court reorganization package intended to be put before the voters as a referendum in November.

description: TRENTON, June 16The state Democratic and Republican Parties began their annual conventions today, with Governor Byrne making an emotional defense of the state income tax, and Senator Raythond Bateman telling Republican delegates, There is a basic lack of faith in pew Jersey state government and espeCially in our Governor.

title: Justices Widen Eyewitness Rule
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Supreme Court ruled today that the jury in a criminal case may be told that an eyewitness had identified the defendant as the perpetrator, even when the police got this initial identification from the eyewitness in a somewhat questionable fashion.

title: Guard Who Caught Burglars Is Bitter
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)Frank Wills, the security guard who discovered the. Watergate burglars, says he did not receive the recognition he deserves and probably would let them go if he had it to do over.

title: High Court Limits Requirement to Grant Sabbath Off
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Supreme Court ruled today that an employer need not arrange Saturdays off for employees .vho celebrate their Sabbath on SP.turday if to do so the employer would have to *ncur such costs as overtime pay for othrs called in as replacements.

title: Opera: The Met Offers Puccini in the Parks
description: THE METROPOLITAN Opera'Opera annual series of concert performances in local parks is given this year to two operas by Giacomo Puccini. Tuesday'Tuesday opener of Tosca in Central Park was afflicted with problematic weather. On Wednesday, for La Boheme in Staten Island'Island Clove Lakes park, the weather was very n;^e indeed. And the Met responded with a nice, tidy performance.

title: MANUEL COHEN DIES; FORMER S. E. C. HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Manuel F. Cohen, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, whose reform policies won him the enmity and respect of Wall Street, died at George Washington University Hospital today of a heart attack. He was 64 years old and a resident of Bethesda, Md.

title: U.S. Says 3 Croats Intended to Seize Yugoslav Hostage,
description: The three Croatians who broke into the Yugoslav Mission to the United Nations on Tuesday and shot a chauffeur were charged yesterday with conspiring to seize the Yugoslav delegate to the United Nations as a political hostage. Jaksa Petric, the alleged intended victim, had no comment on the new charge,, which was made in a Federal complaint.

title: Yonkers Acts on a Police SickOut
description: YONKERS, June 16Yonkers officials today obtained an injunction ordering nearly 450 patrolmen and officers to end their twoday sickout and sought the help of the statecreated Yonkers Emergency Financial Control Board in the matter.

description: WHILE the United States, the Soviet Union and most European states meet in Belgrade this week to examine the effect of the Helsinki Accords, incluc!ing the human rights section calling for freer exchange of people and id$as, several books are publishedhere that cast light in the dark corners of literary freedom.

title: CONVICTION IS SET ASIDE IN SLAYING OF TED GROSS
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn set aside yesterday the conviction of 22yearold Kenneth Gilmore for the murder of Ted Gross, Youth Services Commissioner in the administration of former Mayor John V. Lindsay.

title: Amin (258 Lbs.) Said to Be Borne 25 Mi. by Britons
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 16Idi Amin, the 258pound President of Uganda, was reportedly borne for 25 miles on a litter today by British residents of his country, a former British territory.

description: Frank Crisona, a former Assistant District Attorney and brother of former Judge James J. Crisona of State Supreme Court, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of offering a bribe to an Internal Revenue Service agent.

description: MOSCOW, June 16Robert C. Toth, the correspondent of The Los Angeles Times who has undergone 13 hours of interrogation on his sources for scientific news reporting, was told today that he was free to leave the Soviet Union.

description: Job hunting for college graduates turned out to be easier this year than last, according to a report released yesterday by the College Placement Council.

description: Thelma Foster, Roger Gould, Seth Scholar, Robin Moulds, Christopher Clay and Christy Roberts belong to what has been called the last oppressed minority. They are children.

description: MOSCOW, June 16Leonid I. Brezhnev, the head of the Soviet Communist Party, was also named chief of state today, becoming the first person in his country to hold both posts simultaneously.
