description: The Hanes Corporation, which discovered the profit potential of mass merchandise outlets with its Veggs pantyhose, is prepared to take the same route with a line of cosmetics.

description: In this early stage of its life, the Carter Administration seems to be something of a hybrid on civil liberties neither entirely careless of them nor particularly devoted to their protection.

title: 0.8% DROP IS SCHEDULED IN CAR OUTPUT THIS WEEK
description: DETROIT, June 16The nation'nation automobile plants are scheduled to build 212,189 cars this week, down 0.8 percent from 213,917 last week because of two smallcar factory shutdowns of the Ford Motor Company, according to Ward'Ward Automotive Reports, the industry'industry statistical service.

title: Management
description: The simple biological fact that women tend to live longer than men has begun to cause some concern among pensionfund managers, top managements of some companies, insurance companies and lawyers.

title: At the Movies
description: THE BRASHLY GRINNING athlete who consented to squire creepy Carrie to the catastrophic senior prom was so flauntingly blond, blueeyed and broadshouldered that he reminded many youthful moviegoers of Robert Redford. More than one seasoned viewer did a different kind of double take, however, and experienced a dissimilar shock of recognition, as their memories zoomed in to a closeup of a clinching man and womaneach bearing a marked resemblance to this romantic newcomer with the unromantic name of William Katt. Oldtimers may be forgiven their sudden mental flashback to the 40's in the midst of the thoroughly modern Carrie, in view of the fact that Mr. Katt is the 26yearold son of Barbara Hale and Bill Williams, the lovingand still marriedcouple of such longago R.K.O programmers as A Likely Story and The Clay Pigeon.

title: Six Countries Agree To Accept Refugees
description: SINGAPORE, June 16 (UPI)Sources in the United Nations. High Commission for Refugees said today that West Germany had agreed to take 19 of the Indochinese. Refugees who have been living on the deck of the tanker Leap Dal. Australia will take up to 50, the sources said. Switzerland, France, Britain and AuStria said that they had also agreed to accept refugees from the ship.

title: PACT AVERTS STRIKE AT 54 NURSING HOMES
description: Both sides in the nursing home labor dispute accepted a mediator'mediator settlement formula last night, averting a threatened walkout tomorrpw by 12,000 employees at 54 nursing homes.

title: MIDWINTER RECESS SET FOR NEW YORK SCHOOLS
description: The New York City Board of Education voted Wednesday night to schedule a midwinter recess in the school calendar next year in what the board called an experiment for the purposes of energy saving.

title: Karen Kutsher Is Married To Jeffrey Wilson at Plaza
description: Karen Kutsher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Kutsher of New York and Monticello, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Wilson of New Rochelle, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Plaza by Rabbi Samuel Praia.

title: The Unsung Cole Porter, Just One of Those Sings
description: While he was never known as a pushover. Cole Porter often went along with the whims of those around him when he was writing songs for a new show. For instance, when the producer Louis B. Mayer demanded a new title song for the film Rosalie, the composerlyricist set aside the version that Mayer had called too highbrow and cave him a new one.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (Reuters)The highway bus industry had an overall loss of $9.3 million in the first three months of 19777, Daniel O'O, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today.

description: ALBANY, June 16 Governor Carey today sent to the Legislature a bill it already hadone designed to speed benefits to families of voluntary firemen who die of heart attacks in the line of duty.

description: How would you compare the destructive force of 11 Pittsburgh Steelers or an entire third grade class with that of a gorilla, locomotive or truck?

title: 3,000 in Houston Protest Anita Bryant Appearance
description: HOUSTON, June 16 (UPI)  About 3,000 members of the homosexual cornmunity and their supporters held a candlelight march to a downtown hotel tonight in a peaceful protest against the appearance of the singer Anita Bryant at a lawyers convention.

title: Broadway
description: PRODUCERS are full of hope, and at the moment Eugene Wolsk is more hopeful than almost anyone. Mr. Wolsk'Wolsk hopes however, are mixed with trepidation, and this is understandable because next season he wants to produce three musicals, coproduce one musical and do his usual job as company manager of several other productions as well. Once I had a sailboat, Mr. Wolsk says, and in a way this is like going into the fog in a sailboat without a chart. Mr. Wolsk means that trying to produce this much is exciting, but hazardous, too.

title: People and Business
description: The Carter Administration, which has been pressing for decreased airline industry regulation recently, is now turning its attention to reform of trucking regulation, Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said yesterday in Washington.

title: Truants Tell Legislator School Is Too Dangerous
description: Three young men who were truantsa handful of the estimated 80,000 pupils who habitually stay out of schoolinterrupted their hanging out at the Port Authority Bus Terminal yesterday to tell a State Assemblyman that they had stopped going to school because the schools were dangerous.

title: Prayer of Thanks For the Mets
description: COLUMBUS. Ohio, June 16 (UPI) The Rev. Kenneth Grimes bowed his head, folded his hands and prayed for Divine guidance in the resolution of conflict today to open the floor session of the Ohio House of Representatives.

title: Figures in Watergate CoverUp; Where They Are 5 Years Later
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The major figures in the Watergate and related scandals that rocked Washington have scattered in the five years since the breakin at headquarters of the Democratic National Committee. Following is a listing of some of them, their roles in the events and where they are now.

title: Padres
description: Chub Feeney, the National League president, denied yesterday a protest filed by the San Diego Padres over a June 10 game in Pittsburgh in which Willie Stargell'Stargell name appeared twice in the Pirate lineup card. Feeney noted, however, that the umpire should carefully examine the lineup cards when they are submitted and have any obvious errors corrected before the game begins.

title: Miriam B. Spotnitz, 66, Instructor At Psychoanalytic Studies Centel
description: Miriam Berkman Spotnitz, an instructor at the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies and former director of the Manhattan office of the Jewish Board of Guardians, died Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She lived at 41 Central Park West and was 66 years, old.

title: Conrad Extradition Is Planned by State; Warrant Is Issued
description: Moses Weintraub, Assistant New York Attorney General, said yesterday afternoon that he was working right now on extradition papers for Anthony L. Conrad, the former chairman and president of the RCA Corporation who resigned last Sept. 16 after acknowledging failure to file Federal, state or local income tax returns for five years through 1975.

description: PRINCESS ANNE'ANNE VISIT to Washington yesterday included garden party at British Embassy where she was welcomed by scores of guests and British Ambassador

description: What it will take, said Jerry Koosman, is to win, win and keep winning to make the Mets forget the loss of Tom Seaver and the extraordinary events that led up to last night'night homecoming against the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium.

title: Bridge:
description: Scoring a big bridge tournament requires a massive arithmetical effort by the officials. To compute the results of a single section of play, the scorer must write on a large sheet more than 350 results and calculate a matchpoint score for each player before adding at least 28 columns of figures. During a national championship, this procedure may have to be carried out 1.000 times.

title: New Evidence Found in Cancer Study: Cells Fail to Form Channels
description: Scientisti at the University of Miami have found evidence that certain types of cells grown in a laboratory become cancerous, multiplying uncontrollably, whep they lose the ability to form tiny channels linking them to neighboring cells.

title: Tom C. Clark, ExJustice, Buried; Eulogized in Texas and the Capital
description: DALLAS, June 16 (AP)Tom C. Clark, former United States Supreme Court Justice, was buried here today as 150 mourners, including Lady Bird Johnson, Federal judges and Justice Departnient officials, looked on.

description: New York City said late yesterday that the immediate impact of a federally ordered parking ban would be a loss of all 12,700 onstreet parking spaces in the midtown core area of Manhattan  not the 940 spaces it had announced a day earlier. The core area lies between Third and Eighth Avenues, from 34th to 59th Street.

description: Charles Addams, the cartoonist, Larry Rivers, the painter, and Milton Glaser, the illustrator, are among the artists whose works will be sold in the Special Events Gallery at B. Altman & Company, on 34th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues this weekend.

Brawley of Westport, Conn., and adopted daughter of Mrs.Brawley, was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Nelson Cornell, son of Dr and Mrs. George N. Cornell of Pelham, N. Y. The bride is the daughter also of the late Phyllis Seelye Brewley of White Plains.

title: Music: Westernization Of Korean Song
description: NO ONE who keeps up with the concert world can fail to know that Korea has produced a number of instrumentalists and singers of excellent quality. So far, however, we have little knowledge of what composers in Korea are doing.

title: Camp Fire Girls Move
description: The Camp Fire Girls, founded in New York City in 1910, have closed their national offices at 1740 Broadway and will open new quarters in Kansas City.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)A Federal appeals court handed consumer organizations a major setback today by unanimously upholding the interstate price of natural gas set by the Federal Power Commission.

description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday defendet the controversial expensepaid world air tour planned by its chairman, Dr. Williim J. Ronan, and his wife, by citing previous overseas trips by other Port Authority officials and their wives.

title: Art: To the Last Detail
description: REALISM is now a term that is applied to so many different pictorial styles, from the most academic and reactionary to the most freewheeling and liberated, that a title like Four Young Realists, the name of the new shovi at the ACA Gallery, 25 East 73rd (through July 1), no longer in itself conveys anything very specific. All that we can be sure of is that the paintings will, in way or another, be representational.

title: Brooklyn Delicatessen Waitress Serves Songs With the Pastrami
description: Ten hours a day, six days a week, Joanne Deutsch serves pastrami, corned beef and a hundred other delicacies, with a song in her heart and a tune on her lips.

title: Musgrove Named Coach
description: NEW HAVEN, June 16 (AP)The Connecticut Bicentennials management promoted Malcolm Musgrove, a consultant, to coach today and hired Peter Stuckey and Malcolm Darling, lowerleague English players. Musgrove replaces Bobby Thomson as coach of the North American Soccer League club.

title: Divorce Bill Gains in Brazil
description: BRASILIA, June 16 (AP)Congress tentatively approved today a constitutional amendment permitting divorce in Brazil, which is predominantly Roman Catholic. The measure must receive a second approval by both houses next week and the signature of President Ernesto Geisel before it becomes law. The President, a Protestant, has not taken a public stand on the issue.

title: Screen: The Last Samurai
description: SAMURAI SWORDSMEN are, of course, as indestructible and legendary to Nipponese moviegoers as cowboys are to Occidental film fans. And, naturally, they both fill obvious needs. But in The Last Samurai, the latest entry in the Regency Theater'Theater Japanese movie series, the truly dramatic sadness of the end of an epic age is overshadowed by the familiar, complex, stylized adventure that is often confusing and a strain on Western credulity.

title: Sheryl N. Brustein, Student, Is Married to Dr. Alan Katz
description: The marriage of Sheryl N. Brustein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton W. Brustein of Belle Harbor, Queens, to Dr. Alan Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Katz of Stamford, Conn., took place yesterday at the home of the bride'bride parents. Rabbi AllanBlaine performed the ceremony:

title: High Court Backs du Pont Family On Linking Christiana to Company
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The du Pont family won a victory today when the Supreme Court reversed a lower court'court ruling that had prevented the Christiana Securities Company from merging into E. I du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: SPAIN GIVES SUAREZ CLEARCUT VICTORY; SOCIALISTS SECOND
description: MADRID, June 16Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez'Suarez coalition swept to victory, in yesterday'yesterday election, apparently winning close to half the seats in Spain'Spain new lower house and being assured of firm control of the less powerful Senate.

description: MADRID, June 16 Shortly after being named Prime Minister by King Juan Carlos last July, Adolfo Suarez Gonzalez made a confident prediction to a French journalist: Spain will surprise you.

description: TORONTO. June 16Playing without determination, concentration or enthusiasm, the Cosmos still managed to defeat the Toronto Metros at Varsity Stadium tonight, 21.

title: A Lame Approach to Inflation
description: So far the Administration'Administration antiinflation program is much like the Emperor'Emperor clothesinvisible. Despite a pledge to drive the inflation rate down from this year'year expected 6 percent to 4 percent by 1980, President Carter and his economic advisers have done little to show how they will meet their goal.

title: Arab Hopes and Israeli Fears

They may seriously believe that the United States has the will and the capacity to coerce Israel into policies that most Israelis would regard as incompatible with the national interest.

title: Market Place
description: The New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday released its monthly margin debt figures showing that investors, who in the aggregate owe a huge amount to their brokers, increased such borrowings once again. The latest figures are either frightening or no cause for concern, depending on the point of view.

description: WASHINGTON, June 16If New. York hadn'hadn been quite so willing to produce a 1973 cleanair plan during the days of Mayor John V. Lindsay, an angry Mayor Beanie may not have had to announce the start of widespread parking restrictions in Manhattan yesterday.

Yet, anyone on any kind of bike may go out on the circular, 440yard asphalt track and, in a glorious burst, pedal side by side around the banked turns and down the straightaway with the stars of the Federation of New York Bicycle Clubs in their $700to$1.000 Colnagos, Fujis, Maseratis and Lejeunes.

title: 2 Forecasts for 77 and 78, With Striking Similarities
description: From opposite sides of the country this week have come two of the most respected quarterly forecasts on the American economy for this year and next, and the similarities are striking. They were remarkably close in their numbers for various cote gories of the economy, in their general assessment of the outlook, in their concern over the energy program'gram uncertainty, in their satisfaction with the present course of monetary policy and in their desire for more fiscal stimulus to keep the expansion running beyond next year.

Ehrlichman, who resigned two months earlier as the chief domestic affairs adviser to President Nixon, was telling a Senate committee that there had, been no attempt to cover up Watergate crimes and that the Justice Department'Department investigation of the case had been one of the most intensive in history.

Watergate crimes and that the Justice Department'Department investigation of the case had been one of the most intensive in history.

title: Film: Bittersweet, Uneven Slice of Parisian Life
description: "TOUCHED IN THE HEAD," the French comedy-drama that arrived at the Jean Renoir yesterday, leaves a disturbing feeling of youth being wasted on the young. As a bittersweet, somewhat comic diary of a small slice of the lives of four Parisian adolescents, it is despite its obvious good intentions, a roughly drawn portrait whose parts are a good deal more memorable than the whole.Perhaps the muddy black-and-white print, an often muddled sound track and shimmering, sometimes illegible English subtitles can be held partly accountable for the unevenness of this 1974 first feature by Jacques Doillon. It is clear, however, that he is a compassionate observer and critical of the social forces involving the young baker's assistant, his provincial girlfriend, his auto-mechanic pal and the uninhibited Swedish girl who brings temporary emotional upheavals and liberation into their orbit.Since it focuses largely on the room in which the baker's assistant has locked himself as a protest against the boss who has dismissed him, "Touched in the Head" has a constricted, shabby look. But since the others join him in what is essentially a lark, they become a mnage  quatre that is decidedly unusual, if not strikingly dramatic.They are, with the exception of Ann Zacharias, as the pretty Swedish catalyst, a basically aimless, callow group still bound by their lower-class social mores, despite this extraordinary fling.As the baker, Christophe Soto is mostly glum but still tender with the shy Roselyne Villaume, whom he seems to love but who, naturally, is confused and hurt when he also makes it with the liberated Miss Zacharias. And Olivier Bousquet is just as frustrated as the apparently unrequited member of the triangle. Miss Zacharias, on the other hand, contributes a charmingly natural performance as the understanding siren, who gives them a momentary glimpse of a more exciting existence.They may be temporarily "Touched in the Head" but their sincere, occasionally humorous story remains as fragmentary and inconclusive as their free-wheeling, somewhat juvenile capers.

title: Palmer Gets 70 in Open To Upstage 7 With 69's
description: TULSA, Okla., June 16Arnie had his day today, and with it he saved the 77th United States Open from a nearly anonymous start.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: A recent dispatch from Moscow suggests that it is no easier to plan a city in the Soviet world of democratic centralism than in the American environment of democratic factionalism. This may surprise those who think commercial competition and private speculation are the root causes of inhuman land planning. David Shipler reports that the urban defects which always seemed to him peculiarly Americansprawl, shoddy workmanship, inadequate transportation, and planning on an unfriendly scalealso occur in the Soviet Union, where there is no market competition and the price of land cannot soar because the Government owns it all.

description: LONDON, June 16A group of American and British hanks signed an agreement here today to lend the British National Oil Corporation $825 million for eight years.

Sayre Jr., the leader of the Episcopal Church'Church Washington National Cathedral for a quartercentury, announced plans today to retire on his 63d birthday Jan. 17. Dean Sayre hai also been active in many social causes, from his criticism of the antiCommunist crusades of Senator Joseph McCarthy in the 1950's to his support of the more, recent civil rights and antiwar movements.

title: Books of The Times
description: LIKE PROOFS of the existence of God, explanations for.New York City'City recent fiscal crisis tend to reflect 'whoever is doing the explaining. So it should come as no surprise that Jack Newfield, The Vdlage Voice'Voice intrepid muckraker, blames it all on the rich, the powerful, and the, corrupt (if that third term isn'isn a complete redundancy in Mr. Newfield'Newfield scheme of things). After all, for years now Mr. Newfield has been whaling away at, and sometimes even documenting accurately, the wretched excesses of the bad judges, venal realestate interests, and dishonest politicians who make life miserable for New York City'City poor and powerless. So one fully expected to see them trotted out as the bad guys in The Abuse of Power: The Permanent Government and the Fall of New York, which Mr. Newfield wrote with Paul A. Du Brul, a city planner and former Special Assistant to the Bronx Borough President.

title: If I Were Mayor
description: My first official act as Mayor of New York would be to admit defeat. The big problems of the city are clearly insoluble. Big questions, such as tax incentives to corporations to keep them from moving away are beyond my ken and apparently beyond everybody's. I would confine myself, as Mayor, to what might be called the little things. By this I mean the more tangible quality of life problems; the petty annoyances that drive people to drink or to Now Jersey.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS A FUELSHIFT PLAN

title: Confusion on NoParking Ban
description: Mayor Beame's first steps toward implementing a wide parking ban in midtown Manhattan have resulted primarily in incoherence and confusion, most of which seems to have been created by City Han. Considering that a Federal court had ordered New York City four months ago to take the actions that it began to take this week, observers could only scratch their heads in wonder about why the city was so poorly prepared to do so.

title: The Parking Farce
description: We are touched, almost choked, by the Federal Government's concern for the air New Yorkers breathe and by the concern of the city's political and commercial leaders for the free flow of traffic in downtown Manhattan. Their combined actions and inactions over the past four years resulted this week in some new and confusing courtordered parking regulations under which the number of cars downtown must be gradually reduced by half by 1980.

title: Inflation Hits Clipit: Its Price Goes Above$1

title: Dutch Tolerance of Illegal Abortions Draws Clients From All Over Europe

The number has dropped to 20 a day in the last year, but the proportion of nonDutch women among the patients has continued to rise sharply despite moves revoking antiabortion laws in other countries.

title: 'The Deep,' a Movie, Is Shallow
description: The opening yesterday of "The Deep" at Loew's State 2 and other theaters, as well as of "Exorcist II: The Heretic" (see separate review), mark the arrival of the silly season that more or less coincides with hot weather, out-of-control air-conditioning and asphalt pavements as luxuriously soft as deep-pile carpets."The Deep," which is even sillier than the Peter Benchley novel, recallsthough not to its own advantagethe sort of adventures Frank and Joe Hardy used to have on their summer vacations.Jacqueline Bisset, one of Cinema's natural splendors whether she's wearing a white evening dress composed by a poet or a soaping-wet T-shirt, plays the Joe Hardy role. Nick Noltt, a blue-eyed blond fellow who appears to have been cloned (clufsily) from Robert Redford's press clippings, plays Frank Hardy.While scuba diving off Bermuda, Jackie and Nick come upon the remains of a sunken vessel that turns out actually to be two. One is a World War II ammunition ship, with a $2 million cargo of morphine intact, and the other an 18th-century French merchantman that was apparently hauling something that someone has to callat least once in a review such as thisa king's ransom in precious jewels.Also figuring in the adventure is a gruff but honorable scuba diver, a role played by Robert Shaw with so much colorful crustiness that if he were a boat, and if crustiness were barnacles, he'd immediately sink. Lou Gossett plays the leader of the bad guys, all of whom are black, which may or may not have sociological significance. I doubt it. As a local beach rat, Eli Wallach looks as if he had been gotten up for a hard-time party.The story, as well as Peter Yates's direction of it, is juvenile without being in any attractive way innocent, but the underwater sequences are nice enough, alternately beautiful and chilling. The shore-based melodrama is as badly staged as any I've seen since Don Schain's "The Abductors" (1972), which is to remember incompetence of stunning degree."The Deep," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a lot of gratuitously unpleasant moments, including a scene in which Miss Bisset is massaged with chicken blood (against her will), a life-and-death fight on an outside elevator that I still can't figure out and another fight in which one man breaks the neck of his opponent, accompanied by an exceedingly noisy "click" as the bone is snapped.

title: Film: 'Exorcist II: The Heretic' Is Heavy Stuff
description: Linda Blair may be the least fleet-footed actress Hollywood has produced since the incomparable Joan Crawford attempted to keep up with Fred Astaire in "Dancing Lady." Seen tap-dancing, as she is on two occasions in "Exorcist II: The Heretic," the chubby-kneed Miss Blair appears to be stomping on live cigar stubs. The rest of the movie is even heavier and more lugubrious.Given the huge box-office success of the William Peter Blatty-William Friedkin production of "The Exorcist," there had to be a sequel, but did it have to be this desperate concoction, the main thrust of which is that original exorcism wasn't all it was cracked up to be? It's one thing to carry a story further along, but it's another to deny the original, no matter what you thought of it.I thought it was something even less than good, but this new film, which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, is of such spectacular fatuousness that it makes the first seem virtually an axiom of screen art. It was written by William Goodhart (with no reference that I could see to Mr. Biatty's original conception, which may be his wish), and directed by John Boorman, a man who makes films ("Leo The Last," "Deliverance") just fuzzy enough to seem complex, thus to invite closer scrutiny."Exorcist II" is a fancified exercise in what might be called "simultaneity," which simply means it contains lots of crosscutting between scenes of simultaneous action, in this case involving characters who are supposed to be in telepathic communication. It all looks very busy, though not much happens.Mr. Goodhart's screenplay picks up the exorcised Regan (Miss Blair) four years after the startling events in Georgetown. Father Lament (Richard Burton), a failed exorcist himself, is commissioned by an old friend, a Cardinal (Paul Henreid), to investigate the original exorcism conducted by the late Father Merrin (Max von Sydow), whom we see in flashbacks alive and, all things considered, fairly well.When Father Lamont cooperates with Regan's psychiatrist (Louise Fletcher) in some experimental work involving "synchronized hypnosis" (when the therapist joins the patient in the latter's trance), all hell breaks loose again, though the being that Father Lamont sees still in possession of Regan is no longer identified as the devil. He's now called "Bazoozoo, king of all the evil spirits of the air." Even the mythology of the movie is second-rate, less mysterious than opportunistic, as if designed to offend the fewest possible people."Exorcist II" begins by looking foolish and slowly becomes a straightfaced film of the absurd. The fight for possession of Regan's soul entails several trips to Africa, two to Rome, and finally a climactic one to the same Georgetown house that figured in the first film.Mr. Boorman's strength, however, is not in his narrative or in his handling of actors, all of whom (especially Miss Blair and Miss Fletcher) look extremely ill at ease. It's in his sets and dcor. I especially liked the psychiatric clinic in a large New York hospital, which looks like the Charles Jordan Fifth Avenue shoe store without the shoes, and the mirrored terrace of Regan's New York penthouse that contains a pigeon cote that seems to be a homage to Louise Nevelson. Everything else, including two immolations, is cold mashed potatoes.

title: Books of The Times
description: Sports books, regardless of their quality, can be separated into two easily distinguishable categories. There are the traditional volumes that focus on the glamour of the athletes and the spirit and delight of the games themselves. These books prompt a reflex response in the American male psyche; trolleys to insouciance, they lure adults back to an adolescent world where dominion, even a sense of being, could be realized with a 30foot jump shot from outside the key or with a thirdstrike curve ball that nipped the outside corner. Instant rejuvenation, wheat germ for the anemic post30's ego.

Somehow, it manages to overfeed 600 people buffet style, to toss them a handful of singers (which everyone talks through), and to give them a Broadway show with name entertainers in the lead roles, all for a price that never goes higher than $12.95 on Saturday. The current show is Pal Joey, which is being held over until July 3 on their postagestamp stage. The audience loved it; had reservations.

title: Plan to Drop Licensing Stirs a Dispute
description: A key question surrounds the world of dog shows this summer. Will the American Kennel Club give up the licensing of professional handlers? The current indications are that the query will come up for a vote, Sept. 13, at the A.K.C. delegates meet ing. Adverse criticism in the next month or so could possibly change our minds, but it's very unlikely, said John A. Lafore Jr., president of the A.K.C. There doesn't seem to be any strong opposition, judge by the reaction of the delegates, Lafore said after 200 delegates were notified of the possible move and reasons for it at a meeting last week in New York. It was the biggest meeting we ever had, he added.

I think they'll be dragging all the Local 802 guys out of the orchestra pits and putting them up there on the stage. Miller is one of the four talented musicians whose onstage efforts in I Love My Wife are a major ingredient of that musical's success. The quartet serves both as the show's orchestra and as a hip Greek chorus commenting the action.

title: Samurai Farmhouse Ties East and West
description: THE doesn't really believe there are ghosts in here, does he? Shiro Aoki turned back to the carpenter standing beside him, and repeated the question in Japanese. The carpenter's expressionless face was cocked to one side, and his hands were clasped in front of him. He was the pic ture of indulgent good manners as he waited for Mr. Aoki to translate. What was the American's next question, and how many more before he could return to his work?

title: When to Go for a Show
description: The Vanderbilt Mansion and Museum are open for visits Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and on Sundays from noon to 5 P.M. Both are closed on Mondays, except holidays. Admission is $1 for adults, 50 cents for children.

title: WILL SUCCESS SPOIL AUSTRIA'S ECONOMY?; With Full Employment and Labor Peace, Nation Must Figure Out How to Avoid Overheating
description: VIENNAAustria, an island of full employment and labor peace wedged between repressiye Communist systems and troubled Western societies, is grappling with a set of problems rare in presentday Europeits boom economy is threatening to overheat. How to cool it somewhat is now a matter of debate in this small, scenic and neutral country that lately, has become a little smug.

title: Free School Lunches May End in Fall
description: THERE are some who say there is no such thing as free lunch. In many New Jersey schools this is true, and in many others it may soon come to pass, because a number of legislators are trying to abolish the freelunch program. In 1974, after six years of prodding, the Legislature passed a law requiring most public schools in the state to set up lunch programs. The purpose of the act was to insure that the children of needy and working parents would have the opportunity to have a nutritionally balanced meal.

title: The Picture Changes
description: Perhaps the most remarkable feature of Spain's elections was the unremarkable way Spaniards participated, as though democracy was not a novelty in a country ruled for 40 years by dictatorship. Not surprisingly, the plurality of seats in the country's new parliament went to a centerright coalition led by the architect of the democratic reforms, Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez.

description: The Cosmos will meet the Tampa Bay Rowdies at Giants Stadium this afternoon in a game that could well decide the winner in the Eastern Division of the North American Soccer League. At the moment, the Cosmos, who have triumphea in their last tour games, lead the Rowdies, who, however, have played two games fewer than the Cosmos. The loss column is the important factor in this division and both teams have five defeats.

It can be applied to films or prints, in blackandwhite or color, and it is incorporated in many graphic procedures such as posterization (described below). It also attracts many because of its inherent unpredictability; no two solarizations are ever exactly alike, unless done under controlled scientific conditions.

Diners framed in the picturehat curves of wicker peacock chairs sip cocktails and wine from immense glass balloons. The soaring ceiling of the bare barn restaurant reverberates with lively chatter, tablehopping greetings and the nostalgic buzz of fans. White lace and animalprinted cottons frame windows, drape tables and cover walls. Chandeliers flicker and suntans glow the candlelight.

title: The Age of Opportunity
description: AMERICANS are retiring earlier, living longer, are in better health and have higher incomes than ever before in our history, yet we continue to treat retirees as they were instantaneously useless. In our inupandout society the car with 50,000 miles and the person with 65 years share a common fate. The proverbial gold watch becomes the key to whole new world . . . of leisure, of opportunities for travel. Why is this world so often less than satisfying?

title: IN AMERICA
description: PHILA DELPHIA When the lime came to welcome the young heroes home, a cavalcade of yellow school buses, led by police car with flashing light, swept down Girard Avenue in North Philadelphia victory procession passed dreary and familiar vistas of neglect, abandoned and burnedout housing, of overgrown and rubblefilled lots that probably exist on some dustgathering urban plan as sites of renewal projects that will never now he built. Rut as far as the celebrants on the buses were concerned the avenue might have been decked wit h hunting and st rewn with rose petals; if it had been, it would have seemed only appropriate to them. As street people and ordinary pedestrians swiveled their heads to gape at the procession, handlettered signs started appearing one of the buses. We're No. I, they announced.

Yeats describes them as being full simplicity and musical occurrences, for they are the literature of a class for whom every incident the old rut of birth, love, pain and death has cropped up unchanged for centuries: who have steeped everything in the heart: to whom everything is a symbol. That is a fitting description of the substance of this book. If myths are both the food and fruit of the imagination, then Katharine Briggs has prepared banquet.

He can hardly walk, and the only bathroom in the building on the second floor. His room is lighted by a bare bulb in the ceiling and con tains a bed, two chairs, a table, a stove, sink and refrigerator. He says he has not been outside since last fall.

title: Kabir, Bly and Merwin.

To Kabir, Robert Bly writes, the main danger is spiritual passivity. Its true; Kabir's poems give off a marvelous radiant intensity that never fails. Yet their energy is as natural as a waterfall's, neither rhetorical, hortatory nor anguished.

But in that slender company of the reliable are two mighty rocks which reassure us that some things truly abide: These are the twin facts that the assassination buffs are never going to give up, and that weand I mean all of usare never going to know the truth about the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr.

Come to Broadway. It's turning into a woman's theater and, so far as I can see from a glance back at this season, it's damn well going to stay that way.

title: Another General Called In

Lieut. Gen. Donn A. Starry, an Army commander in Germany told a high school graduating class that, at some time in the future, the United States would be participating in a war between the Soviet Union and China. He also said that the liberal press was not Interested in the truth, but simply in bringing down public official, without regard to public welfare. General Starry was ordered to report to Army Secretary Clifford L. Alexander and was given an official reprimand. Last month, statements by Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub critical of Carter Administration policy in Korea resulted in his transfer from the Korean command.

title: FISHING

Some of the best fishing around the Island is here now as well as off Montauk.

title: TV VIEW; Picky About What You Watch? You're Not Alone
description: The title, and indeed the conclusion, of a new study of public attitudes toward television is The TV Viewer Comes of Age. Initiated in the summer 1976, the project was sponsored by McHugh and Hoffman, Inc., broadcasting consultants, and KPR Associates, a firm of social psychologists. Trendex, Inc., a polling organization, was enlisted to conduct a national survey for statistical support. As with any study of this kind, the conclusions must be handled gingerly. They are useful tools for verifying observations already suggested by common sense and a casual acquaintance with the facts. But they can also become rationalizations for selfinterested tinkering, aimed more at ratings quantity than at content quality but more about that later. In the area of common sense, the study finds that, continuing a pattern set in the early 1960's, the TV audience has become even more selective in what it chooses to view. Conventional broadcaster wisdom once maintained that the audience was an inert lump. Get it to tune into one channel and it would stick with that channel for the evening. In the past few years, however, the ratings charts have demolished that theory. Massive switching from one channel to another, perhaps several times in the course of an evening, has become commonplace. Remotecontrol tuning devices help, of course, but it is also being discovered that the use of TV listings, prereviews and advanced feature articles in the determining program selection has become more widespread, complex and entrenched. This development represents an important key to most of the other conclusions.

Lloyd Baker, president of United Mine Workers rict 20, said he had called a meeting of local union presidents. Alabama has about 17,000 coal miners.

title: A CURIOUS CONTAGION

Four were written wholly or in part by Dr. Vivian Rakoff, professor of psychiatric education at the University of Toronto. Although Rakoff, with his colleague John Sigal, has reported more than 150 cases, he declines most opportunities to write or speak about his studies. When I interviewed him last month, he said he had a story to tell, and spoke without pause for 20 minutes.

title: AN AMERICAN IN PARIS At 62. Robert Motherwell is at the height of his fame.
description: Nearly 40 years ago, on the eve of the Second World War, a young American graduate student who had been studying philosophy at Harvard  he had taken his B.A. at Stanford in this field the year before, in 1937  arrived in Paris to continue his philosophical education. At Harvard, his specialty had been esthetics  he had written thesis on Delacroix's journals  and he had been advised by his professors to pursue his studies abroad. Yet esthetic theory, though never entirely absent from his thoughts over the years, was not to be the discipline that brought Robert Motherwell his great renown. This week he is back in Paris for the opening of a mammoth exhibition of his paintings at the Musee d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris  a retrospective that is probably the largest oneman show any living American artist has ever been given in a French museum. The exhibition opens on Wednesday and continues in Paris through the summer months.

title: nccotti Exit Could End the BeameGoldin Buffer
description: First Deputy Mayor John E. Zucotti Rill heave office this Friday to return to he practice of law, and some city offidolt are wondering whether one unintended side effecrwill be the resumption of the fiery disputes between May or Beame ana Lay Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin that were so common before Mr. Zucotti took office. Mr. Zucotti's friendship with Mr. Goldin goes back 20 years to the time when they were debating partners at Princeton, and continued when they were both law students at Yale and lawyers together in the 1960's at the firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In retrospect the entire career of Roberto Rossellini, who died in Rome June 3 at the age of 71, was a continuing process of discarding those tricks of hack moviemaking that package responses to a single work so effectively that no twomillion people will react very differently from any other twomillion. Rossellini, an open, gregarious man in his private life, was so zealous in his pursuit truth in films that he followed it right out of the commercial cinema onto the public television screen for which, in the last dozen years, he produced a body of work that is unique, not simply for what he was doing but for how he was doing it. It quite conceivable that when the history of cinema's first hundred years is recollected in tranquillitysay in about 150 yearsRossellini's films will be seen as among the seminal works of what, for lack of any more definite term, can be called the New Movie.

title: N.Y.N.J. Schoolboys Star In Junior A.A.U. Track
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 18Paul Lankford, Vince Reilly and Tony Tufariello made high school track history tonight in winning their events at the Amateur Athletic Union's junior national championships.

title: The Ancient Art of Arts
description: AN EXHIBITION of Chinese calligraphy at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven is superior achievement. It is one of the most extensive selections of its kind ever shown in this country, and it is eminently distinctive for the stature of the artists represented in it and for the quality of the works chosen, as well as for their historical and esthetic ranee

title: CHESS
description: Agreat part of the strength of the Sicilian Defense derives from its characteristic pawn formation. Thus, the typical 1 PK4, PQB4; 2 NKB3, PQ3; 3 PQ4, PxP; NxP grants White an advantage in space controlled in the center, represented by the white KP as against the black QP; simultaneously, however, Black acquires a numerical preponderance of center pawns his KP and QP as against White's KP. What this means is that White must always be on guard lest Black take over the center by an opportune .. . PK4 and .. . PQ4.

title: Roof Ventilators Cool Hot Attics
description: ANY homeowner who has ever climbed up into his attic on warm summer day knows how hot that space can get when the sun is shining. Even with the small louvered vents that should be located near the peaks and even with additional openings along the eaves, temperatures can soar to anywhere from 130 to 150 degrees during the late afternoon of a sunny day.

title: The New York Times/John F. Unweller
description: GROTON, Conn., June 18The U.S.S. New York Citythe first naval ship to be named in honor of the citywas launched bare today with a striking New York flavor.

title: Miss Beinecke Becomes Bride
description: Frances Gillespie Beinecke; an environmental analyst, and Paul Joseph Elston, a deputy director of the New York State budget division, were married yesterday in Great Barrington, Mass.

title: United Press International MAIDEN MANNED TEST FOR SHUTTLE: Space Shuttle Enterprise taking off from Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., piggyback on a 747 jumbo jet with Fred W. Haise Jr. and Lieut. Col. Gordon Fullerton on board. Article on page Space Shuttle, Still Piggyback, Carries Its First Crew on Test Flight
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 18 (AP)The space shuttle Enterprise, carrying its first men aloft, flew paignback today on a jumbo jet for slightly more than 54 minutes over this desert space test center.

title: ELIZABETH TRYGSTAD FAST, A MEDIA SPECIALIST, 46
description: GROTON, Conn., June 18Elizabeth Trygstad Fast, a nationally known school media specialist, died Thursday at YaleNew Haven Hospital in New Haven after a fouryear fight against cancer. She was 46 years old and resided at 2 Chestnut Hill Square in Groton.

title: Francis, Faruolo to Play In Final of L.I. Amateur
description: HUNTINGTON, Li., June 18The new $2,500 silver loving cup that goes to the winner of the Long Island Golf Association's amateur champion will spend its first year in the trophy case at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club, thanks to Gene Francis and Frank Faruolo, both members of that East Williston course. They will Meet tomorrow in the 36hole final of the 54th annual L.I.G.A. amateur tournament at the Huntington Crescent Club after each won two matches today.

title: Medical Journal Urges Ban on Drug Taken for Diarrhea
description: A leading medical journal has urged a ban on an antidiarrheal drug widely available outside the United States that Sometimes can cause blindness and permanent damage of the brain and central nervous system.

title: Tom Seaver, a Cincinnati Kid
description: To New York's baseball fans, Tom Seaver was never anything but a winner. One of baseball's best pitchers, Seaver's arrival on the New York Mets team in 1967 changed it from comedy to a contending team, then the surprise winner of the World Series in 1969. But in recent years, Seaver often differed with M. Donald Grant, the team's board chairman, over Seaver's role as a leader in playermanagement discussions and his forthright statements on the team's policies. Seaver was termed an ingrate and a New York Daily News writer devoted entire columns to describing Seaver as typical of the selfish contemporary ballplayer. Those differences dissolved into open bitterness this season, and last week Seaver was traded to the Cincinnati Reds for a young pitcher and two minor league players. A tearful Seaver couldn't face saying goodbye to his teammates, and broke down when asked to make a statement to New York fans. I've given them a great number of thrills, he said, and they've been equally returned.

title: New Satellite System Aboard QE2 Is Far From the Chart and Sextant
description: Time was when a master could sail his ship with the aid of a compass, sextant, chronometer, a hand log and a set of charts.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: FOR us, the era of abundance is over. For most of the world's population, it never was. We are living in precarious times. Our global village is faced with shortages of energy, water, productive land and food. It may be too early to predict the extent of these shortages, but the President has sounded the call to the moral equivalent of war in the area of energy conservation and use.

title: Black Studies Mark Gains but Seek Wider Role
description: Nearly a decade after it first erupted as a major issue on the country's college campuses, the discipline of black studies has apparently carved out a permanent but still quite marginal, place for itself in American higher education.

title: Rime and Reason of the Ancient Mariners
description: AFIFE AND DRUM corps is many thingsa place to hear and play music that its members like, an establishment for people of similar interests and a group in which to drink ale and beer. That describes the Ancient Mariners of Guilford.

description: TOKYO, June 18The Japanese Transport Ministry prohibited the United States Flying Tiger Airline today from making offroute charter flights to Haneda Airport in Tokyo.

description: Regina Eileen Ford, daughter of Mr and Mrs. George G. Ford of Babylon, L. I., was married yesterday to William Aloysius Cahill Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cahill of Northport, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Byrne, an uncle of the bride, in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn.

title: Rowoff for Henley Today
description: A rowoff to determine area representatives in the Henley Royal Regatta in England will be held at 11 A.M today at Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx. Jim Dietz of the New York A.C. is favored in single sculls.

title: Alaska Pipeline Flow Set to Start Tomorrow
description: ANCHORAGE, June 18The TransAlaska Pipeline system, built in one of the world's most hostile climates as a memorable national technical achievement, will go into service at 9 A.M. Monday after surviving attacks by environmentalists, Congressional debates as to its fundamental worth and the financial hazards of billions of dollars of excess costs.

description: TORONTOThat's MINT corner, remarked Eric Brown, president of Canada Permanent, as he looked down from his stately 17th floor office to the intersection of King and Bay Streets a block to the south, where a bank tower stands on each corner.

Miss Fisher, who also lives in Westchester, is an apprentice printer in New Rochelle. Both are young single women breaking into fields that have traditionally been male preserves.

title: Walker Wins in London
description: LONDON, June 18 (UPI)John Walker of New Zealand, running his first European race of the season, clocked 2 minutes 20.1 seconds for the 1,000 meters today at a regional track and field meet. The Olympic 1,500meter gold medalist was five meters up coming off the final bend and strode home to defeat Graham Crouch of Australia who clocked 2:21.08.

description: St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield, N. J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Tracy Lee Garrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Young Garrett 3d, to Stephen Edward Rubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis S. Rubin of South Wellfleet. Mass.

title: Jeanne D. Swan Is Wed To William D. Hart Ir.
description: Jeinne Dewey Swan and Williain Dickinson Hart Jr., both of New Canaan, Conn., were married there yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., assisted by the Rev. Alfred H. Whisler of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Hart's first wife died. They were attended at the wedding by their 10 children.

title: GARDENING
description: WHAT has been the scourge of the gardener since Adam and Eve found it necessary to earn their sustenance by the sweat of their brows? The answer, of course, is weeds. They are not only unsightly but also compete with our plantings for available moisture and nu trients. Would that they were only eaible, as are a few such as purslane and lamb'squarters, but most are not and must be controlled in some manner if we are to reap the fruits of our labors.

title: Track Title to East Coast A. C.
description: Howard Hemmings and Vance Jordan won two events each and led the East Coast Athletic Club to the team victory yesterday in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field championships at St. John's University.

title: Where Wrongs Were Righted
description: RIENDLY neighborhood discussions of human rights, women's liberation and the state of society are nothing new to Hartford. Back in the 1800's, Harriet Beecher Stowe, Mark Twain, womam suffragette Isabella Beecher Hooker and a dozen other 19thcentury notables often gathered for heated discussions in their living rooms or over the back fence of their homes in Nook Farm, Hartford's cultural and intellectual enclave.

title: Pursuing the Boat Thief
description: THERE she was, all 44 glistening feet of her, resting in a Westchester County marina, the chilly tides of November lapping against her sleek, white hull. It was the boat, for sure. There was only one thing wrong with the scene.

title: Crystal Water Triumphs
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 18 (UPI) Water Topweighted Crystal ater fought off the challenge of Cascapedia in the stretch today and scored a neck victory in the 38th running of the $350,000 Hollywood Gold Cup at Hollywood Park.

title: Two LittleKnown Golfers Are Suddenly Contenders
description: TULSA, Okla., June 18It is usually the first round of the United States Open golf championship that is the parade of the obscure. But suddenly two littleknown players are in a position to win tomorrow in the fourth and final round.

title: It Already Made Some Last Week: The Election Gave Form to Democracy
description: MADRIDThe speed and steadiness of Spain's transition toward democracy, climaxing in the country's first parliamentary elections since 1936, have astonished allies and adversaries of the Franco dictatorship alike. But, without diminishing the extraordinary changes in the political climate, Spain has far to go, not only in nourishing a democratic tradition among its people, but in excising or remodeling many vestiges of authoritarian rule.

title: Mayor O'Connor is fighting for his political life. In the streets, in city hall, and in his own bedroom.
description: He's been a bigcity Mayor for 14 years and a husband for 16. Now Jake O'Connor finds both his administration and his marriage falling apart. Courtordered school busing has brought the city to the verge of violent racial confrontation. Even as he struggles to maintain a tenuous neutrality, O'Connor is becoming an object of scorn to his people, a serious liability to his party, and a bitter disappointment to his wife.

description: PRAGUE, June 18The chief of protocol is the last man expected to rock the boat, but at the annual meeting of the International Olympic Committee he has been the first.

C. You see, premiere or no premiere, it lasts only three minutes.

Ross, to Peter McKay Marschalk, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Robert Marschalk, also of New Canaan. Miss Ross was graduated from the Mary A. Burnham School and Mount Vernon College. She made her debut at the NorwalkStamford Junior League Ball in 1967. Her father is executive vice president of Merrill Lynch International Inc. She is a granddaughter of the late George S. Ross,,who was secretarytreasurer of the New York, Chicago & St. Louis Railroad.

title: Police Bar Parade Of a Soweto Protest At Herald Square
description: Andrew Lukele left Johannesburg eight years ago to avoid arrest as a political activist. At times, he thinks of his homeland, but says he is afraid to return to South Africa under the current system of apartheid, for fear of arrest and prosecution.

title: Bedford Inmates Theater as Therapy
description: IT all began as therapy at the Bedford Correctional Facility. The idea of acting as an emotional release appealed to the warden. So the first theater workshops taught by Marvin Camillo functioned much as group therapy sessions do, utilizing theater games, exercises, roleplaying and psychodrama in which inmates acted out traumatic scenes from their own lives to increase their awareness of their feelings.

description: LONDON, June 18 (Reuters)Two big stands in which Greg Chappell, Craig Serjeant and Doug Walters were associated gave Australia a firstinning lead of 62 runs over England in the first test match at Lord's today.

title: COMPROMISE ON CYPRUS REJECTED. BY MAKARIOS
description: ATHENS, June 18 (Reuters)President Makarios of Cyprus said here today that he was not prepared to make concessions under blackmail or threats to accept compromise solution to the Cyprus problem.

title: Campaign Woes In 76 Discussed By Money Men
description: NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., June 18Ronald Reagan flew back to California the day before North Carolina's 1976 primary instead of waiting in that state for the results because his campaign was so short of cash that the airline would have repossessed his plane, if he had stayed one day longer.

title: A Conversation With Jimmy Carter
description: Hands have no tears to flow, said the President. We were alone in the Oval Office, and Jimmy Carter was reciting Dylan Thomas, unsmiling, his eyes turned inward as I hadn't seen them on the television screen. This text was deep inside his head. I thought from his relaxed sprawl in the easy chair beside me, his gray cardigan unbuttoned, that he enjoyed the tune the words made in the room, sounding off the fulllength portrait of George Washington before us. Behind us was the familiar set: the bank of win dows looking out on the Rose Garden, the large Presidential desk with Harry Trtunan's old sign on it, The BUCK STOPS here. It was 9:15 A.M.. Wednesday, May 25.

title: Freddie Laker's CutRate Skies
description: If the British can't serve decent food on the ground, how can we be expected to do it 30,000 feet in the air? asked Freddie Laker when he first proposed a $236 rountrip nofrills tariff for his British charter airline several years am.

title: If You Go
description: to Wheaton Village, take the New Jersey Turnpike or the Garden State Parkway and exit toward Millville. The village, which lies just off State Route 47, is 42 miles south of Philadelphia and about 150 from New York City. It is open seven days a week, excepting New Year's Day, Easter, Thanksgiving and Christmas, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $3 for adults and $1.75 for youngsters under 17 years of age. Children love the playground's sliding boardsan innovative succession of tubes, corkscrew chutes and rippling curvesand a nearby barnyard with pigs, sheep, goats, chickens and other animals. There's also a penny candy counter in the general store, which is crammed to the rafters with household goods, hardware and other remind

title: Illegal Migration to U.S. Gives Mexico an Economic Safety Valve'
description: GUADALCAZAR, MexicoAmado Salas was sharpening a hunting knife and reminiscing about Texas. Last year Mr. Salas, a 32yearold peasant, earned $20 a day working on a farm near Houston as an illegal migrant, but now he is unemployed and growing restless.

title: Koma Takashi And Eiko Otake Dance a Seal
description: It's relatively easier to become more engrossed in the way Eiko Otake and Koma Takashi dance than to think about the specific piece they are performing. Friday evening at the the Cubiculo, they showed Fur Seal, nature study in a highly abstracted mode.

title: Robert Bolt Takes a Detached Look at Lenin & Co.
description: LONDON A nyone who writes of Lenin, Trotsky and Stalin nowadays is likely to be accused of bias by some faction or other, especially if he happens to be a onetime Corn munist who abandoned the faith in disillusion and disgust. But there is no rancor in State of Revolution, the play that brings Robert Bolt to the National Theater after a sevenyear absence from the British stage; no obvious slanting of the evidence, no bullying of the audience to condemn this character or admire that one. Bolt clearly knows he stands little chance of persuading anyone of anything unless he is measured, cool, and as strictly factual as a disputed subject will allow. If that means his Soviet chronicle is a little flat and drab by the standards of A Man for All Seasons and Vivat! Vivat Regina!well, too bad. The dramatic loss is a debating gain.

title: The
description: DAVID McCULLOUGH'S favorite subject the tumbling together of human folly, high achievement and water. His first book described the Johnstown flood; his second traced the plamiing and construction of the Brooklyn

title: St. Francis Women Given Time, Place for Basketball
description: Last summer, the women on St. Francis College's basketball team asked their coach if they could use the gymnasium to keep in practice during the vacation months. A plan to open the gym Wednesday nights was approved

title: DEMAND IS INTENSE FOR SUMMER CAMPS
description: During the last two years many of the things that make children's lives richer have fallen victim to the city schools budget cuts, things like afterschool sports, clubs and music.

description: In the Belmont Hill School Chapel in Belmont, Mass., yesterday afternoon, Joan Deidre Ziegler, daughter of Mr and Mrs. John Ziegler Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, became the bride of Daniel Kilner Hunt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Torrence M. Hunt of Pittsburgh.

title: Wimbledon's Centennial Tournament Stirs Tennis World
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 18Jimmy Connors's thumb injury could be more serious than the original diagnosis and could keep the world's No. 1 tennis player from winning the title in the 100thanniversary Wimbledon championships starting Monday.

title: POLITICS
description: IN THE PAST three centuries in Connecticut, elderly people seem to have lost the special seats up front that had been set aside for them at town meetings, partly because fewer and fewer towns were governed by town meetings, and partly because those town meetings that continued to exist were so poorly attended there was no need to save seats for anyone.

title: Mary Hoskinson Married to Robert Dean, Draftsman
description: Mary Hood Hoskinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bennett Hoskinson of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Bruce Dean, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dean of Brockton, Mass. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. James C. Tetreault in Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Wilton.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: AT THE END of the economic summit meeting in London six weeks ago, the final communiqu of President Carter and six other world leaders stressed their determination to stick to each country's economicgrowth targets, not to accelerate them, and to push forward with antiinflation policies. One line in their message noted that inflation doesn't reduce unemployment, but is one of its major causes.

title: Jean Ellen Thomson Married to Donald Black, Lawyer
description: Jean Ellen Thomson, daughter of Mr and Mrs. James C. Thomson of West Chester, Pa., was married yesterday to Donald Turner Black son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald M. Black of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Robert Young performed the ceremony in the Westmin ster Presbyterian Church in West Chester. Pa.

title: Washington Accommodation
description: After weeks of mutual recriminations, the White House and Capitol Hill seemed to have adopted a new attitude of conciliation on domestic economic matters, lifting spirits at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue. Last week's mood reflected agreements that were reached on two contentious issues involvig money and politicswater projects and appropriations for education and laborand preliminary Congressional approval given to a major element in the Carter energy package, the tax on crude oil. Yesterday was a good day, Mr. Carter said, dropping in on a White House staff luncheon, and the remark clearly could be extended to cover much of the week.

title: The Case
description: Allan Bakke was one of 2,664 applicants to the University of California's medical school at Davis in 1972. He was born in Minnesota, in 1940, to a family of Norwegian ancestry; his father was a mailman, his mother a teacher. Blond, blueeyed, white, nearly six feet talc, he majored in engineering at the University of Minnesota and scored a 3.51 gradepoint average on scale of 4. He served in the Naval Reserve Officers Training Corps and, from 1963 to 1967, in the Marine Corps, rising to the rank of captain after seven months in Vietnam. Then, as an engineer for a spaceagency lab near Palo Alto, he met physicians studying the effects of space on the human body and was seized by the ambition to become a doctor. After night courses in science and volunteer work in hospitals, at age 32, he applied to 11 medical schools, including Davis. Like most medical schools, Davis had by then developed a twotrack system for applicants; 84 of its 100 places were held for open competition and 16 places were reserved for disadvantaged applicantsin practice, MexicanAmericans, blacks and AsianAmericans. The special program was Davis's own idea because so few minority students were admitted in regular competition, but it was, as well, a response to society's general pressure for affirmative action hasten the development of minority professionals.

title: SCHOOL SUPERVISION COSTLY, GOLDIN SAYS
description: New York City is spending $500 a year more than most other major American cities for each public school student, but because most of the extra money goes for administrators, it is actually spending substantially less than the national average on instruction, guidance and career planning.

title: A Critical Time For the Old Theaters Along 42d Street
description: It is the street of emblazoned names.

title: ART
description: THE Montclair Art Museum is always providing imaginative, exciting and provocative cultural contributions to the Montclair community in particular and to the art world in general. One of the most worthwhile and rewarding of this year's endeavors is the current exhibition devoted to the conservation and restoration of art works. Most of us tend to think that a museum's activities center primarily on the acquisition and exhibition of works, forgetting that the maintenance of the works is one of the foremost concerns of an art institution.

title: A Look at the Wellhead Tax, Entitlements Program and Other Esoterica of the Petroleum Industry
description: WASHINGTONFor the last four years, oil pricing has been a mystifying and, some would say, mystical affair, as what at first appeared in 1974 to be a temporary set of price controls evolved into a permanent regulatory system. Today, the language of oil speaks of entitlements, upper tier oil, composite price and other esoterica.

title: A Slippery Business
description: THE energy crisis has given rise to a search for villains. Depending upon your point of view, the wrongdoers are one or more the following: (1) oil companies that manipulated the entire situation in pursuit of profit; (2) environmentalists intent on pastoralizing the nation; (3) austere moralists who want the rest of us to join them in voluntary selfflagellation; (4) Government bureaucrats eager to mess up things they don't know about.

title: Chile Is Said to Free Communist In Return for 11 East Germans
description: BONN, Sunday, June 19 (Reuters)Chile has freed a former Communist senator, Jorge Mentes, from prison and he has been handed over to East Germany in return for the release of 11 political prisoners, the Chilean Embassy here announced today.

title: Maeve J. Keeshan Is Bride of Hans Ashbaugh
description: Maeve Jeanne Keeshan, daughter or Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Keeshan of Babylon, LI., was married yesterday afternoon to Hans Edward Ashbaugh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Gilman Ashbaugh Jr. of Edwardsburg, Mich.

title: Drive Will Seek Adoptive Parents For Many Black Foster Children
description: A campaign to seek permanent homes through adoptions for all black foster children unable to return to their own families will begin in upstate New York this week.

title: VANCE SAYS RED GAIN IN WESTERN NATIONS MAY TROUBLE SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said in remarks made public today that although the United States would prefer that democratic governments persist in the West European countries, he believed Communist Party election victories in that region might ultimately create more problems for the Soviet bloc than for the Atlantic alliance.

title: Warning on Balance of Payments
description: Many economists are now holding that America's balanceofpayments deficit with its Western tracing partners is a nositive sign.
