Spain.

title: A MillionDollar Business From a Mastectomy
description: LOS ANGELESThere's the same feisty sense of selfconfidence, the same bouyant forecast of future growth, the same aggressive, sometimes brash approach to marketing. Ruth. Handler, who made a fortune in the toy business and then lost most of it in a spectacular episode of alleged corporate shenanigans, is back in business.

title: BRZEZINSKI PHONES TOTH, IN LONDON AFTER RELEASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Zbigniew Brzezinski, adviser to President Carter for national security affairs, today telephoned Robert C. Toth, correspondent of The Los Angeles Times, to express the Administration's concern about his treatment by Soviet authorities in Moscow last week.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: TODAY is Father's Day and will pass quietly, almost unnoticed, I am sure, in my house. But all over the Island, other fathers, whose kids are at tenderer ages than mine, will be opening stoppress Father's Day cards, homemade last night against today's deadline. The awkward lettering and drawings of ungainly father figures will all be tributes to Dad done by children who hadn't gotten around to it until Mother's stagewhispered exhortations drove them to it at the last minute.

title: Energy Bill Faces Tough Opposition
description: ABILL designed to create a Department of Energy for the state faces some tough sledding tomorrow, when it is scheduled to be aired in the Assembly, and it may be revised drastically before it is enacted into law.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: In Summary

title: Alberta J. Zotack Is Wed To Peter M. Baigent
description: Alberta J. Zotack, daughter of Mrs. Alberta E, Zotack of Vero Beach, Fla., formerly of Southport, Conn., and the late Mr. Zotack, was married yesterday to Peter Michael Baigent of Syracuse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. Baigent of Halifax, England.

title: SHE CAN BEAT EVERTBUT DOES SHE REALLY WANT TO?
description: In a recent episode of Martina Navratilova, Martina Navratilova  Poor Little Rich Defector, the sturdy heroine lolls barefoot on a Texas prairie, wondering what she will feed her dog, since she's out of dog food and there are no bones. But that's O.K. Only the day before, she has won $25,000 (as much as my father makes in 20 years) for losing, so Navratilova stands contentedly on the thick rug (covering the kitchen floor of the $85,000 house on that portion of the prairie at the northern edge of Dallas), dropping morsels into the mouth of Racket, her blackandwhite mostly poodle. Racket, foundling scooped from bewilderment and traffic din beside the L.B.J. Expressway, looks contented, too. Its mistress, a selfimposed foundling herself, pulls at a strawberry shake and says, Here we are having the dinner of the rich, capitalized American. Then she adds quickly, I don't eat like this much anymore  because she is seri ous about keeping her weight down to 144 pounds (from a recent, desultory 172) and shedding her reputation as the Queen of the Junk Food.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ANY homeowner who has ever climbed up into his attic on warm summer day knows how hot that space can get when the sun is shining. Even with the small louvered vents that should be located near the peaks and even with additional openings along the eaves, temperatures can soar to anywhere from 130 to 150 degrees during the late afternoon of a sunny day.

title: Bloomsday in Dublin, a Time for Rejoycing
description: DUBLIN, June 18As a holiday, Bloomsday has the sanction of neither church no state. There are no fireworks or parades and nobody gets the day off from work, except by stealth.

title: Robert Altman Talks About His Life And His Art
description: Los ANGELES  I can only paint things the way see them, says Robert Altman, who is of course not a painter at all, but a movie director, one of the most controversial around. I don't paint what I think should be; I paint what I don't approve of. I don't paint a sunset because a sunset is true and right and perfect in itself. I cannot enhance it, so why should I show it to you?

title: CHILDREn'S BOOKS.
description: Some folklore themes have so much vitality that they just can't lose, and Patricia Coombs has hit on one of them. Her magic pot is inhabited by a funny little demon, and to a catchy chorus of huckapucka, huckapucka it dances off to raid the rich man's house and returns loaded with bounty for a poor, starving old couple, This bit of Robin Hood whimsy appears to be a skeletized version of the popular tale The Wonderful Porridge Pot, considerably weakened here because the old folks do nothing to help their good fortune along. They're just passive beneficiaries of the showoff demon. But if Coombs's telling has neither the resonance nor the ethnic authenticity of the original, her tidy pencil drawings and cheerful huckahave appeal.

title: A Reprieve for Vanishing Long Island Farms?
description: Tony Babinski surveys the land that he and his family have farmed in Bridgehampton for three generations.

title: Living WindowtoWindow, It's Not Polite to Stare
description: Richard Singer, who is 15, stands alone in his room in the Bronx. He faces his closet door. It is nighttime. A song comes on the radio. Oh that's horrible, he says.

title: Catholic Teaching On Sex Challenged By a Church Panel
description: A study commissioned by the Catholic Theological Society of America, describing sex as God's ingenious gift, breaks sharply with traditional teaching of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: No Bounce in Racquet Sales
description: Club owners and equipment makers are on opposite sides of the net when the talk turns to tennis courts. The owners claim there are too many, and the equipment makers complain there aren't enough.

title: Feeling Good
description: Being a Californian, Eve Babitz is the personification of what she writes about (a willing volunteershe appears as herself in the narrative) on the one hand; and an unwitting example, on the other. Slow Days, Fast Company is a collection of 10 stories about people and places from Laguna to Bakersfield. The author's sensibility presides and prevails throughout, threading together restaurants and landscape, friendship and fornication, diets and death, as if they were all set out en buffet. She confirms my apprehension that Californians stereotypically are for, or into anything that makes them feel good: They can be in the grip of several conflicting ideologies at any one time and feel no pain  a woman will eschew junk food and do cocaine, tan to a precancerous brown but anoint herself only with natural prod

title: Ordained a Priest, He Now Aids Troubled TeenAgers
description: BETWEEN 1972 and 1974, group of professionals and other interested people in San Diego County, California, sought to demonstrate that it was worthwhile in economic as well as human terms to divert some troubled young sters from the juvenile justice system through Project Oz. The program separated the teenagers classified as persons in need of supervision (P.I.N.S.)those essentially involved in family problemsfrom delinquents.

title: LETTERS
description: Justice Black

title: Translated From the French in Yonkers
description: THE young man once had dreams of writing a novel. Now, middle age, marriage and two children have overtaken him and he makes his living from other men's words. Martin Sokolinsky's name does appear on book jackets, but it is always preceded by the fine print of the literary world: Translated by

title: Newton, Kant, Ruskin, Virgins All
description: THERE are three ways you might consider spending your time during the next 17 years:

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Block Island's Contour And Its Palatine Graves

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AFUNNY thing happened when my daughter, Nancy, reached the first grade. This active, wellcoordinated child seemed to abandon physical activity and succumb to the expectation that a girl was nassive nonathletic beine.

title: Miss Griswold Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Alice Bradford Griswold to Basil Wise Stetson Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr and Mrs. George Griswold Jr. of New York and Litchfield and Norfolk, Conn.

title: Private Slovik's Widow Asks Aid
description: The widow of the one man executed for desertion from the United States armed forces in this century, Pvt. Eddie Slovik, has asked that her husband's name be cleared, and that she be awarded his insurance benefits. Mrs. Antoinette Slovik is crippled and indigent. Though Federal law denies such benefits to those convicted of desertion, an Army board has the option of clearing the record in cases of injustice. Private Slovik was executed by firing squad in 1945. He was apparently picked at random from among convicted deserters to be executed as an example to others.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Petty, His Luck Regained, In Michigan Race Today
description: Richard Petty, acknowledged king of the stock car racers whose crown had been tipping just a mite, defines luck as being prepared to take advantage of an opportunity to win.

title: Jumpers Compete at Ox Ridge Today
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 18The Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show concludes tomorrow with what is rapidly developing into a traditional finalea Grand Prix for jumpers. The Grand Prix event is the most demanding, testing and by tar the most difficult class for jumpers. It is designed after Olympic competitions and because of the complexity of the courses required, not all horse shows have the facilities to conduct one. For example, a bank jump is needed and a water jump also is required to make it official. Until a decade ago, there was no such thing as a grand prix in the United States. The event was limited to the big European shows. Now there are perhaps dozen in this country.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: REPRESENTATIVE Lester L. Wolff has a bill in the House with 85 cosponsors to eliminate some of the worst inequities of the G.I. education bill for Vietnam War veterans, especially those from the Northeast, where tuition costs often are highest.

title: Down's Syndrome In a Loving Family
description: WHEN Jason Kingsley was born three years ago, the obstetrician told his father bluntly: Your son is mongoloid. He will be severely retarded. My advice to you is do not let his mother see him, feed him or form an attachment to him. Put him away immediately.

title: NoFault Insurance Is Termed Effective In a Federal Survey
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)A new Federal survey of nofault automobile insurance plans in 16 states concludes that they provide quicker and more equitable benefits than does the liability system.

title: GARDENING
description: USUALLY the women gardeners are the most vocal about their hobby. They are eager to talk about favorite plants and to detail the benefits derived from working with the soil. The feminine enthusiasm is unbounded. Yet, today is Father's Day, an appropriate time for the men to have their say. Too often, a mans approach to gardening is thought to be all muscle and drive. But men have a deep sensitivity to the world of plants that is not often voiced.

title: Neil Young As Good As Dylan?; Neil Young and CSN Neil Young As Good As Dylan?
description: In 1968, David Crosby of the Byrds and Stephen Stills of Buffalo Springfield decided to get together. Shortly afterward they met Graham Nash of the Hollies at the home of Joni Mitchell. The result was a wildly successful album in 1969 called Crosby, Stills and Nash. Shortly after that Neil Young, another former member of Buffalo Springfield, hooked up with the other three.

title: Gerontology Is Still A Very Young Science
description: LOS ANGELESOn the top floor of a building at the University of Southern California here, researchers are trying to discover what chemical processes occur in the brain as people age. They hope to find the chemical mechanism, if there is one, that orchestrates the way people grow old and perhaps alter its effects.

title: Repeat Performance
description: LAST year, Bill Henderson and a select group editors brought out a volume called The Pushcart Prize'a collection of the editors favorite short stories, poems and essays published by noncommercial presses during 1975. It was a modest project, to begin with. Its aim was merely to give the average reader a glimpse of some of the riches produced by this country's 2,000odd alternative publishers and to provide the smallpress writers, most of them unknown, with a slightly wider platform from which to speak,

title: AN OUTRAGE CALLED KISS
description: They are 11, 12 and maybe II, walking (he streets of exurbia swinging their little red Panasonic eighttracks and singing lurid songssongs about hookers, boozing, a doctor who cures sick girls by allowing them to make love to him, a 93yearold man who falls in love with a Iliyearold girl. The songs, which Conor, my 12yearold, and his friends call gross, disgusting, and  most flattering of all  outrageous, are by a group called Kiss. The kids own every tape the group has ever made, every record. They have committed to memory every fact they can dig up from fan malts like Circus and Creern about the group's mysterious members, four ambit iondriven men (the oldest is 32) from Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens.

title: Elizabeth Silver Married
description: Elizabeth Felix Silver, a thirdgrade teacher in WinstonSalem, N.C., and Richard Greene Pratt, a secondyear law student at Wake Forest University, were married last evening in the bride's home in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk of Rye, N.Y., performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Betty S. Silver, achildren's librarian in Ardsley, N.Y., and the late Henry Fluegel Silver. Mr. Pratt's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Logan V. Pratt of Charlotte, N.C. Mr. Pratt is with the Interstate Securities Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., municipal bonds specialists.

title: Food
description: I tongs are seldom vhat they seem Skim milk masquerades as cream, wrote William Schwenck Gilbert in H.M.S. Pinafore. like skim milk, poor quality veal, (baby beef, some call it) is a masquerade. If the veal you peruse at the meat counter of your grocery or supermarket has a distinctly reddish color, reject it Veal should always have a pinkishwhile cast. The best comes from the hindquarters of the calf  the legs fur example  and is the most costly. There is also good veal to he had from the forequarters of the animal, and this can be used for stews. Veal is perhaps the most versatile of meats. Here is a trio of good things to do with it  a robust chili stew with olives and sweet peppers; veal a la Oskar, that classic dish of veal chops; and the traditional, Ital

title: Nancy L. Weinberger Bride of Alan J. Isserlis
description: Nancy Lizbeth Weinberger and Alan Joseph Isserlis were married last night in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by Rabbi Judah Nadich of the Park Avenue Synagogue. The parents of the couple are Air and Mrs. Herbert Weinberger of Woodmere, L. I., and Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Isserlis of Syracuse. Roni Felsenthal and Susan Horowitz were the maids of honor and Clark Isserlis was his brother's best man.

title: State Study Criticizes High Beach Fees
description: SIXTY DOLLARS a season? Or $65? Or even $90? According to the findings of a legislative committee, these are some of the fees that coastal cities in New Jersey have been charging to use publicly owned beaches.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: John J. Santucci, District Attorney of Queens; Maurice Nadjari, former New York special prosecutor.

title: To Date, $100 Million
description: Watergate is now firmly established as a cottage industry. What began as a simple thirdrate burglary and spread and grew until a President fell from office, his aides scattered to prison cells around the nation, has now turned into an American success story. A lot of people are making a lot money in many different ways: books, movies, lectures, television appearances, slide shows, not to mention the legal fees and agents cuts.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHEN IT comes to the importance of public higher education, Samuel B. Gould has a basic philosophical difference with his home state of Connecticut.

title: F.D.A. Says New Canadian Study Reinforces Its Ban of Saccharin
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that a new Canadian study linking saccharin to bladder cancer in men reinforced its decision to ban the artificial sweetener and might change the minds of some of the ban's critics.

title: New York City Draws Big Spenders
description: Mayor Beame's office released a survey on tourism yesterday that suggested that visitors to New York City can afford to spend more money than visitors to other cities.

title: Bonnie Ann Johnson, Student, Is Bride of Gary Richard See
description: in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L. I., yesterday, Bonnie Ann Johnson and Gary Richard See were married by the Rev. Charles G. liewbery. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Richard Johnson of Locust Valley. Mr. See is a son of Mr and Mrs. William Richard See of South Yarmouth, Mass.

title: Mass Transit Costs Outstripping Increase in Riders in Many Cities
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18In this city where the automobile seems as ubiquitous as the sun, mass transit has recently been enjoying a modest resurgence. Since 1972, largely because of reduced fares and expanded service, the number of daily bus riders has increased 40 percent.

title: Tennis
description: AT COMMACK, L.I.

title: To Understand Owners of Teams, Consider a Chariot Czar Named Nero
description: Why do men of wealth and power and good judgment go crazy over owning sports franchises? For an explanation, we should, perhaps, turn to the fiery fiddler himself, Nero, Emperor of all Rome.

title: GARDENING
description: USUALLY the women gardeners are the most vocal about their hobby. They are eager to talk about favorite plants and to detail the benefits derived from working with the soil. The feminine enthusiasm is unbounded. Yet, today is Father's Day, an appropriate time for the men to have their say. Too often, a man's approach to gardening is thought to be all muscle and drive. But men have a deep sensitivity to the world of plants that is not often voiced.

title: DINING OUT
description: WE STARTED out to visit another place, only to find it shuttered, dark and out business. Probably deserved to be, too. But there we were at 9 o'clock on a Sunday night and not the slightest idea of where to go.

title: County Bus Service to Be Explored
description: SUGGESTIONS from Westches residents on how to improve the county's bus system are coming in by the hundreds to the County Office Building in White Plains, and they include the following:

title: Jane deButts, Thomas Kates Wed in South
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Uppervine, Va., was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Jane Sprague deButts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hunter deButts Jr. of Marshall, Va., to Thomas Weed Kates, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Frederick Ward Kates of Silver Creek. N.Y.

title: Carter AmbassadorsCompetence Before Politics
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  President Carter, who pledged as a candidate to end the practice of appointing unqualified persons to major diplomatic posts, has now virtually cumpleted picking his ambassadorsand on the whole, he seems to have lived up to his promise.

title: One in Seven in New York City on Social Security
description: More than one of every seven residents of New York are receiving monthly Social Security benefits.

title: Baltimore County Bans Skateboards
description: TOWSON, Md., June 18 (UPI)Speeding skateboards were officially banned from Baltimore County's public streets Thursday. Ted Venetoulis, County Executive, signed a bill authorizing the police to arrest and fine violators from $2 to $10 for skateboarding on the roadways.

title: Carolyn V. Hendrickson Bride of Warren Wood
description: Carolyn Violet Hendrickson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Hendrickson of Valley Stream, L. I., was married there yesterday to Warren Charles Wood, son of Mrs. Edward Wood and the late Mr. Wood of New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

title: YONKERS POLICEMEN HALT 4DAY WALKOUT ON ASSURANCE OF AID
description: YONKERS, June 18Yonkers policemer ended their fourday walkout late today after assurances from State Senator John. E. Flynn, who had helped mediate the dispute, that money would be available for the city to open new contract negotiations with the unions.

title: The Rashomon Connection
description: We were driving through the mists of morning, two adults in the front of a rented Renault, two preteenagers in the back. Suddenly the spires of the cathedral split the haze ahead. Hey, kids! I cried, enraptured. There's Chartres. From behind came a groan, and my words thrown back at me in total boredom: Oh yeah; there's Chartres.

title: CHINA: UNRAVELING
description: HONG KONG.

title: The World
description: Kremlin Strategy On Human Rights Growing Clear

title: Stories to Practice on Cows
description: FINN McCOOL and the Fianna were using up food and drink together when a giant dressed in the skins of a wild beast walked in on them without passing a blessing on them. This giant had thick legs and thick hair, matted and crawling with worms, and he spoke in a fierce, rough voice. Bald Conan rose up, always a big, bold fellow without any sense, and when he rose up, he scattered the chessmen on the grass. Conan hit the giant on his jawbone, then Finn himself rose and put the blame on Conan because he hit a stranger without any reason. Finn was High King of Ireland, and the stranger invited him to visit the King of the Vikings. Finn launched his fleet of boats with his own shoe, and sent it out swimming . . . riling up the water so that the smooth sand went to the bottom and the rough sand came to the top, and so that the small eels knotted themselves with the big eels.

title: Grandpa Had a Way With Oysters
description: READERS of An Almanac of Words at Play are probably aware that Willard Espy regards the vagaries of his mother tongue with the bemused fascination of a man contemplating proven streak of lunacy in his family. It is not surprising that he regards his family in much the same spirit. After all, both languages and family trees are full of unexpected patterns, logicdefying similarities and dissintilarities, odd crossings of historical paths. Anyone with Mr. Espy's delight in homonyms and other mad accidents of English orthography almost bound to bring a like obsession to the study of his own ancestry. The Espy genealogy as mapped by this scion resembles nothing so much as an amiable living pun: the result of a wonderworking Providence that might in a humorous mood put 15 people named Thurston in the same car on the 10:23

title: Linden Hav emeyer, Law Student, Is Married to David Scott Wise
description: Linden Havemeyet, daughter of Mr.  and Mrs. Harry W. Hagemeyer of New York and Islip, Li, was married yesterday to David Scott Wise, son of Mr.  and Mrs. Harry H. Wise Jr. of Hartsdale. N.Y.

title: East Berlin: Image Vs. Tourist Reality
description: My wife and I have recently returned from a vacation to East Berlin, and acquaintances respond to the fact with expressions that range somewhere between pity and morbid curiosity. Their image of the place, when I press them to describe it, seems to be of a walledin labyrinth of wet, gray, vacant streets and halfruined buildings plunged in perpetual twilight, inhabited by a depressed population of old women, policemen, fanatical athletes, tightlipped spies in brown leather trenchcoats, faceless proletarian armies marching to and from work beneath gigantic political icons.

description: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy

description: DEAR JUDGE KAUFMAN:

title: XRay Technicians Often Not Trained, F.D.A. Expert Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)  A Federal radiology expert warns that in most states individuals can walk in off the street and be hired to Xray patients, for physicians.

title: Cameron Adair Weds Diane Marie Driggs
description: Diane Marie Driggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dixon Watson Driggs of Atlanta, was married there yesterday to Cameron Adair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Dixon Adair, also of Atlanta. The Rev. John Henley performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Christ the King.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Coast Guard to Rescue

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AT the borrowed campus of the State University College at Purchase, about a hundred rather unusual college students are about to receive their degrees. The average age of these students is 37 and most of them have never met one anoth er. Their graduation date has been postponed. But Empire State College is having a graduation this afternoon, and I'm receiving my bachelor's degree 26 years after I started college. This is the college I had been waiting for.

title: Deena Rosenberg, with Bernard Ro senberg, is writing a book on the Ameri Can music scene for Columbia Univer city Press.
U.S. Beats Aussies, 21, To Win Federation Cup
description: EASTBOURNE, England, June 18The United States captured the women's Federation Cup in tennis for the sixth time today with a 21 victory over Australia in the final. For their efforts, the American team of Billie Jean King. Chris Evert and Rosemary Casals collected more than $50,000 in prize money.

title: Miss Espinosa Bride Of W. M. Murphy Jr.
description: Marianne Espinosa, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Albert O. Espinosa of Seaford, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to W. Michael Murphy Jr., son of Mrs. Richard J. Hughes of Princeton, N. J., and Durham, N. C., and the late Capt. William M. Murphy, U.S.A.F.

title: Immaculata Names Coach
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP)Immaculata College named Vicki Harrington yesterday to succeed Cathy Rush as basketball coach at the women's college. The new coach has led the girls team at Paul VI High School in Haddonfield, N.J., since 1968. Her teams have won three South Jersey Conference titles and one state parochial title.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The incremental cost of developing OPEC's oil fields and producing crude oil from them is about 25 cents per barrel, including a 20 percent rate of return on investment. This 25 cents, the price exacted by nature, is what oil would bring in a competitive market. OPEC, however, takes $11 a barrel by tax or $11.51 by direct sale. The tax, though expressed in terms of posted prices, royalty rates, and income tax rates, is independent of market price and real profit; it is in fact an excise tax.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ANY homeowner who has ever climbed up into his attic on warm summer day knows how hot that space can get when the sun is shining. Even with the small louvered vents that should be located near the peaks and even with additional openings along the eaves, temperatures can soar to anywhere from 130 to 150 degrees during the late afternoon of a sunny day.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: U.S. Switches to Noncommercial Blood
description: WASHINGTONAt any moment more than two billion pints of blood are circulating in the United States. While most of this pulses prosaically through human blood vessels, a small fraction of it is a matter of public concern and much political and economic bickering. This is the roughly 10 million pints a year collected for transfusion.

title: Fashion
description: The Romance of Lace

title: Harvard in Sweep Of Navy on Thames
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 18In an effort to keep a rowing tradition alive, Harvard and Navy raced four miles upstream on the Thames River course today, and Harvard won the varsity event and two others at shorter distances.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Puritanism is an unfortunate AngloAmerican traditionit came here on the Mayflower but continued to flourish in Plymouth itself as well on Plymouth Rock. Nowhere is this unfortunate attitude more prevalent than in the way our society views the performing arts in general and those of the theater in particular. My maternal grandfather, stolid, Protestant, irreligious AngloIrishman of the occasionally working class, was convinced that my sole interest in ballet was to watch girls legs. His worst fears concerning my youthful predilections for the theater were once confirmed when he discovered me reading a play called  Tis Pity She's a Whore. (Don't laughup until comparatively recently the full title of John Ford's Jacobean tragedy could not even be printed in the august columns of this newspaper.)

title: All Three States Are Doing What They Can for Clean Air
description: New York

title: Getting Into the Swim at Home
description: ENERGY conservation, which so fashionable these days, has been a way of life for me for years, particularly when it is my own energy that is being saved, not the kind that goes into a gasoline tank or the kind used to heat a home.

title: CRIME
description: In the past we have had blind detectives, fat detectives who never left their homes, onearmed detectives, even nonhuman detectives. Now George C. Chesbro in his first novel, SHADOW OF A BROKEN MAN (Simon and Schuster, $7.95), has given us a detective who is a dwarf. He is also a Ph.D who teaches criminology, has a black belt in karate and was circus stuntman:

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IT WAS a drizzly, chilly Oct. 20, but to the working news force of some 125 on the second floor of The Hartford Times Building, directly behind City Hall, the day's modus operandi was very much evident by midmorning. Page One's key components had been agreed upon, the type had been set electronically, and the composing room was busy pasting up news content.

title: The Devlins of Mountainside
description: IT'S NOT every day, Harry Devlin said with satisfaction, that you get to do something you particularly want to dofor the fourth time. The artistwriter had just been notified that Public Broadcasting of New Jersey had commissioned him to write and host a documentary on Victoriana in New Jerseyhouses, furniture, paintings and all the appurtenances of that era.
