description: LAST NIGHTS GAME Championship

title: Behind the Best Sellers: John Kenneth Galbraith
description: Unlimbering his two and onesixth yards of frame, the lank John Kenneth Galbraith put his feet up and said, I follow John Steinbeck's great rule: The business of a writer is to write, the business of a publisher is to sell. A wise man. I'm only doing a twoday turn for the new book, just to show Houghton

title: Uranium Supply Breeds Doubts
description: WASHINGTONA new issue has emerged in the festering debate over the use of nuclear power in the United States, and it is crucial to the development of more advanced nuclear technology and to the future use of the present technology.

title: State Archery Shrine Names 2 for Induction
description: Dr. Clarence N. Hickman of Jackson Heights, Queens, who revolutionized archery in 1935 when he patented new bow, is one of two persons selected for induction to the New York State Archery Hall of Fame in Auburn, N. Y., July 16.

title: Miss Upham, Daniel B. Cote, Student, Wed
description: Sherrard Douglas Upham, daughter of Mrs. E. Walker Upham of Southport, Conn., and the late Francis Bourne Upham 3d, was married yesterday to Daniel Becket Conklin Me, son of Mrs. David Ford Peck of Dayton, Ohio, and John Jamison ME of Santa Ana, Calif.

title: LOBBYISTS CHANGING ENERGY LEGISLATION
description: WASHINGTON. June 1SAlan Nedry was bothered. The House Ways and Means Committee was busily drafting taxes on continued use of natural gas, and nobody seemed to realize that natural gas is almost essential for starting up coal and oilfired plants.

title: Sentries on the Lonely SovietNorwegian Border Watch Each Other, the Weather and Wandering Rehideer
description: JAKOBSELV, Norway, June 14High and cold on a watchtower, a Soviet sentry turned his field glasses on the cold gray wastes of the Barents Sea and the mistcovered river. He stamped his feet on the narrow boardwalk around the cupola and turned his glasses east toward the barracks, probably hoping, as sentries do, that his relief would release him from the wind and rain.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Poor Little Rich Boys
description: EVERY afternoon, the boys in the little town where I now live come home from school and, after changing into their baseball uniforms, stand outside their homes, waiting impatiently to be driven to Little League practice. As I watch a group of four or five boys who live near me pacing fretfully bad and forth, I feel a little sorry for them, Somehow they seem deprived.

title: German Terror From the Left
description: THIS book is an account of the transformation of the movement that began with the German students demonstrations of the 1960'sfirst against their own universities and later against such things as the American role in the war in Vietnam and the visit of the Shah of Iran to Berlininto the terrorist movement of the 1970's. The BaaderMeinhof gang was formed by leftwing activists in 1970; its leaders were arrested two years later. The trial of the four chief members of the groupAndreas Baader, Ulrike Meinhof, Gudrun Ensslin and JanCarl Raspebegan on May 21, 1975 in a specially constructed maximumsecurity courthouse at Stammbeim that had cost $4 million to build and equip. A year later, on May 9, 1976, while the trial was still proceeding, Ulrike Meinhof committed suicide in her prison cell. The three others were sentenced to life imprisonment in April 1977. Members of the gang are still at large. One took part in the 1976 hilacking of an Air France plane to Entebbe, Uganda, and was killed there by the Israeli rescue

title: Wallace Says He'll Run for Seat In Senate Now Held by Sparkman
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 18 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace said today that he intendsed to run for the Senate seat held by veteran Democrat John Sparkman, who has not announced whether he will seek reelection. There have been rumors that he clans to retire.

title: The Village of Glass: A Patriarch's Legacy
description: Down amid the scrub pines of Millville, N.J., tucked away in the woods from the highway hamburger stands and billboards, a part of an era of Victorian elegance has its monument.

title: Taking Too Much Off the Shelf?
description: IF the universe, which our ancestors tended think infinite, now appears graspable and bounded, how much more should we become aware of the finitude of the world ocean, a terrestrial resource that is often treated as if it were infinite. The Forests of the Sea is an introduction to small but important part of the ocean, the world the continental shelf. John L. Culliney, a marine

title: Meteor Sighted on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18 (UPI)A meteor, originating in the constellation Lyra, brightened the western skies with a brilliant shouter of light that seas seen throughbut Southern California far east as Salt Lake City, early today.

title: White South Africans Appear Willing to Give, but Only So Much
description: JOHANNESBURGAs expected, the anniversary of the upheaval that began in South Africa last June 16, has taken more lives. Yet, for many South Africans, white and black, there was relief that the toll was comparatively so low: By the end of last week, 13 persons had died. In the first three days of the 1976 disturbances, more than 100 died (618 by the end of the year).

title: A SOVIET EMIGRE INSISTS AMY WROTE HIM A LETTER
description: PARIS, June 18Despite White House denials, August Stern, the son of a Jewish doctor who had been jailed in the Soviet Union and then freed to emigrate, insisted today that Amy Carter, the President's daughter, wrote him a very nice letter about four months ago.

title: Ronan Begins Junket Shielded by Security Guards
description: Surrounded by security guards, Dr. William J. Ronan, his wife, and two others in his party strode into the firstclass compartment of a Tokyobound plane yesterday on the first leg of controversial expensepaid world tour that is expected to cost taxpayers more than $4,500 for each of the four persons.

title: Games to Help InnerCity Children Learn
description: For the last 10 years, the challenge of seeing an entire new dimension of success for America's youth has led me on an odyssey covering more than 40 cities and a quartermillion miles.

title: Marjory Ella Oppenheimer Is Married To John Winthrop Judson, a Bank Aide
description: Marjory Ella Oppenheimer, a retail manager with the House of Julio, couture fashion house, and John Winthrop Judson, a project officer with the corporate development division of the Chase Manhattan Bank, were married yesterday afternoon at the Lotos Club. The Rev. William R. Nye performed the Congregational ceremony.

title: Gains in ESP Studies by Soviet Doubted by American Specialists
description: Indications that the Soviet Union is doing serious research in parapsychology have fascinated and worried some Americans for years. As a result of the image of Soviet science as a monolithic institution dedicated to serving the goals of the Communist Party, some people fear that the Russians see such research as leading to some effective method of thought control or psychological warfare.

title: An Activist And Her Fight
description: HEMPSTEAD

title: Births
description: Bloom

title: NONFICTION IN BRUT
description: Like Shays, Jack Cade, the Sepoys and the Boxers, Guy Fawkes is now remembered only by name. Who but specialists or idiotsavants can rattle off these famous rebels nonnegotiable demands? Fawkes lives on in America through the wide dispersion of his first name (alternate form; he signed himself Guido) as a relaxed synonym for fellow. In England, urchins dun you for a penny for the Guy on the anniversary of Fawkes's illfated Gunpowder PlotNovember 5, 1605, when he was caught in the cellar of Parliament with 36 barrels of gunpowder and a slow match, ready to blow up Lords,

title: South Stars Win Lacrosse
description: CROTONONHUDSON. N.Y., June 18 Tim Curran of Scarsdale High School scored six goals today to spark a secondhalf rally as the South team defeated the. North, 13 to 9, in the second Westchester County high school allstar lacrosse game. The North had won by 87 last year. The squads were composed of outstanding seniors.

title: Meadowbrook Polo Victor
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., June 18The Meadowbrook polo team defeated Bethpage,.$8, today at Hickox Field. Paul Rizzo led Meadowbrook with four goals, while Dave Rizzo and Frank Mortimer added two each. Alan Corey tallied four times to lead the Bethpage scoring.

title: Winning Irish Party Is Expected To Offer Little Comfort to I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, June 18After its surprising landslide election victory this week, the Irish Republic's new Fianna Fail Government is expected to follow a policy more or less similar to that of its predecessor and not offer comfort to the outlawed Irish Republican Army in the north.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: DINING OUT
description: THE INN at Ridgefield, like the town it is in, a place of unfailing charm. On a spacious New England street amidst the broad lawns and magnificent shade trees of similar large frame houses, The Inn has been a mecca for travelers and local folk for many years.

title: ART MAILBAG
description: I read Hilton Kramer's review, Detente Yields a Dismal Show (April 24), with some concern. As one who was closely involved in the organization of the exhibition of Russian painting at the Met, I feel it my duty to correct the very distorted perspective provided by Mr. Kramer's review.

title: Tradition Rules at Wimbledon
description: LONDONWhat is so rare as a day in June at Wimbledon, with the hydrangeas in bloom, motionless white clouds in a sunny sky and the strawberries in their heavy Devonshire cream in the members enclosure, the players tea room, the officials buttery, the press tea room, the public buffet and all the other refreshment enclaves. Twenty to thirty thousand eager tennis lovers throng the lovely green lawns an underground (subway) ride from London to Southfields Station.

title: Reparation, American Style
description: A stark question is upon us: Should we reduce opportunity for some whitessomewhatso as to accelerate opportunity for some blacks and other victims of pervasive discrimination?

title: Susan Bloede Wed To C. L.Carneal Jr.
description: Susan Lohn Bloede, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Victor G. Bloede of Plandome, L.I., was married yesterday in the Perkins Chapel of Southern Methodist University of Dallas to Charles Leonard Carneal Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carneal of Dallas. The Rev. Steve Matthew of the Highland Park Methodist Church in Dallas performed the ceremony. The couple are graduates of Southern Methodist. The bride is also an alumna of Greenbrier Junior College in Lewisburg, W. Va. Her father is chairman of Benton & Bowles Inc., the New York advertising agency. Her mother is a member of the administrative board of the Society of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center.

title: THE HEIRS OF THE HOLOCAUST
description: Shami Davidson, director of Shlava Psychiatric Hospital in Tel Aviv, puts succinctly: The trauma of the Nazi concentration camp is reexperienced in the lives of the children and even the grandchildren of camp survivors. The effects of systematic dehumanization are being transmitted from one generation to the next through severe disturbances in the parentchild relationship. Such disturbances are now being studied among children of survivors in Israel, Canada and the United States, but the investigations have been difficult. There are no experts or statistics to consult. The subject is so complex, there are so many variables that it puts researchers off, Davidson says, and it is hard to find the nonclinical population because many parents don't want their children disturbed. Most people tend to deny a problem exists. They want to avoid confrontation with pain of this extremity, and psychiatrists and psychoanalysts are no exception.

title: A Refreshing Experience
description: THE END of June, the Cantella family of New Canaan will drive to the Darien railroad station to pick up their summer guest. Waiting with them for the train from Grand Central Terminal will be a few hundred other Connecticut families who have volunteered to be host to one or more of New York's innercity children for two weeks of fresh air, grass, trees, swimming and outdoors play.

title: Kent School Crew Marks Its 50th Year at Henley
description: Kent School of Connecticut, one of the bestknown in schoolboy rowing circles, will mark its 50th Henley Regatta anniversary when it enters the famed event on the Thames River in England, June 30 through July 3.

title: Theft at Cartier's in Paris
description: PARIS, June 18 (AP)A young man today snatched a necklace and two rings valued at $28,000 from the Cartier jewelry store in central Paris. The police said the man asked a sales clerk to take the jewelry to the door so he could see it in daylight, then snatched it and fled in a car driven by a woman.

title: New York May Waive Zoning for New Apartments
description: The City Planning Commission has announced that it has begun consideration of the first four applications for special permits to erect residential buildings outside of normal zoning regulations in exchange for providing extra amenities and additional design features.

title: Elizabeth Phelps Wed To Warren M. Bayram
description: Elizabeth Stuart Phelps, daughter of Anne Stewart Pollock Phelps of Farmington, Conn., and Gordon Stuart Phelps of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Warren Marc Bayram, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren E. Bayram, also of Farmington.

title: For Whom the Atlantic Beach Bridge Tolls?
description: MILLIONS of beachgoers, surfers, golfers, tennis players and just plain residents have used the Atlantic Beach Bridge to get to and from the island of Long Beach over the last 25 years. Many have moved swiftly across the span and many others have stared blankly at the open drawbridge as a tug would chug leisurely underneath. The whole show still costs the traveler just cents.

title: Women to Get Test As State Troopers
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI)South Carolina has agreed to train at least seven women as state troopers to test its contention that women cannot do the job, the Justice Department said yesterday.

title: Jade Prince, at $63.20, Takes $286,500 Cane
description: YONKERS, June 18The fatherson combination of Jack and John Kopas finished first and second tonight in the $286,500 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Betting, Anyone? Bookies Toe the Line in London
description: LONDONHaving learned a lesson last year, when they were dropshotted by wise bettors, British bookmakers are toeing the service line with caution for the Wimbledon championships.

title: INTERVIEW
description: THERE is a popular conceit among writers that prison is one of the few places left where aspiring authors can find suffi cient peace and quiet to pursue their art. It is no longer the case, if it ever was, according to Robert E. Chinn, No. 42019, Rahway State Prison.

title: The Metropolitan Museum Concerts 19771978
description: Chamber Music

title: Westchester/This Week
description: THEATER

title: A Different Avenue of Minibus Thought
description: A MBER Light on the Minibus, touts the headline on the May 29 Opinion Page above a story written by Alan S. Garner, formerly manufacturer, now a member of the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting. An energetic spokesman, Mr. Garner gives generously of his time and effort to battle the growing popular support for transit in the towns of Fairfield County.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 19, 1977

title: When Mamaroneck Upstaged Hollywood
description: BACK in the early 1920's when Mamaroneck was a center of moviemaking, Joseph Rigano was an employee of D.W. Grif fith's studio at Orienta. I was atone mason and mechanic, the energetic 80yearold said as we toured on foot Edgewater Point, at the top of the Orienta Peninsula.

title: Democrats Pitted In White Plains
description: MICHAEL F. KEATING, former Democratic Mayor of White Plains, who lost his bid for reelection by 72 votes two years ago to Alfred Del Vecchio, the Republican incumbent, and who this year lost by two votes his party's designation to oppose Mr. Del Vecchio again, is challenging the Demociatic designee for the nomination in the September primary.

title: Protest on Chile Continues
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)Three men and two women continued a sitin today at a United Nations agency office, saying they were protesting the disappearance of persons taken into custody by the police in Chile. Participants in the protest, including a priest and a nun, said they were holding a hunger strike to support a group doing the same thing in Chile. The protest at the Washington offices of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America was started yesterday.

title: ROUNDUP
description: Of all the economic forecasting clues to be found in the entrails of public and private statistics, few attract as little notice as prices for industrial scrap materials.

title: BRIDGE
description: Once in a blue moon a bridge hand will leave all four participants excited and breathless, with the feeling that they have just descended from a Coney Island rollercoaster: The ride has gone up and down and up and down and up and down with a viciousness that would make even a seasoned sailor have doubts about his internal stability.

title: Dinah Abigail Seiver Married
description: Dinah Abigail Seiver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Seiver of Villanova, Pa., and Venasque, France, was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Eldredge Foster. He is a son of Capt. Thomas Foster, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Foster of Abington, Pa.

title: Bulgarian Airliner Hijacked to Yugoslavia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 18 (AP)An armed man demanding to be flown to Western Europe hijacked a plane carrying 49 people in neighboring Bulgaria and forced the pilot to land here tonight, officials said. He was overpowered by police who boarded the plane, they reported.

title: Violence in South Africa
description: The potential for racial violence in South Africaimbedded in the country's harsh segregation lawswas again underlined by events. Three black men burst into a Johannesburg maintenance garage last week and opened fire with submachine guns, killing two white men. And the first anniversary of last year's riots during which 600 persons died in Soweto Township, was marked by new protests and new deaths.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater

title: Too Much Gloom and Doom
description: ONCE again it is fashionable to knock the suburbs and those who live in them. As the buds, the birds and the bees appear, so do a spate of antisuburban gloomanddoom articles telling us everything that's wrong with our lives and environment. In smug, contemptuous or pitying tones, writers (mostly urban) tell suburbanites that we are slaves to our homes and possessions, and that we suffer from disenchantment, conformity, emotional numbness, loneliness, fear, dullness, alcoholism.

title: The Blue Ridge: Tours and Detours
description: Guess I'm looking for trouble. Anyone who'd claim he knew the most scenic road in the eastern United StatesI mean, of course, the Blue Ridge Parkwayis going out on a limb. And trying to pick the best section of is sheer follyunless you're sure am.

title: Weddings
description: BatchelorMitchell

title: Decorating
description: Living With Lace

title: The Aged Stir Up Hartford
description: THE PEOPLE and the authorities in Connecticut find increasingly that they are dealing with a different sort of elderly person these daysone who seems less content than an old person might have been 10 or 15 years earlier to be left to spend his remaining days with a few friends at shuffleboard, or to be sent off to a nursing home while he is still able, more or less to take care of himself.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT SURGED in May by 1.1 percent for the fourth straight month of gains, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The biggest gain came in business equipment. . . The number of starts on new housing increased 1.6 percent in May to 1.93 million units from 1.899 million units in April, the Commerce Department reported. The department also announced that personal Income rose 0.6 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted annual level of 51.507 billion.

title: The Choice
description: The law, without too much difficulty, could resolve this case either way.

title: Mary Ruth Davis Married on Coast
description: Mary Ruth Davis, daughter of Mr and Mrs. William Richard Davis of Riverside, Calif., was married there yesterday to Sperry Allen MacNaughton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm MacNaughton of Honolulu. The ceremony was performed in Calvary Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Franklin T. Hudson.

title: Marsha L. R. Wyatt Married To James McCulloch Ellison
description: Marsha Lillian Reeves Wyatt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah Hardin Wyatt of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to James McCulloch Ellison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray W. Ellison of Rumson, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N.J., by the Rev. Bruce G. Ingles.

title: U.S. Yachts Begin America's Cup Trials
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 18Ted Turner will add zest to the America's Cup scene this summer, considerable zest. For starters, the Atlanta Braves, a baseball team that Turner owns and that is now languishing in last place, are being flown up here on Thursday, a day off for them, for a clambake and a trip on the high seas to see how HE does it.

title: Marion C. Amen, 81, Daughter Of President Grover Cleveland
description: Marion Cleveland Amen, daughter of former President Grover Cleveland died Wednesday at her home at 404 East 66th Street. She was 81 years old.

title: Banking With the Quebecois
description: TORONTO  Despite the stunning, victory of the separatist Parti Qubcois in last November's provincial election, Canada's Big Five banks indicate a strong desire to keep operating in Quebec, where they have 13 percent of their branches and 11 percent of their assets and earn 9.5 percent of their profits, according to estimates of Burns Fry. an investment dealer.

title: TIMES WINS FIVE AWARDS IN PAGE ONE COMPETITION
description: The Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday announced its 43d annual Page One Awards for excellence in journalism. The New York Times won five prizes in the reporting and writing categories.

title: Yankee Star Pulled in Rout by Red Sox
description: BOSTON, June 18Reggie Jackson and Billy Martin came within an eyelash of punching each other today in the Yankee dugout in the midst of 104 Red Sox rout of New York at Fenway Park.

title: The Ancient Art of Arts
description: AN EXHIBITION of Chinese calligraphy at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven is superior achievement. It is one of the most extensive selections of its kind ever shown in this country, and it is eminently distinctive for the stature of the artists represented in it and for the quality of the works chosen, as well as for their historical and esthetic range.

title: A Boating Woman Bows Out
description: THE boating season is beginning, and I'm happy to say that this year we won't be among the throngs bouncing along on the Sound. Being married to a captain who in turn was married to his 24foot cabin cruiser, I technically became a boating enthusiast.

title: Belgrade's Deceptive Courtesy
description: BELGRADE, June 18On the surlace, the first phase of the Belgrade conference on security and cooperation has been deleptively courteom It is proceeding in an atmosphere of amiable good will, but under the surface there is a fundamental conflict about the rights of individuals and states and even about the meaning of the Final Act or Charter of Helsinki.

title: In Summary
description: The F.B.I. List Narrows Down To Just Five

title: White House Reiterates Denial
description: WASHINGTON, June 18A White House spokesman reiterated today a previous denial that Amy Carter, the President's nineyearold daughter, had written to the son of a Soviet dissident.

title: Eugenia Yeuell, Art Student, Bride of Eric Turkheimer
description: Eugenia Moore Yeuell, daughter of the Rev, and Mrs. H. Davis Yeuell of Salem, Va., was married yesterday to Eric Nathan Turkheimer, son of Mr and Mrs. Nathan A. Turkheimer of Croton onHudson, N.Y.

title: The Call to Jury Duty Is Falling on Deaf Ears
description: TWO recent New Jersey studies reveal that many people summoned as jurors try to avoid serving. The response by citizens seems to be in opposition to the traditional view of the jury, which has been described with considerable hyperbole as a palladium of liberty and as the cornerstone of democracy.

title: No More Room In the Garage
description: MADRIDThe most significant foreign policy change following this country's election will be perceptible diminishment in Spanish eagerness to join the Common Market, generally known as the European Economic Community or E.E.C. The second changewhich may be listed as likely but by no means certaincould be a soupedup effort to join NATO rapidly and then perhaps switch to it control of the strategic bases now held here by the United States under a bilateral accord.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: There is no evidence that Christian Ludwig, the Margrave of Brandenburg, ever heard the six chamber pieces that Bach apparently sent him 1721 along with an ornate, obsequious note of dedication. If he was not as impressed by the gift you or I would be, who can blame him? He didn't know that they were the Brandenburg Concertos. The scores do not appear in the catalogue of the Margrave's library and there is no record that Bach was paid for them. Perhaps the aristocratic music patron put the package aside and went about his Margravian duties, whatever those may have been, and the butler threw it out.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: The New York Times/Louis Manna

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: For Lycidas Is Dead

title: The Auto and New York City
description: Mayor Beanie, faced with a Federal court deadline to improve Manhattan's air quality by reducing auto traffic, has reluctantly taken the drastic step of banning parking in the midtown area. Since the economic impact of parking ban would be enormous, the city for years has tried to avoid imposing iteven though it was the Lindsay Administration that accepted the prohibition in the first place. Acting under protest, Mr. Beame said he would try hard to have the court order rescinded though the chances are slim.

title: Caputo, a Freshman, Jogs the Old Guard
description: AS a freshman Republican in House of Representatives dominated by Democrats, Bruce F. Caputo of Yonkers could easily have sunk into obscurity. Instead, using his membership on the ethics committee, he has been a driving force for new code of Congressional conduct. And he has advocated a crackdown on Congressmen who have accepted gifts, cash or travel from foreign governmentsespecially South Koreaand from South Korean nationals.

title: Oriana Fallaci Is Convicted, Freed In Refusal to Identify News Source
description: ROME, June 18 (UPI)A Rome judge sentenced the journalist Oriana Fallaci to a suspended fourmonth jail term today for refusing to identify a hews source.

title: Credit:
description: LAWS banning discrimination in extending consumer credit to working women are not always understood either by women themselves or by the officials responsible for enforcing the laws, according to a recent New Jersey survey.

title: Dr. Marion Fenno Wed to Dr. F. L. Mansfield
description: Dr. Marion Joan Fenno, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Brooks Fenno of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Bar Harbor, Me., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Frederick Lawton Mansfield, son of Dr. and Mrs. James S. Mansfield of Lincoln. Mass.

title: The Real Issue of the Mets Trades
description: Dave Anderson

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayBurlington County K. C. 30th all breed dog show and obedience trial. Doughboy Field. Fort Dix. N.J.; 1.568 dogs; 103 in obedience. 121 poodles; 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: But New Government Is Pushing Ahead With Reform
description: NEW DELHIThree months ago, in the closing days of the most momentous parliamentary election campaign that India has held since independence, Indira Gandhi warned the voters not to be fooled into replacing her Government with the newly formed Janata Party, a coalition of widely diverse political elements. This strange, desperate Janata alliance is like an orange, she said. With its skin intact, it gives the impression of oneness, but the moment you peel it off, it falls apart into segments. If they come in, there will be chaos in the Government. But they have come in., and so far, at least, there has not been chaos in the Government.

title: Father and Son
description: NEW HAVENTate fabrication of a hero often leaves the real, accessible, more valuable person behind, lost in the raw dimensions of stereotypeand oversimplification. One 20thcentury subjects)? popular imagemaking was an explorer and scientist who Cost mapped, from the air, Mayan and lidian archeological sites. In the 1930's he worked at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research with Dr. Alexis Carrel, and Published articles in Science, the Scientific Monthly, and The Journal of Experimental Medicine.

title: SENATOR INOUYE TO RESIGN AS INTELLIGENCE CHAIRMAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, said today that he would resign as chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelliat the end of the year.

title: The Martial Art of Mustering
description: THE HILLS are alive with the roll of drums, the whistle of fifes and the blasts of muskets and cannons. The time is summer, the place is Connecticut and the occasions are Ancient Fife and Drum Musters. Those sounds will be heard almost every weekend from midJune to early September.

title: lison Adams Married To Giovanni di Ruffano
description: Alison Mary Adams, daughter of Mr and Mrs. John H. Adams of Darien, Conn., and North Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Giovanni A. Ferrante di Ruffano, son of Giovanni Ferrante di Ruffano of East iWindsor, N.J., and Georgette Davis Ferrante of Kingston, N.J.

title: Green Leads U.S. Open by Stroke at 208
description: TULSA, Okla., June 181n what some people are calling the GreenBean Open, 30yearold Hubert Green will carry a onestroke lead over Andy Bean into tomorrow's final round of the United States Open golf championship. But six others are only two strokes away, four others are three shots away and Jack Nicklaus is five strokes away.

title: Anne Bowman Wed To John D. Martin; Sister Attends Bride
description: Anne Fielding Bowman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fielding Lewis Bowman of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday noon to John David Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Robinson Martin of Chicopee. Mass. The Rev. Dr. Nathan Adams performed the ceremony in the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich., Conn.

title: He Had an Answer for Everything
description: NOW, 110 years after his birth and 18 years after his death, Frank Lloyd Wright seems to be something between an eccentricity and a deity. He appears in retrospect to have been part funny old man, part artistarchitect on a superhuman scale. Each part of his image dates him, but curiously it is his role as a largerthanlife figure that pushes us farthest from any sense of contact with him. Today, we seem comfortable with architects in the mold of Robert Venturi (artistacademics) or Emery Roth (businessmen), but not with Howard Roark heroes.

title: Marie King, Teacher, Is Wed To Philip Andrew Fennell
description: Marie Margaret King and Philip Andrew Fennell were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Gerard DiSenso in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Beirut Plans to Rebuild Its Devastated City Center
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 18Out of the heaps of shattered concrete, twisted metal and charred frames that clog the heart of Beirut, a plan for a new and better city center is taking shape. The new Beirut that the planners envision is to have charms that the old capital lacked: green spaces, pedestrian areas, rapidtransit zones and a cultural center.

title: The Homeless Plight Of America's Musical Theater
description: New musical theater is in the air these days. In a letter on this page last March, ten leading American composers and directors deplored the lack of means to produce and revive contemporary music theater of high quality. They continued: music theater of one sort or another is a vital and creative part of musical and theatrical life todayat the cutting edge of new ideas and developments; yet it is being stymied economically and there is nowhere to turn. The solution is a nonprofit theater organized on a cooperative basis and devoted to new lyric theater. Such a theater, with adequate funding and a permanent home, would fulfill a longstanding need.

title: JANE BRODER, 83, AGENT FOR THEATER AND FILM
description: Jane Broder, a prominent theatrical agent for motion picture actors, died Thursday night at St. Clare's Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 35 Park Avenue in New York City.

title: Signal from the Senate
description: Secretary of State Vance warned last week that the Carter Administration might not have the votes in the Senate for ratification of a new Panama Canal treatyand even as he spoke two votes on similar issues were justifying his words. In one case, the Senate refused to approve an expression of support for President Carter's proposed withdrawal of American ground forces from South Korea. The Foreign Relations Committee had added a commitment of such support to a State Department appropriations bill.

title: Notes: The Met Takes To the Parks With a New Mimi
description: The temptation couldn't be resisted, and the first, slightly awed, question put to Leona Mitchell in a recent conversation was: You're really the 10th of 15 children? The soprano laughed and said, Yes, everyone seems fascinated by that fact. My father was a minister. The family is very tight and we have a gathering every two years in Oklahoma, where was born. There are already 45 grandchildren and 12 greatgrandchildren. At the age of 27, I'm a greataunt several times over.

title: Carter Says Plans of Government Should Keep Families Together
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)President Carter says the Government should give married working couples the same tax benefits available to single working people who live together.

title: Colombia Package Tour...
description: Rafael, our guide, welcomed us to Cartagena: Don't change money on the street . . . ladies shouldn't go to the marketplace ... all the hotels are overbooking and there is a chance there will be no room for you.

title: The Energy Under Our Feet
description: OVER the centuries, man has shown a remarkable capacity to meet crisis because of his ability to look about him and to find and implement solutions.

title: Board Reinstated In Mount Vernon
description: THE Appellate Division has sided with Mount Vernon's mostly Republican Zoning Board of Appeals, which has been fighting the Democratic Mayor's attempts to oust them. In a singlesentence decision last week, the fourjudge panel unani mously upheld a lowercourt ruling that Mayor Thomas Sharpe had acted illegally when he dismissed the sevenmember board on Feb. 25 and installed new Zoning Board of Appeals.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area Senate

title: Horse Show
description: AT DARIEN, CONN.

title: RELIGIOUS REVIVAL FORECAST BY GALLUP
description: George Gallup Jr., said last week that the United States may be in an early stage of a profound religious revival.

title: Realty News
description: Broadway Lease The brokerage concern of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Inc., has taken an additional 16,000 square feet of office space at 120 Broadway in an expansion and consolidation move.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: AT the annual charivari of the American Booksellers Association in San Francisco three weeks ago, there was one book not listed On any official program. Its author was not on the scene for autographing parties. In the booth of its publisher, no book or even book jacket was available for examination. There was a blowup of the book's front cover on display, but generally the book was being described and ordered on faith.

title: U.S. Is Reported To Have Bugged Korea President
description: WASHINGTON, June 18A United States intelligence agency activated electronic surveillance of the presidential mansion in South Korea in 1975 and produced specific reports on Korean bribery of American Congressmen, according to sources connected with the inquiry into the Korean scandal here.

title: A Giant Among Midgets
description: RODNEY JOHNSTONE is builder and designer of boats. Tomorrow, if Block Island weather permits, he will start a fiveday test of the boat he designed. Thee J/24's will compete in the 36yacht Midget Ocean Racing Class division, competing during Storm Trysail Clab's Block Island Race Week.

title: Carter at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., June 18 (UPI)President Carter and his family are spending a leisurely Father's Day weekend at Camp David in Maryland and have decided to skip formal church services, a spokesman said today. The spokesman said Mr. Carter had invited a minister to the Presidential retreat for private services tomorrow.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Tropical Eden or grungy Gomorrah? The question posed by the construction at right, and the articles below, is apt to get as many different answers as there are guests.

title: Small Change At Jamaica
description: THE Long Island Rail Road, in case you haven't noticed, has improved service on my line. At least the railroad calls it an improvement. It is all very puzzling, since the last time we got an improvement (shortly followed by a fare increase), the railroad ended the practice of changing trains at Jamaica and hailed it as great step forward. Now the railroad has restored the Jamaica change for my train.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ANY homeowner who has ever climbed up into his attic on warm summer day knows how hot that space can get when the sun is shining. Even with the small louvered vents that should be located near the peaks and even with additional openings along the eaves, temperatures can soar to anywhere from 130 to 150 degrees during the late afternoon of a sunny day.

title: A Victim in the Sweet Trade
description: Time was when the sugar business was known to all but those who worked the cane fields as the sweet trade. The cane doesn't have to be planted each year and the rattoons, or roots, can produce new stalks for a dozen years or more.

title: Robin S. Gimbel Is Affianced
description: Fern Tailer Denney of Oyster Bay, L. I. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Robin Suffern Gimbel, to Enrique Senior, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Senior of Coral Gables, Fla., formerly of Havana. The wedding is planned for Sept. 24 in Oyster Bay.

title: AUDIT POINTS TO FRAUD IN 537 MEDICAL CASES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 (AP)A continuing Federal audit of Medicaid payments to doctors and pharmacies has turned up 537 cases of apparent fraud or abuse, Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said here today.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Disputed Search

title: Miss Seelaus Sets Record In Rowing
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 18Mary Seelaus, a 20yearold registered nurse rowing for only 11 months, clipped 15.9 seconds fromthe record today in taking the light wherry title at the 12th annual women's rowing championships on calm Schuylkill in hot weather.

title: National League
description: Houston 4, New York 3. Philadelphia 8, Atlanta 5 (12 inn., n.). Los Angeles 2, Chicago 1 (n.). Cincinnati 6, Montreal 0. San Francisco 7, Pittsburgh 5 (12 inn.) San Diego 4, St. Louis 1 (n.).

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: June 24Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey night rally school at the Elm Room, Main Street, Little Falis, N.J., 7:30 P.M. Rally will follow. Information: Jim Bailey, phone (201)3827344.

title: The Membership Is Increasingly Young and Discontented
description: The United Mine Workers, a legendary trailblazer for American labor, is currently the pioneer in a singularly unenviable role. It is the first wellentrenched union in any major industry to show strong signs of disintegration when its membership is growing and its industry prospering.

title: What's Doing in QUEBEC CITY
description: LA DIFFERENCEQuebec City is the most French city on the continent. There is no large Englishspeaking or other linguistic or ethnic minority, as is found, for example, in Montreala visitor who hears other languages besides French in Quebec is probably eavesdropping on other visitors. The French spoken by many Quebecois is not the French one hears in France or learns at an American school: the accent is thick, the local expressions unfamiliar. But if you speak standard French, people will understand perfectly well. On the other hand, most people involved in the tourist trade speak English. The city conveys a sense of history as do few other places in Canada. It was here in 1759 that the English defeated the French on the Plains of Abraham, thus pretty much determining the outcome of the French and Indian Wars, which under the Treaty of 1763 established British supremacy in Canada. And it is here in 1977 that the Quebec Government is trying to reassert French cultural and political power after more than 200 years. With the drive for independence heating up, there is a feeling of electricity and excitement in the air, giving a new dimension to sight and sound.

title: AvantGarde Artists Create Weird Sights at Twin Towers
description: In one corner of the plaza between the twin towers of the World Trade Center, someone wearing blue jeans, a Big Bird face mask and a thick set. of tail feathers, and accompanied by a clarinetist, entertained visitors with some kind of jazz noises.

title: FINAL APPROVAL GIVEN FOR ALASKA PIPELINE
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, June 19William J. Darch, president of Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, announced here today that the Federal Department of the Interior had s=een given final approval for the opening of the transAlaskan Pipeline system.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A recent recipe served at a covereddish supper was for a Texas sandwich. It consisted of grilled, tender, thin beef slices served in a white flour tortilla with a spicy salsa cruda, the Mexican raw tomato sauce with chilies.

title: Green Captures U.S. Open Title by Stroke
description: TULSA, Okla., June 19In a scenario involving a little gutstringer putt on the final green while aware of a telephoned death threat on his life, Hubert Green emerged today as the United States Open golf champion with a par 70 for a 72hole total of 278, one stroke ahead of Lou Graham.

title: Brides and Bar Mitzvahs Bring a Rush on Yarmulkes
description: At the H. & M. Skull Cap Manufacturing Company, 46 Hester Street, on the Lower East Side, the 30 days of June are worse than the 10 plagues of Exodus. Everybody and his mother wants to get married in June, and who can keep up with the demand for yarmulkes?

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSONSylvia. Beloved wife of Moe. Devoted mother of Francine. Dear sister of Martha Fleckner, Natalie Brack, Larry & Joseph Feldman. services Tuesday, June 21, 11:45 A.M. at the Riverside, 76 St. h Amsterdam Ave.

title: Signs of a Long, Hot Summer
description: New York's baseball fans are in for a long, hot summer. Temperatures and tempers have been rising for many weeks, and Saturday the lid blew off. In Boston's Fenway Park, Billy Martin, the practically peerless leader of the Yankees, flipped his lid and tried to slug Reggie Jackson, the $2,900,000 outfielder and television star, who had been impersonating the Sleeping Beauty in right field. In Shea Stadium, members of the Mets kept slipping into the clubhouse to catch their former meal ticket, Tom Seaver, on TV. and hastening back to the field

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions

title: Alan Rosenthal Weds Susan Lynn Miller
description: Susan Lynn Miller and Alan Rosenthal were married yesterday afternoon in the garden of the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leon Miller of Little Silver, N.J. Mr Rosenthal's parents are Mr. and Mrs. M. L. Rosenthal of Suffern, N. Y. Rabbi Jack Rosoff of Temple B'nai Israel in Rumson, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: Rights and Rhetoric Sometimes Collide as 3,000 Convene in Princeton for Women'sYear Events
description: PRINCETON, June 19The little train that once carried F. Scott Fitzgerald's jaded flappers to Princeton weekends was full of women yesterday morning. As they alighted, however, they were met not by silkly undergraduates but by a waiting taxicab driver who greeted them wits cries of, Hi, girls, are you here for the women's lib?

title: Son Can't Afford Gift For Oldest Father, 134
description: BARTOW, Fla., June 19 (AP)Chester Smith, 70, would have liked to buy his 134yearold father a shirt or some socks for Fathers Day, but he says he cannot afford such luxuries on Social Security.

title: ISRAEL SAYS MONDALE OFFERED NOTHING NEW IN SPEECH ON MIDEAST
description: JERUSALEM, June 19Foreign Ministry officials said today that Vice President Mondale's speech on the Middle East, which the White House described as an official explanation of President Carter's policy, contained nothing substantially new and was a recitation of well known positions that have been enunciated in recent weeks by President Carter.

title: Fire From Benzene on a Rail Car Imperils Vienna's Sewer System
description: VIENNA, June 19 (AP)Benzene, escaping from a railroad tanker car early today, spread fire along a threemile embankment and seeped into the sewage system, sending flames shooting out of sewer openings across southern Vienna for seven hours.

title: Robinson Dismissed By Indians
description: CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP)The Cleveland Indians dismissed Frank Robinson today and replaced the major league's first black manager with Jeff Torborg, previously the team's bullpen coach.

title: The Old And The New
description: ALDEBURGH, EnglandWhen Disraeli became Prime Minister in 1868, tad a friend he had climbed to the top Of the greasy pole. His metaphor for the game of politics has lasted, but not everyone realizes that he based it on an actual sport, carnival event in Victorian England.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Japan Reports New Cholera Cases
description: TOKYO, June 19 (AP)Five more cases of cholera were reported today in the port city of Arita, 250 miles southwest of Tokyo, bringing to 56 the number of confirmed or suspected cases since the outbreak was reported last week.

title: Record 62,394 See Cosmos Top Rowdies
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 19It was only fitting that the largest crowd in the history of soccer in the United States gathered today at a game Pele played and saw him score three goals.

title: Nancy Klingenstein Is Bride of Gilbert C. Simpkins
description: Nancy Davis Klingenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Klingenstein of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Gilbert Charles Simpkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert A. Simpkins of Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: CHARLES SCHULTZ
description: Charles Schultz, founder and president of the Prince Range Company, a chain of 21 television home appliance stores in New Jersey and New York, died Saturday at the Northfield Manor Nursing Home in West Orange, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in East Orange, N.J.

title: The Slow Season in Albany
description: ALBANY, June 19A random survey of 100 cars parked near the State Capitol building the other day disclosed a surprising fact. With the summer sun shining and the Legislature entering its twentytoutth and supposedly last week, more

title: U.S. Pushes for O.A.S. Rights Move
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, June 19 (AP) United States diplomats hoping to win backing from Caribbean and Latin Amerlean nations campaigned behind the scenes, today for a strongly worded resolution on human rights by the General Assembly of the Organization of American States.

title: Wanted for the F.B.I.
description: The task of choosing a successor to Clarence Kelley as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation now under way in earnest. An estimable citizens commission headed by Irving Shapiro, the chief executive officer of Du Pont has scoured the country and produced a list of five men for the Presidents consideration. The question that immediately arises is whether these candidates should mark the beginning or the end of the President's own search.

title: Louise Adelsberg, a Teacher, Married to Joseph Kirschner
description: Louise Adelsberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Adelsberg of East Meadow, L.I., was married yesterday to Joseph Kirschner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kirschner of Monsey, N.Y. Rabbi Moses D. Tendler performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: Ali Weds Miss Porche In Ceremony on Coast
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 19 (AP) Amid exceptionally tight security, Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight boxing champion, wed Veronica Porche in a private civil ceremony today. The wedding, in the ballroom of the Beverly Wilshire, was attended by 200 friends and relatives.

title: Drought in South, Worst Since 54, Threatens Crops
description: MACON, Ga., June 19The worst drought in a quarter of a century has hit the farms of the Deep South, irreparably stunting corn and seriously endangering crops of peanuts, soybeans and hay.

title: Park Reported to Have Curbed South Korean Lobbying After Agent Defected to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 19Intelligence reports say that President Park Chung Hee of Smith Korea curtailed allegedly Illegal Korean lobbying operations here early this year after a senior Korean intelligence officer defected and began talkng Federal investigators, according to sources who have seen the reports.

title: Birth Control in Latin America Making Little Headway as Population Pressures Grow
description: MEXICO CITYNational familyplanting programs are slowing birthrates in some countries of Latin America, but for the most part population pressures on limited resources of land, water and capital are increasing dramatically.

title: Hanna Bloomfield Married to Jeffrey Rubins
description: Hanna Ellen Bloomfield, daughter of Dr. and and Mrs. Morton W. Bloomfield of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Bennet Rubins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rubins of Kansas City. Mo.

title: DOCTORS REPORT SEEING EFFECT OF VIOLENCE ON TV
description: CHICAGO, June 19 (AP)Doctors say they are seeing the effects of television violence on children they treat in their offices.

title: Granada Protest Is Put Down
description: ST. GEORGE'S, June 19 (UPI)Police officers and soldiers fired into the air today to break up a demonstration called to draw attention to charges of violations of human rights by the Government of Prime Minister Eric Gairy.

title: Francis Gets His 5th L.I. Amateur Title
description: HUNTINGTON, LI., June 19The record shows that Gene Francis, a former allAmerica golfer from Purdue, today tied Frank Strafaci's record of winning the Long Island Golf Association's amateur championship five times. The 38yearold Francis, who won for the second straight year, feels differently.

title: Commodities
description: Just as all yellowish metal that glitters is not necessarily gold, market prices for the bullion do not always reflect the usual supplydemand or speculative factors.

title: Cost of Moving Oil From Alaska Coming Under Scrutiny of I.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 19As the oil from Alaska's North Slope begins moving through the 799mile pipeline tomorrow, two fundamental questions remained unanswered: How much will it cost to put it through the pipeline and who will get the oil?

title: Lorrie Ann Enos, a Teacher, Bride of Robert Klein on Coast
description: Lorrie Ann Enos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Enos of San Rafael, Calif., became the bride yesterday afternoon of Robert Charles Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Klein of White Plains.

title: Botulism Poisonings Are Linked To Several Cases of Crib Death
description: SEATTLE, June 17Some mysterious cases of sudden infant death may be caused by accidental botulism poisonings, a report to a scientific meeting here suggests.

title: Clouts by Boisclair and Stearns Support Swan
description: Out with the new, in with the old. That was Manager Joe Torre's strategy for the Mets yesterday, as he rested his latest acquisitions and played the guys Tom Seaver used to pitch for at Shea Stadium.

title: Lobbying:
description: WASHINGTONLet's assume that a group of seven people decides to form the Peekskill Bird Watchers Society. During consideration of a bill in Congress to create a wildlife refuge in Westchester County, the society asks a (hypothetical) Miss. Joan Smith, a retired librarian, to coordinate the group's efforts to help pass the bill. To cover her expenses the society decides to pay her $25 per week. So Miss Smith writes a series of letters in support of the refuge to members of Congress and phones 15 Congressional offices. For a period of four weeks this consumes 75 percent of her working time. Under legislation currently being considered in both houses of Congress, the Peekskill Bird Watchers Society is now a lobbying organization, and Miss Smith must register as a lobbyist and file quarterly reports, all under threat of criminal penalty.

title: Carole Sager Sings as Solo
description: Bette Midler must be wondering if a plot is afoot. With her own career proceeding slowly, she has seen her onetime pianist, Barry Manilow, become a commercial goldmine, and performers too numerous to mention have been plundering the contemporary cabaret style she developed. Now Carole Bayer Sager, the lyricist for Miss Midlees latest single, has embarked on solo career.

title: Berner Nine Takes L.I. Title
description: EAST MEADOW. L. I., June 19Berner High of Massapequa defeated Commack South, 20, today, and won the Long Island scholastic baseball championship at Eisenhower Park. Bob Kenyon, the Berner pitcher, limited the Suffolk County team to three hits, struck out 13 and walked one. The Bisons scored in the second as Tom Fuchs singled, stole second and third and scored on Nick Florin's single.

title: ISRAEL SAYS MONDALE OFFERED NOTHING NEW IN SPEECH ON MIDEAS1
description: JERUSALEM, June 19Foreign Ministry officials said today that Vice President Mondele's speech on the Middle East, which the White House described as an official explanation of President Carter's policy, contained nothing substantially new and was a recitation of well known positions that have been enunciated in recent weeks by President Carter.

description: International

title: Friends Report Biaggi Has Decided Against Entering Mayoral Race
description: Representative Mario Biaggi has decided not to run for Mayor of New York. friends of the Bronx Congressman said yesterday. They said he would announce the decision at a news conference he has called for this morning at City Hall.

title: Bridge:
description: American enthusiasts who visit European tournaments cannot improve their masterpoint holding but they can come away with cash  an unfamiliar experience but not an unpleasant one. A Goren group of 20 pairs competed in the Monte Carlo tournament at the end of May and some of the Americans were rewarded for their efforts.

title: Say It Isn't So
description: WASHINGTONWhy should the spirit of pundits be proud? Here, in ostentatious humility, are a few of the denials, denunciations and diatribes that have come this way in the past month.

title: March Held in Hitler's Birthplace
description: BRAUNAU, Austria, June 19 (Reuters) About 32,000 Austrians and West Germans, many of them. World War II veterans, marched through the streets of Hitler's birthplace here today to mark the 30th anniversary of their veterans association. The rally, which is held annually, has been attacked in the East European press as a cover for a meeting of former Nazi SS officers. No incidents were reported.

title: Military Strategy of New Importance in North Norway Near Soviet
description: BODO, Norway, June 15Recently, the Russians, only a short distance from this area of northern Norway, fired two unarmed ballistic missiles into an area of the Barents Sea where fishing rights are claimed by both Norway and the Soviet Union.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Joan Bath Oxenfeldt Wed to Dr. Martin Bruce Camins
description: Joan Bath Oxenfeldt, daughter of Gertrude E. Oxenfeldt of Rockville Centre, LI, and Alfred R. Oxenfeldt of New York, was married yesterday in the Park Lane to Dr. Martin Bruce Camins, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hyman Camins of Highland Park, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Reuven Siegel.

title: Miss Morse Golf Victor
description: HONOLULU, June 19 (UPI)Cathy Morse of Miami, despite doublebogeying the 18th hole, captured the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women's golf title by two shots with a fourround total of 299 yesterday.

title: Youth Soccer Teams Giving Cosmos Fans an Extra Boot
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, June 19It is possible that scoring the goahead goal in Rockville Centre's 3to1 victory over the Glen Rock Rascals at Giants Stadium here today was not the most exciting moment in John Lamstein's life. It is also possible that the sun will not rise today or that birds will forget to sing.

title: LongDistance Runners Crowd Suburban Streets
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 19When Phyllis Wachtel tried to return to her Scarsdale home after a trip to the bakery this morning, she discovered she couldn't get back on her block.

title: LEGISLATURE FACES THREAT OF A STRIKE
description: TRENTON, June 19  After a recess of nearly a month, the New Jersey Legislature returns to work tomorrow to face a possible strike by state employees and to debate a controversial energy proposal.

title: Jazz: In the Spirit of the Duke's Men
description: Since 1961, the Duke Ellington Society has been giving an annual concert of the Duke's music, played by onetime members of the Ellington band and nonEllingtonians who play in the spirit of the Duke's men. Over the years, the musical colors, the solos and the arrangements of the Ellington repertory have been recreated at these concerts.

title: Tuning In on Public Broadcasting
description: If the future problems of public broadcasting can be glimpsed in its present problems, the new Carnegie Commission on the subject should have no trouble filling an agenda. Public television's quest for money has forced it to an escalating schedule of fundraisers which rivals the commercials of other stations in nuisance value. The contest over primacy in national programming continues between the Corporation for Public Broadcastingwhich distributes tax money for new productionsand the Public Broadcasting Service, which distributes programs around the country. The dependence on imports, particularly from Great Britain, raises the question of why America's broadcasters do not produce more impressive programming of their own.

title: Philadelphia Youth Recalls Cure
description: ROME, June 10 (AP)When he finally announced that Bishop Neumann was now St. John Neumann, it gave me the chills inside, said Michael Flanigan, 20, of Philadelphia.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1977

title: Chess:
description: Perhaps the most curious result of the quarterfinal candidates matches was the 65 victory of Lev Polugaevsky of the Soviet Union over Henrique Mecking of Brazil in Lucerne. Polugaevsky won only one game while drawing 11.

title: John F. Morse, First Director Of Defense Student Loan Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 19John Frisby Morse, a teacher and educational administrator, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

description: The New York Times/Fred R. Conred

title: Britain Seizes 4 in Hawk Theft
description: LONDON, June 19 (Reuters)Detectives today questioned four men suspected of offering a wealthy Arab a stolen hunting falcon worth about $3,400. Peregrine falcons are protected by law in Britain.

title: Rug Concert Pianist, a Minor, Gets a Major Franck Ovation
description: Most of the audience at the New York Philharmonic's Rug Concert Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall jumped up from their foam rubber cushions after Franck's Symphonic Variations to give the piano soloist, Ken Noda. a standing ovation. This was partly because Mr. Noda had played the tricky piece with considerable aplomb and dexterity, but also because he is only 14 years old.

title: OS FUNDS TO ALLOW POLICE TO HIRE 1,000
description: About 750 New York City police officers now holding desk and support jobs will soon be shifted to active lawenforcement duties as a result of the scheduled hiring of 1,000 civilian employees with Federal funds.

title: Conference on Demilitarization Of Mediterranean Set to Open
description: VALLETTA, Malta, June 19 (Reuters)Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta will open an international conference here.. tomorrow that'has as one of its major themes the elimination of all foreign military bases and fleets in the Mediterranean area.

title: Israelis Deny Charges
description: LONDON, Monday, June 20 (Reuters)The Israeli Embassy issued a strongly worded denial today of allegations made yesterday by the Sunday Times of London that Israel routinely mistreats and ofte4 tortures Arab prisoners.

title: Victoria Erin Towns Bride of Law Student
description: Victoria Erin Towns, a staff writer with House Beautiful magazine, and Alan Harris Kupferberg, a student at the Brooklyn Law School, were marries yesterdav in the Tillman Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, the chaplain, officiated.

title: Arkansas Church to Go Into Court In Custody Fight With Parents of 4
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., June 19The Tony and Susan Alamo Christian Foundation, a fundamentalist church, will go before th Arkansas Supreme Court tomorrow to seek a writ of protection for four adult members whose parents want them removed from the influence of the church.

title: S.E.C. Is Failing to Curb Utilities Under 1935 Law, G.A.O. Finds
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission allows utilities to operate everything from a pistachio nut farm to real estate operations, despite a law designed to keep them out of unrelated lines of business, congressional investigators reported today.

title: Laffite Drives to First Grand Prix Victory
description: ANDERSTORP, Sweden, June 19 (AP) Jacques Laffite scored his first victory in the serves fcr the allFrench LigierMatra team in the Swedish Grand Prix today. He triumphed in a dramatic finish when Mario Andretti, the leader, was forced into the pits for gas withonly three laps to go.

title: BEAME PANEL SAYS STATE WASTE COSTS MILLIONS IN MEDICAID
description: Shortcomings in the state's administration of Medicaid are adding $400 million a year to the cost of the program in New York City, a special mayoral panel asserted yesterday.

title: Mathias to Seek Health Agency
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, said today that he would try to break up the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and establish a separate Cabinet position to take care of health matters. In a speech prepared for delivery before the Shriners in Philadelphia, Mr. Mathias said that a separate health department was needed because health policies had bogged down in the bureaucratic morass of a gargantuan, unmanageable Department of Health, Education and Welfare in which health has taken the back seat.

title: NBC Computer Errs, Plays Strike It Rich
description: ORANGE, N.J., June 19 (UPI)Assemblyman Richard J. Codey, Democrat of Orange, received a $10,700 check from the National Broadcasting Company this weekend, apparently mailed as a result of a computer error.

title: Genetic Decoders Plumbing Deepest Secrets of Life
description: CAMBRIDGE, EnglandUsing a new arsenal of chemical manipulations, scientists here and in several other laboratories are reading with increasing rapidity the genetic messages that control all life processes of an organism, from its orinins until its death.

title: Jersey Residents Let Off Steam at Town Meetings
description: PASSAIC, June 19Residents of this city and 42 other communities in New Jersey gave vent to their emotions yesterday in oldfashioned town meetings that served as outlets for criticism of local government, neighbors and the Establishment.

title: GEORGE HUTT
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP)George Hutt, 48 years old, a member of the City Board of Education for 12 years, died yesterday at his west Philadelphia home, apparently of a heart attack. Mr. Hutt became involved in the school system in 1962 when his daughter was denied admission to a west Philadelphia school because she was black. He was named to the school board three years later and was reappointed twice.

title: Breedermania
description: PRINCETON, N.J.The Carter Administration has underscored its concerns about the spread of nuclear weapons by deferring indefinitely in the United States all civilian nuclear power activities aimed at the commercialization of a plutonium economy. Specifically, the President has moved to halt the Clinch River Breeder Reactor Demonstration Proiect.

title: Manila Holds 4 as Murderers Of a Son of a Critic of Marcos
description: MANILA, June 19 (Reuters)  The Philippines police said today that four men had been arrested for the murder of 15yearold Luis Manuel Mijares, son of one of President Ferdinand Marcos's severest critics;

description: To the Editor:

title: Bishop Devoted His Life to Poor and Church
description: Legend has it that when John Nepomucene Neumann arrived in New York from Bohemia in 1836, he had a dollar in his pocket and one hopeto be ordained.

title: Pamela Wallis Is Married
description: In Hampshire House at noon yesterday, Pamela Carrie Wallis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Wallis of Skokie, Ill., became the bride of Richard Lowell Gelfand, son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Harold Gelfand of NeW York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Haskell Lookstein. The couple are 1975 graduates of the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Gelfand iS a student at the Georgetown University Medical School.

title: Capt. Paul Legunn Marries Capt. Karen Schulsinger on L.I.
description: Capt. Karen Schulsinger and Capt. Paul Legunn, both Dental Corps, U.S.A.R., were married yesterday afternoon at the Bellerose Jewish Center in Floral Park, Li., by Rabbi Alvin M. Poplack.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Geoffrey B. Moore, director of businesscycle research at the National Bureau of Economic Research and former United States Commissioner of Labor Statistics, thinks most economists are being too optimistic about the trend of inflation. The

title: 100 Animals Saved At Shelter in Y onkers
description: An overwhelming response to an appeal by the Yonkers Animal Shelter has saved the lives of at least a hundred dogs and cats at the facility.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: Week ended June 17, 1977

title: Hughes Relatives Reported Agreed on Dividing Estate
description: Beset by rival claimants, relatives of Howard R. Hughes have agreed out of court to compose their differences over their shares of the late industrialist's fortune, it was reported yesterday.

title: Moving Into Summer's Tempo
description: We call it the summer solstice. The earth begins swing back on its pivot and we have the longest daylight of the year. Solstice, and summer, and beedrone in the clover; field corn reaching for the sun; fledglings out of the nest. The vast green world settling down into the warm reality of growth, into summer's tempo.

title: Aide of Bhutto Says Pakistan Will Hold Elections in October
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, June 19 (Reuters)Finance Minister Abdul Hafeez Pirzada, a close confidant of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. has said here that the elections agreed to by the Prime Minister and opposition leaders would be held in Pakistan in the first week of October.

title: Andrus Investigates Resource Issues on Busy Coast Tour
description: LOS ANGELES, June 19A young man who had trudged eight miles into the redwood wilderness this week, seeking solitude, was jolted when he came upon 30 people hanging on the words of tall thin man who used to plug Idaho potatoes on television.

title: Havana Declines to Issue Visas For Employees of News Service
description: CHICAGO, June 19 (UPI)The Cubai Government today declined to issue visas to two United Press International repre sentatives who had planned to visit Cuba this week with a group of businessmes from the Midwest.

title: ESKIMOS ASK UNIFORMITY ON ARCTIC OILGAS RULES
description: BARROW, Alaska, June 19 (AP)Eskimos from three nations have called on all governments to establish uniform rules for offshore oil and gas development throughout the Arctic.

title: Tanana of Angels Stops Brewers for 11th Victory, 6th Shutout
description: Frank Tanana was a 15yearold high school student in Detroit in 1968 when Denny McLain won his 31 games for the Tigers. Now, almost nine years later, Tanana, also is on a 30game victory course. The California Angels 6foot3inch lefthander. took another step in that direction yesterday blanking the Brewers, 7.0, at Milwaukee County Stadium.

title: Ingenious Chemical Techniques for Reading
description: CAMBRIDGE, EnglandThe methods developed in the past year or two for rapid reading of the thousands of message units, or nucleotides, in the code of life are masterpieces of chemical ingenuity.

title: MMERRAND'S PARTY RALLIES BEHIND HIM
description: NANTES, France, June 19  Showing full confidence that he will be governing France next year, Frangois Mitterrand won renewed backing from his Socialist Party here today, but the support from its left wing was reserved.

title: Sandlot Soccer Teams Provide the Preliminary Kicks for Cosmos Fans
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 19It is possible that scoring the goahead goal in Rockville Centre's 3to1 victory over the Glen Rock (N.J.) Rascals at Giants Stadium here today was not the most exciting moment in John Lamstein's life. It is also possible that the sun will not rise tomorrow or that birds will forget to sing.

title: A Janitor Who Dreamed That His Daughters Would Be Doctors
description: LONG BRANCH, NJ., June 19This is a Father's Day story about Donald Thornton and his daughters, the doctors.

James Devine performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Mary Queen of Heaven Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, where both families live.

Graduate School of Business Administration, were married at noon yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Spevak performed the ceremony'at the Electchester Jewish Center in Flushing, Queens.
