description: Steve Siegel, the stocky little pro from Teaneck, N.J., who has played on clay courts from here to Florida in his long career, won the New York State men's tennis championship for the first time yesterday with a 63, 61 triumph over Bob Tanis of Wayne, N.J. It was also the first time in the tournament's long history that two New Jerseyans had made the final.

title: Drought in South, Worst Since 54, Threatens Crops
description: MACON, Ga., June 19The worst drought in a quarter of a century has hit the farms of the Deep South, irreparably stunting corn and seriously endangering crops of peanuts, soybeans and hay.

title: NADJARIAND SANTUCCI IN BITTER TV MEETING
description: Maurice H. Nadjari has been guilty of many, many indiscretions and is a disgrace to the legal profession, according to John J. Santucci, the Queens District Attorney. It's Mr. Santucci who is a disgrace, Mr. Nadjari retorted.

title: VETO OF WATER PROJECTS DOUBTED BY HOUSE LEADER
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)Jim Wright, the Hbuse majority leader, said today that he expected President Carter to sign compromise bill allowing survival of number of water projects he wanted to delete. Mr. Wright said he did not expect the President to veto the legislation, as he has threatened, when it comes out of Congress.

title: Arson Damage in Italy Is Put at $15 Million
description: MILAN, Italy, June 19(AP)Gangs of arsonists disguised as policemen forced their way into two large warehouse oomplexes today and set them afire, the police said. Damage was estimated at more than $15 million.

title: Robinson as a Manager: From Ecstasy to Agony
description: Frank Robinson's career as baseball's first black managerat the moment shortlivedbegan with drama and ecstasy. He received a thunderous standing ovation when introduced before his first game on April 8, 1975. And when the Indians playing manager came to bat in the first inning against the Yankees and hit a home run, the Cleveland crowd of 56,204 stood again and roared even louder than the first time.

title: PARISHIONERS OPPOSE CHURCH'S RENOVATION
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 17Who owns a church? The parish or the parishioners? The question is at the center of a dispute that has sharply divided the Polish Town section of this community. Members of St. Isidore's Roman Catholic Church, who are opposed to extensive renovation work being done on the landmark building, have picketed their church, boycotted the collection plate and called for the resignation of the pastor. During one demonstration, two church elders were arrested.

title: Business Tax Reform in New York State A Costly, Complicated Goal, Study Finds
description: Reforming the New York State tax system to make the state more attractive to business and businessmen will be more costly, complicated and politically difficult than has been assumed by many public and private sector leaders, according to a new study made for Governor Carey.

title: Coast Exchange Has National Plans
description: LOS ANGELESIf and when a national market system for trading secuiitles goes into operation, among the beneficiaries will be the regional stock exchanges that now compete relatively unsuccessfully with the New York Stock Exchange for a share of the action.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Rock: A MusicImage Confusion
description: The relationship of rock music and the rock musician's imagethe personality and stance he wishes to projectused to be reasonably clearcut. The Beatles looked shaggy but clean and they played that way. The Rolling Stones were shaggy and not so clean and their music reflected the difference. At present, these correspondences have broken down completely, and no acceptable system has taken their place. Las Vegas crooners dress like 1960's hippies, hard rockers emulate the Marlon Brando of the 1950's, onetime white blues singers appear in tuxedos, and so it goes.

title: Bishop Neumann Canonized; First Male Saint From U.S.
description: ROME, June 19Pope Paul VI today declared Bishop John Nepomucene Neuthann of Philadelphia a saint today in a solemn highmass watched by a huge crowd in blinding sunshine on St. Peter's Square.

title: Space Shuttle Test Set June 28
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 19 (UPI)Engineers attempted today to eliminate some problems that occurred in the first manned piggyback test flight of the space shuttle yesterday and announced that the second of four tests would be held June 28. The shuttle and orbiter craft, the first space craft designed to be used more than once, is to begin operations in the 1980's.

title: Carter Replies to Pravda Charge
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)President Carter responded sharply today to charge by the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda that his support for human rights was a coverup for an American arms buildup, and the President said his campaign was an embarrassment to the Soviet Union.

title: METHADONE RULING TO SAVE NEW YORK $50 MILLION
description: New York City has won a decision by the state Court of Appeals that averts payments by the city of more than $50 million in potential increases in Medicaid reimbursement for private methadone maintenance clinics retroactive to the start of 1973.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Economists
description: The United States economy will continue a balanced, healthy growth through this year and next, according to a 12member panel of distinguished economists and business analysts set up for the midyear economic forum of the Conference Board.

title: Arizona State Gains Title In College World Series
description: OMAHA, June 19 (UPI)The Arizona State Sun Devils took the championship of the college world series last. night with a 21 victory over South Carolina. thanks to a home run by Chris Bando and the pitching of Jerry Vasquez.

title: Judicial Study Finds 250 Judges Involved In Fixing of Tickets
description: A widespread pattern of ticketfixing by New York State judges has been uncovered by the Commission of Judicial Conduct.

title: In Memoriam
description: KATZIsaac, 1913.1937. And the tear that wo shod, though In secret it rolls, Shall long keep his memory green In our souls.

title: Bank Lag Said to Hinder S.E.C.'s New York Probe
description: WASHINGTON, June 19A 17month investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into possible fraud surrounding New York City's financial crisis has been delayed because the S.E.C. has had difficulties in obtaining detailed information from some of the banks that bought and sold city securities as the crisis developed, according to sources close to the investigation.

title: U.S. INQUIRY IS BEGUN ON ARSON IN BRONX
description: A Federal grand jury has begun an investigation into possible arson for fraud in the Bronx, where in recent years entire neighborhoods have been ravaged by fires, first in the South Bronx and more recently in the West Bronx.

title: Turner Sails Courageous To 2 Cup Trial Victories
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 19Ted Turner's reintroduction to America's Cup yachting was a smashing success today as he sailed Courageous, the old 12Meter boat, to two victories over the new one, Enterprise. Turner did it the hard way both times by sailing Courageous from behind and through Enterprise on weather legs, meaning beats to windward. That's hard to do in match racing, one yacht against another.

title: College World Series
description: AT OMAHA

title: Israeli Torture of Arab Prisoners Reported by London Sunday Times
description: LONDON, June 19The Sunday Times of London published today detailed allegations of mistreatment and torture by Israelis of Arab prisoners from the Gaza area and the West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: ANGOLAARMYBRIGADE JOINED MAY UPRISING
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 19Despite tight news blackout imposed by the Angolan Government, it is becoming evident that an attempted coup in Luanda last month was a serious uprising that involved army units, left many dead and sharply rocked the precarious unity of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.

title: Chagall And Art: A 'Homage'
description: As the world's most renowned living artist, Marc Chagall, who will be 90 on July 7, is proof that Hippocrates wasn't precise in observing that "life is short and art is long." And Harry Rasky, the Canadian writer-producer-director of "Homage to ChagallThe Colours of Love," which had its premiere yesterday at the Little Carnegie, is lovingly true to his title in projecting a fairly justifiable admiration of the now legendary man and his immense artistic output.If he ignores critical apathy toward some of Chagall's later work, his unabashed "Homage" is, perhaps, more of a tribute to the range and detail captured by the color camera eye, and often poetic dialogue, than it is to extensive analysis or all-inclusive biography.But as a dedicated professional known for such documentaries as "Tennessee Williams' South" and "The Wit and World of G. Bernard Shaw," Mr. Rasky, with the aid of appreciative narration by James Mason and Joseph Wiseman, portrays Chagall as an all-too-human figure, as memorably lively and colorful as some of his noted spirited, if mystical, paintings.Tracing Chagall's life through his art from Czarist Vitebsk, where he was born, to his present, flower-filled sanctuary in Provence's sunlit St. Paul de Vence, makes for a color-drenched odyssey that obviously includes a good deal more than the "Fiddler on the Roof" or the Metropolitan Opera's immense "Sources" and "Triumph of Music" murals that most easily come to mind.The succession of dream-world-like paintings teeming with Vitebsk Jewish elders, roosters, donkeys and levitated lovers featuring Bella Rosenfeld, his late first wife, who often served as his model, are minutely inspected and annotated. But this happy, post-1910 Parisian period is balanced by the likes of the fairly moody "L'Exode," which reflects his shock and sorrow for Jewish persecution in his figure of Christ on the cross dominating masses of Jews.There are, of course, a variety of paintings, murals and mosaics on religious and other themes stretching from the United Nations Building stained glass windows to the museums in Jerusalem and Nice and Chagall's own garden in St. Paul. But these, and notably the close-up views of his paintings on the ceiling of the Paris Opra, are a credit to photographic expertise. More important, from a moviegoers' view, is the fact that the white-haired but robust Chagall is engagingly wise, natural and unassuming in seemingly unrehearsed, carefully considered answers translated from the French by his wife, Vava, the former Valentine Brodsky whom he married in 1952. They are, it is also more obvious on film than in words, both a serenely contented couple and in love.The recently closed exhibition of some of Chagall's finest paintings at the Pierre Matisse Gallery here deserved the praise it received. And, although this "Homage," which was televised in Canada on March 30, may be specialized biography stemming from Chagall's autobiography, the Bible and other sources, it is an affectionate and visually beautiful celebration of both the man and his art painted with what Andr Malraux termed "the colours of love."

title: Red Sox Hit 5 Homers, Set 3Game Record of 16
description: BOSTON, June 19The Yankees restored a semblance of harmony to their dugout today, but the Red Sox shattered the peace on the field, handing New York yet another Fenway Park trouncing, this time by a score of 111.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HAIL, HAIL As small as it is92 acresBryant Park has a goodsized history. The park behind the New York Public Library dates to 1822 when it served as a Potter's Field. By 1853 the park had evolved sufficiently to be the site of the World's Fair. A Crystal Palace, reproduction of the London structure, was erected for the fair and stood on the site until it spectacularly burned down in 1856.

description: Professor Lee J Seidler of New York University was named over the weekend to succeed the late Manuel F. Cohen as chairman of the Commission on Auditors Responsibilities, it was announced yesterday. Prof. Seidler had been deputy chairman.

description: A widespread pattern of ticketfixing by New York State judges has been uncovered by the Commission of Judicial Conduct.

Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

title: Burt Reynolds Will Direct and Act in The End
description: Burt Reynolds, who made his debut as an actordirector last year with the contemporary adventure, Gator, will repeat that dual assignment in The End, a comedy written by Jerry Belson, in which Joanne Woodward will costar with Mr. Reynolds.

description: ROME, June 19Pope Paul VI today declared Bishop John Nepomucene Neumann of Philadelphia a saint today in a solemn high mass watched by a huge crowd in blinding sunshine on St. Peter's Square.

title: SHARP U.S. DEBT CUT SPURS RATE DECLINE
description: The United States Treasury, which had expected to pay off about $2 billion of the national debt during the three months ending June 30, will end up reducing the debt by some S7 billion, credit market analysts now predict. More than St billion will be paid off this week alone.

title: Wimbledon Warmup: Miss Austin Is Star
description: LONDON, June 19It is all new to Tracy Austin. Meeting Arthur Ashe and Ilie Nastase for the first time. Being interviewed on the BBC. Wearing jewelry on the tennis court, just like all the other girls.

title: Silver Series Victor in Ohio
description: NORTH RANDALL, Ohio, June 19 (UPI)Silver Series romped to a 4length victory today in the 43d running of the Ohio Derby at Thistledown Race Track.

title: Carter's Education Chief Urges More Variety
description: WASHINGTON. June 17Development of more flexibility in American high schools will be a major educational priority of the Carter Administration according to Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, the new Commissioner of Education.

title: Ellen Schwartz, Lawyer, Wed to Edward M. Spiro
description: Ellen Kay Schwartz, daughter of Shirley Dinitz and the late Murray Schwartz, was married yesterday to Edward Mark Spiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Spiro of the Bronx. The ceremony was performed in the Central Synagogue by Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman.

title: Forest Fire Checked at Los Alamos
description: LOS ALAMOS, N.M., June 19 (AP)Firefighters held a line on the north side of a 10,000acre blaze late today, apparently ending the threat to the research center where America's first atomic bomb was developed.

title: Israel Cancels Visit by Chilean Ship
description: TEL AVIV, June 19 (Reuters)Israel today cancelled the official visit here of a Chilean navy training vessel, the Esmeralda, because it served as a political prison and people now living in Israel were tortured on it, it was officially announced here. The woodenhulled, sailing ship will; however, be able to get supplies, fuel and other harbor services it calls here next Tuesday as planned.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: YONKERS POLICE HEAR APPLAUSE AND JEERS
description: YONKERS, June 19As two patrolmen walked past a housing development for the elderly here today, a group of residents who were sunning themselves, rose and broke into applause.

title: Battle for Evictions at Coast Hotel Is Delayed as Court Studies Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 19A temporary truce has eased the tension between residents who defied an eviction order by barricading themselves in their downtown hotel last week and the authorities who were ordered to carry out the eviction.

title: Spain's Vote: Socialist Feat
description: MADRID, June 19Though Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez's centerright coalition emerged with the largest number of seats in last week's election, the more significant victor may have been the resurgent Spanish Socialist Workers Party, which finished a strong second. One can say that AdolNews fo Suarez won the race, but Analysis the real winner of the day was Felipe Gonzalez, said the liberal Madrid daily El Pais, referring to the Socialists 35yearold first secretary.

description: The entry fee for the lowtar cigarette derby is soaring.

title: Green Triumphs in the U.S. Open
description: Hubert Green won the United States Open golf championship by one stroke yesterday in Tulsa, Okla. He shot a 70, even par, on the last round for a 72hole total of 278. Lou Graham was second, and Tom Weiskopf was third with 281. Green's victory gave him the first major championship of his sevenyear career.

title: Esther Davidowitz Bride
description: The marriage of Esther Davidowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lipot Davidowitz of Fresh Meadows, Queens, to Mitchell Stephens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Stephens of Albertson, L.I., took place yesterday at the Westbury Hebrew Congregation in Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Melvin Kieffer officiated. The bride is feature editor of The Westsider and The Chelsea Clinton News.

title: New Director Says Royal Ballet Will Not Become Ballet Morrice
description: LONDONNorman Monica, the new director of the Royal Ballet, is virtually unknown in New York, though he studied modern dance there, had some of his works performed there by Israel's Batsheva Company, and scored a success at Jacob's Pillow with The Two Brothers, his very first ballet.

title: Queens Principal Who Defied School Board Will Chastise It in His Valedictory
description: The walls were covered with newspaper clippings from all over the country telling about the New York City high school principal's war with the Board of Education on the issue of student discipline.

title: Kathe Weschler Wed to Thomas Rafferty
description: Kathe Mary Weschler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Frederic Weschler of Erie, Pa., was married yesterday at her parents home to Thomas Francis Rafferty of St. Louis. where he is chairman of Venture Stores Inc., the discount division of the May Department Stores Company. Judge Edward H. Carney of the Court of Common Pleas of Erie County performed the ceremony in the presence of the immediate families.

title: Japanese Bidding for U.S. Market In. Basic Semiconductor Circuitry
description: DALLAS, June 19Japan's electronics industry is driving toward capturing a significant share of markets in the ultraminiature semiconductor circuitry that is basic to the worldwide proliferation of computers. American industry experts agree.

title: Genetic Decoders Plumbing Deepest Secrets of Life
description: CAMBRIDGE, EnglandUsing a new arsenal of chemical manipulations, scientists here and in several other laboratories are reading with increasing rapidity the genetic messages that control all life processes of an organism, from its origins until its death.

title: World News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 19 (UPI)Tear gas was used by the police today to break up groups of black youths who were, stoning cars and buses in Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg.

title: Judy Rankin Wins By 2 Shots on 212
description: NOBLESVILLE, Ind., June 19 (AP)Judy Rankin overcame a double bogey on her first hole today and won Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament for the 23d time in a 15year career with a fourunderpar 212 at the 6,044yard Harbor Trees Golf Club.

title: U.S. INQUIRY IS BEGUN ON ARSON IN BRONX
description: A Federal grand jury has begun an investigation into possible arson for fraud in the Bronx, where in recent years entire neighborhoods have been ravaged by fires, first in the South Bronx and more recently in the West Bronx.

title: Desai Wants Return to Government for the People
description: NEW DELHI, June 16An American resident of India, calling on a government official whom he sees regularly, was surprised to discover the other afternoon that he was no longer required to stop at the desk in the lobby, fill out a form, and then be escorted down the corridor by a guard.

title: Bomb Blast in Car Injures Man In Hispanic Section of Chicago
description: CHICAGO, June 19 (UPI)  A bomb explosion today injured one man in the largely Hispanic Humboldt Park area, the scene of riots that left three dead and hundreds injured two weeks ago. Policemen investigating the blast reported that they were increasing patrols in the area.

title: Army Presses Efforts to Ease Tensions Between Whites and Blacks
description: FORT BRAGG, N.C.The United States Army, with a growing proportion of blacks 1n its ranks, is quietly struggling to blunt racial tensions.

title: Market Place
description: Investors, vexed by public hearings last week concerning the Federal National Mortgage Association, are wondering whether shares of this company can advance as long as Washington attempts to put additional members to be appointed by the President on the board of directors.

title: Bergen Project Coaches Womento Compete for Jobs
description: HACKENSACK, June 19  A pilot project has begun in Bergen County for women who are either bored with their jobs and want to earn more money, or are eager to reenter the job market now that their children are grown.

title: Soviet Union Terms Rights Drive By U.S. Pretext for Arms Buildup
description: MOSCOW, June 19 (AP)The Soviet Union accused the United States today of preparing for a new dangerous spiral in the arms race under the pretext of protecting the West and guaranteeing human rights around the world.

title: Survey Finds a Black Majority Prefers to Attend Black College
description: The United Negro College Fund said yesterday it had conducted a survey that showed a majority of black students prelerred to attend predominantly black colleges.

title: ARAB GROUP CLEARS WESTINGHOUSE AND G. M. ON BLACKLIST
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, June 19 (AP)The General Motors Corporation and the Westinghouse Electric Company, two American business giants threatened with being blacklisted by Arab states, have been cleared after submitting proof they have no dealings with Israel, Arab boycott officials said today.

title: Rosalie Scott Day, Teacher. Bride of Dr. John B. Hughes
description: Rosalie Scott Day, daughter of Mrs. Francis P. Day of Plainfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Day, was married yesterday to Dr. John B. Hughes, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Hughes of Haverford, Pa.

title: BODY OF GIRL, 15, FOUND ALONG JERSEY HIGHWAY
description: HARDING TOWNSHIP, N.J., June 19 (AP)A nude body found along Route 287 here has been identified as a teenage girl who, along with a friend, had been missing since June 12, the police aid today.

title: BEAN PANEL SAYS STATE WASTE COSTS MILLIONS IN MEDICAID
description: Shortcomings in the state's administration of Medicaid are adding $400 million a year to the cost of the program in New York City, a special mayoral panel asserted yesterday.

title: Wendy N. Jacobson Bride of Tom A. Bernstein
description: Wendy Nan Jacobson. daughter of Beverly Jacobson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Julius H. Jacobson of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Tom A. Bernstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bernstein of Scarsdale and New York

title: EXLEADER OF NEPAL WON'T REMAIN IN N.Y
description: A longdetained former Prime Minister of Nepal. released to get medical care in New York, says he will return home even though he faces arrest, trial and a possible death sentence.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Opening
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 19The new legislation granting $11.5 million in tax relief to the harness industry and offering benefits to thoroughbred owners will begin aiding Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night when the track opens its 18night summer meeting.

title: Albany's Unfinished Business
description: Governor Carey knows as well as the rest of us that only two weeks remain in the 1977 legislative session, and the pressure seems to be causing the executive branch to settle for unworkable compromises on some proposed laws and to give up entirely on others.

title: Swinging Hal, Blue Times Score at Suffolk
description: BOSTON, June 19 (UPI)Swinging Hal, a 14.1 shot ridden by Steve Pagano, led all the way and posted a fourlength victory today in the second division of the $143,000 Massachusetts Handitzp at Suffolk Downs.

title: Rise in Convictions Is Reported After Rape Center Is Established
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI)  An unexpected result of a federally sponsored center for rape victims has been the arrest and conviction of more suspects, the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration reported today.

title: Vesper Women Take EightOared Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 19The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia completed the 1,000meter Schuylkill course today in 3 minutes 15.S seconds to regain the open eightoared crew title at the end of the fourday national women's rowing championships.

title: Books of The Times
description: So let us propose discussion of the idea that a new art, with its own rules, is being generated in the 20th century,says E. L. Doctorow in his introduction to The Crowned Cannibals: the Lieder of victims of the state. It sings of regimes so repressive as to be funhouse mirror images of civilization. It recounts years of solitary confinement. It tells of pliers for pulling fingernails, it speaks of electric currents sent Into sexual organs, it describes prison cells in which person can neither stand up nor lie down. True, this is a necessarily small range of subject. There is a limit to the possibilities of metaphor. The subtext has to do with the degrees of death in life. But within these strictures the poet is entitled to sing with his or her own voice.

title: Cornell Professor Is Named as Assassinations Panel Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, June 20G. Robert Blakey, a professor at Cornell University Law School who is a proponent of the use of wiretapping In the control of organized crime, was named today to be chief counsel and staff director of the House Select Committee on Assassination.

title: Summary of Decisions on Constitutional Issues by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: World News Briefs
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, June 20 (AP) The Organization of American States unanimously approved a resolution today asking its permanent council to seek new ways for hemipheric cooperation to combat terrorism.

title: It Takes an Expert to Regulate Utilities
description: Governor Carey should have looked farther than Peter Peyser in choosing a chairman for the New York Public Service Commission. Mr. Peyser served ably as a Westchester Representative in Congress and there is nothing objectionable in his general views on questions facing the commission. But his appointment raises anew the question of whether a chairman without training in regulatory law or economics will be able to maintain the commission's special position as the country's foremost state utility authority.

title: Advertising
description: The directors of BBDO International yesterday elected Bruce Crawford, the 48yearold president, the chief executive officer. He replaced Tom Dillon, 62, who had held that title for a decade. Mr. Dillon, who continues as chairman, is still chief executive of the domestic company, Batten, Barton Durstine & Osborn.

title: Topics
description: FEDERAL JUDGESHIPS The death of Justice Tom C. Clark, who was in New York working as a senior judge to help carry the heavy Federal caseload (as he had done around the country since his retirement ten years ago) again calls attention to the need for more Adges. A bill already passed by the Senate would create 113 new Federal district judgeships and 35 new circuit court judgeships. Chief Justice Burger has said that without the help of the 130 senior judges working past retirement, the Federal judicial system would collapse. The Judicial Conference calculates that since 1970, when the last set of new judgeships was created, the caseload per judge has risen from 277 to 400. That makes a House subcommittee's deletion from the bill of one circuit and 32 district court judgeships incomprehensible. The Judiciary Committee should correct the error.

title: Weekend Baseball Games Average 28,260 Fans
description: Major league baseball games from last Friday to Sunday drew a total of 1,073,882 fans, an average of 28,260 fans for each of the 38 dates, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office announced yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: On the basis of an inaccurate news release, it was incorrectly reported in yesterday's editions of The Times that Prof. Lee J. Seidler will succeed the late Manuel F. Cohen as chairman of the Commission on Auditors' Responsibilities. The chairmanship will remain. vacant. Professor Seidler will preside as deputy chairman over the commission's public hearings beginning today in Washington.

title: Recital: English Pianist in Debut
description: David Ward is an English pianist who has specailized in the music of Mozart. In making his New York debut on Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, he fell back on his favorite composer with an allMozart program. If this was natural, it was also a risk: attitudes toward the performance of the Mozart repertory can be firm, and Mr. Ward was not telling anything about himself as a musician and pianist except how he played Mozart.

title: A Deal for Whales
description: Once more the whale, the grandest of all mammals, stands trial for its life. The International Whaling Commission meets this week in Canberra for its annual wrangle over how many of each specie of whale may be killed and in which waters. Slow progress has been made at these affairs to protect the whale, but its future is still as misty as spray from a blowhole.

title: About New York
description: The sense of freedom now is in going the wrong way, in going back out on the water from Manhattan over to Ellis Island, where the cavernous immigration buildings stand turreted and tired as an old amusement park.

title: OperatorsThreatentoShut 66 Homes for the Elderly In Dispute Over Payments
description: The operators of 66 oldage homes in New York City and Nassau County threatened yesterday to close the homes on July 1 because state officials had failed to meet with them on proposals for increased reimbursement for residents in the Supplemental Security Income program.

title: RhythmandBlues Revivalism Comes in 2 Styles at Bottom Line
description: Two sorts of rhythmandblues revivalism were on display Sunday at the Bottom Line, with a double bill of Frankie Miller's Full House and the reformed Booker T. and the MGs. Unfortunately neither half of the bill lived up to the highest standards of the revival.

title: NBC to Televise Junior Olympic Finals
description: LINCOLN, Neb., June 20 (AP)NBC will televise some of the championship events of the Amateur Athletic Union, Junior Olympics, to be held here Aug. 13 and 14.

title: New York Legislature Starts Struggle to Adjourn
description: ALBANY, June 20The New York Legislature started what its leaders de; scribed as a final push toward adjournment today but immediately became bogged down in partisan differences that held off action on major matters.

title: Notes on People
description: According to Margaret Trudeau, that short cocktail dress she wore at a formal White House dinner, thereby setting some tongues clacking was actually chosen for the occasion by her husband, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada. In an interview in the July issue of the Ladies' Home Journal Mrs. Trudeau, now separated from her husband, said President Carter didn't frown at me and Pierre had picked out the dress to start with.

title: BEGIN TAKES OFFICE AFTER 8HOUR DEBATE
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 21Declaring that the prevention of another war in the Middle East was his primary concern, Menahem Begin, leader of the rightwing Likud bloc, early this morning became Israel's sixth Prime Minister.

title: MAN CONVICTED IN DEATHS OF 2 TO GET A NEW TRIAL
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday cleared the way for a new trial for a man convicted in New York of murdering two brothers during a robbery in 1968. The court ruled that the trial judge erred by not allowing the defense to call a witness who had previously confessed to the murders.

title: Bottle of Wine Brings $3,816
description: LONDON (UPI)  Vintage Imports, a Miamibased wine company, paid $3,816 at Christie's wine auction Thursday to import a single bottle of 1929 vintage Chateau Mouton Rothschild wine.

title: ASSEMBLY IN ALBANY VOTES NOFAULT BILL
description: ALBANY, June 20After narrowly defeating an amendment that would have rolled automobile insurance rates back to January levels and frozen them for a year, the Assembly tonight reluctantly approved Governor Carey's proposed revisions to the state's nofault law.

title: New Ways to Save Energy
description: In 1975, threequarters of our energy demand was met by oil and gas resources that will soon be too scarce to serve as the backbone of our energy supply system. The United States Energy Research and Development Administration has been spending billions of dollars to investigate alternative technologies which may be common by the end of the century.

title: Spring Goes Out With a Yawn, Ushering In Lazy Days of Summer
Dollar Up Slightly Against Yen
description: TOKYO, June 20 (AP)The dollar gained slightly against the Japanese yen today closing at 272,775 yen, up from 272.475 yen last Friday.

title: Italy Seeks to Widen Police Powers
description: ROME, June 20With violence increasing, the Italian Government is moving to restrict the rights of suspects by proposing that the police be allowed to question them without the presence of their lawyers.

title: Plan to Halt Whaling for 10 Years Opposed by Soviet Union and Japan
description: CANBERRA, Australia, June 20 (Reuters)Japan and the Soviet Union. whose fleets together account for 75 percent of the whales killed each year. today opposed calls for a 10year moratorium on whaling.

title: France's Aged Musketeers Join Wimbledon Celebration
description: LONDON, June 20Fifty years after they brought the Davis Cup to France for the first time with a victory over the United States; the Four Musketeers are well and as spirited as ever. They attended the 100th Wimbeldon celebration today as a block.

title: Market Place
description: A short while ago, George Willett, a spry 85yearold millionaire with 60 years of investing experience, made an offhand estimate of his stock portfolio.

title: Pope Asks U.S. Bishops to Follow Neumann's Moral Example
description: ROME, June 20 (AP)Pope Paul VI urged bishops from the United States today to follow the example of their country's first male saintJohn Nepomucene Neumannand carry out with ever greater energy their teaching mission, especially in sexual morality.

title: People and Business
description: The Rev. Leon Sullivan, minister of the Zion Baptist Church in North Philadelphia, disclosed yesterday that 21 more United States companies operating in South Africa had endorsed six principles aimed to end segregation and to promote fair employment practices for their black and nonwhite employees in South Africa.

title: Winston Lord Selected as Head Of Council on Foreign Relations
description: The directors of the Council on Foreign Relations have elected Winston Lord, a close associate of former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, as the council's new president, effective this fall when Bayless Manning retires after six years in the post.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: WASHINGTONRobert L. Herbst, the Interior Department's new Assistant Secretary for Fish and Wildlife and Parks, believes that most waterfowl hunters will accept the gradually expanding ban on lead shot with good grace and understanding.

title: Dollar Ends Mixed In Europe and Gold Gains $1 an Ounce
description: LONDON, June 20(AP)The price of gold rose by as much as $1 an ounce in European bullion markets today while the dollar closed mixed in uneventful trading.

title: Yanks Lose to Fidrych 3Hitter, 21
description: DETROIT, June 20  Just after the Yankees resolved their managerial problems here tonight, at least temporarily, they had the unenviable task of facing Mark Fidrych and the Tigers at Tiger Stadium.

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS PLAN CLOSER LINKING OF MONETARY GOALS
description: PARIS, June 20  The United States and other industrial countries are planning to cooperate more closely in monetary policy as part of their efforts to reduce inflation and restore stable economic growth, according to diplomatic sources.

title: BEGIN TAKES OFFICE AFTER 8HOUR DEBATE
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 21Declaring that the prevention of another war in the Middle East was his primary concern, Menahem Begin, leader of the rightwing Likud bloc, early this morning became Israel's sixth Prime Minister.

title: Israeli Cabinet: A New Lineup
description: JERUSALEM, June 20Following are the names of officials taking major positions in Israel's new coalition Government, led by the rightwing Likud bloc:

title: Carter Renews Call to Free Airline Rein
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  President Carter urged Congress today to reduce Government regulation of airline routes and fares, saying it would step up competition and make air travel cheaper.

title: Mexican Workers Being Admitted After Reported Carter Intervention
description: WASHINGTON, June 20After a reported personal intervention by President Carter, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has admitted Mexican workers to pick crops in southwestern Texas despite a recommendation by the Labor Department that the Mexicans be barred.

title: Bridge:
description: It is now clear that the cheating scandal that disrupted the Italian bridge scene a year ago is having a delayed reaction at the international level.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Meadowlands Results
description: Time2:02 4/5. Eracta (49) paid $169.20 ScratchedAreena Herne.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Monday.

title: Fruehauf Plans Plant
description: The Fruehauf Corporation of Detroit announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, the KelseyHayes Company, would build a new automotive wheel plant in Sedalia, Mo., with financing provided by a proposed $25 million industrial revenue bond issue. The facility is expected to produce 10 million wheels a yeas with three years of completion. A projected date for the start of production has not yet been set.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A complex Eurocurrency loan equivalent to $505 million was signed in London yesterday by a group of 20 banks with representatives of the Brazilian Steel Company, Aco Minas Gerias, and the Republic of Brazil. The loan, coordinated by Morgan, Grenfell & Company, is the largest single financing by a Brazilian borrower in the Eurocurrency market.

title: High Court Upholds Attorney General in 2 Voting Discrimination Cases
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Supreme Court decided today that rulings by the Attorney General in two kinds of voting discrimination cases are not subject to direct review in the courts.

title: Public TV Eagerly A waits Carnegie Commission Study
description: Most industries become apprehensive and resentful when independent commissions are formed to examine their activities and recommend legislation that would create change. But the public broadcasting industry has greeted with enthusiasm the news that the Carnegie Corporation of New York, with the sanction of the White House, has established a commission to study a future course for noncommercial television and radio in the age of satellite communications.

title: CORRECTION
description: On the basis of an inaccurate news release, it was incorrectly reported in yesterday's editions of The Times that Prof. Lee J. Seidler will succeed the late Manuel F. Cohen as chairman of the Commission on Auditors' Responsibilities. The chairmanship will remain vacant. Professor Seidler will preside as deputy chairman over the commission's public hearings beginning today in Washington.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS TAX AID TO BUSINESS TO SPUR FUEL SAVING
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The House Ways and Means Committee today accepted with minor modifications President Carter's proposals for business tax incentives to encourage fuel conservation and conversion away from oil and gas.

title: Democrats' Nest Egg
description: WASHINGTON  The welldressed audience of several dozen men and women, seated informally around tables in a small meeting room of one of Washington's leading hotels, listened with obvious approval as the speaker concluded the morning's proceedings.

title: COURT RULES STATES MAY DENY MEDICAID FOR SOME ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that neither the Constitution nor current Federal law requires states to spend Medicaid funds for elective abortions.

title: BLACK PANTHER SUIT DISMISSED IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, June 20The $47.7 million civil damage suit against police officers who participated in the 1969 raid on a Black Panther Party residence in which two Black Panthers were killed was dismissed today after a Federal jury was unable to reach a verdict in the case.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Fairfax M. Cone, 74, the Founder And Chairman of Ad Agency, Dies
description: Fairfax Mastick Cone, one of the country's best known advertising men, but a frequent critic of some elements of his own industry, died yesterday after a long illness in his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: The Standings
description: Tuesday, June 21, 1977

title: Confidence Expressed in London
description: LONDON, June 20Some British officials expressed confidence today that there would be something to sign before the present agreement expired.

title: Israel Will Offer Asylum to 66 Vietnamese Refugees
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 21Minutes after becoming Israel's Prime Minister, Menahem Begin said that his first official act today would be to offer asylum to 66 Vietnamese refugees.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: WASHINGTON  The two most influential tax legislators in Congress say they are becoming intrigued by the valueadded tax  a kind of national sales tax widely used in Europe  as a source of money for the ailing Social Security system.

title: Books of The Times
description: It may seem obvious to you that we have a problem with noise in contemporary civilization. But believe me, you won't understand a quarter of the problem until you have browsed, as you surely ought to, In R. Murray Schafer's The Tuning of the World, a survey of sound in the past and a passionate plea for a utopian future, by a Canadian composer who in recent years has become increasingly involved in the study of sound and the sonic environment.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSONSylvia, beloved wife of Moe, devoted mother of Francine and Bruce, dear sister of Martha Fleckner, Natalie Brack, Larry and Joseph Feldman, loved grandmother of Marshall, Jennifer, Todd, Seth and Craig. Services Tuesday, June 21. 11:45 A.M. at the Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: PRESS IS MONITORING CRIMINAL CODE BILL
description: For 10 years now, the press has watched with a wary eye the continuing Congressional efforts to enact a new Federal criminal code. The primary concern has been whether a new code would make it more difficult for reporters to cover, or uncover, the activities of government.

title: Court Approves Water Charges In Long Beach but Scores Billing
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 20A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that water rates charged by the City of Long Beach were not unreasonable, but that the manner of billing residents for water and sewage service was illegal.

title: Brzezinski's View Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)A reporter today asked Zbigniew Brzezinski head of the National Security Council, what he knew of President Amin's whereabouts. Silently, Mr. Brzezinski made a sign of a cross.

title: Assembly Approves $14.3 Million For State Employee Pay Increases
description: TRENTON, June 20The State Assembly approved today the restoration of $14.3 million in automatic raises for some 30,000 state employees, thereby easing the threat of a July 1 strike. The Senate earlier had approved a similar measure.

title: Patient Is Given Heart Of a Baboon but Dies
description: CAPE TOWN, June 20 (AP)Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, a pioneer in heart transplant surgery, implanted a baboon's heart in the body of a human tonight, but the recipient died hours after the operation, Groote Schuur hospital announced.

title: Martin Saved in Manager's Job After Yankee Team Conference
description: DETROIT, June 20Gabe Paul, the president of the Yankees, gave Billy Martin a lastminute reprieve tonight, just when it appeared Martin was on the brink of dismissal as manager of the troubled team.

title: Jeanne Ehrlichman Allows a Glimpse Into Tumult of Watergate
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.The drama called Watergate began five years ago and today it may be over and done with in a lot of places, but here on the shores of Lake Washington, it is still going on. It is here in the silence and emptiness of a 75yearold house. It is here in the pain and the serenity that vibrate through everything Jeanne Fisher Ehrichman, Mrs. John D. Ehrlichman, once of Washington and Watergate, says.

title: 10 L.E.A.A. Regional Units to Be Closed
description: WASHINGTON. June 20 (AP)The Carter Administration will shut down all 10 regional offices of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration in September, eliminating nearly onefourth of the agency's 850 jobs.

title: Planned Move of Museum of Black Art From Harlem Stirs Dissension Among Institution's Staff Members
description: The directors of a museum that was established in Harlem to increase blacks' participation in the city's cultural life are planning to move it out of Harlem because, they contend, the middleclass blacks and whites they had hoped to attract do not want to go there.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal grand jury in Newark indicted five former stockbrokers on charges that they took part in a largescale stock fraud involving false books and records, mail fraud and conspiracy.

title: G.N.P. Revised Upward
description: The economy grew at a rate 6.9 percent in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said yesterday. It was the second upward revision on the increase in the gross national product. Page 43.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: CONGRESS PRESSURE KEEPS F18 JET ALIVE DESPITE NAVY DOUBTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The United States Navy, under powerful pressure from Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., has quietly kept alive a controversial and expensive Navy fighter plane program it had planned to drop.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1977

title: FINANCIAL
description: U.S. TREASURY BILLS

title: Stocks Are Up 3.82 on Forecasts Of Strong Growth in the Economy
description: Stock prices advanced moderately yesterday in response to forecasts of strong growth in the United States economy this year and next.

title: Harrelson Puts His Feelings in Note to Seaver
description: Shea Stadium finally became the quiet corner of the baseball world last night, far from Tom Seaver and his new teammates, far from the Yankees and their new troubles. And it became even quieter about 9 o'clock when the line of thunderstorms buffeting New York caused the Mets to postpone the opening game of their series against the Atlanta Braves.

title: Curtain Falls on Harkness Theater
description: The Harkness Theater in the Lincoln Center area has been sold and is being gutted, a victim of harsh economics of the performing arts beyond the Broadway theater district. The theater opened in April 1974 to considerable fanfare as the first and only major theater in the United States specifically designed for the presentation of dance.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Mount Washington Takes Title in Club Lacrosse
description: The Mount Washington Lacrosse Club of Baltimore defeated the Long Island Athletic Club, 125, and won the national club championship Saturday night before 1,200 fans at Norris Field in Baltimore.

title: Fate of Amin Is Uncertain Amid Tension in Uganda
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 20Rumors concerning Uganda and its President, Idi Amin, swept Nairobi today in the aftermath of what was reliably reported as some shooting two days ago at Entebbe. where Marshal Amin lives.

title: Gunmen in Italy Shoot Foreman in the Legs
description: ROME, June 20 (UPI)Gunmen shot a Milan electrical company foreman in the legs today, 18 new Fiat cars were burned in Florence and firebombs were thrown at an office of the ruling Christian Democratic Party in Rome in a mounting wave of urban terrorism.

title: Showmanship Is Loosed on Crime at Park
description: Performing artists put on a show in Bryant Park yesterday in an attempt to help rid the park of its criminal element. The performers delighted several hundred spectators, including some of the very lawbreakers they hoped to displace.

title: Panel Charges Two Suffolk Judges In Handling O'BrienKelly Dispute
description: Two Suffolk County judges have been charged with improper handling of a witness by a grand jury dealing with a dispute between the county's Police Commissioner and its District Attorney.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Higher Education Board Reelects Harold M. Jacobs as Its Chairman
description: The Board of Higher Education unanimously reelected Harold M. Jacobs last night as its chairman for the fiscal year starting July 1.

title: COURT RULES STATES MAY DENY MEDICAID FOR SOME ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Supreme Court ruled today, 6 to 3, that neither the Constitution nor current Federal law requires states to spend Medicaid funds for elective abortions.

title: Two Portraits of Rastafarians: A Cult of Violence or Righteousness
description: KINGSTON, JamaicaMen claiming devotion to Rastafarianism, a 47yearold Jamaicanborn sect espousing peace and love that is rapidly being spread to England, Canada and the United States by emigrating Jamaicans, have been trafficking in drugs and committing assaults. robberies and murder in New York City.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Monday, June 20, 1977

title: Geraldine Brooks, Actress, 52, Starred on Stage, Screen and TV
description: Geraldine Brooks, the actress, died Sunday night of cancer at the Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, L.I. She was 52 years old.

title: 12 CONVICTED PERSONS RUN NURSING HOMES
description: Twelve nursinghome operators who have recently been convicted of felonies or misdemeanors still operate homes in New York State, health investigators said yesterday.

title: Director, Czar and President
description: President Carter is now confronted with the necessity for two decisions. each of which is about as important as any he will make. He has to choose a new director for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, presumably from list of five names submitted to him by a special commission; and he has to decide whether to appoint a single director for all the various agencies loosely known as the intelligence community.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 21, 1977

title: A National Energy Policy: Controversy, Uncertainty
description: Two months have passed since President Carter offered his comprehensive 10point plan for a national energy policy without any lessening of controversy surrounding it and without any substantial clarification of the type and program that will eventually emerge from Congress. The criticisms are unlikely to evaporate because most of them are based on fundamental philosophical differences between the Administration and its opponents on how to moderate the nation's dependence on foreign oil in the next decade.

title: Attitude of Asians Hardens Toward Indochina Refugees
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 19Boatloads of Vietnamese refugees are landing along the east coast of Malaysia almost every day, and how many are pushed back out to sea by police, navy and immigration authorities will never be known.

title: 1,000 in New Mexico Battle Fire Threatening Nuclear Laboratory
description: LOS ALAMOS, N.M., June 20Nearly 1,000 firefighters today struggled for the fourth straight day to contain the stubborn, windwhipped blaze that has blackened more than 11,000 acres and posed a continuing threat to the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, a major Government nuclear research facility.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BANG, POW, SOCKO! Rodolphe Tpffer, a Swiss illustrator, believed that more people can look than read. He drew picturestory books and amassed a collection of drawings, Histoires en estampes, were forerunners of the comic strip. In America, the 1890's saw the birth of the Yellow Kid, Little Bears and Tigers and the Katenzjammer Kids in Sunday newspapers.

title: Ruling Calls for 1Man Police Cars
description: An arbitrator has approved the New York City Police Department's plan to begin using oneman radiocar patrols and its current duty chart requiring police officers to work 10 additional days a year, despite the opposition of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, official sources said last night.

title: Contaminated Trout Being Sold; U.S. Puts Pressure on Dealers
description: DETROIT, June 20For at least three or four years, according to state and Federal wildlife officials, unlicensed renegade fishermen on Lake Michigan have been illegally netting lake trout contaminated by the toxic chemical PCB and selling them as table fare for unsuspecting consumers in New York, Detroit and Chicago.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Twain Meet in City Ballet's Bugaku
description: Naturally George Balanchine is taken for granted, so are Fifth Avenue and the Bronx Zoo. One day we will indeed be sorry. Meanwhile, we treat this still unfinished portrait of She artist as an old man with a pleasantly surprising lack of reverence. Mr. Balanchine would want it that wayyet he is remarkable, an act of nature set to choreography.

title: Business Unit Cites Carey as Man Who Led City to Fiscal Recovery
description: Accepting tribute as the man who led New York City away from the brink of bankruptcy two years ago. Governor Carey last night cited the lowinterest rate of recent state borrowings to illustrate what he described as a collective triumph of the most massive selfhelp and selfrescue effort in the history of state and local government.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Minister Slain After Giving Stepdaughter's Eulogy; He Is Called a Suspect in Her Death and Four Others
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 20A state investigator acknowledged today that a rural Alabama minister who was slain Saturday in the chapel of a funeral home was a prime suspect in the murder of his stepdaughter, whose eulogy he delivered just before he was shot.

title: G.N.P. GAIN NOW PUT AT 6.9% IN 1ST PERIOD
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)The Commerce Department, revising its estimate upward for the second time, said today that the economy grew at a rate of 6.9 percent in the first Quarter.

title: Senate Unit Is Divided on Terms of Nuclear Reactor Sale to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, June 20A Senate delegation gave a divided reportt yestetron whether Israel should be permitted to buy two American nuclear reactors without first permitting international control over its topsecret facility at Dimona, which is rumored to be the source of a dozen or more Israeli nuclear weapons

title: Trane Raises Prices 3 to 5%
description: The commercial airconditioning division of the Trane Company has announced price increases of 3 to 5 percent on all large unitary product lines, most water chillers, and airhandling products. The increases are effective immediately.

title: East and West Vie In Seeking Agenda For October Talks
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 20Preparatory talks for an October meeting on European security and cooperation resumed here today with the Soviet and Western blocs confronting each other over rival proposals for an agenda.

title: Senate Unit Opposes Calif ano Plan Enforcing Busing
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Senate Appropriations Committee, taking its cue from the House of Representatives, voted today to prohibit the Carter Administration from implementing a new policy to use busing to desegregate public schools.

title: 12 CONVICTED PERSONS RUN NURSING HOMES
description: Twelve nursinghome operators who have recently been convicted of felonies or misdemeanors still operate homes in New York State, health investigators said yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: The Philadelphia Eagles and Mike Boryla have worked out an agreement under which Boryla, an unhappy 26yearold quarterback, will be traded. Boryla had declared that he was a free agent because an optionrenewal letter had not been sent him by May 1. the deadline set up by the National Football League.

title: South Africa Charges Poet With Plotting in Prison
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, June 20The saga of Breyten Breytenbach, a romantic poet who fell afoul of the South African security police when he joined the antiapartheid underground, developed a curious new twist today when he appeared in a courtroom here accused of having tried to subvert white rule from his prison cell.

title: Wildfire Takes Honors
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 20Patrick Malloy's custom 52foot sloop, Wildfire, took Class A honors in the first race of the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island Week regatta today. Wildfire beat the scratch boat, Guerrriere, by almost five minutes.

title: Arab League Adds 5 U.S. Concerns To Boycott List for the First Time
description: Arab League officials wound up a 12day meeting in Alexandria, Egypt yesterday, adding 12 companies to the Arab boycott list, including five American companies for the first time, according to League sources.

title: Burns, Blumenthal Back Checking Account Interest
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal today urged Congress to permit banks in all 50 states to pay interest on checking accounts and similar deposits, but clashed over the degree of flexibility the Federal Reserve should have in dealing with a companion provision in the Administration's principal piece of financial reform legislation.

title: CALIFANO'S CRITICISM CHALLENGED BY A.M.A.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 20The leadership of the American Medical Association said today that the criticisms of their professon and warnings of more Federal controls made yesterday by the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare had disturbed only a few convention delegates.

title: Hua May Be Chairman, but Peking Rule Is Becoming a 2Man Show
description: HONG KONG June 20As nearly every Chinese school child now knows, Hua Kuofeng is Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party. But more and more, it appears, the man who helped put him in that post and who stands behind him is Yeh Chienying, the 78yearold Minister of Defense.

title: Ray Would Be in Grave Danger In a Federal Prison, Lawyer Says
description: PETROS, Tenn., June 20 (UPI)James Earl Ray would be in grave danger from those who want to keep secret the details of the Rev. Martin Luther King's assassination if he is transferred to a Federal prison, Mr. Ray's attorney said today.

title: Oil Venture Expanded
description: The Standard Oil Company of California and Texaco Inc, said that the General ??etroleum and Mineral Organication of Seudi Arabia had approved their further development of a joint venture for construction of a major specialized refinery to manufacture lubricating oils and petroleum fuels.

title: HEALTH BENEFITS CUT BY MINE UNION'S FUND
description: WASHINGTON, June 20  Attributing losses of income to the spread of uncontrolled wildcat strikes by angry and often leaderless coal miners, the United Mine Workers union's multimillion  dollar health and retirement trust fund announced today a series of benefit reductions, the first in a decade.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: U.S. Track Squad Paces Wet Turin Meet
description: TURIN, Italy, June 20 (AP)Steve Williams of San Diego won the 100meter dash tonight in 10.28 seconds in pouring rain to highlight an otherwise mediocre triangular track and field meet among Italy, Britain and the United States.

title: Unit of Merrill Lynch In Britain to Expand
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, parent corporation of Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith, announced yesterday in London an expansion of its commercial banking operations outside the United States.

title: The Times Will Curb Ads for Pornographic Films
description: A new policy sharply limiting the size, format and type of information contained in the advertising of pornographic films in The New York Times will take effect July 1, according to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher.

title: METALS
description: Sales: estimated 5,645. ssettling

title: Hempstead Bank Shareholders Approve United Bank Takeover
description: The acquisition of the Hempstead Bank of Long Island, with assets of about $200 million, by the United Bank Corporation of New York, with assets of about $1.4 billion, was approved by Hempstead Bank shareholders, United said in Albany yesterday.

title: Around the Nation
description: BALTIMORE, June 20 (AP)Federal District Judge Robert Taylor ordered today an investigation of an anonymous report that the jury foreman in the trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel knew the Governor socially.

title: High Court Asks U.S. View on Doctrine in Hunt Suit
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)The Supreme Court today asked the Government for its view on the 68yearold legal doctrine that Federal courts do not have jurisdiction in antitrust cases involving official actions of foreign nations.

title: Brezhnev Gets Elaborate Welcome In Paris on First Trip as President
description: PARIS, June 20Leonid I. Brezhnev received an elaborate welcome here today on his first visit abroad as President of the Soviet Union, and his first visit to the West since he came to France in December 1974.

title: Savings Banks Withdraw TV Ad That State Finds Unfair to Rivals
description: ALBANY, June 20Savings banks may or may not be for people, but their advertising campaign, in the opinion of the State Attorney Genere, is for the birds.

title: Copper Prices, in Surprising Gain, Follow Up on Friday's Late Surge
description: Although copper futures prices rose a mederate 0.70 cent a pound yesterday, the action came as a surprise to many traders in that market. The reason was that the gain extended what traders thought was an abnormal oneday advance last Friday.

title: Companies List Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended April 30 unless otherwise indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Excharm, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: MRS. ABZUG REVIVES CITY U. TUITION ISSUE
description: Bella S. Abzug urged yesterday a commitment to free tuition at the City University, but stirred some confusion about the specifics of the commitment she called for.

title: Macken and Nadziejka Tied For New Jersey Golf Lead
description: SCOTCH PLAINS. N.J., June 20One thing about an A. W. Tilinghast golf course is that the more some folks play on it the more they become skittish and even afraid. That feeling leads to continuous difficulties on the outstanding courses, such as Quaker Ridge, Ridgewood, Baltusrol, Winged Foot and many others constructed by Tilinghast, as golfers try to outthink this architect.

title: Senate Asks No Mail Service Cut
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)The Senate passed a resolution today asking the Postal Service not to carry out its plan to reduce mail deliveries from six to days a week to five by early next year. The resolution, which is not binding, was added to a $7.8 billion appropriations bill for the Postal Service, the Treasury Department and other executivebranch agencies.

title: Alaskan Oil Starts Flow in Pipeline
description: PRUDHOE BAY. Alaska, June 20One hour late, the transAlaskan pipeline opened today, unlocking the wealth of oil that lies beneath the tundra of the continent's North Slope.

title: Cash Prices
description: Monday, June 20, 1977

title: Arabs Stage New Move Against Israel in I.L.O. Despite U.S. Warnings
description: GENEVA. June 20Arab countries today staged a new antiIsrael maneuver in the annual assembly of the Internationa Labor Organization despite warnings by the United States that continued political actions might impel it to go through with its announced intention of quitting the agency.

title: Maccabee Wins Cup
description: LOS ANGELES, June 20 (UPI)Abraham Cohen scored goals in the 59th and 80th minutes to lead Maccabee of Los Angeles to a 50 victory over the GermanHungarian Club of Philadelphia in the National Challenge Cup final yesterday. Maccabee also won in 1973 and 1975.

title: Fire Inspection of Nightclubs Set
description: As a result of the nightclub fire that killed more than 160 persons in Southgate, Ky., last, month, New York City fire officials plan to inspect all Manhattan nightclubs, discotheques, restaurants and various other kinds of places where 75 or more people gather for entertainment and amusement, an official said yesterday.

title: CONGRESS PRESSURE KEEPS F18 JET ALIVE DESPITE NAVY DOUBTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The United States Navy, under powerful pressure from Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., has quietly kept alive a controversial and expensive Navy fighter plane program it had planned to drop.

title: Senate Creates Panel to Study Gas Supplies
description: TRENTON, June 20The State Senate created a special committee today to investigate the amount of natural gas that will be available for New Jersey next winter. The committee has the power to subpoena the books and records of the various utilities.

title: $1.5 Billion Bond Issue Planned By Treasury to Replace Notes.
description: The Treasury, in a move aimed at extending the average maturity of the national debt and thereby making it more manageable, disclosed yesterday that planned to sell a 15year, $1.5 billion bond issue next Tuesday in place of the fiveyear notes it has been marketing every three months.

title: England Rallies to Lead Australia in Cricket
description: LONDON, June 20 (Reuters)Bob Woolmer served a century and led a rally by England on the fourth day of the first cricket test against Australia at Lord's today.

title: SUPREME COURT REJECTS SUIT OVER PANAMA TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI)  The Supreme Court today rejected a suit from six members of Congress who are trying to stop any treaty between the United States and Panama that would give up United States jurisdiction over the Panama Canal Zone.

title: South African to Meet Vance
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa will meet Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance for a discussion on the entire range of concerns between the two countries, the State Department said today Mr. Botha arrived here on a private visit last night and is staying through Friday.

title: Turner Sails Courageous to 40 Mark
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 20  Ted Turner won two more races at the America's Cup trials today with Courageous beating his teammate, Ted Hood, in Independence by margins of 67 and 47 seconds. after 21 miles of yacht racing under ideal conditions. Those were sound trouncings and if the America's Cup had to be defended next week rather than in September, Turner and Courageous would be the ones selected to do the job.

title: Chaste Ads for Porno Films
description: Starting next month, The Times will severely limit the size and format of advertisements for films whose primary purpose is to portray sex acts of various kinds. We do so because we believe that advertising which glamorizes pornography in films offends the community in which we publish as well as the standards of taste that we seek to apply throughout our newspaper.

title: Rain Keeps Crowd to 10,538, but Roosevelt Opens With Hopeful Outlook
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 20When he was a young man in his early 70's, 15 years ago, George Morton Levy used to hustle Bobby Riggs on the golf course.

title: C. Palmer Bateman Sr., 78, Father Of Jersey Gubernatorial Candidate
description: C. Palmer Bateman Sr., father of New Jersey State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, died yesterday at Somerset Hospital, in Somerville, N.J., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: NEW STATE LOTTERY SET FOR NEW YORK
description: Taking its cue from the illegal numbers game, New York State will offer a new lottery in which players will be able to bet on threedigit numbers they choose themselves.

title: Griffin Leads Hipkins Sail
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 20Philip Griffin of the host Cedar Point Yacht Club held a onepoint lead today after the first three races in the 26th annual men's Long Island Sound championship for the Commodore Clifton A. Hipkins Trophy. The competition opened in light southerly breeze in the bay off the club.

title: The Fabric for Fall, With a Builtin Glow, Is Satin
description: Last year, the evening fabric of the minute was tafetta. It rustled. For this fall and winter, it's satin. It shines.

title: DEVELOPMENT RIGHTS OFFERED BY FARMERS
description: MEDFORD, June 20State officials said today they had been swamped with offers from farmers in four communities of Burlington County who wish to sell development rights to their property to the state and thus maintain the area as an agricultural preserve.

title: State May Deny Child Aid if Father Quits Job or Strikes, Court Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that states may deny welfare benefits to the children of fathers who are dismissed for misconduct, go on strike or quit work.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, June 20, 1977

title: Light in Dark Corners
description: Doctor Omniscient answers the mail:

title: RICHARD HYDE
description: Richard Hyde, chief engineer of operations at CBS News, died on Sunday at the New Brunswick (N.J.) General Hospital after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived in East Brunswick

title: A Soviet Dissident Calls On Carter to Safeguard Relief Fund for Prisoners
description: MOSCOW, June 20 (AP)Arrests, searches and new fiscal regulations have almost crippled a fund established by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn to aid Soviet political prisoners.

title: Hearing on Port Unit's Criteria On Concorde Ban Set for July
description: A hearing to determine whether the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has acted unreasonably or discriminated against the Concorde supersonic airliner has been set for July 12, according to lawyers in the dispute who met with Judge Milton Pollack yesterday in his chambers in Federal District Court House in Manhattan.

title: Major League Scores
description: EDobs??, Duffy. DPCleveland 3 LO??Cleveland 13, Toronto 8. 2BBlanks, Dade, Du?? Ault. 2BFosse HR? (2). SB?? S?? Ault, BBell.

title: Lions Club Award to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)The international president of the Lions Club gave President Carter, a club member, the club's Head of State medal today.

title: Summaries of Wimbledon Tennis
description: MEN'S SINGLES FIRST ROUND

title: Other U.S. and Foreign Stock Exchanges
description: Monday, June 20, 1977

title: 2 Portraits of Rastafarians: A Sect Of Violence or Righteousness
description: KINGSTON, JamaicaMen claiming devotion to Rastafarianism, a 47yearold Jamaicanborn sect espousing peace and love that is rapidly being spread to England, Canada and the United States by emigrating Jamaicans, have been trafficking in drugs and committing assaults, robberies and murder in New York City.

title: Sony's Videotape Recorder Sales Help Lift Quarter Income by 30%
description: Strong sales of videotape recorders and the sharp increase in equity earnings of affiliates lifted the consolidated net income of the Sony Corporation 30 percent to $36 million, or 17 cents per American depositary share for the quarter ended April 30, it was reported yesterday. (Each A.D.S. represents one common share.)

title: New Hazard for Golf's Best Tournament
description: TULSA, Okla., June 20Now there's a new hazard in the United States. Open golf tournamentcrank calls. As if the rough wasn't thick enough, the greens slick enough and the bunkers treacherous enough, now there is the hazard of a crank call warning that the tournament leader will be shot with a bullet from out of the woods while he's putting. That's the hazard that Hubert Green had to defy in winning the Open, and no matter how much he brushed it off later, he had to be thinking about it every time he crouched over a putt, Not that a touring pro would wear a bulletproof vest. It would restrict his putting stroke, to say nothing of his backswing. But from now on, golfers, like athletes in other sports who have had their lives threatened, might be the target of some crank who is betting on somebody else to win. Shake him up, Break his concentration. But perhaps Hubert Green proved what some golf people have suspectedthat making a short putt to win the Open is more serious than any crank call. And when he had won, Hubert Green didn't even flinch when he was asked if he felt he had survived rather than won.

title: Justice Dept. Won't Help ExC.I.A. Aide Fight Curb on Writing
description: WASHINGTON, June 20The Department of Justice has refused to help Victor Marchetti, a former Central Intelligence Agency official, seek to dissolve an injunction that prevents him from speaking or writing about classified material that he obtained when he was a C.I.A. employee without first having it cleared by the agency.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY. JUNE 21. 1977

title: Yastrzemski Player of Week
description: Carl Yastrzemski hit four home runs and batted .444 last weekto win the American League's playeroftheweek honors.

title: Money
description: Monday, June 20, 1977

title: 40Ton Super Magnet Is Flown From U.S. to Moscow for a Joint Project Aimed at Conserving Power
description: MOSCOW, June 20A 40ton American super magnet was flown into Moscow today and delivered to a Soviet research facility, opening a new phase of a joint effort to find more efficient ways to generate electrical energy.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: 2 in Atlantic City Postal Robbery Agree to Testify Against 3 Others
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 20Two of the five persons indicted in a milliondollar robbery of the Atlantic City post office have agreed to testify against the others in exchange for light sentences, an official said today.

title: CARL ROY KEENEY
description: Carl Roy Keeney, director of industrial relations for the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday in Princeton, Me., where he was on vacation. He was 54 years old and lived in Darien. Conn.

title: Leinsdorf's Rug Fascinates
description: The people who plan programs for the New York Philharmonic's Rug Concerts must be wondering today if they really do understand what impels people to attend these offseason events. If they have been relying heavily on the novel ambiance or the comparatively low ticket price to draw the floorloungers, they were served notice on Sunday night that other factors must be considered. A few hundred people, lost in the vast spaces of Avery Fisher Hall, turned up to hear Erich Leinsdorf conduct Hindemith and Strauss.

title: DOMINICK A. SPINA, EXNEWARK OFFICIAL
description: Dominick A. Spina, who headed Newark's police force during a recent period of high racial tension, died Sunday at Clara Maass Memorial Hospital, Belleville, N.J. He was 66 years old and a resident of Newark.

title: Alaskan Oil Starts Flow in Pipeline
description: PRUDHOE BAY, Alaska, June 20One hour late, the transAlaskan pipeline opened today, unlocking the wealth of oil that lies beneath the tundra of the continent's North Slope.

title: SWISS OFFICIAL, ACCUSED IN BANK SCANDAL, RESIGNS
description: BELLINZONA, Switzerland, June 20 (AP)  The chief executive of the Swiss canton of Ticino resigned today following public accusations that he was involved in the $880 million Swiss Credit Bank scandal.

title: Alice Hughes, 78, Wrote A Women's New York In The WorldTelegram
description: Alice Hughes, a newspaper columnist and foreign correspondent, died yesterday at the White Plains Center for Nursing Care. She was 78 years old and had been a resident of the center for several years.

title: U.S. Confident of LondonN.Y. Air Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI)Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said today that the United States and Britain were very close to settling a sharp dispute over aviation rights that could abruptly halt air service between the countries Wednesday.

title: LENIENCY APPEARS LIKELY IN SPY CASE SENTENCING
description: LOS ANGELES, June 20Christopher John Boyce, who was convicted April 26 of spying for the Soviet Union while operating a code room for the Central Intelligence Agency, today was ordered to undergo 90 days of psychiatric tests before final sentencing.

title: Tanner, Kodes Lose in First Round As Connors Snubs Wimbledon Fete
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 20First came a parade of champions, snubbed by Jimmy Connors. Then Roscoe Tanner lost his super serve when it really counted. And finally, Hank Pfister, last wek's instant hero, fizzled under the strain of the big time.

title: Assembly Backs Use Of Laetrile in State
description: TRENTON, June 20  The Assembly rejected a recommendation from the New Jersey Health Council and tonight passed by a vote of 62 to 5 a bill to legalize the use of laetrilea controversial substance used as a treatment for cancerin New Jersey. The council had recommended that the bill be defeated.

title: Shifting Alliances Increasing Tension in the Horn of Africa
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, June 16  Tensions have risen throughout the Horn of Africa, spurred by majorpower rivalry and a shift in political alignments in this eastern part of the continent.

title: Wise Fans 10 in 2 Hitter, Red Sox Keep Up Attack
description: The Boston Red Sox, just finished with a weekend massacre of the Yankees, continued their assault on the American League East contenders last night by downing the secondplace Orioles in Baltimore, 40. behind the twohit pitching of Rick Wise. doubled in two runs and Butch Hobson's home run accounted for the other tally.

title: Quake Hits San Francisco Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 (AP)moderate earthquake registering 4.7 on the Richter scale shook the San Francisco Bay area this evening, but there were no immediatereports Of damage or injuries. Bruce Bolt, a University of California seismologist, described the quake as one capable of causing damage. Thu quake that devastated San Francisco in 1906 has been estimated at 7.9 on the Richter scale.

title: State Supreme Court Affirms Ban On OutofState Garbage Dumping
description: TRENTON, June 20The State Supreme Court reaffirmed today a four yearold ban against outofstate garbage dumping in New Jersey that has not been enforced since the 1973 law was enacted.
