title: TV: 4Part Michener's World Goes to Holy Land
description: There is a kind of project that is tailored to the good taste bureaucracy cf public television. James Michener's World is that kind of project. A wellknown name presides over a subject of great breadth, mixing enough facts with enough generalities to create the impression of nonthreatening depth. There is none of the potential controversy cf an investigative report, none of the raw power of a drama series such as Visions, none of the possibly jarring language of an offbeat acquisition.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF IN WEEK 2.6% TO 2.6 MILLION TONS
description: Steel production for the week ended June 18 fell 2.6 percent to 2.6 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday, marking the third consecutive weekly decline since output hit this year's peak of 2.8 million tons in the week ended May 28.

title: Dancers and Images Juxtaposed
description: Beverly Schmidt Blossom made one of her infrequent visits to New York from the University of Illinois at Urbana over the weekend at the Theater of Riverside Church. Historically she is out of the Alwin Nikolais school and contributed imaginatively to the vanguard explosion in the late 1950's and early 60's. One can still detect traces of her interest in juxtaposing the live performer and the visual image, and of course her works have the immaculate finish that one expects from someone with her background.

title: Ailey Troupe Takes Japan by Storm
description: TOKYO, June 20The Alvin Ailey Dance Theater is now staging two weeks of performances in Japan for the first time in 15 years, and it is getting a response unusually enthusiastic from the otherwise docile audiences.

title: Technology
description: Leaders of the American electronics industry are bemoaning what they consider a low rate of growth in productivity in the United States. They are attributing this to what they call longterm malnutrition of research and development in many parts of industry, including consumer electronics.

title: EUROPEANS OPPOSING U.S. PLAN FOR LENDING PORTUGAL $1 BILLION
description: PARIS, June 21The Carter Administration is facing European opposition to its plans for a $1 billion international loan for Portugal, according, to diplomatic sources.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Battle Is Shaping Up in Albany Over Peyser P.S.C. Appointment
description: ALBANY, June 21The Senate majority leader said today that he would not allow the Senate to adjourn without deciding on what he termed the rather weird nomination of Peter A. Peyser to head the Public Service Commission. The announcement signaled what could become a serious battle over Governor Carey's appointment of the former Westchester Congressman.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE OF THE most important things in learning to cookand in knowing how to cookis flexibility. It's the ability to adapt and alter a recipe to circumstance, to the need of a day. You can't or shouldn't be hidebound by rule, and many times personal judgment is vital whether it pertains to baking times or the use of an herb or spice.

title: Study Finds Carter Welf are Plan Favors Rural Over Urban States
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Calculations based on Government figures indicate that the industrial states of the Eastern Seaboard and the Middle West would not fare as well under the Carter Administration's proposed revision of the welfare law as would the rural states of the South and West.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW SOUNDS The contemporary composers series at the Downtown Whitney Museum is structured with the realization that there is more to some music than meets the ear.

title: Ballet: Stuttgart's Final Onegin
description: ASKED TO NAME any one ballet that they associate most intimately with the Stuttgart Ballet, balletgoers would probably cite Eugene Onegin. The ballet is a danced manifesto of the type of narrative fullevening work that the late John Cranko felt should distinguish the compan). It received its last performance this season Monday evening at the Metropolitan Opera, with Marcia Haydana Richard Cragun as the principals and Michael Wasmund taking the role of the illfated Lensky for the first time.

title: Federal Jury Indicts Wells Fargo, Brink's on Charges of Rigging Bids
description: Brinks Inc. and the Wells Fargo Armored Service Corporation were indicted yesterday by an Atlanta Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to divide customers in that area between themselves and to submit rigged bids for armored car service contracts from 1968 through August 1975.

title: England and Australia In TestCricket Draw
description: LONDON, June 21 (Reuters)The first EnglandAustralia cricket test ended in a draw at Lord's today after poor light shortened play on the fifth day with the Australians, chasing a target of 226. on 114 for six wickets.

title: Stiff New York Law On Drugs Is Termed Ineffective by Study
description: New York's 1973 drug lawwith its stiff, mandatory sentencing provisionsneither reduced drug use nor drugrelated crime, a federally financed study concluded yesterday.

title: Boos Greet Connors as He Triumphs
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 21Wimbledon welcomed Jimmy Connors onto the center court with a chorus of boos and hisses today, but the 24yearold American left with his pride intact after a 63, 62, 64 victory over Richard Lewis of Britain.

title: Chilean Surrenders After Hijacking Jet
description: MENDOZA, Argentina, June 21 (AP) A hijacker seized a Chilean jetliner with 78 persons aboard today, forced it to fly over the snowcapped Andes to this Argentine border city, then abandoned plans to fly to Algeria and surrendered, officials of Chile's state airline, LanChile, said.

title: Two Get 35Year Jail Terms For RobberyKidnapping Plot
description: TRENTON, June 21 (AP)Two men who plotted to kidnap a Staten Island executive and force him to rob his own payroll company have been sentenced to 35year prison terms.

title: PAROLE BOARD GIVEN VOTE OF CONFIDENCE
description: TRENTON, June 21A State Semite committee reported today that the three members of New Jersey's parole board apparently had stopped squabbling among themselves and were once again granting paroles at a reasonable rate.

title: Missing Girl, 17, Turns Up Safe; Is Questioned on Death of Friend
description: MORRISTOWN. June 21A 17yearold girl who had been missing and whose 15Yearold friend was found dead on an embankment of Interstate 287 near here last Friday, turned up unharmed today in South Amboy. Denise Macinsky, who authorities feared had fallen victim to foul play, walked into the police station in the Raritan Bay community shortly after 9 A.M. She was escorted by a young man, whom she was said to have been with since June 12, the day she and the dead girl, Valerie Tersago, were last seen in the exclusive private community of Smoke Rise in the Borough of Kinnelon where the girls lived.

title: Farmers' Markets With a Bounty of Freshness . . .
description: Now in their second year of operation around the city, farmers' markets promise to be bigger, brighter and busier than ever. While their main purpose is to bring freshly picked, locally grown produce to city dwellers, there are other reasons that inspire the founders. Both the Greenmarket project of New York City's Council for the Environment, and the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, which operates the Jamaica farmers market, cite a desire to make farming viable so farm communities can continue, and the hope that these open markets will revitalize marginal areas in each borough while adding interest to the city's life.

title: In Search of Conscience on Abortion
description: The antiabortion backlash is in full swing nowa cruel scythe aimed directly at the poorest and least sophisticated women in America. The Supreme Court decided on Monday to let states and localities deny not only funds but even facilities for the abortions the Court pronounced legal in 1973. Now the Senate is deciding whether to forbid the use of Medicaid funds for nontherapeutic abortions. This double blow threatens to move the nation back to the dark ages of hypocrisy and deceit that lifted only in 1970, when New York and Hawaii liberalized their abortion laws.

title: Wine Talk
description: APHENOMEN unique to the California wine scene is the rise in recent years of the winemaker as celebrity. In most of the world's wine regions. the winemakers toil annoymously among their vats and presses.

title: Terrorists Shoot a Rome Professor in the Legs
description: ROME, June 21 (UPI)Terrorists shot a Rome University professor in the legs and set fire to seven buses in a depot near Milan today on the third day of a wave of violence coinciding with the trial of a guerrilla leader.

title: The City's Odd Balancing Act
description: True to its passion for unanimity, the Emergency Financial Control Board postponed consideration of New York City's thirdyear financial plan when it became clear that City Comptroller Harrison Goldin would oppose it. Mr. Goldin attacked what he called an improper means of accounting in the 1978 budget and produced a report from the accounting firm of Touche, Ross and Company that sustained his view. In response his colleagues sought another accounting opinion, from Peat, Marwick and Mitchell, who will become the city's official auditors.

title: House Votes to Block Saccharin Ban
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)The House voted today to block any Government ban on the use of saccharin for the next 15 months. The bill would also require the Food and Drug Administration to spend $1 million for its own study of the artificial sweetener's possible cancercausing effects. The vote was 45 to 35.

title: ExFranklin Officer in Guilty Plea
description: The former vice chairman of the nowdefunct Franklin National Bank pleaded guilty in the Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to falsifying records of the bank in 1974 to hide a $2 million loss.

title: Miss Desch's 77 Leads By a Stroke in L.I. Golf
description: JERICHO, L.I., June 21Chris Desch of Southampton upstaged Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, the metropolitan titleholder, today in the opening round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association stroke championship at Meadow Brook Club.

title: Chess:
description: The only one of the quarterfinal candidates matches that went into overtime resulted in an 87 victory by a former world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, over Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia. The match was played in Iceland, where Spassky lost his title in 1972 to Bobby Fischer of the United States.

title: Threepenny Opera To Play Central Park
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival's production of Threepenny Opera will start free public performances at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park next Tuesday. Philip Bosco play Macheath, Penelope Brody will appear as Lucy and Ellen Greene as Jenny. Other principals include Caroline Kava, Barbara Andres, Roy Brocksmith, Jerome Dempsey, Gretel Cummings, David Sabin and Edward Zang.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LAST 7 PERFS! FINAL PERF. SUN. AT 8 P.M. PROBABLY THE MOST IMPORTANT PLAY OF THE SEASON. I LOVED IT! Clive Barnen

title: Film: 'Mon Affaire' Cheats on Laughs
description: IF HALF A DOZEN LAUGHSsome of them solidspaced over nearly two hours were enough to qualify a film as outstanding comedy, "Pardon Mon Affaire" would merit designation as a hit. But as it stands, something on the order of half a dozen consecutive days of 90-degree temperatures and matching humidity plus a resolution of the Concorde dispute sufficient to touch off a wave of uncritical Francophilia will be necessary to blind audiences to the schizophrenic lopsidedness of this French movie, which opened yesterday at the Baronet.The work of Yves Robert, who directed "The Tall Blond Man with One Black Shoe," "Pardon Mon Affaire" is basically a standard-issue French infidelity comedy  built around Jean Rochefort as Etienne, the bumbling middle-aged civil servant who takes one look at a model named Charlotte (Anny Ruperey) and decides the time has come to cheat on his wife, Marthe (Daniele Delorme).Having no previous experience at infidelity, Etienne manages to make an inadvertent assignation with his receptionist; to make an idiot of himself on horseback after he discovers the model likes to ride; to find himself in Brussels while the model is waiting for him in London; to lure her to what he believes is a vacant apartment only to discover that he has brought her to his own birthday party; and to wind up on television when he takes refuge from the model's husband on a Paris window ledge.It's thin stuff, but it has its amusing moments, including the pursuit of Etienne's wife by a student whose ardor is matched only by his utter humorlessness.What makes "Pardon Mon Affaire" a lopsided film is its concern with Etienne's friendsBouly, who cheats regularly on his wife and is devastated when she leaves him; Simon, the doctor who is henpecked by his mother, and Daniel, who turns out to be a homosexual.When they are simply adjuncts to the story of Etienne, they serve a useful purpose. But "Pardon Mon Affaire" seems to be trying to say something about the lives of these three other men and beyond that, about the friendship of all four. Unfortunately, it either lacks the time or the insight. Whatever the reason, the result is an unbalanced film, torn between the silly and the serious, doing total justice to neither.This film is rated PG (Parental Guidance Suggested"). There is nothing terribly erotic about it, but there are some caresses and scenes in bed.

title: New Religious Movements Considered Likely to Last
description: BERKELEY, Calif.There are signs here and elsewhere across the country that the youthoriented religious sects that sprang into existence a few years ago are gaining a foothold for an enduring future.

title: High Court Rejects a Move to Ease Curb on Search Without Warrant
description: WASHINGTON. June 21The Supreme Court unanimously rejected today an attempt by the Justice Department to limit substantially the reach of the Fourth Amendment's requirement that the police get warrants before conducting searches.

title: The Wrong Debate About Intelligence
description: A battle is raging in Washington, fierce as only conflicts over budgets, turf and power on the banks of the Potomac can be. This particular fight involves control of the intelligence apparatus of the United States. Is it to be consolidated under a superdirector of Central Intelligence as the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Stansfield Turner, is proposing? Or should control continue to be dispersed, with the National Security Agency and the National Reconnaissance Office remaining under the Department of Defense, as the Defense Secretary, Harold Brown, is arguing?

title: Burgeoning Popularity of Soccer Attributed to American Youths
description: Acceptance of the Cosmos by the ethnic melting pot of the metropolitan area is greatly responsible for the flood of 62,394 fans who watched the soccer game at Giants Stadium last Sunday. However, that is only part of the reason the Cosmos drew about 59,000 more people than they did for any Sunday in June three years ago.

title: Argentine RightWingers Set Back by Court Decision
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 21A court decision freeing former President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse from jail in a politically controversial case has helped to restore confidence in the independence of Argentina's federal judiciary. The order by a federal Appeals Court releasing General Lanusse and three other members of a former military regime harmonizes with efforts of President Jorge Rafael Videla to strengthen the rule of law against violence from left and right.

title: Bill on Multifuel Holdings Has Failings, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Although he remained officially noncommittal, the Justice Department's antitrust chief took what was in effect a chilly. view today of a bill aimed at preventing major oil companies from owning coal and uranium properties.

title: ExPennsylvania Official Appeals
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP)Herbert Fineman, former Pennsylvania House Speaker, yesterday appealed his conviction in Federal court on two counts of obstruction of justice. The appeal was filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Mr. Fineman, a Philadelphia Democrat, was convicted May 20 of obstructing a Federal inquiry into alleged payoffs by parents trying to get their children into professional schools. He was sentenced to two years id jail and fined $5,000.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, June 21, 1977

title: Ottawa Rejects Quebec's Plans On Language Policy in Schools
description: OTTAWA, June 21The federal Government took strong issue today with a proprosal by the separatist government of Quebec to force virtually all children in that province into Frenchspeaking schools, regardless of their linguistic backgrounds.

title: Mercy
description: In the discussions that may soon be held between United States and Cuban representatives, Knight not our man say a quiet word about Huber Matos? That it would help smooth relations if he were released from jail and allowed to leave Cuba?

title: Unions Turning to the Law And College tor Top Officials
description: Almost as inviolable as seniority in the canons of organized labor has been the concept that the best union leadership conics out of the workplace. George Mealy, who picked up a plumber's ren ell after only a year in high school, epitomizes that tradition. So do the new heads of the country's three biggest industrial unionsDouglas A. Fraser or the United Automobile Workers. Lloyd McBride of the United Steelworkers of America. and William W. Winpisinger, who will be formally installed nest week as president of the International Association of Machinists. An three took up tools as teenagers before completing high school.

title: PIPELINE PROVIDING NO PROBLEMS SO FAR
description: ANCHORAGE, June 21In the first 12 hours that the transAlaska pipeline system was in operation, it was filled for about 17 or 18 miles, officials said today. The pipeline stretches from the Prudhoe Bay oil field on the northern coast of Alaska for 799 miles south to Valdez.

title: Books: Nuances of Marital Ennui
description: I DON'T REMEMBER why I married. Oliver, Virginia Grant Marbalestier, the narrator of Raw Silk, says early on; and with that admission, Janet Burroway sets the tone of this, her fourth novel, a moving account of the alienation of two people and the disjunction of a marriage.

title: Cauthen Back at Belmont.
description: Steve Cauthen, the riding wonder from Kentucky, was welcomed back to Belmont Park yesterday after a fourweek absence from the races because of injuries.

title: Reform Rabbis Elect Leader
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 21Rabbi Ely E. Pilchik of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, Short Hills, N.J., today was elected president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, a group that represents 1,300 Reform rabbis who serve an estimated million Jews in the United States, Canada and abroad. Rabbi Pilchik is an author and is past president of both the Jewish Book Council and the Association of Reform Rabbis of New York. He succeeds Rabbi Arthur J. Lelyveld of Fairmount Temple, Cleveland.

title: GISCARD COUNTERS BREZHNEV CRITICISM
description: PARIS, June 21President Valry Giscard d'Estaing took issue today with complaints by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the visiting Soviet leader, about Western concern over human rights, ideological tension and French defense policy.

title: Bucks Hire Killilea
description: MILWAUKEE, June 21 (AP)John Killilea, an assistant for the last five seasons with the Boston Celtics, was hired today as assistant coach of the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Red Sox Get Helms, Put Griffin on Waivers
description: BALTIMORE, June 21 (UPI)The Boston Red Sox acquired today Tommy Helms, who had been given his unconditional release by the Pittsburgh Pirates, and placed Doug Griffin on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

title: Trade Show Designed to Spur Arab Buying in U.S.
description: A trade exhibit and conference designed to open direct buying in this country by Arab businessesa reversal of the eager selling efforts of American companies in the Middle Eastopened here yesterday.

title: RETAIL PRICES IN MAY UP BY 0.6%, BUT RATE OF INCREASE IS EASED
description: WASHINGTON, June 21Retail prices for a broad range of consumer goods and services rose in May but at a lesser rate than in recent months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: Recital: Soprano From Brazil
description: NANCY MIRANDA, a Brazilian soprano who has studied singing here as well as in her own country, and Sosio Manzo, an Americanborn tenor who has sung opera in Italy, were presented in a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night by the Brazilian Coffee Institute. The piano accompanist was Tom Schilling.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 22, 1977

title: BENJAMIN H. ANIBAL, 90; DESIGNED PONTIAC AUTO
description: DETROIT, June 21 (AP)  Benjamin H. Anibal, designer of the Pontiac automobile, died Sunday in a suburban Royal Oak hospital. He was 90 years old.

title: No Bars, Armed Guards or Uniforms for Haldeman
description: LOS ANGELES, June 21  Lompoc Federal Prison, where H. R. Haldeman began serving his Watergate coverup sentence today. offers high school and college credits but few inmates bother to earn them because they already have college degrees.

title: Aspen Institute Discussing Merger With Center Founded by Hutchins
description: LOS ANGELES, June 21The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, the intellectual retreat in Santa Barbara founded by the late Robert M. Hutchins, and the Aspen Institute of Aspen, Colo., are discussing the possibility of a merger.

title: A FEW OFFICERS JAM RADIOS IN PROTEST
description: Some police officers in two Bronx precincts jammed their car radios yesterday to protest an arbitrator's ruling that the Police Department could use oneman patrol cars and continue its current duty chart requiring 10 extra workdays a year. Most officers throughout the city, however, expressed their resentment in angry comments.

title: PURGE SAID TO FORCE EXODUS FROM UGANDA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 21Hundreds of Uganda refugees were reported by the Kenya News Agency tonight to be streaming into this country, fleeing from what was described as a purge organized in the aftermath of an attempt on the life of Uganda's President. Idi Amin.

title: Gov. Grasso Orders a Halt to Payments for Elective Abortions
description: HARTFORD, June 21  Gov. Ella T. Grasso said today that Connecticut, on the strength of a ruling yesterday by the United States Supreme Court, would cease using welfare funds to pay for abordons where there was not an overriding medical need for them.

title: Child's World
description: THE Kissing Cooties Club, an organization of 9yearold girls who wore boys sneakers (the high, black kind) is now defunct.

title: News Summary
description: BritishAmerican talks for a new treaty on aviation rights were pressed in London in hopes of averting a halt in scheduled airline service that could begin today. As the midnight deadline for the expiration of the old treaty neared, Alan Boyd. the chief United States representative at the negotiations, said that chances for a new agreement were extremely good. [Page A1, Column 5.]

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently received a birthday present, a jar containing five black truffles from France. In years past I have always bought small cans of truffles, just enough for one use I'm afraid to open them for fear that unused truffles will spoil. How do I preserve them once opened?

title: New Account Plan Is Due for Testing By Merrill Lynch
description: A different kind of brokerage account, encompassing some banking services new to the securities industry, was announced yesterday by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN AGREE ON AIR SERVICE PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 22Britain and the United States averted a rupture in airline service early today by agreeing on a new pact on aviation rights to replace an agreement in effect since 1946.

title: Jesse and Laz, 1, 2 in Pole Vault, Pace U.S. Track Victory in Turin
description: TURIN, Italy, June 21 (AP)Larry Jesse and Doug Laz scored a one, two sweep in the pole vault tonight as a young American track and field team dominated the men's triangular meet with Britain and Italy.

title: Warnke in Soviet to Discuss Disarming Indian Ocean
description: MOSCOW, June 21Paul C. Warnke, the Carter Administration's top arms negotiator, flew into Moscow today to open negotiations with the Soviet Union on demilitarizing the Indian Ocean.

title: A Shrewd and Quiet Man
description: MADRIDToday's least flamboyant and most interesting Spanish political figure is Santiago Carrillo, 62yearold general secretary of the Communist Party, which was legalized only this spring after two generations of Francoist ban.

title: Algeria Pardons 6 Frenchmen
description: ALGIERS, June 21 (Reuters)  Six Frenchmen found guilty of economic crimes have been pardoned by President Houari Boumediene and will be released shortly, the official press agency reported today. Among the six being released are Michel Pelloie and Jean Claude Chauchard, engineers sentenced last year to 10 and three years in prison respectively, in a case that was felt in France to have been affected by the poor state of relations between Paris and Algiers at the time.

title: Veteran's Protest to President Fails as Carter Returns Gift
description: NORTH WILDWOOD, N.J., June 21 Joseph Evangelista, a decorated former Army platoon sergeant, wrapped his three medals in a package and dispatched them to President Carter in protest against his pardon of virtually all Vietnamera draft evaders.

title: INTEREST RATES UP IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest rates, apparently pushed too low too quickly last week, were moved back up yesterday in an effort to get investors to buy new fixedincome securities, but the effort was only partly successful. Interest rates rose in the Government, corporate and taxexempt bond markets.

title: Processors Come of Age, and Are Put to the Test
description: It now seems clear that the food processorthat muchtouted miracle worker which has served as much as status symbol as mechanical servant in the American home for the last several yearsis finally coming of age. Age, in this case, meaning sufficient competition and mass production have been generated to make the processor less of a luxury and more economically viable for a large segment of the public.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Best Buys
description: WELL, here we are in summertime, and while the livin' may not be easy it's a little better than it was during the last week of spring, when it comes to buying food.

title: FiveParty Marxist Coalition Takes Over West Bengal
description: NEW DELHI, June 21West Bengal became India's only Communistruled state today as a coalition government of five Marxist parties took office as a result of last week's state elections.

title: short Interest on Big Board Falls
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest declined 574,361 shares in the month ended June 15 to 29,575,331 shares. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 23,527,818 shares.

title: Plea by 4 in Custody Fight Denied
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., June 21A Federal District Court judge refused today to grant an injunction requested by four adult members of a fundamentalist church who. are seeking to block their parents from taking legal custody of them.

title: F.D.A. CRACKING DOWN ON SOME SEDATIVES
description: WASHINGTON. June 21The Food and Drug Administration announced today a crackdown on the advertising and the use of many popular daytime sedative drugs that may be purchased without a prescription.

title: Runoff Is Called After Firemen Vote
description: Michael J. Maye and Richard J. Vizzini will face each other in a runoff vote for the presidency of the Uniformed Firefighters Association as a result of a mailballot election yesterday that gave neither the required majority.

title: Ralph Hayes, Noted FundRaiser; Led New York Community Trust
description: Ralph Hayes, director of the New York Community Trust for more than 40 years and a pioneer in fund raising efforts for charitable causes, died Monday in Wilmington, Del. He was 83 years old.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES FOR $28 TAX REBATE FROM CRUDE OIL LEVY
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to rebate to consumers money collected through higher taxes on crude oil, although it modified the Administration's proposal and limited the program to one year.

title: The Last Of The Giants
description: BELGRADE, June 21If you think you're confused about the politics of New York or Washington, you should come to Belgrade. It breaks every rule in the political book. It sounds like Moscow and works like Pittsburgh. Everything runs upstream in this bustling valley but the Sava and Danube Rivers.

title: Dollar Moves Up Slightly Against Some Currencies In Brisk New York Trade
description: The United States dollar gained slightly against the Swiss franc and Canadian dollar in brisk foreignexchange trading in New York yesterday, and also rose against Scandinavian currencies in London, the Associated Press reported.

title: U.S.BRITAIN AIR TALKS MOVE NEAR DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, June 21BritishAmerican negotiations for a new treaty on aviation rights were pressed in London tonight in the hopes of averting a possible rupture tomorrow in scheduled airline service.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Drive Begun for New York City As Site for '84 Summer Olympics
description: ALBANY, June 21Governor Carey, Mayor Beame and the leaders of the Legislature have opened a major drive bring the 1984 Summer Olympics to New York City.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Fling With a Sling

title: Met Homer In 11th Tops Braves, 52
description: M. Donald Grant made his first appearance at Shea Stadium last night since banishing Tom Seaver from the Met kingdom and lived to tell about it. He also will tell over and over again how he watched Steve Henderson, one of the unknowns he swapped for Seaver, hit a threerun, 11thinning home run that propelled the Mets to a 52 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: The Kid Wanted To Direct
description: RON HOWARD, who plays Fonzie's best friend on the toprated television series Happy Days, is everybody's favorite AllAmerican boy. He has reddish hair, pinkish cheeks, pale blue eyes, a slight split between his front teeth and a look of perpetual surprise on his face.

title: NewYorkers, etc.
description: THE MAN WAS a bit of a hypochondriac, although not much, but the fact was that for years he had smoked inordinately, drunk immoderately, and lived mostly off junk food. His only concession to good health had been his refusal to keep alcohol in the house. That was because he lived alone. Some men could manage this very well, but he himself, he knew, was not good at it. On his first night alone, he had opened a bottle of Scotch, forgotten about dinner, and started to read The Annotated Alice. He had finished Alice: he had finished the Scotch, too, and when he had gotten up from the easy chair he had fallen over the footstool. The next morning he gave all his liquor to the doormen, and he had not had any around since. In its place, he kept ice cream. If he were to reread Alice, he would do so with Haagen Dazs chocolate, or maybe Breyer's strawberThey were what comforted him.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Restrict the Use of Medicaid Funds for Abortions
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to ban the use of Medicaid funds for abortions except when a mother's life is endangered, in cases of rape or incest, or where serious genetic disease threatens the child.

title: About Real Estate
description: The New York version of the Philadelphia plan has gone into effect, with savings bankers saying that the activity it generates will clarify the extent of unmet demand for mortgage credit in the city.

title: Independence (15) Bows To Enterprise (33)Twice
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 21Frederick E. (Ted) Hood may be at age 50 the best racing sailor in the country, depending upon whom one asks, and he has achieved all sorts of honors on the water including one defense of the America's Cup. Today at the America's Cup trials he had a bad day, Hood and the new yacht, Independence, which he designed, dressed as to sails, and skippers.

title: The Connors Enigma: Streak of Individuality
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 21What makes Jimmy Connors run? Is he really the little imp who steals cookies from the jar and then says, Who me? Or does he need continual diallenges to keep his combative juices flowing on the tennis court?

title: Rodgers Nears 75 Years in a Life of Music
description: It is probably bad form to ask a major composer who has spent more than half a century creating 39 stage scores, nine film scores, four television scores and assorted other works what he does in his spare timebut someone did just that the other day to Richard Rodgers.

title: A Return to Horseplay
description: WASHINGTONWe must take a new look at the cavalry, its traditional role and future possibilities in international military power, if any progress is to be made toward world peace and stability. A mounted military might be far more civilized than what we now have, and less dangerous to us.

title: Pop: Rag And Blue On Guitar
description: JOHN FAHEY'S solo guitar defies labeling as readily as it charms even the most jaded ear A single piece: as performed by Mr. Fahey is likely to include improvising over a drone in the manner of Indian music snatches of Protestant hymns, fingerpicked ragtime and blues, and although these elements are strung together episodically, they coexist without a hint of strain.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES FOR $28 TAX REBATE FROM CRUDE OIL LEVY
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to rebate to consumers money collected through higher taxes on crude oil, although it modified the Administration's proposal and limited the program to one year.

title: Philippine Immigration Chief Bars Expulsion of American Reporter
description: MANILA, June 21 (AP)Immigration Commissioner Edmundo M. Reyes today barred the expulsion of an American journalist, accused of writing articles unfavorable to the Philippine martiallaw regime.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Tuesday, June 21, 1977

title: Court Told L.I. Incinerator Violates Ruling
description: The Town of North Hempstead, L. I., and three of its officials have been charged with failing to comply with a Federal judge's order to shut down an incinerator when the wind was from the east so pollutants would not be spewed over Queens and Westchester County.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 (AP)The American Medical Association rejected today a proposal that laetrile be made available without a doctor's prescription, saying such a move could open the floodgates of quackery.

title: Miss Quinlan's Status Said to Deteriorate
description: Karen Anne Quinlan, who has been in a coma for more than two years, suffered a further deterioration yesterday morning, and her parents remained at her bedside in the Morris View Nursing Home in Morris Plains.

title: Thousands in Cities Have Turned Lots Into Thriving Vegetable Gardens
description: CHICAGO, June 21Bernice Henderson considered herself thoroughly urbanized. She was accustomed to the hot asphalt in the summer, the noise, sights and smells of the big city.

title: ADM. ROBERT WORKMAN, 92, EXCHIEFOFNAVYCHAPLAINS
description: Rear Adm. Robert DuBois Workman, retired, the former chief of Navy chaplains, died yesterday at the Chester County Hospital in West Chester, Pa. He was 92 years old.

title: People in Sports
description: Rumors that Manager Frank Lucchesi of Texas would lose his job grew stronger yesterday, despite the Rangers move into third place in the American League West Monday night with a victory over Minnesota. The Associated Press in Dallas reported a source in Minneapolis with the club as saying Lucchesi would not last the week.

title: LILCO TO PAY FOR TRIP TO ATOMPLANT RALLY
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 21In an effort to counter the bad publicity given nuclear power by the recent demonstrations in Seabrook, N.H., the Long Island Lighting Company is offering its 5,400 employees a free oneday bus trip to Manchester, N.H., with lunch and dinner thrown in, to rally on Sunday in favor of nuclear energy.

title: ELIZABETH W. BURBANK, 89; WIDOW OF HORTICULTURIST
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., June 21 (UPI)Elizabeth Waters Burbank, widow of the famed horticulturist, Luther Burbank, died on Sunday. She was 89 years old.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday a tentative agreement to sell its HollywoodBurbank Airport to the cities of Glendale, Pasadena and Burbank for $51 million.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAINT JOHN, New Brunswick, Wednesday. June 22 (Reuters)Twenty prisoners were killed last night as a fire swept through the cell block at police headquarters here, authorities said today.

title: Dance: 5 by 2 Company Plus 2 Equals 4
description: AREPERTORY DANCE company for two dancers really does seem to be stripping down to the barest essentials and even beyondbut that is the aspiration of a company found, formed and functioned by Jane Kosminsky and Bruce Becker. It is called the 5 by 2 Dance Company and it appeared on Monday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, beginning a brief seasoo that ends tonight

title: Allied Stores Weighs New Retail Venture
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, which operates Stern's and Gertz in the metropolitan New York area, is discussing the possible acquisition of another departmentstore business, but declined to identify it, other than to say several prospects were being studied, including a Lit store.

title: TV: PBS Explores Deafness and Dance
description: TWO of public television's more worthwhile series are on particularly impressive display this evening. At 8 o'clock, Nova, produced by Boston's station WGBH, has Across the Silence Barrier, a broad and remarkably informative study of deafness. At 9, WNET/13's Dance in America looks at trailblazers of Modern Dance.

title: Shutdown Ends at Danish Paper
description: COPENHAGEN, June 21 (Reuters)Berlingske Tidende, Denmark's leading newspaper, reappeared today after a dispute of four and a half months with printers. The printers returned to work despite continued objections to what they considered undermanning. The dispute ended with a 25 percent cut this year in the paper's printing staff of 1,000.

title: Advertising
description: Brothers! Sisters! I have discovered radio! I have seen the light. Hallelujah! Amen! Amen!

title: State of Miss Quinlan Said to Deteriorate
description: Berne, Roger  45  June 21stKaren Anne Quinlan, who has been in a coma for more than two years, suffered a further deterioration yesterday morning, and her parents remained at her bedside in the Morris View Nursing Home in Morris Plains, N. J.

title: Careers
description: While overt discrimination appears to have dropped sharply in the hiring of women who hold Master of Business Administration degrees, 10 who recently received their degrees from, the University of Chicago reported to the university that discrmination has gone underground into more subtle areas.

title: The Gospel According to John
description: To render unto Caesar et al, these tales were told by a race track character named John The Baptist Clark; they are included in the memoirs of Raleigh Burroughs, gentleman, angler and racing journalist, under the title Horses, Burroughs and Other Animals (A. S. Barnes & Co., $9.95); they reached this desk through the agency of James P. Roach, former sports editor of The New York Times, and the courtesy of Bradley Telias, secretary to the New York Racing and Wagering Board. From here on the tales are repeated as Raleigh wrote them but to minimize typographical confusion, his words are not enclosed in quotation marks: When the subject of making horses run better than they want to came up, John again won first award. You all remember Trainer Bradshaw? he asked, and everybody did. (Bradshaw is a pseudonym. I feel that deceased trainers would rather be remembered for their glorious feats in conditioning horses than for the cute tricks they pulled.) Here is John The Baptist's yarn in his own words:

title: odgers Nears 75 Years in a Life of Music
description: It is probably bad form to ask a major composer who has spent more than half a century creating 39 stage scores, nine film scores, four television scores and assorted other works what he does in his spare timebut someone did just that the other day to Richard Rodgers.

title: BLACK MARINE IS SENTENCED FOR AN ASSAULT ON WHITES
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., June 21 (UPI)  Marine Cple. Curtis Jones Jr., 22 years old, was sentenced today to three months' confinement at hard labor and was reduced in rank three pay grades to private El on charges growing out of an attack by black marines on white marines.

title: CAREY OPPOSES BAN ON PARKING IN CITY; SUIT ASSAILS DELAYS
description: Governor Carey yesterday threw his weight behind opponents of any drastic streetparking ban in Manhattan. A courtordered ban, parts of which went into effect last Tuesday, would have a terribly adverse economic impact on the city, the Governor said at an Albany news conference.

title: King Meets With Catalans and Raises Hopes for Regional Home Rule
description: King Juan Carlos today received a delegation of Catalan Socialists, fresh from their triumph in last week's elections, as legislators from both Catalonia and the Basque provinces began maneuvering for the return of autonomy statutes abrogated by Franco

title: Stiff New York Law On Drugs Is Termed Ineffective by Study
description: New York's 1973 drug lawwith its stiff, mandatory sentencing provisionsneither reduced drug use nor drugrelated crime, a federally financed study concluded yesterday.

title: Cashing In On Credit
description: GETTING a department store charge card in New York is not all that hard. What is hard is not getting a department store charge card.

title: Copper Futures Prices Decline by 2.40c Across Board
description: Copper futures prices dropped 2.40 cents a pound across the board yesterday, confirming what many traders had thought was an unwarranted rise of 3.60 cents the previous two sessions on New York's Commodity Exchange.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Figures
description: For Periods ended May 31 unless otherwise indcated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) OvertheCounter

title: 2 DENTISTS CHARGED WITH BILLING FRAUDS
description: In the first investigation by a New York City District Attorney of bill padding and the faking of Blue CrossBlue Shield bills by dentists, District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens yesterday announced the arrest of two dentists.

title: Beatrice Foods Net Up 15.7%; Heinz Climbs by 6.5%
description: Two major food cornpaniesthe Beatrice Foods Company and the H. J. Heinz Companyreported yesterday sales and earnings increases in the latest quarter.

title: Summaries of Wimbledon Tennis
description: MEN'S SINGLES

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Signs of Inflation Ease Lift Stocks In Heaviest Trading in 2 Months
description: The stock market, propelled by signs that inflation has eased, advanced broadly yesterday in the heaviest trading in two months.

title: ELDERLY GROUP CITES MEDICAID TIPOFFS
description: A federation of elderly people yesterday complained to Governor Carey that some nursinghome operators sentenced already for Medicaid ripoffs had got increases in the costplus reimbursement rate set by the State Health Department this year.

title: 1YEAR POVERTY PROGRAM VOTED BY CATHOLIC BISHOPS
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)The United States Roman Catholic bishops have voted overwhelmingly for a oneyear extension of the church's domestic antipoverty program after rejecting a move for a fiveyear extension.

title: Cauthen Back at Belmont
description: Steve Cauthen, the riding wonder from Kentucky, was welcomed back to Belmont Park yesterday after a fourweek absence from the races because of injuries.

title: Bayer's Print Attack On Tylenol Campaign
description: Tylenol from Johnson & Johnson, with only two years of consumer advertising behind it, has become the country's bestselling analgesic brand. It also has at least one angry competitor.

title: Assembly Passes a Measure Aimed At Crime Against Aged or Infirm
description: ALBANY, June 21A bipartisan bill aimed at curbing crime against the elderly and the physically handicapped was passed by the Assemlby today, but many of those who voted for it expressed Misgivings about its potential effectiveness.

title: Orders in May For Durables Advanced 0.5%
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)New orders for durable goods rose a moderate fivetenths of 1 percent in May, the third advance in four months, the Commerce Department said today. The increase represented a rebound from the revised seventenths of 1 percent decline in April but was well off the strong 7.5 percent advance registered in March.

title: 28 in Chile Continue SitIn At U.N. Office in Protest Over Missing Relatives
description: A sitin and hunger strike by 26 women and two men went into its seventh day yesterday in a United Nations office Santiago, Chile. The protesters are dedemanding an investigation of the dispearance of relatives arrested by the Chilarrested by the Chilean Government.

title: Private Lives
description: SCON WE LEAVE, in one of those tin pterodactyls that abolish the decency of distance between the East Coast and the West. I shall have to cope with the terrors of leisure for a month. In the mountains, overgrown with children, lacking any work to hide behind, I am oppressed by the fidgets. A couple of years ago was the summer of the rattlesnake. I had thought at first to vanquish the rattlesnake with an acetylene torch, which would have been a good way to set all of droughtridden Southern California on fire. I settled instead for a shovel, and that was fine; it gave us something to talk about.

title: Consumer Notes
description: New Jersey's tourism industry, which has been lagging sadly in recent years, is expecting a revitalization from casino gambling in Atlantic City and from a possible 10fold increase in state spending in tourism, according to industry officials.

title: Big Board Dominance Seen Bar To National Securities Market
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)Spokesmen for several regional stock exchanges said today that progress toward a national securities market is being hampered by the New York Stock Exchange's dominance.

title: Surveillance Report Assailed as False By Envoy of Seoul
description: WASHINGTON, June 21The South Korean Ambassador here, Kim Yong Shik, asserted today that the State Department had assured him that a report in The New York Times on electronic surveillance of the presidential mansion in South Korea by an American intelligence agency was absolutely false.

title: Pop: Byrdie Green's Easy Blues
description: Somewhere not very far under the glossy performing surface that Byrdie Green presents at Jimmy Weston's, 131 East 54th Street, there lies an easy, natural bluessinging talent. But Miss Green appears reluctant to let this aspect of her work become too apparent because she holds it off until the end of her set as she labors through heavily mannered and superficial treatments of overly familiar songs to which she has nothing fresh or personal to contribute.

title: Mondale's Tax Return Approved by I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service has given Vice. President Mondale a clean bill of health en his 1976 income tax return.

title: Bridge
description: The European team championship, which has been contested annually since 1932 except for the World War II years, promises to be of unusual interest this year. More than 20 teams will compete, from July 31 to Aug. 12 in Denmark at Elsinore, no doubt oblivious of the shade of Hamlet: A little shuffling (Act IV, Scene 7).

title: THE EXPERT SHOPPER
description: Of the various foods purchased by the average consumer, few pose so great a mystery as fish, both in the buying and the cooking. For that reason, all too often a family fish dinner is based strictly on fillets. Yet without too much training, anyone should be able to judge quality and freshness at the fish market, and so take advantage of more interesting and economical choices.

title: Yanks Drop 5th in Row, 52, As Tigers Win on 2 Homers
description: DETROIT, June 21The Yankees, supposedly firm in their field management but still looking shaky at bat, lost their fifth game in a row tonight, dropping a 52 decision to the Tigers at Tiger Stadium.

title: Theater Leaders Applaud Curb on Ads in The Times
description: Gerald Schoenfeld, head of the Shubert Organization, said yesterday he expected Pa better image for Times Square and For New York to result from a new policy of The New York Times restricting advertising for pornographic films.

title: Mallet Hill Polo Team Wins
description: BROOKVILLE, LI, June 21The Mallet Hill polo team defeated Fairfield, Conn., 109, today in the semifinal round of the Monty Waterbury Tournament at Hickox Field. Paja el Effendi led Mallet Hill with six goals, while Steve Orthwein and Fred Fortuno added two goals each. Bunny Guitteras and Jules Romph shared scoring honors for Fairfield with three goals each.

title: ArmyPrinceton Combine Tops British Track Team
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., June 21The ArmyPrinceton track squad, led by three allAmericans, Craig Masback, Curt Alitz and Dave Wiener, today repulsed the invading British of the OxfordCambridge track team, twelve events to four.

title: Richard H. West, ExChairman Of Irving Trust, Is Dead at 82
description: Richard H. West, the retired chairman of the board of the Irving Trust Company, died yesterday at his home in the Pierre Hotel. He was 82 years old.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Drive Begun for New York City As Site for '84 Summer Olympics
description: ALBANY, June 21Governor Carey, Mayor Beanie and the leaders of the Legislature have opened a major drive to bring the 1984 Summer Olympics to New York City.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The poor are increasingly concentrated in New Jersey cities and blacks and Puerto Ricans even more so, a study by the Regional Plan Association reveal.

title: Letters
description: The Origin of Julienne

title: ABC Sued for $25 Million For Halting Ring Events
description: Five boxers filed a $25 million suit against the American Broadcasting Corporation yesterday for unilaterally canceling an elimination tournament designed to produce champions for several classes.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: P.S. 77 Graduates Hear Young
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 21Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, joined 17 teenagers in cap and gown yesterday to celebrate a school graduation that, for many of them, meant leaving behind a life on New York City's streets.

title: Confidential Musings of Literati Go Public
description: DEAR DIARY: This is going to be smudgy. You're going to be smudgy. Do you have to be made of fragile newsprint, in narrow column wells with sides bleak and precipitous? Must you gorge on mechanical type rude and artless? Could you not receive the intimacies of monologue inscribed in a fine hand, on noble paper, perhaps even in a volume edged with sold?

title: Cabbies Like Diesel Taxis, but some Owners Think They Cost Too Much
description: Good times and bad, Ben Fein has been hacking in New York City for 0 years. As far as his driving is concerned, life took a turn for the better three years ago. That was when he bought his first diesel taxi. I wouldn't trade it for the world, he said the other day.

title: VANCE TOLD OF PROBLEMS IN TIES WITH SOUTH AFRICA
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)Foreign Minister R. F. Botha of South Africa met with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today and said continued insistence on a oneman, onevote system for South Africa would lead to a rapid worsening of relations between the two countries.

title: BERGER ALTERS VIEW ON CITY PAY RAISES
description: The executive director of the State Emergency Financial Control Board said yesterday that New York City should be permitted to give its employees costofliving increases if they work harder, even if their increased productivity does not save the city any money.

title: Tiffany Seeks to Tap Oil Wealth of Mideast
description: We are working intensively to expand our contract sales by capitalizing on the oil, money in the Mideast, Walter Hoeing, chairman of Tiffany Inc., said at the annual meeting yesterday. We are already involved with three major corporations there.

title: E.P.A. Warns of Sharp Crackdown On Water Polluters After July 1
description: WASHINGTON, June 21 The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it would crack down aggressively, with heavy fines and possible criminal penalties, on major polluters failing to meet the statutory July 1 deadline for achieving clean water standards.

title: Byrne Again Opposes Port Unit; Vetoes Its Plan for Bus Projects
description: Governor Byrne vetoed yesterday for the second time in two months the actions of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, including a proposal to shift $240, million in masstransit rail commitments to bus projects in both states.

title: Letter: On Balance of Payments
description: To the Editor:

title: UNLIMITED DONATIONS FOR POLITICS SCORED
description: NEWARK, June 21New Jersey Common Cause challenged today a law that allows individuals to make unlimited donations to help candidates pay off prir mary campaign debts. Donors are limited to $600 contributions in the general election.

title: CARTER TO GET IDEAS FOR REORGANIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 21  President Carter will receive recommendations next week for a reduction in the number of agencies under direct Presidential control and some reduction in the 1,712 people employed in them, an Administration official said today.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$9.600, pace, mile.

title: Oral Contraceptives Called Risk In Women Predisposed to Cancer
description: A California study that began a decade ago indicates that prolonged use of oral contraceptives may promote the development of cancer of the cervix in women who are predisposed to the disease. Such women have a benign abnormality of the cervix called dysplasia.

title: Mrs. Abzug Sprints While Rivals In Mayoral Race Pace Themselves
description: In an almost bare Manhattan office yesterday, Representative Herman Badillo of the Bronx held a news conference with three reporters, then left for Washington. Representative Edward I. Koch of Manhattan was at work in Congress all day. Percy E. Sutton, the Manhattan Borough President, met with members of his staff in the Municipal Building. Mayor Beame had five public events on his official schedule. Mario M. Cuomo began a brief vacation from his job as Secretary of State and listed six campaign stops.

title: Cave in Northern Greece Is Yielding Evidence of Early Human Life
description: PETRALONA. GreeceA Greek anthropologist believes that a cave discovered outside this village in northern Greece was occupied by ancestors of modern man for more than 100,000 years, beginning about 750,000 years ago.

title: 3 Share Lead in Jersey With 144's

That total gave Nelson a share of the lead with two others at the halfway mark of the 76th annual New Jersey Golf Association amateur tournament, being held at the Shackamaxon course.

title: Books of The Times

In the hours of triumph, Roxane Witke, tells us, Mao's fourth wife. Chiang Ching, once a Shanghai movie actress, never quite accepted by the revolutionary veterans, wondered if now she would languish in the latterday women's quarters or like the dowager Empress Tzuhsi maneuver behind the throne and one day sit square on it.

title: Film: 'New York' In a Tuneful Era
description: ROBERT DE NIRO is an actor of too much furious intelligence and humor to be contained very long by the ritualized conceits of "New York, New York," Martin Soorsese's elaborate, ponderous salute to Hollywood movies of the 1940's and early 50's in the form of a backstage musical of the period.Seeing Mr. De Niro as Jimmy Doyle, a talented, selfish, womanizing saxophonist, a variation on the sort of role that Tyrone Power played more than once, is to watch a man running to catch a train, only to pass right by it. The movie can't keep up with him.Nor, eventually, does it well serve Liza Minnelli as Francine Evans, the Helen Forrest-Kitty Kallenlike singer whose career, for a brief period of time, coincides with Jimmy Doyle's in the last years of the big-band era. Miss Minnelli doesn't outrun the film. With her apparently whole-hearted cooperation, the film uses her, especially toward the end when she's placed front-and-center to perform a series of evocations of her mother, Judy Garland, that are effectively eerie without being in the least bit moving."New York, New York," which opened yesterday at the Ziegfeld, means to recall the lost sights and sounds of post-World War II movies with affection and wit. Indeed, the good will is immense in the early scenes that establish the characters of the saxophonist and the singer, who meet as cute as Tyrone Power and Alice Faye ever did, and who become a "boy-girl" act after she, a nonlooker, saves his first audition by singing with him.The big-band sounds are right, as are the sets and costumes and especially the movie conventions. "New York, New York" knowingly embraces a narrative line as formal and strict in its way as the shape of a sonnet. Even the sets are meant to look like back-lot sets, not the real world. When Jimmy and Francine walk down a New York street, it's that New York street so many of us grew up with, the one that abruptly terminates in a row of brownstones because, after all, there was only so much studio space.Yet, after one has appreciated the scholarship for about an hour or so, admiring Mr. De Niro's manic intensity and Miss Minnelli's way of desperately throwing out comic lines as if they were failed lassoesthings that are often funny in themselvesone begins to wonder what Mr. Scorsese and his writers, Earl Mac Rauch and Marik Martin, are up to."New York, New York" is not a parody," but the original genre is really not interesting enough to have had all of this attention to detail spent on it. It's not that the movie runs out of steam long before it has gone on for two hours and 33 minutes, but that we have figured it out and become increasingly dumbfounded. Why should a man of Mr. Scorsese's talent ("Mean Streets," "Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore." "Taxi Driver") be giving us what amounts to no more than a film buff's essay on a pop-film form that was never, at any point in film history, of the first freshness?Even more disturbing is the movie's lack of feeling for the genuine feelings that those old movies were meant to inspire.Toward the end of the film, when Miss Minnelli is being photographed in such a way as to recall Miss Garland (in "The Man Who Got Away" number from "A Star Is Born"), or being dressed in the black tights and mandarin jacket that her mother favored late in her career, it seems that nothing is sacred. That suspicion is confirmed by the film's title song, a new number written by John Kander and Fred Ebb that is not to be confused with the classic from "On the Town," written by Leonard Bernstein with Betty Camden and Adolph Green.The three other new Kander and Ebb songs are not objectionable, and the dozen or so old songs are fine, including those sung by Miss Minnelli and one, "Honeysuckle Rose," sung by Diahnne Abbott (Mrs. De Niro), in what appears to be a recollection of Billie Holiday. Mary Kay Place, one of the great attractions of "Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman," has some good moments as another band singer, and Lionel Stander and Lenny Gaines are among the more prominent supporting players."New York, New York" is not a disaster of the order of Peter Bogdanovich's "At Long Last Love." Mr. De Niro and Miss Minnelli have talent in excess. Yet "New York, New York" is a somehow more painful movie, being nervy and smug. "At Long Last Love" was appealing in the way of someone who gallantly refuses to acknowledge having two left feet."New York, New York," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language, but is otherwise not much more explicit than films of the period that it recalls.

title: Plan to End Electoral College Survives Close Vote
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The plan to choose the President by national popular vote rather than through the Electoral College narrowly survived its first test in Congress today, but its problems have only begun.

title: Ziegler First American to Be Elected Head of N.H.L.
description: CHICAGO. June 22After adopting constitutional changes that free its chief executive officer from the restraining grip of the chairman of the board, the National Hockey League surprised no one this afternoon by unanimously electing John A. Ziegler Jr. as its next president. He will be the first American to head the Canadian dominated league and will be its fourth president.

title: Peruvians Battle Police In Five Cities in Protests Over Austerity Measures
description: LIMA, June 22 (Reuters)Violence has been reported in five Peruvian cities as students have taken to the streets in protest against Government austerity measures.

title: Film: 'High Street,' A Tour de Force:'Benji' Movie A Sequel
description: A CHILLING AND VOLATILE depiction of agony, profound rage, grief and madnessthe hideous legacy of Nazi inhumanity in Brussels during World War IIseizes the eye and wrenches the heart in "High Street," a Beligian-French film that opened yesterday at Quad Cinema 3.A tour de force by the French actress Annie Cordy constitutes the visual and emotional centerpiece of this prize-winning film based on case histories of people who carry through life the ineradicable psychic wounds inflicted as an almost careless byproduct of the captivity and murder of six million Jews.Miss Cordy portrays Mimi, a deranged woman who attends more than operates a fish stand, who lives in a cruel yet understanding symbiotic relationship with a mysterious silent man, and who rails at her neighbors, the clergy and the tourist buses that stop near her pauper's flat in a lower-class section of Brussels called the Marolles.She is an embarrassment to the clergy, a scold to the churchgoers, an unexceptional case to medicine, an object of derision and abuse to some of her neighbors and a disquieting lunatic to the passengers aboard the tourist buses whose arrival ignites some of her most unsettling outbursts.To David Rheinhardt, an expatriate American artist who lives in an adjacent quarter of the city, this traumatized woman who calls his name is, at first, an inescapable aberration in the local landscape, then an irresistible riddle who propels his art from the abstract to the real as he seeks to fathom it.And finally, as he moves beyond art to an involvement in her life through pity and protection, he gains a measure of her trust. But there is no eradicating the wounds inflicted one night in 1943, when Gestapo agents and German troops seized David Blum, her Jewish husband, and left her with a dead child amid indifferent neighbors.In the climactic image of this haunting film, David Rheinhardt is seen venting his agony and rage against the windows of one of the tourist buses. They are not, of course, what the insane Mimi has perceived them to bevehicles that will someday bring David Blum home. He will never come home. They are metaphors of indifferenceof life perceived at a remove, in passing, by creatures whose anatomy qualifies them as people, but whose failure to rise up, to speak out in the face of vile outrage excludes them from the ranks of humanity.For all its power, "High Street" is not a movie without faults. Not all the performances are up to the standards set by Miss Cordy and Bert Struys, the mysterious man who cares for her. Secondary roles are sometimes amateurishly rendered. And in its will not merely to reach out to the emotions, but to seize them with barbed talons, the narrative is warped. The cause of Mimi's traumahinted at to the audience in brief, rapid flashbacks cut into her bouts of madnessis withheld from David Rheinhardt long beyond the time when reason tells us he would have learned the entire story.Nevertheless, "High Street" is an extraordinary movie, as shrill and emotional, perhaps, as its central character, and for the same good reason. It has something to say worth saying for as long as there is any danger that mankind may forget the awful sins of the past.

title: U.S REBUFFS ISRAEL ON JOINT ARMS DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The Defense Department, citing security reasons, has abruptly turned down a proposal for the coproduction by an American concern and one in Israel of an elaborate military communications system.

title: EXKOREA AIDE SAYS K.C.IA HELPED SET UP CLUB IN WASHINGTON

title: Port Contract Talks Recessed
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 22 (UPI)Officials of the International Longshoreman's Association and the Council of North Atlantic Shipping Associations announced adjournment today of negotiations toward a new master labor contract for North Atlantic ports. Both sides said they would review their negotiating positions and resume talks shortly.

title: Jones on Disabled List

A righthanded pitcher, Dave Freisleben, was called up by the Padres from their Hawaii farm team.

title: Corporate Bond Market Is Active; Citicorp Raises Size of Note Issue
description: With the credit markets heading toward slightly higher bond prices and lower interest rates yesterday, Citicorp increased the size of the note issue it plans to sell today to $250 million, Trans World Airlines priced units of preferred and common stock to yield 9.50 percent and General Motors Acceptance Corporation announced a $300 million financing.

title: Panel Says Food Research Drive Could End Famines in Generation
description: The threat of chronic malnutrition and repeated widespread famines could be removed from the world within one generation if the United States and other countries mounted a major mobilization of research on agriculture and nutrition, a panel of experts convened by the National Research Council has concluded.

title: Terrace Marigolds

While that is true for most of the varieties grown in gardens, there are also stately marigolds reaching three feet or more in height. These are perfect against a brick wall background.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

He had been accused of killing Ernestine Timmons, 33 years old, on May 1, 1970, by beating and kicking her and then dismembering her body and removing it in two cellophane bags from his church at 222 Brooklyn Avenue in the BedfordStuyvesant area.

title: New Jersey Briefs

Judge John F. Crane granted a stay of Mr. Napoli's release at the request of the investigation commission at least until Tuesday.
