title: Little Change Held In Effect on Trade
description: Since 1950, when the Arab nations instituted an economic boycott of Israel, the measure has been largely ignored. The boycott had little economic effect on Israel, and because trade between the United States and the Arab nations was minimal, there was a Economic dominant feeling that any problems arising from the boycott could be handled through diplomacy. The atmosphere has changed dramatically in the last three years. The bill limiting corporate participation in the boycott that President Carter signed yesterday comes at a time when many American companies have developed large stakes in the Middle East and at a time when the boycott has become an emotional issue. The President described the boycott yesterday as profound moral issue, from which should not shrink. the Arab nations was minimal, there was a Economic dominant feeling that any problems arising from the boycott could be handled through diplomacy. The atmosphere has changed dramatically in the last three years. The bill limiting corporate participation in the boycott that President Carter signed yesterday comes at a time when many American companies have developed large stakes in the Middle East and at a time when the boycott has become an emotional issue. The President described the boycott yesterday as profound moral issue, from which should not shrink.

title: Mitchell Enters Alabama Camp To Serve Term
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 22John N. Mitchell, the first former United'States Attorney General, to go to prison, arrived here aboard a private jet today and rode to jail in a blue, Cadillac to begin his sentence for Watergate crimes.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, June 22, 1977

title: Radio
description: 78 AM, WNCN. Quando le sere al placido from Luisa Miller, Verdi; Fugue from First Violin Sonata, Bach; Navarra, Albeniz; Sinfonia in G. Mozart; Organ Concerto No. 4, Arne; Air de Lia from L'Enfant Prodigue. Debussy.

title: The House on F Street
description: Memo to: ComradePresident Brezhnev

title: Home Repair Q & A
description: Q.I have some chairs made of wicker that have been coated with shellac. The chairs are now beginning to show rough edges and the wicker is beginning to shred. Can you please tell me how I can restore the chairs to their original condition, or at least prevent them from deteriorating any further?B. D. M., Manhattan.

title: China Seen as Still Pushing Purge
description: HONG KONG, June 22China has ousted the longtime party leader of Kansu Province in the northwest after he apparently failed to carry out the current purge of followers of the country's socalled radicals fast enough.

title: F.P.C. SEES 3% DROP IN WINTER SUPPLIES OF INTERSTATE GAS; SHORTAGES ARE POSSIBLE AGAIN; Weather Would Be Major Factor Decline of About 170 Billion Cubic Feet Is Predicted
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The Federal Power Commission predicted today that interstate supplies of natural gas would again decline in the coming winter, raising the possibility of renewed gas shortages. Although gas supplies are relatively, easy to predict, shortages are not, because weather is a major factor.

title: Defendant Ruled Incompetent
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (UPI)  A municipal court judge ruled today that Charles Dixon Jr., charged with the murder on June 3 of his father, was incompetent to stand trial for the slaying. Judge Meyer C. Rose ruled at a scheduled preliminary hearing for the 34yearold defendant and scheduled a new hearing for July 27. Mr. Dixon was sent to Holmesburg Prison's diagnostic facilities for 30 days.

title: Oil Companies Decide to Halt Saba Island Drilling Venture
description: PHILIPSBURG, St. Maarten, June 22 (UPI)Oil companies have decided to abandon a $4.5 million dry hole, shattering hopes for the tiny Dutch island of Saha to become a Caribbean oil producer.

title: Opponents Rally to Block Opening Of New Sanitary Landfill in Edison
description: EDISON, June 22Contaminated water supplies, rats, flies and other environmental hazards were forecast today if a new sanitary landfill operation was permitted to operate in this suburban Middlesex County community.

title: Carey, Anderson and Bob Hope Go Out and Take a Few Swings
description: VOORHEESVILLE, N.Y., June 22He ought to act like a Governor Or get out, Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, said yesterday of Governor Carey.

title: AMIN NOW BELIEVED ALIVE AND IN POWER
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 22Idi Amin is alive and in control of Uganda and while there is still much uncertainty about what has happened in the country in the last week, there were growing indications that earlier accounts of widespread disorder and fleeing refugees were exaggerations.

title: RESULTS
description: (OTB) payoffs subject to 5% Municipal tax.)

title: Miss Quinlan's Condition Is Reported as Stable; Priest at Nursing Home
description: MORRIS PLAINS, N.J., June 22Karen Anne Quinlan, who has been in a coma for 26 months and who was removed from a respirator more than a year ago so that she could be allowed to die with dignity, was reported in stable condition today at the Morris View Nursig Home here. Last night she was reported to be dying.

title: Eleanor S. Reese, 84; Was Philanthropist And Singer in Operai
description: Eleanor Steele Reese, singer, philanthropist and rancher, died Monday at her Salmon, Idaho, home. She was 84 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, June 22 (AP) A strong human rights resolution sponsored by the United States won approval in a key committee of the Organization of American States today.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Wednesday, June 22, 1977

title: 2Tier Level Set Up On Aluminum Prices
description: The prospect of twotiered pricing in aluminum outside the United States became a reality yesterday when Alcan Aluminum Ltd. of Canada, which traditionally sets international pricing, said that its price for aluminum ingot still stands at 51 cents a pound.

title: Levi Net Rises 25.6% in Quarter And 22.1% for the Half From 1976
description: Sustained demand for jeans and other casual wear, increasing overseas growth plus higher average selling prices helped Levi Strauss & Company raise earnings in the quarter and six months ended May 29, it was reported yesterday.

title: Albany Court Changes Appear Ready for Fall Ballot
description: ALBANY, June 22  Constitutional amendments to reorganize some elements of the state's court system today seemed almost certain to appear on this fall's ballot as the Assembly's Democratic leaders abandoned their insistence that the proposals be presented to the voters as a package.

title: SECONDCLASS MAIL COSTS WILL BE INCREASED JULY 6
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)The United States Postal Service announced today that the cost of mailing magazines, books, records and other secondclass mail items will go up July 6.

title: Raytheon and Falcon Seaboard Agree on a Merger
description: The Raytheon Company and Falcon Seaboard Inc. announced yesterday that the twoan electronics producer and a coal mining companyhave reached tentative plans to merge in a stock swap valued at nearly $235 million.

title: Disks: Beethoven, Mozart and the New Dalta Ahkri Jazz Quintet
description: The attempt to find a fruitful symbiosis between the controlled intelligence of written music and the spontaneous flow of improvisation is perhaps the most difficult task faced by the contemporary jazz musician. Jazz themes are no longer brief written passages that bracket lengthy improvisations. In the new jazz, written material is likely to he scattered throughout a performance, lending direction and substance to the improvising.

title: U.S. Physician Rhodesia Ousted Says Rebels Have Wide Support
description: An American missionary doctor who was expelled from Rhodesia for having given medical advice and supplies to guerrilla soldiers said yesterday he was convinced that the insurgents had widespread support among the black population, despite allegations to the contrary by the white minority Government.

title: McTear Outruns Quarrie, 4 Others in Cologne Dash
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, June 22 (AP)Houston McTear sped to a 10.13second clocking in the 100meter dash tonight and beat Don Quarrie of Jamaica and four other Americans in an international track and field meet before a crowd of 20,000 at Cologne Stadium.

title: Raising A Standard
description: LONDON, June 22One of the most respected diplomats in London, a person with no time for illusions, was talking about President Carter's human rights policy.

title: COMPROMISE REACHED ON EDUCATION FUNDS; Mayor Beame and School Board End StaviskyGoodman Law Dispute, Settling on $13.5 Million
description: Mayor Beame and the Board of Education, locked in a dispute over school spending for more than a year, reached an agreement yesterday in which the school board would receive $13.5 million in new city funds in return for dropping its claim to more than this sum under the StaviskyGoodman Law.

title: A Spectacular Year For Whooping Crane
description: WASHINGTON. June 22Despite the ravages of coyotes. snowstorms and a naturally high infant mortality rate, the whooping crane took a giant step away from the brink of extinction this spring, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service reported today.

title: A TOP NEW YORK AIDE GIVEN POST IN H.U.D.
description: Thomas Appleby, New York City's Housing and Development Administrator, has been named by the Carter Adminis. tration to a major post affecting New York and New Jerseyregional administrator of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Former Chief of Korea's C.I.A. Kim Hyung Wook
description: WASHINGTON, June 22For several days Kim Hyung Wook said he had been getting ominous telephone calls from unknown Koreans warning him not to testify before a House subcommittee today. But the former director of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, no stranger to violence or threats of violence, said his piece anyway. A chunky, powerful man who looks a decade younger than his 52 years, Mr. Kim has been soldier, revolutionary, intelligence officer, politician and exile. He fought as an infantry troop commander in the Korean War, was among the young colonels who led a coup d'tat to take power in 1961 and was a member of the ruling junta for two years

title: People in Sports
description: The National Football League yesterday voted Chuck Sullivan, a lawyer and vice president of the New England Patriots, to the key post of chairman of the Management Council executive committee.

title: COURT LIMITS POLICE IN ANTISMUT ARRESTS
description: In a ruling that appeared to deal a blow to part of New York City's campaign against pornography, a Federal District Court judge yesterday barred the Police Department from using obscenity laws to harass three midtown bookstores.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Wednesday, June 22, 1977

title: Panel Says Food Research Drive Could End Famines in Generation
description: The threat of chronic malnutrition and repeated widespread famines could be removed from the world within one generation if the United States and other countries mounted a major mobilization of research on agriculture and nutrition, a panel of experts convened by the National Research Council has concluded.

title: PANEL IN SENATE REFUSES TO BAN RADIATION BOMB
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)On A tie vote in closed session, the Senate Appropriations Committee refused today to prohobit production of the neutron bomb despite arguments that no one knows enough about the weapon to add it to the arsenal.

title: Bridge:
description: Some plays by a declarer are so automatic that if he fails to make ?? the opponents are likely to be totally deceived. Suppose that in a notrump contract the opening lead is the king of a suit not indicated by the bidding and that declarer holds Axx with Jxx in the dummy.

title: Ballet: Shrew Rolls 'Em in the Aisles
description: THE MYSTERY of the bad ballet that works is simply solved. It just is not a bad balletor at least not a bad ballet as such. Functioning is a measure of at least modest success  and certainly John Cranko's The Taming of the Shrew functions.

title: Intelligence Budget Is Passed by Senate In a Public Session
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  The Senate passed by voice vote tonight and sent to the House the first unified budget covering all United States intelligence activities. It was the first time in history that a vote to authorize expenditures on intelligence was taken in public.

title: Again
description: There it is, going on 10,000 years ago, right in front of our eyes, and there's nothing we can do about it. Even our highestpitched, deepestprobing laser shouts would not be heard. If they were, they'd arrive too late to do anyone any good. Never was it more plain that what's past is present and what's present is past.

title: Enterprise Leads Race, Then Loses Her Mainsail
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 22Ted Turner, who has yet to lose at the America's Cup trials this week, was about to get his today when snap, crackle, pop, down came the mainsail of Enterprise, the boat that Turner and Courageous were falling farther and farther behind. Enterprise had to drop out and the race was stopped.

title: BREDINEV CONCEDES STRAINS IN U.S. TIES
description: PARIS, June 22President Valry Giscard d'Estaing today said he had learned from his talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev that the Soviet Union's relations with the United States were going through a difficult phase.

title: About New York
description: The Vietnamese refugee family of Le Thank Hoang Dan, striving to root itself now for two years in Flushing. Queens, has lost its eldest daughter to a confessed murdererrapist and Vietnam veteran who entered a plea of insanity this, week: He said he had killed her because he had thought he was interrogating a Vietcong back in Vietnam.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Eliminate 8 of 17 Disputed Water Projects
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)TheSenate Appropriations Committee voted uanimously today to eliminate 8 of the 17 water projects approved by the House over President Carter's objections. The action affirms a decision last week by a subcommittee with jurisdiction over the projects.

title: Design Treasure Trove
description: ON THE RIGHT as you go through the door is an orderly tangle of the very latest in adjustableheight shower heads and their brass hosessome with massage action pulsating sprays that sell for $59.25 and up.

title: Secretary of Labor Says U. S. Is Likely To Quit I. L. O. Soon
description: WASHINGTON, June 22Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall, who returned last week from what he characterized as a disappointing assembly of the International Labor Organization in Geneva. said today that the United States was likely to pull out of the specialized United Nations agency this November.

title: MANDEL'S EXWIFE TOLD TO TESTIFY AT HIS TRIAL
description: BALTIMORE. June 22 (AP)Barbara Mandel, former wife of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, has been subpoenaed to testify at his political corruption trial, defense attorneys said.

title: YESHIVA IN BROOKLYN TO MOVE TO SUBURBS; Buys a Former City Child Shelter in BedfordLinks Decision to Violence in Williamsburg
description: A 40yearold yeshiva, K'han Adas Kashau, announced plans yesterday to move from Brooklyn to the former Hillcrest Center for Children in the Westchester County community of Bedford. The yeshiva bought the center, which was once owned by New York City, at auction for $1.6 million.

title: ARAMCO TAKEOVER TALKS SAID TO BE COMPLETED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22 (UPI)Negotiations for the 100 percent Saudi takeover of the ArabianAmerican Oil Company, the joint SaudiAmerican venture that controls the world's largest oil reserves, were reported today to have been completed.

title: Personal Beauty
description: SUMMER ISN'T just coming in; it arrived offidaily this week. It's time for light, pretty clothes and a lighter makeup to wear with them. What's the word from the experts about summer makeup? Mainly that there's a lot less of it. They advise not masking a tan with a winterweight foundation, to ease up on eye makeup and to wear lighter rouge and lipstick colors.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Win a Puch moped bicycle!

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The 30th anniversary of the Marshall Plan this month has been commemorated in Europe but paid little notice in the United States  as though it had been an act of generosity requiring European thanks and American blushes. In fact, Washington's $13.4 billion postwar rescue of Western Europe from economic misery, social disorder and Communist political danger was essentially an act of enlightened selfinterest and the United States was a major beneficiary. That needs to be better understood on both sides of the Atlantic. For there is a pressing new need for today's strong countries  in their own interest to do more to help the weak, both in Europe again and in the third world.

title: Letter From Home
description: New Haven THE DISCOVERY of a great hill for skateboarding is big news in a family where the sport is taken seriouslyas it is in ours. To be the father of a skateboarding son is to share indirectly in the pleasure of pure motion and directly in the acquisition of some of the most arcane knowledge and language in America. None of it does me any good; yet I enjoy being along on the trip.

title: Vladimir D. Timakov, 72, President Of Soviet Union's Medical Academy
description: MOSCOW, June 22 (AP)Vladimir D. Timakov, president of the Soviet Union's Academy of Medical Sciences since 1968, is dead at the age of 72, Tass said today.

title: CHICAGO BROKER PLEADS GUILTY IN SOYBEAN CASE
description: CHICAGO, June 22, (AP)One of seven soybean brokers accused of illegal commodity dealing on the Chicago Board of Trade has pleaded guilty to one count in a Federal indictment.

title: G.M. Recalling 100,000 Trucks
description: DETROIT, June 22 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation anounced today the recall of 100,000 1975 and 1976 Chevrolet and G.M.C. lightduty trucks because drivers of about 9,000 of them could lose control of their vehicles due to defective ball joints. General Motors said there had already been two reported incidents in which drivers lost control of the trucks and crashed, resulting in three minor injuries.

title: Advertising
description: There are a number of ad agency heads who have a very low regard for advertising awards and never enter their work in them. Michael G. McDonald, chairman and chief executive of McDonald & Little, the fastgrowing Atlanta shop, isn't one of them.

title: Music: National Composers Association's Debut Attracts and Repels
description: THE NATIONAL Association of American Composers and Conductors was founded 37 years ago by Henry Hadley to promote American music. It was recently reorganized as the National Association of Composers, USA (NACUSA), and as such gave its first concert Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Mitchell's New Home
description: MONTGOMERY, June 22The Federal prison camp where Mr. Mitchell began, serving his prison term today is bordered on one side by the Alabama River, where inmates often pass their time by fishing or sunning, and on the other side by a 54hole golf course for officers assigned to Maxwell Air Force Base.

title: Railroad Is Blocked By Jersey Derailment
description: Twenty cars of an 87car Conrail freight train derailed in Metuchen, N.J., last night, tearing down overhead wiring and blocking the four main tracks between Washington and New York City.

title: Panel Scores City U. on SEEK Project
description: The City University's SEEK program for disadvantaged students has been so badly and wastefully managed that its administration should be taken away from the university and put under New York State's Department of Education, the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday.

title: CRUDE IMPORTS IN WEEK OFF 500,000 BARRELS A DAY
description: Crude oil imports for the week ended June 17 dropped to 6.8 million barrels daily from the 7.3 million barrels daily the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Barons Face Deadline
description: CHICAGO, June 22 (AP)The National Hockey League gave the Cleveland Barons until 2 P.M. Eastern daylight Time tomorrow to consummate a sale of the club or the franchise will be considered folded.

title: U.S. Analysts Say Shifts in Soviet Seek Flexibility, Better Planning
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The induction of Leonid T. Brezhnev as President of the Soviet Union last week and the unveiling of a new Soviet Constitution are viewed by topranking Administration analysts as moves aimed at rooting out entrenched bureaucracies curbing the power of the individual republics and improving national economic planning.

title: Home Beat
description: Elsie De Wolfe, as almost everyone knows, was the mother of interior decoratingthe first recognized authority in the field, and the most prominent designer in New York in the first quarter of the 20th century. She died in 1950 in her 90's.

title: Design Notebook
description: LOS ANGELES IT is easy to think, that the most real place in all of Southern California is that vast complex up the Hollywood Freeway known as Universal City. Here, sprawling across 450 acres of North Hollywood, there are rows of storefronts, bodies of water, and one suburban street.

title: May Sales of Used Machinery Rose 29.7 Points Above Old Record
description: Sales of used machinery in May reached a new high for the month, the Machinery Dealers National Association reported yesterday. The trade association said that its monthly index hit 194.7. or 29.7 points higher than the old record, which had been set in May 19174. The index is based on average monthly sales in 1972 as 100.

title: Major League Scores
description: Kelli?? DPCh?? ??, cago 5, San Francisco 5. 2BSwisher, B??,HRBil?? (3), JeMorales(5). SBBuckner, Murcer.

title: Body Found in Pacific Crash
description: AGANA, Guam, June 22 (Reuters)Searchers combing the waters off Wake Island today found the body of a United States Navy crew member but called off the hunt for 15 others missing after a communications plane crashed last, night on the way to Guam from Hawaii. The Navy C130, which flies classified cornmunications missions in the Pacific, crashed into the ocean and exploded in flames, witnesses told Navy officials here. Those aboard were not identified,

title: The V.A. and Medical Schools
description: A little known but critical aspect of the American health care system is the relationship between the Veterans Administration and the nation's medical schools, which work closely together to teach medical students and young doctors to care for all Americans, not just veterans. The relationship has grown tremendously since World War II, to a point of a mutual dependency best illustrated perhaps by the V.A.'s policy of building hospitals near medical school campuses.

title: For $4 to $4,000, Crafts Fair Has It
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y. A few years ago, attendants at the Rhinebeck Craft Fair's main gate were startled to see three couples wheeling empty shopping carts up the asphalt path to the fairgrounds. Hours later the couples returned, their carts overflowing with purchases.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Gov. James B. Langley of Maine yesterday vetoed a bill designed to expedite the processing of environmental permits for the 210mile Maine section of a 500mile natural gas pipeline that Tenneco Inc. had proposed to build from New Brunswick, Canada. to Albany. As planned, the line would pass also through parts of southern New Hampshire. western Massachusetts and eastern New York.

title: Hoboken Pays Tribute to Old Blue Eyes
description: HOBOKEN, June 22Tamby and Skelly had a reunion of sorts today in the reading room of the public library here and reminisced about 1935, the Hoboken Four, and their old friend Slats.

title: Miss Austin Freshens Event In the Chris Evert Tradition
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 22Christine Truman Janes watched Tracy Austin walk on the court to serve for the match against Elly VessiesAppel today.

title: Deficit in Balance Of Payments Sets Quarterly Record
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)  The United States balance of payments, a key indicator of the nation's international economic standing, fell to a record deficit during the first quarter when it sank into the red by $4.3 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Swiss Credit Bank Faces Tax Charges
description: GENEVA, June 22Already facing heavy losses because of the improper handling of $880 million in investor funds by one of its branches, the Swiss Credit Bank must also answer charges of failing to pay $88 million in withholding taxes on the improper dealings.

title: SOPHIE S. JAGENDORF
description: Sophie S. Jagendorf, who began her career as an innovator in modern dance and went on to teach retarded children, died of pneumonia Monday night at her home on 110 Riverside Drive. She was 83 years old.

title: Israeli Labor Party Bounces Back in Union Election
description: TEL AVIV, June 22Israel's Labor Party has bounced back from its crushing defeat in the parliamentary elections of May 17 to win a clear majority yesterday in the General Federation of Labor, retaining control of its administration.

title: Even the Doorkeepers Are Jolly These Days
description: THE BROADWAY theater is in a much jollier state these days, as you can tell if you pay any attention at all to the gentlemensome in tuxedos, some dressed like the rest of uswho take tickets at the door. The chances are that you don't pay much attention to these anonymous figures, any more than you focus your sharp, attention on the chaps selling souvenir programs (whose eyes you are probably trying to avoid, not catch), and, half the time, neither do I. I'm usually talking to someone over my right or left shoulder (lobbies are awfully crowded lately) as I hand over the pasteboards that will admit and sooner or later seat me, and the barest glance is all a doorkeeper is likely to get in the circumstances.

title: Toy Dogs on Parade at N.J. Show
description: The Pekingese has the rolling gait of a sailor and resembles a lion, both in body and temperament. The Shih Tzu has a tail curved like a teacup handle. The Brussels Griffon was once the street urchin. The Papillon's head suggests the outline of a butterfly, and this little dog was favored by both Madame Pompadour and Marie Antoinette. The Pomeranian is a bowl of fluff. The Italian Greyhound was the pet of Frederick the Great. I try to make sentences that would stick in people's memories and point out things not found in the breed standard, explained Mary Brewster, a dogshow judge for more than four decades and the breedof many bestinshow winners.

title: DISSIDENTS IN SOVIET FOUND DEMORALIZED
description: MOSCOW, June 22Recently, Irna Astakhova McClellan was informed once more by the Soviet authorities that she would not be permitted to join her American husband in the United States. The former Moscow teacher has been waiting nearly three years.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The National Orchestral Association, New York's training ensemble for symphony players, will give four concerts in Carnegie Hall under guest conductors during the 197778 season.

title: Dollar Eases in Trading Abroad and Gold Declines to $139.62 an Ounce
description: The dollar, damaged by news of a record firstquarter balance of payments deficit for the United States, closed broadly lower against most other currencies in foreign exchange trading here yesterday, the Associated Press reported.

title: SENATE UNIT REJECTS SACCHARIN BAN DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)Calling it the wrong approach at the wrong time. a Senate committee rejected today a Housepassed proposal to block any Government ban on saccharin for 15 months.

title: Cash Prices
description: Wednesday, June 22, 1977

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON  Economic spokesmen for the Carter Administration are currently suggesting that depreciation allowances may be liberalized under tax reform proposals headed for Congress this summer. Businessmen, meanwhile, welcome the moves but maintain they are long overdue.

title: Calendar of Events for House and Home
description: Some events of interest for enthusiasts of the house and home.

title: Louisiana Legalizes Laetrile
description: BATON ROUGE, La., June 22 (AP)Gov. Edwin W. Edwards has signed into law a bill to allow the manufacture and sale of laetrile in Louisiana. The state is the 10th to permit use of the substance, which some say can treat or cure cancer.

title: Milton FoxMartin Is Dead at 64; International Marketing Executive
description: Milton FoxMartin, an internationally prominent marketing executive who retired six years ago as president of the underwriting division of the Anchor Corporation of Elizabeth, N. J., a major sponsor of mutual funds, died Tuesday in Amsterdam after a short illness. He was 64 years old.

title: EUGENE FOLDES
description: Dr. Eugene Foldes, who practiced internal medicine for more than 50 years at 898 Park Avenue, died Tuesday in his residence at 7 East 85th Street. His age was 86. Dr. Foldes, who was on the staffs of Polyclinic and Lenox Hill Hospitals here, was a graduate of the University of Budapest and became an associate professor at the university before coming to this country.

title: Gellinoff Named His SoninLaw To Jobs That Paid $33,500 in Fees
description: Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff of New York Stale Supreme Court appointed his soninlaw as an arbitrator and a referee in two cases that came before him in 1967 and 1974, positions for which the soninlaw received $33,500 in legal fees.

title: Three Young Men Seized After Dead Girl's Clothes Are Found in South Amboy
description: SOUTH AMBOY, June 22Three young South Amboy men were arrested today after clothing belonging to 15yearold Valerie Tersago, whose nude body was found in Morris County last Friday, was discovered in the apartment of one of the men, authorities said.

title: One Cop, One Car
description: Nothing can frighten the mayor of a large city so much as the specter of largescale disaffection among his police. That is what Mayor Beame faces as members of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association jam their patrol car radios and picket Gracie Mansion in protest against an arbitrator's decisionnot yet publicly announced but widely leakedupholding the dity's right to have one, man rather than two operate patrol cars in lowcrime areas during daylight.

title: Lorillard Sells Rights, On Cigarette Brands
description: The Lorillard division of The Loew's Corporation said yesterday that it had sold rights to make and market its cigarettes outside the United States and American posessions to a British concern for $141 million in cash.

title: Three Are Tied for Lead In L.I. Women's Golf
description: JERICHO, L. I., June 21Chris Desch of Southampton, the openinground leader with a 77, scored a triplebogey 7 on the 347yard final hole today at the Meadow Brook Club and fell into a threeway tie for the lead at 159 in the second round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship.

title: Notes on People
description: IN an unusual move, John S. D. Eisenhower, son of the late President and General Dwight D. Eisenhower, has made available a large selection of Mr. Eisenhower's World War II love letters to his wife, Mamle Eisenhower, in order to refute stories of General Eisenhower's reported wartime romance with Lieut. Kay Summersby.

title: Police in Downtown Detroit Don Old Uniforms for a New Image
description: DETROIT, June 22Are you real police?

title: Panel Backs Curb On C.I.A. Buildup Of a Secret Fund
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The House Appropriations Committee, largely at the prodding of a middleoftheroad Missouri Congressman, has voted to place restrictions on a secret contingency fund that the Central Intelligence Agency has, in the past, used to initiate covert operations without the prior knowledge of Congress.

title: BREZHNEV CONCEDES STRAINS IN U.S. TIES
description: PARIS, June 22President Valery Giscard d'Estaing today said he had learned from his talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev that the Soviet. Union's relations with the United States Were going through a difficult phase.

title: Goldblatt to Assume 2 Korvettes Leases
description: Goldblatt Brothers Inc., a leading Chicagobased department store chain, said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent with Korvettes Inc. to take over the leases of two of the four Korvettes stores in the Chicago area.

title: To Hyphenate or Not to Hyphenate Is Belgrade Issue
description: BELGRADE, June 22Nine neutral nations today suggested inserting some hyphens between clauses of a proposed draft agenda for the conference on EastWest cooperation, hoping to resolve a conflict in the Soviet and Western positions.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOLDSTEINLillian. We express our sincere sympathy to the bereaved. family of Marilyn Friedberg on the passing of her beloved mother. Walter Reichwald, President Laurelton Jewish Center.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk discusses the question of whether weakly led democratic societies can deal effectively with the problem of inflation. Page D5.

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, June 22, 1977

title: Books of The Times
description: AT THIS LATE DATE, it seems superfluous to add to the chorus of praise for Roger Angell's Five Seasons: A Baseball Companion. Yet the facts are inescapable. No one currently practicing, with the possible exceptions of George Plimpton, Red Smith and Norman Mailer, brings to sportswriting quite the combination of precision, humor and respect that Mr. Angell does. There is his gift for delightful metaphor. When [Bob Feller's] searing fastball missed the plate it had the batters jumping around in the box like roasting popcorn. . . . any catcher who has been the battery mate of a star knuckleballer. . . has thus spent six or seven innings groveling in the dirt in imitation of a bulldog cornering a nest of field mice. And Luis Tiantin Five Seasons, it is Boston's venerable pitching star who inspires Mr: Angell's imagination most of allLuis Tiant wheels and rotates on the mound like a figure in Bavarian clock tower. . . . Tiant, noted for odd pitching mannerisms, is also famous mound dawdler, stands on hill like sunstruck archeologist at Knossos. Regards ruins. Studies sun. Studies landscape. Looks at artifact in hand. Wonders: Keep this potsherd or throw it away? Does Smithsonian want it? Hmm. Prepares to throw it away. Pauses. Sudd. discovers writing on object. Hmm. Possible Linear B inscript.? Sighs. Decides. Throws. Wipes face. Repeats whole thing.

title: Site of Tennessee Reactor Called One of Worst in Engineers' Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The engineering company in charge of building the Clinch River breeder reactor concluded four years ago that the planned location of the project was one of the worst sites ever selected for a nuclear power plant based on topography and rock conditions.

title: Rabbi to Testify Pvt, Slovik Was Shot as an Example
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP)A Pentagon panel, considering charges that the World War H execution of Pvt. Eddie Slovik was unjust, agreed today to hear a witness who contends that Private Slovik was selected from among several deserters and shot as an example.

title: Dispute Widens on Naming McKinney to Bank Board
description: The expected nomination of Robert H. McKinney, an Indianapolis banker, as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, is stirring widening controversy. In addition to drawing fire on the ground that bankers should not regulate their own industry, Mr. McKinney is being criticized for possible conflicts of interest in Indiana.

title: Marigolds Versus Bugs
description: Folklore for years has promulgated growing marigolds for insect control. As with many old stories it involves more than a grain of truth. Marigolds have eliminated root nematodes in gardens and fields, and they are grown in the tropics as weevil repellents. The question is, why do they work that way for some gardeners and not for others?

title: Jazz: Pepper Returns With Style
description: ONE BY ONE, jazz stars of the 1950's are emerging from periods of eclipse. Last fall, Dexter Gordon made a triumphal return after many years in Denmark. This week, Art Pepper, one of Stan Kenton's featured saxophonists more than 25 years ago and a star of the West Coast jazz movement of the early 50's who has been inactive during most of the last two decades, is at the Village Vanguard, making his first New York appearance as a leader.

title: OldCrop Soybean Futures Slump; Corn and Oats Hit Contract Lows
description: Prices of the oldcrop soybean futures contracts tumbled about 20 cents a bushel yesterday, bringing the near July delivery down to a sixmonth low of $7.20. The near August delivery, the last of the oldcrop contracts, closed off 19 cents at $7.21.

title: Panel Scores City U. on SEEK Project
description: The City University's SEEN program for disadvantaged students has been so badly and wastefully managed that its administration should be taken away from the university and put under New York State's Department of Education, the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Eddie Stanky's Curious Full Circle
description: For students of baseball geometry, the hiring of Eddie Stanky as the Texas Rangers' manager completes a curious circle. Eddie Stanky succeeded Frank Lucchesi, who succeeded Billy Martin, who now is in jeopardy as the New York Yankees' manager. But not many people know that three years ago Billy Martin, then the Rangers' manager, was thinking about moving upstairs into the Texas front office and hiring Frank Robinson as his successor in the dugout. Instead, the Cleveland Indians selected Frank Robinson as the major league's first black manager. Now the Indians have discharged Frank Robinson, one of the early black teenagers to be scouted after Jackie Robinson had broken baseball's racial barrier with the Brooklyn Dodgers under Branch Rickey, who cherished Eddie Stanky for his intangibles as second baseman. Full circle.

title: Acting Director at Met Museum
description: WHILE THE SEARCH for a new team to run the Metropolitan Museum of Art continues, Philippe de Montebello, vice director for curatorial and educational affairs, has been named acting director, effective July 1. His appointment will enable Thomas Moving, slated to retire from the director's post on Dec. 31. to withdraw from daytoday activities.

title: ASSEMBLY TOUGHENS DEATHPENALTY BILL
description: ALBANY, June 22The Assembly tonight approved an amendment that would add premeditated murder and murder committed during other crimes to the list of murders subject to the death penalty in New York State.

title: A Job Well Done in Spain
description: Spain's first free parliamentary election since the 1930's has been successfully completed, providing the most impressive proof yet of the nation's great strides toward democracy since the death of Francisco Franco only a year and a half ago. Much of the credit must go to King Juan Carlos and his inspired choice of a leader to dismantle the Franco dictatorship, Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez. Though outraged by many of the past year's developmentsespecially the legalization of the Communist Partythe diehard Francoites in the military and elsewhere were deftly outmaneuvered and held at bay; the widely feared rightist coup was forestalled.

title: Film: Rameses vs. Priests In 'Pharaoh' From Poland
description: "PHARAOH," Jerzy Kawalerowicz's Polish-made dramatization of an ancient struggle for power, which opened yesterday at the Thalia more than a dozen years after it was completed, is as much of an enigma as the Sphinx's smile, for its important issues remain simple, obvious and unresolved. The picture is a stately spectacle of evil men triumphing over good intentions with a Cecil B. DeMille-like cast of thousands in panoramic battles or demonstrations.Like such veterans as Andrezj Wajda and Aleksandr Ford, the 65-year-old Mr. Kawalerowicz, remembered for his 1962 mystical 17th-century drama "Joan of the Angels?" again illustrates his fascination with history in "Pharaoh," which he helped adapt from a 19th-century Polish novel. In the film, he focuses on a young, handsome, socially conscious sovereign of an Egypt threatened by its neighbors and dominated by its covetous priests.Rameses' entanglements with his machinating priests, who refuse to relinquish their grip on the people or their secreted treasure, evolves as a series of largely orotund declamations that smack more of debate than drama. If further explanations seem needed for the film's abrupt passages, perhaps they can be attributed to the cutting of a lengthy work.Mr. Kawalerowicz's cameras, moving through authentic, picturesque locales in Luxor, Cairo and Bokhara in Uzbekistan, have captured the vivid colors of Egypt's mammoth temples, pyramids and statuary and the dun desert wastes on which those thousands of extras, lined up in military array, clash to the sounds of roaring voices, horns and drums.Despite the slowly measured pace of his early sequences, the director has elicited grimly sincere but occasionally emotional performances from some of his principals. George Zelnik, as the beleaguered heir to the throne and as the ill-fated Pharaoh, is confused, driven and torn by his desire for supremacy, by an inherent solicitude for his subjects and by the destructive cabals of his priests and foreign powers.Piotr Paulovski is moodily forbidding as the austere, conniving high priest Herhor, who is aided by, among others of his order, the oily, manipulative Stanislav Milski. And, Christine Mikolayevska, as the tragic Hebrew concubine and mother loved by Pharaoh, and Barbara Bryl, as the Assyrian priestess, who seduces him, are not only obviously decorative in near-nude portrayals but also fairly convincing in their involvements with him.Their "Pharaoh," dubbed into English of varying accents is an impressive sweeping, if fairly familiar, picturization of a historical past, even if its humans and their conflicting causes are not fully realized.

title: Public Workers in Chicago Accused of Welfare Fraud
description: CHICAGO, June 22 (UPI)A Federal grand jury has indicted 93 persons including 92 present or former employees of municipal and Federal agencies, on charges that they illegally obtained welfare payments. United States Attorney Samuel K. Skinner announced today.

title: Bill Seeks to Widen PriceFixing Suits
description: WASHINGTON. June 22Congressional and state government antitrust lawyers drafted today a onesentence amendment to the Clayton Antitrust Act that would overrule a June 9th Supreme Court decision limiting the right. to sue for damages where there is pricefixing.

title: COMECON LEADERS STRESS SELFHELP FOR PROBLEMS
description: WARSAW, June 22 (Reuters)Prime ministers at the East European economic summit here today urged a policy of selfhelp by participating states to solve their energy and raw material problems, PAP, the Polish news agency reported.

title: Mitchell Enters Alabama Camp To Serve Term
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 22John N. Mitchell, the first former United States Attorney General to go to prison, arrived here aboard a private jet today and rode to jail in a blue Cadillac to begin his sentence for Watergate crimes.

title: Arguello, 132, Takes the Measure Of Sanchez in 4 Rounds at Garden
description: The methodical but deadly punching of Alexis Arguello provided the only exclamation point to Madison Square Garden's Summer Festival of Boxing program last night, a card that drew an international crowd of 7,364 and fashioned a gate of $67,143.

title: EXKOREA AIDE SAYS K.C.I.A. HELPED SET UP CLUB IN WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 22A former Director of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency, in the first public testimony on the Korean lobbying scandal, disclosed today that the K.C.I.A. had arranged the financing of the exclusive George Town Club here, to which President Ford, many Cabinet officers, Justices of the Supreme Court and numerous Congressmen have belonged over the years,

title: 2 Young Novelists in Japan Reflect the Winds of Change
description: TOKYO, June 18Some unusual, and puzzling, winds of change are blowing through Japan's writing community these days, igniting talk of a radical new literary era in this ancient nation.

title: Around the Nation
description: Around the Nation

title: Gottfried, Panatta Toppled at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 22It was a threering circus at staid old Wimbledon today. Brian Gottfried and Adrian Panatta were beaten, Ilie Nastase turned clown and then threatened to attack a newsman and Billie Jean King and Bjorn Borg were extended to the limits.

title: RONAN MEETS AIDES OF HONDA IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO, June 22Dr. William J. Ronan, the outgoing chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, conferred with officials of Honda Motors and attended a meeting of the World Trade Centers Association during a threeday trip here at public expense.

title: WilkesBarre Reborn, 5 Years After Flood
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., June 22At 11:14 A.M. on June 23, 1972, the Susquehanna River, swollen by tropical storm Agnes, rose to 40 feet. rushed over the dikes and flooded this former coal town, damaging or destroying 25,000 homes, forcing the evacuation of 80,000 people from the area, and leaving in its wake mud, rubble and bitterness, but not despair.

title: Faith May Move Mountains But Muscles Move Ships
Portuguese Workers Demonstrate
description: LISBON, June 22 (AP)More than 100,000 Communistled workers, shaking fists and shouting slogans, marched down Lisbon's main street tonight as part of nationwide labor union protests against th economic programs of Premier Soares.

title: Market Place
description: The protracted takeover battle involving the bid by Anderson, Clayton & Company to acquire the Gerber Products Company saw two more skirmishes yesterday. Anderson, Clayton would appear to have made points in both, but no decisive victory or defeat seemed likely soon.

title: College Graduates in U.S. Volunteer Programs Charge Mistreatment and Threaten Legal Action
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 22Several hundred college graduates who entered Federal volunteer programs threatened today to take legal action to obtain rights they say are being denied them.

title: People and Business
description: Max M. Fisher. chairman of the United Brands Company, yesterday announced that Paul Milstein, 54 years old, had become vice chairman of the board. Mr. Milstein will report to his brother, Seymour, 56, who is president and chief executive of the company. Mr. Fisher, who is 68, said Paul Milstein would be actively engaged in all the company's affairs, particularly in the operations of its subsidiaries.

title: MISS QUINLAN CALLED IN STABLE CONDITION
description: MORRIS PLAINS, June 22Karen Anne Quinlan, who has been in a coma for 26 months and who was removed from a respirator more than a year ago so that she could be allowed to die with dignity, was reported in stable condition today at the Morris View Nursing Home here. Last night she was reported to be dying.

title: Books: Rich Life
description: The need to see Shakespeare plain dies hard in the marrow of modern seholars. No matter that after centuries of Shakespeare studies, he, as a man, remains undefinable, remote; or that the Shakespeare revolution in the theater from William Poel to Peter Brook projects an infinity of images.

title: Broker to Open Connecticut Office
description: Herzfeld & Stern, a New York Stock Exchange member firm, announced that it would open a branch office in Stamford, Conn., early in July. The office, the firm's first in Connecticut, will he at 21 Broad Street.

title: Al Dente designs In Porcelain
description: FORTUNATELY, not all the avantgarde Italian designs of the 1960's have been retired to glass showcases in museums. For a while, however, the Danese Collection, which helped move plastics outof the kitchen and into the living room a decade ago, seemed threatened with that fate. If that had happened, New Yorkers might never have seen the extraordinary bowls and vases Enzo Mari has designed for the Milanbased accessories producer. The ceramic vessels are both witty and sensual; they look, in fact, as though they were fashioned of pasta, not porcelain.

title: Alien Politics Instead of Policy
description: By admitting 800 Mexican farm workers at the request of some Texas onion growers, the White House has cast doubt on its own ability to deal consistently with the tide of illegal aliens. The Department of Labor turned down the original request of the growers of Presidio, whereupon the House majority leader, Representative James C. Wright Jr., of Texas, appealed to the White House, which persuaded the Justice Department to order the workers admitted in the national interest.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Is the industrial world in a lull before a storm  what could become the most stvere storm in half a century? A lot of European investors think so, and are moving billions of dollars in flight capital to the United States  as happened in the 1930's  because this country is considered the safest haven in a world that might crack apart. New York securities dealers, investment counselors and

title: 23,000 MINERS STRIKING IN DISPUTE OVER BENEFITS
description: About 23,000 southern Appalachian coal miners stayed away from work in a wildcat strike yesterday, protesting reductions in union health benefits that were caused by financial problems in the United Mine Workers health and retirement funds, The Associated Press reported.

title: Homer by Nettles, Jackson's Double Score 5 in 8th
description: DETROIT, June 22Billy Martin called tonight's game between the Yankees and Tigers a laugher, but he did not really mean it beause the score was 1211 and either team could have won.

title: U.S. Businessmen In Cuba for Talks On Trade Outlook
description: SANTA MARIA DEL MAR, Cuba, June 22 (Reuters)An American delegation of businessmen, including some from major corporations, is holding talks with Cuban officials on prospects for trade between the two countries.

title: About New York
description: The Vietnamese refugee family of Le Thanh Hoang Dan, striving to root itself now for two years in Flushing, Queens, has lost its eldest daughter to a ocnfessed murdererrapist and Vietnam vetran who entered a plea of insanity this week: He said he had killed her because he had thought he was interrogating a Vietcong back in Vietnam.

title: The U.S. and Arab Oil
description: The conduct of United States foreign relations continues to be handicapped by the energy question. American dependence on a single oil supplier, Saudi Arabia, will give that country considerable leverage and the ability to impose almost singlehandedly another embargo if it chooses to do so.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Joan C. Geiler, at 54, Lawyer;  Wife of a Supreme Court Justice
description: Joan C. Geiler, wife of Justice William R. Geiler of State Supreme Court, died yesterday in North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a lingering illness. She lived at 17 Taylor Road, Huntington, L.I., and was 54 years old.

title: To Limit the Role Of U.S. Companies
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)President Carter, saying foreign boycotts go to the very heart of free trade between all nations, today signed compromise legislation aimed at limiting the involvement of United States corporations in the Arab boycott of Israel.

title: U.S. Believes He's Alive
description: WASHINGTON, June 22The State Department said today that it believed President Amin was alive.

title: Japan's Auto Output Off in Month
description: TOKYO, June 22 (UPI)Japan's auto, mobile production totaled 683,097 units in May, down 2.8 percent from April, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association reported today. Still, this May's production set a record for the month and was up 8.7 percent over May 1976.

title: The Standings
description: Thursday, June 23, 1977

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Gardens are in a profusion of bloom everywhere, and many household objects are brightened with a sprig or two. Florals are legion on china, fabrics, wallcoverings and domestic linens. But there are some things they rarely appear on, and the fun of the decorativehorticultural chase is to find them on unexpected objects. Plumbing fixtures, for example. Sherle Wagner has just come out with some flowersprinkled apartmentsized sinks for those with bathrooms of negligible dimension. After all, why should one be penalized for having a small loo? Flowers circle the outside of each bowl and run down the baseartichoke blossoms, chrysanthemums, water lilies, in a variety of colors. There are eight handpainted patterns in all, some with a choice of color combinations. You can get matching bathroom tiles, soap dishes, jars and the like. Basins, 23 inches across, stand on a gracefully curving pedestal suggestive of a flower stem. Prices start at $625, without faucets. The eightinchsquare tiles, also handpainted, come in various patterns. They are $7.80 to $20 each. Sherle Wagner is at 60 East 57th Street.

title: Suspended Bristol Sees Pocoroba Connect in 2d
description: With five majorleague managers having lost their jobs already this season, Dave Bristol lost his for the second time in six weeksbut again, only temporarily.

title: State Senate Approves Carey's Plan To Produce Jobs With Construction
description: ALBANY. June 22The Republicancontrolled Senate, with some grumbling criticism of Governor Carey for not moving more expeditiously with his economicdevelopment program for the state, gave its approval this evening to the Governor's proposed $750 million bond issue to finance jobproducing construction projects.

title: Carter Praises Saudi Arabia
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (Reuters)President Carter praised Saudi Arabia for its cooperation wi??. the United States as he bade farewell today to John West, the new Ambassador to that country. There has not been any nation in the world that has been more cooperative than Saudi Arabia, he said, alluding to its efforts to limit oilprice increases by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Plan Called for Sites to Produce Income
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that an 11yearold program to build New York City public schools in combination with private incomeproducing housing and businesses did not adequately fulfill any of the purposes for which it was established.

title: At Your Service
description: IT USED TO be,that the only way one could learn the craft of custom woodworking was to be apprenticed to an expert. But in Manhattan recently, woodworking schools have been popping upand prospering teaching hundreds of people the arts of custom cabinetmaking, finishing, woodcarving, framemaking and even how to build a doll house, It's kind of an explosion, said Jerry Gerber, a director of one of the schools that teaches woodworking, its practical ap plications and how it can save one money.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended May 31 unless other. wise Indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) OvertheCounter.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 23, 1977

title: Senate Backs Inland Shipping Fees
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)The Senate voted today to impose fees on ship and barge owners on most of the nation's inland waterways.

title: Convicted L.I. Wife Slayer to Get $60,000 in Settlement of Will
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 22Dr. Charles E. Friedgood, who was convicted of murdering his wife, Sophie, will receive $60,000 worth of bonds from the total of $600,000 in securities he was convicted of stealing from her.

title: CARTER IS COMING TO NEW YORK CITY
description: With the personal touch or a local politician running for district leader, President Carter will work the tables at a $1,000aticket dinner in New York City tonight.

title: Cabaret: 5 High Heeled Comics
description: ANY GATHERING of standup comics is likely to produce a mixed bag of results. In this sense, the five comics who make up the cast of High Heeled Women at Barbarann, 349 West 46th Street, follow form. But there is a difference in that all five are women and the overall balance is tipped in their favor by the enthusiasm with which they leap into their routines.

title: Stage: Cracks Has Holes
description: THERE IS a certain perverse glee in telling a bad joke. Even good joke is told at the momentary expense of the hearers; for one split second, before they see the point, the rug is twitched from under them.

title: Dr. Bruce C. Heezen, 53, Dies; Mapped Ocean Floors
description: Dr. Bruce C. Heezen, a pioneer in mapping the ocean floors, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, aboard a submarine that was about to explore submerged, midAtlantic mountains that had been a focus of his career. He was 53 years old.

title: Court Asked to End Parking Ban
description: Saying it was virtually impossible to conform with some provisions of the courtordered ban on parking in midtown Manhattan, the city yesterday urged the Federal District Court to discard the parking plan that went into effect last week or to grant a sixmonth stay that would allow the city and the state to come up with a better plan.

title: $300 Million Hearst Contract Signed by World Color Press
description: The City Investing Company announced that its subsidiary, World Color Press Inc., had signed a 10year printing contract valued at more than $300 million with the Hearst Corporation.

title: Unveilings
description: COHEN  Lena. A Monument to the memory of Lana Cohen, Thursday, June 23d, 1 P.M., Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

title: New U.S.British Air Pact Will Affect Travel Habits
description: The agreement on a new BritishAmerican air treaty yesterday made alterations in the pattern of airline routings that will significantly affect transAtlantic travel habits.

title: Screen: Clanking 'Matatabi'
description: KON ICHIKAWA, one of Japan's top-flight and veteran directors known here principally for such contemporary subjects as the World War II "Fires on the Plain" and "Tokyo Olympiad," is artistic but unclear in his period drama, "Matatabi," which arrived yesterday as the final offering in the Regency Theater's Japanese film series. His saga of wandering gangs of the 1840's may shed light on a little-known facet of Nipponese history, but his script is as circuitous as his peripatetic principals.The existence, actions and, above all, strange ethical codes of these so-called "toseinin," or errant, peasant swordsmen for hire, are made fairly clear with the aid of an off-screen narrator and English subtitles. And it is also evident that they are dependent on the local, petty 'bosses" they protect, and on their laws, by which they live.The three young, unkempt peasant swordsmen in "Matatabi" adhere to the ritualistic demands of their code as they earn their keep by beating a rival gang of gamblers. But the going thereafter is as complicated as a maze.Moreover, these complications smack of contrivance as Genta, one of the "toseinin," discovers that his father, who deserted the family for more exciting, profitable fields, is now planning to undermine Genta's gambler-boss. This leads not only to patricide, according to the code, but also to ostracism from the local gang. And, on and on, to the final decimation of the once cohesive trio into one aimless wanderer.The director makes an interesting point of stressing the power of a code that could bind such lower-class young men in loyalty to the death for a mere pittance of patronage. And, as in previous films, he has captured eye-catching scenes of picturesque beauty, as well as the prescribed, fairly constant vignettes of often gory action.He has also elicited tender sequences between Ichiro Ogura, as the driven Genta, and Reiko Inoue, as the young farm woman who leaves her husband for him. If Isao Bito and Kenichi Ogihara also display nuances of genuine emotion as members of his brotherhood, they are, in the main, wanderers through a complex series of foggy, seemingly unfinished adventures.

title: 11 Countries Agree on $750 Million Loan to Portugal
description: PARIS, June 22The United States and of 10 other rich countries agreed today to lend Portugal $750 millionjust half the amount the United States had originally proposed  to shore up its still shaky democratic regime.

title: Plan Called for Sites to Produce Income
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that an 11yearold program to build New York City public schools in combination with private incomeproducing housing and businesses did not adequately fulfill any of the purposes for which it was established.

title: Deaths
description: ATKINLilla. Loving sister of Jack Atkin. Devoted aunt of Lynn, Adrien and Jack. Services Thursday 11 A.M. The Riverside, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to the Cancer Fund would be appreciated.

title: British Envoy Is Returning Home Really Comforted About U.S
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  Her Britannic Majesty's Ambassador to Washington took a onceoverlightly glance today at the country where he has spent seven of his 29 years as a diplomat and then said to a group of Americans. I think you are in for a good time.

title: Fred Corcoran Dies
description: Fred Corcoran, a widely known golf promoter and executive, died at the age of 72 yesterday. Obituary on D13.

title: Space Agency's New Chief Robert Alan Frosch
description: The new chief of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reached space by way of the sea, which is not as unlikely a route as it might seem. Throughout his careerin underwater acoustics, Navy research and development, and nucleartest detectionDr. Robert A. Frosch has established an impressive record as a manager of complex scientific and engineering endeavors. This experience should stand the 49yearold Dr. Frosch in good stead as he takes over this week as NASA administrator, replacing Dr. James C. Fletcher, who resigned after six years in the post. Dr. Frosch's appointment by President Carter was confirmed last week by the Senate.

title: Steinbrenner Avows His Support of Paul
description: Mayor Beame took an hour out from the cares of his office yesterday afternoon to watch the Mets and Yankees play the annual Mayor's Trophy exhibition game at Shea Stadium and immediately found that, with the Yankees at least, there are as many complications in baseball as in the city's fiscal crisis or its eightway Democratic primary.

title: SPEAR IS GIVEN APPROVAL TO COMPETE IN 19 STOCKS
description: Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, the largest specialist unit at the New York Stock Exchange, has received approval to begin competing in the 19 stocks registered with the specialist unit of Blair S. Williams & Company, the exchange announced yesterday.

title: Other Jazz Pests In Manhattan
description: The NewportNew York Jazz Festival, which begins today, is not the only jazz festival in town. Four musicianrun lofts. are presenting festivals of their own during part or all of Newport's 11day run.

title: Wreck Brings Excitement to Residents of Metuchen
description: METUCHEN, June 23There was almost a carnival atmosphere here today as a result of the 17car freight train derailment last night.

title: A Small Gain In Chile
description: Twentysix hunger strikers have forced Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the iron ruler of Chile, to give a little groundbut not muchon the question of the approximately 1,500 persons who have disappeared in Chile.

title: Freight Derailment in Jersey Disrupts Amtrak Service
description: METUCHEN, N.J., June 23Rail service for at least 30.000 commuters and longdistance travelers on Amtrak's busy BostontoWashington corridor remained disrupted today because of a freighttrain derailment at the southern tip of the business district here last night.

title: Cottrell Gets Post
description: CULLOWEE, N.C., June 23 (UPI)Steve Cottrell, an assistant basketball coach at Southern Methodist, was named head coach at Western Carolina today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The caption under a picture on page 1 of yesterday's editions identified a visitor to the White House as Under Secretary of Commerce Sidney Harman. It was Alfred H. Moses, a vice president of the American Jewish Committee.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: The uniforms and equipment have all been bought, the name tapes affixed, the trunks packed and shipped and all that remains are the farewells before the big separationof sleepaway camp.

title: Restaurants
description: GALLAGHER'S, the 44yearold steak house on 52d Street just west of Broadway, is one of the local landmarks we tend to take for granted. But a few weeks ago, leaving a theater at 10:30 completely starved, we remembered that Gallagher's stayed open late and so a group of six walked in unrecognized and without a reservation. The total experience that followed was altogether felicitous and satisfying.

title: WILLIAM MALLARD
description: William Mallard, a former vice president and general counsel for RKO General Inc., died Monday in an Annandale, Va., nursing home. He was 77 years old and a resident of MacLean, Va. Mr. Mallard, who retired from RKO in 1948 after 30 years of service, was a graduate of the Colimbia University Law School. He leaves two sons, William Jr. and Cole.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY. JUNE 24. 1977

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Alumax Inc., an integrated aluminum company with headquarters at San Matec, Calif., yesterday announced plans to build a $400 million primary aluminum reduction plant at a site to be chosen in either Berkeley or Georgetown County, S. C.

title: Who's Doing What, Where and When
description: Friday

title: Out of Doors
description: THEY HAVE NAMES like Screaming Eagle and Excalibur 2, and they look easy to build. That is why these days all my loose change goes into buying engines and all my free hours are spent shooting off rockets somewhere over Long Island.

title: Fred Corcoran, 72, Pro Golf Promoter and Executive
description: Fred Corcoran, whose 60year association with golf as a promoter and an executive helped build the sport to its present stature, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 23, 1977

title: Around the Nation
description: OAKLAND, Calif, June 23 (UPI) Twentyone friends of Wendy Yoshimura Patricia Hearst's underground companion: put up $50,000 today to help her remain free on bail while she appeals her conviction in an explosives case.

description: Plays

title: What the Chinese Forces Lack: Most Types of Modern Weapons
description: China's appetite for modern weaponry could prove insatiable should the United States ever decide to offer it sophisticated weapons.

title: BANKERS ARE TAKEN ON TOUR OF NEWARK
description: NEWARK, June 23Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and development officials led a bus tour of 45 bank and other finance executives through the city today to encourage investment in the selfimprovement program of the state's largest urban center.

title: U.S. Study Sees Peril in Selling Arms to China
description: WASHINGTON, June 23A major policy review in the Carter Administration has concluded that the sale of United States military technology to China would lead to a fundamental reassessment of Soviet policies toward the United States and an increase of tension between Moscow and Peking.

title: Dispute Delays Accreditation Of City U. Unit
description: Reaccreditation of the Borough of Manhattan Community College has been held up because of questions about why an evaluation team's critical report was replaced by a more favorable document.

title: Where to Launch
description: The Bronx. Ferry Point Park, at the Whitestone Bridge.

title: Petrofina to Sell Refinery
description: American Petrofina Inc. and the Dorchester Gas Corporation said in Dallas that they had signed a letter of intent for Dorchester, in its first venture into crude oil refining, to buy Petrofina's Mt. Pleasant, Tex., 26,000 barreladay refinery.

title: Medieval Merriment for a Summer Night
description: Hankering after pike with dandelions or a cool tankard of cuckoo foot ale? Been some time since you've watched a good duel? Maybe you'd just like to lean back and gnaw a bone while jesters cavort to the sound of lutes and shawms.

title: Zuccotti Says His Goodbyes Amid Praise and Predictions
description: The empty cardboard boxes for John E. Zuccotti's belongingsthe papers. mementos and office detritus from his 19 turbulent months as First Deputy Mayorwere hauled into City Hall the other day. Mr. Zuccotti quickly ordered them hidden in a closet.

title: Market Place
description: The Sunshine Mining Company, operator of the nation's largest silver mine in the Coeur d'Alene district of northern Idaho, has an allyat least indirectlyin the Idaho Attorney General.

title: Stiffer Teacher Test Upsets Blacks in South Carolina
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., June 23Increases in minimum scores required for teacher certification in South Carolina threaten to almost eliminate the hiring of new black teachers and may set the stage for a Supreme Court test on the use of written examinations for the hiring of teachers.

title: Dispute Delays Accreditation Of City U. Unit
description: Reaccreditation of the Borough of Manhattan Community College has been held up because of questions about why an evaluation team's critical report was replaced by a more favorable document.

title: High Prices Bid For Oil Leases
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 23 (AP)The Gulf Oil Corporation bid $378 million to buy oil and gas rights. in the Gulf of Mexico, setting the pace for unexpectedly high prices in today's sale of offshore leases.

title: COOK GIVES UP SEAT ON BOARD OF TRADE
description: MEMPHIS, June 23 (UPI)Cook Industries, stung by yearend losses of $87.4 million, has given up its seat as a clearing member on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Red Sox Beat Orioles, 7 to 3, For 7th in Row
description: BALTIMORE, June 23 (AP)  Butch Hobson drove in two runs, one with a home run that extended Boston's homerrecord streak to 30 in nine consecutive games, and the Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles tonight, 73, and completed a fourgame sweep.

title: Met Nets Verrocchio Dolphin
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has landed a 500year old sculpture of a winged boy hugging a slippery fish done by Andrea del Verrocchio and, before it gets away on July 3, you can see it in the central court of the Lehman Pavilion.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: TV Weekend:
description: THE television schedule has slipped quietly into a typical pattern of summer sluggishness, but it is not without occasional offbeat forays that, for good or ill, can Jeave the viewer startled. One unusual project, scheduled for this afternoon at 3:15 on Channel 13, is called Documenta 6.

title: Soviet Women Set Record
description: DORCHESTER, England, June 23 (Reuters)The Soviet Union's women's trapshooting team set a world record of 277 points of a possible 300 at the European championships today. The performance was 2 points better than the previous record set by another Soviet team in Czechoslovakia last year.

title: Foyt Edges Rutherford For Pocono 500 Pole
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., June 23 (UPI) A.. J. Foyt upstaged Johnny Rutherford with a late qualifying start today and won the pole position for Sunday's Pocono 500mile race with a twolap average speed of 189.44 miles per average speed of 189.44 miles per hour.

title: Chileans Stage Protest in Geneva
description: GENEVA, June 23 (Reuters)Eight Chilean political retugeesfive women and three menbegan a hunger strike today in the hall of the international Red Cross Committee headquarters here to protest what they described as the disappearance of 2,500 people in Chile.

title: McKinney Is Named To Home Loan Board
description: As expected, President Carter yesterday nominated Robert H. McKinney, an Indianapolis banker, to be chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: People and Business
description: William. J. Koslo, 47 years old, executive vice president of the Diamond International Corporation since 1973, has been named president and chief executive of the diversified lumber and paper products company. Mr. Koslo, who joined the company in 1955 and has spent his entire career with Diamond, succeeds as chief executive officer Richard J. Walters, 47, who last month asked for and was granted a temporary leave of absence as chairman, president and chief executive of the company.

title: New Water Purity Standards
description: Adult Americans drink from one and a half to four or more quarts of water a day, depending on the climate they live in, the kind of work they do, how big they are and other factors.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions.

title: MILTON ARONS DEAD; UNION MEDICAL AIDE
description: Milton Arons, a prominent figure in trade union health services, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital, He was 60 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Sander Vanocur Gets Post at ABC
description: Sander Vanocur, television editor of The Washington Post and former network correspondent, has been named vice president in charge of special reporting units of ABC Television, supervising political and investigative reporting from Washington.

title: Carey Signs a Measure Designed To Bar Excessive Finance Charges
description: ALBANY, June 23Governor Carey signed into law today a bill designed to protect consumers from excessive finance charges by prohibiting the previous balance method of computing charges on credit accounts.

title: Art People
description: WE OPEN IN Sao Paulo Oct. 1, and in Paris the same date. That is, despite the usual dearth of money for mounting shows, plans are firm for United States participation in Brazil's Sao Paulo Bienal, the major art event in Latin America, and the 10th Biennale de Paris (for artists under 35), according to the International Exhibitions Committee of the American Federation of Arts. And we are looking towards a United States show for the controversial Venice Biennale which, late word has it, will open as usual next June (it was last held in 1976) without the big display of dissident art from Eastern Europe pushed by the Biennale Council itself but strongly opposed by the Russiants.

title: Excerpts From Decision on Grand Central Terminal
description: Grand Central Terminal is no ordinary landmark. It may be true that no property has economic value in the absence of the society around it, but how much more true it is of a railroad terminal, set amid a metropolitan population, and entirely dependent on a heavy traffic of travelers to make it an economically feasible operation. Without people Grand Central would never have been a successful railroad terminal, and without the terminal, a major transporation center, the proposed building site would be much less desirable for an office building.

title: Bluefish Are Popping Up Near Margate and Ridge
description: AREA A  Bluefishing has been generally excellent in this area. Dave Goldner of Margate, N. J., and Chuck Furimsky of Ocean City hauled in 48 blues in less than five hours on Wednesday morning. They were fishing about seven miles off Margate, using spinning rods with surface popping plugs, and their catch weighed in at 389 pounds. Blues have also been plentiful on the Ridge, with catches averaging 6 to S pounds at night and 3 to 5 pounds in the daytime. A large school of blues has moved to within 15 miles of Seaside Park, and catches have been made with poppers and plugs that range from 5 to 12 pounds. Fluke has also been a popular catch, especially in the bays around Margate, in Bernegat Inlet and in Manasquan Inlet.

title: Bridge:
description: The great majority of American players who participate in European tournaments do so as members of groups organized under the banner of Charles Goren. Goren has long been retired from such activities, and the mastermind for the Goren enterprises is Harold Ogust of New York, who won many national titles before he decided to concentrate on the business side of bridge.

title: Art: A Survey Of Eva Hesse
description: FOR THE INAUGURAL exhibition in its handsome new quarters at 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, the DrollKolbert Gallery is presenting a survey of the work of the late Eva Hesse (through July 15). At the time of her death in 1970, at the age of 34, Miss Hesse had already earned a certain renown as one of the more innovative artists of the 1960's. The memorial exhibition organized by the Guggenheim Museum two years ago gave a wider public its first comprehensive glimpse oi. her work, and a recent monograph on the artist by Lucy Lippard provides an indispensable guide to its character and development. The interest of the DrollKolbert show is twofold: it brings together some of the work we already know, shows certain other works that were not included in the Guggenheim exhibition and will therefore be new to most viewers of the exhibition.

title: Commodity Price Index Declines 1.8 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 206.4 from 208.2 last week.

title: Newport's Back in Town
description: AFTER 24 years, six of them in New York, the Newport Jazz Festival still thrives on an unsettled formula.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Boarding House Fire Kills 4 in Sea Bright

title: Junior Yankees Win
description: In a contest held yesterday morning at Shea Stadium. the Junior Yankees defeated the Junior Mets, 104. in the 37th annual Greater New York Sandlot Alliance allstar game.

title: Dance: Exuberance at Stuttgart and City Ballets
description: THERE IS A WEIRD summer madness that overtakes ballet audiences at this time of the year. For example, at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night, where the Stuttgart Ballet was dancing, very nicely I must say, Glen Tetley's Voluntaries. Toward the end, a man in the orchestra was so overcome by the sheer beauty of it all that he groaned loudly in ecstasy. Elsewhere on both sides of the Lincoln Center plazaaudiences applaud quite modest dance feats as if the choreographic millennium had come, and cheer as if they were at a ball game and, for once, a New York team was actually winning, Weird.

title: Topics
description: Probably no one polled grandmother or even motherabout optional life styles for women. But today's teenagers are being asked, and despite an obvious awareness of women's needs, a good number of them still need help.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday.

title: Report Shows Byrne Supporters Spent $90,000 on Primary Day
