description: Implementation of a state law requiring many of the state's Medicaid recipients to pay part of their fees for drugs and medical supplies was halted pending a court trial, when a Federal District Court judge issued a preliminary injunction late Thursday.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S.A.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 4 (AP)A bomb planted by a Moslem separatist group exploded at Bangkok airport today, wounding four persons and setting off panic among hundreds of others, the police said.

title: Carter Owes No U.S. Tax for '76 But He Volunteers to Pay $6,000
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  President Carter offered today to make a voluntary payment of $6,000 to the Government after his 1976 income tax return showed that, because of investment credits and deductions, he owed no tax on a gross income of almost $55,000 for that year.

title: A Smoky Fire Routs Trade Center Diners
description: A smoky fire broke out on the 46th floor of the World Trade Center's Tower No. 1 last night interrupting the dinners of 1,000 patrons at the. Windows on the World restaurant on the 107th floor. A police officer who battled the fire and two cleaning women were admitted to Beekman Downtown Hospital for treatment for smoke inhalation.

title: BLACK AFRICAN PICKED AS LUTHERAN LEADER
description: A black activist bishop from Tanzania yesterday became the first African and the first of his race to head the 58 millionmember Lutheran World Federation.

title: Foster Parents Defy Court on Girl, 3
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered the Bronx County sheriff to begin searching for a 3yearold girl whose foster parents defied a court order to surrender her to her natural father after an eightmonth custody fight.

title: Justices Broaden  Power of States. To Give Aid to Parochial Schools
description: WASHINGTON, June 24In a ruling that strengthens the power of states to aid parochial education, the Supreme Court held today that sates may finance therapeutic, remedial and guidance counseling services for parochial schoolchildren as long as the services are provided at peutral sites off the school premises.

title: Senate Turns Down Funds to Carry Out Carter Pardon Plan
description: WASHINGTON. June 24Rejecting appeals to heal the wounds of war, the Senate refused today to give the Administration money to carry out President Carter's pardon of Vietnam draft resisters.

title: General Dynamics and Beech Aircraft Say They Have Held Preliminary Merger Talks
description: The General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis, and the Beech Aircraft Corporation of Wichita, Kan., said yesterday that they had held preliminary merger discussions.

title: New York City Tax Base Declines
description: New York City's propertytax base shrank this year by $215 million to a new total of $38.611 billion, according to the City Tax Commission. It was the second decline in the total value of taxable teal estate in 34 years.

title: L.I. Village Faces Federal Action On Vile Smell From Incinerator
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 24East, west or south, no matter which way the wind blowsexcept northpeople complain about the Roslyn Incinerator.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: HAPTFORIX, June 24 (Reuters)The SCM Corporation opened its $1.76 billion antitrust suit against the Xerox Corporation today by asserting that Xerox had built a wall of patents to stifle competition in the copier field.

title: Egypt Says That Links With Soviet Are Still Strained
description: CAIRO, June 24The Government of President Anwar elSadat, which has been feuding with the SoViet Union for the last five years, declared today that the time for reconciliation between the two countries was not yet at hand.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope Warns Rebel Prelate of Irreparable Break
description: ROME, June 24Pope Paul VI has warned a suspended French prelate that he risks an irreparable break with the Roman Catholic Church if he goes ahead with plans to ordain 14 priests next Wednesday in defiance of a papal ban.

title: Soccer
description: NORTH AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Dollar Off in New York But Is Mixed in Europe; Advance Shown by Gold
description: The dollar had mixed fortunes yesterday, declining broadly in New York, easing in three European countries and rising in three others, The Associated Tress reported.

title: Croatian Leader's Home Bombed
description: PITTSBURGH, June 24 (UPI)A predawn explosion today ripped through the suburban Pittsburgh home of the president of the Croatian Fraternal Union of America, John Podovinac. The police said there were no reports of injuries. Mr. Podovinac was reportedly vacationing with his family.

title: Miss Evert Ousts Tracy Austin, 61, 61; Nastase and Gerulaitis Also Advance
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 24Chris Evert remembers nothing about her endless summer of '71, but she will user forget today's first meeting with Tracy Austin on the center court at Wimbledon.

title: Pleasant Tales of Conspiracy
description: MADRIDIt pleases the agile Mediterranean mind to explain political events in terms of conspiratorial theory and nowhere is this addiction more enthusiastically evident than in Spainabove all since true freedom has removed any threat that flights of fancy might incur punishment from the state.

title: Spoleto Open Its 20th Festival
description: SPOLETO, Italy, June 23To the delight of opera buffs, theater lovers, music enthusiasts, and boutique, gallery and restaurant owners and hotelkeepers, the Spoleto festival opened last night in this small Umbrian town.

title: Beirut Hit by Strike Of MoneyChangers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 (Reuters) Lebanon's leading moneychangers suspended operations today to protest the lack of security in postwar Lebanon, following a coolly executed daylight robbery here yesterday.

title: Morales's Bat Helps Reuschel to No.10
description: CHICAGO, June 24The struggling Mets stepped smack into the intensity of the, National League East pennant race today and got flattened by the Chicago Cubs, 50.

title: Junior Jumper Title Won By The Poet at Middlesex
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 24The Poet, owned by Mrs. Patricia Millner and handled by her daughter, Leslie, scored 13 points and won the junior jumper championship today at the Middlesex County Horse Show. The show, which runs through Sunday, is being held at Johnson Park.

title: HOUSE FUNDS MISSILE, PUTS OFF VOTE ON B1
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)Over Carter Administration objections, the House today approved funds for a nonnuclear version of the Lance missile. It put off any vote on the B1 bomber.

title: Accord on SouthWest Africa Seen
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 24Roelof F. Botha said here today that he foresaw an agreement that would bring independence by the end of next year to SouthWest Africa, the territory also known as Namibia.

title: Carter Begins Talks ion Tightening Budget for 1979
description: WASHINGTON, June 24.  President Carter intends to submit his budget for the fiscal year 1979 to Congress next January with a substantially reduced deficit. As part of the budget review process to meet this goal, he has just established lean preliminary projections covering spending by agencies and departments.

title: School With Heart Graduates 40
description: In a cap and red gown, 18yearold Kevin Carro awaited the first graduation ceremony of his experimental school yesterday and thought himself lucky.

title: Senate Turns Down Funds to Carry Out Carter Pardon Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 24Rejecting appeals to heal the wounds of war, the Senate refused today to give the Administration money to carry out President Carter's pardon of Vietnam draft resisters.

title: McGovern Endorses Mrs. Abzug
description: Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, who lost the Presidential race to Richard M. Nixon in a landslide in 1972, ndorsed Bella S. Abzug for Mayor yesterday, citing her personal force, dramatic flair and political insights. The Senator said that he was not sure whether his endorsement would help Mrs. Abzug. But, I feel better now that I have decided to offer it, he added.

title: Town Official Helps Rescue Pilot in Lagoon
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. June 24A small helicopter crashlanded into a purification lagoon next to the town of North Hempstead's incinerator here today, and a Town Commissioner dived into the water and helped rescue the pilot.

title: A Correction: White, Not Wright
description: We apologize to Representative James C. Wright Jr. of Texas, the House majority leader, for wrongly charging him with the intervention at the White House that caused the Justice Department to override the Labor Department and admit 800 Mexican farm workers for the onion growers in Presidio. Our editorial deploring the decision should have wagged a finger at Representative Richard C. White, of the Presidio region. His office notes that the growers would have paid the Mexicans the prevailing wage of $2.83 an hour, as required by the Labor Department, but are able to pay less because Labor's refusal set the stage for a special immigration exemption.

title: PRINCETON BUILDING FUSION TEST DEVICE
description: PRINCETON, June 24Site preparation is beginning on Princeton University's vast Forrestal campus for construction of a factory that will house the world's largest fusion test reactor.

title: News Summary
description: With a commitment for a higher average rate of economic growth next year as a means of cutting back rising unemployment, the United States and other major industrial nations of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development ended their ministerial meeting in Paris. An average growth rate of 5 percent for next year is the goal of the organization's 24 member countries. This is one percentage point more than the 4 percent average rate the countries in aggregate are likely to achieve this year. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: POLICE OFFICER DISMISSED. AFTER COURT CONVICTION
description: A police officer was given a conditional discharge following his conviction in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday of attempted assault, harassment and menacing a cab driver who, in defense, swung his umbrella at another police officer, hitting him in the eye and killing him.

title: Obsession Wins Trysail Division
description: BLOCK ISLAND, June 24Obsession clinched first place in the cumulative standing of the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island Week racing regatta today by winning her final Division F race of the series.

title: Golfers to Pay Tribute
description: PLYMOUTH, Ind., June 24 (UPI)The men's and women's professional golf tours will pay tribute to Fred Corcoran, the former golf official who died yesterday at the age of 72. Play will be suspended for one minute at noon tomorrow in the women's Hoosier Classic in Plymouth and in the men's Western open in Oak Brook, Ill., as a tribute to Mr. Corcoran.

title: Memarial Seruires
description: LYRASNicholas M. A memorial service commemorating the 40 day anniversary of his death will be celebrated at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral on East 74M St., en Sunday, June 26, at 11 A.M. An Agapl will be, sponsored after the service by Nicholas A. and Gewalt Lyres. His beloved Meal wife. MARIA, will be sponsoring a simultaneous macs in Greece, his sister Man, in London.

title: Chen's 138 Leads in Japan
description: SHIZUOKA, Japan, June 24 (AP)Chen Chienchung of Taiwan fired a threeunderpar 69 today for a onestroke lead at the halfway mark of the $90,000 Shizuoka open golf tournament. Chen, who had started the secondday play one stroke off the pace, had a 36hole total of 138. The field of 132 players, including 16 amateurs, was cut to 66 pros and five amateurs with scores of 149 or better for the final two rounds, tomorrow and Sunday.

title: New Report Offers Description of Jobs Available in U. S
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)There is a need for typists in New York. for weavers in South Carolina and for teachers in South Dakota, according to a Labor Department listing of the nation's most abundant lob openings.

title: Women Learn How To Start a Business
description: The swelling demand for information from thousands of women in the New York area who want to start their own businesses was the impetus for a recent daylong conference at the New School for Social Research.

title: USAC Loses Citicorp Pact Over Foyt
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., June 24 (AP)  A.J. Foyt's public behavior after he qualified yesterday for the pole position in Sunday's Schaefer 500 apparently will cost $350,000 to $400,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Samuel Gompers Vocational High School in The Times en June 13 incorrectly reported that Hank Crystal, a teacher at the school, had said: We were all looking forward to a black principal because we thought it could be a good experience. But We're still waiting for the real black. principal. The remark was made by a former student.

title: PRINCETON BUILDING FUSION TEST DEVICE
description: PRINCETON, N.J June 24Site preparation is beginning on Princeton University's vast Forrestal campus for construction of a factory that will house the world's largest fusion test reactor.

title: Market Gairis in Heavy Trading; Dow Closes at 929.70, Up by 4.33
description: The stock market advanced along a wide front yesterday in continued heavy trading.

title: Consumer Notes
description: With motors in cars and boats being revved up for vacations at the shore, the New Jersey State Safety Council is offering a lot of sound advice on how to avoid accidents.

title: FED VOTED TO NUDGE FUNDS RATES HIGHER TO SLOW MONEY RISE
description: The Federal Reserve decided at a midMay meeting to nudge shortterm interest rates higher in order to slow the growth of the nation's money supply, according to minutes of the meeting released in Washington yesterday.

title: The Standings
description: Saturday, June 25, 1977

title: Lebanon to Allow the Formation Of Some New Banks, Official Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 (AP)Lebanon has decided for the first time in 10 years to allow new banks to be established in the country, Finance Minister Farid Raphael said today.

title: ExCommander at Quemoy Dies
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 24 (Reuters)Gen. Hu Lien, former commander of the Nationalist Chinese forces on the island of. Quemoy, has died at the age of 71, the Central News Agency said today. General Hu was in command when the Chinese Communists first tried to seize Quemoy in 1949. He was also commander in 1958, when they tried to bombard the island into submission. Since 1972 he had been strategic adviser to Presidents Chiang Kaishek and Chiang Chingkuo.

title: Sorcerer, Action Movie Set in Latin America
description: The memory of HenriGeorges Clouzot's suspense melodrama, The Wages of Fear, is not so vivid in my mind that it seems to be any sort of sacrilege that William Friedkin should make a new film based on the same Georges Arnaud novel that had been adapted by Clouzot. About all that I remember of the earlier movie was the performance by a Very young Yves Montand, the steamy Latin American locale and the hairraising climactic sequences: Mr. Montand and three other desperate characters attempting to drive two truckloads of nitroglycerine across 200 miles of mountain and jungle obstacles to fight an oilwell fire.

title: Atlantic City Sets Casino Sites
description: ALANTIC CITY, June 24The City Commission adopted an interim zoning ordinance early this morning that establishes 11 areas as sites for gambling casinos.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Blueprint for a New Kind of Bureaucracy
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif.Tomorrow, Sim Van der Ryn, the state architect of California, said the other day; we're going to announce that we've bought 50 bicycles.

title: Barclays Says Role In Israel Continues
description: LONDON, June 24 (AP)Barclays Bank Ltd. has denied a statement made Sunday in Egypt that it had liquidated its Israeli operation to get its name removed from the Arab boycott list.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JUNE 25, 1977

title: Deaths
description: ARONSMilton. The Members end ors of the International Ladies Germent Worker Union mourn the passing of the Administrative Director el its New York Union Health Center. Coming to the confer with an already extensive background in labor health care, he served the ILGWU's pioneer medial Institution since 1961 with great effectiveness, ability and distinction in administering the day to day complex Willy. Himself the son of garment workers, imbued with the ideal of social tusk, he brought to his tasks a warm, sensitive concern and interest le the personal welfare of the tens of thousands of garment workers who utilize the Center's services. We deeply feel his loss. International Ladles Garment Workers Union SOL C. CHEHAIKIN President SHELLEY APPLETON. Gen. SecretaryTreasurer WILSURT DANIELS. Exec Vice Pres. FREDERICK R. STEMS, Exec. Vice pros.

title: U.S.Aided Ships Cleared to Haul Oil From Alaska
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Commerce Department said today that within certain limits it would let Americanflag ships built with Federal subsidies and intended for foreign trade carry. crude oil from Alaska to the Pacific end of the Panama Canal.

title: An Instant Video Identifier of Poisons
description: WASHINGTONA new analytical instrument patented this week is intended to save the lives of victims of poison or drug overdose by instantaneously identifying toxic substances in fluids. The instrument, called a video fluorometer, was invented by James B. Callis and Ernest R. Davidson, faculty members at the University of Washington, in Seattle. They were granted Patent 4,031,398.

title: Beirut Having Fun Again, but Troops Watch
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24For the first time since the devastating civil war the public has welcomed with grateful cheers art exhibits, a fashion show, an operetta and an international star and, now, horse races. The Lebanese capital has shown a fierce determination to escape the horrors of the last two years and have some fun again. Although the heart of the city is still in ruins and much of the old antagonisms and insecurity remains, Beirutis have somehow succeeded in recovering a semblance of normal social life.

title: South African Campaigns in U .S . Against Black Rule
description: WASHINGTON, June 24South Africa's Foreign Minister ended a week's visit to the United States today on the note he had sounded incessantly throughoutthat American insistence on oneman, onevote democracy in South Africa would bring violence, bloodshed and eventual destruction of the white population.

title: Dispute With Somalia
description: ADDIS ABABA, June 24 (Reuters)Ethiopia's ruling military council charged today that the neighboring country of Somalia was sending infiltrators to eastern and southern Ethiopia and committing economic sabotage with the aim of annexing parts of the country.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Samuel Gompers Vocational High School in The Times on June 13 incorrectly reported that Hank Crystal, a teacher at the school, had said: We were all looking forward to a black principal because we thought it could he a good experience. But we're still waiting for the real black principal. The remark was made by a former student.

title: RULING BY HIGH COURT PROTECTS CONCERNS WITH DELAWARE TIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Suprem Court ruled today that stockholders of corporations chartered in Delaware were not subject to having their shares seized as part of a lawsuit against them in that state when both they and the stock were situated elsewhere.

title: Unueilings
description: RIECELDavid. Unveiling of a monument in his memory TOMORROW, Sunday, June 26, at 12 noon, Mt. Zi?? Cemetary, Maspeth, Queens. Path 11. No postponements.

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS SET ECONOMIC GOAL OF 5% GROWTH IN '78
description: PARIS, June 24In an effort to curb high unemployment, the United States and other major industrial nations in the nonCommunist world committed themselves today to achieve a higher average rate of economic growth next year than they are expected to attain during 1977.

title: All New York City Highway Patrol Cars to Get Radar
description: The New York City Police Department will soon supply all its highway patrol cars with radar in a move to tighten enforcement of speed limits and reduce accidents.

title: Radio
description: 64 AM, WQXR. Suite No. 4, Delalande; Grosse Fuge, Beethoven; Introduttione Teatrale No. 5, Locatelli; Symphonic Movement in C minor, Mendelssohn; Violin Concerto, Tchaikovsky; Ballet Suite, RameauMotti; Horn Concerto in D minor, Mercadante; Danse Villageoise from Suite Pastorale, Chabrier; The Wood Dove, Dvorak.

title: SAUL COHEN
description: Saul Cohen, a former tax consultant and accountant in Far Rockaway, Queens, and Jersey City who migrated to Israel four years ago, died Tuesday in Jerusalem at the age of 61.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Four Are Guilty in 1976 Slayings of Two Guards
description: Four men were convicted of seconddegree murder and robbery yesterday in the 1976 holdup of a Times Square movie theater in which two armed guards were slain with shotguns.

title: HOUSE PANEL IS FIRM ON GASGUZZLER TAX
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The House Ways and Means Committee, after two days of discussion, reaffirmed today its approval two weeks ago of a tax on lowgasoline  mileage automobiles that is weaker than the initial Carter Administration proposal.

title: A Boy, 13, Is Slain After Refusing Delinquent Center's Sex Initiation
description: A 13yearold boy was stabbed and bludgeoned to death at an upstate juveniledetention center near Rochester after he refused to participate in a sexual initiation to a club there, the state police reported yesterday.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended May 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) Over the Counter

title: Dodgers, John Foil Seaver, 32
description: CINCINNATI, June 24A standing room crowd of 51,864 welcomed Tom Seaver home to the banks of the Ohio tonight. But the longtime hero of the New York Mets was outpitched by Tommy John as the Los Angeles Dodgers edged the Cincinnati Reds, 32, in the opening round of the battle foil the National League's Western Division.

title: Flags Honor Slain Homosexual
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 (UPI)Mayor George Moscone ordered the city hall flag flown at halfstaff today for a homosexual who was slain in .a street attack. The Mayor also offered a $5,000 reward for information leading to the arrest of the youths who attacked Robert Hillsborough, 33 years old, and Jerry Taylor, 27, a homosexual couple. Mr. Hillsborough died, but Mr. Taylor escaped from four youths shouting faggot, faggot.

title: Bergman Sons Replaced in Posts At Nursing Home by Court Aide
description: Two sons of Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator convicted of Medicaid fraud, were replaced yesterday as administrator and controller of the Park Crescent Nursing Home by the trustee appointed to take over the operation of the home from Mr. Bergman.

title: No Tribute for This Aid Bill
description: The House of Representatives has voted by a lopsided margin to prohibit any international institution from using American money for aid to seven countriesCuba, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Angola, Mozambique and Uganda. In a fit of uncomprehending pique, liberals, centrists and conservatives made common cause thus to undermine President Carter's attempts to reestablish some decent relationships with Indochina and Cuba, and to cloud the future of the international aid agencies.

title: Independence Falters in Cup Yachting Trials
description: NEWPORT, R.I, June 24Independence, the yacht that has been the least impressive of the three at the America's Cup trials this week, broke down twice today, or once and a half, while racing Courageous. The observation committee of the New York Yatch Club, which eventually will select one yacht to defend the Cup, called off the races, which in both instances had only begun, so very little was accomplished.

title: SULAMITH ISHKISHOR, 80,WROTE CHILDEN'S BOOKS
description: Sulamith IshKishor, an author of children's books that included a number with a religious theme and were based on biblical figures, died Thursday in her apartment in Manhattan. She was 80 years old.

title: Derailment Spills Corrosive Acid
description: INVERNESS, Fla., June 24 (AP)Thirty cars of a Seaboard Coast Line freight train traveling from Tampa to Montgomery, Ala., jumped the tracks yesterday, spilling 10,000 gallons of corrosive acid, officials say. No injuries were reported.

title: Tennis
description: At Wimbledon

title: CONTROL BOARD VOTES 70 APPROVE BUDGET FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday unanimously approved New York City's financial plan and budget for the fiscal year beginning Friday and a policy for granting costofliving raises to 200,000 city workers. It then formally requested a $750 million seasonal loan next month from the United States Treasury Department.

title: Golf
description: AT WESTCHESTER C.C.

title: Spanish Marveling at Ease Of Transition to Freedom
description: MADRIDWhether Spain has already been significantly transformed since Franco died in November 1975 is a topic of intense among many people here, but not for the provincial Communist Party leader in San Sebastian.

title: Picture Credits
description: CYVCINC

title: Soviet Crime and Punishment
description: VALERY CHALIDZE, who with Andrei Sakharov founded the Moscow Human Rights Committee in 1970, and who has lived in the United States since November 1972, represents the legalist view among Soviet dissidents, which looks to the further development of the Soviet legal system as the best hope for the protection of human

title: INVESTING
description: Taxexempt bond funds, the newest and fastestgrowing type of mutual funds, are now almost eight months old, and $1.4 billion of them have been sold to investors eager to avoid paying income taxes.

title: INTERVIEW
description: ROBERT W. BELL is 45 years old now, the principal of the Setauket School, a resident of Stony Brook, married and the father of two teenage daughters. But his thoughts linger on a day when he was 11 years old.

title: War by One Who Waged It
description: FROM the triple perspective of leading participant, sensitive eyewitness and reflective historian, Milovan Djilas has brought aliveas has no other authorthe chaos and carnage, heroism and comradeship, flawed idealism and sheer endurance of the Yueoslav epic in World War II.

title: White House Plans to End Office That Sets Communications Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Carter Administration is preparing to eliminate the Office of Telecommunications Policy, a White. House agency that guides Federal policies involving communications.

title: Canada's Stratford Festival Is Looking Pretty Good
description: STRATFORD, Ontario

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: Ienjoy watching birds and listening to them sing, but for me it is sheer background diversion that is nothing like the passion with which birdwatching friends of mine, the length of the Island, eavesdrop on our feathered friends. I am not knowledgeable in detailsthe redthroated seersucker might easily be mistaken by me for the ringnose hayfork. (I don't even know if these are real ornithological working models, but they will serve to underscore my ignorance of the topic.)

title: The Impetus To Sell More Arms Remains Very Strong
description: WASHINGTONTwo officials of companies that produce weapons sat recently in Duke Zeibert's, a downtown Washington hangout which serves generous portions of corned beef and cabbage and gossip. Let's say we're worried about the arms policy, but we don't know yet what it means. It's a little vague, said one of the officials.

title: The Politics of Health Care
description: Proposed solutions to the problems of the nation's health needs are highly predictable. During the 1960's it was commonplace to state that certain number of physicians and nurses had to be trained and in service by a certain date to forestall crisis in national health.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayUnited States Auto Club Schaefer 500 at Pocono International Raceway. Long Pond_ Pa,. 1 P.M.

title: British Take Rowing Trophy, With U.S. 4th
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 25The first series of races of the fifth annual Nottingham International Regatta concluded here today with Britain capturing the Guinness International Trophy, awarded to the national team amassing the most points in the Elite I category of rowing.

title: LOIS CASSATT THAYER
description: Mrs. John B. Thayer of Rosemont, Pa., the former Lois Cassatt, died yesterday at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. She was 82 years old.

title: Barbara Mumford Bride of John Hand
description: Barbara H. Mumford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Saltonstall Mumford Jr. of Dover, Mass., was married yesterday in Manchester, Vt., to John R. Hand, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Hand of Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. Robert Clayton performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Chapel. The Rev. Martin Clancy, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted.

title: BRIDGE
description: Bridge players are just like other people: They have days when everything they touch turns to gold and other days when the fates seem to be conspiring against them. In the latter category consider the sad story of a player in a major team match who bids intelligently, plays well, and finds when he compares scores that his team has suffered a disaster without anyone having done anything clearly wrong.

title: SYRIA SAYS U.S. IS TRYING TO KEEP ARABS DIVIDED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25In a resumption of criticism of the United States, Syria has accused Washington of trying to keep the Arabs divided and Israel militarily strong.

title: American Dancer Awarded Medal In Moscow Contest
description: MOSCOW, June 24  Financial and medical problems nearly prevented Yoko Ichio from leaving New York to participate in the Third International Ballet Competition in Moscow. The dainty Californiaborn ballerina made it nonetheless, and today was awarded a bronze medal for her graceful performance.

title: Home Style
description: It works like this: An advertising agency hires a production company to put together a television commercial for its client. If a set is neededa certain style kitchen, a barn, a castlethe production house frequently hires scouts who live where those locations might be found.

title: Torborg, Indians Pilot, Runs Afoul of The Bird
description: Jeff Torborg was doing fine until he ran into The Bird.

title: Diana Price Is Bride Of Jeffrey Dupuis Hill
description: The marriage of Diana Mary Price, daughter of Mrs. Hugh Nowell Price of St. Andrews, Scotland, and the late Mr. Price, to Jeffrey Dupuis Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lewis Hill of North Palm Beach, Fla., took place yesterday. The Rev. G. Kerry Robb performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church. Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The bride was attended by Claudia Crawford and Mrs. N. Roger Crooke, sister of the bridegroom. Dr. Robert S. Chapman was best man.

title: A Back Seat for Air Travelers
description: Thanks to an eleventhhour agreement, the planes are still flying between American cities and London. But that's about the only good thing to be said about the AngloAmerican air pact initialed last week. By further restricting competition among airlines, the pact promises to reduce the quality of transAtlantic air service and possibly raise its cost as well. More disturbing, the agreement will serve as a standard for other countries seeking new air agreements with the United States.

title: Driver Killed in France
description: ROUEN. France, June 25 (UPI) Fiancois Burdet, a 24yearold French driver. was kilted today when he crashed in heavy rain during practice for a Formula Renault race tomorrow. Burdet lost control of h s Renault when it skidded on a wet area between two bends on the 3.4mile RouenlesEssarts circuit. The car rammed a tree and doctors said Burdet was killed instantly.

title: Big Problems Down on the Farm
description: WASHINGTON  Is the United States headed toward a farm depression? The precedents of history suggest it certainly is possible.

title: Celebrating the 4th: Bach to Cherry Bombs
description: THE Dixie Dandies and a guitarist strumming Bach will mingle their music with the sizzle of sparklers and the bang of cherry bombs at picnics, fairs and fireworks displays all over Westchester next weekend.

title: Make Way for. the Goldman Band
description: In a world of traumatic changes, the Goldman Band is a comforting oasis of predictability: A few days ago, the 54piece ensemble swung jauntily into its 60thanniversary season in Damrosch Park in Lincoin Center, its classicstopops menu largely unchanged since those longgone days wheh it was the New York Military Band, and the free summer concerts were held on the Green at Columbia Uni versity.

title: Man Slain in Hotel Room
description: A resident of a Times Square hotel was found stabbed to death late Friday night in his room, the police reported. They said that the homicide had taken place in the Strand Hotel, at 206 West 43d Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, and that a man had been seen fleeing. According to the police; the victim was in his 40's, but his name was being withheld pending notification of his family. The police were not certain of a motive for the murder.

title: Where Is Cheese Traded? Green Bay
description: GREEN BAY, Wls.Every Friday morning at 10 o'clock a buzzer sounds and the National Cheese Etochange is open for business. What happens in the neat halfhour has a vital influence on the price of cheese in the United States.

title: McKinney in the Washington Maelstrom
description: A few weeks ago Robert H. McKinney, who was earning well over $130,000 a year in Indianapolis as a banker, lawyer and businessman, took his wife house huntine in Washineton D.C.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: The group which calls itself Society is composed of symbolic figures. Each of its members represents some abstraction. It is necessary that all the powers of this world should somewhere meet together; that money should converse with beauty, and politics become familiar with elegance; that letters and birth grow friendly and serve each other teu. . . . Just as banknote is only a slip of paper, so the member of society is a sort of fiduciary money made of living flesh. This combination is extremely favorable to the designs of a subtle novelist.

title: REV. MOON'S CHURCH HELD NOT CHRISTIAN
description: The Commission on Faith and Order of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the United States of America has declared that the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon is not a Christian church as it professes to be and that many of its teachings are incompatible with Christian belief.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Controversy Over Drafting of Women Pits Israel's Military Needs Against Orthodox Religious Beliefs
description: QIRYAT MALAICHI, Israel  If I'm taken, I'll sit in jail the whole time and give them problems, said Amelia Biton, a spirited 18year old Moroccar Jew.

title: A Slashing Defense Against Muggers
description: Personally, I never had trouble during many years of walking through New York neighborhoods at all hours, but rumors and statistics persist in adverusing the hazards. Fear tends to exagVista the threat, but selfdefense is nevertheless important.

title: The Showdown Seems Near
description: WASHINGTONIn the course of the latest House conflict over abortion, Representative Mary Rose Oakar managed to be accused of treachery by both sides. The antiabortion movement branded the Ohio Democrat as a backstabher. The proabortion forces called her a doublecrosser. Miss Oakar's sin, as it turned out, was to be a feminist who opposes abortion. Somehow, she said with a rueful laugh, I became a national target for both groups.

title: Susan Hewitt, J. L. Fischer Jr. Marry Upstate
description: Susan Hewitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin N. Hewitt of Lewiston, N. Y., was married there yesterday to John Lawrence Fischer Jr. of Dallas, son of Lois Chamberlain Fischer of Hamden, Conn., and Mr. Fischer of San Francisco.

title: WOMEN AT UTAH MEETING OPPOSE RIGHTS PROPOSAL
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 25 (AP)An overwhelming majority of the 4,000 women at a workshop of the Utah International Women's Year conference has voted to go on record against the equal rights amendment.

title: Queens Youth Grows Into Wimbledon Attraction
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25John McEnroe walked toward his first Wimbledon interview today when an official in a blue blazer stopped him on the grounds of the AllEngland Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Book About Laetrile To Carry a Warning
description: A book by Dr. John A. Richardson, Laetrile Case Histories, is scheduled to go into national distribution with the following warning printed on it:

title: Huey Newton Arrested On Arrival in Toronto; Was on Way Back to U.S.
description: TORONTO, June 25 (Reurers)Hvey Newton, the Black Panther leader, was taken into custody tonight ???? arrived in Canada from Havana. A spokesman for the Canadian Department of Manpower and Immigration said he was being held at the Brampton jail after an immigration officer interviewed him.

title: Borg. Miss Evert Head W.T.T. Stars
description: Bjorn Borg and Chrts Evert, the defending Wimbledon champions, will head, the nationallytelevised World Team Tennis allstar match July 9 at the San Diego Sports Arena.

title: There's a Long Way to Go, but General Videla Opposes an Elitist Regime
description: BUENOS AIRESA struggle for power between democratic and authoritarian tendencies in the Argentine armed forms is being won by President Jorge Rafael Videla, the leader of the military moderates. For the first time since the armed forces overthrew President Isabel Martinez Pern 15 months ago, General Videla, commander in chief of the army, has begun to speak with authority about political proposal that the Government is preparing bring about a stable democracy in Argentina.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Boston Red Sox conclude their series against the Yankees Yankee Stadium at 2 P.M. today. The Mets play a threegame series Shea Stadium with the Philadelphia Phillies at 8 P.M. tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday. The Yankees are back in Yankee Staduim against the Detroit Tigers at 8 P.M. Friday, 2 P.M. Saturday and (for a doubleheader) 1 P.M. Sunday.

title: HULL A BATTLEGROUND IN CANADIAN CONFLICT
description: HULL, Quebec, June 22This rundown French city at the frontier between French speaking and English speaking Canada is one of the biggest stakes in the evergrowing political battle between Ottawa, the federal capital across the river, and Quebec City, almost 300 miles away.

title: Taking a (Vegetable) Stand in Hartsdale
description: FOR the last 26 years, David Polidoro has run The Square Deal Farm in Hartsdale. In that time, he has seen suburban developments replace the baronial country estates that once surrounded his 16 acres.

title: Gail H. Gordon, Joseph McCale, Lawyers, Wed
description: Gail Hill Gordon, daughter of Mrs. William J. Gordon of Norwich, N.Y., and the late Mr. Gordon, a Chenango County Judge and Surrogate, was married yesterday to Joseph P. McCale, an assistant state attorney general. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. McCale of Camden, N.Y.

title: In Search of the Perfect Beach Campsite
description: Early in our courtship my wife, Annette, and I discovered that we shared a strong interest in hot sandy beaches. We could lie for hours under a brilliant sun, seldom moving, seldom talking, oblivious. Such compatibility soon led to marriage, which in turn led to three children.

title: Helen Marie McNally Bride Of Richard Tufaro. Lawyer
description: Helen Marie McNally, daughter of Mrs. Helen Duffy McNally of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Chase Tufaro, son of Mrs. Frank P. Tufaro of Hartsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Tufaro. The ceremony was performed in St. Joieph's Roman Catholic Church in West Orange N.J., by the Rev. James F. McCloskey.

title: The Nuclear Drive Is On, But It's Long And Tortuous
description: In a more benign time, when power companies preached the virtues of electric kitchens and Americans consumed energy the way Tchaikovsky scored percussion, engineers who planned for the future were a relatively carefree lot. There seemed to be plenty of land for whatever new power plants might be needed and, more important, plenty cheap oil with which to fire them.

title: Sarah Vaughan, Terry, Gillespie Join in Sassy, Dramatic Evening
description: If Sarah Vaughan seemed somewhat bemused in the early portion of her Newport Jazz Festival concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening  she forgot a lyric on a Gershwin song and than got lost on East of the Sun it may have been because her mind was on what she knew was ahead of her.

title: WIRETAPS MADE ISSUE IN NEW HAVEN RACE
description: NEW HAVEN, June 25  Allegedly illegal wiretaps by the police, here have become an issue in the city's crowded race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

title: Constance Bosworth Married
description: Constance Bosworth, a style coordinator for the women's wear division of Lanvin, was married yesterday to Michael Aaron, vice president of SherryLehmann Inc., wines and spirits merchants. The Rev. Gerard Di Senso performed the ceremony in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Dreuil Bosworth of New Orleans. The bridegroom, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is the son of Freda Goodman and the late Jack Aaron, founder of the Sherry Wine and Spirits Company, which merged with M? Lehmann Inc. to form SherryL???hmann.

title: It's a Bird! It's a Plane! It's a Movie!
description: IVERHEATH, England

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, June 25 (AP)A senior Govenunent minister sent by President Idi Amin to argue Uganda's case before the Uinited Nations Human Rights Commission may have defected to Britain, The sunday Times reported today.

title: Ethiopia, Set for Drive on Rebels, Parades New 80,000Man Militia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 25 (Reuters)Ethiopia today marked the start of a major drive against secessionist and insurgent forces by parading its new 80,000me'ber peoples militia, the third largest armed force in Africa.

title: Buffalo Group Dances Toretta
description: The dominant tempo of the Buffalo Black Dance Workshop is that set by gospel music, with its recognition of pain but its confident surge toward triumph. The piece that most clearly defined the spirit of the company on its program at the Theater of Riverside Church on Friday evening was Coretta.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL POWER COMMISSION predicted that Interstate supplies of natural gas would decline again this winter, raising the possibility of another gas shortage. The commission calculated that deliveries would fall 23 percent short of requirements .. The House Ways and Means Committee voted a rebate of about $23 in 1978 to consumers on the money collected from higher crude oil taxes.

title: Italy, Past and Future
description: MARIO SOLDATI jets into the future; Luigi Fusco stumbles along the past. There is no drawing them together. The fact that they are Italians simply confirms that in the messy, laissezfaire literary scene of the West each country produces novelists as apart as these two in subject and style. In quality, too, but that needs no confirmation. This is the first of Fusco's novels to be published here, but Soldati, who is also a filmmaker, is an old hand, known to us principally through The Confession, which won the Strega prize. Both care about Italy but have very different ways of showing it.

title: The Region
description: Nine months ago, New York City policemen took to the streets and even marched threateningly on a station house to protest a new duty chart requiring them to work 10 extra days a year. Their anger flared anew last week, A labor arbitrator not only upheld the tougher work schedule but also approved a city plan long opposed by the police unions: patrol cars with one officer instead of two.

title: Values in Danbury Area Taking Off
description: Fred Charles considers himself lucky. When Union Carbide transferred him to its New York City headquarters in August, 1975, he had heard there was good chance his company would eventually move to Danbury, Conn. long commute to the city rather than risk the possibility of having to make another move later, he says.

title: And the Panorama Isn't All
description: ONE of the Island's most attractive restaurants is a place where interior decoration matters least. Given the location right on the beach overlooking the Sound, Steve's Pier in Bayville needs only the windows. Those it has, in generous expanse, visible from every table with panorama of sailboats joyously scudding across the water by day, the glow of sunset and glitter of lights in the evening.

title: The Liberals Take A New Twist
description: WHEN the furor subsided, after the the Liberal Party had dropped a political bombshell into the contest for Westchester County Executive by joining the Conservative Party in endorsing the Republican candidate, Assemblyman Gordon W. Burrows, the politicians began to figure out what it meant in votes. But there were almost as many opinions as there were politicians, and selfinterest as usual colored the speculation.

title: They Interview for History
description: THERE ARE places around Connecticut these days where it's good idea to watch your language. Something you say could wind up on a tape recorder, and the next thing you know you might become a footnote in history, or maybe even a whole book.

title: With Polkas  And Pride
description: RIVERHEAD

title: Legislature Gets Mixed Marks
description: SUNSHINE can be the best disinfectant. So goes the famous opengovernment metaphor. If the openness of this year's General Assembly were described in such meteorological terms, it would have to be described as typically overcast, with significant but only intermittent sunshine.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, JUNE 26, 1977

title: Auditor Visits at 3 State Hospitals Find 22 Night Employees Asleep
description: State auditors making postmidnight spot checks in the wards of three state mental hospitals in Suffolk County found 22 employees asleep and . seven others who appeared to be dozing when they all should have been watching over sleeping patients.

title: THE ECONOMIC .SCENE
description: The general rim of data on the state of the American economy is continuing to show more sparkle than the mood of many businessmen, investors and economic analysts. ge it has been for many months nowthe rise of a widespread disposition to fear that all the good things that have been happening are too fragile to last. Only in Government economic circles, rather strangely, has the spirit of confidence seemed to match the economy's performance.

title: SEX MOTIVE IS DENIED IN SLAYING OF INMATE
description: ROCHESTER, June 25The superintendent of the State Agricultural and Industrial School at Industry today discounted police reports that the murder of a 13yearold inmate stemmed from a sexual initiation rite in which the boy refused to participate.

title: Vietnam, Grunt'sEye View
description: LIKE the recent No Bugles, No Drums, Close Quarters is a firstperson grunt'seye view of the Vietnam War, although narrator Philip Dosier is no infantryman but part of an outfit that maintains and operates tracks, heavily armored personnel carriers of various kinds. The reader gets to know these combat vehicles as well as he knows his own car, and to know also the look and texture of the base, the countryside, the motor pool (the smell of a junkyard in a driving rainstorm). Larry Heinemann appears to have total recall of his own tour of duty 10 years ago, and is in command of a thick, naturalistic prose (and an ear for G.I. speech) well suited to rendering life at close quarters in wartime, and the gory facts of combat.

title: Feminist Food for Thought
description: BLOODROOT is a feminist restaurant. It's not easy to blend gourmet cookery with feminism, activism, vegetarianism, ecology and economy, but Selma Bunks and her partners, Samn Stockwell and Betsey Beaven. have done it.

title: British Unemployment Rated 6.2% Close to Peak Since World War
description: LONDON, June 25 (Reuters)People leaving school pushed Britain's unemployment figure up to 6.2 percent in the last month, approaching the worst level since World War H, the Government said this week,

title: Koreas Mark Anniversary of War
description: SEOUL, South Korea,June 25 CAP)The two Koreas marked the 27th anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean War today with mass rallies above and below the 38th parallel. Both counties demanded the ouster of the other's leader.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The 1877 trade dollar pictured here, which is in proof condition, is the rarest of all the proof trade dollars listed in the Mint Director's report (total mintage of these proof dollars was 510). This should make it the king of trade dollars, but life and numismatics can take strange twists. Another trade dollar, dated 1885, has just changed hands at a figure estimated to be between $200,000 and $300,000, yet the one shown here is catalogued at only 81.400.

title: LAWYERS WHO SUE LAWYERS
description: One Sacramento Imvyer after another refused to take Mrs. Rosemary Smith's case. It wasn't a had suit. But it was aimed at her own divorce lawyer, Jerome Lewis, president of the Sacramento County liar Association. Lewis, while representing Mrs. Smith, had advised her that, despite California's community property laws, she was not entitled to half of her husband's military pension. Naturally, she was disappointed at the loss of a possible $.100 or more a month for life. Her disamnntment, however, turned to rage and a determination to sue Lewis once she discovered that he had probably been wrong.

title: $10,000 Carter Share In Peanut Device in 1970 Is Now Worth $130,000
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)President Carter's need for a way to dispose of peanut shells seven years ago led to a $10,000 investment that is now worth more than $130,000 to him.

title: Looting Old Buildings Of Valuable BricaBrac A New Urban Sport Called Shopping
description: Every Sunday for the last several months, Jim B., an advertising copywriter, and a friend, both Brooklyn homeowners, have arisen at dawn, crawled into Jim's VW van, and, armed with crowbars and screwdrivers, gone from one abandoned building to another, stealing things.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTORS CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeThe Sunshine Boys. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through July 30). $3.90$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: Bruce N. Stewart Is Fiance Of Stavriani Papadopoulos
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Papadopoulos of Athens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stavriani Papadopoulos, to Bruce Norman Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman W. Stewart of Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: Miss Geyelin, William Hoar, Bankers, Wed
description: Antoinette Rawle Geyelin and William Pierce Hutton Hoar, second vice presidents in the international department of the Chase Manhattan Bank, were married yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. Frederick B. Stimson Jr. of Sharon, Conn. The Rev. Carol Anderson assisted.

title: Little, ExBronco, Fails In Retirement Pay Bid
description: DENVER, June 25 (AP)Floyd Little, former star running back for the Denver Broncos of the National Football League, isn't entitled to $30,000 in retirement pay because he retired from the team before his 35th birthday, a district court judge ruled yesterday.

title: Letters: The Games Some Couples Play
description: To the Editor.

title: Things to Do July 4 Weekend
description: A few years ago, George Wein, the jazz promoter, pulled his Newport Jazz Festival out of Newport, R.I., and transferred it to New York City. The geographical dispersement is still continuing. Now,

title: While Children Wait
description: Recently I pointed out that at least 100,000 and perhaps 300,000 hardtoplace children were in foster homes or institutions in this country, waiting for adoption. Federal and state spending on these youngsters runs at $1.2 billion a year, many of them are suffering unnecessary emotional damage, but efforts to find adoptive homes for them are handicapped by lack of cooperation between adoption agencies, lack of communication and uniform standards among the states, uncertain state funding and the absence of centralized leadership information

title: A Smashing Player Courts the Big Time
description: GLEN HEAD

title: Mary La B. Stockman Is Bride Of Mark Livingston Wainwright
description: Mary La Branch. Stockman and Mark Livingston Wainwright were married yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, Li. The Rev. Patrick J. Whitney performed the ceremony.

title: If It Sounds Good, Play It
description: IN 1883, Claude Debussy was investigated by authorities at the Paris Conservatoire for attempting to radicalize his fellow music students. When asked by a pedantic registrar what rules he followed in his dissonant harmonies Debussy replied, Mon plaisir. This concise manifesto, which marked the unofficial beginning of Debussy's alternate career as an avantgarde music critic, was entirely characteristic of a man who, according to Aaron Copland, was the first composer of our time to make his ear the sole judge of what was good harmonically. Eventually, conservative music critics (the norm then, as now) were reacting to Debussy with stereotypical outrage. In 1907 The New York Times described La Mer as persistently ugly and The Post asked, Does anybody for a moment doubt that Debussy would not write such chaotic, meaningless, cacophonous, ungrammatical stuff if he could invent melody?

title: SuperAgent Strikes Again
description: When Henry A. Kissinger was calculating how to turn his years in Washington into a commercial success after leaving the Government, his friends Robert Evans, the film producer, and Barry Diller, chairman of Paramount Pictures, advised him to hire an aeent.

title: Newark: A Collector's Collection
description: ART exhibitions usually focus on shows organized by museums and galleries from their own collections or from the collections of other institutions. Rarely does one get the chance to view the collection of a private individual unless a personal invitation is extended by the collector to see the pieces in his home.

title: What They Are Saying
description: A Cincinnati sportscelebrity agent, on how successful Tom Seaver will be in obtaining endorsement opportunities: I can't see any local advertiser making a grab for him until he's proven himself in a Reds uniform.

title: The Grand Jury Under Examination
description: The grand jurya panel of citizens empowered, and in Federal law and that of 21 states solely empowered, to bring criminal indictmentshas recently fallen if not into disrepute at least into controversy. In New York, for example, a number of indictments voted by grand juries advised by former special prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari have been dismissed for causes including insufficient or illegally obtained evidence and improperly presented cases. Federal prosecutors have allegedly used grand juries to harass radical causes.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Recombinant DNA research in New Jersey has received a lot of press recently, but no legislative action. Federal legislation has been proposed and the state's Department of Health has received recommendations from the Public Advocate's office, but no definitive move toward protecting people from the possible dangers of this research has resulted.

title: Hilary Walker Is Married to Peter J. Gilmore
description: Hilary Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Walker of Oyster Bay, LI., was married yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Orleans, Mass., to Peter J. Gilmore, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Gerald Gilmore of South Orleans, Mass. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE is something to be said for courage the restaurant business, and George Venizia cannot be faulted for the daring he has displayed by opening Atlantic City's first, and only, French restaurant, Le Cafe de Paris. Even French accentand Mr. Venizia's is of the Montreal varietyis welcome in this resort city, which is sort a temple of funk food.

title: DINING OUT
description: AT THE dock's end on South Norwalk Harbor, The Pier restaurant looks out upon hundreds of expensive pleasure boats, tightly berthed, row upon row, nudging the restaurant's narrow walkway. Its main dining room is huge and very informal, open to the elements on three sides. Glasspaned overhead garage doors, the room's only novel architectural feature, were rolled back on the balmy night that we visited; they can be pulled down in various combinations to form barriers against the weather.

title: Visit With A. L. Rowse
description: AL. ROWSE, 73yearold bachelor, eccentric, misanthropist, poet and, whatever his detractors may say, foremost Elizabethan scholar of his age, lives in a fine, stonebuilt Georgian manor house overlooking St. Austell bay on the South Cornish coast of England.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The case against saccharin has been strengthened by a new Canadian study linking the artificial sweetener for the first time to human bladder cancer. An earlier study, also Canadian, had found a similar link in laboratory rats.

title: GARDENING
description: WHEN an accomplished indoor gardener told me that her Medinilla magnifica was blooming at last after five years, I must have looked blank.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Gangsters In Japan tend to be proud of their choices of career, flaunting their identities with flashy clothes and cars and boldly placing gang names and symbols on their office buildings. With 10,000 gangsters reportedly operating in 316 gangs in Osaka, the chief superintendent of the city's Criminal Investigation Division, Raisuke Miyawaki, broke out a fearsome retaliatory weapon three months ago: social ostracism.

title: Fleet Victress Sets Belmont Turf Mark
description: It's beginning to appear that 17yearold Steve Cauthen may prove the greatest thing for the horse's popularity among youth since the merrygoround. Youngsters were seen at Belmont Park yesterday in surprising numbers, and in Many cases were brought there to see the teenage Kentucky jockey con??? Ma comeback.

title: CRIME INCREASE REPORTED IN FEDERAL PARKS BY G.A.O.
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)Crime in Federal parks and other recreational areas is a worsening problem, which the National Park Service and other agencies are ill equipped to handle, according to the General Accounting Office.

title: King Arthur's Musical Camelot Still Survives
description: CAMELOT is playing to full houses at An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford and has extended its run to July 17. This is the Lerner and Loewe musical of 1960 that followed their impossibletotop My Fair Lady. It is based on the King Arthur legend as told by T. H. White in his The Once and Future King.

title: Miss Rusack Wed on Coast; 7 Attend Her
description: The Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. Paul in Los Angeles was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Rebecca Morrison Rusack, daughter Of Bishop Robert Clafin Rusack of the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles, and Mrs. Rusack, to Richard Waycott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Waycott Jr. of Brentwood, Calif.

title: The End of the Road For a Neighborhood
description: ON Taylor and Bayberry Roads in Elmsford, there is no longer any live controversy, there is no petition to be signed, nor any meeting to be attended. It is all over. There are only phrases muttered around kitchen tables, sentences spoken hesitantly in driveways and long silences in tidy parlors.

title: The Score on Music Camps and Schools
description: AFTER the annual spring music recital, many children put their instruments away and don't think about another note until Septemberbut not the hundreds of Westchester youngsters who will be making music this summer at the public and private music camps and schools scattered throughout the county.

title: The Prosecutor Seems To Have Taken Over
description: he notion of the grand jury as shield for the innocentpresumably at the heart of the reasons for its inclusion in the Bill of Rightsis continually echoed in judicial opinions. Relatively recently the Supreme Court stated:

title: Mr. Carter Was Exasperated, the Cabinet Was Surprised
description: WASHINGTON The Cabinet meeting last April 11 had been set aside for a discussion of welfare policy, and Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, had the floor. Using a stock of multicolored charts to illustrate his points, Mr. Califano described a number of ways to overhaul the nation's welfan. system. Each would be expensive, but more money had to be spent, he said, it some people were not to be left much worse off than they are now, and if the states and cities were to be given a measure of fiscal relief.

title: Robert S. Barnett Jr. Weds Penelope Fox
description: Penelope Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson Fox of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. Luke's Episcopal Church to Robert S. Barnett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Barnett of Beacon, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Benjamin Minifie performed the ceremony.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: After reading The Schools: Worse Every Year by John J. Petrale [May 29], I feel obligated to respond. I teach for BOCES in Yorktown Heights, in the health/medical area, and my job is to help students discover an appropriate occupation.

title: AntiAbortion Forces Gain
description: Four years ago, when having an abortion was still a crime in most states, the United States Supreme Court ruled that the constitutional right to privacy entitled women to have them. The decision, as well as the relative speed with which the explosive social and religious question was settled, at first stunned opponents of abortion. Then, regrouping, they moved to unsettle the issue by taking it back to the courts and the legislatures. Last week the foes of abortionondemand won significant victories in both

title: Roland A Gallimore, Partner In Philadelphia Concern, 53
description: Roland A. Gallimore, the principal partner in the Philadelphia architectural firm of Geddes, Brecher, Qualls, Cunningham, died of cancer Friday at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 53 years old and lived in St. Davids, Pa.

title: IN AMERICA
description: LO RANGER, la. Skeet Hewitt, who promotes the Saturday night rasslin  and the Sundayafternoon stockcar races in this speck of a town between Ponchamkt and Bogalusa, had heard that Billy Carter doesn't come cheap. But he had to catch his breath when he called the Top Billing agency in Nashville inquire about the availability of its hot test talent, who's billed as the funloving First Brother from Plains, Ga. The price he was quoted for an afternoon's guest appearance at the Southeast Louisiana Cajun Music Festival, which Hewitt had just conceived in what he took to be a moment of inspiration, was a cool $5,000 plus expensesexactly double what he had been prepared to spend. Hewitt did quick calculationfiguring that with a $5 admission charge for each adult, the extra $2,500 could he made up by only 500 curiosityseekers  and plunged ahead. Though even $2,500 would have been more than he had ever paid a performer, it hardly seemed a gamble.

title: The Continuing Saga of Idi Amin
description: The Continuing Saga of Idi Amin

title: Experts Call for New Research on How Plants Grow
description: In recent years American farm productivity has leveled off or even declined in some cases, and top agricultural experts say the reason is that the applied research that once led to steadily increasing yields has nearly depleted its storehouse of basic knowledge of how plants grow.

title: Soviet Medicine Mixes Inconsistency With Diversity
description: MOSCOWA middleaged woman from a country town about 100 miles from Moscow was admitted to the finest cardi; ac institute in the Soviet Union several months ago. She had little hope of survival without radical surgery, so in an eighthour operation one of the country's most skilled heart surgeons implanted an artificial valve. The prognosis is guarded, but she is recovering well.

title: Fairfield and Middlesex Resolve Conflict in Dates..
description: The Fairfield County and the Middlesex County horse showsboth major eventsend their fourday runs today and the conflict in dates seems to have hurt neither. The Fairfield County event is held at the Fairfield County

title: Health
description: At New York's elegant Four Seasons restaurant, a favorite of midtown businessmen, it's the new lunchtime drink. Two years ago, Elaine's. the Manhattan restaurant frequented by writers, actors and familiar names from the gossip colunms, sold seven or eight bottles a week. Foday, it gets through more than a case a night. It is bottled water in particular, a French, carbonated called Perrier.

title: Tobey, Golden Retriever, Is Best at MidHudson
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Labor Lost Most Issues
description: AS FAR AS Connecticut workers are concerned, the 1977 session of the General Assembly passed some damaging legislation, failed to pass some proposals that would benefit many workers and enacted only a few good measures that could be termed prolabor.

title: Sports Briefs
description: MARACAIBO, Venezuela, June 23 (AP)Antonin Cervantes Pambele of Colombia captured the vacant World Boxing Association junior welterweight title tonight on a technical knockout er Carlos Maria, Gimenez, of Argentina.

title: Father's Day Is Every Day, Or Red Cougar Meets Red Hawk
description: WHAT price fatherhood? Last September, my 7yearold son, Christopher, brought home from school one of those joinandhavefun handouts that sometimes seem to outnumber math assignments. It urged that we join an organization called Indian Guides, sponsored by the Ridgewood Y.M.C.A., and take advantage of opportunities to get to know one another better.

title: He Aids Student Aid
description: A HIGHSCHOOL senior came into Milton Heimlich's office at New Rochelle High School, inquiring about college financial aid. He is an orphan; his father died when he was 4 and his mother, more recently.

title: CRIME
description: Here's a pair of British haportsMURDER WITH MALICE by Michael Underwood (St. Martin's, $7.95) and ARMSTRONG by Alec Whitney (Doubleday, $6.95).

title: THE CLASS OF 77; ALL'S QUIET AT SCARSDALE HIGH
description: CSCARSDALE, N.Y. hris Douglass came to Scarsdale High School to teach English in the late 1960's, right out of Harvard. He remembers how it was then, what students were like what he was like and how things have changed.

title: Airborne WASPs On a New Target
description: ONE wintry afternoon 33 years ago, the Army Air Forces mother plane maneuvering the empty drone target plane over the Atlantic off Cape Cod shuddered and tinned over on its side.

title: The MeatandPotatoes Japanese
description: AH, the wonders of exotic cuisine! What is this huge hunk of meat, this sour white emulsion, this raw green root? To Americans, it's a roast beef dinner with appetizers of raw vegetables and sour cream. But to the six Japanese women, all newcomers to the United States who had paid $40 for four lessons in American cooking, it was an adventure in foreien cuisine.

title: Johnson Skin Cancer Is Reported, But Widow and Physician Deny It
description: The Reader's Digest reported yesterday that Lyndon B. Johnson had a secret operation for skin cancer when he was President, but Lady Bird Johnson and the late President's personal physician denied that Mr. Johnson ever had any form of cancer.

title: At Budget Time, Voters Go for Quality
description: AT this writing, 32 Westchester school districts have submitted to their taxpaying electorates proposed budgets for the operation of schools next year. Six of these proposals have been defeated. As a more than casually interested observer I've been in educational administration for more than a decadeI undertook to learn the reason for this 19 percent failure rate. I make no claim that the research reported here is statistically valid.

title: Old and New For the 4th
description: THE big Bicentennial festivities may be over, but the memory lingers on. Just barely. For though this year's Independence Day events on the Island retain just a hint of the special flavor of last year's celebration, in most cases it will be back to business as usualand an oldfashioned, newfashioned, preBicentennial Fourth of July.

title: Game Operators Fear Casinos
description: THERE was a time when the operators of amusements along the state's numerous boardwalks had only one nemesis: the weather. They would wear smiles or grumble all winter on the turn of a couple of weekends. However, because many of them spent their winters in Florida, their complaints evoked raised eyebrows rather than genuine sympathy.

title: A Place Where Barren Land Blossomed
description: When my husband first took me to see the barren halfacre where he planned to build house, and more importantly, a dock for his beloved sailboat, I almost collapsed. There was not a blade of grass, no soil, nothing growing at all. I'll never be able to have a earden here. I thoueht.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: The longterm impact of the Tax Reform Act of 1976, which increased the effective capital gains tax to as much as 49.125 percent, will be felt by those who may never pay significant amounts of such taxesby American workers in search of jobs.

title: Ballet: Sleeping Beauty Debuts
description: The Stuttgart Ballet is not a company whose strong point is the 19thcentury classics, and its new production of The Sleeping Beauty is carried more by production values than dancing.

title: MOST STATE U. STUDENTS WILL PAY NEW HEALTH FEE
description: ALBANY, June 25 (UPI)Most of the 343,000 students of the State University of New York will be paying a health services fee of up to $20 this fall, and tuition for medical, dental and optometry students will be up $800 to $1,000.

title: Chasing Crooks in the Futures Pits
description: Where profits flow, can darn builders be far away? Not in the booming commodity futures and options trade, where honest  and some less than honorablebrokers have been enjoying a decade of uninterrupted increases in volume and commissions.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: Coming in too solidly on the headpin often will result in an impossible split such as the 46 or 8.10 or 710 or 79. However, if the solid hit (for a righthander) is slightly to the left of the headpin as you face it, quite often the result is the 310, also known as the baby split.

title: Patricia M. Flood Bride Of Ronald Charles Stanko
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, Patricia Marie Flood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Flood of Larchmont, N.Y., became the bride of Ronald Charles Stanko. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Charles Stanko of West Lawn, Pa.

title: What's Doing in PROVIDENCE, R.
description: GOD'S PROVIDENCEWhen Rhode Island, the smallest waxed disproportionately wealthy from 18thcentury sea trade 19thcentury industry, its captains and merchants made Providence worthy capital graced by stately public buildings, elegant residences and wellendowed schools and braries. In the 20th century, especially since World War many mills and factories drifted elsewhere, and the city whose population has alipped to about 180,000 from a high of 000 in the 1930's, has tightened belt. But the Bicentennial brought a new pride in the landmarks other reminders of the prosperous past, such as Prospect Hill known as College Hill), which street on street of early Federal mansions. Downtown, enormous storative projects are under Providence is, in fact, a sightseer's town, though hordes of prospective visitors on Interstate 95 and state 195 speed right through scarcely a sidelong glance.They thus never see the golddomed Old Stone Bank or the First Baptist Meeting House, the mother church of that denomination, or the where Roger Williams, fleeing thoritarian Massachusetts Puritans in 1636, founded the settlement named in commemoration of Providence. The spring, flowing, is about to become centerpiece of a national park.

title: Meetings Scheduled By Council This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held this week by New York City Council committees:

title: Chinaglia: A Troubled Character
description: As the story goes, the Cosmos ended their world tour in Tokyo last year and went to the airport to begin the 36hour, fourstop flight home. The itinerary didn't exactly enthrall Giorgio Chinaglia, who has never been one to go along with a crowd. So Chinaglia said, Thanks, but no thanks to management and, See you next month to his teammates, then took $1,233 out of his pocket and booked himself firstclass on a 14hour, nonstop flight to New York City.

title: Preview of a StarSpangled Day
description: PROBABLY because of a feeling of anticlimax after last year's Bicentennial extravaganzas, many Connecticut towns will be celebrating Independence Day this year a little less spectacularly. It will still be Glorious Fourth, but there will certainly be fewer fireworks and almost none of those elaborate historical Projects.

title: The World
description: Menahem Beg1n took office as Israel's sixth Prime Minister but his regime's hold on power is slim. He is dependent for a majority in Parliament on the support of two religious parties whose narrow policies could complicate any efforts to reach a peace agreement with the Arabs. In domestic affairs he confronts the continued strength of the former Labor Party Government in Histadrut, the labor federation that has an important influence on employment and economic matters.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Turns to Milton Friedman
description: JERUSALEMFaced with the impact of the Arab boycott, plagued by spiraling inflation rate and vexed by a series of currency devaluations, Israel is struggling mightily to encourage foreign investmentsand to that end the new Likud coalition Government has asked Milton Friedman, the conservative University of Chicago economist and Nobel laureate, to advise it.

title: Traffic Inspector in South Africa Leaves Parking Ticket on Own Car.
description: HARRISMITII, South Africa (UPI)It is no unusual to have a scofflaw say, that he did not pay a parking fine because the ticket blew off the windshield. It is something else again when the same excuse conies from a traffic inspectorwho gave himselt the ticket

title: Byrd Urges Caution on B1 Work, Citing Many Unmet Public Needs
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, said today that the United States ought to go very slow in developing the B1 bomber because expanding production would mean forgoing many unmet public needs.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Pickerel Angler's Quarry
description: An angler's bookshelves do not creak with the burden of tomes devoted to himas they do with trouting literaturebut the chain pickerel is a grat????? quarry.

title: A Marine Theft Bureau Is Considered
description: Confronted with an explosive growth in the theft of pleasure boats and equipment, the major companies underwriting marine insurance are considering financing a Marine Theft Bureau along the lines of the National Auto

title: Britain's Adventurous Patron Of Modern Dance
description: American modem dance's best friend in England is Robin Howard, a bearded Martha Graham fan who was also her benefactor and who enjoys losing a per sonal fortune in deficitridden dance causes.

title: Peter Briggs Weds Tally Smith
description: Talbot Lee Smith, daughter of Mrs. J Buckley Smith of Sharon, Conn., and William F. Smith 2d of Duxbury, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Leland Briggs, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Bradford Briggs of New Canaan, Conn., and Acoaxet. Mass.

title: TV VIEW
description: JOHN J. O'CONNOR

title: The Disappearing Farm: Can Anything Be Done?
description: THE sky on this June morning is a radiant blue and the air is unseasunally chilly. In a doorway of an old white barn, Frank and Ernie Henker are looking out at the land spread before them, the land of their father and now their own land, a sea of redbrown soil, broken by wave after wave where rows have been plowed. They are talking the chill, hoping it will leave the crops undamaged, and they are talking about the land itself.

title: California Has Learned To Sidestep the System
description: OS ANGELESAlmost 20,000 felony cases will be prosecuted in the Superior Court of Los Angeles County this year. But only about 50one in 400will be heard by a grand jury. For the vast majority, this is the procedure followed in Los Angeles County and the 57 other counties in California:

title: 30 COMPANIES FIGHT MOVE TO OUST THEM
description: Contend Action by N.Y.U. Violates the Intent of a City Program

title: Decorating
description: This is the season for having, or being, a houseguest. And houseguests mean house gifts which should be as good to give as to get. The nice thing about orientally inspired objects like these is that they work with any decorative scheme. Best of all, theyre $25, or less.

title: Europe And the Congress
description: LONDON, June 25In the debate over the Communist bid for influence or power in France and Italyand what the United States would do about itone vital factor seems to be missing in Europe's analysis of the problem.

title: Rising Prices Squeezing FirstTime Home Buyers
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25James Minor, the United States Public Health Service pharmacist here, is 28 years old, and his wife. Yvonne, is 26. For months. they Watched the price of houses climb into the stratosphere, while their $240 apartment rent left them with nothing to show but a receipt.

title: Art CentersCall for Action
description: THE hearings in the Hackensack Meadowlands are over. The question of whether or not to have a cultural arts center for New Jersey has been approached from number of angles, and certain common denominators have become clear.

title: Bringing in the Wheat
description: SALINA, Kan.The weather is never far away in Kansas.

title: Italy's Rival Parties Cooperate, but Crisis Continues
