description: ROME, June 25A year after the elections that many Italians hoped would calm strife in the country, Italy continues in a state of political and economic crisis and is plagued by growing violence.

title: Was This Pipeline Necessary?
description: ANCHORAGEBetween now and late July the 800 steel miles of the Alaska pipeline will be filled with nine million barrels of oil, putting into operation a major new addition to the nation's petroleum supply.

title: 2 EDITORS DISMISSED IN ARTICLES DISPUTE
description: LANSING, Mich., June 25John P. McGoff, who heads companies that publish eight daily newspapers and more than 40 weeklies in several states, has discharged two of his Michigan editors after they failed to obey orders to run provocative articles that were highly critical of President Carter.

title: INQUIRY CASTS DOUBT ON LAETRILE FIGURES
description: LOS ALTOS, Calif.With states legalizing the use of laetrile at an increasing rate, an inquiry into the background of some leaders of the movement to promote the purported anticancer drug shows that they have frequently been the subject of exaggerated claims about their scientific and medical competence.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: TODAY, I cleaned my closet, driven by whiffs of summer and the needs of a rash of Princeton fairs and fetes. I recommend it. Rightaway gains included the joy of giving, free space to dream of filling with superbuys and some wearables long lost in the dark.

title: Ann Landis Morfogen Betrothed to Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Zachary P. Morfogen of Boonton Township and Barnegat Light, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Landis Morfogen, to George Sperry Weaver 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Weaver Jr. of Wheeling, W. Va.

title: Semester In the Sun
description: THE other day, Jeff Blomberg, senior, stood outside amid the greenery of the State University Center at Stony Brook and, in front of his classmates in Theater Improvisation, acted out whatever thoughts came into his mind. His free, uninhibited movements were typical of the summer folksiness and casualness that have turned this campus into a veritable stage for spontaneity and amusement.

title: Virginia Peterson Is Bride
description: Virginia Lee Peterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Douglas Peterson of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Daniel McDade, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Hardinge McDade Jr. of Mamaroneck, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Doyle performed the ceremony in St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Weston, Conn.

title: Of Ladder Tacks and Chair Backs
description: WHEN a doityourself homeowner is faced with an exterior remodeling or painting job that involves working on one part of the home's exterior for hours at a time (for example, putting up new siding or shingles, removing large areas of paint, replacing windows or trim), it can be tiring to stand on the rung of an extension ladder. At the same time this position also limits the movement possible to either side. The problem is further complicated when an assistant is needed at the same level or when heavy tools or materials must be handled.

title: The Air Is Fine but the Wind Is Ill
description: DESPITE all the state's efforts, Connecticut remains overhung with an acrid haze on some sunny days in summer, thanks in large part to the fairly steady winds of that season from New York and New Jersey.

title: ETHIOPIA IS SAID TO USE DYNAMITE IN EXECUTIONS
description: STOCKHOLM, June 25 (Reuters)A Swedish aid official who recently returned from Addis Ababa said Ethiopia's military rulers were so short of ammunition earlier this year that they used dynamite for executions.

title: Man Is Charged With Burn Murder Of His  3MonthOld Son
description: The father of a 3monthold boy who died of burns Friday was arrested by homicide detectives and charged with the infant's murder yesterday, according to the police.

title: Judge Bars Accord In Trial of 2 Indians Held in 74 Slaying
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25Dozens of shoulders sagged and a sigh swept the courtroom as a judge in a murder trial of two American Indians rejected a bargain that might have ended the nearly threeyearold case

title: Home for Retarded Is Opened in Queens After a Bitter Fight
description: A tileroofed house on a hilltop in Little Neck, Queens, became a home for retarded children yesterday, two years after neighbors started a bitter court zoning fight to keep it away.

title: Police Battle the Inmates Of a Prison Who Travel To Diamond on West Side
description: The last time Edward Rodriguez played ball against Roger LaBonte, Mr. Rodriguez's team, Isabella, defeated Mr. LaBonte's team, St. John's, for the championship of the sixteam semipro Roberto Clemente League in the Bronx.

title: Realty News.
description: Prime Madison Avenue retail space has been taken by two concerns that are noenine their first stores here.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Bryden, who has staged his own play, ought to know: he has not only mounted plays in the National Theater's other houses but is an associate director of the whole shebang. Yet, in one of its brochures, the National Theater answers the question what the Cottesloe was built for this way: Theater is always changing, and many of its most important changes start on small scale and before a limited audience. This kind of work is a necessity to keep the theater in touch with its future and to attract inquiring audiences. Do I detect a slight gap between intention and practice here? If this be change, and harbinger of the future, how, pray tell, would you describe the status ??uo?

title: The Man Who Put the Colors Into Finian's Rainbow
description: I got em I got em! I gotta basketful of songs, exults a character in the 1944 musical comedy Bloomer Girl, music by Harold Arlen, lyrics by E. Y. (Yip) Harburg. Like many lines in Harburg songs, this one catches the enthusiasm and joie de vivre that have propelled the seemingly ageless lyricist through 81 birthdays and hundreds of lyrics. Harburg has been writing songs at a rapid rate for 50odd years, among them Brother Can You Spare a Dime?, It's Only a Paper Moon, April in Paris, Somewhere Over the Rainbow and How Are Things in Glocca Morra? The latter, of course, is from Finian's Rainbow, which Harburg wrote with Burton Lane in 1947 and which is being revived by Guy Lombardo at Jones Beach this Thursday.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ALTHOUGH most of you, I'm sure, think differently, it is an incontrovertible fact that Atlantic City is not keeping pace with its gambling development.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Saturday, June 25. 30th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: DR. HUGH H. SMYTHE, WORKED WITH DUBOIS
description: Dr. Hugh H. Smythe, an international sociologist and a former United States Ambassador to Syria and Malta, died Wednesday at Doctor's Hospital in Manhattan He was 63 years old and lived in New York City and Newton, Conn.

title: Federal Workers Right to Dissent Is Backed by Chief of. Civil Service
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Alan K. Campbell, the new chief of personnel in the Federal Government, expressed cautious hope today that President Carter would keep campaign promise to protect dissident Federal employees from reprisal and dismissal.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: You'll recognize the format right off the bat. Man seeks surcease from urban ills: a patch of terra firma to cultivate on weekends, an arc of sky, maybe a brook, a simple shelter for his loved ones that will rise by his own hand and inspiration (while wife prepares mansized meal and tends the kids back at the tent).

title: Oria DouglasHamilton, right, displays one of the beaded designs
description: It can get very depressing, our work with conservation, and when this happens, I turn to my creative side.

title: 3 Buffalo Policemen Fail to Appear For Lineup/ After Fatal Beating
description: BUFFALO. June 24Three Buffalo policemen tonight failed to appear at lineup that was called to identify suspects in the beating of a youth who died early yesterday.

title: AUTO FANTASIES
description: The National Safety Council, which keeps a kind of Domesday Book of death by automobile, told me the other day, in its splendidly morbid way, that up to 600 people will be killed in automobile accidents next weekend. Next weekend is, of course, the three days of the Glorious Fourth. And the Council adjured me, as it does every holiday, to look out for bad drivers. learned about bad drivers I don't want to get psychoanalytical about it, but, for reasons best known to themselves, my parents took me one awful day to see Rudolph Valentino in Blasco lbatiez's The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

title: DR. EDUARD D. MUEHSAM
description: Dr. Eduard D. Muehsam, a surgeon and urclogist who fled the Nazis in 1940 and set up a private practice in New York City, died Thursday at Oiange Memorial Hospital in Orange, N. J., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and, lived at 15 Central Park West.

description: But Mayor and Governor Are Unable to Agree on Choice to Supervise Consolidation of Hospitals

description: ince the grand jury was imported to this country from England during the Colonial era, an intricate and sophisticated body of law has developed that attempts to balance the interest of individual freedom with the interest of the state in uncovering ariminal activity. In the last few years, critics of the grand jury contend that the balance has tipped against the individual, and dozens of proposals to change the grand jury have been made. The following represents some of the issues presented in Congressman Eilberg's bill and in other legislation introduced in Congress and state leeislatures:

title: Eleanor Whiteside Mudge Is Wed to Charles Cares
description: Eleanor Whiteside Mudge, daugnter of Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Mudge of Lyme, N.H., was married there yesterday to Charles Christian Cares of Boulder, Colo.

title: Fleetwood Mac Finds the Combination
description: The singer, who is wearing a backless dress, black top hat and witchy, translucent black wings attached to her bare arms, leans dreamily into the microphone. She begins the seductive, hypnotic song in a nasal, confidential tone, like the crooning of some ancient rite. Before long She'll De weaving about the stage, almost oblivious to the lanky, ear nest guitarist to her left, the hardwork ing keyboard player to her right, thl dour bassist or the angular, industrious drummer behind her.

title: Ottawa Proposes a Bill  To Expand federal Role  In Aid Plans for Needy
description: OTTAWA, June 25The Canadian Government praposei to increase the range of federak participation in socialwelfare programs provided by the provinces.The result wouuld be to add $132 million to the yearly tax bill of $444 million Ottawa pays for assistance to the elderly the disable and others in need.

title: Dr. Randall Zisler Weds Joan Rasna
description: Joan Marie Rasna and Dr. Randall Craig Zisler, an assistant professor at the Princeton University School of Architecture and Urban Planning, were married yesterday afternoon at the Princeton University Chapel by the Rev. Ronald Conner of Trinity and All Saints Episcopal Churches in Princeton. The Rev. Charles Weiser, a Roman Catholic priest who is the director of the university's Aquinas Institute, assisted.

title: The Nation
description: A former South Korean government official testified publicly on his country's efforts to influence United States officials. Kim Hyung Wook, chief of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency from 1963 to 1969, appeared last week before the House Subcommittee on International Organizations; much of what he said was previously reported, but not in public or under oath, and the excitement was evident.

description: Pamela Keller Wiggin and Jon Hazelton Barry were married yesterday in St Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien. Conn., by the Rev. Frederick T. Bender.

title: It's Pops Time in Princeton
description: PRINCETON AN OUTDOOR pops concert, to  be played here next Sunday evening by the full 80member New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in a relaxed, bring your own picnic on the lawn setting, will wind up with an explosive finale of cannon volleys and multicolored rocket bursts for !Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture.

title: Linda Diane Cohen Is Bride
description: Linda Diane Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Cohen of North Hills, L.I., was married yesterday to Harold Marc Dickens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dickens of Warwick, R.I. The ceremony was performed at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Robert S. Widom. The bride is a registered nurse at the ColumbiaPresbyte, clan Medical Center. Mr. Dickens teach. es mathematics and biology at South, Kingstown (R.I.) High School.

title: Mexican Pickers Helping Growers Buy a Little More Time
description: PRESIDIO, Tex., June 24When the men from the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced that they were finally going to get tough with growers who hired illegal aliens from across the Mexican border to harvest their crops, Bill Bishop began to worry.

Stroup. The bride is a daughter of Dr. Robert E. Lee of Scarsdale and Sally Gosling Lee of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Scheel of Westfield Center, Ohio.

At the same time this position also limits the movement possible to either side. description: Helen DeVore Alexander, coauthor of magazine and newspaper articles on jewelry with her husband, A. E. Alexander, a former vice president of Tiffany & Company, died yesterday of a heart attack at her home at 155 East 47th Street. She was 75 years old.

description: EVERY Tuesday morning, the editors file into the modest office of Roger W. Straus Jr., overlooking Union Square, to talk about the manuscripts they're reading, the authors and agents and foreign publishers they've lunched with, the possible future books for the list of Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: A Post Tito Yugoslavia Is Worrying NATO
description: LONDON  Two generals and an admiral were discussing with a visitor what they regarded as the world's explosion points. After they had surveyed Korea, the Horn of Africa, the Middle East and southern Africa, they focused on what they regarded as potentially the most explosive situation of allYugoslavia after the death of President Tito.

title: After Joseph Papp,What Next for Lincoln Center?
description: The recent resignation of Joseph Papp as theatrical impresario of Lincoln Center has raised doubt about the future of the Center's Beaumont and Newhouse theaters. Accordingly, The Times invited a number of leading theatrical figures to respond to the questions: What should be done with the Beaumont and Newhouse theaters in terms of artistic policy, people, organizations and financing? Is there any alternative to Federal subsidy? What sort of productions are appropriate in the Lincoln Center setting? Must the Beaumont be redesigned as Mr. Papp has insisted? Here are 21 replies.

title: Auction of an Abortion Criticized in Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 25 (AP)The Louisiana state director of the American Civil Liberties Union says she was surprised at critical reaction when an A.C.L.U. fundraising auction included an abortion.

title: Los Angeles Hopes to Get 84 Olympics
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25 (AP)In this era of cities fearing billiondollar losses in staging Olympic Games, Los Angeles is bidding for the 1984 event with expectations of at least breaking even.

title: FILM VIEW
description: A: I thought youd never ask. Well, it takes place four years after the little girl in The Exorcist played by Linda Blairin both filmswas exorcised by the exorcist played by Max von Sydow. It now seems that von Sydow, or Father Merrin as he was called, was a bit sloppyif it had been an appendectomy, Lindas mom would have grounds for a malpractice suit. Another priest, played by Richard Burton, and psychiatrist, played by Louise Fletcher, discover that doing the original job Father Merrin sewed up the wound without getting out all of the infection. So to speak. But this time its not the devil whos after Miss Blairs soul, but demon only identified as Bazoozoo, king of the evil spirits the air .

title: Fresh Air Children Off to Country
description: I. got on the train and we rode for two or three hours. Then the train stopped and we got off and all these people were waiting outside. I was scared.

title: A Nothing Sacred Newspaperman
description: GENE FOWLER (18901960) was a star reporter in Denver and New York. He has been called the greatest reporter ever to stride across the American scene. This is surely debatable, depending on the kind of reporting you're talking about; but indisputably Fowler was outstanding. His looks alone made him stand out. He was strikingly handsome in a completely virile way, a tall, trim 200pounder with a loud, infectious laugh and an ingratiating manner that made almost everyone take to him immediately. Of the thousands who knew Fowler, it's doubtful that more than a few ever forgot the first time they met him. I recall my first time perfectly. It was a stag dinner at Madison Square Garden in honor of T. Joe Cahill, the Sheriff of Cheyenne, Wyo., who was in town for the rodeo. Fowler rose and told a long, complicated dirty story

title: A Method in His Madness
description: ONCE upon a time in the 50's three BroadwaytoHollywood comets, named in order of seniority, Montgomery Clift, Marlon Brando and James Dean, gently jostled each other for a place in the sun. Each embodied a new blend of emotional sensitivity and sensual presumption that congealed into mistyeyed macho. Each flaunted the Method in his madness, and each, in turn, was accused of confusing mumbling with truthtelling. Of the three, Clift was clearly the most vulnerable, the most delicate and the most persistently selfdestructive. He neither survived grossly like Brando, nor perished prematurely like Dean. Clift lived just long enough for his legend to fester into pitiable disrepute. When he died, at 45 in the early hours of July 23, 1966 in his New York town house, his only companion was a male nurse named Lorenzo. For years there had been loud whispers about CRCs promiscuous homosexuality, his heavy drinking, his prodigious pillpopping, his unsavory associations and, above all, his bizarre social behavior. But for more

title: Women in Buffalo Struggle To Enter Labor's Top Ranks
description: BUFFALOWhen Barbara Lashbrook was asked to head a faction vying for eon trot of her local of the United Automobile Workers, she hesitated for fear that she would be manipulated by men who knew more about union politics than she did.

title: Kimberly Hornung Is Wed to T. W. Marcy
description: The United Methodist Church in Norwalk, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Kimberly Hornung, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald K. Hornung 2d of Norwalk, to Theodore Wendell Marcy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry 0. Marcy 3d of Oak Brook, Ill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard A. Thornburg.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: ANCHORAGEEdward L. Patton has presided over the disbursement of a fortune in other people's money.

title: MANDEL TRIAL HEARS DIVORCE PACT TERMS
description: BALTIMORE, June 25Details of the 1973 divorce settlement of Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland have been disclosed at his political corruption trial, showing that his wife agreed to move out of the Governor's mansion only after a political associate of Mr. Mandel guaranteed the financial terms of the agreement.

title: Correction
description: In The Week in Review of June 19, a publication entitled Look Homeward, Jimmy Carter, was incorrectly described as a manifesto published in Moscow. The document, dealing with President Carter's position on human rights, was actually a publication of the Communist Party of the United States.

title: F. E. Sheehan Jr. Weds Kim Greene
description: Kim Elisabeth Greene, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey A. Greene of Larchmont, N. Y., became the bride yesterday afternoon of Francis Edward Sheehan Jr. of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheehan of Skaneateles, N.Y.

title: ART VIEW
description: HILTON KRAMER

title: The NOW People Now
description: TEN mothers of 26 children, the grandmother of one, the wives of eight men and the former wives of two, met recently in my living room. We were reunited for the first time in seven years since we began a chapter of the National Organization for Women in Westchester to discuss feminism and its effect on our lives.

title: Miss Wright, Mrs. Carner Lead at 138
description: PLYMOUTH. Ind., June 25 (UPI)Fortytwoyearold Mickey Wright. in semiretirement the last. 10 years, fired a fourunderpar 68 today to grab a share of first place with JoAnne Carner going into the final IS holes of the Hoosier Classic golf tournament. The winner will collect $7,000 of the $50,000 purse.

title: Surprises in the Kitchen
description: NOBODY else cooks like Gladys Dinoff. She has a flair for improvising dishes that are interesting variations on familiar themes. An unexpected herb will spike a sauce, a garland of unusual vegetables will wreath a roast, or chocolate will find its way into a fruit dessert. A printed recipe gleaned from her boxes of clippings and scores of cookbooks is no more than the point of departure. The final destination is often a surprise.

title: A Whale of a Party
description: IF YOU LIKE MUSIC, or even if you just like whales, then a couple of people in Wilton have organized the ideal entertainment for the Fourth of July weekend. We just wanted to have a great big party, said Sophie Black, 19yearold coproducer of the rock, jazz and bluegrass concert that will take place July 3 from noon to midnieht. as a benefit to save the whales.

title: JEHOVAH'S WITNESSES ELECT NEW LEADER, 83
description: Frederick W. Franz has been elected president of the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society, better known as Jehovah's Witnesses. Hesucceeds Nathan H. Knorr who died June 8.

title: Reorganization: a Good Start
description: THE Connecticut Constitution says that the supreme executive power of the state shall be vested in the Governor. Studies over the last four decades have shown that Connecticut's executive branch is not organized according to this constitutional prescription. Legislation at the 1977 session of the General Assembly moves the executive branch closer to what the Constitution calls for.

title: For Waterloo, A Music Festival
description: STANHOPE LAST year, 16yearold Nai Yuan Hu, one of Taiwan's leading violinists, was invited to study in Rome and Vienna. Instead, he chose to study at the Yale University Music School under Syoko Aki, a leading violin soloist who divides her teaching chores between her native Japan, where she teaches at the famous Toho School in Tokyo, and Yale.

title: Best Sellers
description: FARTHER OFF FROM HEAVEN, by William Humphrey. (Knopf, $8.95.) A loving recreation of the novelist's boyhood and adolescence. THE GENTLE BARBARIAN, by V. S. Pritchett. (Random House, $10.) A deft, complexly shaded portrait of Ivan Turgenev.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Seaver Trade Revisited
description: I am completely aghast that the Mets traded Tom Seaver to the Cincinnati Reds. Seaver's achievements and success were an example for all of us. We all want to be great at what we do. Tom Seaver was an example that our dreams could come true.

title: Under the Spreading Maple Tree
description: NOW THAT the vegetable garden is planted and the annuals and perennials are in place, the shade under the maple tree should be just about right. Yet the maple tree may need your attention next.

title: Vietnam: To Aid or Not to Aid?
description: WASHINGTONAlthough the Vietnamese no longer talk of war reparations, and the question of aid was muted in talks with the United States that recessed this month in Paris, there is no doubt that Hanoi wants diplomatic relations with Washington in large part because it wants American money. Congress has said no on aid to Vietnam, but some American funds have entered the country through international lending and relief agencies. Now even these avenues may be blocked by Conaressional hardliners.

title: Begin Gets Support Among Jews in U .S . As His Visit Nears
description: When Menahem Begin surprisingly won election in Israel last month, the American Jewish community registered stunned disbelief. Next month, when he visits Washington, Mr. Begin will find a deep measure of support among the rank and file of Israel's supporters.

title: Connecticut Yankee In Business in India
description: NEW DELHINineteen years ago John L. Bissell, a young Yale graduate, came to India because he liked the look and feel of handwoven fabrics and because his father, who had been here during the war, had intrigued him with tales of India. Mr. Bissell has lived here ever since.

title: BEAME'S SCENARIO: HOW TO BEAT BELLA
description: A man fell blissfully asleep recently while candidate Edward I. Koch was asking him and some of his friends for money. Across the city, an elevator door opened in front of candidate Bella S. Abzug; a voice shouted, Hey, Bella, were for you, and, when Bella started to reply, the door shut in her face. Candidate Percy E. Sutton gave a press conference, and nobody came. Mario M. Cuomo couldnt get his own father to treat his candidacy with respect.

title: Flourish of Flutists Brightens Brewster
description: NOW that the flute has tootled its way to wide popularity, the benefit master class that Julius Baker, solo flutist of the New York Philharmonic, is conducting in the Brewster area for the third year is a sellout. Among the 120 people enrolled for the 1977 session of the class are trained musicians from distant states and distant lands.

description: KEARNY, N..J., June, 25  Bob Tank of Wayne and Hugh Hyde Jr. of Far Hills reached the final of the New Jersey State men's singles championship at the Arlington Players Cluh today.

title: GARDENING
description: ARECENT reference to summer seeding of delphiniums elicited several requests for information on the summer seeding of other perennials and biennials.

title: CARTER SAID TO SEE NO IMMEDIATE GAINS IN TIES WITH SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  President Carter doubts there will be an improvement in United StatesSoviet relations in the coming months, a close White House aide said today after the President had met for 75 minutes with his top foreign policy advisers.

title: Plans for France
description: FRANCE'S President Vaidry Giscard d'Estaing, who announced that he had quit his party after his election In order to be above partisan politics, felt a need after all for score kind of programmatic base to sustain and explain his policies. So he wrote a book, an unusual exercise for a leader while he holds office. But French Democracy is not a memoir, or an apologia or a collection of tales from the political battlefield. It is quite simply, as the publisher says, what Giscard believes and is planning for his country.

title: Miss Van der Hyden Wins In Fairfield County Show
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 25Wind Song, an aged bay mare owned and ridden by Susan Van der Hyden, made her second start of the season a successful one by winning the amateurowner jumper championship today at the Fairfield County horse show at the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

title: POLITICS
description: THERE is another wellknown political personality, in addition to Governor Byrne and Senator Raymond H. Bateman, who will play an important role in this year's gubernatorial election.

title: The Minstrel Wins Sweeps Race
description: DUBLIN, June 25 (AP)Lester Piggott and his horse, The Minstrel, completed a double at the Curragh race track today when the winner of the English Derby stormed through the stretch to win the Irish Sweeps Derby over 1 miles.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: POWER, INC, by Morton Mintz and Jerry S. Cohen. (Bantam, $2.95) The authors argue that giantoften multinationalcorporations rule us as surely as our government and undertake to reveal how these power centers avoid accountability. The mountains df evidence they marshal are overwhelming, the remedy they propose perhaps too simple.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Western Turkey, renting car is only one way to see the high spots. (If you do drive, be sure to demand a rental car with a sideview mirror; Turkish drivers do not consider it a necessity, but most Americans will feel more secure behind the wheel if they have one.) Turkish Airlines (Turk Havo Yolari) flies daily from Istanbul to Izmir and Antalya. The Turkish Maritime Lines in Istanbul also arranges 10to 14day boat trips along the Aegean and Mediterranean coasts, stopping at Canakkale (for Troy), Izmir (for Bergama), Kusadasi (Ephesus) and Bodrum, formerly Halicarnassus, where King Mausolus built the tombthe first mausoleumthat was another of the seven wonders of the ancient world. Other stops: Marmaris, Fethiye, Finike Antalya, Alanya,

title: Fashion
description: Everybody probably has the basics for a summer weekend wardrobe  jeans, swimsuit, trusted tops, scarves, etc. But what everyone looks for now are the new, and inexpensive, pickmeups that give the basics this summer's twist on fashion. The bits and pieces shown here do just that. And, best of all, none costs more than $1 8.

title: Music Mountain: A Heavenly Clime
description: NEARBY New Yorkers proudly hail the concerts at Caramoor (about which more in this column next week), and Massa chusetts residents quite justifiably revel in the cultural doings at Tanglewood, but there's an extraordinary summer festival in Connecticut that predates them both: next Saturday will usher in the 48th consecutive season of chamber music at Music Mountain.

title: A Weary Voice Shouts Against the Noise of Man; `Why can't there be silence? What's wrong with quiet?
description: REMEMBER the civilized sound of welloiled, ballbearing blades revolving in the good old lawnmower? No nasty smell, lingering haze of noxious fumes or stuttering drone and roar. One cut grass and still heard the telephone from the house, chatted with passing neighbors and even heard the evening thrush pouring its rippling rhapsodies from topmost branches.

title: New Plan Is Offered By G.0 .P . in Albany In NoFault Impasse

title: :North Carolina  Wets Foiled in Bid to Pass Liquor Bill
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 23With number of Baptist ministers and lay leaders still out of the state after the Southern Baptist Convention in Kansas City, Mo., and a number of leading Methodists encamped at their own conference in the North Carolina mountains, backers of bill to allow sale of liquor by the drink saw their chance to slip the legislation through the state's General Assembly with little opposition from North Carolina's powerful religious lobby.

title: Sue Kaufman, 50, Author Of Five Novels Dealing With Stress of Urban Life
description: Sue Kaufman, the author of five novels on the stresses of modern urban life as well as numerous magazine articles, died yesterday at her home after a long illness. She was 50 years old and lived at 544 East 86th Street.

title: Square Deal at the Round Table
description: CAMELOT is playing to full houses at An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford, N.Y., and has ex tended its run to July 17. This is the Lerner and Loewe musical of 1960 that followed their impossible to top My Fair Lady. It is based on the King Arthur legend as told by T. H. White in his The Once and Future King.

title: Religion, Not Politics, May Be Likud's Problem
description: JERUSALEMMenahem Begin, Israel's new Prime Minister, can get 63 votes in the 120member Parliament and probably more if Israelis feel that their country's future is at stake on such an issue as establishment of a Palestinian state on the West Bank. Less apparent, but perhaps more real, is the threat to the fragile Begin coalition posed by the equally basic economic, social and religious issues which the new Government faces.

title: SPORTS FIGURES EXTOL CORCORAN AT SERVICES.
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 25Fred Corcoran was lauded today for his wit, love of life and helpfulness as friends from golf and other sports attended funeral services for the golf executive and promoter at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Pius X. Mr. Corcoran died Thursday at the age of 72.

title: Big Blues Are Standoffish
description: WITH BLUEFISH, it's either feast or famine. Schools of small blues are providing good action now along the Island's North Shore. Solid concentrations of big stammers seem to have settled in for the summer off Montauk and Block Island. But this voracious fighting fish continues to ignore the western portions of the South Shore in its northerly migrations.

title: N. A. A. C. P. Parley Is Expected to Focus On Internal Disputes
description: Torn by some of the most serious internal disputes of its 68year history, including attempts to oust top leaders and to recast the leadership structure, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will open its annual convention tomorrow in St. Louis.

title: Irving Kendall: Courts for the People
description: CITY JUDGE Irving B. Kendall was standing in front of a Mount Vernon church after a funeral few years ago when a family court judge asked him if he was interested in that department, noting there was an opening. I've always been Family Court judge, the jurist replied with a grin. I just don't get the salary.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: To most traveling photographers the camera a close friend that brings many hours of pleasure, as well as serving as a valuable assistant that records people, places and eventseither for professional reasons or merely to satisfy one's personal requirements. But I have found that the camera can also be a foewhen it is not properly handled with discretionary caution and consideration for others.

title: 3 Share Golf Lead With 214's
description: OAK BROOK. Ill., June 25 (AP)The Butler National course haunted the pacesetters as they ran into doublebogey trouble today in a wild third round that left Tom Watson. Wally Armstrong and Torn Weiskopf tied for the Western open lead, each with a twounderpar 214.

title: Around The Garden
description: JOAN LEE FAUST

title: U.S. Men Lead on West German Track
description: GELSENIURCHEN, West Germany. June 25 (UPI}Despite the absence of its best athletes. the United States men's track and field team took a 3point lead today over West Germany at the halfway mark of a twoday dual meet.

title: Racing. Families Reunited at Pocono
description: Today's Schaefer 500mile race for United States Auto Club championship cars at Pocono (Pa.) International Raceway will have reunions of prominent racing families. Billy Vukovich and Gary Bettenhausen will drive cars entered by J. C. Agajanian, dean of USAC championship car owners. Their fathers, Bill Vukovich and Tony Bettenhausen. both drove for Agajanian during their illustrious careers, and Bill Jr. and Gary both passed their driver's test at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in Agajanian machines in 1968.

title: A Look at the Budget
description: AT MIDNIGHT Thursday, New Jersey goes from a $3 billionayear to a $1billionayear state, for that is when the new budget takes effect. Two years ago, New Jersey was getting by on $2.7 billion a year.

title: GOVERNOR OF ALASKA AIMS FOR REELECTION
description: ANCHORAGE, June 22As Jay S. Hammond, a bush pilot, licensed guide and former State Senator from Naknek, a tiny settlement on the Bering Sea at Bristol Bay, nears the end of four years as the fourth Governor of Alaska, he has decided to run for reelection but does not say so flatly.

title: Major League Averages
description: Records Include Games Played Friday Night

title: Rug Concert Offers A Suite by Weill
description: Since their inception the idea of the New York Philharmonic's Rug Concerts has been that they should be at least a little different from conventional orchestral concerts: The one given at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night filled the bill.

title: NEW YORK GETS PLAN ON SLUDGE DISPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The director of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's office in New York City has outlined a plan for disposing of the city's sewage sludge, dilapidated piers and harbor debrisall at the same time.

title: Changes: East and West
description: PARISThe principal current difference between the Soviet bloc and the NATO bloc is that the former knows where it wants to go but is having unexpected difficulty getting there and the latter isn't quite sure what its real goals are.

title: A Contest for the Conservatives
description: THE Nassau County Conservative Party, which has fewer than 12,000 enrolled members, may show once again the impact of a minor party's votes in several races this November involving candidates of both major parties.

title: DrottningholmA 200YearOld Theatrical Jewel
description: STOCKHOLM

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: DONAL HENAHAN

title: HUGHES'S DEATH LAID TO MASSIVE DRUG USE
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP)Howard Hughes took massive doses of narcotic and painkilling drugs for many years, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer. The illegally obtained drugs destroyed his kidneys and ultimately caused his death, the newspaper said in a copyrighted story.

title: Garment Workers Name First Woman to Manage A Local in New York City
description: The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, long criticized by feminist groups for having too few women leaders, has chosen its first woman as manager of a New York City local.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: The author, center, at 15, with George R. Hinman, left, now chairman of America's Cup Committee, and Sterling Kryder. Left: The Ranger, last of Jboats, .on which Mr. Knapp was a crew member in 1937 America's Cup.

title: Exorcising a Demon Along the Colorado
description: One of the most spectacular and irritating sections of Interstate 70 through Colorado lies west of the Continental Divide in Glenwood Canyon. There, the Colorado River has carved an abyss a thousand feet deep between honeycolored cliffs embossed with evergreens. But there, too, the once sweeping freeway is suddenly pinched by precipices on one side and water on the other into a narrow, twoway road.

title: Sarah Cleland Married
description: Sarah McDermott Cleland, daughter of Sherrill Cleland, president of Marietta College, and Mrs. Cleland of Marietta, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Harold William Gold, son of Mrs. Sydney Gold of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Gold. The Rev. Dr. Roland Fredericks of the First Presbyterian Church in Marietta performed the ceremony in the garden at the Cleland Home.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Victor Lasky
description: Victor Lasky took a puff on his cigar and smiled. Triumphantly. Nobody wanted to publish my book, he said. Even my agent didn't like the idea, so I got a new agent. She took my outline and five or six chapters around to the publishing houses, and she got

title: Thracian Clues To Our `Barbarian Heritage
description: The Greeks had a word for themall those obscure nomadic peoples who prowled the vast outer darkness of Asia and Europe, beyond the circle of light that was classical civilization. They called them barbarians, and for nearly three thousand years we took their word for it. In fact, it's less than 10 years since we began to suspect that the Greeks might have been somewhat mistaken.

title: Notes: Skytrain May Change Travel Habits
description: President Carter's approval two weeks ago of Skytrain, the lowcost, nofrills shuttle service promoted by Britain's Laker Airways, is expected to have a revolutionary impact on the travel habits of millions of Americans.

title: Because Payoffs Are a Way of Life in Korea, Seoul Thought They'd Work in Washington,
description: WASHINGTONUnder the steady gaze of the United States marshals protecting him in the packed, tense hearing room on Capitol Hill, a former Director of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency explained last week why President Park Chung Hee ordered a covert and allegedly illegal attempt to buy influence in America starting in 1971.

title: Immaculata's New Coach Has a Habit of Winning
description: Vicki Harrington has known how to play basketball since she was a gradeschonier in the 1950's. She vividly recalls the days when girls basketball teams were not quintets but played six to a side. The court was divided into

title: Patricia Mercedes Fox Bride of Michael Healey
description: Patricia Mercedes Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Fox of Milltown, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael F. Healey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Healey of Metuchen, N.J.

title: Madlen Heine Goldstine Bride of Marc Simon
description: Madlen Heine Goldstine and Marc Neal Simon were married yesterday afternoon in Princeton, N.J., at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Herman Heine Goldstine. Federal Court Judge Morris E. Lasker of the Southern District of New York performed the ceremony.

title: Resignations Peril HealthCare Plan
description: APIONEER healthcare delivery system based on placing familypractice physicians out in the community and backing them up with medical specialists employed by the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington is in trouble.

title: Of Ruthless Baseball and Candy Bars
description: No one familiar with the fictional but deadly accurate baseball world of Ring Lardner or the real one of Ty Cobb will imagine that greed, egomania and querulousness have only now made their debut on the diamond. But even a casual reader of the sports pages must sense that these lessthanheroic qualities have grown more prevalentto the point, in fact, where one can no longer turn to those pages for relief from the grimness of the news columns.

title: Lyndhurst Prepares for Its Night Season
description: FIREWORKS, a fife and drum corps, and a great big tent. State fair? The circus? No, it's just look ahead at next Saturday's opening night at Lyndhurst, one of Westchester's more relaxed music festivals.

title: State Is Recycling Sludge
description: IS New Jersey about to become the sludgerecycling capital of the country? That may not seem like an enviable distinction until one realizes that the state is in the process of solving what many people believe is the coming environmental problem.

title: CHESS
description: Ttying to take advantage of an opponent's shortage of time is a twoedged proposition that sometimes degenerates into a comedy of errors. The most famous gaff of all time was committed by Tigran

title: McEnroe,18, Reaches Quarterfinals At Wirnbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25The big guns were still firing today at WimbledonJimmy Connors, Bjorn Borg, Hie Nastase and Vitas Gerulaitis, But so was John McEnroe. Yes, John McEnroe.

title: Obsession Wins Morris Trophy
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 25 The Everett B. Morris trophy for the outstanding yacht in the Storm Trysail Club's seventh Block Island Race and Regatta Week was awarded today to Obsession, the victor in Class F in the fiveday series.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on Mine safety bill, to promote safety and health in the mining industry, passed, 78 to 18, June 21.

title: A Giant Among Midgets
description: RODNEY JOHNSTONE, for 30 of his 40 years, has been sailing, racing and winning in both small craft and offshore cruisers. As he sailed other people's designs, trying to get maximum efficiency and speed from each boat, he analyzed their strong and weak points. His goal was to design his own boat, prove it a winner, then have it produced as a stock boat.

title: ROUNDUP
description: The bill that President Carter signed this week limiting the involvement of American corporations in the economic boycott of Israel is an attempt to straddle morality and economics.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: LET'S SAY you change your address from East 69th Street, Manhattan, to Huckleberry Lane in Weston. Are your sleeping habits altered? Do your dreams change? Is nighttime in an exurban bedroom community different from in penthouse? Does birdsong at 5 A.M. in Wilton produce less or more anxiety than fire engines pounding down Lexington Avenue?

title: A Taste of Japan in Larchmont
description: THERE is in Hokkaido, the northernmost is land of Japan, a crystalline lake set between two mountains. It is a special place of beauty where the roiling of the waves turns a water weed into puffballs of floating green. That ball of weed is called marimo.

title: A Design Contest Spurned
description: IT TOOK the Southold Town Board three years to get enough money from the Federal Government to build a longawaited community center. Nobody in town seemed to mind that very much. But with the money obtained, it took the Town Board considerably less than three yearsin fact, several monthsto decide how and by whom the new recreational facility should be designed. The decision bothered some people, particularly those groups who had been advocating a design competition open to all architects in the state.

title: Music's Backup Star
description: FOR a minute it seems that Ralph MacDonald has lost his mind. Running around the garden room of his large missionstyle home in Mount Vernon, he begins bang ing on vases, milk bottles, cans of roach spray, tables, chairs, anything he can find, to ascertain the uniqueness of every percussive sound.

title: Engagements
description: HershMiller

title: The Best Baseball Town
description: The label never used carelessly. It identifies a city as a good baseball town. Only a few cities deserve the label. Cincinnati has always been known as a good baseball town. So has Boston and Detroit and Chicago and Los Angeles, but right now New York is the best baseball town of all. Conflicts on both the Yankee% and

title: Diplomas for Nassau's Finest
description: IN a complex and rapidly changing society, said the Nassau Police Commissioner, Daniel P. Guido, we need in police work people who have acquired disciplined minds, who will continually ask why we do things, who will seek truth and readily admit errors.

title: SHOP TALK
description: AT one time or another we can all use a little magic in our lives. And Creative Magic Products Inc., at 786 Merrick Road in Baldwin, caters to that craving.

title: Bruce Chapin Weds Lydia Marie Murray
description: Lydia Marie Murray, daugnter or Mrs. Edward E. Murray of Old Westbury, L.L, and the late Mr. Murray, was married yesterday to Bruce MacFarlane, Chapin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Chapin Jr., of Sharon, Conn.

title: HELP WANTED AT THE MET
description: When Thomas Hoving, seventh director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, announced last fall that he was leaving the museum, he set the art world whirring. His departure, which is scheduled to take place this week, has touched off one of the hottest headhunts in years. It may also turn into the most debated, since the search for Hoving's successor has raised serious questions about who will shape and guide the 107yearold Met into the 1980's.

title: For the Moment, the Financial Wrongdoing Seems to Be Over
description: When New York State's Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes ended its investigation a year ago, it warned that despite improvement in the industry, the potential for abuse persisted and that in five to ten years another investigation would be necessary.

title: With Benefit of Clergy
description: ANN DOUGLAS sees an Intimate connection between popular culture in the middle decades of the 19th century and modern mass culture. Her thesis is that sentimental female writers and the clergymen with whom they were allied dominated popular culture and created the passive consumerism and antiintellectualism which characterize modern mass culture.

title: Cairo Gets Arms Aid From Peking; Link Is Seen to Feud With Moscow
description: CAIRO, June 25The Egyptian Government, which yesterday declared that it had made no progress toward improved relations with the Soviet Union, today pointedly announced that it has received a shipment of military spare parts from China.

title: Severe Water Shortage in Jidda
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, June 25 (AP)Saudi Arabia is rushing seven desalination units to this Red Sea port to cope with a severe fresh water shortage. The Government has announced a crackdown on water profiteers, who charge up to $170 for 4,000 gallons of drinking water. The normal price is $57, officials said

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THERE are some very serious differences among Congressmen and officials of the New YorkNew Jersey shore areas on how to get rid of increasing quantities of sewage sludge. And the issue becoming a heated one in Congress.

title: STAMPS
description: Summer has arrived, and on stamps (as in nature) flowers are in full bloom, birds are on the wing or in the trees, and fish and marine life glide through the waters.

title: BEAME PANEL WARNS CITY NOT TO RETURN TO HIGHER SPENDING
description: Commission on Finances Concludes Nearly 2 Years of Study With Call for Tax Cut and Reduced Debt

title: Melissa Leach Bride Of George F. Dickson
description: Melissa Leach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Wallace Leach of Essex, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to George Frederick Dickson, son of Natalie Bruce Wright of New York and Thomas Dickson Jr. of Bridgeton,

At the same time this position also limos the movement possible to cub.! id. I he problem is further complicated when an assistant is needed at the ???? level or when heavy tool.. or materials must he

title: New York Troubles
description: It is not till it is discovered that high individual incomes will not purchase the mass of mankind immunity from cholera, typhus, and ignorance, still less secure them the positive advantages of educational opportunity and economic security, that slowly and reluctantly, amid prophecies of moral degeneration and economic disaster, society begins to make collective provision for needs which no ordinary individual, even if he works overtime all his life. can provide himself.

title: Home Shelving Systems Fit Almost Anywhere
description: One problem that seems to be common to every home regardless of whether it is a small apartment or large houseis the need for more storage space, or at least a better way to make use of the space now available. In many cases the simplest solution is to install additional shelving on one or more previously unused wallsshelving which is attractive as well as functional. The shelving can also be in the form of a freestanding unit which can serve as an attractive looking room divider or a twosided storage or display wall.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Anita Bryant's triumph over homosexuality in Miami reminded me of schoolteachers. There was a lot of discussion in that dispute about teachers and whether their sexual proclivities do or do not influence children and, if they do, whether homosexual teachers can divert the young from the heterosexual path.

title: Headliners
description: A bishop from Tanzania, Josiah M. Kibira, has been named to head the 58millionmember Lutheran World Federation. An outspoken but popular activist, Bishop Kibira's defeat of a white South African bishop for the Lutheran presidency is seen as further evidence of the growing influence of the black African church in the world Christian community.

title: BigTime Sports at Rutgers: Is the Cost Worthwhile?
description: Richard Zerneck's article (If You Worry About Yanks and Knicks, You Forget to Worry About Big Things, May 22) discusses sport as a tool that diverts people from the problems of American society. He cited only New York examplesthe $100 million of public funds spent on Yankee Stadium while social services are cut back, and of the millions earmarked for the 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid while the Tuition Assistance Plan is sliced.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: ADA LOUISE HUXTABLE

title: Under the Spreading Maple Tree
description: NOW THAT the vegetable garden is planted and the annuals and perennials are in place, the shade under the maple tree should be just about right. Yet the maple tree may need your attention next.

title: A Father and Son Find That, the Game Of Baseball Is More Than just a Game
description: The boy's large eyes fixed me with a demanding look. Just pitch a few, he said. Then, seductively, After that, I'll pitch and you can hit.

description: Howard Alan Cohen, Flutist, in Debut

description: ALAN SCHNEIDER

description: 89 A.M., WKTU: Mellow Child. Children's songs and stories. 8:358:50, WXLO: Equal Time. Guest, Chani Bergman, chairman of the Women's Organization in Israel.

title: Yes, but Is It Art?
description: IS there progress in art? is a question that ranks just after Is there sex after death? in terms verifiability. Nevertheless, critic and artist Suzi Gablik dares to pose the possibilitysure to be hotly debated in art circlesthat recent art, especially serial, minimal and conceptual art, is the fruition of a millenialong development of the human perceptual faculties. This is, to be sure, not a simple task; but Gablik marshals some impressive arguments favor of her hypothesis that art, like science, follows

title: France's Socialists and Communists Just Aren't Getting Along
description: PARISParliamentary elections, not due until March, 1978, but already dominating almost everything in France, have provoked sharp new tensions in the SocalistConununist alliance that still has a winning lead in the opinion Dolls.

title: Tonry Loses Primary, Faces Trial
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 25 (UPI)Ron Faucheux, a freshman state representative, defeated Richard A. Tonry tonight in voting to pick a Democratic nominee for the Congressional seat from which Mr. Tonry resigned May 4 after a vote faud scandal.

title: In Defense of Tax Loopholes
description: To try to perform an objective analysis of tax loopholes may seem akin to attempting a dispassionate analysis of murder or rape or arson. To most people, the very notion of loophole is pejorative, signifying some special advantage that someone is receiving at the expenses of the public welfare. Nevertheless, the importance of these special tax provisions surely requires some analytical attention.

title: The Domestication Of the Poolhall
description: Gone are the small, smokefilled, maledominated poolrooms in the neighborhoodsrun out of business by coinoperated pool tables in taverns and bars, spiraling real estate costs, laws prohibiting the sale of alcoholic beverages and a stigma that has followed the game and the socalled pool sharks who play it.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE first day I met Theresa, she was 7 years old, big for her age, a little frightened and eager to enjoy herself. I stood on the Cold Spring Harbor train platform clutching the Fresh Air Fund forms in my hand, listening to the volunteer tell us how to pick up our particular children.

title: State Gets Thick
description: THE CUT that the state will get of the new $4 billion Federal pie being sliced up for publicworks projects is pretty big after all, considering the size of the state.

title: Seaver Gets RedCarpet Treatment
description: CINCINNATI, June 25when Torn Seaver took up residence in Cincinnati this weekend after 11 summers as cult hero in New York, he was greeted by banner headlines, 400 letters, a standingroom crowd of 51,648 in Riverfront Stadium and an editorial cartoon portraying him as Superman with a cape draped over his new Cincinnati Reds uniform.

title: Miss Burnstine Wed To Louis G. Hecht Jr.
description: Nancy Lynn Burnstine, daughter or Mrs. Fred E. Manulis of Palm Beach, Fla., and Robert Lehman Burnstine of New York, was married yesterday to Louis Gerstley Hecht Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Hecht of Baltimore.

title: The Pitfalls of Pet Travel And How to Avoid Them
description: Whether it's an old French poodle in the cab of a custommade camper or a Siamese cat tucked between suitcases in the belly of a 747 jet, every year thousands of pets travel with their masters. How an animal weathers the trip and what shape it's in upon arrival depends on everything from the time of day it travels to the size of its nose.

title: Letters
description: As a divorcing, single mother, I am growing tired of articles about the poor divorced father or the single father (Life With Father by Daniel D. Molinoff, May 22).

title: Clippers, Monuments Vie In Doubleheader Tonight
description: The Baltimore Monuments, leading the Eastern Division of the American Professional SloPitch Softball League, conclude a fourgame weekend series against the secondplace New York Clippers with a doubleheader tonight at 8 o'clock at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Memorial Stadium. The Monuments are led by Jay Smith and his .627 batting average.

title: Larger Question of Deployment of BigCity Police Forces Is Also Raised
description: Fifty years ago police officials in America thought they had discovered the answer to most of the oountry's crime problems. The solution was radio car patrols. It was thought that mobile police officers, learning quickly from headquarters about crimes recently reported or in progress, would be able to capture more criminals and thereby reduce crime. But like most theories about making the police more efficient this one turned out to be more of a myth than an answer.

title: For Merrill Lynch, a Visa to Banking
description: The thundering herd is still bullish about investing in stocks, but Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the nation's largest brokerage house, is thinking of thundering into the green pastures of consumer finance.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The old adage, what goes up must come down, didn't hold true for the stock market last week.

title: Of Special Interest
description: The annual summer season of the New York Shakespeare Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park starts Tuesday, but there will be no Shakespeare in the park this year. Instead, producer Joseph Papp has decided to bring to the Delacorte two productions staged under Festival auspices earlier this season at the Vivian Beaumont (Mr. Papp recently announced his intention to sever that connection). Starting at the Delacorte on Tuesday will be The Threepenny Opera, the Bertolt BrechtKurt Weill musical, in an innovative staging by Richard Foreman. Threepenny stars Philip Bosco and Ellen Greene and runs through July 24. Second at the Delacorte will be Agamemnon. Andrei Serban's muchdiscussed interpretation of Aeschylus's tragedy will be presented Aug. 2 through 28. (See Theater)

title: Australian Air Strike Ends
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, June 25(Reuters)Major domestic airline services throughout Australia resumed tonight after pilots and maintenance engineers ended strikes that had left thousands of passengers stranded.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Cairo to Execute Egyptian
description: CAIRO, June 25 (Reuters)A military court today sentenced an Egyptian to death on charges of spying for Israel. Hafez Oweida, 27 years old. arrested last February with a sophisticated radio and a smallsize camera, said in court that he had been trained as a spy in Israel while serving a prison term there. He was also fined the equivalent of $1,700.

title: NORMAN OGDEN WHITEHOUSE
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 25Norman Ogden Whitehouse died at his home, Landsmere, here today after a long illness. He was 89 years old. He is survived by his wife, the former Princess Tamara Bagnation Moukrani.

title: Lu Eldridge Seiler Bride Of David A. Fahrland
description: The Pierce House, a historical landmark in Lincoln, Mass., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Lu Eldridge Seiler and David Arthur Fahrland. The Rev. H. William Gregory performed the Congregational ceremony.

title: New Light on Electronic Tubes
description: MOST peopleexcept, perhaps, electrical engineers are not prone to goose pimples when the subject of vacuum tubes is broached. Howard Schrader of Princeton Junction is different. He views them as thrilling wonders, and he covets them: klystrons, magnetrons, multipliers, triodes, MIMO's, travelingwave tubes, microwave tubes, the Zworykin iconoscope and kinescope, the Goddard tube and more.

title: What Now for Lincoln Center?
description: The departure of the protean Joseph Papp and his New York Shakespeare Festival from Lincoln Center leaves the Vivian Beaumont and the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theaters without a script. Mr. Papp tried everythingnew plays, revivals, star vehicles, classicsand concluded that no theater company could operate profitably st Lincoln Center. A successful season, such as the one just past, which featured The Threepenny Opera, Streamers and The Cherry Orchard, ended with $1.6 million deficit. The season was subsidized largely by Mr. Papp's hit musical, Chorus Line.

title: Mrs. Ibarruri Rebukes Soviet
description: MADRID, June 25 (UPI)  Spanish Communists, led by the 81yearold president of the party, Dolores lbarruri, rebuked the Soviet Union today for its attack on their independent orientation.

title: Nets Cast for Boat Pirates
description: THERE she was, all 44 glistening feet of her, resting quietly in Westchester County marina. was the boat, for sure; the chilly tides of November were lapping against her sleek, wide hull.

title: Swedish Expert Says Joblessness Could Increase Suicides by Youths
description: HELSINKI, Finland, June 25 (Reuters) A Swedish expert warned that mass unemployment could cause an increasing number of young people to take their own lives.

title: Judith Schneid Wed To James M. Lewis
description: Judith Ann Schneid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Schneid of Patchogue, L.I., was married yesterday to James Miller Lewis, son of Col. James L. Lewis, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Lewis of Alexandria, Va.

title: Bergen Police Story: 11 Months as an Underworld Spy
description: HACKENSACK LIEUT. JOE DELANEY'S career as a policeman was no more distinguished or extraordinary than those of thousands of other suburban policemen until a mason with friends in the underworld approached him in a pastry shop in Paramus one June day in 1974.

title: Collision Leads to Loss
description: CHICAGO, June 25Awed before today's game by the largest collection of oldtimers ever assembled for an exhibition outside Cooperstown, the Mets proceeded to be even more awed by the Chicago Cubs newtimers at Wrigley Field.

description: poetry and action, will read from her own works. Tomorrow at 8 P.M. The Pub, Sarah Lawrence College. Free. 3370700, ext. 315. HARRISONOperation Lifeline, a cardiac pulmonary resuscitation program with Harold Roth, Anthony Fazio and Charles Scheffler. Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. Harrison Public Library, Bruce Ave. 8350324.

title: Rebecca Reading Married To John Taylor Howell 3d
description: Rebecca Reading, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Reading of Rochester, was married yesterday to John Taylor Howell 3d, son of Mrs. J. Taylor Howell Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and the late Dr. Howell.

title: Cumberland Presbyterians Reject Proposals on 3 Controversies
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 25 (AP)Delegates to the 147th General Assembly of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church have declined to take stands against homosexuality, the expansion of nuclear power and capital punishment.

description: Barak

title: FISHING
description: THE large concentration of big bluefish that has been hanging off the South Jersey coast apparently is on the move and is likely to hit the northern hot spots, such as the Shrewsbury Rocks, this week.

description: OSSINING, N.Y.Twenty adults were honored here last Wednesday in an unusual graduation ceremony in which many of the graduates shunned the spotlight by remaining at home and others sat inconspicuously among the audience.

title: Tracking Xenophon In Western Turkey
description: The death of Dareios, king of Persia, is the starting point of Xenophon's Anabasis, known in the yellowing paperback edition of my college days as The March Up Country. A classic tale of military adventure and political intrigue in Asia Minor 2,300 years ago, it made a fascinating literary companion on a recent trek thrrtnah Western Turkey.

title: PreFeminist  Entrepreneurs
description: IT TAKES MORE than feminist rhetoric to make a working woman into an entrepreneur. In fact, conversations with five older enterprising women whose business successes predate the women's movement indicate that, at least in some instances, consciousnessraising and rapping may be just politically acceptable contemporary substitutes for the oldfashioned. discredited kaffee klatsch.

title: Dr. Joan Harvey Married To Dr. Michael T. Lotze
description: Dr. Joan Harvey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. McGehee Harvey of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Thomas Lotze of Rochester. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of Christ Episcopal Church in Cooperstown, N. Y., where the rector, the Rev. George F. French, officiated with the Rev. John Sise, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Turner Aglow as Early Trials End
description: NEWPORT, RI., June 20Couragenus continued to conquer here today at the America's Cup trials for the three United States yachts, winning two more races on the last day of this preliminary series. That left Ted Turner, the vivid Atlantan who skippers Courageous, cackling like a good old Georgia rooster who has just found the corn bin left open.

title: Black Boy, Black Man; AMERICAN SAGER; Black Man
description: APERSONAL history by one of our most important writers, lying in some drawer for over 30 yearshow was this possible? How could it have been lost or forgotten? Richard Wright's publisher explains that American Hunger forms the second part of an autobiography Wright had completed by 1944, but that only the first part, the nowfamous Black Boy, was put into print. Why we have had to wait so long for the second part we are not told.

title: FILM VIEW
description: VINCENT CANBY

title: Hard Drugs and Simple Solutions
description: An Impressive new report on the ineffectiveness of Governor Rockefeller's hardline harddrug law illuminates two vexatious problems: the drug traffic and the criminal justice system. The basic lesson, that neither is susceptible to the quick dramatic fix, may not be comforting news, but it is the beginning of wisdom.

title: A Gym Suit Requirement for Girls Successfully Challenged as Biased
description: AMHERST, Ohio, June 25 (AP)A mother who decided to make an issue of a school rule requiring her daughter to wear a uniform in gym class has won. Now the boys also have to wear uniforms.

title: The Art of Drinking
description: TIME was, when the notion of American crafts would conjure up images of ceramic plates and bowls so heavy they could barely be lifted and given to colors such as khaki and chocolate. Things have changed and a variety of new attitudes are included in an exhibition called Let's Drink to It at the unusual shopgallery called The Elements, 19 Liberty Way. Greenwich.

But no, it's a brandnew Gaelic folktale (we need a term for such creations, like instant antique but without the pejorative note) devised and related for the first time by the British writer Mollie Hunter. description: The conservative tone of the United States Trust Company, one of the nation's leading trust banks, is evident even when it comes to profits, a subject that concerns bankers more than most people.

title: DRIVE FOR RED UNITY SEEMS UNDER WAY
description: PARIS, June 25The harsh Soviet attack this week on the Spanish Communist leader, Santiago Carrillo, seemed to signal a major new Moscow campaign to tighten ideological controls. Moscow's denunciation of independent Communist national movements highlighted important differences among Western Communist parties on what is called Eurocommunism.

description: IN THIS day of women's lib, Kay Willis has started a new career: helping women who stay home with their children not to feel guilty about not seeking outside jobs.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Clifford D. Simak once wrote a remarkable series of stories about the last men on earth and their companions and successors, the intelligent robots and the intelligent dogs. These stories (collected under the title City) dramatized with great inventiveness and dignity one of the grandest themes imaginable  the evolutionary segue from one dominant species to another. What is remarkable about Simak's new novel is that the same man who wrote City could have written anything so ill conceived and sloppily executed.

title: HUMAN DRAMA IN A SMALL CAGE
description: Shortly after the guinea pigs came to live with us I became concerned. The cage, the pet store had assured me, was adequate for the male and female, but as I watched them chewing intensely, aimlessly on the bars, I wondered if the limits, the unchanging horizons of their lives, disturbed them in some dim, nonverbal way. The children fed them lettuce and pellets every day. Scamper, the female, black and white (hair so long one could not quickly tellunless it was in actionthe front end from the back), seemed more lethargic, less eager to rush to the water bottle hanging upside down like intravenous fluid meant for feeding on the side of the cage. Sniffles, the shorthaired male, white with brown spots and a black ear, flashed his long front tooth easily as he bit madly on everything he could find. searched his eyes for reflection of thought or feeling. They were like stones; the inner light of the creature did not shine out. Daily I cleaned the cage. Eating and eliminating machines, teased the older children. Rodents, whispered one of our adolescents. Both guinea pigs squawked furiously whenever a human form approached or passed their cage. They demanded food constantly. Their only solace, their only joy, their only distraction from the boredom of existence. Like prisoners with a longstanding grudge against a society that's failed them, they nipped at fingers that strayed or stayed too long in their little cell, their dreary

description: DIGBY, Nova Scotia, June 25United States and Canadian officials have indicated that a boundary dispute created by the declaration of 200mile fishing limits migh have to be decided by a third party .'to avoid serious friction in our relations.

title: Boat Theft: A $1 Billion Business
description: THERE she was, all 49 glistening feet of her, resting quietly in Westchester County marina, the chilly tides of November lapping against her sleek white hull. It was the boat, for sure. There was only one thing wrong with the scene. The Irish Rover, a Pacifica 44 cabin cruiser, should have been docked in Setauket, L.I. She had been reported stolen a year ago.

title: D. H. Lawrence Was O.K. for Words
description: MABEL GANSON, born rich in Buffalo in 1879, and given no education worth mentioning, eloped with a local man named Evans while still in her teens, and soon gave birth to a I3pound baby whose emergence tore up her insides so badly she needed corrective surgery nearly a generation later. Supposing she'd asked, proper Buffalo society might have told her that was par for the course, fit warning to a rash, romantic girl to settle down, suffer and be quiet. But Mabel did not ask. Instead, she went off to Europe with baby John after a hunting accident eliminated Evans, got married to Edwin Dodge, a rather feeble Boston architect with a Beaux Arts degree and outlook, found and redid in cinquecnto style a villa near Florence, where she flourished as a hostess between 1902 and 1912. Here people like the Steins (Leo and Gertrude) floated into her net. She developed a taste for celebritystroking and manipulation which was neurotic, no doubt, but which also entailed legitimate aspirations to be someone in her own right and to understand what was going on in the political, artistic and literary worlds.

title: GOODMAN CRITICIZES SCHOOL BUS PAYMENT

description: VIENNAWith delegates from 35 nations meeting in Belgrade this month to set an agenda for assessing compliance with the 1975 Helsinki accords, the host country, especially its policy toward human rights, inevitably comes under scrutiny. title: Menace on the Right
description: JOANNESBURGOn the surface, there is little about Gerrit van Niekerk Viljoen to suggest an influence reaching to the furthest corners of South Africa. He is the mildmannered, whitehaired rector of the Rand Afrikaans University, whose spacious campus, dominated by futuristic concrete buildings, occupies what used to be a golf course in the inner suburbs of this city. In his university post, the former classics professor is one of the leading educators in the country, But his real importance comes from the fact that he is chairman of the Broederbond, or brotherhood, the secret society that is the single most powerful institution in Afrikanerdom.

Dennis Russell Davies conducted the New York premiere of just such a concerto by Calvin Hampton, and the effect of this unusual if not actually unpromising combination turned out to be altogether exhilarating.

title: The Death of a Laetrile Patient
description: From March through October 1972, Schneck underwent a series of laetrile injections of 10 cc each prescribed by respondent (Dr. Richardson) as a preventative treatment for cancer. In addition, respondent prescribed vitamin therapy including various enzymes, pangamic acid (another outlawed chemical) and laetrile tablets. The cost of said injections was $20 each plus $20 for said laetrile tablets and an additional amount for said vitamins.

title: Confessions of a SoapOpera Addict
description: For almost four years now, I've been addicted to a television soap opera called The Young and the Restless. When people ask me what like about soap operas in general or The Young and the Restless in particular, I reply that liking or disliking has nothing to do with it; I'm merely supporting a habit. You don't ask a junkie what he likes about heroin. Of course, things could be worse: Consider, for example, the fact that this Thursday one of CBS's old warhorse soaps, The Guiding Light, celebrates its 25th anniversary on television. Add to that quarter century the 15 years the program spent on radio before moving to television and we're talking about marathon run of 90 years. Thus, by comparison with the longtime devotees of The Guiding Light, my fouryear romance with The Young and the Restless is a mere soap bubble amid the galaxy of suds. No Homeric or chivalric epic, no avantgarde theater piece of

title: Wimbledon Mobs Are A Problem
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25Halfway through Wimbledon's centennial tennis celebration, the most serious question being debated is not who will win the men's and women's singles titles, but whether Wimbledon has become too big and overcrowded.

title: Roosevelt Island Goes Colonial on 2d Birthday
description: Visitors curious about Roosevelt Island must have found the place more exotic than they had expected yesterday as residents there strolled in threecornered hats or in gowns, while children with hoops and sticks frolicked in a parking lot near the tramway.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: IN The Boom in Spanish American Literature, Jose Donoso says that he left his native Chile to escape the social realist or slice.oflife parochialism that dominated the novel there. Like many another literary expatriate, he went abroad in search of a deeper desolation, a more universal unease. On the evidence of Sacred Families, which consists of three novellas, I believe he both gained and lost by the move.

title: Housing Sales Boom Across U.S

title: TwiceForgotten Glimpses on a Road to Fame
description: IN 1940, after years of selfexile in France, Abraham Rattner and Henry Miller returned to the United States. Relatively unknown at the timeexcept in small circles that had discovered Mr. Rattner's avantgarde painting and Mr. Miller's controversial novelsthe two expatriates, who had become devoted friends during the fervid Lost Generation period in Paris, set out on a crosscountry journey to reexamine their roots.

title: Carter Favors New Arms Deal For the Israelis,
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  President Carter will propose sales of $115 million in arms for Israel in a move that has strong political overtones, authoritative Administration sources reported today.

title: RICHARD THE LIONHEARTED SLEPT HERE
description: I awoke at QUM{ MOM a aeep afternoon sleep, coaxed reluctantly to consciousness by the tolling of a medieval church bell from the village below. Though early summer, it was cool. The chamber had thick stone walls, floors rough but gleaming, made from oak felled in centuries past, and an armoire with doors huge enough for a cathedral. I wrapped a thick wool blanket about my shoulders and went to a turret window where once, they say, Richard the LionHearted had stood. Presumably his view was the same as minefields stretching forever outside the castle, fields as green and as rich as emeralds. Here, the armies of Protestants and Catholics once fought violently, but on this day nothing but a strong chestnut horse and an impudent little donkey grazed and nuzzled symbiotically. In the moat, swans glided through mossy shadows. Old women clattered across cobblestone streets no wider than goat cart, hurrying home with net shopping bags filled with immense artichokes, wedges of camembert, liters of wine. From the kitchens of the castle drifted upward the temptations of the night : new spring Iamb bathed in garlic and herbs, tarts of immense strawberries. steaming kettles of cassoulet and

title: Albany Legislators Move to Open More State Filesbut Not Theirs
