title: Plans Flow In for the Beaumont
description: The possibility that the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi E. Newhouse theaters in Lincoln Center could become part of a Los AngelesNew York national production network in partnership with the Mark Taper Forum has been raised in discussions between the two cultural institutions.

title: Commodities
description: If information is the key to successful trading, then those in the commodity futures marketsinundated by Government, industry and brokerage house reportsshould always be winners.

title: Leather Boat Arrives in Canada After a Voyage Across Atlantic
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, June 26 (Reuters)A leather boat that four men sailed across the Atlantic in an attempt to prove that 6thcentury Irish mariners may have been the first Europeans to reach North America landed in Newfoundland today.

title: Debra Edith Goldberg Is Married to Isaac A. Saufer
description: Debra Edith Goldberg, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Jacob Goldberg, was married yesterday to Isaac A. Saufer, sun of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Saufer of Rego Park, Queens. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father at the Fort Tryon Jewish Center in upper Manhattan, where Rabbi Goldberg has been spiritual leader the last 31 years. Rabbi Hirsh Goldberg, an uncle of the bride, and Rabbi Marvin Luban assisted.

title: Advertising
description: Behind New Country Yogurt, which began what appears to be a successful introduction in this market in September, are two guys from the advertising culture.

title: The Bergen Youth Orchestra Is Off to Washington for the First American Festival
description: ENGLEWOOD, June 26All last week, as the Bergen Youth Orchestra's big oneweek trip to Washington was approaching, the home phone of Lois Hargrave, the orchestra's general manager, was seldom auiet.

title: HISPANIC PARENTS SUE L.I. SCHOOL DISTRICT
description: The Brentwood, L.I., school district, in which nearly a fifth of the population is of Hispanic origin, has been accused in court of denying equal opportunities to Spanishspeaking schoolchildren by dismissing 18 of its 24 bilingual teachers.

title: It's the Locker Room Look
description: Take a pair of boxing shorts, add an undershirt and a pair of running shoes or sneakers, put them all together, and there you areright in the thick of The Locker Room Look.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: State Approves Montclair's SchoolIntegration Plan
description: MONTCLAIR, June 26A State Department of Education hearing officer has approved a controversial school board integration plan for the public school system here despite intense and organized opposition by a concerned citizens group and by the local chapter of the League of Women Voters.

title: Sweetness and Light in the Bronx
description: The best baseball team money can buy is a cuddly company oozing sweetness like a charlotte russe. Leading off the sixth inning in Yankee Stadium yesterday, Boston's Jim Rice sliced a sinking fly to right field, which is the office where Reggie Jackson conducts his $2,900,000 business. Reggie regarded the ball with distaste. It would not have been easy to catch it, and Reggie played it safe, letting it drop in front of him for a single. In the crowd 55,039, one of the biggest in the American League this year, were some of Reggie's best friends and severest critics. They said, Boo! On the bench was Billy Martin, one of Reggie's best friends and severest critics. He said nothing audible outside the dugout, did nothing visible from the stands. In Boston last week Reggie's languid approach to a single enabled Rice to stretch the hit to a double, and the Yankees' practically peerless leader sprang from the dugout, removed Jackson from the game in full view of network television, and when Reggie demurred the manager endeavored to slug him. Since then Martin came this close to becoming the Yankees' former leader but had a hearttoheart with George Steinbrenner, the club's principal owner, whereupon peace and concord settled upon the best team money can buy.

title: Architect's Unstable Designs Relieve Monotony
description: SACRAMENTOThere is very little to relieve the monotony of the environment of this dull capital city, and its suburban outskirts could be anywhere in the United States.

title: The Threat of Terror in Italy
description: Hardly a day passes without reports from Italy of political shootings, kidnappings and clashes with the police. In a country of over 55 million, most people's lives are not directly affected by the violence, but the impact on political discourse, and on respect for civil liberties, is troubling.

title: Defeated Candidate To Challenge Result Of Miners' Election
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 26Lee Roy Patterson, defeated candidate for the presidency of the United Mine Workers. said today he would challenge the result of the recent election in which the incumbent president, Arnold R. Miller, narrowly won reelection with less than a majority of the vote in a threeman race.

title: Shortage of Unleaded Gasoline Is Expected
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  Although gasoline supplies are nearing record levels, a potentially severe shortage of unleaded fuel looms for this summer, according to Government and oil industry sources.

title: Publicity Called Spur to Suicides
description: Widely publicized accounts of suicides by prominent persons apparently stimulate a number of imitative suicides disguised as automobile accidents, a California sociologist has found.

title: In Memoriam
description: DOBSONRichard Allen, Jr., MD. Jun 27, 1917May 4, 1977

title: Catha Maslow Is Married To P. D. Horton, Teacher
description: Catha Maslow, daughter or Mr. and Mrs. Will Maslow of New York, was married in Warwick, N.Y., yesterday to P. David Horton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Horton of Columbus, Ohio. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony at the Willowbrook Inn.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: Week ended June 24, 1977

title: Philadelphians Honor a New Saint in Outdoor Mass
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26Tens of thousands of Philadelphians flocked to an outdoor mass and concert today in homage to St. John Neumann, who was canonized by the Roman Catholic Church in Rome a week ago and is known here as The Little Bishop of Philadelphia.

title: Leonard Silk
description: President Carter is searching for a policyand a policymakerto help him deliver on his goal of getting the inflation rate down to 4 percent by the end of 1980. The constraint on the lookedfor miracle worker is that he must achieve the antiinflation goal without forcing the Administration to abandon its other goalgetting the unemployment rate down to 4 percent in the same time. Two of Mr. Carter's chief hopesand one of their prime criticshave strong feelings on how to reach the goal.

title: Judith Tell Is Married To Dr. David J. Feldman
description: Judith Tell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Tell of Rockville Centre, L. I., was married at noon yesterday to Dr. David Joseph Feldman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Samuel Feldman of Short Hills and Barnegat Light, N.J.

title: A Children's Opera Opens Caramoor Festival
description: KATONAH, N.Y., June 25The 32d annual Caramoor Festival opened today with two eventsa gala opening night that was indeed in many respects gala, and two performances in the morning of a less successful new children's opera composed for Caramoor.

title: An Unlikely Setting for a Violent Crime
description: The people inside the Elephas discothque had been commenting that the night was unusually quiet. The people in the Bayside, Queens, neighborhood of neat onefamily homes had noticed no more than the usual commotion surrounding the young people's meetine place.

title: Muncey Is Hydroplane Winner
description: DETROIT, June 26 (AP)Bill Muncey of La Mesa, Calif., won the Gar Wood Trophy Race for unlimited hydroplanes on the Detroit River today, finishing the 15mile race at an average speed of 108.608 m.p.h. Muncey, driving Atlas Van Lines, finished almost a full minute ahead of the secondplace boat, Natural Light, which posted an average speed of 98.576 m.p.h.

title: HOMOSEXUALS MARCH FOR EQUAL RIGHTS
description: Waving placards and chanting rallying cries, a vast sea of homosexual men and women marched up Fifth Avenue under bobbing banners of liberation yesterday in what many called the largest homosexual rights demonstration ever held in New York City.

title: Barry M. Mitnick Marries Margery S. Manesberg
description: Margery Sue Manesberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice D. Manesberg of St. Louis, was married there yesterday at the home of her parents to Barry Michael Mitnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold I. Mitnick of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Bernard Lipnick performed the ceremony.

title: Tonry, Who Quit Congress, Beaten In Louisiana Vote
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 26 (AP)Richard A. Tonry got the second chance he asked for when he resigned his seat in Congress last month, but the result was a sound thumping at the polls.

title: 4 Cycle Titles Won in Europe
description: Four European bicycling championships were held yesterday. In the Italian open championship, Enrique Paolini beat 93 opponents in the 166mile event at Sorrento. Marcel Tinazzi captured the 154mile championship of France, and Fedor Den Hertog took the Dutch professional title over a hilly, 155mile course. The Belgian crown was won by Michel Pollentier, who in the last month also has won the Tours of Italy and Switzerland.

title: Soloists Grow Apace at Rug Concert
description: There is an old and very funny revue skit by Marc Blitzstein called Triple Sec about a man at a nightclub. As he continues drinking the performers he is watching are doubled, tripled and quadrupled, a hallucination his sober companions don't share.

title: Chesapeake Crab Crop Making a Comeback
description: GLOUCESTER POINT, Va.The good word from Willard A. Van Engel was that the doomsayers were wrongat least for this yearand that the blue crabs are coming back.

title: Body of Slain U.S. Yachtsman To Be Buried in Caribbean Sea
description: KINGSTOWN, St. Vincent, June 26 (UPI)The body of a slain American yachtsman, Carl Schuster, was taken by plane today from St. Vincent to the neighboring island of Grenada for burial in the Caribbean waters he sailed for 17 years.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: MIDEAST PEACE PLAN ATTACKED BV JAVITS
description: The Carter Administration's peace ideas for the Middle East are unrealistic and likcly to increase rather than lessen the danger of renewed war, in the view of Senator Jacob K. Javits. The New York Republican says he secs an imbalance in what the Israelis and the Arabs are being called on to do, with too many concrete concessions demanded of Israel and not much more than promises of the Arabs.

title: Offer of B.P. Stock Draws Many Bids
description: LONDON, June 26 (Reuters)The giant sale of shares in Britain's partly stateowned oil company, British Petroleum, has been thoroughly oversubscribed, the Bank of England announced today.

title: Young Uses a Recorder In Talk With Reporters
description: RICHMOND, June 26 (AP)Andrew Young, who has often accused reporters of misquoting him or quoting him out of context, turned on a tape recorder he was wearing under his suit coat before speaking with reporters here yesterday.

title: Bronx Students Focus Cameras Close to Home
description: Sturlson Pahrr, a bantam of a boy with the stance of a lightweight fighter, took one look down a long street in the South Bronx and shook his head. We go down there, he said solemnly, they gonna mug us for these cameras.

title: Fiesta de San Juan Draws 11,000 to Mass in the Park
description: On St. John's Day in Puerto Rico, you fill a glass, cover it with paper, put a needle on the paper. The paper eventually saturates and sinks, and. Juan Aviles remembered yesterday, the needle floats, you'll have good luck. It floats 95 percent of the time, he saidbut then Puerto Ricans do work hard for their luck.

title: Bringing Up Ralph Nader: A Mother's Food for Thought
description: WASHINGTON  You are encouraged to come hungry, announced Ralph Nader on the telephone  for his mother was to he the cook.

title: Watson Wins Western Open
description: Tom Watson, the Masters champion, won the Western open golf tournament by a stroke with a last round of 69 for a total of 283. Page 37.

title: LEBANON REBUILDING ITS SHATTERED ARMY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24Lebanon is Slowly rebuilding its army, but faces political obstacles linked to the question of a Middle East settlement.

title: Dissident Actor in East Germany Follows His Star to West Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN, June 26When Manfred Krug crossed from East Berlin to West Berlin a few days ago he would have liked to consider his move as something normal, just moving from one part of the country to another.

title: Yugoslavs Back Spanish Party
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 26 (Reuters)The Yugoslav Communist Party, which has strongly supported the independent line followed by the Spanish and other West European Communist parties, said today that recent East European attacks on them were inspired by Stalinist conceptions.

title: Audit Shows Eagles Violated Bank Loan
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP)  In losing $1.27 million last season, the Philadelphia Eagles violated a bankloan agreement that limited total player salaries to $2.5 million, an audit has shown.

title: Trade Agreements Are Signed by U.S. And East Germany
description: WASHINGTON, June 26The United States concluded new accords this month on trade and economic relations with East Germany, which is listed as ninth among the world's most productive industrial countries.

title: Irish Setter Is Judged Best in Show at Staten Island
description: The Staten Island Kennel Club's 37th allbreed show at Fort Wadsworth featured 1,397 competing dogs yesterday but the final choice by Dr. Wolfgang A. Casper was narrowed to an Irish setter and a boxer. Ch. McCannon Marquis, the setter, was selected as best in show over Ch. Salgray's Nlarket Wise, as Casper put it, only by his glowing elegance and crowdpleasing movement.

title: American Crews Prosper at Nottingham
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 26The United States' crews competing in the Nottingham international regatta today enjoyed their most successful showing ever, winning or placing in all of today's major races.

title: TENNESSEE JAIL FIRE KILLS 42, INCLUDING LOCKEDUP PRISONERS
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn., June 26Fortytwo persons died today in a fire that poured choking smoke through the Maury County Jail here. Most of the victims were prisoners who were either locked in their cells or behind a security screen in the visiting area of the jail.

title: TAXABLE
description: TUESDAY

title: Feeling Fine
description: PRINCETON, N.J.During the early 1960's and for a decade thereafter, this nation markedly increased its commitment to improving medical care for all citizens. Federal dollars directed toward health activities soared from $2.1 billion to $15.1 billion annually. This came about due to a consensus of the times that professionals from the public and private sectors working together could produce a dramatic improvement in the medical care available to Americans, if the nation would consciously and in a planned manner make more resources available.

title: Taiwan Cautiously Easing Its Curbs on Dissenters
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 26Human rights has lately become a popular subject in Taiwan, and a flurry of articles has suddenly appeared in the local press, mostly emphasizing Taiwan's efforts in upholding human rights.

title: Capitol Awaits The Final Gavel
description: ALBANY, June 26Just before the end of any session, Jerome Kretchmer, counsel to the Senate Democrats, said the other day, there are always a few days when everything seems to he falling apart. That's where we are now.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DRUMS AT NOON A young drummer, Roy Haynes literally beat his way out of Boston in the 1940's, and ever since has been recognized in the profession as one of the nation's best percussionists. In 1962, for example, he won a Downbeat magazine critics' poll as a talent deserving wider recognition. He has worked with Lester Young, Charlie Parker, Miles Davis, Thelonious Monk and, for five years, with Sarah Vaughan.

title: Walter Kennedy, 64, Of N.B.A. Is Dead
description: Walter Kennedy, who served as Commissioner of the National Basketball Association during its period of greatest growth, died of cancer last night at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. He was 64 years old.

title: Supreme Court Ruling Sparks Moves to Halt Medicaid Abortions
description: A 20yearold woman sat in a St. Louis clinic the other day holding her ticket for abortionan orange welfare card. Where would I get the money to pay? she said.

title: STUDY OF DESERT BEAN FOR OIL IS PAYING OFF
description: It is not exactly an oil boom, but years of patient research into the oilbearing bean of the jojoba, a drab desert shrub, are beginnig to pay off in arid regions of the United States, Mexico and Israel.

title: TAXEXEMPT
description: TUESDAY

title: David Schultz, Retired Executive For Several Electronics Concerns
description: David T. Schultz, the president of the Allen B. du Mont Laboratories from 1956 to 1961 and a former senior vice president of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company, died Saturday in his home at 115 Central Park West. He was 83 years old.

description: B TONIGHT

title: Carter Attends Baptist Service
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)President Carter attended church today and heard the Rev. Dr. Edward Hughes Purden of the First Baptist Church say that promoting human rights in a world of dictators showed that the scriptures could be dynamite. Dr. Purden added that supporting integration at a church that segregated its congregation could be dynamite, too. Mr. Carter has supported efforts to desegregate his hometown church in Plains, Ga.

title: ISRAELI LEADER THANKS CARTER ON ARMS DECISION
description: TEL AVIV, June 26 (AP)Prime Minister Menahem Begin thanked President Carter today for his reported decision to supply Israel with $115 million worth of tanks, armored cars and antitank missiles.

title: A Commuter and His Shadow
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J.We have been traveling together for about a year. Perhaps longer than that, but it was about a year ago that I began to take notice of him.

title: Debbie Austin Sets Mark In Indiana Golf With a 207
description: PLYMOUTH, Ind., June 26 (AP)Debbie Austin carded a fiveundergar 67 today and won the $50,000 Hoosier Classic with a tournament record total of 207.

title: Hyde Overcomes Tanis For Jersey Tennis Title
description: KEARNY, N. J., June 26Hugh Hyde Jr. of Far Hills won both the singles and doubles finals today in the New Jersey State men's tennis championships at the Arlington Players Club.

title: Camden Suit Says Census Bureau Made Gross Undercount in City
description: CAMDEN, June 24The Census Bureau, which estimates that it missed some five million people in 1970, including 1.9 percent of the nation's whites and 7.7 percent of its blacks, has developed some new techniques and is trying them out here in a pre1980 test census.

title: Soccer
description: NORTH AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: 57,191 See Pele Score 3 Goals as Cosmos Win.
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 26Inspired by another large crowd, 57,191, at Giants Stadium and led by the brilliant Pele's three goals, the Cosmos scored a 52 triumph over the Los Angeles Aztecs in the North American Soccer League today.

title: Glenaris, $10.20, Takes $113,100 Coast Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 26 (AP)Bill Shoemaker piloted Glenaris to an upset victory today in the $113,100 Hollywood Oaks at Hollywood Park. Favored Taisez Vous finished, third in the 1 18mile race for 3yearold fillies.

title: Dance: N.Y.U.
description: To know that a ptarmigan is a species of North American grouse with completely feathered feet is little help in appreciating Nancy Meehan's new work, Ptarmigan Wall. But then it's not really necessary for this appealing piece, which she showed for the first time Thursday evening at New York University's School of Education auditorium.

title: Commodities: Ailing Cotton
description: Profits prove elusive in cotton futures as evaluations of market factors go awry. Page 43.

title: Walter Kennedy, 64, Of N.B.A. Is Dead
description: Walter Kennedy, who presided over the National Basketball Association's growth into a major league in the 1960's, died last night at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford. Conn.

title: World News Briefs
description: FLAVIGNY  SUR  OZERAIN, France, June 26 (Reuters)Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre of France, already prohibited from performing priestly duties, today ignored a severe papal warning and ordained a priest to a private ceremony at a monastery here.

title: Jody Cohen Becomes the Bride Of Peter Robbins, Cornell '74
description: Jody Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Cohen of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Robbins of Armonk, N. Y. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel.

title: Carol Thalia Flaxman Bride of Louis Richter
description: At Temple EmanuEl yesterday, Carol Thalia Flaxman. daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour L. Flaxman of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married to Louis Michael Richter, son of Jean F. Richter of Chicago and the late Dr. Irving B. Richter. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: GEORGE S. ENGLE
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., June 26 (UPI)  George E. Engle, a wealthy oilman who founded the Coconut Grove Playhouse in Miami, died at his home here yesterday.

title: .44Caliber Killer Wounds Two In Car Parked on Queens Street
description: The psychopathic killer who calls himself Son of Sam struck again early yesterday when he shot at a young couple, wounding them as they sat in a car parked on a residential street in Bayside, Queens.

title: Stephen Haff, Financial Editor Of The Paterson (N.J.) News
description: Stephen Haff, financial and business news editor of The Paterson (N.J.) News, died Saturday of leukemia at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Ringwood, N.J.

title: 66 Vietnamese Reach Haven With Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, June 26Sixtysix Vietnamese refugees who sailed from their country three weeks ago for no certain destination landed today in Israel, among the last places they had in mind when they set off into the Pacific in a leaky fishing boat.

title: Men Offer Main Wimbledon Drama as Top Women Advance More Predictably
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 26The women professionals keep telling the world there is great depth in their sport, that the tour has never been tougher, that it's only a matter of time and a baseline rally before the new faces become the next stars.

title: Machine Tool Orders Rose by 5.3% for May
description: May orders for new machine tools edged ahead of April's by 5.3 percent and reached $265.2 million, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported over the weekend.

title: MODERN THEBES FINDS HERITAGE A HEADACHE
description: THEBES, GreeceSeveral years ago a landowner on the main street of Thebes wanted to build an apartment house, but when he tore down an old structure and started digging a foundation, he discovered some ancient building stones.

title: CAMDEN SUIT ASSAILS CENSUS BUREAU TEST
description: CAMDEN, N.J., June 24The Census Bureau. which estimates that it missed some five million people in 1970, including 1.9 percent of the nation's whites and 7.7 percent of its blacks, has developed some new techniques and is trying them out here in a ore19S0 test census.

title: A Grand Decision for Grand Central
description: New York City has won a resounding victory in the fight to save Grand Central Terminala unanimous decision of the state Court of Appeals to uphold the building's landmark status. This was round three of a tenyear legal battle pitting the city against the Penn Central and a developer who wanted the Terminal's air rights for a piggyback office tower.

title: 2 Debuts Highlight City Ballet
description: Two debuts were the highlight of the New York City Ballet's program Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. The first was Heather Watts's first appearance as the maneating female in Jerome Robbins's The Cage, while the second debut showed Jorge Donn of Maurice Bjart's Company partnering Suzanne Farrell in George Balanchine's duet Meditation.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: EYeager. LOB Los Ahgeles 9, Cin cinnati 0. 2B ?? S?? Cov. Lopes. HRYeager (81, Driessen (81), Concepcion (4). SBRoss, Driessen 2.

title: When Zealotry Is King
description: LONDON, June 26Union printers blocked the publication of a national newspaper for many hours here last night because they disapproved of an advertisement it carried. Thereby hangs a tale of contemporary Britain.

title: WILLIAM C. BROWNING
description: William C. Browning, a founder of the Golden's Bridge (N.Y.) Hounds and an officer and director of Browning King & Company until his family's ownership of the company ended in the early 1930's, died Saturday at the Pavilion Nursing Home in Danbury, Conn. He was 84 years old and lived in Ridgefield, Conn., until a year ago.

title: U.S. and Soviet: Testing Time
description: WASHINGTON June 26The current state of United StatesSoviet relations, in terms of public appearance, might be compared to a round in a boxing match between a rangy young fighter and an overthehill but still dangerous slugger. That is also the way President Carter, who is 52 years old, appears to see his relationship with Leonid I. Brezhnev the 70yearold Soviet leader, according to the observations of three of his White House associates.

title: Backers of Coal Slurry Pipelines Expect a Victory
description: HOUSTON, June 26The proponents of coal slurry pipelines, bouyed by endorsements from the. Carter Administration, appear to be winning their long, bitter battle with the railroads for a piece of the action in transporting stripmined western coal.

title: Diplomatic Realignment in Africa Makes Americans Welcome in Sudan
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan  These days a United States Navy destroyer cruising the Red Sea can call at Port Sudan and get a cordial reception. So can a perspiring, briefcasetoting American businessman who checks into the new Hilton Hotel at the confluence of the Blue and White Niles.

title: Tom Sneva Triumphs in 500 at Pocono
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., June 26Only 100 miles remainedan easy 40minute drivefor the skilled Mario Andretti, who was leading today's Schaefer 500 comfortably when he roared into his pit area, nearly crashed into his crew and lost his chance at victory.

title: News Summary
description: The Spanish Communist Party rejected the recent harsh attack by Moscow on Santiago Carrillo, the Spanish Communist leader, and vowed that it would maintain its independence from the Soviet Union. Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Nina Simone a NoShow
description: Nina Simone, the singer and pianist who was to perform in New York for the first time in three years last night at the Newport Jazz Festival, failed to appear at Carnegie Hall for her midnight concert. According to the Festival producer George Wein, she was returning to Europe because of a fear and unhappiness in America.

title: Tennis
description: AT KEARNY. N.J. N.J. MEN'S CHAMPIONSHIPS

title: Oh Smacks 735th Homer
description: TOKYO, June 26 (AP)Sadaharu Oh blasted a threerun home run, his 19th homer of the season, and led the Yomiuri Giants to a 104 victory over the Yakult Swallows in Japanese baseball action today. Oh now has 735 career home runs, 20 fewer than Hank Aaron's major league career total of 755.

title: Carew Lifts Average to 403 as Twins Rout White Sox With 18 Hits
description: The largest regularseason crowd in the 17year history of the Minnesota Twins turned out yesterday in Bloomington, Minn., and was treated to a spectacular slugging display by the Twins. They pounded out 18 hits and set a club record for runs in a game in a 1912 rout of the Chicago White Sox. The triumph lifted the Twins into a onegame lead over the White Sox in the American League's Western Division.

title: HEART PATIENT IS DRAINED OF BLOOD FOR 37 MINUTES
description: McLEAN, VA., June 26 (UPI)Eugene Tison, 44 years old, has made medical history at the Washington Hospital Center.

title: State Town Meeting Is Held in Trenton
description: TRENTON, June 25New Jersey became the first urban state in the country to hold a town meeting assembly as citizens from all over the state met here to discuss local concerns and to share possible solutions.

title: $23 Million Graham Fund Disclosed
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 26 (AP)An arm of Billy Graham's ministry has amassed almost $23 million over the past seven years in land, stocks, bonds and cash holdings in a fund that has been. shielded from public view, The Charlotte Observer reported in its Sunday editions.

title: One District, 20 Schools and 32 Principals
description: School District 4 in East Harlem has 12 more principals than it has schools 32 principals for 20 schools.

title: Fight Urged on Computer Crime
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that new Federal legislation was needed to punish electronic burglars who used computers to steal or manipulate information or property. He said that he would introduce tomorrow a bill that would set penalties of 15 years in prison or a $50,000 fine or both for computer crime.

title: ALBANY IS CRITICIZED ON FOOD STAMP PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 26Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, and five other members of a House Agriculture subcommittee charged today that New York State was violating the rights of hundreds of thousands of needy New Yorkers who were eligible for food stamps but were not receivin them.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Books of The Times
description: Both the style and substance of this excellent book are reflected in that sentence. The subject is the rightwing Israeli underground militiaMenachem Begin's Irgun, the deadly Stern gang and their bombthrowing offshoot, the LEHIand J. Bowyer Bell recounts their adventures in rolling cadences and with a fine sense of their zealous desperation. The result is a skillfully written, fastpaced anecdotal narrative of one of the bloodiest and leastdocumented chapters of Zionist history.

title: Around the Nation
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 26 (UPI)The first major brush and forest fire of the season in South California blackened more than 2,000 acres of the Angeles National Forest by this morning and raced northward before being contained this evening.

title: Newton's Attorney Asserts U.S. Approved a Stopover in Canada
description: TORONTO, June 26A lawyer for Huey P. Newton, the former Black Panther leader who is being held in jail near here, said today that the United States Department of Justice had approved the stopover here by Mr. Newton before he returned to California to face charges of murder.

title: Ballet Stars Take Bows on Stage and at Alpine Reception
description: ALPINE, June 26At a little before 11 o'clock last night, Edward Verso of Oakland was standing on the stage of the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack acknowledging the applause and bravos for his performance as the lead dancer in the New Jersey Ballet's new production, Emperor Waltz.

title: Jazz: Rivbea
description: Studio Rivbea, 24 Bond Street, used to be one of a scant handful of new jazz alternatives to the NewportNew York Jazz Festival's more conservative fare. Now it is one of many, but a festival at Studio Rivbea is still an important event. Sam Rivers, the saxophonist who cofounded the studio with his wife, Bea, seems to select very carefully the musicians who will appear, and his loft is unusually comfortable and smoothly run. His festival continues nightly through the Fourth of July.

title: Race in Separate 800'sOvett Takes Mile in 3:54.69
description: LONDON, June 26Nine runners broke four minutes in the mile, and the world's top two halfmilers ran the 800, but not against each other, during the windup of the Debenham Jubilee Games today.

title: A Good Way to Hold Down Electric Bills
description: Everyone who pays a monthly electric bill understands the importance of saving a watt. But few Americans know that when they consume electric power is almost as important as how much they consume. The cost of producing electricity increases dramatically when utilities are forced to operate near peak capacity. If a sizable number of consumers could be persuaded to reduce demand during critical periods, the national power bill could be reduced by as much as $7 billion a year.

title: Federal Food Grading Systems Outmoded, Senate Panel Told
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)The Federal system of grading meat, produce and other food is outmoded and confusing, a Congressional report said today.

title: U.S. Men Beat West Germans, but Women Bow
description: GELSENKIRCHEN West Germany, June 26 (AP)Neil Pyke won the 10,000meter walk in 42 minutes 22.6 seconds, an American record, and the Unites States men's team defeated West Germany by 118104 today in a dual track and field meet.

title: SHIFT BY LEGISLATORS CHARGED BY N.A.A.C.P.
description: ST. LOUIS, June 26Officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, on the eve of the organization's 68th annual convention, bitterly accused some Northern legislators with opposing civil rights in recent years.

title: Eliska Hasek Becomes Bride
description: Eliska Hasek, director of the office of Presidential messages at the White House, and daughter of Joseph Karel Hasek of Washington, and Mrs. Milan Smutny of London, was married yesterday afternoon to Nicholas Jefferson Coolidge of New York, a vice president and a director of Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Reports of End of Pricing Split In OPEC Confirmed in Kuwait
description: KUWAIT, June 26 (AP)Kuwait's Minister of State, Abdul Aziz Hussein, confirmed today that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would soon announce an end to its twolevel price system for crude oil.

title: Superb. Singing by Betty Carter Overshadows 3 Jones Brothers
description: Betty Carter has known where she was going, musically, for more than 20 years. Her records of the late 50's, some of which have recently been reissued, make this quite evident; the essentials of her stylea personalized extension of the direction in which Billie Holiday was travelinghad already been formed by then.

title: Capitol Awaits The Final Gavel
description: ALBANY, June 26Just before the end of any session, Jerome Kretchmer, counsel to the Senate Democrats, said the other day, there are always a few days when everything seems to be falling apart. That's where we are now.

title: One Policeman Held, 2 Are Listed As Suspects in Buffalo Slaying
description: A Buffalo policeman was arrested on a manslaughter charge and two other officers were listed as suspects yesterday in the fatal beating and stomping of an 18yearold motorist by a group of six to 10 men after a minor traffic incident early Saturday morning.

title: Air Travelers Found Annoyed More by Infants Than by Smoking
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)  Frequent airline passengers are more irritated by crying babies than by cigarette smokers, but many would like tighter restrictions on the use of cigars and pipes, according to a survey released today.

title: India Alters Its Course in Key Areas of Foreign Policy
description: NEW DELHIIn addition to changing dramatically the daily lives of the Indian people by the restoration of civil liberties, the new Government here has also charted important new courses in foreign policy in the three months since its election victory.

title: 2 Killed as Search Plane Crashes
description: GUNNISON, Colo., June 26 (UPI)A Colorado Air Patrol plane participating in a search for a missing light plane carrying a California family crashed today in rugged high country, killing the pilot and his observer. The plane was among a dozen aircraft searching for Robert Adams, his wife, Diane, and their 19monthold son, missing since December on a flight from Ridgecrest, Calif., to Columbus, Ohio. Earlier searches were prevented by heavy snows.

description: Partial list of scheduled for week follows:

title: Spain's Communists Rebuff Soviet And Vow to Maintain Independence
description: MADRID, June 26In a defiant counterattack against Moscow, the Spanish Communist Party's Central Committee has firmly rejected Soviet criticism of Santiago Carrillo, its secretary general and vowed to continue its Eurocommufist line of independence.

title: Credit Market Price Gains Seen On Slower MoneySupply Growth
description: The credit markets perked up last week after the nation's money supply showed a $700 million decline, confounding many traders and analysts who had guessed that it would increase. As a result, bond prices rose Friday, and underwriters regained hope that the New York Telephone Company's $200 million of debentures yielding 7 percent would eventually be placed with investors.

title: 3,000 in Manchester, N.H., Hold A CounterRally for Nuclear Plant
description: MANCHESTER, N.R. June 26Some 3,000 construction workers, electric comparry employees and industry representatives rallied here today in support of the controversial proposed nuclear power plant in Seabrook.

title: Angolan Nationalist Group Says It Will Accept Help From South Africa to Aid Fight Against Government
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, June 26A senior spokesman for the Angolan nationalist faction that has been waging a bush war against the Luanda Government and its Cuban forces said here today that the organization, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, would accept South African assistance without apology if it were to be offered.

description: Herman N. Finkelstein, legal counsel to the law firm of Nickerson, Kramer, Lowenstein, Nessen, Kamin & Soll and an expert in real estate, trusts and corporate law, died Friday in his home at 4 East 88th Street. He was 76 years old.

title: Cubs Beat Mets, 5 to 2, For Sweep
description: CHICAGO, June 26Gentlemen, said Manager Joe Torre before today's final game of the series with the Chicago Cubs, now we can judge the character of the New Yorks Mets. Now we'll see if we can come back after being shut out in the first and blowing the second game.

description: The Carter Administration's peace ideas for the Middle East are unrealistic and likely to increase rather than lessen the danger of renewed war, in the view of Senator Jacob K. Javits. The New York Republican says he sees an imbalance in what the Israelis and the Arabs are being called on to do, with to many concrete concessions demanded of Israel and not much more than promises of the Arabs.

description: STANLEY, IdahoBill Harrah, the Reno gambling baron, has been a regular visitor to Stanley for almost 40 years. Apparently he likes this townhe has already bought half of it.

description: School District 4 in East Harlem has 12 more principals than it has schools 32 principals for 20 schools.

title: Notes on People
description: The White House announced yesterday that President Carter intended to nominate Walter LaBerge to be Under Secretary of the Army. Mr. LaBerge, who is 53 years old, has been serving as Assistant Secretary for defense support at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Previously he served as an Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for research and development. He is from Chicago.

title: Steelmakers Gloomy as Output Slumps for 4th Week
description: Pessimistic forecasts by steelmakers coincided yesterday with the fourth consecutive week of a slump in production.

description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday included all 22,000 Civil Service workers in Nassau County in a lawsuit brought by three of them to challenge 1 percent kickbacks allegedly demanded by county officials for appointment or promotion.

title: Drawbridge Is Stuck, 7 Trains Are Delayed
description: About 200 passengers were rerouted last night and early this morning when seven Amtrak and Conrail trains were delayed as a drawbridge was stuck open on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River.

title: French Politicians Fanning AntiGerman Sentiment
description: PARIS, June 27An effort by French politicians on the left and the right to revive antiGerman feelings has become a matter of concern on both sides of the Rhine.

title: Dave Anderson
description: More than an hour after having scored three goals Sunday in the Cosmos' 52 victory, Pel talked to the last newsman and signed the last autograph and slid into a blue Cadillac parked outside the locker room. When the sedan slowly approached the highwire fence at the players' entrance at Giants Stadium, it was surrounded by perhaps 200 people who realized that Pel was inside. The sedan crept carefully through the crowd as the people chanted Pel ... Pel ... Pel, and banged affectionately on the roof and fenders. Eventually the blue Cadillac sued off through the parking lot and the petiole turned and waited for Franz Beckenbauer to appear. In the Cosmos Phenomenon, most of the cheers are for Pel and Franz Beckenbauer, but Werner Roth understands what's happening perhaps better than any of the other Cosmos players. Werner Roth grew up kicking a soccer ball in the Ridgewood streets on the BrooklynQueens border. When he joined the Cosmos in 1972, virtually nobody knew who they were. Worse, virtually nobody cared. But now Werner Roth is the Cosmos' captain, and at halftime Sunday he looked around Giants Stadium and soaked up the significance of the 57,191 spectators, just as he had looked around the previous Sunday when the Cosmos drew 62,394 spectators, the largest crowd in United States soccer history.

title: People in Sports
description: Carlos Monzon, the world middleweight champion from Argentina, suffered a cut over his left eyebrow during a sparring session in Rome yesterday. The injury forced postponement of his July 9 title bout in Monte Carlo with Rodrigo Valdez, of Colombia, until either July 23 or 30.

title: Threat to Close Alaska Pipeline Termed a Bluff
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)The battle lines over transAlaska pipeline rates were drawn today as companies that own the pipeline said they might have to shut it down if the Interstate Commerce Commission did not approve their oil transport charges and the Government called that a bluff.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, June 27 (AP)The man convicted of shooting his estranged wife to death in front of 29 children in her classroom was sentenced today to life imprisonment at hard labor, with a recommendation of no parole.

title: Rangers Pick Billy Hunter As 4th Manager in a Week
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., June 27 (AP)Billy Hunter, a coach with the Baltimore Orioles, was named manager of the Texas Rangers today, becoming the Rangers' fourth field leader in less than a week.

title: BAN ON USE OF SACCHARIN EVEN BY DIABETICS STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)The Fpod and Drug Administration may prohibit saccharin use even by diabetics because of a new study linking the artificial sweetener to human bladder cancer, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Donald Kennedy. said today.

description: TOKYO, June 20Japan's politicians, who have been campaigning informally for weeks, can do it legally now following an official announcement of parliamentary elections July 10.

title: Black Family to Keep Its Farm in Alabama; Settlement Is Reached With Judge's Estate
description: ALICEVILLE, Ala., June 27 (AP)There is a new field of cotton growing on the Woolridge Farm. And the Joe Woolridge family will be able to see it and future cotton crops harvested on land that belongs to them.

title: Anker Says 12 Extra Principals In East Harlem May Be Excessive
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Irving Anker, said yesterday that he intended to meet with the new District 4 school board to go over what he described as the apparently excessive number of highly paid supervisors in the East Harlem district.

title: MARY C. SALISBURY
description: WASHINGTON, June 27Mary C. Salisbury, who served as Comptroller of the Democratic National Committee for 28 years, died Saturday in Bethesda, Md., after a short illness. She was 75 years old.

title: LOUIS SATTLER
description: Louise Sattler, a retired Brooklyn College professor of chemistry, died Wednesday at his home in Heritage Village, Southbury, Conn. He was 79 years old.

title: SUPREME COURT TO REVIEW RULINGS ON INTERSTATE GAS
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The Supreme Court agreed today to review two decisions by the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals that would lead to a reduction the supply of natural gas that reaches the interstate market.

title: Controversial Art Exhibit in Moscow Is Postponed
description: MOSCOW, June 27 An officially sanctioned exhibition by a prominent Soviet artist was indefinitely postponed today following a dispute over one controversial painting that portrayed the exiled writer Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn in prison garb along with other figures oonsigned to historical obscurity by the Kremlin.

title: Cominco Cuts Zinc Output 30%
description: Cominco Ltd., reported yesterday that it had cut zinc production at its refiner at Trail, British Columbia, by 30 percent. Production at that facility last year totaled 224,000 tons. The company said the reduction was an inventory control measure reflecting weak markets. Cominco also said, it planned to close its lead smelter at Trail for August to carry. out normal repair work.

description: The breakoff of merger negotiations between the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchangea mighthavebeen that could have changed the basic stracture of securities tradingfoundered essentially on one word: options.

title: The C.I.A., Cuba and Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON  Our Government should have no higher priority than stamping out terrorism. Civilization, as most Americans value it, breaks down as bombs explode in airports and trains full of children are seized. Yet, for the last 35 years, our Government has made regular use of terrorism as an instrument of foreign policy.

title: ALBERT EDISON MILLER, 88, A TECHNICAL OIL EXPERT
description: Albert Edison Miller, a technical expert who spent 53 years in the petroleum industry in the United States and Europe, died of heart failure at Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield, N.J. He was 88 years; old and lived in Westfield. N.J.

title: BUFFALO POLICEMAN DENIES KILLING YOUTH
description: BUFFALO, June 27Public criticism of official handling of the stomping murder of an 18yearold youth was voiced today as the victim, Richard Y. Long, was buried.

title: Mel Torme and Gerry Mulligan Bring Jazz Into Sharp Focus
description: Mel Torme, who may be the most accomplished of the current pop singers, has a keen sensitivity for jazz that is always an element in his performances but is rarely brought into focus as sharply as it was Sunday night in Carnegie Hall at the Newport Jazz Festival. Backed by Herb Pomeroy's big band from Boston and with Gerry Mulligan's baritone saxophone weaving in and out of his songs, Mr. Tome's jazz side worked its way up through a program that started in his pop vein and became increasingly jazzoriented as he went along.

title: Troy's Perjury Trial Starts in Jamaica Courtroom
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr.. former Democratic leader of Queens, went on trial yesterday for perjury allegedly committed last November under oath in State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz discusses the prospects for the stock of the Chemex Corporation, which recently was recommended in a market letter. Page 40.

title: Oil Tanker Explodes in French Port
description: SETE, France, June 27 (Reuters)A Finnish oil tanker exploded and set the sea ablaze today as two tugs towed it from this southern French tourist resort. The blast hurled most of the crew overboard and at least one seaman was killed, port officials said. The 11,321ton vessel. from Mariehamn, was ripped in two by the explosion and the severed aft section blocked the entrance to the harbor.

description: Monday, June 27, 1977

description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 (AP) World Team Tennis is going international with the formation of a sixteam European dvision next year, the league said today.

description: Monday, June 27, 1977

title: CYANIDE GAS BLAMED IN DEATHS IN JAIL FIRE
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn., June 27Cyanide fumes and carbon monoxide pouring from a padded cell were identified today as the deadly agents that killed 42 inmates and visitors in a fire that erupted in the Maury County Jail here yesterday.

title: Carey Planning to Sign State Ban On Topless Entertainment in Bars
description: ALBANY, June 27Governor Carey, with a blast at garish, smutty and filthy entertainment that has no place in New York City, said today he would sign a bill to ban topless entertainment in bars licensed by the State Liquor Authority.

title: Court Rules Lawyer May Advertise Fee For Routine Service
description: WASHINGTON. June 27The Supreme Court ruled today that lawyers cannot constitutionally be prohibited from advertising the fees they charge clients for routine legal services. The vote was 5 to 4.

title: Panamanians Protest U.S. Presence
description: PANAMA, June 27 (Reuters)Police officers wielding clubs dispersed about 200 students today from demonstrating in front of the United States Embassy, where the students shouted, Yankees go home. The students had demonstrated earlier in front of the Panamanian Foreign Ministry, painting its walls with antiAmerican slogans. There were no reports of casualties or arrests.

title: Importation of Green Sea Turtle Outlawed By Veto By Gov. Brown
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 27 (UPI)California will become the first state to, in effect, outlaw importation of green sea turtle products as a result of a bill vetoed by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.

title: MAJOR LOSSES CITED INHUGHESOPERATIONS
description: In the last six years of Howard R. Hughes's life, the Summa Corporation, his holding company with three of his longtime employees in firm control, lost $131,799,000, according to an affidavit by a Hughes tax lawyer filed in Chancery Court in Wilmington, Del.

title: Trade Deficit of $1.2 Billion In May Smallest for 1977
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Lower imports of oil and coffee, plus higher exports of manufactured goods and soybeans, helped the United States record its smallest trade deficit of the year last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SOME RULES OF E.P.A. CALLED INEFFECTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, June 27A report by the National Academy of Sciences has raised questions about the effectiveness of some of the Environmental Protection Agency's regulatory programs but found that the overall economic and energy cost ?? regulations was relatively low and manageable.

title: RON EINSTOSS
description: RENO, June 27 (UPI)Ron Einstoss, publisher of The Reno Evening Gazette and Nevada State Journal, died in a hospital yesterday after an 18month battle with leukemia. He was 47 years old.

title: Chancellor, Seeking a New NBC Pact, Reportedly Wooed by CBS
description: The five'year contract of John Chancelor, the premier anchorman for NBC News, expires next fall, and he is negotiating a new agreement with the network. CBS News is reported to have made overtures to Mr. Chancellor for the position of commentator, which will become vacant next November, when Eric Sevareid reathes the retirement age of 65if Mr.Chancellor and NBC fail to reach an agreement.

title: VELMA JOHNSTON, 65; WILD HORSES' FRIEND
description: RENO, Nev., June 27 (UPI)Velma B. Johnston, known as Wild Horse Annie for her campaign to halt slaughter of horses and burros that roam the West, died today. She was 65 years old.

title: 2 Witnesses Describe Man Fleeing Scene of Shooting As Police Press Efforts to Find the .44Caliber Killer
description: At least two witnesses near the scene of the latest attack by the .44calibre killer early Sunday morning told the police they saw a man dressed in a beige leisure suit jump into a car and hurriedly drive off.

description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)A joint subcommittee of the House Interior Committee today voted a sixmonth delay in consideration of coal slurry pipeline legislation, which is adamantly opposed by railroads.

description: The British Government yesterday out lined its plan to sell a 13.36millionshare block of British Petroleum Company stock in the United States and Canada, The Associated Press reported.

title: BIRTH RATE SLOWING IN INDONESIAN AREAS
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  International population experts concluding a census here have discovered significant evidence that the growth rate has slowed in eastern Java and Bali, the most densely populated region of the fifth most populous country.

Ziegler, the N.H.L.'s presidentelectwho was running the highpitched meetings in Chicago.

title: POLITICAL BATTLING RENEWED IN HAWAII
description: HONOLULU, June 27Gov. George R. Ariyoshi and Mayor Frank F. Fasi of Honolulu are on a collision course in the latest development in Hawaii's controversy over efforts to control the rising population.

title: Citing Quackery, Carey Plans Vetoes On 2 Laetrile Bills
description: ALBANY, June 27  Governor Carey said today he would veto any bill permitting the use of laetrile, the purported anticancer drug, because I believe it's not only quackery, it may be fraud and, indeed, profiteering on a worthless drug.

title: LAWYERS IN HANAFI CASE REPORTED UPSET AT JUDGE

title: About New York
description: The talk of searching for the .44caliber killer momentarily struck on ruminations of courtship. At his desk in the Flushing precinct station house, speaking around the heel of his sandwich lunch, Deputy Inspector Timothy J. Dowd, a friendly, shrewd detective, tried for a hit of felicitous phrasing in describing what we all already knowthe type of victims chosen by this unknown armed psychopath  and he talked of courting females and young men.

title: Filling Humanities Post Is an Art; Search Sparks Carter's Interest
description: When Dr. Ronald S. Berman resigned as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities last January after five years, no one in Washington foresaw trouble in filling the post. Yet what started out as a lowkey effort to replace him has mushroomed into an intensive talent search bringing more than 80 names into consideration.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Most of the candidates recommended for the job of United States Attorney in New Jersey have been interviewed by the Justice Department in Washington, it was disclosed yesterday.

description: Well, said Dunleavy, I see where the Democrats gave a thousanddollaraplate dinner at the Waldorf and 800 people showed up.

title: Senate Votes to Let Courts Name Special Prosecutors For High Level Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)The Senate passed tonight a bill providing for the appointment by courts of special prosecutors to handle investigations involving the President or other highlevel officials of the executive branch.

title: Bridge:

Blumenthal and his partner, Mike Lawrence of Berkeley, Calif., form one of the country's strongest partnerships.

title: U.S. CALLS ON ISRAEL TO QUIT SOME LANDS IN ALL THE SECTORS

title: SPAIN'S LEADING RED SEES SOVIET THREAT
description: MADRID, June 27Santiago Carrillo, secretary general of the Spanish Communist Party, said today that the Soviet Union might attempt to set up a rival Spanish party to battle the emerging doctrine of Eurocommunism.

description: The driver of a car that went out of control and killed three women sitting on a bench on Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on a number of charges including manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide, speeding and auto theft.

Mr. Leinsdorf's program had neither a guest soloist nor a novelty to lure the audience, just three symphonic staples by Mozart, Beethoven and Stravinskyenough wonderful music to keep everyone happy.

title: Saigon Chief Says Collectivization Will Be Completed in South by 1979
description: HONG KONG, June 27All business and agriculture in what once was South Vietnam are to be fully collectivized by 1979, the senior Communist official for Saigon has disclosed.

title: Meadowlands

title: Capital Hotel Chef Honored by French, But His Patrons Can't Sample the Fare

But ornamenting its lobby is a trophy of which the hotel is very proud, attesting to the talents of its executive chef.

title: Saudi Iceberg Plan: Will It Hold Water?
description: PARIS, Tune 27 (AP)A Saudi Prince and a French polar explorer said today that international experts would gather in the United States this fall to consider using nuclear submarines to push icebergs to countries short of water.

title: RHODESIANS REPORT 31 ARE KILLED IN DAY
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 27 (Reuters)The Rhodesian military command reported today that 31 persons had died in a single day of fighting with black nationalist guerrillas, suggesting there had been major clashes.

title: Pope, Installing 5 as Cardinals, Again Warns Rebellious Prelate
description: ROME, June 27Pope Paul VI appealed anew today to the rebellious French Archbishop, Marcel Lefebvre, to abandon his plans to ordain 14 priests and 22 subdeacons Wednesday at his unauthorized seminary in Switzerland.

title: Supreme Court Activities
description: The Court refused to review, and thus left in effect, a decision by the New Jersey Supreme Court last November that invalidated rules of certain nonprofit, nonsectarian hospitals prohibiting elective abortions on their premises. The New Jersey court had seemed to base its ruling on state law regarding the obligations of quasipublic institutions. The majority gave no reasons for the Court's refusal to review the case.

title: State Bill Is Threat To Sunday Openings
description: A threat to continued Sunday openings by department stores and supermarkets in New York State was raised yesterday when the state's Senate rules committee reported to the Senate floor an amended bill which would prohibit major merchandise categories from being sold on Sunday.

title: Policemen on Bicycles Arrest Five In a Girl Gang Linked to Terror
description: CHICAGO, June 27 (UPI)Bicycleriding policemen patroling a South Side neighborhood have cracked down on a gang of teenage girls believed to have been responsible for terrorizing, beating and robbing elderly neighborhood residents.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Blue Jays Halt Bid in 9th After 2 Score
description: TORONTO, June 27After 11,453 games in the United States, the Yankees played a regularseason game in a foreign land for the first time tonight and they instantly helped United StatesCanadian relations.

title: Pope, Installing 5 as Cardinals, Again Warns Rebellious Prelate
description: ROME, June 27Pope Paul VI appealed anew today to the rebellious French Archbishop, Marcel Lefebvre, to abandon his plans to ordain 14 priests and 22 subdeacons Wednesday at his unauthorized seminary in Switzerland.

title: Rep. Jordan Warns of Shift to the Right
description: PITTSBURGH, June 27 (AP)Women's rights are being hurt by a perceptible shift of America to the right, Representative Barbara Jordan told participants in a Womankind Conference, sponsored by the International Women's Wear Commission this past weekend.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Evert Crushes Mrs. King by 61, 62
description: WIMBLEDON. England, June 27It was a match Chris Evert wanted to win badly, a challenge, she said, at a time when new challenges are scarce in her tennis career. Win it she did. 61, 62. The margin was so big that Billie Jean King, her opponent, got only one more game against the topseeded defending champion on the center court than 14yearold Tracy Austin did.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Monday, June 27, 1977

title: MEDICAID IS BANNED IN SOME ABORTIONS
description: TRENTON, June 27A Federal District Court judge ruled today that an 18monthold New Jersey law barring the payment of Medicaid funds for elective abortions could go into effect pending a final hearing next month.

title: Zuccotti, ExBeare Aide, to Help Javits and Moynihan With City
description: New York's two Senators, Jacob K. Javits, Republican, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat, joined yesterday to announce that John E. Zuccotti, who has just resigned as First Deputy Mayor of New York City, would serve as their unpaid consultant for New York City affairs.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NET PROFITS An expedition of New York Zoological Society fish hunters scoured the waters of the Lawa River in Surinam, the former Dutch colony on the northeast coast of South America, and returned with a netful of exotic fish.

title: TREASURY PLANS SALE OF $1.5 BILLION BONDS
description: The Treasury is scheduled to sell $1.5 billion of 15year bonds early this afternoon, and Government securities dealers yesterday predicted the new securities would yield 7.3 percent or a little less.

title: Major League Scores
description: EFosse, Belanger, DPBaltimore 2. LOBBaltimore ?? Cleveland 5. 2bDauer, Muser, Carty 2, Melton HR?? SBS??pay, PaKetly, SShopay.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The helicopter that turned over on Its side atop the Pan Am Building last month, killing five persons, probably will have to be removed piece by piece by elevator, according to an insurance company spokesman.

title: State Orders Edison Landfill Shut
description: TRENTON, June 27The State Department of Environmental Protection ordered today that KinBuc Inc. in Edison Township stop accepting solid waste and close its landfill operation within 30 days.

title: YONKERS POLICE PACT QUESTIONED BY STATE
description: YONKERS, June 27An aide to State Comptroller Arthur Levitt said today that Yonkers could not use the promise of new state funds to balance its budget. The pledge of those funds was the key to an agreement that ended a sickout by 450 policemen last week that had left this citythe fourth largest in the state without protection.

title: $250,000 Rembrandt Recovered In an F.B.I. Fence Operation
description: BUFFALO, June 27  A Rembrandt stolen in France in 1971 and valued at S250,000 was recovered when officials smashed a fence operation here, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. F.B.I. agents along with state and local policemen arrested 23 suspects throughout western New York and other suspects still were being sought.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The caption under a picture in The Times yesterday incorrectly identified a New York State Assemblyman as George W. Miller. It was a picture of Woodrow Lewis, Democrat of Brooklyn.

title: Cubs Beat Expos, Refuse to Buckle
description: At a time when supposed baseball experts are expecting the Chicago Cubs to revert to their alsoran status of the last 30 National League seasons, the leaders of the Western Division are playing at the top of their stunning form.

title: Colorado Paper's Price Cut
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, June 27 (UPI)The new management of the Colorado Springs Sun, a morning newspaper, announced today that it was reducing its price from 15 cents to 10 cents and from 35 cents to 25 cents for Sunday editions. The Sun was bought by the Oklahoma Publishing Company from the Colorado Publishing Company.

title: WILLIAM D. RICHARDSON
description: William D. Richardson, a salesman, died Sunday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 52 years old and a resident of Huntington.

title: Jordan Named Chief Of BBDO Unit in U.S.
description: James J. Jordan Jr., president of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, the domestic operating company of BBDO International, was named its chief executive yesterday. A week ago, Bruce Crawford, president of the parent company, became its chief executive.

title: LENORA WALKER HOLLOWAY
description: Lenora walker Holloway, a former teacher and club woman, died Saturday at the Sheridan Manor Nursing Home in Buffalo. She was 85 years old and a resident of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Aides Say Beame Never Intended To Carry Out All of Parking Bans
description: Aides to Mayor Beame said yesterday that the Mayor had never intended to put into effect all of a court order banning most onstreet parking in Manhattan.

title: Assembly Democrats in Trenton Pass Bill Creating Energy Office
description: TRENTON, June 27  Assembly Dmocrats, using all the pressure at their command, tonight brought out of order and passed a bill creating a state energy office.

title: Eskimos, United by Alaska Meeting, to Press Claims
description: OTTAWA, June 25Eskimos of Canada. Alaska and Greenland, fresh from their first international conference, are preparing to press a series of demands upon their respective government ranging from land claims to political recognition.

title: SPAIN'S LEADING RED SEES SOVIET THREAT
description: MADRID, June 27Santiago Carrillo, secretary general of the Spanish Communist Party, said today that the Soviet Union might attempt to set up a rival Spanish party to battle the emerging doctrine of Eurocommunism.

title: KHALID WANTS TO RESIGN, ARAB BUSINESSMEN REPORT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27Arab businessmen arriving here from Saudi Arabia say they have heard from sources close to the royal palace that King Khalid, who is ailing, has expressed a wish to abdicate.

title: New York Will Allow Doctors to Advertise
description: The New York State Board of Regents plans to allow doctors and other professionals to advertise, Regent Emlyn Griffith said yesterday. The Committee on Professional Disciplines, which Mr. Griffith heads, has already unanimously approved regulations, which will become effective in October. Lawyers do not come under the board's jurisdiction.

title: U.S. Statement on the Middle East
description: We believe strongly that progress toward a negotiated peace in the Middle East is essential this year if future disaster is to be avoided.

title: F.B.I. Bars Use of Technicalities To Deny Pleas to Get Information
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)Under new freedom of information guidelines issued by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, the Federal Bureau of Investigation will not use technicalities to deny information or to cover up official wrongdoing, Justice Department officials told Congress today.

title: COMMITTEE UPHOLDS GASOLINE TAX ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The House, Ways and Means Committee voted today, for the second time, in favor of a plan to eliminate the Federal income tax deduction for state and local gasoline taxes, although the proposal faces an uncertain future.

title: Television
description: 11:00 A.M. The Story of. Louis Pasteur (1936) (5)

title: Reader's Digest Says It Didn't Check Cancer Story With the Johnsons
description: Reader's Digest again defended yesterday its article stating that Lyndon B. Johnson had secret surgery for skin cancer while President, but the magazine conceded that it had not independently checked the facts with members of the Johnson family or the Johnson Administration.

title: PRESSES STOP IN DISPUTE AT THE NEW YORK POST
description: The New York Post stopped its presses about 4 P.M. yesterday as a result of a dispute with the pressmen, Sidney Orenstein, lawyer for the newspaper, said.

title: Rejected Students Win in City College Suit
description: City College will have to pay damages of $1,500 apiece to at least nine and maybe more white and Asian students who had been turned down for admission in 1974 to its Center for Biomedical Education, which trains wouldbe physicians.

title: U.S. Aide in Brazil Attacked
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 27 (Reuters)The United States Consul in the northeastern Brazilian city of Recife, Marvin Hoffenberg, escaped unhurt when a young man opened fire on his car over the weekend, an American Embassy spokesman announced today. Mr. Hoffenberg was recently host to Rosalynn Carter and introduced to her two American missionaries in Brazil who described the tortures they said they had been subjected to and had witnessed in the Recife Prison, where they had been detained for three days.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Cairo Newspaper Editor Killed
description: CAIRO, June 27 (AP)Mahmoud Abdul Aziz Mahmoud. 50 years old, managing editor of the semiofficial Cairo newspaper Al Ahram, and his chauffeur were killed yesterday when their car ran off a desert road and overturned, his paper reported today. Aly Hamdy elGamal, the editorinchief, suffered slight injuries, Al Ahram said.

title: JOSEPH P. M'LAUGHLIN
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP)Joseph P. McLaughlin, a former newspaperman. who was a political consultant for state and national political candidates in Pennsylvania, died here yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter des??gnates OTB listing

title: SWISS VOTERS TO DECIDE ON ALLOWING ABORTIONS
description: GENEVA, June 27  After three years of acrimonious debate, the Swiss Parliament has passed a bill that would permit abortions for other than medical reasons. But it is to go into effect only if a proposal to allow abortions freely within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy is defeated in a referendum that had been previously scheduled for Sept. 25.

title: Thieves Take a Mare In Foal to Secretariat
description: PARIS, Ky., June 27 (Reuters)Fanfreluche, a broodmare in foal to Secretariat whose worth is estimated at $500,000, was stolen from a paddock at Claiborne Farm here over the weekend; the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today. The F.B.I. said the thieves had cut a fence and apparently led the Canadianbred mare to a truck.

title: Court Rules HeightWeight Requirement for Job May Discriminate Against Women
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The Supreme Court ruled today that employment requirements for height and weight discriminate illegally against women when employers fail to demonstrate that the tests have some real relation to the ability to handle the job.

title: Dealing With Fidel
description: WASHINGTON  Negotiating with Cuba is no longer inevitable, it has begun. My purpose is not to question the wisdom of talking to Fidel Castro, but to suggest how we should go about it. What's important is that the Carter Administration's mindless moralizing about human rights is likely to gain us nothing. In fact, it is more likely to worsen the lot of the Cuban people.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: WASHINGTONAlthough no one seems willing to admit it publicly, a major dispute has developed within the Carter Administration over the seriousness of the nation's huge foreign trade deficit. The closest that one top Government official came to acknowledging it recently was to concede that a difference of perpective on the issue exists between some departments of the Federal Government. The Treasury Department has taken what appears to be a benign attitude toward a trade deficit that so far has been running about $20 billion to $25 billion for 1977. By contrast, the imbalance has stirred considerable concern at the Commerce Department, as it has among many financial analysts in the private sector and at the Bank for International Settlements, the central bankers' bank, in Basel, Switzerland.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, June 27One of the last radical strongholds in China, the eastern province of Anhwei, has been put under the control of three longexperienced political figures who represent the old guard of Chinese politicians.

title: It's Cozy, Comfy And au Courant
description: Other years it was knitted caps. Or kneehigh boots. Or coatlike sweaters. This fall, the magic word in fashion is shawl. It's the accessory of the moment that transforms an old outfit and makes a new one look justborn. What's more, it makes sense. Besides being decorative, it keeps you warm.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Aide Says Carter Disappoints Blacks
description: ST. LOUIS, June 27President Carter's goal of a balanced budget was attacked tonight by a leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as harmful to the interests of blacks.

title: Senate Unit Upholds Clinch River Breeder
description: The $2 billion Clinch River breeder demonstration project, which the Carter Administration would like to cancel as part of a campaign to limit the spread of nuclear weapons technology, yesterday won the backing of a Senate committee.

title: TVEquipped Tractors Lighten the Long Hours
description: FREEHOLD, N. J.I don't want to sound oldfashioned, said Warren Wagner, but I don't see how you can drive a tractor and . watch TV at the same time.

title: Kennedy Plans Hearings to Study Antitrust Practices in Medicine
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the Senate antitrust subcommittee, which he heads, would hold hearings on anticompetitive practices in the medical and hospital industries.

title: Severe Overcrowding Cited
description: The Italian Consul General in New York emphasized yesterday that the ban on foreign students applied to all foreigners and was not aimed specifically at Americans.

title: Gordon V. Adams at 72, Headed Canadian Firm's New York Office
description: Gordon V. Adams, a retired banker, died Saturday at his Sherman, Conn., home., He was 72 years old.

title: MOSCOW STILL BEAMING MICROWAVES, U.S. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)The Russian are still beaming microwave radiation at the United States Embassy in Moscow, but tests of Americans who used to work there have shown no harmful health effects, the State Department said today.

title: In Memoriam
description: AUGERRachel. Your second year In Eternity. Birds still sing for you and roses bloom around your window. You never really went away although the clocked stopped forever on June 28, 1975.

title: Market Place
description: There is always hope that some day cancer will be cured, and it follows that any company identified with efforts to eradicate this dread disease will be favored by speculators.

title: Nina Simone's Concerts Canceled
description: Nina Simone, who was scheduled to perform in New York for the first time in three years Sunday night at the Newport Jazz Festival, failed to appear at Carnegie Hall for her midnight concert.

title: KitchenTable Justice
description: If you're a pregnant woman with enough money to pay for an abortion in a hospital, you've got an ironclad constitutional right to have that abortion. If you're a pregnant woman without enough money to pay for an abortion in a hospital, you've got an ironclad constitutional right either to beg or borrow the money, or to have yourself butchered on a kitchen table off some back alley.

title: Two Jazz Groups Are Electrifying
description: Musicians involved in the jazz avantgarde have usually approached electronic instrumentation with misgivings. Electronics are typical of the worlds of rock, soul, modern Europeanderived or classical music, and jazzrock, a music which most avantgardists seem to consider artistically regressive and commercially motivated. Only Sun Ra, Sonny Sharrock and a few other keyboard players or electric guitarists have convincingly integrated electronics into the primarily acoustic textures of the new jazz.

title: Youth Charged in Fire Said He Wanted to Run Again
description: DOUSMAN, Wis., June 27 (UPI)I am sorry, Al, but it is in my mind to run again, so I must.

title: Groucho Marx Reported Gaining
description: LOS ANGELES, June 27 (UPI)Groucho Marx, the comedian, hospitalized with a lung inflamation, was reported improving today, but it was not known how long he would remain in the hospital. He is suffering from pneumonitis, a condition described as similar to pneumonia but not so severe.

title: House Votes Restrictions On Federal Legal Agency That Assists Poor People
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)The House voted today to restrict the amount of money the Legal Services Corporation could receive from Congress and the ways in which it could use the money on behalf of poor people.

title: GOLD PRICE UP SHARPLY; DOLLAR IS OFF ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 27 (AP)Gold jumped $2 an ounce to close at $143 in London today and rose almost as much in Zurich. The dollar, meanwhile, eased against major European currencies.

title: A Kennedy Mass Is Scheduled At Stamford Church Thursday
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 27A funeral mass for Walter Kennedy, the former commissioner of the National Basketball Association, who died yesterday, will be held Thursday at Il A.M. at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Struggling With School Desegregation
description: At first glance, the Supreme Court has moved neither forward nor backward constitutionally in its longawaited decision on school desegregation. in Dayton, Ohio. The great fear of liberals on this issue had been that the Court would undo the landmark Denver case, which empowered Federal judges to order desegregation and busing throughout a school system wherever official segregation had been found to have systemwide effect. The Denver precedent appears to have survived the Dayton case, even though a court plan for widespread busing in Dayton must now be abandoned for something more modest.

title: Metroliner Fire Delays 11 Trains
description: PERRYVILLE, Md., June 27 (AP)A motor fire on a Washingtonbound Metro liner resulted in delays for several hundred passengers today as 11 trains were held up and another was canceled on Amtrak's main line between New York and Washington. An Amtrak spokesman in Philadelphia said the fire broke out at 12:39 P.M. in a traction motor of a train due in Washington at 1:29 P.M. There were no reports of injuries.

title: CYANIDE GAS BLAMED IN DEATHS IN JAIL FIRE
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn., June 27Cyanide fumes and carbon monoxide pouring from a padded cell were identified today as the deadly agents that killed 42 inmates and visitors in a fire that erupted in the Maury County Jail here yesterday.

title: Banque Arabe Adds To Stake in Reynolds
description: A Frenchbased investment bank halfowned by Arab interests has quietly built up its stake in Reynolds Securities International, the big American brokerage house, to nearly 16 percent.

title: Baby Brokers Reaping Huge Fees
description: The scarcity of adoptable Caucasian infants has become so critical in this country that prices paid for them on the illegal market now run as high as $20,000, with brokers getting most of the money. The black market, so extensive that includes international networks for procuring infants, is under investigation by prosecutors in New York and several other major cities.

title: Effects of Ruling on Lawyers
description: Today's decision will effect profound changes in the practice of law. Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. wrote yesterday in dissenting from the Supreme Court's ruling that lifted the ban against lawyers' advertising their fees.
