Few lawyers would dispute Justice Powell's prediction, but, in the confusion that inevitably accompanies a major decision, there was little agreement as to what these changes would be and how quickly they would come about.

title: $250,000 Rembrandt Recovered In an F.B.I. Fence Operation
description: BUFFALO, June 27  A Rembrandt stolen in France in 1971 and valued at $250,000 was recovered when officials smashed a fence operation here, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. F.B.I. agents along with state and local policemen arrested 23 suspects throughout western New York and other suspects still were being sought.

title: Passion for Sea Persists, but Positions Become Scarce
description: If Eugene O'Neill were writing his seaplay Anna Christie today, he would probably have the blustery ship's stoker, Mat Burke, traveling the Staten Island ferry to satisfy his passion for the sea but earning a living by driving a cab.

title: Town Auction Ends Tourist Site Dream
description: JONES, Mich., June 27 (AP)Piece by piece. Jones fell to the auctioneer's gavel over the weekend as a Kitty Litter magnate gave up h:s dream of turning this tiny town into a tourist attraction.

title: Major Steel Issues Lead the Decline as Dow Falls 5.60
description: Bluechip stocks, particularly steel issues, were prominent losers yesterday in a general market decline that saw the Dow Jones industrial average drop 5.60 points in moderate trading.

title: Miss Evert Crushes Mrs. King by 61, 62
description: WIMBLEDON. England, June 27It was a match Chris Evert wanted to win badly, a challenge, she said, at a time when new challenges are scarce in her tennis career. Win it she did. 61, 62. The margin was so big that Billie Jean King, her opponent, got only one more game against the topseeded defending champion on the center court than 14yearold Tracy Austin did.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Jerome Kurtz, the new commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, is taking a hard look at taxing fringe benefits. There are indications that everything from personal use of the corporate jet to companypaid taxi rides for late  working employees will come under scrutiny.

title: Assembly in Albany Approves Weakened Bill to Decriminalize Possession of Small Amounts of Marijuana
description: ALBANY, Tuesday, June 28The Assembly voted early this morning, 79 to 63. to approve a weakened bill that would end criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana. seven Republican votesleft some ques. But the slim marginwhich included tion over what the future of the measure Would be in the Republicancontrolled Senate. Seventysix votes are needed for passage in the Assembly.

title: Arthur W. Perdue, 91, Founder Of Poultry Concern in Maryland
description: SALISBURY, Md. June 27 (AP)Arthur W. Perdue, founder of Perdue Inc., one of the nation's largest poultry producing companies, died today at Peninsula General Hospital here. He was 91 years old.

title: Dollar Slips Against Japanese Yen
description: TOKYO, June 27 (AP)The dollar fell slightly against the Japanese yen in moderate trading on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today. The dollar closed at 271.625 yen, compared with 272.025 yen Friday.

title: Money
description: Monday, June 27, 1977

title: Bridge Repairs Scheduled
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey police said yesterday that because of repairs on the George Washington Bridge, motorists traveling toward New York and intending to use the Henry Hudson Parkway or Riverside Drive would have to use the upper level of the bridge from 8 P.M. until 6 A.M. through Thursday. All 14 lanes on the bridge will be open to traffic during rush hours. The parkway and the drive will be reachable then via both the upper and lower levels, the police said.

title: Court Rules Lawyer May Advertise Fee For Routine Service
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Supreme Court ruled today that lawyers cannot constitutionally be prohibited from advertising the fees they charge clients for routine legal services. The vote was 5 to 4.

title: News Summary
description: In a policy statement directed at Israel's new Government, the Carter Administration said that in return for an Arab agreement for a true peace, Prime Minister Menahem Begin should agree to an Israeli withdrawal from some occupied lands cffi all fronts and to the formation of a Palestinian homeland. The statement, affirming previous Administration positions, had the effect of warning Mr. Begin in advance of his trip to Washington next month that he faced a dispute if he refused to negotiate a withdrawal from at least part of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Profiles of Psychopath's Victims
description: Five of the shootings occurred in Queens, two in the Bronx. All but one took place on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday. Most of the victims were couples seated in parked cars in the early morning hours. Three of the couples had been to the movies just prior to the attacks; one couple had been to a discothque. Most of the women victims had long, darkbrown hair; so did one of the male victims.

title: Copper Futures Fall 2.80 Cents; Soybeans and Wheat Up Sharply
description: Futures prices for copper, often considered the key industrial commodity, plunged to the daily downward limit of 3 cents a pound yesterday before recovering a bit to close off 2.80 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Except for a fleeting encounter with Bernardine Dohrn, that bad Weather person, before she went underground, I have never knowingly been in the company of a terrorist, yet I feel intimately acquainted with several. The introductions were arranged, long before the current fashion for hijackings and hostages, by a few novelists who transmitted their fascination to the impressionable reader. For me, the prototype of the calling will always be The Professor, met in the pages Joseph Conrad's The Secret Agent and never forgotten.

title: Books of The Times
description: When Rex Reed wearies of too much makebelieve in his job as film, drama and nightclub critic, he likes to devote an occasional day to reality, he tens us in the diary that kicks off Violets & Vitriol, otherwise a collection of celebrity interviews. Reality, in Rex Reed's hyperventilated world, means going to cocktail parties.

title: TVEquipped Tractors Lighten the Long Hours
description: FREEHOLD, N. J.I don't want to sound oldfashioned, said Warren Wagner, but I don't see how you can drive a tractor and watch TV at the same time.

title: AVCO INCOME CLIMBS 6.1% IN MAY QUARTER
description: The Avco Corporation, a conglomerate whose operations range from insurance to aircraft equipment, reported yesterday that net income rose 6.1 percent in the May quarter, although firsthalf net was down 13.1 percent. In the 1976 halfyear, there had been an extraordinary gain of $20 million on property.

title: The Standings
description: Tuesday, June 28, 1977

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Bill Tarrant's Best Way to Train Your Gun Dog (David McKay Co., 186 pages, illustrated, $9.95) is delightful. This is no dry compendium of how to raise a dog for fieldtrial competition or hunting, but happy and informative reading throughout.

title: JUSTICES BACK ORDERS ON REMEDIAL CLASSES AS AID IN INTEGRATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The Supreme Court ruled today, 9 to 0, that Federal courts in school desegregation cases may order school districts to provide remedial education programs to help children recover from the effects of going to illegally segregated schools.

title: Carter Names Panel on Military Pay and Pensions
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  President Carter announced today the appointment of a ninemember commission to propose changes in the system of military pay, pensions and benefits that now make up more than half of defense spending and to analyze how well the volunteer armed services system is working.

title: Working on Plan for Settlement
description: LONDON, June 27 (Reuters)Britain and the United States are working on a package of three proposals for a negotiated settlement of the Rhodesia dispute, British officials said today.

title: No Love Lost at Wimbledon
description: When Grantland Rice wrote those lines, neither he nor the world had ever heard of Ilie Nastase, and the great sportswriter went to his grave innocent of the crude drama the Rumanian star was to bring to the genteel game of tennis.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Sotheby Parke Bernet Group announced in London yesterday the details of the share offering it said in April would make it a public company. The international art auction house plans to sell 3.85 million ordinary shares for the equivalent of $2.58 each, or a total of $9.9 million. That would amount to about 35 percent of its equity base.

title: Deaths
description: ARMSTRONGJasper H., Jr., on June 17, 1977 of N. Y. C., beloved son of Mrs. Beatrice Armstrong and the late Jasper Armstrong Sr., brother of Robert Armstrong and Jasmine Turner. Service and cremation were held at the convenience of the family.

title: Shakespeare in the Park Opens Without the Bard of Avon
description: It was a Joseph Papp production all the way under the hot sun in Central Park yesterday.

title: Baby Brokers Reaping Huge Fees
description: The scarcity of adoptable Caucasian inkilts has become so critical in this country that prices paid for them on the illegal market now run as high as $20,000, with brokers getting most of the money. The black market, so extensive that it includes international networks for procuring infants, is under investigation by prosecutors in New York and several other major cities.

title: GIRL, 16, SUES JERSEY ON FLAGPLEDGE LAW
description: NEWARK, June 27Some time before school reopens in the fall, a Federal Judge here is expected to rule on the constitutionality of a state law that requires all pupils at least to stand at attention while the pledge of allegiance to the American flag is being recited in their classrooms.

title: A.C.L.U. Unit Scores Anita Bryant
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 27 (UPI)The Arkansas affiliates of the American Civil. Liberties Union has adopted a resolution condemning Anita Bryant for her campaign against homosexuals. The A.C.L.U. board of directors, at its annual meeting Saturday, also adopted a resolution urgng state and local governments and the Federal Government to ban discrimination based on sex, sexual preference or marital status. Miss Bryant led the campaign in Dade County, Fla., for repeal of an ordinance prohibiting discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Legislature Adopts Carey's Plan For a $750 Million Bond Issue
description: ALBANY. June 27The Assembly gave final passage tnight to Governor Carey's proposal for a $750 million bond issue to finance construction projects that would generate jobs in the private sector.

title: Fifth Death Linked To Vinyl Chloride
description: SOUTH CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 27 (UPI)A fifth former employee of the Union Carbide chemical plant here has died of a rare form of liver cancer believed to be linked to longterm exposure to vinyl chloride, a company spokesman said today.

title: Lockwood Tagged With 42 Loss
description: Joe Torre ended his first month as manager of the Mets last night with a rude reminder of the headaches that go with the job: The Philadelphia Phillies scored two runs in the seventh inning to tie the Mets, then two more in the ninth to defeat them, 42.

title: Advertising
description: The most ambitious and extensive advertising program ever undertaken to make New York State a tourist mecca broke last night on TV in 20 markets in and around the state.

title: Carey Won't Sidestep Bill on Curbing Dogs
description: ALBANY, June 27Governor Carey said today he planned to sign a bill that would subject dog owners in New York City and Buffalo to $100 fines if they failed to clean up after their dogs.

title: Cauthen Wins 524th in Finale As Apprentice
description: On the last day the beleaguered bettor could enjoy the advantage of Steve Cauthen's apprentice weight allowance, the old pro, Angel Cordero Jr., guided home Bailjumper to victory yesterday in the $54,850 Saranac at Belmont Park.

title: For Ambitious Women, a Survival Guide to the Land of Bosses
description: Margaret Hennig and Anne Jardim have written a compelling, eyeopening guide for women going to a foreign countrythe Land of the Bosses.

title: Prosecutor Says Michigan Nurses Did Not Aim to Kill
description: DETROIT, June 27Murder was not the object of two nurses accused of poisoning patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., the prosecution declared today in a sevenhour summation of its case in Federal District Court.

title: Court Will Rule on Girl's Suit Against Standing for Pledge
description: NEWARK, June 27Some time before school reopens in the fall, a Federal judge here is expected to rule on the constitutionality of a state law that requires all pupils at least to stand at attention while the pledge of allegiance to the American flag is being recited in their classrooms.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JUNE 27,1977

title: JOHN BERLY
description: HOUSTON, June 27 (AP)John Berly, former pitcher for three National League baseball teams, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 74 years old. Berly, a native of Natchitoches, La., signed originally with the St. Louis Cardinals and was traded in 1931 to the New York Giants. He later pitched for the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: 3 Companies Name Women as Directors
description: The corporate scramble for prominent women to serve on boards of directors continues

title: Italy Closing Its Universities to Foreign Students
description: ROME, June 27The Italian Government has decided to bar foreign students from Italian universities for the next two years.

title: Newton Plans to Resume Control of Black Panthers
description: BRAMPTON, Ontario, June 27Huey P. Newton, preparing to face murder charges in California after three years as a fugitive in Cuba, declared today that he planned to resume the leadership of the Black Panther Party and to expand the movement's social programs throughout the United State.s

title: Companies List Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For Periods ended May 31 uniess otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchanee. (A) American Stock Eadvange and (0) over the counter.

title: Wine Talk
description: THIRTYONE states now permit wine to be sold in grocery stores, the way it is in France and Jtaly. A bill that would add New York State to that list has been pigeonholed in Albany.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: DPChicago 2 LOR Chicago ?? Motreal 4. 2BCromartie. HRJeMorites (6), Garrett (2) 51 ?? Swisner SFClines, Gross.

title: White Opposition in South Africa To Regroup and Try to Broaden
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 28  South Africa's official white opposition group disbanded today in preparation for forming a somewhat wider organization tomorrow in the hope of better challenging the governing National Party of Prime Minister John Vorster.

title: Smith, on Graffiti, Wins Aachen Jumping Event
description: AACHEN, West Germany, June 28 (AP)Harvey Smith of Britain, riding Graffiti, won the first jumping event at the 41st international Aachen equestrian meeting today as he led the 9yearold gelding faultlessly over the 500meter, 14obstacle course in 28.5 seconds.

title: Technology
description: The sixyearold industry that produces tiny computers on fingernailsized chips of silicon, the socalled microcomputers, has shown strong signs in the last several weeks of moving toward an evolutionary, rather than a revolutionary, approach to introducing changes in design.

title: Head of Auto Union Urges Carter to Aid Labor Law Reform
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The new president of the United Automobile Workers union, Douglas Fraser, called on President Carter today to lead the fight to reform the national labor law this year and warned of political consequences if changes were not made.

title: Oppenheimer Opposed On Bid for Havatampa
description: The Justice Department filed a suit in New York yesterday to block the $40.6 million sale of the Havatampa Corporation to a company formed by Oppenheimer & Co., the Wall Street investment firm.

title: BEAME CITES RECORD OF GETTING JOB DONE
description: Coffee in cardboard containers, canned orange juice and four Deputy Mayors (three current, one past) talking about New York City's aid to business were served by Mayor Beame at Gracie Mansion yesterday to an audience of executives and financial contributors to his reelection campaign.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, June 28 (UPI)City school officials said today that they had been notified by the Department of Health. Education and Welfare that charges of civil rights violations against the district had been dismissed.

title: Alexander E. Eltz, ExOfficial Of Engelhardt Industries, at 66
description: Alexander E. Eltz, who retired as senior vice president of Engelhardt Industries of Newark in 1971 died at his home near Salzburg, Austria, last Saturday at the age of 66.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended May 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter

title: L. I. Man Is Accused Of Kidnapping 2 Boys To Obtain a Confession
description: A 39yearold East Rockaway, L.I., man was arrested yesterday and charged with luring one teenage boy into his home, forcing another into it, assaulting them both and holding them captive at gunpoint for two hours while attempting to make them confess to a burglary.

title: Bridge
description: Tournament enthusiasts who agree to play conventional responses to an opening bid, such as transfers, splinters, or three notrump as a strong raise substitute, often fail to discuss an important detail with their partners: Do these conventions still apply when the opponents intervene?

title: 80 DOCTORS ON LIST IN MEDICAID FRAUD
description: The New York State Department of Social Services has turned over the names of 80 physicians to the Manhattan District Attorney and to the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York for prosecution of suspected Medicaid fraud.

title: New Haven Policeman Says F.B.I. Agents. Knew About Illegal Wiretapping Activities
description: NEW HAVEN, June 28Federal Bureau of Investigation officials knew about illegal wiretaps by the New Haven police, a local officer testified last night.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court,. First Department, will hear an appeal of an order that the Bronx sheriff begin searching for a 3yearold girl whose foster parents defied a court order to surrender her to her natural father.

title: Games People Play At Night
description: IT WAS WELL past 11 P.M. Even Sheridan Square was hushed. But in the musclebuilding club across Seventh Avenue, a few hardy weight lifters were banging the weights around. Bang, bang, clang, clang,' said a cheerful slab of a man named Brian Destazio. If you come here late, when there's only a few people around, you can make that much more noise. Sometimes it sounds like thunder.

title: Country Music: Queens Hears Kitty Wells
description: KITTY WELLS is billed as the Queen of Country Music, so her appearance Monday night in a supermarket parking lot in the heart of Queens can be taken either as a denial of that title or a classic case of noblesse oblige.

title: Mobile Sheriff and 8 Are Indicted In a Plot to Kill Fleeing Prisoner
description: MOBILE, Ala., June 28The sheriff of Mobile County and eight of his assistants were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges that they had plotted to allow a prisoner to escape from jail and then had shot him to death from ambush.

title: House Votes to Build B1 Bomber As Carter Decision on Plane Nears
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The House of Representatives, in a move that buoyed proponents of the B1 strategic bomber, voted today to support production of the expensive and controversial weapons system.

title: Collapses at Reception
description: ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP)Mr. Hill collapsed at a reception several hours after addressing the convention. He was sent to a hospital where a spokesman said he was suffering from a rapid heart beat. He was kept about an hour for observation.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: A NIGHT AT THE OPERA Giuseppe Verdi who was born in Busseto, Italy, in 1813, became a composer and organist as a youth. Later, when he applied for admission to the Milan Conservatory, he was rejected as too old and not talented enough. Undaunted, evidently, he went on to produce some of the most popular operas: Aida, Rigoletto, II Trovatore, La Traviata and Don Carlo.

title: Nassau Prosecutor Announces a Curb On Plea Bargains
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 28Denis E. Dillon, the District Attorney of Nassau County, announced today that, starting next week, plea bargaining would not be permitted once a defendant had been indicted by a grand jury.

title: SIDNEY RITTER
description: Sidney Ritter, a retired partner of Leo Ritter & Company, a realestate investment concern at 1776 Broadway, died Monday in Roosevelt Hospital following a heart attack. He lived at 145 Central Park West and was 71 years old.

title: Navy Confirms Johnson Had Surgery for Skin Cancer
description: A Navy official confirmed yesterday that Lyndon B. Johnson had secret surgery for skin cancer while President.

title: Council Stays Queensboro Project
description: A City Council committee yesterday approved the first step in the development of $2 million market under the Queensboro Bridge, but withdrew its approval a halfhour later because it decided it did not know enough about the developer or what the city stood to gain.

title: McEnroe in Semifinals on 5Set Victory
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 28The Dead End kids are running the show at Wimbledonunpredictable, spontaneous, whippy, brazen.

title: Advertising
description: I have a lot of I.O.U.'s out, said Derrick Michael O'Dea, the 42yearold Briton who recently became president of the New York office of D'ArcyMacMan us & Masius.

title: JACOB I. MIGDEN
description: Dr. Jacob I. Migden, who conducted a private medical practice in New York City since 1937, died Monday in Beth Israel Hospital, where he was a member of the staff. He lived at 7020 170th St., Flushing, and had offices at 216 East 12th Street, Manhattan. His age was 66.

title: Ailey, Citing Costs, Drops Lincoln Center Season
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has canceled its twoweek season at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center (Aug. 1628) because of escalating performing costs. Mr. Ailey said: It is sad and frustrating that our company must now join the Joffrey Ballet, Dance Theater of Harlem and American Ballet Theater in having to reduce public appearances for economic reasons. Now on a world tour, the company finished a noteworthy threeweek engagement at the City Center on West 55th Street on May 22.

title: Carter Nominates Gerard C. Smith As Delegate to Vienna Atomic Un
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)President Carter announced today that he was nominating Gerard C. Smith to be special representative in efforts to curb the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: People in Sports
description: Roger Neilson accepted a oneyear contract yesterday as coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs, succeeding Red Kelly, whose contract was not renewed when it expired last week. Kelly, 50 years old, is undergoing extensive treatment for a spinal injury he suffered when he accidentally collided with a Toronto forward, Larry McDonald, during practice in March. He would have been rehired if in good health, according to Toronto's owner, Harold Ballard, who said Kelly had been offered another position in the organizetion.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSGordon V., of Sherman, Conn., on June 25. Survived by his who, Elaine, three sons, six grandchildren. Services will be held at Sherman Congregational Church in Sherman, Conn., at 1 P.M. on Wednesday, June 29. In lieu of flowers, donations may he sent to New Milford Hospital Develop ment Fund, New Milford, Conn.

title: U.S. Creating Maximum Security, Prison for Women
description: ALDERSON, W. Va., June 27The coils of razoredged wire have just been fixed along the top of the eightfoot chainlink fence outside, and the steelbar doors are installed inside the twostory brick building here at the nation's only Federal prison exclusively for women.

title: Pop: JazzRock by Dixie Dregs
description: The name Dixie Dregs might seem catchy enough, but the jazzrock quintet, which finished a threenight showcase engagement at Trax, 100 West 72d Street, last night, is really not very felicitously titled. The name suggests both a scuzzier than usual assortment of beerdrinking Southern boogierockers, and the leftovers from other such bands.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: THE TRUTH is that Fred Astaire now does character parts, Gene Kelly does commercials, and there are no dancers left. Here and there, however, are signs, and they suggest that dancing, or at least dancing that is characterized by men and women holding one another in their arms, is coming back.

title: U.S. Acts to Curb Leaks On Economic Reports
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today that it would issue several major monthly economic reports at an earlier hour in order to prevent leaks that allegedly were being used to advantage by some Wall Street investors.

title: BEAME ASSERTS SST WILL FAIL NOISE TEST
description: Mayor Beame, in his strongest attack on the Concorde supersonic transport. said yesterday that the probable inability of the plane to comply fully with noise rules at Kennedy International Airport was reason enough to reject the application for landing rights there.

title: Jazz: From the Hendersons' 20's Bands
description: THE HE BASIC ELEMENTS for a retrospective view of the music of Fletcher Henderson. the pioneering bigband leader of the 20's, and his brother Horace were at hand in New York University's Loeb Student Center on Monday evening.

title: About Education
description: College and school administrators across the country greeted with relief a court decision in Bridgeport, Conn., that denied a tuition refund to a student who contended she did not learn what was promised in a catalogue course description.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, June 29, 1977

title: B1: The Unneeded Weapon
description: President Carter has been pictured as wading through a 1inch stack of reports on the strategic implications of the B1 bomber plus a thick book of engineering evaluations. The indications are that he intends to approve continued production of the plane on a reduced basis. If so, then it may be that Mr. Carter understood more about the plane when he knew less.

title: China Rebuffs U.S. Bid to Widen Scholarly and Scientific Visits
description: HONG KONG, June 28Peking has rebuffed an effort by American academic organizations to expand the scope of scholarly and scientific exchanges with China, saying that such action must await full normalization of relations between the United States and China, the president of the American Council of Learned Societies disclosed today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: MARY HOTCHKISS
description: Mary Hotchkiss, who retired in 1953 as head of the sociology and psychology department at Finch Junior College here, died Monday in her home in Lyons, N. Y., after a long illness. Her age was 90.

title: Senate Votes to Block Carter From Forcing Schools to Bus Their Pupils
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Senate tonight passed legislation intended to block the Carter Administration from forcing school districts to bus pupils to achieve school desegregation.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Orders for American aircraft totaling nearly $290 million were announced by the Kuwait Airways Corporation and the Scandinavian Airlines System.

title: About Real Estate
description: The rehabilitation and revival of the once troubled Carlton Gardens housing complex is in full swing in central Queens, propelled by an unusual financing mechanism. It is an $11.5 million exercise in urban uplift that is curing what has become a menacing blight in the center of a stable residential neighborhood off Kissena Boulevard at 73d Avenue, a mile from Queens College.

title: HOSPITAL WORKERS WIN PAY INCREASE
description: An arbitrator in the dispute between 38 private, nonprofit hospitals in New York City and more than 37,000 employees yesterday awarded wage and benefit increases that will amount to $40 million over the next 12 months.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: have also been increased, making more than 100 men involved in the case.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Somewhile ago in Italy, I dined on a very simple but beautiful soup made with a tiny pasta called quadretti. It was served in a nice chicken broth along with small pieces of chicken livers and tasted of sage and cheese. Do you know of such a pasta or such a recipe?

title: SOVIET QUESTIONS MOTIVES OF U.S. IN PRODDING ISRAEL
description: MOSCOW, June 28 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today questioned the United States' sincerity in its call for Israeli withdrawals from occupied Arab lands as part of a Middle East peace settlement. Washington's words and deeds, the Soviet Government was quoted by the official Tass Dress agency as having said.

title: Dance: Nureyev's Romeo and Juliet
description: LONDON, June 26Rudolf Nureyev's completely new staging of Prokofiev's ballet Romeo and Juliet is very different from its predecessors and is absolutely fascinating. It is fresh and original, andconsidering that this new work for the London Festival Ballet is the first time he has created a completely original ballet on such a scale, the certainty of the achievement is all the more remarkable.

title: Scientists Seeking to Spur Plants By Curbing Carbon Dioxide Loss
description: Agricultural scientists who study the way plants use sunlight to convert carbon dioxide and water into food believe that plants may be able to do this faster if they are stripped of a natural biochemical mechanism in their cells that wastes half or more of the carbon dioxide they take in.

title: O'Connor Leads by Nine In British Senior Golf
description: CAMBRIDGE, England, June 28 (AP) Christy O'Connor equaled his dayold course record with a fourunderpar 68 today in the third round of the Bristish Senior golfers' championship over the Cambridgeshire Hotel course. He took a ninestroke lead over his nearest challenger, Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina.

title: House Panel, in a Reversal, Bars Tax on Horne Users of Heating Oil
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Under intense pressure, the House Ways and Means Committee today reversed a decision of two weeks ago and agreed to exempt residential users of heating oil from the proposed new tax on domestically produced oil.

title: Energy Office's Powers
description: TRENTON, June 28New Jersey's proposed new energy department, which received final legislative approval last night and is expected to receive Governor Byrne's endorsement, will have the power to say how and where energy may be used in New Jersey.

title: Letters
description: Dance On, Dance On

title: Officials Raise Questions on Hughes's Alleged Drug Use
description: LOS ANGELES, June 28Attorney General John Hill of Texas has requested a California court to compel a personal aide to the late Howard R. Hughes to answer questions regarding Mr. Hughes's use of drugs and how they were obtained.

title: New Issues Are Found Unaffected by Options
description: A study commissioned by the Chicago Board Options Exchange, conducted by two academic economists and released yesterday showed that exchangetraded options had no negative effect on the market for lowpriced new stock issues.

title: Quarrie's 20.1 Best of Season At 200 Meters in Oslo Track
description: OSLO, June 28 (AP)Don Quarrie of Jamaica won the 200meter dash at an international track and field meet tonight. His time of 20.1 seconds was the best recorded in the distance this season.

title: HOUSE VOTES 243178 TO BUILD B4 PLANE; CARTER ACTION NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The House of Representatives, in a move that buoyed proponents of the B1 strategic bomber, voted today to support production of the expensive and controversial weapons system.

title: Reuschel Posts 11th Victory as Cubs Win
description: Two years ago, Ricky Eugene Reuschel won 11 games and lost 17 for the Chicago Cubs. Last night at Montreal, he reached that 11victory mark only 69 games into the season. Reuschel, 1412 last year, is one of the major reasons why the Cubs remain comfortably ahead of the other teams in the National League East.

title: Books of The Times
description: INSOFAR as there is a prescriptive point to Martin Green's Transatlantic Patterns: Cultural Comparisons of England With America, it is approximately this: Neither England nor the United States has erected a civilization that holds the key to the future of the Englishspeaking cultural and intellectual community. But if we compare their many opposing tendencies, it is possible to imagine a synthesis that may point the way to a more vital future.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ARECENT COLUMN devoted in part to encounters with strangers prompted Alan B. Rosenfeld to recall the day whenhis arms laden with film editing supplieshe came upon two winos who were sitting on a stoop in the West 50's not far from where Mr. Rosenfeld works.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Mrs. Philip K. Wrigley; Was 75
description: CHICAGO, June 28Helen Blanche Atwater Wrigley, widow of Philip K. Wrigley, died last night in Lakeland Hospital, Elkhorn, Wis. She was 75 years old.

title: Carter Planning to Invite Byrne to the White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  President Carter expects to invite Governor Byrne of New Jersey to the White House to bestow the same kind of political blessing he conferred today on the Democratic candidate for Governor of Virginia, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Norton Simon Shareholders' Suit On Chairman's Pay to Be Settled
description: Norton Simon Inc., a diversified corporation with major interests in food and food service, has agreed to settle a shareholder lawsuit that challenged the compensation and fringe benefits paid to its chairman, David J. Mahoney.

title: CAREY NAMES THREE TO FINANCIAL BOARD
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday the appointment of three new members of the Emergency Financial Control Board John C. Sawhill, president of New York University; Francis J. Barry, president of Circle Lines, and Stanley S. Shuman, executive vice president of Allen & Company, an investment banking firm.

title: Tips to Put You In the Shade
description: Before you buy sunglasses, turn them over. Hold them about a foot away so that an overhead fluorescent light is reflected on the inside of the lenses. Move the glasses slowly so that the reflection travels across the lens. If the reflection is wavy or distorted in any way, the lenses are flawed.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Tuesday, June 28, 1977

title: HOME BANK BOARD ENDING RETIREMENT PLAN LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today the $1,000 minimum deposit requirement for retirement savings plans would be lifted July 6.

title: Belmont Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Task Force Seeks Power to Study Theft of Drugs at Makers' Level
description: WEST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, June 28 A fight against doctors, pharmacists and other medical professionals who divert legal drugs into an illicit market has proved so successful, officials said today, that state law enforcement officials are now seeking authority to investigate manufacturers whose employees may be stealing drugs for sale to addicts.

title: Mozambique Asks U.N. for Arms For Defense Against Rhodesians
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 28Mozambique appealed in the Security Council today for military equipment to defend itself from what it said were increasingly heavy attacks by forces of Rhodesia's white minority govenment.

title: High Court Upholds U.S. Control Over Papers and Tapes of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Supreme Court upheld as constitutional today the 1974 law that gave the Government control over Richard M. Nixon's Presidential papers and tape recordings.

title: Japan Reports '76 Trade Surplus Increased $6.3 Billion Over '75
description: TOKYO, June 28 (AP)Japan's trade surplus with industrialized nations rose sharply to the equivalent of $8.7 billion in fiscal 1976 from $2.4 billion in fiscal 1975, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: Child's World
description: THE CHILD stares through a miniature jungle underbrush. Suddenly there's movement: the flash of a tail, a glimpse of snout, a beady eye. It's the kind of excitement that comes with watching the small creatures in a vivariuma terrarium that contains live animals.

title: BRITISH FLEET PAYS TRIBUTE TO QUEEN
description: ABOARD THE HELICOPTER SUPPORT SHIP ENGADINE, at Spithead, off Southern England, June 28The British fleetmuch reduced in scope but still the heir to the rich tradition of Drake and Nelson paid its Silver Jubilee tribute to Queen Elizabeth II this afternoon.

title: Sports Festival Proposed by Kane
description: A national amateur sports festival bringing together all of America's top athletes is under consideration for the summer of 1978.

title: Books: Brothers in Blood
description: IN My Enemy, My Brother, Joseph E. Persico attempts to recreate a soldier's eyeview of the most momentous battle ever fought on American soilthe battle of Gettysburg. Later battles of the Civil War were more costly in casualties, but the 43,000 dead, wounded and missing suffered by both sides in those three blazing hot July days of 1863 were a highwater mark in carnage thus far. Americans proved to the world they were capable of slaughtering one another with superior technology and glorious stubbornness.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1977

title: Japan Makes Sato Envoy to Peking
description: TOKYO, June 28 (Reuters)The Japanese Cabinet today approved the appointment of Shoji Sato, a Deputy Foreign Minister, as ambassador to Peking. Mr. Sato, 63 years old, succeeds Heishiro Ogawa, who has served there since relations were normalized in 1972.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: I think one of the finest acts of the world nations that has ever occurred was to establish the State of Israel. So the first prerequisite of a lasting peace is the recognition of Israel by her neighbors; Israel's right to exist; Israel's right to exist permanently; Israel's right to exist in peace. That means that over a period of months or years that the borders between Israel and Syria, Israel and Lebanon, Israel and Jordan, Israel and Egypt must be opened up to travel, to tourism, to cultural exchange, to trade, so that no matter who the leaders might be in those countries the people them selves will have formed a mutual understanding and comprehension in a sense of a common purpose to avoid the repetitious wars and death that have afflicted that region so long. That is the first prerequisite of peace.

title: When the Menu Misleads You
description: DO ALL of the Maine lobsters offered on restaurant menus really come from Maine, or are some of the less desirable the products of Rhode Island or Montauk waters? How often is chopped chicken liver made of beef liver and Roquefort dressing made of blue cheese?

title: Mets' Box Scores
description: EHeaner, DPPhiladeIphia 1, Mets 1. LOBPhiladelphia 10. Mets 5. 2BStearns, Boone. HPLuz?? (16), McBrioe (6). SBMcBrice 2, Kepner. SBowa.

title: Chess
description: Nona Gaprindashvili of the Soviet Union, the world women's champion, achieved the greatest triumph ever by a woman in tying for first place in the Louis D. Statham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., with Grandmaster Yuri Balashov, also of the Soviet Union. Grandmaster Oscar Panno of Argentina and International Master Sahovic of Yugoslavia.

title: HOUSE DENIES ITSELF COSTOFLIVING RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to deny a costofliving pay increase to members of Congress, Federal judges and other top Government officials. The action was regarded as a prehide to tomorrow's vote on a controversial proposal to roll back the $12,900 raise that members of Congress received earlier this year.

title: Ballet: Sign Of Better Times
description: ACOMPANY that presents The Sleeping Beauty without a single firstrate Princess Aurora is a bold one. The Stuttgart Ballet has taken that risk this season at the Metropolitan Opera and, oddly, its gamble has partly been won.

title: Petrolunds Signs Agreement to Halt Its Alleged Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)Operators of a $76 million oil drilling tax shelter, whose investors included professional athletes Larry Csonka and Brooks Robinson, have agreed to stop allegedly fraudulent activities, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: U.S. Defers Two Loans to Chile, Citing HumanRights Situation
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The State Department said today that two loans to aid Chile's poor farmers had been blocked at least temporarily because of the humanrights situation in that countrythe first time economic assistance for humanitarian purposes is known to have been held up for such reasons.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Tuesday, June 28, 1977

title: Technology
description: The microcomputer industry has shown strong signs recently of moving toward an evolutionary, rather than a revolutionary, approach to the introduction of design changes. Page D5.

title: Pollution Leads to Closing of 5 Fire Island Beaches
description: OCEAN BEACH, L.I., June 28The Suffolk County Health Department closed five bayside beaches on Fire Island today. but the greatest concern among residents here seemed to be about reputation rather than pollution.

title: Market Place
description: While most New York City moneymarket banks have been getting unfavorable publicity, bank stock analysts have been recommending the socalled regional banks.

title: How the Assembly Voted on Marijuana
description: ALBANY, June 28Following is the rollcall by which the Assembly voted to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana:

title: Reports of Soviet Buying Lift Grains and Soybeans
description: Trade reports that the Soviet Union was buying American corn and perhaps some wheat strengthened grain and soybran futures prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Burton H. White, 77, Partner In Burlingham Admiralty Law Firm
description: Burton H. White, formerly senior partner in the New York City admiralty law firm of Burlingham, Underwood, Wright, White & Lord, died at his home in Charleston, S. C., Monday. He was 77 years old.

title: Rival Palestinians Battle Again in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 28At least 15 persons were killed in fierce fighting here between rival Palestinian guerrilla groups last night and early today, according to Lebanese police sources.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Official Asserts Labor Is an Enemy of Minority Workers
description: ST. LOUIS, June 28Reflecting deep anjer and frustration within the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and among civil rights leaders over a recent ruling by the Supreme Court on seniority rights for employees, Herbert Hill today attacked organized labor, one of the association's major allies, as an enemy of minority and women workers.

title: Give Vision a Chance in the Middle East
description: The trouble now brewing between Israel and the United States can be attributed to a single, regrettable fact: President Carter refused to quit while he was ahead in the Middle East maneuvering.

title: ISRAELIS ARE IRKED BY U.S. STATEMENT
description: JERUSALEM, June 28The Government of Prime Minister Nlenzthem Begin said today that there was no basis for a State Department assumption that Israel was unwilling to discuss the occupied territories of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank in any peace negotiations with the Arabs.

title: Scientist Who Predicted PenicillinResistant Gonorrhea Is Tracking Its Cause
description: SEATTLEHe gave the report at a medical meeting in London, predicting that the germ of gonorrhea might abruptly develop total resistance to penicillin, the drug that had been effective against it for decades.

title: Noah: Six Years Later
description: MANY people wonder what to name their baby. I still don't know what to call my 11yearold son. It is six years since I wrote A Child Called Noah. My son was then 5 years old and had finally seemed to achieve that great pinnacle, toilet training. He was capable of a few words of rewardinduced imitative speech but generally pretty much behaved like a Iyearold with poor sleeping habits. His idea of play was flexing and unflexing his hands before his eyes, picking at infinitesimal shreds of lint on the floor, and bouncing up and down on sofas and couches and beds or endlessly rocking. He seldom interacted with anybody or anything.

title: Neil Simon Is Sure You Must Remember This....
description: HOLLYWOOD THE YEAR IS 1940. The time is midnight. (It is always midnight in detective stories, says playwright Neil Simon.) Mary Astor, Lauren Bacall, Ingrid Bergman, Gladys George, Lee Patrick and Claire Trevor shiver at the end of the fogshrouded San Francisco pier (It is always foggy in detective stories, says Neil Simon) and coil themselves around Humphrey Bogart for warmth.

title: IRVINE PICKS KREMER AS ITS NEW PRESIDENT
description: LOS ANGELES, June 28The president and two top officers of the landrich Irvine Company announced their resignations today effective with the July 25 sale of the company to TaubmanAllen Irvine Inc., a group of investors that includes Henry Ford 2d.

title: Japan Color TV Exports Off in May
description: TOKYO, June 28 (UPI)  Japan's exports of color television sets in May totaled 411,976 units, down about 10,000 units from April, but up 4 percent from the yearearlier level, the Japan Electronics Industry Association reported. Shipments to the United States in May amounted to 239,234 units, down about 16,000 units from April, the association said.

title: Phils Extend Mets' Losing Streak to Six, Winning on Two Homers, 31
description: The Mets found a few new ways to make their fans unhappy last night at Shea Stadium, losing to the Philadelphia Phillies, 31, and losing many of their customers through a 1hour 52minute rain delay.

title: TAX FRAUD INQUIRY ON GENERAL MOTORS IS ORDERED TO GO ON
description: DETROIT, June 28United States District Judge James P. Churchill today allowed the Justice Department to proceed with a grand jury investigation of criminal tax fraud allegations against the General Motors Corporation.

title: Market Stages a Sharp Retreat; Dow Closes at 915.62, Down 8.48
description: Weakness in steel stocks spread yesterday to other heavy industry groups and sent the market into a sharp afternoon retreat.

title: JELLO: The Story of a Just Dessert
description: To a 30's child JellO was not a dessert but a way of life. Every Sunday I sang JELLO and said JellO again with Don Wilson and Jack Benny. I snitched JellO packages from the cupboard to sniff them like glue, to eat the powder raw, to dream of a dress in each of six delicious colors. JellO was my first cooking triumph and I scorned glittering molds that concealed cabbage, cucumbers, cottage cheese and mayonnaise when they were supposed to have marshmallows and maraschino cherries.

title: Chinaglia, Told He'll Play, Hits the Road With Cosmos
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the emotional Italian who was benched by the Cosmos Sunday and threatened not to travel to the West Coast for two games this week, departed with the team early yesterday, but only after some assurances from Coach Gordon Bradley.

title: High Court Upholds U.S. Control Over Papers and Tapes of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Supreme Court upheld as constitutional today the 1974 law that gave the Government control over Richard M. Nixon's Presidential papers and tape recordings.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: AGOOD, easilymade reduction of tomatoesan essence of tomatoes, to use another phrasecan be one of the greatest boons whose goal is rapid cooking. The reduction can be added to soups, sauces and turned into a fine spaghetti sauce simply by heating it in oil with garlic, oregano and chopped parsley. The essence will also keep well if tightly stored in the refrigerator, particularly if a light layer of oil is spooned over the top to help preserve it. It can also be frozen.

title: Index of HelpWanted Advertising Gained in May for 51 Newspapers
description: The Help Wanted Advertising Index, the Conference Board's barometer of employment trends, rose in May.

title: U.S. STUDY FINDS ASIANS LEAD CALCULATOR SALES
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)Japan and other Far Eastern countries are crowding out American companies in fierce competition for selling calculators in the United States, a Government study said today.

title: P.U.C. ACTS TO FIND WINTER GAS SUPPLY
description: NEWARK, June 28Joel R. Jacobson, president of the State Board of Public Utilty Commissioners, said today that he hoped a trip to Texas would answer the board's questions on whether New Jersey was in for another shortage of natural gas next winter.

title: Tough DeathPenalty Bill Passed By Big Margin in Albany Assembly
description: 1ALBANY, June 28The Assembly passed overwhelmingly late tonight the tough new deathpenalty bill it created last week with an unusual amendment on the floor.

title: Dollar Is Irregular; Gold Stabilizes
description: The dollar closed mixed against major world currencies in foreign exchange trading both at home and abroad yesterday, the Associated Press reported. The price of gold stabilized in major European bullion markets.

title: I.C.C. Slashes Alaska Oil Pipeline Rates
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Interstate Commerce Commission made deep cuts today, at least for the time being, in the rates proposed by oil companies for moving crude oil through the transAlaska pipeline.

title: South African Trial of 12 Points Up Growing Concern With Terrorism
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 28A theater in the old market here has been echoing with laughter on recent nights as John Kani, a black actor, parodies South African Government statements belittling attempts by black militants to use terror attacks on whites as part of the struggle against apartheid.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 28State Legislative leaders today named members of a commission to consider revisions in New Jersey's no fault automobile insurance plan.

title: Cominco Prepared to Bid $18 for Bethlehem Copper
description: Cominco Ltd., the Canadian mining company, said yesterday in Vancouver, British Columbia, that it was prepared to pay $18 a share in Canadian currency, or a total of $102 million for the Bethlehem Copper Corporation shares it does not already own.

title: North Sea Oil Output at Record
description: LONDON, uJne 28 (AP)British North Sea oil production rose to a record 836,417 barrels a day last month, the Department of Energy said today. May's output was up 16.5 percent from April, when average production was 718,000 barrels a day.

title: South Africa Seizes 3 in Hunt for Guerrillas
description: JOHANNESBURG, June 28 (AP)The South African security police today announced the capture of three more black urban guerrillas, described as having been trained in Angola.

title: Horned Toads and Ruby Cabernet
description: DEL RIO, TEXAS Surrounded by horned toads, cactus, jackrabbits, tarantulas, rattlesnakes, coyotes, drug smugglers, and multitudes of incorrigible drinkers of tequila, whisky and beer, there exists on the edge of this sleepy border town a tiny winery.

title: U. S. Safety Agency Ends Secret Order Aiding Some Mills
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)Government officials acknowledged today that cottonseed oil mills and mattress factories had been exempt from Federal health and safety standards for at least two years, apparently under political pressure from Capitol Hill.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$9.600, pace, mile.

title: Black Art Label Disputed by Curator
description: As guest curator, David C. Driskell put together the Brooklyn Museum's exhibition, Two Centuries of Black American Art, the first major historical survey of the black aspect of American art, but he does not believe there actually is such a thing as black art.

title: TREASURY BOND SALE ON NEW NOTES HEAVY
description: The treasury sold $1.5 billion of 15year bonds yesterday at an average interest rate of 7.29 percent as the demand for the securitiesa new maturity for Government bondsexceeded Wall Street's original expectations.

title: A WhoopDeDo At the Bronx Zoo
description: Carrie Grant couldn't make up her mind whether an elephant ear flopping against her bare foot was pleasant or not. But she did know one thing. She wouldn't want to ride an elephant all day.

title: Son of Sam Investigators Trying To Trace All .44Bulldog Pistols
description: The New York Police Department, frustrated in hunting the killer who calls himself Son of Sam, yesterday began an extraordinary canvass of 2,000 governmental agencies, businesses, clubs and groups in the United States and Canada.

title: Britain's Changing Mood
description: LONDON, June 28You can't come to Britain these days without wondering why it looks so good and sounds so terrible. In the generation since the last war, the condition of the people has improved beyond most predictions, but still it grumbles as much about the Socialists today as it used to about the Tories.

title: Yankees Win in 11th, 51, After 85 Loss
description: TORONTO, June 28Reggie Jackson, who once again aroused Manager Billy Mann's ire, played a significant role tonight in one of the Yankees' worst defensive performances of the season. But the Toronto Blue Jays did their best to match that performance in the second game and the teams wound up with a split of their doubleheader.

title: CORRECTION
description: The name of Joseph Duffey, Assistant Secretary of State for educational and cultural affairs, was omitted from a list of persons being considered for the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Humanities because of a typographical error in The Times yesterday. In addition, the affiliation of Dr. John D. Maguire, president of the State University College at Old Westbury, L.I., did not appear correctly.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Court Clears Way for Cannonball TV Suit
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Supreme Court ruled today that the First Amendment does not protect a television station from being sued for damages by a human cannonball if it broadcasts his entire performance as a news item without his consent.

title: How Senate Voted
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, June 29Following is the roll call by which the State Senate this morning voted to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana:

title: Best Buys
description: WITH one eye on the calendar and another on the pursestrings, the City Department of Consumer Affairs is counseling comparison shopping for people planning Fourth of July picnics.

title: Palafox's Tips Help Protege Stun Wimbledon
description: The man who prepared Johnny McEnroe for Wimbledon was laughing almost hysterically. We had two weeks to work and I could see his confidence growing, but I never expected him to go that far, said Tony Palafox at the news that his sensational 18yearold protg had reached the semifinals.

title: End of OPEC Price Split Seen
description: VIENNA, June 28 (Reuters)Indonesia's Mining Minister, Mohammed Sadli, said today that the end of a price split among oil exporting countries would be announced tomorrow, but a spokesman at the headquarters of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries here said he could not confirm the Indonesian statement.

title: It Seemed Real
description: They arrived at the crabbing place on the tip of the Oscawana Bend, and took the saddles off the horses, Even though he was only seven, Marshall went alone and led them out into the sandy flats, where they drank from clear pools. A long freight full of cattle and hogs was moving down the tracks which ran parallel with the riyer, The smell of their stale and echoes of their frightened moans lingered until the jolting cars disappeared and the wind blew all memory of them back into the soft swamps. By the time Marshall returned and tied up the horses Livingston had baited the traps with gristle and meat scraps. They climbed the rocks and went to a deep place where, with all his strength, Livingston threw the cages out into the water. They took the lines and wrapped them around a stump, after which they sat down in the sun and ate lunch. It was very hot and humid, with the wind coming off the river.

title: 2 Rye Yachtsmen Win 25Mile Race
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 28 (AP)Al Brainard and Carl Ament of Rye, N.Y., skippered their OneTon offshore racer Jonathan Livingston Seagull to victory today in the first 25mile inshore race for the Sail Cup.

title: GEN. L C. JAYNES, 85, LED A TRIAL OF NAZIS
description: Maj. Gen. Lawrence C. Jaynes, who retired from the Army in 1953 after 35 years of service in three wars, died June 20 at the National Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., at the age of 85. He lived in Sumner, Md.

title: AFRICA LEADERS FACE DECISION ON RHODESIA
description: LIBREVILLE, Gabon, June 28Foreign ministers of more than 40 African countries have decided here to leave to their heads of state the difficult issue of which Rhodesian nationalist faction should be tecognized and supported by the Organization of African Unity.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The release from prison of two reputed mobsters, Ralph A. Napoli and Joseph Zicarelli, was blocked yesterday.

title: An Alliance That Never Was
description: CASTEAU, BelgiumSEATO, unlike NATO, was an alliance that in fact never worked as an alliance, and now formally disappears tomorrow, June 30. Its Bangkok headquarters terminates all functions, its secretarygeneral leaves his office, and the whole rickety shebang vanishes into history.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Factory Jobs Rise In New York City After 16Year Loss
description: After 16 consecutive years of losses that cost New York City 400,000 factory jobs, employment in manufacturing rose by 7,000 jobs last year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Payments Overseas Disclosed by Grolier
description: WILMINGTON, Del., June 28 (AP)Grolier Inc., one of the nation's largest reference book publishers, made some $1.2 million in questionable payments overseas in the last seven years, company officials said today.

title: CHICAGO NAZIS EXPECTED TO CANCEL JULY 4 MARCH
description: CHICAGO, June 28The Illinois Appellate Court today apparently ended the threat of a Nazi march on the Fourth of July in the predominantly Jewish suburb of Skokie.

title: Cauthen Takes First Day Of RegularJockey Status In Stride, Wins 3 Races
description: Embellishing his legend, the 17yearold jockey called Stevie Wonder by his fans won his first three races yesterday on his first day without the apprentice's weight allowance.

title: Newport Jazz: Art Pepper
description: THE MONDAY EVENING concert billed by the NewportNew York Jazz Festival as an insight into the New York Jazz Scene was not primarily or even particularly that. Art Pepper, a Californian, was making his first New York concert appearance, and although Double Image and the Revolutionary Ensemble, the two other groups on the program, could perhaps be said to represent two disparate New York trends, the former was more typical of European and West Coast chamber jazz than of contemporary sounds in Manhattan.

title: Nude Child Pictures in Any Book Face Ban in Bill on Carey's Desk
description: ALBANY, June 28Governor Carey, who today signed into law a ban on topless dancing in bars, now faces a much more difficult decision on an equally popular antipornography billone that outlaws the use of children in sexual performances and which also would make illegal books that used pictures of nude children for sex education or other legitimate purposes.

title: Sheriff in Mobile and 8 Aides Indicted in Plot to Kill Fleeing Prisoner
description: MOBILE, Ala., June 28The sheriff of Mobile County and eight of his assistants were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges that they had plotted to allow a prisoner to escape from jail and then had shot him to death from ambush.

title: COMPROMISE VERSION OF MARIJUANA BILL APPROVED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, June 29The State Senate narrowly gave final approval early today to a bill that would remove criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana for personal use.

title: Carey Rebuffed on Peyser Position By G.O.P.Ruled Senate Committee
description: ALBANY, June 28Republicans in the Legislature delivered a pointed rebuke to Governor Carey today when, in a straight partyline vote, a Senate committee declined to recommend confirmation of Peter A. Peyser as a member and prospective chairman of the Public Service Commission.

title: World News Briefs
description: OTTAWA, June 28Canada and the United States signed an agreement today establishing a joint steering committee for cooperation and mutual policy development in the field of housing and urban affairs.

title: CORRECTION
description: The name of Joseph Duffey, Assistant Secretary of State for educational and cultural affairs, was omitted from a list of persons being considered for the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Humanities because of a typographical error in The Times yesterday. In addition, the affiliation of Dr. John D. Maguire, president of the State University College at Old Westbury, L.I., did not appear correctly.

title: Largest Land Snail In Captivity Is Dead
description: HOVE, England, June 28 (AP)What was reputed to be the largest land snail in captivity died today.

title: A FenceMending Operation By Two New Union Chiefs
description: Two new union chiefs who plan close collaboration in efforts to broaden labor's social horizons are about to undertake a fencemending operation within their own borders. The wouldbe conciliators are Douglas A. Fraser installed this month as president of the 1.5millionmember United Automobile Workers, and William W. Winpisinger, who takes office Friday as president of the millionmember International Association of Machinists. Their first joint venture will be an attempt to close an acrimonious breach that developed between their organizations in 197475 over negotiation of new wage agreements in the aerospace industry, a field in which both unions have strong footholds.

title: Lawyers for Two Nurses Conclude With Attack on Prosecution Tactics
description: DETROIT, June 28After 13 weeks of trial, a Federal court jury will begin tomorrow to deliberate the fate of two Filipino nurses charged with poisoning patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor.

title: Ehrlichman Novel to Open ABC Season
description: ABCTV WILL OPEN its new season this fall in an unorthodox way, with the presentation of a 12hour drama on six consecutive nights, the same form in which Roots was so successfully presented last January.

title: 2D POLICEMAN IN BUFFALO HELD IN YOUTH'S KILLING
description: BUFFALO, June 28 (UPI)A second suspended Buffalo policeman was arrested today on a firstdegree manslaughter charge in the weekend beating death of a young man.

title: Pop: Tipica '73, BigBand Salsa
description: One of the features of this summer's Newport Jazz Festival is a fiveevent series called Salsa en la Calle, or salsa in the street. What it means is that leading salsa groups perform around New York City from the Jazzmobile, a truck that has been converted into a movable platform for music.

title: Careers
description: For the last two months, Karen Dolmatch Shaw, a political scientist, has been using her training to do research and write reports for the Bank of America, the nation's largest bank.

title: Carter Seeking to Meet Brezhnev; Informal Talks in Alaska Possible
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  President Carter would like to meet with Leonid I. Brezhnev, possibly this year, but no time or place has been fined, the White House said today.

title: All About: Sunglasses, Functional and Fashionable
description: CELEBRITIES WEAR sunglasses so they won't be recognized by nonentities who wear them hoping to be taken for celebrities. Fashion overachievers wear them all the time, indoors and out. They own a dozen pairs in different colors, but never with rhinestones. Just plain folk wear them to keep out the glare of the sun.

title: A Ruby Slipper for Shirley Temple
description: LOS ANGELES ON THE 20TH CENTURYFOX lot where she sang and danced her way into the heart of America during the Depression, Shirley Temple Black was given the Life Achievement Award of the American Center of Films for Children Monday night.

title: Notes on People
description: A former astronaut, John L. Swigert Jr., yesterday announced his candidacy for the United States Senate, in a bid to take the seat now held by Senator Floyd K. Haskell,Democrat of Colorado. Mr. Swigert, who is 46 years old, is a Republican now serving as executive director of the Colorado House's Committee on Science and Technology, a job which he said he'll now give up.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Saban Enters Clinic
description: CLEVELAND, June 28 (UPI)Lou Saban, head football coach at the University of Miami, entered Cleveland Clinic for diagnosis of a heart ailment and possible surgery, the clinic said today. The 56yearold Saban formerly coached the Boston Patriots, Denver Broncos and Buffalo Bills.

title: Comptroller's Rejection Of State Aid Plan Draws Attack by Yonkers Aides
description: YONKERS, June 28City and union officials here reacted defiantly and angrily today to the State Comptroller's rejection of the use of promised state aid to balance the city's budget. It was the pledge of that aid, with its possibility of raises for policemen, that ended a sickout by the police two weeks ago.

title: The City Is Running Hard For '84 Olympics
description: The man in charge of selling New York City as the site for the 1984 Summer Olympics thinks that Roosevelt Island might be the place to build the Olympic Village and that without question Shea Stadium should be the main arena for the games.

title: Kissinger Warns Of Economic Crisis
description: WASHINGTON. June 28Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, in his first public address since assuming a professorship at Georgetown University here, warned that the Western democracies are in the midst of a revolution that we have only begun to perceive. The next decade, he said, will determine whether the industrial democracies will be able to manage their economic policies, and maintain social peace in the face of a probably lower longterm growth rate in the 1980's.

title: New Mexico Town Fearful of Loss Of Scarce Water If Mining Starts
description: CERRILLOS, N. M.By rights, this little town should have vanished long ago, gone the way of other ramshackle mining camps thrown up around here in the boom years of the 1880's, only to be left behind as hulks with boarded windows and creaking doors when the richest of the lodes ran out.

title: Personal Health
description: THE mercury is climbing80, 85, 90, even 95and the humidity is not far behind. You're sweaty and sluggish and would like nothing better than to relax in the shade (or better yet an airconditioned room) and sip a cold drink. Maybe even nap. Many people, however, don't have the opportunity or inclination to give in to such feelingsnot, at least, when they interfere with work, weekend tennis or golf, a hike, bike trip or a parade.

title: The Stalking of Random Victims Has Terrified Public Over Years
description: The notion of a psychopath stalking victims at random and eluding detection like the killer who calls himself Son of Samhas long terrified and fascinated the public, although, it seems, more often in fiction than in fact.

title: PILLSBURY'S PROFIT GAINED IN QUARTER
description: The Pillsbury Company, a major manufacturer of convenience food products and a leading flour miller and merchandiser of grains, reported yesterday sales and profit increases for the final quarter and fiscal year ended May 31.

title: The Day Young Steve Grew Up
description: The burning question was: Now that Steve Cauthen was a journeyman jockey whose mounts would have to carry much weight as Angel Cordero's or Ron Turcotte's or Bill Shoemaker's, would the young man still be able to ride as fast as his horse could run? No doubts were expressed out loud at Belmont yesterday, but a chestnut filly named Hutchinson Gal had mental reservations. Back in January when Hutchinson Gal had just turned 3, she broke her maiden under Cauthen's guidance and a fortnight later she won again with the kid on her withers. Then they parted. Cauthen kept on wintying, getting home first with 284 of his mounts between Jan. 1 and June 27. Hutchinson Gal raced four times under other riders and won only once. Now they were back together in yesterday's first post parade. The filly was the first horse Steve climbed aboard after losing his 5pound weight allowance as an apprentice, and she didn't like carrying both the kid and enough lead to make up 117 pounds.

title: For the Fourth, A Salmon Celebration
description: IN GASTRONOMIC LORE, there's an imaginary land called Cockaigne where the houses are built of sugar and cake, the streets are paved with pastry and the shops supply their wares for free. Birds fall out of the sky, spitroasted and ovenready, and fish spring out of rivers and streams into the nets of fishermen. It is said that in the earliest days when white men arrived on this continent, the rivers of New England and New York were so filled with salmon it seemed like Cockaigne. So much so that after the Declaration of Independence was signed it became a New England customprincipally around Boston and in the Connecticut areato serve steamed salmon with green peas and new potatoes as the holiday meal, with strawberry shortcake for dessert. Although there doubtlessly are still families that will observe that happy custom next Monday, the salmon that graces those holiday tables will almost surely come from far afield, from Canada or the West Coast. Nonetheless, July, just hours away, remains the finest month for contemplating the uses and virtues of salmon, luxury though it may be.

title: Classic Eubie Blake
description: It's a for way from the parlor of Aggie Shelton's sporting house in Baltimore to the elegant Rainbow Room on the 65th floor of the RCA Building. Eubie Blake, who finally reached the Rainbow Room on Monday evening, to play two sets as an adjunct of the Newport Jazz Festival, noted that it took me 75 years to get to this place.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Thrills, No Spills

title: U.S. Creating Maximum Security Prison for Women
description: ALDERSON, W. Va., June 27The coils of razoredged wire have just been fixed along the top of the eightfoot chainlink fence outside, and the steelbar doors are installed inside the twostory brick building here at the nation's only Federal prison exclusively for women.

title: Bomb Goes Off Early
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 28One of two men who allegedly were installing a bomb under the hood of a car in a murder plot was injured today when the bomb exploded prematurely.

title: House Panel, in a Reversal, Bars Tax on Home Users of Heating Oil
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Under intense pressure, the House Ways and Means Committee today reversed a decision of two weeks ago and agreed to exempt residential users of heating oil from the proposed new tax on domestically produced oil.

title: Boy Dies in Brooklyn Pool
description: A 14yearold Brooklyn boy, out with two friends for an earlymorning swim in a Parks Deparement pool in McCarren Park, at Driggs Avenue and Lorimer Street, drowned yesterday. He was identified as Vernon Weiderhold of 157 Monitor Street, in the Greenpoint section. The police said he climbed a fence into the park about 3:30 A.M. to get to the pool.

title: TV: Subtle Godot,Unsettling Passport
description: WHEN SAMUEL BECKETT's Waiting for Godot was given a Broadway stage production in 1955,a good many critics and paying customers were thrown into, as O'Casey's Joxer Daley would have called it, a state of chassis. A former secretary of James Joyce, Beckett had foisted a conundrum upon the world of musical comedy and earnest drama. The meaning of it all was debated furiously. Was the play a monstrous joke, or a darkly comic and brilliant metaphor for the 20th century?

title: Carter's Global Challenge to Soviet Is Questioned by Some
description: President Carter's willingness to challenge the Soviet Union politically and ideologically in the world's trouble spots strikes a number of America's friends in allied, neutral and friendly governments as a worthy but slightly unrealistic position. Diplomats, soldiers and politicians interviewed in six weeks of travel in Western Europe and the Middle East argued that an effective challenge must be backed by conventional military power and be supported by public opinion.

title: ISRAELIS ARE IRKED BY U.S. STATEMENT
description: JERUSALEM, June 28The Government of Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that there was no basis for a State Department assumption that Israel was unwilling to discuss the occupied territories of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank in any peace negotiations with the Arabs.

title: Ebullient New Voice for the Voice of America
description: Ebullient is the adjective most commonly applied to R. Peter Straus, president of Straus Communications Inc. whose selection by President Carter to be director of the Voice of America was announced yesterday. Mr. Straus sounded ebulliently in character as he talked yesterday about his new job and its challenges. It is the CarterMondale commitment to human and individual rights that particularly turns me on, he said in an interview. Asked if he planned any major shifts of direction for the Voice, which is the overseas broadcasting arm of the United States Information Agency, Mr. Straus said he did not.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 4 INDICTED IN FRAUD ON SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: Three officers of an agency that conducted a summer food program for needy children were indicted yesterday on charges of billing the Government for food that was never served and of serving it sometimes at unauthorized sites and sometimes to adults instead of children.

title: Family Money: When a Better job Calls. for a New Home
description: THEODORE D. BELL is a precise, softspoken executive who for the better part of a decade has been counseling that new breed of migrant worker, the whitecollar corporate transferee.

title: Goro Seki, 82, Leader in Trade Between U.S. and Japan in Silk
description: Goro Seki, 82, Leader in Trade Between U.S. and Japan in SilkGoro Seki, a leader in the raw silk trade between Japan and the United States, died Tuesday at the United Presbyterian Home in Syosset, N. Y. He was 82 years old and a resident of Great Neck, L.I.

title: GARDENING
description: FORTUNATE, indeed, are those who remembered to tuck a fragrant plant or two near the door yard, in a window box or close to city terrace windows. For the scents of summer are delicious to have, no matter how subtle the fragrance.

title: 51,745 See Fidrych Check Red Sox, 72
description: Detroit is not only the motor capital of the world, but also one of the best baseball towns in the United States. That was proved again last night when 51,745 fans jammed Tiger Stadium to watch Mark Fidrych beat the slumping Boston Red Sox, 72.

title: FRIENDLY RELATIONS WITH CHINA TERMED KEY GOAL BY VANCE
description: Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said here last night that the United States was committed to seeking full diplomatic relations with Peking and that friendly relations with China were a central part of our foreign policy.

title: 9 in OPEC Drop Planned 5% Rise For Price of Oil
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Organ ization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, moving toward an end of six months of acrimony and dissension, announced today that nine of its members would cancel a 5 percent oilprice increase scheduled for Friday in an effort to achieve internal unity.

title: Man Accused of Shooting Porpoise
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 29 (AP)A 58yearold man has been charged with shooting a porpoise in what officials say is the first such arrest under the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972. James Smith of Seminole was released on $1,000 bond after a hearing yesterday. Federal agents said the charge was based on an incident last Thursday in the Gulf of Mexico off St. Petersburg Beach, after passengers aboard a charter fishing boat reported that a man in a small boat had fired a halfdozen rifle shots into a school of porpoises, apparently killing at least one of them.

title: ACCOUNTING BOARD SETS UP STANDARD ON TROUBLED LOANS
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board announced yesterday that it had established a standard for the treatment of the restructuring of troubled loans, eliminating the possibility of multibilliondollar writedowns by the banking industry.

title: People in Sports
description: The New York Jets yesterday signed Marvin Powell of the University of Southern California, their first draft choice, to a series of five oneyear contracts that are estimated to be worth a total of about $500,000. The 6foot4inch, 245pound Powell, a native of Fort Bragg, N.C., was the fourth pick in the National Football League's college draft. He plays offensive tackle.

title: Flow of Savings to Thrift Units Accelerated in May From April
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (Reuters) The net inflow of savings into Federally insured savings and loan institutions ac celerated in May to $3.41 billion from $1.92 billion in April, the Federal Horne Loan Bank Board said.

title: Three Disgraced Chinese Officials Reported Denounced in Huge Rally
description: PEKING, June 29 (Reuters)Three disgraced Chinese officials have been subjected to mass criticism at a rally attended by a roaring crowd of 1.1 million in the troubled southwestern province of Yunnan, according to a radio report.

title: Carey Signs Marijuana Measure Reducing Penalty for Possession
