description: Governor Carey signed into law yesterday afternoon the marijuana bill that was given final legislative passage by the State Senate early in the morning. New York thus became the ninth state in the union to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana.

title: Big Board Issues Its Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.

title: All Nippon to Add Jumbo Jets
description: TOKYO, June 29 (UPI)  All Nippon Airways, hoping to increase its passenger load, will add Boeing 747SR jumbo jets powered by General Electric engines to its fleet of Lockheed Tristar jetliners, the Kyodo News Agency reported today. The decision was made yesterday at a special technical panel meeting.

title: Hers
description: I HEAR a pendulum swinging. Topless entertainment may lose some of its license; homosexual rights are wronged; a Wisconsin judge finds rape normal in a permissive world, only to find himself strictly overruled by an outraged community. We'll be back with these and other stories in a minute.

title: Tribute to Wilkins Unites Feuding N.A.A.C.P. Parley
description: ST. LOUIS, June 29In a glowing tribute to Roy Wilkins, C. Delores Tucker, a member of the N.A.A.C.P.'s board of directors, repeatedly characterized the outgoing executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People as the Rock of Roy at a ceremony here last night.

title: 'Empire of the Ants' A Snail's-Pace Film
description: BERT I. GORDON seems to be fascinated by the Animal Kingdom. Last year he conjured up a menagerie of mammoth voracious rats, chickens and bees for "Food of the Gods," a film inspired by an H. G. Wells story. Now Mr. Gordon has come up with a man-hungry colony of giant insects in "Empire of the Ants," also derived from a work by H. G. Wells. The movie swarmed into local theaters yesterday; unfortunately, the insects and the people in this mlange of ersatz science-fiction and dull adventure deserve one another.There are some "15,000 different species of ants," an off-screen narrator tells us, whose industry and intelligence are astounding. But these king-sized insects don't appear to get much competition, intellectual or otherwise, from the covey of humans who figure in this picture. The humans are a group of prospeceive buyers conned to undeveloped acres apparently in the vicinity of the Everglades, where some of the film was shot.In any case, salesmanship soon gives way to special effects as the ants, keening and racketing like helicopters, start stalking and decimating the group as the humans try to escape via a river and the swampy, jungle-like terrain. If credulity isn't strained at this point, it certainly is when the humans finally make it to a village and sugar refinery controlled by, you guessed it, sugar-loving ants.As a laconic charter boat skipper, Robert Lansing seems to be more level-headed than the rest as he leads this largely ill-fated party out of a frightening mess. But the human's fright is seen as play acting, and the account of their progress over a gory trail is slow and repetitive. And, aside from some multifaceted ant's-eye views of humans, the special effects are artificial and unexciting.This "Empire of the Ants," as Albert Salmi, in the small role of the village sheriff, puts it, is "hard to believe."This film is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") probably for its occasional bloody scenes and its ant attacks, but these simulated terrors are not likely to shock viewers past the age of, say, 10.

title: Design Notebook
description: ADDING to an old building that is not a single unit, but a complex that grew gradually over the years, is a tough problem. Building a tall tower in the middle of a block of much lower structures is at least as difficult. And creating apartments of betterthanaverage layout, given the constraints of New York City economics, often seems nearly impossible.

title: U.N. Resolution Asks Members to Aid Mozambique
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 29Security Council members appeared to have reached agreement tonight on a resolution asking governments to provide material assistance to help Mozambique to defend itself from border attacks by troops of Rhodesia's white minority Government.

title: House Vote Defeating Pay Rollback
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)Here is the rollcall by which the House defeated today by a vote of 241 to 181 an amendment that would have cut off funds for the pay rises for members of Congress, high Government officials and top civil servants that went into effect earlier this year. A yes vote is a vote to roll back the pay increases. Those who did not vote are denoted by xxx.

title: G.O.P. to Drop 2 Campaign Suits Against Carter on Postal Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)The Republican National Committee said yesterday that it would drop two lawsuits involving President Carter's campaign because the Postal Service agreed to establish new rules for mailing election materials.

title: Police Decoy Teams Are a Shield for the Helpless
Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, June 29The state announced plans today to set aside a 760squaremile portion of New Jersey's Pine Barrens as a critical area for which all sewage disposal systems must meet standards for protecting the region's highly prized water supply and natural environment.

title: Magda Lupescu, Woman Behind Rumania's Throne, Is Dead at 81
description: ESTORIL, Portugal, June 29 (Reuters)Princess Elena, the former Magda Lupescu, who had a 22year love affair with the late King Carol of Rumania before becoming married to him in exile, died here today at the age of 81, family sources said.

title: Joe Rudi Out of Action
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 29 (AP)Joe Rudi will be out for at least three weeks because of a fracture of the index finger on his right hand, a spokesman for the California Angels said today. Rudi, an Angel outfielder, was hit by a pitch thrown by Nelson Briles of the Texas Rangers in the first inning of the second game of a doubleheader last Sunday. His spot on the roster will be filled by Thad Bosley, an outfielder who has been called up from Salt Lake City of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Rebellious Prelate Ordains 14
description: ECONE, Switzerland, June 29Defying warnings from Pope Paul VI, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the rebellious French prelate, today ordained 14 students of his unauthorized seminary here as priests and consecrated 16 others as subdeacons.

title: Alaska Pipeline Ahead of Schedule
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 29 (UPI)The pumping of Alaska's North Slope oil from Prudhoe Bay to Valdez, Alaska, has been running ahead of schedule, the Alyeska Pipeline Services Company reported today. By Saturday, the oil was expected to be crossing the Yukon River, 350 miles south of Prudhoe Bay and near its halfway point in the 799mile route.

title: Air Pollution: It's Inside, Too
description: BERKELEY, CALIF. THE smog is so thick it makes your eyes water. Even though the tears, you can see the brownblue haze that coats the buildings in your cityNew York, Chicago, Los Angeles or any other American city plagued with air pollution.

title: Carter Picks Four Areas for Studies On Improving Federal Bureaucracy
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  President Carter today ordered studies of how the Federal Government could better perform its functions in four major areaslaw enforcement, local economic development human services and administrative servicesthrough what he called desperately needed goVernment reorganization.

title: Car  Insurance Rate Curbs Scored
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, June 29The president of the Independent Insurance Agents of America charged today that restrictive and irresponsible legal restrictions were making New Jersey the most significant trouble spot for the insurance industry in the United States.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1977

title: FRIENDLY RElATIONS WITH CHINA TERMED KEY GOAL BY VANCE
description: Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said here last night that the United States was committed to seeking full diplomatic relations with Peking and that friendly relations with China were a central part of our foreign policy.

title: A Man, 25, Is Slain Near Gramercy Park With His Bound Fiance in the Next Rooth
description: When Fred Fuller and his fiance opened the door of his apartment near Gramercy Park late Tuesday night and switched on the light they were confronted by a masked man with a piece of pipe in one hand, and a gun in the other.

title: When Free Trade Hurts
description: International trade benefits the United States and its trading partners. Free trade, unfettered by tariffs or quotas or other interventions, allows each country to specialize in goods it produces most cheaply, thereby increasing the income of all. That's what the textbooks say, and for the most part they are right.

title: A Guide to Home Pool Maintenance
description: THE POOL owner's work, like the housewife's, is never done, or so it seems. Opening a pool at the start of the season and winterizing it in the fall are major projects that people often have professionally done. It is the constant chore of keeping a pool clean and sanitary that is so timeconsuming, and those who can afford it often have this taken care of professionally too.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONThough bitter political battles are not unusual in this capital, the intensity of the fight over natural gas pricing has startled even veteran observers.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET CREW TESTS ECOLOGICAL CHAMBER
description: A Soviet testing team has completed a stay of four months in an isolation chamber in a Siberian research institute in a continuing program aimed at developing artificial ecological systems for long interplanetary space missions.

title: BEAME SEEKS SHIFT ON L.I.R.R TERMINAL
description: Mayor Beame proposed yesterday that Grand Central Terminal, rather than a new building at 48th Street and Third Avenue, be made the East Side terminal for the Long Island Rail Road.

title: A $600,000 Bilking Of 30 Pro Athletes Is Laid to ExAgent
description: MINEOLA, L.I., June 29Richard Sorkin a former agent for many professional athletes was arrested by the Nassau County District Attorney's office today and charged with the theft of more than $600,000 from 30 players he had represented.

title: Backgammon:
description: Last April the World Backgammon Club sponsored the ninth annual tournament for the important Wacker Cup in St. Martin, in the West Indies. In the finals Jason Lester made a dramatic comeback to beat Prince Alexis Obolensky Jr. After trailing 18 to 4, Lester won the cup, 25 to 21. Lester, from Montreal, is only 19 and looks even younger hence his nickname, Baby Jason. However, his youthful appearance belies his skill as an exceptionally strong natural player, one of the rising stars of the game. In the diagrammed position, Lester demonstrated his fine grasp of endgame technique.

title: Lucia Isenring Is New Juliet To Madsen's Winning Romeo
description: JOHN CRANKO'S production of Romeo and Juliet for the Stuttgart Ballet is familiar here; it is his best ballet and also one of the best ballet versions of Shakespeare's play.

title: Dance: The Twain Meet
description: THE SCORES of Japanese student dancers who flocked to the United States after Martha Graham's phenomenally successful tours of the Far East during the 1950's and 60's have now become performers and choreographers in their own right. They all show a keen interest in the contemporary American scene that surrounds them, although they also retain elements of traditional Japanese dance to a greater or lesser extent. Saeko Ichinohe has taken a long look at a variety of styles and presented an entertaining collection of her works at the Open Eye Tuesday evening.

title: Irish Breeding Legend Judging U.S. Dogs
description: Sheelagh Seale, originator of the Ballykelly Irish wolfhounds, is a legend in her time. Breeders speak in awe of the noted authority, and her prefix has long been the identifying stamp on leading champions throughout the world. However, Miss Seale made only her first visit to the United States this month to judge the West Coast specialty at Lake Tahoe, Calif. A petite blonde with a soft voice, she said: I hate judging; you have so many enemies. It took a lot of courage to say I would do it over here, but I wanted to see my many friends.

title: Delay in Filling Vacancies Leaves Nuclear Agency Without Quorum
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Because of a fivemonth delay by President Carter in filling vacancies on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the commission will cease to have a legal quorum on Friday and will be unable to perform some of its functions.

title: Yen Surges to 44Month Record As the Dollar Finishes at 268.90
description: TOKYO, June 29The yen climbed to its highest level in three years and eight months today amid indications that the Japanese Government was under heavy foreign pressure to let the currency float even higher.

title: Licenses of 295 Radio Stations Challenged on Job Bias Charges
description: A coalition of more than a dozen organizations has filed a complaint with the Federal Communications Commission in Washington challenging the renewal of licenses for 295 small radio stations throughout the country. In addition, the complaint includes 16 broadcast centers and some small television stations.

title: PigeonOwner Scores A Coo d'Etat in Court
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 29 (AP)Ralph Farese, his pigeons and their coop have scored a coup in Superior Court here. Judge George B. Gelman said Mr. Farese's neighbor, Joseph Rigoglioso, had fallen far short of showing that the pigeons were a nuisance.

title: Clock Repair: Time Is Money
description: SO you've bought or inherited an old clock and you want to find out what makes it tick, or, more likely, why it doesn't tick? Good luck. Without some knowledge of timepieces you may find yourself at the mercy of clock repairmen the way some people are at the mercy of auto mechanics. And, although the prices of repairs vary substantially, most often those prices are high.

title: Market Place
description: When the shares of a company fall below book valuethe theoretical breakup value of the companythey are often regarded as attractive. This is particularly so if such a company has recorded substantial earnings over the years.

title: Newport Tazz: Vibrant Virtuosos
description: IT CAME AS NEWS to one listener at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening that the group sound is currently prevalent in jazz. Solos, one might have thought, have dominated jazz for the last 25 years.

title: Poolside Structures That Make a Splash
description: POOLS are bottomless pits, so to speak. When you first get your pool, you think the only accessories you need are a few towels. But before long you crave chaises, an umbrella for shade, a large ice bucket, plastic glasses, gin and tonic and a bar cart.

title: The Where of It All
description: Sizing up a town where you might like to live is at best a difficult sociological exercise. Among the balancesheet items E.T.C. urges its clients to ponder are the quality of the schools, how far you have to travel to get to a hospital, transportation, and the job market for other members of the family besides the chief breadwinner.

title: Meadowlands
description: SECOND$9,000, pace, mile.

title: People and Business
description: Directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation voted yesterday to discontinue the company's step down at 60 policy. The program, which provided that the top management committee would be required to retire at the age of 60, has been in effect since 1972. The new retirement age reverts to the pre1972 level of 65.

title: TV: Turn To Soft And Silly
description: WHILE THE TRADITIONAL hourlong documentary the one that attempts to deal with important subjects and issues in some depthstruggles with dwindling and demoralized production staffs, miserable time slots and low ratings, television news departments are increasingly preoccupied with lighter and breezier forms. Two examples, one In a veteran format. and the other in a brandnew one, are on tap. Mr. Rooney Goes to Work can be seen next Tuesday on CBS at 8 P.M. Now is unveiled on NBC tonight at 10 o'clock.

title: Memorial Services
description: ROBINSONPaul Hoover. A memorial service will be held at United Methodist Church, East Clinton and George St., Tenafly, NJ on Wednesday, July 6 at 7 PM for the late Paul Hoover Robinson who passed away on June 27. Contributions may be made to the United Methodist Church of Tenafly or to the Cancer Society.

title: MAY ECONOMIC INDEX DECLINED, SIGNALING PAUSE IN RECOVERY
description: WASHINGTON, June 29A Government index designed to signal future economic trends declined in May, perhaps foreshadowing some slackening in the strong pace of recovery, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Government Bond Prices Decline Ona Low Yield for Treasury Issue
description: Government bond prices fell yesterday in the wake of the Treasury's sale of 15year bonds on Tuesday as the 7.29 percent yield on the securities apparently seemed disappointingly low to some investors. Toward the close, prices recovered somewhat.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A union county superior Court judge ordered a halt yesterday to the spinning wheels, rolling dice and blackjack dealing at the Atlantic City Casino Dealer School Inc. in New Jersey's first legal move to enforce the new Casino Control Act.

title: Belmont Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Companies List Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended May 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and, (O) overthecounter

title: Books of The Times
description: ISUPPOSE I qualify as a WASP under Florence King's definition: German on my father's side, English on my mother's, but the transAtlantic business took place well over 100 years ago. White. Sufficiently Protestant to know the words to Jesus Loves Me and There Is Sunshine in My Soul Today.

title: Williams Seeks Meehan Merger To Form Stronger Specialist Unit
description: In a move to strengthen itself against the day when the largest specialist unit on the New York Stock Exchange is likely to begin to compete in making markets in the 19 stocks it now handles exclusively, Blair S. Williams & Company, a specialist firm, said yesterday it planned to merge with M.J. Meehan & Company, one of the bestknown specialists on the floor.

title: Sound
description: SILENCE, after the clangor of the city, seems one of the main attractions of a summer house. I am always thrilled on a still day when no wind rustles the leaves, and my hilltop cabin in the Berkshires is so quiet that I can hear my heartbeat. Utter calm, for a while, is all I want. But then I get homesick for music.

title: Swivel, Whirl, Rock and RollIn Comfort
description: CHICAGO ASCORE of chairs rock better, roll better and swivel more efficiently  or cradle the sitter in astounding comfort  have been introduced here at Neocon 9, the nation's largest wholesale market for architects, designers and store buyers.

title: Deaths
description: BANCROFTFrances, of Portugal, formerly of Essex Fells. (See McLeod Frances Bancroff).

title: British Company Sells Prayer Mats to Mecca
description: WARRINGTON, England, June 29 (Reuters)A British company that exports prayer mats to Mecca won the Incredible Exporter of the Year Award today.

title: Start of G.&W. Aide's Term Is Set
description: The former general counsel of Gulf and Western Industries, whose sentence for check forgery had been delayed more than a year while he cooperated with authorities, was ordered yesterday to begin serving immediately a prison term of up to three years. But later in the day he was given a two week reprieve.

title: Leonard Silk
description: As the Marxists see it, business and government in capitalist countries work in close harmony with business calling the tune. But that is not the way Henry A. Kissinger sees it; based on his experience as Secretary of State, Business has no perception of its longrange interests, Mr. Kissinger told a group of highlevel business executives meeting here today in a seminar staged by Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies. Mr. Kissinger has become a professor at Georgetown.

title: Theater of the Crowd
description: LONDON, June 29One of the civilizing elements in the life of great cities has been the place of casual encounterthe Roman piazza, the Paris cafwhere people talk and drink and in their mass provide each other's entertainment. If modern cities have an inhuman feeling, one reason may be that too few places in them invite pause or social mingling; all is busy, swift, isolated.

title: Letters
description: The Old Double Standard

title: Who Is the New Virginia Wade?
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29She has always been Our Ginny, to the British, and the country seemed to rise and fall each summer with Virginia Wade's trying tennis fortunes at Wimbledon.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS CARTER PLAN, 2221, TO CURB GAS PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The House Commerce Committee voted today to adopt President Carter's proposal for natural gas price regulation and to abandon a proposal for deregulation accepted three weeks ago by a subcommittee.

title: Golf Cart Kills Operator
description: DEAL, N. J. (UPI) June 29John J. Martucci, 19 years old, of Ocean Township was killed last night when the golf cart he was driving apparently flipped over on him while he was tending the grounds of the Deal Golf and Country Club, the police reported. The police in nearby Ocean Township discovered Mr. Martucci's body about 10:15 P.M., shortly after he drove onto the golf course to check the club's water sprinkling system.

title: 5 Beaches Remain Closed On Bayside of Fire Island While Pollution Is Traced
description: OCEAN BEACH, LI., June 29The bayside beaches here and at four other Fire Island communities remained closed for a third day today as Suffolk County health officials attempted to find the source of pollution in the bay.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter cesignates OTB listing.

title: Virginia Wade Upsets Chris Evert by 62, 46, 61
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29Chris Evert, drained by the emotional drama of the last two weeks and the determination of Britain's revitalized tennis heroine, Virginia Wade, was beaten in the semifinals at Wimbledon today.

title: Major Tiremakers Plan Price Rises
description: AKRON, Ohio June 29 (AP)Most of the nation's major tiremakers win raise prices by 3 to 5 percent early neat month, the companies said today. They said the increases were necessary because of rising costs, including wage increases won in last year's rubber workers' strike.

title: Healy Is an AllStar As Yankees' Mediator
description: TORONTO, June 29He is of Irish descent, not German, but Fran Healy, an unheralded, se!dcmused Yankee, is Henry Kissinger and Thurman Munson wrapped in one.

title: TROY OPENS HIS DEFENSE AGAINST PERJURY COUNTS
description: The Queens District Attorney's office yesterday rested its case in the perjury trial of Councilman Matthew J, Troy Jr. in State Supreme Court.

title: Meadow Maiden Triumphs in Sire Stakes
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 29Rallying in the stretch, Meadow Maiden scored a 1length triumph tonight in the $56,366 New York Sire Stakes for 3yearold pacing fillies at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: East Harlem JobTraining Project Continued Despite Goldin Attack
description: A contract for what Comptroller Harri son J. Goldin denounced as one of the worst jobtraining programs in the city was awarded by the Board of Estimate yesterday at Mayor Beanie's urging.

title: An Interpreter Of Taste
description: LONDON DAVID HICKS once drew cornflake boxes for the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency. He currently designs residences for royalty like Princess Anne and Prince Charles and untitled nobility like Jacqueline Onassis and Mrs. Paul Mellon.

title: Farm Prices Fell 5% in 30 Days Ended June 15, First Decline in 7 Months
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)Prices farmers get for raw products dropped 5 percent between May 15 and June 15, the first monthtomonth decline in seven months, the Agriculture Department said today

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1977

title: Cuomo Assures $100 Backers Carey Is Not His Frankenstein
description: Some 450 people paid $100 each share coffee and danish with Mario M. Cuomo yesterday, and they listened in respectful silence while he criticized Mayor Beame's budget as replete with gimmicks and tricksand then, from that friendly crowd, Norman Goldberg, a shoe salesman, stood at a floor microphone.

title: Britain, in a Reversal, Tries to Stem London Exodus
description: LONDON, June 29Shelley wrote in 1819, Hell is a city much like London, a populous and smoky city.

title: Work of Undercover Man Ends Fence's Operation, Gold Reports
description: A fencing operation that dealt in guns, counterfeit currency, stolen checks, typewriters, sneakers, suits and even a Gucci fur coat was closed and its owner and 15 customers were indicted, District Attorney Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday.

title: Cleveland Labor Newspaper Sold
description: CLEVELAND, June 29 (UPI)  The Cleveland Citizen, one of the country's oldest labor newspapers, has been sold for an undisclosed price to the Cleveland Building and Construction Trades Council. which plans to convert the bimonthly, eightpage paper into a weekly and expand it to 12 pages. The seller, A. I. Davey Jr., has had financial problems for some time. The newspaper, founded in 1891, has a circulation of about 18,000.

title: New York and 7 Other States Sign Accord For Mutual Penalty on Drivers' Violations
description: Soon there may be no place to hide. As of yesterday, a New York driver who ignores an outofstate speeding ticket risks losing his driving license in New York.

title: Moody's Cuts Rating For GAF Debentures
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it was lowering its rating: on the GAF Corporation's 5 percent debentures that come due in 1991 to Baa from Ato medium grade from upper medium grade. The company promptly decided to withdraw from the commercial paper market.

title: Police Decoys Shield the Helpless
description: That derelict slumped in the dank doorway, her purse spilled open, may have a pistol in her pocket. Since 1970 the streets of New York City have been infiltrated by police decoys. The program has paid off, with a drop in crime against the elderly and against taxi drivers, and an arrest rate that is rising.

title: Murder Plot Laid to Prison Guard
description: A New York City correction officer and his brother were charged yesterday with conspiring to murder a prostitute who had accused one of them of robbing her at gunpoint.

title: SENATE VOTE FORBIDS USING FEDERAL FUNDS FOR MOST ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Senate voted tonight to bar Federal funds for abortions except when the mother's life is in danger, in cases of rape or incest or in certain other cases when it is considered medically necessary.

title: Notes on People
description: FOR Charles Aznavour, there was good and bad news yesterday. First the bad news: The French singer was found guilty of tax evasion prior to mid1972 on undeclared income outside of France and sentenced to pay $720,000 to the tax authorities. And the good news: The oneyear prison sentence that went with the verdict of a court in Versailles was suspended and the court renounced a claim for $3 million more for alleged undeclared money transfers abroad since 1972. The court accepted the argument that Mr. Aznavour at the time became a legal resident of Switzerland and thus ceased to be under relevant French regulations.

title: State Agrees to Guard the Rights of Mental Patients
description: TRENTON, June 29State officials acknowledged today that patients in New Jersey's mental hospitals had been mistreated physically and medically.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Abortion Proposal
description: WASHINGTON. June 29 (AP)Following is the 56to47 rollcall vote by wh ch the Senate rejected today an amendment by Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, to remove al (restrictions on the use of Federal junds for abortions:

title: Advertising
description: Once again, Don Johnston, a president and chief executive who believes in tailoring the organization to its management's skills, is restructuring the J. Walter Thompson Company and in doing so is thrusting more challenges on his star players.

title: High Court Vacated Order Calling for Broad Busing In Omaha and Milwaukee
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)The Supreme Court told lower courts today to take another look at school desegregation orders requiring extensive busing in Omaha and Milwaukee.

title: Profit in '76 Reported by Renault
description: Rgie Nationale des Usines Renault, the French Governmentowned automotive company, like the American automotive producers, made a sharp.recovery in operating results last year.

title: Pope Marks Anniversary
description: ROME, June 29 (UPI)Pope Paul VI celeprated his 14th year on the Throne of St. Peter today with an appeal to all Roman Catholics for unity.

title: 9 in OPEC Drop Planned 5% Rise For Price of Oil
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, moving toward an end of six months of acrimony and dissension, announced today that nine of its members would cancel a 5 percent oilprice increase scheduled for Friday in an effort to achieve internal unity.

title: Israel to Investigate School Exam Sales
description: JERUSALEM, June 29 (AP)The Israeli police opened an investigation today into black market sales of carefully guarded advance copies of national high school exams.

title: Home Beat
description: NOBODY asked us, but if we were going to hand out awards, the award for the best graphics to come in the mail this season would go to Martex and Wamsutta for two mailing pieces.

title: NICKEL LOBBY STARTS FOR CONSUMER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 29In a strategy based on metallic irony, Ralph Nader and a 95member group of his allies started a lobbying effort today to nickel undecided Congressmen into voting for a consumer protection agency.

title: All Robert Hall Stores Padlocked; Signs of Permanent Closing Seen
description: Robert Hall Clothes, the nation's largest retail chain selling men's and women's clothing, last night padlocked all of its 366 stores in a surprise move that immediately drew charges of a lockout from three unions with which it has contracts.

title: HIGH COURT RULES OUT EXECUTION OF RAPISTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29In the final act of its current term, the Supreme Court held today that the death penalty may not be used as punishment for rape, at least when the rape victim is an adult.

title: Carter's News Parley Is on Television Today
description: The three television networks and their local stationsChannels 2, 4 and 7have scheduled live coverage this morning of President Carter's news conference, starting at 10:30. The following radio stations will also broadcast the session live: WBAI, WCBSAM, WINS and WMCA.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Burroughs Corporation demonstrated here yesterday a new process for printing checks that are at least partly forgeryproof when reproduced on the Xerox Corporation's color copier. Burroughs has applied for patents on the new system called Super Safety II. The company declined to explain how it works, but showed that when a colored check was duplicated on, a color copying machine using normal settings, the word void appeared across the face of the check.

title: Blumenthal Defends View on Trade Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, June 29W. Michael Blumenthal, Secretary of the Treasury, denied today that the United states was conducting a policy of either complacency or benign neglect in dealing with its gaping trade and balance of payments deficit this year.

description: FIRST GAME

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Call of the Wild

title: Nuclear Reactor in the Northwest Closed for Second Time in 4 Days
description: HANFORD, Wash., June 29 (UPI)The nuclear reactor at the Hanford Atomic Reservation was closed for the second time in four days today when a pinsized hole developed in the metal casings that house uranium fuel elements and traces of radioactive material began leaking into water used for cooling.

title: Harrison Rejects Nestle Bid to Build Purchase Offices
description: HARRISON. N.Y., June 29The Harrison Town Board voted unanimously tonight to reject a Nestle Company petiiton to build its headquarters on a 53acre sire in the center of the town's Purchase section. Its headquarters are now in White Plains.

title: Mets Defeat Phillies, 53, Ending Skid
description: The Mets put together a mixture of good pitching, opportune hitting, fine fielding and adventuresome baserunning last night at Shea Stadium to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 53, and break their sixgame losing streak.

title: CAROLYN DAVISON MORROW
description: Carolyn Davison Morrow, wife of Hugh Morrow, a former press secretary and now an adviser to former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller, died Sunday at her Bronxville, N.Y., home. She was 55 years old.

title: Legislators in Albany Are at Odds On ApartmentConversion Limits
description: ALBANY, June 29Although faced with imminent expiration of a state law limiting the right of landlords to convert rental apartment buildings into cooperatives or condominiums, leaders of the Legislature remained unable to reach agreement tonight to extend tenant protection.

title: Americans Dominating Meet
description: HELSINKI, Finland, June 29 (UPI)Americans dominated the start of the twoday 11 th World Games track and field meet at Helsinki Olympic Stadium today.

title: Letter From Home
description: NEW HAVEN THE NEWTOWN BEE held an open house on Sunday to celebrate its 100th birthday, and about 1,400 wellwishers came from all over to toast its obviously good health.

title: Borek, Bruno Ousted In Westchester Golf
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 29Two major upsets marked the first two rounds of match play today in the Westchester Professional Golfer's Association championship. The event was played in sultry werther at the 6,530yard, par 35, 3671 Elmwood Country Club course.

title: Bridge:
description: The president of the Italian Bridge Federation, speaking in Turin on Monday, sharply rejected cheating allegations relating to some famous Italian players and threatened to withdraw from world competition.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Wednesday, June29,1977

title: A Revolutionary Returns
description: LISTEN OR DANCE, that's all you can do with music, Ornette Coleman, the composer, saxophonist, trumpeter and violinist, was saying the other day. Sometimes you can do both. Mr. Coleman was talking about his new album, Dancing in Your Head, his first in five years, and about the music he will be playing during the second half of his concert tonight at P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. The first half of the concert, which is his first in New York since a Carnegie Hall performance in 1973, will be a kind of retrospective of the music Mr. Coleman introduced in the late 1950's and continued to play through the mid70's. It is a music that created a revolution, pulling musicians of the stature of John Coltrane and Sonny Rollins along with it.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, June 29 (Reuters)The leader of the Spanish Communist Party, Santiago Carrillo, today compared the Kremlin with the 16thcentury inquisitors of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Where the Sorg of Sam' Struck, Young Women Walk in Fear
description: Most of my friends are wearing their hair up, Debby Pannullo said, as she slowed her car for a red light on NorthOn Boulevard in Queens. My boyfriend wanted me to dye mine, it's so scary. If I have to go out, I try not to come home late.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: 2 Soviet Activists Face Jail
description: MOSCOW, June 29 (AP)A Soviet prosecutor recommended prison terms of seven and 10 years today for two Ukrainian human rights activists, Mykola Rudenko and Oleska Tikhy, accused of antiSoviet propaganda, dissident sources reported. The defendants are members of a group established to monitor Soviet compliance with the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accords. Mr. Rudenko is chairman of the group.

title: VIRGINIA POLLARD ROBINSON
description: Virginia Pollard Robinson, an educator and author, died yesterday of a heart attack at the Pine Run Health Care Center in Doylestown, Pa. She was 93 years old.

title: ExChaplain Recalls How Slovik Was Chosen to Die
description: WASHINGTON, June 29A former Army chaplain testified today that Pvt. Eddie D. Slovik, the only American soldier to be executed for desertion in this century, had come from a pool of six deserters being considered for the firing squad, and that Private Slovik was chosen on the basis of his psychological profile.

title: U.S. Airlifts Ill Russian Sailor
description: ASTORIA, Ore., June 29 (UPI)A sick Russian sailor picked up from a Soviet trawler by a Coast Guard helicopter was reported in stable condition today at a hospital here. Peznichenko M. Sergeevich, 40 years old, suffering from an ulcer, was vomiting blood when he was airlifted from the trawler, Mys Grina, off the Oregon coast.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Freeholder Group Alters Its Composition, Adds 30,000
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 29The 56yearold New Jersey Association of Chosen Freeholders became the New Jersey Association of Counties today, increasing its membership from 135 freeholders to 30,000 elected and appointed county officials.

title: Calendar of Events for the House and Home
description: Some events of interest for enthusiasts of the house and home, including two craft festivals for the Fourth of July weekend, one in the city, the other in the suburbs.

title: Punk's Horror Show
description: Punk is sweeping the country.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Ahern, ExNew Haven Police Chief, Linked by Witness to Wiretapping
description: NEW HAVEN, June 29At the same time that former Police Chief James F. Ahern was winning national acclaim as a new breed of liberal policeman, he was running an extensive illegal wiretapping operation here, according to one of his former officers.

title: Carey Signs Marijuana Measure Reducing Penalty for Possession
description: Governor Carey signed into law yesterday afternoon the marijuana bill that was given final legislative passage by the State Senate early in the morning. New York thus became the ninth state in the union to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana.

title: Jazz: A Striking McCoy Tyner
description: MC COY TYNER'S Tuesday evening concert at Avery Fisher Hall was everything one would have expected. Mr. Tyner was a mesmerizing and influential pianist 15 years ago with the John Coltrane quartet. Today he is undoubtedly the most widely imitated acoustic pianist in contemporary jazz, and his group style, a more studiously Eastern and Africanoriented version of the late Mr. Coltrane's, is also reflected in the work of countless other musicians.

title: Cauthen Gets Triple Again at Belmont
description: Steve Cauthen continued to enthrall his followers yesterday at Belmont Park in his new role as a journeyman jockey.

title: Hoving Era at the Met, Decade of Change, Ends
description: The Thomas Hoving era at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is over. Today the man who for 10 years has shaped the destiny of our largest and greatest art museum, enlarging an already huge institution and generating immense publicity and sometimes stormy controversy at every turn, steps down, succeeded for the moment by a newly appointed acting director, Philippe de Montebello.

title: Rebellious Prelate Ordains 14
description: ECONE, Switzerland, June 29Defying warnings from Pope Paul VI, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the rebellious French prelate, today ordained 14 students of his unauthorized seminary here as priests and consecrated 16 others as subdeacons.

title: 26 U.S. Crews to Row at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England. June 29The Henley Royal Regatta, rowed since, its inception in 1839 on the same stretch of the Thames River that flows through this idyllic town, begins tomorrow. In honor of Britain's Silver Jubilee celebration, Princess Anne is scheduled to represent the royal family at the fourday event. The Princess, along with spectators who will crowd the shores of the 1mile550yard course, will witness an almost exclusively Englishspeaking entry for the 12 separate cup races that make up the regatta.

title: Disks: Beethoven by Brendel
description: This is the first installment in Alfred Brendel's second cycle of the Beethoven piano concertos. He recorded them before for Voxwith different orchestras and conductorsperformances that are still available boxed and separately, on Turnabout. The present release, put out In conjunction with his current tour of this country, anticipates a scheduled boxed Philips set in the fall of the complete concertos, all with Bernard Haitink and the Londoners.

title: Two Farewells
description: No one has rushed to more municipal fires in this time of crisis than John Zuccotti. As First Deputy Mayor, he was virtually New York's indispensable man. Yet suddenly he is gone, to rest and to make some money. It is hard to imagine John Zuccotti remaining on the sidelines for long.

title: Bell Will Aid House Korean Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell assured Representative John J. Flynt Jr., chairman of the House ethics committee, that the Justice Department would cooperate with the panel in the investigation of the Korean lobbying scandal, a department spokesman said today.

title: Kenya Reports Attack by Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 29 (Reuters)Kenya said today that 3,000 regular Somali troops had made a surprise attack on one of its border zone police posts and 13 men had been killed in the fighting.

title: HIGH COURT RULES OUT EXECUTION OF RAPISTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29In the final act of its current term, the Supreme Court held today that the death penalty may not be used as punishment for rape, at least when the rape victim is an adult.

title: House Defeats Move to Roll Back $12,900 Pay Rise by 241181 Vote
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The House of Representatives defeated today an attempt to roll back the $12,900 Congressional pay rise in what many members regarded as the most politically sensitive vote that they would cast this year.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World. Albums are determined by sales figures from all major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Virginia Wade Upsets Chris Evert by 62, 46, 61
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29Chris Evert, drained by the emotional drama of the last two weeks and the determination of Britain's revitalized tennis heroine, Virginia Wade, was beaten in the semifinals at Wimbledon today.

title: CUTOFF OF MEDICAID FUNDS IS PROHIBITED IN 4 STATES
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)Federal courts have issued restraining orders prohibiting the Department of Health, Education and Welfare from withholding Medicaid money from at least four of 20 states faced with a cutoff of funds by this Friday.

title: Loose Security On School Test Laid to Board
description: New York City's Comptroller blamed the Board of Education yesterday for lax security on the annual citywide reading test that was prematurely divulged to several thousand students last March.

title: Nomination for U.S. Attorney
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)  Peter E. Corning, District Attorney of Cayuga County, was nominated today by President Carter to be United States Attorney for the northern district of New York State. Mr. Corning, who is 41 years old, was recommended by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who said the nominee was selected by a screening committee headed by Leonard Garment, onetime counsel to President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Carter Planning Talks on Changes In U.S. Tariff Curb on Venezuela
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (Reuters)President Carter told Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, today that he would talk to Congressional leaders about possible changes in legislation that excludes Venezuela from tariff concessions enjoyed by most other developing countries.

title: Justice Dept. May Seek Special Revenue Sharing to Replace Anticrime Grants
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The justice Department wants to remove the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration from its jurisdiction if the controversial agency, which has distributed $6 billion in anticrime grants, cannot be abolished altogether, according to a department official.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Kay McEnroe was talking on the telephone in her Douglaston home when she excused herself. My child, she said gently, is on television. Her child is John McEnroe Jr., the Wimbledon Kid, the suddenly famous 18yearold tennis player from Queens who will oppose Jimmy Connors today in the semifinals. And for both him and his family, this is a time of arrival, a time to cherish, because it happens only once. Until this week John McEnroe Jr. was a sports name known only to those involved in teenage tennis tournaments. But now John McEnroe Jr. has gone public as the youngest player in 100 years of Wimbledon to gain the men's semifinals. Newspapermen are asking him questions, photographers are taking his picture, and films of his matches are being bounced off satellites. In his Queens home, the telephone is ringing, and his father (a Manhattan lawyer), his mother and his two younger brothers, Marc and Patrick, are being interviewed. For better or for worse, the life of John McEnroe Jr. will never be quite the same again.

title: Bahrain Is Ending Fort Services for U.S. Navy
description: BAHRAIN, June 29 (Reuters)Bahrain announced today that a sixyearold agreement giving United States naval vessels base rights at the port of Jufair would he terminated on Friday.

title: Carey Signs a Law Requiring Refunds On Studies by Mail
description: ALBANY, June 29A measure that requires correspondence schools to refund at least part of the tuition if a student drops out of a course was signed into law today by Governor Carey.

title: Recital: Krasovsky Displays Brilliant Pianism
description: THE MOST significant thing about Emanuel Krasovsky's playing at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night was not his big technique, although that was impressive enough, but that the young pianist did not use it to overpower the music. Mr. Krasovsky, who was born in Lithuania and emigrated to Israel 10 years ago, graduated from the Juilliard School last spring and has been finding his way around the international concert circuit. His recital served notice that he was ready for an important career.

title: Home Repair Q & A
description: Q. Can I remove ceramic tile from a wall and floor without destroying the tile, so that I can use it again in another area?M.M., Uniondale, L.I.

title: Gonorrhea Vaccine Tests Planned
description: An experimental vaccine against gonorrhea will be tested later this year on a small group of human volunteers by a University of Pittsburgh research team, the head of the group announced yesterday.

title: House Votes Capitol Construction
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)The House approved today a $55 million addition to the west front of the Capitol to shore up the crumbling sandstone wall and provide Congressional office pace. The proposal needs concurrence by the Senate, which has traditionally voted against such plans.

title: CLEAVER IS DENIED ACCESS TO POLICE FILES BY COURT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 (AP)The California Court of Appeal refused today to grant Eldridge Cleaver, a former Black Panther leader, access to police and Government files. He had said that some of the files showed an organized campaign to destroy him and the party.

title: Blacks and Women to Be Hired For Louisiana PoliceFire Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Justice Department obtained a consent decree in a Federal court today that will require most of the large cities in Louisiana, with the exception of New Orleans, to hire significant numbers of women and blacks for their police and fire departments.

title: SENATE VOTE FORBIDS USING FEDERAL FUNDS FOR MOST ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Senate voted tonight to bar Federal funds for abortions except when the mother's life is in danger, in cases of rape or incest or in certain other cases when it is considered medically necessary.

title: LIMITS ON RENT RISES SET IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Newand in most cases slightly higherceilings on rent increases for rentstabilized apartments were adopted yesterday by New York City's Rent Guidelines Board for apartments whose leases are signed over the next 12 months.

title: SAMUEL KRAFT
description: Samuel Kraft, the founder and retired senior partner of the accounting firm of Kraft and Finkelstein, 79 Madison Avenue, died Tuesday in New York Infirmary. His age was 85 and his home was at 1070 Park Avenue.

title: Proxmire Charges Lance Reneged On Vow to Avoid Banking Matters
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Bert Lance, director of the Office of Manangement and Budget, who pledged during his confirmation hearings not to become involved in banking legislation, has recently urged Congress to reject a controversial banking provision in a housing bill being considered on Capitol Hill.

title: Squabbles Hurting Chances of the Left In French Election
description: PARIS, June 29The mounting intensity of the quarrels between the uncomfortably allied French Socialists and Communists has given new heart to Governmentsupporters that they may win the next elections after all.

title: About New York
description: Murray Laufer, who is in nuts and bolts, spots Mayor Beame stranded momentarily on the traffic island between City Hall and the Municipal Building. The Mayor is shaking everyone's hand these days, so, no problem as friendly Mr. Laufer sidles over.

title: Britain, in a Reversal, Tries to Stem London Exodus
description: LONDON, June 29Shelley wrote in 1819, Hell is a city much like London, a populous and smoky city.

title: Personal Beauty
description: WHO'S THAT hiding under the clay pack? At the Cinandre salon it could be Richard Kennedy, a boutique owner. At Jerry's in Bergdorf Goodman it may be Andrew Stein, a retired textile manufacturer, while at Ann Keane's facial emporium, one finds Warren Mirabile, who works in a delicatessen. At Georgette Klinger it's a constant stream of men, who have a facial area all to themselves.

title: Quake Shakes Adak, Alaska
description: PALMER, Alaska, June 29 (AP)An earthquake registering 5 on the Richter scale shook Adak, Alaska, last night, but apparently did no damage, the Palmer Observatory of the National Weather Service reported.

title: Surgical Clinic Approved
description: NEWARK, June 29 (AP)The Regional Health Planning Council has approved plans to open a clinic for elective surgery here. The center, designed to reduce surgical costs by eliminating the overhead of a hospital, would be used for minos surgery that did not require an overnight hospital stay.

title: Police Decoys Shield the Helpless
description: That derelict slumped in the dank doorway, her purse spilled open, may have a pistol in her pocket. Since 1970 the streets of New York City have been infiltrated by police decoys. The program has paid off, with a drop in crime against the elderly and against taxi drivers, and an arrest rate that is rising.

title: The Olympic Hurdles for New York
description: There is a devilish new wrinkle in the competition among American cities for the 1984 Olympics. Stung by a public backlash in Denver against the 1976 winter games, the American Olympic Committee seeks not only financial guarantees but also an opinion poll and other evidence of a favorable public attitude. In other words, anything we may say about the desirability of luring the event to New York may be held against us.

title: Special Pensions Are Hidden in an Albany Labor Bill
description: ALBANY, June 29The Assembly gave final passage today to a bill that was supposed only to implement a labor settlement by the state with its employees earlier this year. But hidden within it, by agreement of legislative leaders, were clauses giving substantially higher pensions to staff members and permitting some legislators to join a lucrative pension plan.

title: On Target for Offshore Oil
description: Four months ago a Federal judge ruled that the Interior Department's procedures for selling oil leases on the outer continental shelf were a charade. By a vote of 12 to 4, the Senate Energy Committee has substantially agreed with that view. It has sent the Senate a bill to end the charade, to give the states a real chance to protect their coastal lands and, in the process, to allow small oil companies to compete against the giants.

title: Florida Girl Scout Abducted at Camp By a Male Intruder
description: SARASOTA, Fla., June 29 (AP)A 15yearold girl who was abducted from a Girl Scout camp by a man who ripped through the hack of her tent at dawn today telephoned her father late tonight and said that she was all right and would be released soon, the authorities said.

title: Honolulu Embroiled in Intrigues Of Partisan and Ethnic Politics
description: HONOLULU, June 28Political life here becomes daily more entangled with charges of venality, explanations of how business is done at the top and, most recently, a $51 million libel action. Partisan and ethnic politics have roles in all this swirl. The libel suit is by a man who was accused in print of being the godfather for organized crime in the Islands. His name is Larry Mehau, and he is a friend of the immediate past and present Governors. He is partHawaiian, a former Honolulu policeman who weighs 250 pounds, and was once the state champion of Sumo wrestling, the Japanese style.

title: Yen Soars Against Dollar
description: The dollar dropped to 267.80 yen in Tokyo today, its lowest rate in nearly four years. There were indications of foreign pressure to let the yen float even higher, because of high Japanese export levels. Page D10.

title: Carter to Announce B1 Decision Today; Approval Indicated
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  President Carter met today with Defense Secretary Harold Brown to discuss the controversial B1 strategic bomber amid a growing belife in Pentagon and Congressional circles that the President would authorize production of the plane at a limited rate.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Late Stock Rally Fails to Offset Decline on Weak Economic News
description: A Government report that leading economic indicators declined in May, the first drop in four months, sent stock prices modestly lower yesterday.

title: Justices Nullify Lower Court Order Barring Publication of Lawyers Fees
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)The Supreme Court nullified today a lower court order blocking two consumers groups from publishing a directory listing lawyers' fees.

title: Plimpton's Peroration
description: CAMBRIDGEI have been led to understand that tomorrow you are going to graduate. Well, my strong recommendation is that you don't go. Stop! Go on back to your rooms. Unpack! There's not much out here. Chekhov tells the story of the traveler faced with three roads ... if he takes the one to the right, the wolves will eat him up, if he takes the one to the left he will eat up the wolves, and he takes the one to the center he will eat himself up.

title: AGENCY TO PAY AIDE FOR TERM IN PRISON
description: An East Harlem antipoverty agency financed largely by the city has agreed to give its executive director nearly $13,500 in back pay, some of it for time he spent in a Federal prison facility on conspiracy and perjury convictions. Some of the charges involved his work with the organization.

title: 9 Democrats in Senate Give Carter A Measure of Support on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Nine Democratic senators sent a letter to President Carter today offering a measure of suppOrt for his efforts to arrange a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Soviet Explosion Reported
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, June 29 (AP)The Uppsala Seismological Institution reported an underground explosion today in the Semipalatinsk area, the Soviet nuclear testing grounds in western Siberia. The institution said the explosion measured 6.2 on the Richter scale.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, June 29The case of two Filipino nurses accused of poisoning patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor was turned over to a jury of nine women and three men today.

title: Inside Story: Where to Buy A Gazebo
description: Where do you buy a gazebo? Naturally any architect or landscape architect would be happy to design one for you. But if that seems like too big a deal, there are other ways to get a pool structure.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Rochester Telephone Corporation announced that residential customers may buy the telephones and outlets in their own homes. The company said it has the first utility in the state and possibly the first in the country to sell phones to residential customers.

title: Ban Is Voted In Davis Cup Withdrawal
description: LONDON, June 29 (UPI)The Davis Cup tennis nations voted today to impose automatic oneyear suspensions on countries that refused to play matches on political grounds. The proposal was carried by 40 votes to 12.

title: Film: Egos Beset Chekhov's 'Sisters'
description: THE THALIA THEATER, under its new management, has been maintaining one of the most original, unusual and, sometimes, odd programming policies of any theater in New York. In recent months they've allowed us to see a filmed recording of Laurence Olivier's extraordinary Chichester Festival production of "Uncle Vanya," Josef von Sternberg's last film, "Anatahan," and the huge Polish epic called "Pharaoh."When you drop into the Thalia, the chances are you'll find something out-of-the-ordinary, a film that isn't likely to turn up in any cricuit house. It might not be great or even good, but it will be rare.Such is the Thalia's newest program, which opened yesterday. It's the 1965 videotape version, transferred to film, of the Actors Studio Theater production of Chekhov's "The Three Sisters" as it was staged by Lee Strasberg. The production was originally done in 1964 in New York, where it received more or less mixed notices, and later went to London, where theater people behaved as if we'd sent them a red-white-and-blue stinkbomb.As it looks now, we had.Yet it's a fascinating footnote to the history of the New York theater and, especially, of the Actors Studio. This production is virtually bulging with the self-assurance of an organization that thought it could do anything if everyone, just sweated and fretted long enough. Never have I seen a "Three Sisters" half as long, nor four actresseswho play the three sisters and their sister-in-lawwho seem less likely to become victims of anything except a natural disaster on the order of a majormagnitude nine on the Richter scaleearthquake.The cast includes some fine performers, as well as some not-so-fine, but what wrecks the production is the aggressive tone, for which, I assume, Mr. Strasberg was responsible. Everything is too literal, too calculated, too coarse, too busyeven the pauses rattle the screen. The accents don't match, some are out of Topeka, Kan., some out of Broadway and some out of the Yiddish theater. It's less a production than a convention of actors on fire for what they think is a good cause.Two performers who come close to achieving some kind of unity of style and feeling are Kim Stanley as Masha, the middle sister, and Kevin McCarthy as Vershinin, the unhappily married army officer who, briefly, lights up the lives of the sisters in the dreary Russian provincial city where they are forever marooned.Geraldine Page, one of the best actresses we have, seems misdirected as the oldest sister, Olga. Sandy Dennis as Irina, the youngest, acts as if she were afraid her upper teeth were going to pop out. The recurring gesture of a hand reaching up to the mouth evokes not emotional desperation but severe orthodontic panic.Shelley Winters, as the arriviste sister-in-law, Natalya, who methodically dispossesses the sisters, is out of control from start to finish. She's as pushy as a waitress in a hamburger joint who wants to get the customers out by closing time. James Olson has some decently theatrical moments as Baron Tuzenbach, Irina's suitor. No one else need by mentioned by name.The film quality is not at all bad considering the videotape origins, but Paul Bogart, who directed the taping, favors too many close-ups that have the effect of isolating actors when they are, in fact, part of an ensemble. It is, however, a fitting metaphor for a production in which each actor seems so occupied with his own performance that he's incapable of communicating with someone no more than a foot or two away.

title: Death Penalty Voted; Carey Veto Expected
description: ALBANY, June 29The State Senate tonight gave final legislative passage to a measure that would allow the death penalty for virtually all murders.

title: 4 INDICTED IN FRAUD ON SCHOOL LUNCHES
description: Three officers of an agency that conducted a summer food program for needy children were indicted yesterday on charges of billing the Government for food that was never served and of serving it sometimes at unauthorized sites and sometimes to adults instead of children.

title: Old U.S. Custom House Takes on a Cultural Role
description: A band played a fanfare entitled Custom Job, dancers performed on the steps and the old United States opened to the public yesterday for the summer in a new role as a cultural institution.

title: T. F. G. Daly Named a U.S. Judge
description: HARTFORD, June 29 (AP)  T. F. Gilroy Daly, the lawyer who gained national prominence for his role in winning Peter Reilly of Canaan, Conn., a new trial in the slaying of his mother, was nominated today for a Federal judgeship by President Carter. Mr. Daly was proposed for the District Court position by Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Connecticut Democrat.

title: Celtics Choose Satch Sanders
description: BOSTON, June 29 (UPI)Tom (Satch) Sanders, a 13year veteran of the Boston Celtics and more recently head basketball coach at Harvard University, was named today as the Celtics' assistant coach. Sanders, 38 years old, replaces John Killilea, who last week resigned to take a similar post with the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1977

title: CONSTRUCTION STARTS SET RECORD FOR LAST MONTH
description: The total contract value of construction started in May reached a record of $15.9 billion, largely due to the start of work on five big electric power plants.

title: PEYSER WITHDRAWS AS NOMINEE TO P.S.C.
description: ALBANY, June 29Faced with almost certain rejection by the Republicancontrolled State Senate, Peter A. Peyser withdrew today as Governor Carey's nominee to head the Public Service Commission.

title: SOYBEANS FUTURES DROP, ENDING 4DAY ADVANCE
description: CHICAGO, June 29 (AP)Soybean futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade today after four days of price advances that had produced a gain of more than 70 cents a bushel.

title: $12.5 Billion for Agriculture Dept. In 1978 Is Approved by the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)The Senate approved by voice vote today a $12.5 billion appropriation for the Department of Agriculture in 1978.

title: ITALY'S RULING PARTY GIVES ROLE TO REDS
description: ROME, June 29The governing Christian Democrats, in a move to get unpopular economic and other major measures through Parliament, entered into an agreement today on a limited legislative program with the Italian Communist Party and other groups.

title: CBS Wins 19Year Tax Break On Studio It Plans on East Side
description: The city's Commercial and Industrial ??entive Board yesterday approved a 19year tax abatement on the $2 million television production studio that CBS Inc, plans to build on the East Side.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Wednesday, June 29, 1977

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ROLL 'EM The complete series of Roots, a legendary symphonic broadcast with Arturo Toscanini conducting, a festival of outstanding dancers, the opening night of Lincoln Center and other programs linking special events and cultural projects to the New York scenethese make up Summer Fortnights, a series of television playbacks now under way at the new Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street.
